HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Inventing a Science and Technology Museum

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER; E-mail address: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
PHILADELPHIA has the Franklin Institute. San Francisco has its Exploratorium. Pittsburgh has the Carnegie Center. Columbus, Ohio, with a population of 1.1 million, recently replaced its 35-year-old science center with a new, $125 million state-of-the-art facility.
Major hands-on science museums, it seems, are everywhere, except on Long Island. That irked Art Rossoff, 77, of Moriches, so much that he decided to do something about it. 
 "There is nothing appropriate to Long Island's population nor appropriate to its high-tech economy and certainly not appropriate to its aspirations to be another Silicon Valley," Mr. Rossoff said, discounting pocket museums like the North Shore Science and Technology Center in Shoreham-Wading River and the Science Museum of Long Island in Port Washington as too small. The Hall of Science in Flushing Meadow, he asserted, belongs to Queens.
"I decided Long Island had to have one," Mr. Rossoff said, having already visited science museums nearly everyplace else.
So Mr. Rossoff, a retired engineer and former assistant to the president of Polytechnic University, began to gather local volunteers and enlist industrial and government support for Limsat, the Long Island Museum of Science and Technology.
His long-term goal is to spawn a new generation of home-grown engineers and scientists, the solution to a serious shortage for industry throughout Long Island.
"If you turn kids on to science," Mr. Rossoff said, "it stands to reason they are going to pursue it in terms of career."
Two years ago, Nassau County agreed to provide the space and make the science center part of phase two at the Museums at Mitchel Center, said Ed Smith, planning coordinator for the complex, which will share a 75,000-square-foot addition with an aerospace adventure camp. The second stage also includes the Long Island Children's Museum, the Firefighter's Museum and Safety Center, Nunley's Carousel and an exterior plaza. Construction will take two and a half years.
In July, the strategic concept plan for a 40,000-square-foot space, with a common lobby with the Cradle of Aviation Museum and the IMAX Dome Theater, will be complete. And after wooing corporate executives at leadership breakfasts, said Steve Barre, who took over as Limsat's president last summer, the nonprofit organization will embark on a $20 million to $30 million capital campaign to develop, build and install exhibits.
In a sense, Limsat won't really be a museum at all, Mr. Barre said, but an educational science center devoted to exploring Long Island's technologies. Unlike archival exhibits that dwell on the past, it will be an investment in the future.
Interactive exhibits will focus on biotechnology, electronics, computer software and interactive graphics, areas important to the 1,500 medium- and small-sized technology companies in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Mr. Barre said.
"I see it as a dynamic place; the exhibits will change as the technology changes," said Mr. Barre, 60, president of the Servo Corporation of Westbury, which makes infrared heat detectors that keep the antennas on communication satellites pointed toward Earth.
And, the developers hope, an inspiring place.
"The role of the science center is primarily to excite young people and get them interested in science," Mr. Rossoff said, "which is not to say it will be an amusement park."
But perhaps it will include a tornado, the swirling liquid kind fashioned from soda bottles fastened mouth to mouth, as in many a grade school science fair project, and a full-service weather station transmitting data for students to collate. Or a clicking Geiger counter, testing minute levels of radiation emitted by household smoke detectors, like the one Frederick Kruger, the volunteer exhibits director and a speech and hearing scientist, set up at Limsat's development laboratory at the R. J. Osgood Administration Center Complex in Kings Park. The prototype center will be open to schoolchildren this fall.
"The business of designing an exhibit for such a museum is very elusive," Mr. Rossoff said. "You don't always know if you have a good one. It may look good to you and kids walk right past it. There is an inexact science associated with this."
What might catch a child's fancy is the loopy science fiction sound emitted by waving hands near the Theremin, a musical instrument Dr. Kruger built from a kit, or the flat spinning spindle showing magnetic levitation. Or touching a plasma ball, causing sparks to dance because of electrical discharges in an atmosphere of mixed gases.
"Right now it's a pragmatic display," explained Dr. Kruger, sticking his Pentium chip key chain under a research microscope attached to a video screen in the biotechnology cubicle and pointing out the tiny details of an integrated circuit.
"What we could get going either fast, easily or thought was critical is here in some stage of development," said Dr. Kruger, giving a visitor a tour of his fledgling two-classroom museum, complete with a larger-than-human sized slide rule. "We are trying to highlight some of the technologies of Long Island in a hands-on fashion. No matter where the kids go here, they can touch it, feel it, make it do something and see the response."
Some day that may also include an exhibit explaining the differences between an X-ray, a CAT scan and an MRI, a technology born on Long Island, and another on fiber optics, so much of which was invented locally, he said. And he is putting together a computer-parts exchange as a resource for students building science fair experiments.
"The only thing I'm not looking to do is get burnt out toasters," Dr. Kruger said as he fiddled with an old oscilloscope.
Across the hall, green, red and blue lights shining on the wall create a simple exhibit about color mixing. A hand battery shows how the human body can act like the acid in a battery, causing a meter to deflect.
Through virtual computer hookups, Mr. Barre added, Limsat will be a hub science center, linking the region's smaller science museums to the central facility.
"We're hoping to make this an islandwide project, not just a Nassau county or a Mitchel Center project, Mr. Barre said. "It's hard to be opposed to Limsat. It's like motherhood and apple pie. It's good for everybody. It's good for economic development. It's good for supplying the future science and engineering talent that we need. It's entertaining. It will draw tourists. There's nothing negative about it."
 
Heartfelt Words
"I have no pictures of my family," said Sarah Lew not long ago, her voice quavering, her hands quivering as she recited a poem about the innocent who have no tombs, just cemeteries in the clouds. "But the pictures are framed in my heart."
Along with a promise. Mrs. Lew, of Woodmere, is a Holocaust survivor. From 1939 to 1945, she was in a series of Polish ghettos and in five concentration camps. And she assured her father, as he pushed her during a roundup of Jews to another, more fortuitous line, allowing her to live and not die, that she would tell her story.
So she has written her memoirs, tentatively titled, "From Bialystock to Brooklyn." Two hundred pages of romance and sorrow, from her childhood in Poland through the horrors of the Holocaust that left her with "a lonely soul" to owning a department store in Brooklyn and raising three sons. But she needs a publisher.
"I have an obligation," she said. "So long as my eyes are open, I feel the pain. It's important the world should know. Most of us are gone already."
Mrs. Lew's entire family perished. Her mother, father and two brothers were killed by the Nazis. She still lives, she said, with visions of Dr. Josef Mengele, the notorious Angel of Death, in front of her eyes.
"You are supposed to go on with your life, get a new family, and new troubles and new aggravations," she said. "That's what life is."
Although Mrs. Lew did that, time has not dimmed her memories.
"The first miracle was to survive," she said. "The next miracle will be to publish."

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
Great River's High-Tech Center Begins to Hum

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: GREAT RIVER

 BODY:
THE sprawling 355,000-square-foot structure on Sunrise Highway here, once owned by Northrop Grumman and now being renovated by new owners, may look like yet another manufacturing building undergoing an upgrading, but it is far from that.
Inside the Long Island Technology Center pulses a sophisticated array of wired and wireless communications systems designed to attract high-tech companies for whom high-speed, high-capacity transmission is essential. 
 The first phase of what will be a $24 million renovation officially opened June 8. Ten leases for a total of 22,000 square feet have been signed and 10 leases for an additional 30,000 square feet are in various stages of negotiation. Only technology- and education-related companies are accepted.
The first phase consists of 37 prebuilt and prewired offices ranging in size from 250 to 17,000 square feet and totaling of 150,000 square feet. Annual rents are $21.50 a square foot, which includes electricity.
Each office is connected by optical fiber and high-speed copper wire to a main communication room. Carriers include Bell Atlantic, Cablevision Lightpath and North American Telecom and additional carriers are expected to come on board, with tenants free to choose the one to use. Switching from one carrier to another can be accomplished seamlessly through an internal fiber-optic cabling system devised by Rudin Management and the Cogswell Realty Group, joint venture partners in developing the Great River building. Both companies are based in Manhattan.
In a joint venture with Keyspan Communications, the telecommunications arm of Keyspan Energy, the developers will construct a link from the building's fiber-optic network to the Keyspan's network. The link will allow high-speed transmission of data -- 10 billion bits of information per second -- to domestic and global networks. A year ago, Keyspan Energy took over the operations of the Long Island Lighting Company.
"The Keyspan piece brings the broad-band global network right to the desktop of the tenant," said John J. Gilbert 3d, Rudin's chief operating officer. "We've created the raw material that these companies need to compete in the global marketplace."
He went on to say that "global connectivity" was essential, adding that "our motto is, 'If you're not communicating electronically with your customers today, you're not going to be in business tomorrow.' "
The Great River building will offer the same technologically advanced infrastructure on Long Island that Rudin developed successfully at its New York Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street in Manhattan. The same system will be incorporated in the Reuters headquarters building now under construction at 3 Times Square, a joint venture of Rudin and Reuters.
"Along with providing electricity, air-conditioning and plumbing, you also have to allow information to flow as easily as water," said Herb Hauser, president of Barnes Wentworth, a Manhattan-based technology engineering company that is installing the Great River fiber optics. "Information has become the fourth utility."
The Long Island Technology Center promises to position Long Island as a "technology capital" similar in reputation to the Route 128 corridor near Boston and other concentrations of high-tech companies, said Peter Goldsmith, chairman of the Long Island Software and Technology Network -- LISTnet for short -- which has moved into the building.
He called the project "our White House and the essential ingredient to allow that to happen."
"It was very important for Rudin and Cogswell to recognize the potential here and cultivate it," he added.
LISTnet, a nonprofit membership organization that promotes Long Island's high-tech industry, started with about 50 companies a year and a half ago and has since grown to almost 600 members, Mr. Goldsmith said. The organization brought Long Island to the attention of Rudin and Cogswell among others, he noted, adding: "Before that, all they knew about Long Island was what they saw on their way to the Hamptons."
THE high-tech corridor, extending from the State University of New York at Stony Brook to the north to Great River in the south, includes Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, Computer Associates International in Islandia and Symbol Technologies in Holtsville.
Cogswell Realty purchased the 82-acre property from Northrop Grumman last August for $10 million. Rudin Management became a joint venture partner shortly thereafter. Lehman Brothers is providing the construction financing.
"We are ahead of our expectations and without even a grand opening we had 10 pioneer companies who saw what the building has the ability to do and signed on," said Arthur R. Stern, the chief executive of Cogswell Realty.
The quality of tenants has also far exceeded expectations, Mr. Stern added. "These are enormously talented people that are in the right industry at the right time," he said, "and with the capital markets being the way they are, they have access to capital to develop their ideas."
Among the tenants is Storage Networks of Waltham, Mass., formed by Peter Bell and Bill Miller nine months ago. The company, which is leasing 3,516 square feet at Great River, already has locations throughout the United States and expects to double its 75 employees by the end of the year, Mr. Bell said.
Storage Networks, which provides online data-storage services for clients like major banks, is providing the data-storage infrastructure at the Long Island Technology Center. Its service allows customers to securely store data on its network, to access it instantaneously and to have it delivered offsite all with the ease of a telephone call.
Another tenant, Keytrade, an online brokerage firm, is about to move into 5,579 square feet. Anthony J. Imbo, the chief operating officer, said he expected to attract 50,000 to 100,000 accounts within a year of the company's mid-July launch. Keytrade technology enables customers conducting an on-line stock or mutual funds trade who need help to simultaneously connect to a customer representative in an online chat room instead of having to seek assistance by phone.
Video Net Services Corporation, which has leased 2,289 square feet, was started by Clay Shuder and Hank Shouler in a 244-square-foot office in Mr. Shouler's Northport home. It encodes anything recorded on videotape into a language computers can understand so that the material can be transmitted over the Internet.
Imperial Software, an educational software developer and provider that has leased 5,866 square feet, is bringing 30 of its 125 employees to the building and expects to triple that number in three years, said Thomas Murphy, the company's president.
Another company, Comview Corporation of Huntington, which provides integrated phone systems, is taking 1,500 square feet.
The building's 205,000-square-foot second phase will include a "digital sandbox," a copyrighted name developed by Rudin that refers to a flexible space offering everything from video conferencing to a place to meet. Mr. Gilbert of Rudin called the sandbox -- a name he coined -- "the water cooler of cyberspace where all the companies can get together, where they can collaborate, train and do events." It is, he added, "a sandbox for adults to come and play."
AT Great River the sandbox will be "a multistoried very flexible space, almost like a theater in the round," said Scott E. Spector, principal in charge of the Great River project at the Spector Group, architects in North Hills. About 10 smaller conferencing spaces will surround the main area, he said.
Tenants may now gather in a landscaped courtyard and the 300-seat Terabyte Cafe will open shortly. A day-care center, expected to open by Labor Day, will allow parents to monitor their children via a video link.
The 82-acre site permits the construction of 787,000 square feet of additional space, and negotiations are now under way with tenants who want an entire building, said Mr. Stern of Cogswell Realty.
Inclusion into Islip's Economic Development Zone, which Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation announced at the June 8 ceremony, will provide tax credits, sales tax exemptions, wage tax credits and energy discounts, among other incentives.
That just adds the icing, tenants say, because they have come for the sophisticated communications system that would require a huge capital outlay to install individually, the backups to safeguard systems from going down, the secure premises and an intangible -- the ability to share ideas.
"The interaction with other companies is going to be a wonderful way to bounce ideas off other people," said Mr. Shuder of Video Net Services. "We may have a niche that people take advantage of, and hopefully they'll have things that offer a reciprocal relationship."

HEADLINE: In the Region /Westchester;
When Developers, and City Officials, Think Big

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
NOW that New Roc City, the entertainment/shopping complex, is nearing completion in downtown New Rochelle, Louis Cappelli, its developer, is considering another project there.
"I'm so pleased by the progress of the construction," said Mr. Cappelli, a managing general partner of New Roc Associates, L.P., which is developing the project. "It's up, it's done. We've met our scheduled opening date for the middle of August. I'm now looking to do something else for the next thing." 
 Toward that end, Mr. Cappelli has asked the city to make available to him two parcels within the urban renewal area and adjacent to New Roc City -- totaling about six acres -- so he can build 250,000 square feet of office space, 300 units of housing and 75,000 square feet of low-rise retail space.
"I definitely think the center is going to generate excitement and interest," Mr. Cappelli said, "and I want to get as much land around it as possible."
Meanwhile, in White Plains, Tishman Speyer Properties, a Manhattan-based developer, just received city approval to acquire urban renewal parcels surrounding the former Macy's building on Mamaroneck Avenue for a development similar to NewRoc City.
The additional property , which runs along Mamaroneck Avenue and Main Street, is considered essential for the viability of Tishman Speyer's $175-million proposal to transform the Macy's site into a 425,000-square-foot entertainment/shopping complex.
The city must first take over the property by eminent domain and then sell it to Tishman Speyer. "We've already agreed to sell it to them," said Michael Graessle, the White Plains planning commissioner. "The first step is getting the property appraised."
In New Rochelle, however, Mr. Cappelli still awaits approval of his purchase of the adjacent parcels. "We have to determine if the territory is suitable for urban renewal first," said Joseph Madonna, the city's Commissioner for Development. "Then the city has to decide whether it wants to buy it and sell it to Cappelli. We still need to find out more specifics about what he plans to do with it."
Mr. Cappelli called projects like his NewRoc City the "hot new thing."
"Since I started New Roc City, I've been contacted by half a dozen other cities and towns, both in New York and in other states," he said. "I'll probably be doing three more of these types of developments in other locations, but not in Westchester."
Both the White Plains and New Rochelle projects are prototypes for this type of development in the county. They both promise to enliven their downtown locations, and have a spillover effect on surrounding areas.
The 450,000-square-foot New Roc City will be anchored by a 19-screen movie complex, including the county's first IMAX theater. There will also be twin ice-skating rinks, two restaurants, a supermarket and a fitness club.
Its spillover effect has already taken place, with the current construction of a 123,000-square-foot office building on a nearby parcel, and a 123-room Marriott Residence Inn, which is being built over the center's parking garage. Both are scheduled to open in September.
In addition, Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va., will soon break ground on a 1,000-unit rental development called Avalon on the Sound. And the city plans to build an intermodal transportation center, with new bus and train terminals, near its Metro-North and Amtrak train stations.
All this has also led to cosmetic improvements. The city is in the process of a sidewalk improvement program, with new sidewalks, streetlights, and plantings.
"It all started with Home Depot and Costco, when they moved in in 1996," said Commissioner Madonna. "Then after NewRoc got started, we got a lot of calls and momentum picked up. Now we have enough development plans to take us through the next six to seven years."
WHITE PLAINS is hoping for a similar lift from Tishman Speyer's project, said Mr. Graessle, but it's a little too early for concrete results. "The project's changed in scope and size since it was originally proposed earlier this year," he added.
The current proposal is for a 21-screen, 5,000-seat Loews movie theater as anchor and 10 to 12 retailers, as many as four of which would probably be restaurants. "From the tentative tenant list I've seen," Mr. Graessle, "they're all solid recognizable names, the kind you're likely to find near theaters today.
"Every movie theater seems to need a record store, a bank, an electronics store and coffee shops, the traditional support," Mr. Grassele said, adding that there had been a lot of interest, especially from restaurants, in the street locations surrounding the center. "They've expressed interest, but they also want to wait and see if the Tishman project is really going to come off," he said. "Once they're closer to construction, I'm sure we'll see space fill up."
According to city estimates, the Tishman project is expected to generate $96 million in retail sales and $1.6 million in sales tax-revenue, and attract 2 million visitors a year.
At one time, a residential component was also proposed, but Tishman Speyer has since withdrawn it. "At one time, the developer was proposing building 451 units of housing on Martine Avenue, but they've withdrawn it," Mr. Graessle added "It's still possible they'll do the housing, but it's more likely it will be half the number of units."
Tishman also dropped plans for a second floor of retail. "They were having difficulty leasing the second floor, so they dropped it," Mr. Graessle said. "If it had been an interior mall, and the retail faced inside, I think the space would have leased up.
"But the city has always insisted that the retail face the street," Mr. Graessle continued. "Our purpose with this project has always been to enliven Mamroneck Avenue. If the project had to be reduced in size and delayed in order to accomplish that, then that's the price we pay. We'll take it."

HEADLINE: Helping Parents as Children Leave for College

BYLINE: By DONNA CORNACHIO

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
WHEN Lisa Charles considers the departure of her 18-year-old daughter, Tyler Morris, for college this fall, sometimes all she can do is cry.
"I look through her yearbook and get all choked up," Ms. Charles, who lives here, said. "I worry who's going to watch out for her. Will she be O.K. on her own?" 
 Ms. Morris, who is going to the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, appears more excited than anxious about leaving home, though she admits to feeling twinges of homesickness. "I definitely feel ready to move on and be responsible for my life," Ms. Morris said. "But I will certainly miss my parents and my little brother a lot."
It is a conflict that is universally shared as thousands of Westchester parents and their young-adult children celebrate high school graduation and prepare for the three-month limbo known as the senior summer. It is a state of mind that Carol Barkin, an author who lives here, knows all too well. Her recently published guide for parents in the midst of senior summer angst, "When Your Kid Goes to College: A Parents' Survival Guide" (Avon), is the result of the experience she and her husband had in sending their only child to college five years ago. "It was such a confused time for all of us," Ms. Barkin said. "I wanted so much to be able to let my kid go while still staying connected with him. I could tell David felt that same push and pull."
During that summer and well into David Barkin's freshman year at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., Ms. Barkin met informally with other parents whose children were also leaving the nest. The talk was only about their children, and despite differences of race, sex and economics, some themes were universal. "I worried about my daughter feeling isolated at school," recalled Linda Bulmer of Yonkers, who was among the parents Ms. Barkin interviewed for her book. "I worried whether the people she would be associating with would respect the morals and values I'd instilled in her."
Although children have been sent off to college for generations without any parents' survival guide, Ms. Barkin talked about why this era is different. "There seem to be fewer rules and controls than when we were at college," said Ms. Barkin, who graduated from Harvard University in 1965. "When I was at school, I had to conform to curfews and parietals; neither of which exist today except at select religious colleges. Parents today worry there's no safety net to catch their kids if they fall."
Ms. Barkin said that it may be more a parental perception than a reality of a hands-off administration; all colleges do have campus support groups for students to turn to. But there are fewer rules on today's college campuses than when the parents were the students. Aside from concern about issues of safety and alcohol and drug abuse on campuses, parents worry about the minute and the mundane: Is he going to be able to wake up on his own for class? Will she be able to live with a difficult roommate?
In her book, Ms. Barkin provides practical information for parents to talk to their children about everything from a crash course in laundry ("discuss the dangers of mixing new dark or bright clothing with light colors") to sex, drugs and drinking. A mother whom Ms. Barkin interviewed for the book told her, "You talk to your kid about unprotected sex, date rape, drugs and alcohol, and then you keep your fingers crossed." In her book, Ms. Barkin also discusses the importance of parents raising such sensitive issues ("even if it's for the zillionth time") with college-bound children. "Your child needs to know where you stand on these questions," she said. "He also needs to know that you trust him and have confidence in his ability to make decisions about his life."
Most children, Ms. Barkin added, end up reflecting their parents' values. Her son, David, 22, who graduated from Tufts last May, contributed a final chapter to his mother's book, entitled "Advice From a College Senior." In the chapter, he offered this advice: "If you have trusted your child until now, don't worry too much. Most kids handle the pressures of drinking and drugs without too much trouble."
Many parents, the Barkins included, try to cram as much as they can into their family's life the summer before their children go to college only to find out that their children want nothing more than to be with their friends. "I'd thought we'd take one last family vacation together, but Tyler really didn't want to come along," Ms. Charles said. "At the same time, I also notice she's spending more time at home with us than before."
And who says you can't go home again? David Barkin, now an assistant teacher at the Windward School in White Plains, is sleeping back in his old room, at least until he can afford to move out on his own. As a college graduate, he said he now finds he has a different relationship with his parents. "I get along with my parents really well," he said. "They now seem to think of me as more responsible and independent, and I feel as though I can speak to them as an adult."
For her part, and only half joking, Ms. Barkin said she was considering David's return as the subject for her next book: "When Your Kid Comes Back Home After College."

HEADLINE: New Rochelle Project Nears Completion

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
ONLY six weeks to go. "That's when the theaters will be open for business," said New Rochelle's Mayor, Timothy C. Idoni, referring to a cinema that will have an Imax theater, the first in the county, and 18 other regular screens. The theater is one of the anchors of New Roc City, a $190 million project that will include family entertainment and retail and mixed use development.
"New Roc City is the biggest thing ever to come into New Rochelle," the Mayor said. For one thing, he said, the project, the cornerstone of a plan to revitalize downtown New Rochelle, is expected to create more than 600 permanent, full-time jobs. The 1.2-million-square-foot complex, built on the former Macy's and New Rochelle Mall sites, has already contributed to a rise in real estate values, Mr. Idoni said. 
 For example, "Two years ago, the asking price was $600,000 for an adjacent office building on the corner of Main Street and Le Count place," he said. "Today, the asking price is $2 million."
The complex, taking shape as an army of sheet metal and steel workers, carpenters and electricians go about their tasks, includes a roof-top amusement park ride that rises 235 feet into the air, a National Hockey League regulation-size rink, a country-like skating lake and shops with sports themes, along with a 120-room Marriott Residence Inn and a 110,000-square-foot office building.
"We didn't want an enclosed mall with a box-like row of stores," said Louis R. Cappelli, a partner with Robert M. Greene and Kenneth Narva in New Roc Associates, the White Plains-based developer of the project.
New Roc is being built with tree-lined promenades and benches to encourage pedestrian traffic. A facade of limestone and brick buildings, depicting New York City in the 1920's, creates a neighborhood theme, which Mr. Cappelli said is "very appropriate for an entertainment center."
Mr. Cappelli's own company, Cappelli Enterprises in Valhalla, is the general contractor for the project, which he describes "as a cross between the Mall of America in Minnesota and Universal Studios in Orlando."
The estimate is that it will attract about 5.5 million people a year from a radius of 50 to 60 miles and will generate about $1.5 million to $2 million in sales tax revenue from the retail stores alone.
Financing for the $190 million project was arranged through public and private sources, including a low-interest loan from the Empire State Development Corporation. The city of New Rochelle contributed toward the demolition and reconstruction of the parking garage, which will have room for 2,200 cars.
Approximately 740,000 square feet of the 800,000-square-foot rental space in New Roc has been leased, Mr. Cappelli said. The tenants already signed up include a recreation center called Sports Plus, a division of Family Golf Centers; it will occupy 150,000 square feet, with video games, batting cages, Laser-Tron, a climbing wall, motion-simulator rides and virtual reality games. Sports Plus will also manage the hockey rink, which will be rented out to school groups and other organizations, and the skating lake, where lessons and skating will be available by the hour.
"They also have the Huguenot Tower like Disney World's Tower of Terror," Mr. Cappelli said. "That will certainly draw attention to New Rochelle. It's fashioned after the Eiffel Tower and will be visible for miles." The Tower propels 12 riders, fastened in with safety harnesses, more than 200 feet straight up in the air with the force of a space launch. The ride, which will be priced at $3 to $4, will last 40 seconds.
The complex, which is expected to be in full operation by September, will also include a Bally fitness center, three family-style restaurants, a Super Stop & Shop supermarket and possibly a conference center.

HEADLINE: ART;
Happily Ever After: When Form Married Function

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON

 BODY:
THE Bush Storehouse in Greenwich is part of a compound of six buildings that climb a hill (at this time of the year speckled with flowers and a vine-covered grape arbor) to an enviable view over the Miamus River.
The setting inspired the American Impressionists to colonize and paint at the Bush-Holley House, now the site of the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich. And two years ago it prompted the renovation and transformation of the circa-1805 Justus L. Bush storehouse into a visitors' center including galleries now showcasing its fifth exhibition, "Art for Everyday Living: The American Arts and Crafts Movement 1890-1920," which can be seen through Sept. 12. 
 The movement, following on the heels of the Industrial Revolution, filled a vacuum and answered a yearning. The antithesis of industrial ideals (which placed economy and profit above hand artisanry), the arts and crafts movement at its peak (between 1890 and 1920) influenced American decorative arts and architecture, and was embraced by popularizers including Louis Comfort Tiffany, Gustav Stickley, the Stickley Brothers, Rookwood Pottery, the Roy Crofters and Frank Lloyd Wright.
The subject appealed to the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich because "it covered the same period, the late 19th to 20th century, that the art colony was here and at its peak," said Karen Blanchfield, the Historical Society's curator.
"In the early 1900's," Ms. Blanchfield said, "the artists and writers at Bush-Holley House were discussing modern art and modern life while the arts and crafts movement was addressing a lot of the same issues. Advocates strongly believed that through handicraft, either by making it or living with it, people would attain and enjoy a better life."
The exhibition captures an aura of the style-reform movement that coveted and turned everyday objects into artistic statements. Arranged primarily by medium, it highlights those influenced by the movement. Most dominant is a wall of furniture. Stark, simple and with a distinctive design, it seems to say it well and to sum up the show.
"There was an overt hand-craftedness," Ms. Blanchfield said, capturing a single part of the design's essence. "You can see the construction techniques." There's Charles P. Limbart's oak chair with vertical slats and ebony inlay, Gustav Stickley's strikingly simple geometric bookcase with hand-hammered brass pulls, and the younger Stickley brothers' graceful, almost flowering pedestal. "Gustav Stickley was considered the father of the movement," Ms. Blanchfield said. "But his younger brothers, who were originally thought of as copycats, took it a step beyond evolving their own product line, sometimes with more grace."
There are those who will recognize the signature style of Frank Lloyd Wright, who studied arts and crafts architecture at the time, and for whose houses the younger Stickley brothers manufactured furniture.
One showcase features English pewter and silver biscuit tins, one made by the English designer Archibald Knox, and an American knock-off. The American version in pewter with a brass wash has irregular sides, free-form decoration and hammer marks. "Silver was a popular medium in England, but was not popular in America where it was considered elitist," Ms. Blanchfield said.
The movement also promoted applied arts, including needlework, as a practical opportunity for women to use artistic skills. "Women were not encouraged to become professional artists, painters or sculptors, or sell their art," Ms. Blanchfield said. "But if they wanted to decorate art pottery or embroider textiles, that was acceptable and fashionable." Female students came to the Bush-Holley House at the time of the Impressionist art colony, but did not become famous artists like their male colleagues.
A pillow is displayed, elaborately embroidered with a popular motif of the time, an orange poppy. There is also a folding screen, carved and painted by Elmer MacRae.
The renowned art potter Leon Volkmar's ovid-shaped vases are on display as well as jewelry carved from jade with ginkgo leaves, its organic design seeming to sprout from the material.
There are also hand-printed books and greeting cards, illustrations of bungalow houses and furnishings, and humble-looking art pottery. "There was nothing flashy about arts and crafts," Ms. Blanchfield said. "The goal was not to impress esthetically, but quietly influence."
 
The galleries of the visitors' center at the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich (39 Strickland Road, Greenwich; 203-869-6899 extension 10) is open Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, noon to 4 P.M., Saturday, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Sunday, 1 to 4.

Above: Circa-1910 biscuit tin of pewter with brash wash. Below: Circa-1915 oak arm chair made by the Charles P. Limbart Company and a circa-1890 pillow cover with silk and cotton embroidery.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3257 words

HEADLINE: The Loft Law's Pursuit of Lofty Goals

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THE old loft space -- not even all that expansive at 1,800 square feet -- is now worth a lot more than it was back in '78; and, amid all his video equipment, Mike is wondering whether there isn't a sizable chunk of profit to be made by selling now.
He doesn't live there any more; it's just his studio now -- really! Not like in the old days when the landlord looked the other way while the couch was carried in and the freight elevator was an adventure; when Asian women still bent over their sewing machines next door and the streets downtown were plastered with those "SoHo's Being Co-opted" stickers. And, certainly, way before all those chic boutiques dotted the block. 
 Mike is a fictitious character, and his loft -- with its internal Doric columns, sprinkler pipes, ersatz walls and raw-lumber loft bed -- is, in reality, a walk-through exhibit currently showing at the New Museum of Contemporary Art on Broadway, just south of Houston Street.
But while the exhibit is a product of the imaginings of two installation artists, Joshua White and Michael Smith (down to the created leak stain on the kitchen ceiling), it is certainly art imitating life. And it is symbolic of the ongoing and, for some, wrenching evolution of the loft market.
It is an evolution that has seen some artists, like Kathy Arlt, who lives in a former caviar warehouse on Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, metamorphose from tenants to owners by way of arduous financial and legal combat. And one in which many landlords, like Diana Agostini of Greene Street in SoHo -- in the face of old, demanding industrial buildings and reluctant lending institutions -- are joined in constant struggles to make the numbers add up.
It was 17 years ago that the Loft Law -- more precisely Article 7c of the New York State Multiple Dwelling Law -- first legalized what had been the clandestine tenancy of artists already occupying commercial spaces downtown, while also mandating that landlords bring their buildings into housing-code compliance.
And with a five-year renewal of the Loft Law, which is to expire at the end of the month, up for a vote in Albany (the Assembly has already passed its version), partisans in the continuing contentiousness between landlords and tenants are assessing the effectiveness of legislation that, though directly affecting only a sliver of the market, served as a wedge for the creation of a whole new source of housing in a city long plagued by limited supply.
The assessment is relevant, however, not just for the 835 buildings registered under the Loft Law -- 460 of which have, so far, achieved code compliance or are in the process of doing so -- but for an estimated 2,600 other loft buildings scattered about the city.
For in recent years, artists, artisans and others priced out of the increasingly gentrified co-op and condominium loft market downtown have been illegally slipping into spaces in long-fallow manufacturing areas in Greenpoint and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the South Bronx and Long Island City, Queens. And some tenant advocates, generally satisfied with a law that has assured them legitimate occupancy and protection under rent stabilization, argue that it should be extended to those neighborhoods.
"The law has worked insofar as protecting the tenancy of these tenants," said William Hall, co-chairman of Lower Manhattan Loft Tenants, a 700-member group. But there remains, Mr. Hall contends, a core of landlords resistant to bringing buildings into compliance, "and enforcement continues to be a problem."
The New York City Loft Board, established in accordance with the Loft Law, is charged with enforcing the statute's provisions and deadlines, with writing the rules that govern the relationship between landlords and tenants and with resolving disputes.
CHUCK DeLANEY is the tenant representative on the nine-member Loft Board. "Everyone acknowledges that doing code-compliance work in loft buildings with the tenants in place is a complicated and delicate process," he said.
Still, Mr. DeLaney said: "There are now several thousand legal, code-compliant housing units in the city thanks to the Loft Law, and many more in the pipeline. To me, that's a success."
"The problem," he said, "is the real stubborn owner who doesn't care about coming up to code, doesn't register and just ignores the fines."
In recent years, "illegal conversion has occurred in Brooklyn, and a bit in Queens," Mr. DeLaney said. "The city should enforce against new illegal conversion because, if it turns its back, we're going to see the same problems."
In the glass-half-full, glass-half-empty debate, however, landlord representatives describe the law as ineffective, pointing out that, after 17 years, 375 of the 835 registered buildings remain out of compliance. The law is unfair, they argue, because it fines them for failing to comply, but offers them little help in finding financing to undertake the extensive renovations it requires. It is a Catch-22, they say, that a building owner who cannot obtain a loan for renovations because the banks are wary of a low rent base is then punished by a law that allows tenants to stop paying rents altogether because the renovations haven't been made.
"The Loft Law has sentenced owners to perpetual illegality and made them owners of unsafe buildings," said Thomas Berger, president of the Association of Commercial Property Owners, a 400-member loft-landlord group. "They cannot get financing because the banks see no sufficient rental to cover the mortgage."
The landlord representative on the Loft Board, John Lansden, said the law "should have taken into account that, for the most part, these are small buildings where there is not a lot of income, even after legalization."
"These are not professional landlords," Mr. Lansden said. "Many have businesses in the building and bought the property to insure the survivability of the business. And as a matter of financing the legalization, they're just not equipped to do it. That's the nuts and bolts of it. What we have is a highly technical, confusing series of regulations that are more penalty than incentive."
But Mr. Hall of the tenants group countered that the Loft Board has a "very liberal" extension procedure. "Any owner who can demonstrate having made a good-faith effort to comply receives an extension," he said.
Tenant leaders assert that the owners would simply rather see their tenants leave, so they can go to market-rate rents or the buildings can be converted to co-ops or condominiums -- even though, in a blurring of the demarcation lines, some original loft tenants have themselves banded together to partake of the conversion possibilities. "I would say that to whatever extent the neighborhood has not become Disneyfied," Mr. Hall said, "it's because we are still there."
At stake is the survivability not only of the loft pioneers, but of succeeding generations of artists who, in the estimation of Dr. Elliot Sclar of the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, are vital to the city's continuing economic growth.
"It's not just paint on canvas," said Dr. Sclar, who with a team of students wrote "SoHo: A Community at a Crossroads," a 1996 study. "It's important to remember that creative people develop the software, the images, the movies, the lights -- the culture -- that attracts other industries and individuals to locate here."
"This whole new media industry growing up around Times Square now," Dr. Sclar said, "is built on the backs of this world-class arts community centered in Lower Manhattan."
And, as "Mike" -- the archetypal loft resident of Messrs. White and Smith's exhibit at the New Museum -- seems to be asking: Can the artist colony that begat the downtown residential boom survive its own success, especially when it is so difficult for some of those same artists to ignore the lucrative possibilities that their old lofts now offer?
"Years ago, he considered himself a loft pioneer," said Mr. Smith, who looks remarkably like Mike in the videos stationed around the exhibit that serve as tour guide, and prospective seller.
"Back then he was trying to save SoHo for artists," Mr. Smith said of his alter ego. "He thought this neighborhood had integrity beyond market value." But Mike also "had to eat," Mr. Smith said, and went into commercial art; most recently producing a "point-of-purchase video" for "The Downtown Look" -- a lip definer.
"Now 20 years have passed and Mike wants to test the market," Mr. Smith said. "He's ambivalent about selling because the loft represents a certain identity to him. But the market is so hot right now that he wants to see what he can get for it."
Quite a bit, apparently, according a recent survey of the price trajectory of 289 co-op or condominium lofts downtown. The report -- prepared by the Mitchell Maxwell & Jackson appraisal company for the Corcoran Group residential brokerage -- found that in TriBeCa between 1988 and 1998, the average price for 1,700- to 2,500-square-foot lofts increased from $495,000 to $800,000, or 62 percent; and from $855,000 to $1,440,000, or 68 percent, for lofts of 3,500 square feet or more.
In SoHo, the report said, the average price for lofts of 1,700 to 2,500 square feet rose from $495,000 in 1988 to $820,000 in 1998, or 66 percent, while lofts of 3,500 or more square feet jumped 164 percent, from $700,000 to $1,850,000.
Kathy Arlt, a longtime loft-dweller, and 23 neighbors bought their six-story, 34-unit building -- an old caviar company's warehouse at Greenwich and Watts Streets in TriBeCa -- in 1993, after a long and bitter dispute with the landlord. Told of the museum exhibit and its protagonist's inner conflict about selling, she said, "Sounds like me."
Ms. Arlt, a writer who ran a typesetting business out of her 1,300-square-foot loft, moved in in 1978, when "there was nothing down here: no food store, no video store, no drug store, certainly no doggy day-care like we now have."
Her initial rent was $350. "But we all paid for everything involved in operating the building," she said. "If one of the elevators broke, we would all pay a percentage; likewise taxes, fuel bills."
The landlord purchased the building in 1975 for $350,000. In 1981, a year before the Loft Law was enacted, the leases expired and the owner decided to raise Ms. Arlt's rent to $1,000 a month, twice that for the larger units. "But we would still pay all those expenses," she said, "so we went to court."
THE landlord's position was that, since the leases had expired, he could go to market-rate rents before being channeled into rent stabilization under the law. "We prevailed," Ms. Arlt said, "because we were still appealing before the law went into effect." Rents were frozen. For years, claiming economic hardship, the landlord did little to comply with the housing codes. And in 1990, the tenants went on rent strike.
The difficulties in converting factory space to residential use are hardly insubstantial. Any conversion must comply with laws on access for people with disabilities -- most dearly, the elevators. Many old factories do not have adequate rear yards to meet fire, safety and air requirements, so it may be necessary to remove parts of the building. Fire escapes must be installed; leftover industrial contamination eliminated. Commonly, the buildings require plumbing, electrical work, ventilation for kitchens and bathrooms, sprinklers and smoke detectors.
While the burden usually falls on the owner, in many cases the original tenants paid for the renovations -- as well as improvements like sanded floors, interior walls, appliances -- and then entered legal combat over who was responsible for those modifications and who would be compensated when the original tenant moved.
In Ms. Arlt's building, the burden was eventually assumed by the tenants.
By 1993, Ms. Arlt said, the landlord's widow "decided she had had enough, she wanted to sell." For $990,000, 24 tenants became owners, "and took out a loan for over $3 million," Ms. Arlt said, to cover the renovation costs.
These days, TriBeca "is where everybody wants to live," she said. "It hasn't become SoHo yet, but it's getting there. And I'm thinking of moving before the neighborhood gets to that point. In two years, I think, it might be time to move."
Ms. Arlt paid $22,000 for her unit, not including her share of the renovation costs, and believes she could now get "somewhere in the vicinity of $400,000."
Diana Agostini didn't really know what she was getting into when she became a landlord. "That's for sure," she said.
Her father, Peter Agostini, a sculptor, had purchased the six-story, century-old clothing factory on Greene Street in SoHo, along with a partner, for about $250,000 back in 1972. Each used one floor, and they leased the other units -- two commercial spaces on the ground floor and seven residential lofts.
Ms. Agostini's father died in 1993 and, because his partner failed to pay real estate taxes for several years, the entire burden of the building came down on her.
"The process of coming up to code had started even when my dad was alive," Ms. Agostini said -- but was never completed.
"We had an architect," she said. "I have my blueprints, my permits. Everything's been approved by the Loft Board. But I haven't been able to secure a loan big enough to pay off the $300,000 on the back taxes, plus the $200,000 to come up to code."
Most of Ms. Agostini's tenants were struggling artists when they moved in. Now, she said, they seem to be doing quite well -- one makes shoes for Broadway shows, one owns a recording studio and a restaurant, another owns another building in SoHo.
Three times the tenants went on rent strike between 1990 and '95 -- over issues like lack of heat, the front door not locking and, more broadly, whether they were required to pay rent while the building was in tax arrears. "I'm out $80,000 that I will probably never collect," Ms. Agostini said. Currently, there is relative peace in the building -- only one tenant is withholding rent.
The tenant on the top floor pays $1,004 for about 3,000 square feet. Those on lower floors each pay about $770 for 1,700 square feet. And there is an art gallery and a jewelry designer in the ground-floor commercial spaces. "Thank God I have them because their rents are like $3,300 each and they are good tenants," Ms. Agostini said.
Total rental income is $12,000 a month and operating expenses come to $10,000. "That does give me an extra $2,000," Ms. Agostini said, "but I've been paying legal fees and architect bills for the renovation plans. And right now I have a cornice that I have to fix. That's $5,000 I have to borrow."
"So that extra $2,000 goes pretty quickly," she said.
Ms. Agostini would gladly complete the compliance process. "I'm not resisting coming up to code, I just don't have the money," she said.
"Part of me is emotionally attached to it," she said. "It's a dream of my dad's that I would like to fulfill. And when you've given so much blood and sweat, you just don't want to walk away."
Not every loft building is a cauldron of contention.
GERALD MARKS, creator of high-tech installations for museums like the New York Hall of Science in Queens, has lived in his 1,600-square-foot loft in Chelsea for 30 years. When he sanded his floors in the 1895 building on 28th Street, "sewing-machine needles came out of the cracks," he said.
The Loft Law, he said, "has been a godsend, an imperfect godsend, that has given me a legal standing and made for nice truce conditions with the landlord."
The building's current owners -- the Chinese importers on the ground floor -- "are very close to complying," Mr. Marks said. And, frankly, he is surprised it hasn't happened sooner.
Mr. Marks, for one, is aware of contradictions at work in a residential loft market where finger-pointing is often based on stereotypes -- who is the victim, who is the money-grubber and on whom does the building hang like an albatross -- that are about as valid as a cliche: overused.
Mr. Marks thinks that those landlords rigidly holding out against compliance -- "Hoping, somehow, it will go away," he said -- have done so "not in their best interests." Even if a building were to go to market-rate rent or conversion, "we would still have our rights," he said.
Declining to state his rent, Mr. Marks pointed out that his landlord would likely now be getting $2,000 a month from him had the building achieved code compliance and, therefore, been granted a residential certificate of occupancy. "In a way, it works to my benefit that he doesn't fully comply," Mr. Marks said.
"If they had fully legalized under the Loft Law," he said, "eliminated the violations and got the C of O, then we would be channeled into rent stabilization and I would have been paying increases compounded on increases for the last decade."
"But the fact is I'd rather pay more," he said, "and know that everything is A-1 legitimate. It can really work beautifully for both sides."
 
Loft Law: In the Beginning
 The Loft Law was enacted in 1982 in response, particularly, to the phenomenon of artists moving into warehouses and factories in lower Manhattan with the knowledge of the owner but in violation of the certificates of occupancy.
When the housing market heated up, some landlords tried to evict their tenants, said Andrew Scherer, author of "Residential Landlord-Tenant Law in New York" (West Group, 1998). "The tenants organized," Mr. Scherer said, "and applied political pressure for a law to assure their tenancy and bring the buildings into compliance with housing codes."
 Within nine months of the law's effective date, owners were required to file an alteration application; and, three months after that, to have the plan approved by the Loft Board and the building designated an Interim Multiple Dwelling. Eighteen months after approval, they had to meet the safety and fire requirements of the state's Multiple Dwelling Law.
They then had 36 months -- either from the effective date of the law or from the designation as an Interim Multiple Dwelling -- to obtain a residential certificate of occupancy. The board could, if a landlord showed cause, grant up to two 12-month extensions.
In 1992 and again in 1996, the Legislature extended the law but added "a kind of amnesty for owners who hadn't come into compliance," Mr. Scherer said. "Essentially, they could start from that point on."
The penalty for failure to comply, in both the initial and reset schedules, was that the tenants or the board could file for a finding that the owner had missed deadlines, with the owner subject to a fine of up to $1,000 for each deadline missed. In addition, the tenants could withhold rent.
The law stipulates that, at the time of filing the alteration application, an owner is eligible for a 6 percent rent increase; then, upon obtaining the alteration permit, an additional 8 percent increase. Upon achieving compliance with safety and fire standards, the owner could get 6 percent more.
After meeting all compliance obligations, the owner may apply to the board for a rent adjustment based on the cost of compliance -- dividing the total cost among the units over a 10-year period. At the same time, the owner can factor in the currently allowable Rent Guidelines Board increase -- establishing the initial stabilized rent, subject to further increases set by the Rent Guidelines Board.

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE;
Ocean City Holds Back The Tide

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: OCEAN CITY

 BODY:
The old Coast Guard station here, so rich in historic credentials that it made Preservation New Jersey's list of the state's 10 most endangered sites, is almost surely saved. Its cause was so popular that the City Council agreed to buy it from the developer who had planned to put three duplexes in its place at the corner of Fourth Street and Atlantic Avenue.
But preservationists are worried about the hundreds of more modest but historic houses, set on the resort town's oldest streets, that do not have such protections. Increasingly, as the galloping economy raises the demand for summer rentals, the streetscapes of gracious porches and steps are being interrupted by duplexes put up by developers who are buying old houses and tearing them down. 
 "There's this building," said Jack Snyder, an architect and the chairman of the town's Historic Preservation Commission, nodding toward the Coast Guard station from the cafe across the street, "and then there's the overall degradation of what people imagine Ocean City to be."
The "teardowns" moved a group of residents to organize Citizens for Historic Preservation a year and a half ago, said David Swift, the group's president. "Ocean City is tearing down more houses than any other city in New Jersey," he said. "Fifty-nine percent are single-family homes, and many are historic and Victorian, and being replaced by duplex condos. They're forcing out single families and the assessment rates are sky high, so buildings are rendered economically insignificant."
That nearly happened to the Coast Guard station, built in 1885 and operated as one of many "lifesaving stations" for maritime rescues along the Atlantic coast. It became a private residence in the 1940's.
The latest owner, Elizabeth Sheehan, had planned to have the house's newer sections demolished and the original structure moved. But because the house was in the historic district, the Preservation Commission had to approve. The commission denied the permit, and Mrs. Sheehan completed the sale to a Pennsylvania builder.
After a long battle, the City Council voted to apply for state Green Acres financing of $850,000 -- as it turned out, $120,000 more than the builder paid to buy the house. Last week, a grant and loan package was approved by the legislative committee in Trenton that allocates Green Acres funds. The city ordinance officially approving the deal is to be introduced this week. Meanwhile, the city is expected to negotiate with the developer for the purchase.
Last year, 301 dwelling units were demolished in Ocean City, and the total for the last three years is 731. They are most noticeable in the island's oldest section, from First to 18th Streets, which has buildings up to 120 years old. Homes in the historic district, roughly from Third to Ninth Streets, are protected in that a demolition cannot proceed if a buyer who will preserve the structure and will pay fair market value comes forward within a six-month waiting period.
Mr. Snyder said only one house in the district has been demolished. "The district works," he said.
But outside the district, he said, houses are routinely sold within hours and demolished within days. And on a stroll just beyond the district's boundaries, pointing out the Victorians and 1920s-vintage houses on Fourth Street, he repeated a fellow commission member's comment that "you can't save them all."
The city administrator, Richard Deaney, says the effect of the teardowns has been exaggerated. Of the 301 demolitions last year, he said, only 73 were single-family homes. "No doubt there are a lot of demolitions and a lot of duplexes being built," he said. "But there are also a lot of duplexes and other multifamily buildings being torn down."
Moreover, Mr. Deaney said, almost all the duplexes being built are in areas zoned for duplexes, even if they were occupied by single-family homes.
That is sparse comfort for preservationists. Many of the new side-by-side duplexes have spots of Victorian-style trim, which Mr. Swift calls "vinyl gingerbread," though their vintage is apparent from sliding doors and vinyl siding. And their neighbors miss the solid old houses that they are replacing.
"Every time I go down there I see another vacant lot," said Lisa Sarajian, a New Yorker who spends weekends in the meticulously kept arts-and-crafts-style house on Fourth Street that her parents bought when she was a child. Two doors down from her, an identical house was just sold to a developer.
"Since it's a middle-class community, lots of people are real estate rich but cash poor," she said. "It's easier for them to sell than to rehab the homes. They don't have the capital to save these structures. The dirt is worth more than what's on them."
That was the plight of Ms. Sheehan, a 59-year-old widow who had cared for her ailing father in the house until his death two years ago. In a memorandum she wrote to the Preservation Commission after it denied her application for a partial demolition permit in February, she said she had exhausted her assets and could not burden her children with the maintenance costs. The house will now be used as an education center concentrating on coastal history and environment. As more grant money becomes available, the newer sections can be stripped away and the original lifesaving station restored, said Councilman Jody Alessandrine, the council's chief advocate for the project.
Mr. Alessandrine said the city was initially reluctant to undertake any such thing.
"Their argument is that they don't want to get in the business of buying property," he said. "This is the only one that has the depth of historic value."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Bricks, Mortarand Sociology

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
WHEN Nortel Networks consolidated its global headquarters in a renovated building in suburban Toronto in 1997, Roy Dohner, the vice president for real estate, wanted to see to it that the company changed its culture as well.
Employee surveys told him that the most irksome feature of the company's old main office was reserved parking. "If you had to park very far from the front door, it might give you an indication of the value the company placed on you," Mr. Dohner said. 
 So the new lot is general admission, and the staff is, he presumes, happy.
Moves like that make Mr. Dohner the very model of a modern corporate real estate executive, according to people in the field. Far from simple buying, leasing and building of space, the state of the real estate art is now all about collaboration and togetherness: gauging employee satisfaction alongside the human resources department, consulting with the finance people on costs and conferring regularly with the crew in information technology. The new ideal is to be a ground-level force for better morale, lower costs and higher productivity.
At least that was the talk at a recent conference for real estate executives in Boston, sponsored by a professional association called the International Development Research Council. And it is a theme that many managers have picked up.
PERSUADING the rest of the world of their importance to corporate America's bottom line is a matter of survival for real estate executives. The profession had a brush with extinction in the recession of the early 1990's, when corporate downsizing and a trend toward contracting out support functions combined to wipe out many in-house real estate departments.
"It was the clean-out period," said Bill Agnello, vice president for real estate and the workplace at Sun Microsystems. "The real estate function was at the end of the line."
Seeing its rolls dwindle, the professional association began promoting the idea that real estate can offer a competitive edge and that real estate managers are the people pushing that edge.
Much of the activity is on the human-element end of the new real estate spectrum -- Mr. Dohner's egalitarian parking, for example, or a stress-reduction drive at Charles Schwab & Company that was led by the company's real estate chief, Parkash Ahuja. To ease workers' minds about nagging personal annoyances, Mr. Ahuja introduced on-site concierge and dry cleaning services and asked the cafeteria to start selling take-home meals. Now, he said, "we have less absenteeism and employees tend to stay longer."
But real estate executives are more likely to get the attention of top management by delivering direct cost savings.
When Cisco Systems found that its sales representatives spent only about 30 percent of their time in their offices, the real estate department switched its focus from just providing square feet of space for those employees to supporting their mobility; it saved $12.6 million over five years in the company's Manhattan office through a desk-sharing arrangement.
AT Nortel, the move of offices from three Toronto locations to a renovated former factory in Brampton, Ontario, cut occupancy costs by two-thirds. The $50 million renovation, which included graffiti-style art to promote a casual atmosphere, was successful enough that Nortel held its shareholder meeting in the new offices, piping the proceedings to television sets around the building.
"Historically, real estate people want to have real estate monuments," Mr. Dohner said. This project, instead, was about "people, process and productivity," he said.
No one has yet demonstrated a clear link between pretty buildings and productive office workers. Measuring output is easy in factories, said Marina van Overbeek, a planning and design executive at Cisco, but gauging it in office work with a creative element is more elusive.
"One of the next challenges is white-collar productivity," she said. "How does the workplace impact productivity? It may not be a dollar measure."
Without an objective yardstick, executives rely on instinct. "What's really important is what feels good for us," said Mr. Agnello at Sun Microsystems. His company, with 15,000 new workers in the last five years, is changing too fast to stay with old real estate standards, he said.
At Sun's new $123 million facility in Burlington, Mass., individual offices are smaller than those the company had previously, and there are more spaces for small group meetings. Whether the design will prompt impromptu brainstorming sessions when employees pass in the hall, as the designers hoped, remains to be seen.
Is "corporate infrastructure resource management" -- a phrase that the International Development Research Council has registered as a service mark -- keeping corporate real estate professionals employed?
At Sun, the real estate department has 140 people, as it did five years ago. But now only a third of those workers handle traditional property-management tasks; the rest work on research and innovation.
For some real estate executives, the new approach is paying off in greater responsibility and more respect at the conference table. Mr. Agnello now reports regularly to Sun's chief financial officer and has the ear of the company's chairman, Scott McNealy. And Mr. Ahuja at Schwab now oversees all the corporate services that touch employees, including travel and payroll as well as real estate.
Although the council provides reams of literature on "strategic alignment" and "integrated management," it is hard to say how many companies have embraced the philosophy of real estate as a force for good.
Buzzwords aside, experts like Michael L. Joroff, a lecturer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a proponent of the broader approach to real estate management, say that technology, human resources and real estate departments will need to collaborate more, come what may. Trends toward telecommuting and the wider adoption of mobile communications mean that the future of business will be "intertwined platforms of brick and mortar and cyberspace," Mr. Joroff said.
At Fidelity Investments that means a move toward giving employees cell phones as their only telephones -- but not before the company studies how comfortable workers will be with the setup.
"It's easy technology," said Charlie Brenner, senior vice president at Fidelity's Center for Applied Technology. "It's odd sociology."
