HEADLINE: The World: The World Takes Notice;
Kashmir Gets Scarier

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: SRINAGAR, Kashmir

 BODY:
HIGH in the forbidding Himalayan foothills north of here, the half-century-old struggle for control of Kashmir is entering a new and unpredictable phase. Islamic fighters have crossed the line that divides the state between zones of Indian and Pakistani control, and the Indian Army is waging a bloody campaign to drive them back. It is the latest battle in a conflict that has taken tens of thousands of lives over the last decade.
In the wake of the Kosovo campaign, awareness is growing in Washington and other capitals that the world pays a high price for waiting too long to address growing crises. The one in Kashmir is among the most combustible, and the fact that both contending nations are armed with nuclear weapons lends it an apocalyptic urgency. It is now drawing more serious attention than at any time since it started. 
 When President Clinton telephoned the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan last week to urge them to resolve this crisis, he was stepping gingerly, and on territory where few outsiders have dared to tread at all. His message was vague and tentative, but in suggesting that Pakistan use its influence to pull the insurgents out of Indian territory, he was at least signaling the world's growing fear that this obscure conflict could spiral out of control.
"We're facing a small war, but it can escalate," one of Kashmir's wise men, Sufi Ghulan Mohammed, editor of the Urdu-language Srinagar Times, said last week. "Escalation means devastation. It does not have to be planned. Anything can happen at any time."
The Kashmir conflict, overlaid with religious passion as well as chauvinistic competition, is perhaps even more complex than those that have shaken the Balkans. Kashmir is about 75 percent Muslim, but when India and Pakistan were created in 1947, the maharajah, a Hindu, chose to lead it into Hindu-dominated India rather than Islamic Pakistan. He felt that the mixed society he ruled would fare better in an avowedly secular state than one devoted to a single religion.
Pakistan has never accepted Kashmir's accession to India, and has waged two wars to seize it. The last one, in 1971, ended with a cease-fire that left two-thirds of the state in India and the rest in Pakistan.
One reason the conflict is so difficult to solve is that in different ways, Kashmir is central to the national ideals of both India and Pakistan. Indian leaders fear that losing Kashmir would set off a wave of separatist movements in other Indian states, and implicitly accept the failure of the premise on which India is built: that it can embrace peoples of many different religions.
Pakistan, in contrast, was built on the idea that all Muslims on the sub-continent should live in their own state. Allowing all or part of Kashmir to remain under Indian rule contradicts that.
Some powerful Pakistanis believe that Kashmir represents the unfinished agenda of the 1947 partition. Others see war here as a way to punish India for its support of Pakistani rebels who succeeded in separating Bangladesh from Pakistan in 1971. But the real fire behind the current conflict is the desire of Islamic militants to wrest control of what they consider a Muslim land from the control of infidels. Many of them fought in Afghanistan; some are loyal to the anti-Western Muslim fundamentalist Osama bin Laden.
Over the years, Pakistan has sought to internationalize the issue by bringing it before the United Nations and other bodies. India opposes all such efforts, and insists that the question be resolved only by the two nations. But President Clinton's telephone calls last week, along with expected discussions of the problem at this weekend's meeting of leaders of the biggest industrialized countries in Germany, suggest that India may now have to accept the world's growing concern.
In the wake of the holocaust in Rwanda and successive catastrophes in the former Yugoslavia, many voices are being raised in favor of intervening before future crises around the globe reach the point of explosion. There is still no consensus on how, when or where to act, and much fear about the consequences of aggressive intervention. But few international summits are likely to pass now without discussion of the possibility of assertive action in places like Kashmir.
Kashmir is a good place to start because it reflects not only how dangerous obscure wars can become, but also how difficult it is to resolve them. Many people in the Indian-held section are highly suspicious of Pakistan, which is in even worse social, economic and political shape than India and where religious fundamentalism is on the rise. But they have no love for the Indian security forces, which human rights groups say regularly ransack and burn villages, torture prisoners and assassinate suspected militants.
OVER the years, some Indian leaders have suggested that the solution lies in giving the province what Prime Minister Narasimha Rao in 1995 called "anything short of independence" and what Prime Minister Deve Gowda a year later called "maximum autonomy." That, however, is anathema to much of the Indian establishment, which fears a precedent for splintering India itself.
Every proposed solution, in fact, is fraught with danger. To reach a lasting peace, all three sides would have to make historic compromises involving their basic principles.
In addition to the West, China, which borders Kashmir and faces a rising Islamic movement in its own western provinces, is increasingly worried and increasingly ready to apply pressure for a solution. But if outside powers are to break this deadlock, they need strong partners in both India and Pakistan, leaders who can break with the past and persuade their peoples to do so too. No such leaders are on the horizon.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1038 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Latin America's Armies Are Down But Not Out

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
THE generals who once made and deposed presidents are now so marginal a factor in Brazil's daily life that a milestone went almost unremarked this month. When President Fernando Henrique Cardoso signed a bill merging the Army, Air Force and Navy ministries into a single Ministry of Defense headed by a retired senator, Brazil became the last member of Mercosur, the South American customs union composed of former military dictatorships, to place its armed forces under full formal civilian control.
Though the rest of the world still envisions the likes of Pinochet, Peron, Trujillo, Somoza, and Torrijos when it thinks of Latin America, these are trying times for soldiers throughout the region. Government spending is declining even faster than the prestige of a military career. In virtually every country the armed forces confront what Armando Borrero, a Colombian scholar of the military, calls "an existential problem: What is their role now that they are no longer the dominant force in their societies?" 
 For the whole region, getting soldiers to go back to their barracks has brought indisputable political and economic benefits. When generals were in charge in Argentina and Brazil two decades ago, for instance, troops were deployed on their border, and both were pursuing costly nuclear programs.
But after democratic civilian rule was restored in the mid-1980's, the countries buried their historic grievances and married their fortunes in Mercosur. Trade and other forms of contact have exploded. This month, Mr. Cardoso and Argentina's President, Carlos Menem, even decided to seek a common currency.
Similarly, Argentina and Chile have settled all but one of 23 border disputes, and civilian presidents in Peru and Ecuador just recently laid to rest a boundary conflict that caused several wars in the past 50 years. Perhaps that explains why the Clinton Administration, which lifted longstanding restrictions on United States arms sales to Latin America in 1997, has found so few takers for the wares it wants to sell.
"The military leadership does not want to go back to the old system," said Richard Millett, the author of "Beyond Praetorianism: The Latin American Military at the End of the 20th Century." "They see less to gain from confrontation than in cooperation against the real enemy, like transnational crime groups. They know that the strength of your neighbor is not a menace; it's his weakness that is dangerous."
In March, in fact, the armed forces of Ecuador and Paraguay resisted the temptation to intervene in a crisis. They know that a coup would lead to ostracism, loss of trade benefits and elimination from prestigious and profitable United Nations peacekeeping missions. Mr. Cardoso even warned Paraguay's soldiers that Mercosur is a club for democracies only and that a coup would lead to expulsion.
While the Latin American military may be out, it is not necessarily down. "You do not yet really have true civilian control of the military," Dr. Millett said. "What you have is enhanced civilian influence and reduced military autonomy. The civilian defense ministers in a lot of these countries don't order the generals around, they consult and negotiate with them."
One big question for any civilian government is what to do to keep the idled troops out of mischief. Washington's answer, regarded as a recipe for disaster by every government in the region, has been to press the armies to enlist in the war against drugs.
"Americans tend to think that Latin America spends so much on the military that it might as well get something useful out of them," said Alfred Stepan, author of several books on the Latin American military. "But that is a dangerous way of looking at things. If the military get involved in the anti-drug wars, not only are they not prepared for it, but doing so has a corrupting impact and may contribute to an expansion of their role."
The Central American military offers a different but no less disturbing model. With no more guerrillas left to battle -- or slaughter -- they have been transformed into economic conglomerates that threaten to choke off competition from private enterprise. In a study titled "Soldiers as Businessmen," Arnoldo Brenes and Kevin Casas have documented how Central America's armed forces have taken over banks, hotels, funeral homes, radio stations, advertising agencies, supermarkets and stores through their pension funds.
I N general and at a theoretical level, many people are concerned by the fact that the military, which already has the power of arms, may also try to obtain uncontrolled economic power," they write in the book, published last year in Costa Rica by the Arias Foundation for Peace and Human Progress. When the profit motive replaces national defense as the army's mission, the pair warn, "the very reason for the existence of the armed forces is distorted."
Their patron Oscar Arias, a former president of Costa Rica who won the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize, argues that the best way to avoid such problems is to follow his country's example and abolish the armed forces altogether. "What we need in our countries is a good police force with a civilian mentality and some cheap, light arms, not an army that needs to maintain its power with sophisticated weapons," he says. The only other countries to follow that recipe have had second thoughts. Panama is unable to fend off Colombian guerrillas who regularly cross into its territory, and Haiti finds its sovereignty ignored by drug traffickers.
Then there is Venezuela, where the rise of Hugo Chavez, a cashiered colonel who led an unsuccessful coup attempt in 1992 and was elected president last December, has meant a more prominent role for the military. But that country, Mr. Arias noted, was spared the last cycle of military rule and abuses, which makes it a special case.
"After the suffering that people in the rest of Latin America have endured, nobody wants the return of the military," he said. "People are not going to forget what the military did to repress and oppress. They know that the litmus test of democracy is the subordination of military power to civilian authority and that is what civil society demands."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Greenspan on Inflation: Wait, Don't Wait. Go Figure.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN, the Federal Reserve chairman, strongly hinted last week that the central bank will raise interest rates later this month to prevent the galloping economy from setting off inflation -- even though, he conceded, inflation remains inconsequential. "Pre-emptive action can obviate the need of more drastic actions at a later date," he told Congress.
Huh? 
 Is this the same Alan Greenspan who has steered unemployment rates to their lowest levels in 30 years precisely because he was willing to let the economic party go on? Now he says growth, averaging 4 percent a year, is on an "unsustainable trend," even though increases in hourly wages are falling and inflation last month was zero.
Has Mr. Greenspan reversed course, discarding his brilliantly executed regime of watchful waiting in favor of pre-emptive strikes against nonexistent inflation?
Some students of the Fed say Mr. Greenspan has been more a pragmatic opportunist than a watchful waiter, taking clever advantage of special circumstances like falling oil prices and spikes in productivity. Others say he has been more lucky than good.
Lurking beneath this debate is a more important one about how the economy works and how central bankers should control it.
Conventional economic wisdom, circa 1990, came in three parts. First, there was thought to be a minimum long-term unemployment rate, estimated to lie between 6 and 6.5 percent. If the Fed would try to push unemployment any lower, the theory went, it would send wages, then prices, spiraling upward. Second, inflation, once started, tended to accelerate out of control. Breaking inflation would require the Fed to raise interest rates so much that recession would follow. Third, it was thought that Fed policies to break inflation would need a year or more to take hold. Conventional wisdom said, then, that the Fed should strike pre-emptively against inflation.
But something weird and wonderful happened on Mr. Greenspan's watch. For reasons nobody really understands, unemployment fell steadily from above 7 percent in 1992 to 4.2 percent today. Yet inflation stayed quiet. Something was wrong with the Fed's models.
Some economists, like Prof. Frederic Mishkin of Columbia University, chalk up Mr. Greenspan's success to subtle pragmatism. In 1992 and 1993, Mr. Mishkin cites as an example, banks were in poor financial health, so Mr. Greenspan kept interest rates low; that way, banks wouldn't have to pay as much to depositors. After the banks recovered, he raised rates in 1994 to keep the economy from overheating. Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard provides another example. In 1998, the Fed reduced rates to keep the economy from slowing in response to the financial crisis spreading from Asia. Now, Mr. Greenspan indicated during his testimony last week, the Asian crisis has dissolved and some of the rate cuts may no longer be needed.
Joseph Stiglitz, the chief economist at the World Bank and former head of the Council of Economic Advisors under President Clinton, takes a dimmer view of the Greenspan record, suggesting that the post-1993 recovery happened despite errors Mr. Greenspan made. Mr. Stiglitz says the Fed misjudged the favorable economic impact of the budget plan that Congress passed in 1993 to trim the deficit. It therefore sat on the sidelines as the economy roared ahead, pulling the unemployment down to levels the Fed had thought dangerous. If Mr. Greenspan had correctly forecast the impact of the budget plan, Mr. Stiglitz argues, he would have raised interest rates to fight inflation -- and the country would have lost a roaring recovery that has brought jobs to millions of low-paid workers.
BUT whether Mr. Greenspan achieved spectacular economic results by accident or mistake, Mr. Friedman gives him credit for letting unemployment fall to levels the Fed considered unsafe -- thereby discovering the economy could do a lot better than the Fed had thought possible. Mr. Stiglitz draws some other lessons. Research by the Council of Economic Advisers, he says, refutes most of the conventional wisdom. Inflation is not the scourge it was only recently thought to be. Professor James K. Galbraith of the University of Texas agrees. "Research does not show that, once started, inflation automatically spirals upward," he said. "Nor is there evidence that reversing modest increases in inflation is all that costly."
By this line of argument, there's no harm in waiting to attack inflation until it actually appears. And waiting has the advantage of letting the Fed learn how fast the economy can grow. So, it might seem, the debate comes down to a dispute between economists who think it is important to pre-empt inflation and those who think fighting inflation can wait. It's not quite that simple. This is, after all, the Delphic science of economics.
Listen to Professor Friedman. He agrees that the Fed can reverse modest inflation with only modest recession as a result. In this, he sounds like Mr. Stiglitz. But he also wants the Fed to raise interest rates next week. That sounds like the strategy preferred by Mr. Greenspan. Professor Friedman has an explanation: "I called for rate hikes five years ago when I thought the economy was growing too fast. And I was wrong. I called for rate hikes two years ago. Again, I was wrong. But labor markets are tighter now than they were five years ago or two years ago, and our economy is growing even faster. The Fed cannot wait around for mistakes to happen when it thinks they are in the works."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Grade Inflation;
New Math: No One Is Below Average

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
IN Lake Wobegon, Garrison Keillor's mythical Minnesota community, the women are strong, the men are good looking and the children are all above average. But who knew that those children were pawns of standardized testing?
Twelve years ago, a country doctor in West Virginia, John J. Cannell, was treating teen-age patients with self-esteem problems. Although their school test scores showed them performing above average, they were depressed about not doing well in class. When tested on different test, by independent psychologists, the children scored below average. 
 Enlisting his staff as detectives, Dr. Cannell surveyed school districts across the country and found that most of them reported their students scoring above the national average on standardized tests -- something that any high-school math student would dismiss as statistically impossible.
Dr. Cannell's discovery, nicknamed the Lake Wobegon effect, set off a furor over standardized testing as researchers confirmed what he had discovered. Now an increasing number of states are adopting high-stakes testing as a condition of high school graduation and to reward or punish schools. Experts warn that the incentive to massage test results is great, and that parents and children should beware of the recurrence of Lake Wobegon effect.
"It may be forgotten, but it is not gone," said Robert L. Linn, a professor of education at the University of Colorado in Boulder, who investigated Dr. Cannell's original findings.
There are many ways for scores to be artificially inflated, from companies marketing old tests to outright cheating. There have even been treatises on the politics of testing; how changing tests can lower scores when mayors are elected or school superintendents are appointed and raise them over the next few years so those in charge can take the credit.
Take New York City, the nation's biggest school district.
In 1997, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigned for re-election touting a rise in reading scores of three percentage points, even as his opponent, Ruth W. Messinger, scoffed that such a gain was hardly cause to, as her press secretary put it, break out the champagne. The Mayor was celebrating results showing the school system, with its high concentration of poor children and immigrants, could produce results comparable to the national average.
That blissful picture was shattered recently when the Board of Education announced the results of new tests, administered in April. Last year, 49.6 percent of the city's elementary and middle school students could read as well as the typical American student. (By definition, 50 percent of all children should be reading better than the typical student, and 50 percent worse.) This year, the percentage of children reading at this level dropped suddenly, to 44.6. Math scores dropped 10 points, from well above the typical level to a shade below.
"Let me guess," said Walter M. Haney, a professor and senior research associate in the Center for the Study of Testing at Boston College. "They changed the test."
Well, yes, they did.
New York City changed from one major battery of standardized tests, the California Achievement Test, to another, the Comprehensive Tests of Basic Skills. The city also updated its scoring, comparing schoolchildren to a national sample who took the test in 1996, instead of 1991. The combination of new material and a higher standard depressed the scores.
Still, the Board of Education argued that scores had risen one percentage point in reading, not dropped, using a method called equating -- a statistical calculation designed compare old and new tests.
MOST statisticians, though, say equating is deeply flawed and valid in only the most narrow circumstances. In New York City's case, the test publisher, CTB/McGraw-Hill, refused to endorse the equating done by the city's Board of Education.
A national testing program, which President Clinton proposed in his 1997 State of the Union message, would impose consistent standards and dampen the Lake Wobegon effect. But many states have balked, saying that a universal test would intrude on the tradition of permitting school districts to set their own policy and curriculum. As a compromise, Congress asked the National Academy of Sciences to study whether the wide array of state and commercial tests could be equated to one another -- or to the National Assessment of Education Progress, which is the closest thing to a nationwide test.
"Our conclusion was that it is really not feasible to develop a common scale for those tests," said Michael J. Feuer, director of the board on testing and assessment of the National Academy of Sciences.
Some equations are simple, Dr. Feuer said. Visiting a friend in Germany, you may learn that the temperature there is 30 degrees Centigrade and easily convert it to Fahrenheit. But what if you wanted to convert temperature to rainfall? Reading, like the weather, is not measured by only one factor. That is the equating dilemma.
As for New York City, Daniel M. Koretz, a senior social scientist at Rand Education, a research group in Washington, predicts that the latest results will soon be a distant memory. Test scores will begin their inevitable rise again, he says, driven by the growing familiarity of teachers with the test and an outdated standard of grading.
Dr. Cannell is now a forensic psychiatrist living in Los Osos, Calif.
"It's a real time-consuming task," he said last week of his crusade to end the manipulation of test scores, "and one that brings me enemies, not friends. Politicians, test publishers, schools, they just have too much to gain by having test scores that are going up every year."

HEADLINE: The World: Where Serbia Fits;
Rebuilding Is Hard Without the Keystone

BYLINE: By ALISON SMALE 

 BODY:
AS the fighting raged in Kosovo, Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and other leaders cast the latest Balkan battle as a moral imperative on the order of fighting Nazism. Much less forcefully stated was another goal: creating a Europe whole and free. Then Mr. Clinton, in his speech marking the end of bombing, invited Serbia to join what he termed "this historic journey to a peaceful, democratic and united Europe." But he insisted Serbia would get nothing but the most basic humanitarian aid unless its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, goes.
So NATO's military might has proved, in the end, able to realize one alliance goal: the return of the Kosovo Albanians forced out by Serbian terror and the sheer violence that followed the alliance's decision to bomb. But it left its other goal -- the rebuilding of the Balkans -- very much open to question. In large part, that is because, barring the sudden disappearance of Mr. Milosevic, the West is proposing to rebuild the area without rebuilding Serbia, the country at the Balkans' heart. 
 Last week, as NATO's troops took control of Kosovo, they were finding more evidence of the kind of atrocities widely associated with Serbian security forces. Those horrors had already earned Mr. Milosevic and some of his closest cohorts indictments from the international war crimes tribunal. Confirmation of the murder and brutality described by Kosovo's fleeing Albanians seems certain to isolate Serbia even further.
The moral satisfaction of doing no business with Mr. Milosevic may wind up conflicting with the political and economic logic of finally bringing the Balkans fully into the new Europe, a costly and long-term enterprise.
The problem is that Europe does not need the Balkans to prosper, but cannot truly be at peace unless the Balkan states prosper too. For a century, these lands, haphazardly formed from the collapse of the Hapsburg and Ottoman Empires, have been of interest to the rest of Europe only when fresh imperial ambitions made this expedient.
Now, the builders of the new Europe -- the Europe of a single currency and trading bloc, of a common security and foreign policy -- seem to have concluded that this Europe has no chance without finally quieting the Balkans.
For now, that goal must be achieved through tens of thousands of peacekeepers and aid workers, who have already created a virtual protectorate in Bosnia, dependent on foreign money and might for its existence. If a less clinging child is to be born in Kosovo, and the tens of thousands of NATO soldiers pouring in there are ever to leave, the world will have to help its people build a functioning state, one where Serbs and Albanians can trust each other with their lives. That would be more difficult with a pauperized, resentful Serbia next door.
In the Balkans, the larger task is now to close the yawning territorial gap between the north European and Greek halves of the European Union, and between most NATO members and the Greeks and Turks. The paths for commerce and tourism along the Danube, between northern and southeastern Europe, from the Black Sea to the Adriatic would be more open and secure.
Apparently, none of this was of great concern when Western Europe failed to end the war in Bosnia in the early 1990's, or when the Clinton Administration later passed up the chance to expand NATO swiftly into the post-Communist Balkans by rejecting Romania in the first wave of NATO enlargement. But now the continuing bloodshed, having drawn NATO into a major military role in the region, seems to have convinced the West to try to close the gap.
That cannot be done without the 10 million Serbs, who are still the most numerous people in the former Yugoslavia, outnumbering all but the Greeks and Romanians on the Balkan peninsula. Geographically, Serbia is at the heart of this region -- its roads, railways and rivers indispensable to any commerce or communication that might finally wear down the hatreds and rivalries that have gnawed at these lands this century.
Serbia is to the Balkans what Germany is to Europe: a country and culture too big to ignore. After World War I, Europe and America considered Germany to have been the main cause of that conflict, and punished Germany by imposing impossible reparations and effectively isolating it from the rest of Europe. The policy was perhaps morally satisfying, even just. One of its unintended results was the rise of Adolf Hitler.
IN the Balkans, leaving Serbian hatreds and the traumas of the past 12 years of Mr. Milosevic's rule to fester could well turn many Serbs even more against the outside world. Mr. Clinton has called on the Serbs to remove Mr. Milosevic but there is no assurance that they will, any more than Iraqis have followed the urgings of Mr. Clinton and his predecessor, George Bush, to rid themselves of Saddam Hussein. And for as long as he remains in power, Mr. Milosevic and his media would still paint Serbs as victims of foreigners and the other peoples of the old Yugoslavia.
The brutal killers who have served the Serbian leader would have little compunction about acting as arms procurers or mobile guerrillas to anyone willing to pay (Iraq is among Serbia's closer allies). Politically, Mr. Milosevic could be driven even further into the arms of the only president who visited him during the Kosovo war, the Stalinist leader of Belarus, Alexander Lukashenko.
With such a state at its heart, the Balkan region would have little hope of achieving stability or peace. And the European Union, which will pay most of the bill for rebuilding the Balkans, might well find itself wasting any money it throws at the struggling states of Bulgaria, Romania, Albania and Macedonia.
Thus, while declaring that it is up to the Serbs to topple Mr. Milosevic before they get any help, the Clinton Administration does seem to be working quietly toward the Serbian leader's ouster. Robert Gelbard, one of Mr. Clinton's envoys to the Balkans, has been meeting with Serbian opposition leaders in Montenegro, and the President has reportedly approved a covert action program to destabilize Mr. Milosevic's Government.
The retreat forced upon Serbia by the allied bombing may inspire more Serbs to oppose Mr. Milosevic's continued rule. Back in the winter of 1996-97, they staged highly disciplined but ultimately unsuccessful protests against Mr. Milosevic. Last week, as NATO peacekeepers poured into Kosovo, the Serbian Orthodox Church called for him to be replaced.
Zoran Djindjic, a Serbian opposition leader who fled to neighboring Montenegro during the Kosovo war after Belgrade accused him of being a traitor, was encouraging Westerners last week to work with provincial opposition leaders; many of these are mayors of some of the most heavily bombed cities in Serbia, such as Nis, Cacak, Kragujevac and Novi Sad. "There are regions and cities in Serbia that share the same views that I do and it wouldn't be suitable or just if these people pay the price of the isolationist policy of Mr. Milosevic, which will leave all of us isolated together," Mr. Djindjic said.
A leader as resilient as Mr. Milosevic is unlikely to go quietly, though, and a danger of trying to topple him from a distance is that any failure could reinforce East European doubts about the West's resolve. The Hungarians, Czechs and Poles bitterly recall how little NATO (which they have finally joined themselves) did for them when their own people tried to throw off Soviet power in 1956, 1968 or 1981. For the Western message to have any genuine attraction for the Serbs, they will have to see that this time the West is serious, realistic and yet imaginative.
In Kosovo, for instance, the Serbs are watching to see if the West can guide Albanians to build a state, and steer them away from their own version of the Greater Serbian nationalism that has proved so disastrous for the Serbs, and is now ebbing in Serbia.
F OR the past 120 years, the great powers, or the international community as it's now called, have intervened in this region to further their strategic aims and inflicted enormous damage on the people of the Balkans," said Misha Glenny, a British author who has written extensively about the Balkans. "For the first time in 120 years the great powers now have an opportunity to make good the destruction for which they bear considerable responsibility. If they fail to address the pressing economic and social needs of the region, then the Balkans will again be a theater of war."

HEADLINE: Grand Canyon Blazing Trail With Light Rail Line

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: GRAND CANYON, Ariz., June 19

 BODY:
Mass tourism to the Grand Canyon started in 1901 with the construction of a Santa Fe Railroad spur to the south rim. Now, at the century's twilight, the canyon is returning to its mass-transit roots, breaking ground recently for the first light rail in a national park.
Sandwiched in the decades between was the National Park Service's love affair with the automobile -- scenic drives, drive-through overlooks, acres of parking, and, outside the south entrance, the kind of development symbolized by a two-story statue of Fred Flintstone calling out "Yabba-dabba-doo" to motorists looking for a campground. 
 While work starts this summer on the $100 million light rail system, which is intended to cut vehicle traffic by 80 percent, Grand Canyon National Park is innovating on a different front: refurbishing its tacky commercial gateway.
In a rare collaboration between developers and environmentalists, nine environmental groups have endorsed a $330 million plan to build a gateway to the park that would include 1,220 hotel rooms and 250,000 square feet of commercial space. In July, the Forest Service is expected to approve a land swap that would allow the developer, Canyon Forest Village, to exchange 2,200 acres of private land scattered around the Kaibab National Forest for 272 acres next to the terminus of the light rail line. There, trains will leave every seven minutes for the south rim, 8.5 miles away.
"We have seen what the marketplace has done around the Grand Canyon -- junk, strip malls, sprawl -- we are not interested in seeing any more of that," said Brad Ack, program director of the Grand Canyon Trust, a regional environmental group. Noting that during five years of negotiations, environmentalists and Indian tribes have won major changes in the project, he said, "It's a pretty interesting approach to environmentalism. Instead of saying no, and losing, we say yes and win."
Expected to draw nearly 5 million people this year, the Grand Canyon is one of the nation's most visited parks. The turn to mass transit here presages a larger shift in how Americans will visit their most popular parks in the 21st century, park officials predict. Over the last 30 years, the number of visitors to American national parks has nearly doubled, hitting 287 million last year.
"At the big parks, our goal is not to limit people, but to limit their cars," Jackie Lowey, a deputy director of the Park Service, said recently from Maine, where she was preparing the June 21 inauguration of free shuttle-bus service from Bar Harbor to sections of Acadia National Park.
In southern Utah, Zion National Park is buying a fleet of buses that run on clean-burning fuels. Next spring, park officials plan to close Zion Canyon to cars, shuttling visitors in and out by bus.
In Alaska, at Denali National Park and Preserve, almost all motorized access is by van or bus. In Wyoming, at Yellowstone National Park, and in California, at Yosemite National Park, officials are studying ways of using buses to reduce traffic. In announcing the Yosemite study last December, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said, "At times, the valley reminds you very much of being in Times Square in midsummer."
Already, about 40 of the nation's busiest parks, including the Grand Canyon, have some form of mass-transit system. Here, a steam railroad continues to take tourists to the canyon and shuttle buses transport them down West Rim Drive.
Visitors should "have a park experience, not a parking experience," Robert Arnberger, the Grand Canyon's superintendent, said at the April 23 groundbreaking for the hub of the new light rail system.
Gazing down into the mile-deep depths of what some Indians call the House Made of Dawn at times inspires mystical feelings. But a one-hour search in 100-degree heat for a parking spot can inspire fist fights. On a busy summer day, 6,000 vehicles dispute 2,400 parking space in the park's south side, the destination for 90 percent of the park's visitors. The roads and parking lots were built in the 1960's, when the park had about one million visitors a year.
Rather than building six-lane freeways and multistory parking garages, park officials have opted for a parking lot for 3,500 vehicles around the transit center at the park's southern entrance.
"It's going to take time for people to embrace this new way of seeing national parks," said Bradley Traver, the park's chief planner.
At the rim's edge, where tour bus drivers now idle engines to keep air-conditioning running, a maximum of 4,200 people an hour will arrive by train, then shift to bicycle and pedestrian trails or to buses powered by electricity or natural gas.
"If we run diesel-belching monsters for buses, we are part of the problem," Mr. Traver said. Air pollution has cut visibility at the canyon to an average of 110 miles, from 140 miles at the start of the century.
In another effort to reduce the mark of man, Interior Department officials support the Canyon Forest Village development, which would be built 8 miles from the canyon in the Kaibab National Forest.
Under this plan, the Parks Service would demolish substandard worker housing in the park and build up to 500 housing units in the new development. Thomas A. De Paolo, the developer, believes that the parks high school and medical center can also be moved into the development.
With a host of new hotel rooms at the park's edge, the Park Service will demolish two boxy, 1960's lodges on the south rim.
Environmental groups like the proposal because it calls for importing water by train and pipeline from a section of the Colorado River on the Arizona-California line. Hotels in the gateway town of Tusayan now pump well water from an underground aquifer, which environmentalists argue robs water that is vital to the canyon's delicate ecology.
"Any project that relies on groundwater pumping is unacceptable," said Dave Simon of Albuquerque, regional director of one watchdog group, the National Parks and Conservation Association. "We are going to have one master-plan development in one area that is already developed, instead of three or four developments that will smear the problem over a big area," he said.
Three Indian tribes of the Colorado Plateau have endorsed the Canyon Forest plan, largely because the developers promise them jobs, market space for their wares and a museum that gives weight to Native American views of the Grand Canyon. Although tourism injects nearly $1 billion a year into the canyon area, the surrounding county, Coconino, ranks among the 10 poorest in the nation.
Mr. Ack, one of the environmentalists, said from Flagstaff, "For the first time, the tribes have been asked to be part of the economic engine of the Grand Canyon, other than selling trinkets by the roadside."

HEADLINE: Washington's Teen-Ager Curfew to Start Soon

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
With school out for the summer, teen-agers nationwide can look forward to two months of freedom and carefree summer nights. But not here in Washington.
A Federal Appeals court ruled on Friday that teen-agers do not have an unrestricted right to roam the streets late at night and that a youth curfew is constitutional. The law, an effort to reduce crime, bars those under 17 from being in a public place unaccompanied by a parent or guardian between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M. Monday through Thursday, and midnight to 6 A.M. Friday to Sunday. 
 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled that the Juvenile Curfew Act of 1995 does not infringe on the rights of children or the rights of parents to raise their children.
The appeals court's ruling lifts an injunction that has prevented Washington police from enforcing the law since 1996. Supporters of the curfew said enforcement was likely to begin soon.
Breaking the curfew could result in 25 hours of community service for young offenders. Parents could be ordered to pay fines up to $500 for allowing children to disobey the curfew. There are eight exceptions to the law, including errands sanctioned by parents or guardians, emergencies and certain kinds of employment.
Judge Lawrence H. Silberman wrote the opinion that was joined at least in part by eight others on the 11-member court. It found that although young people are generally afforded the same constitutional guarantees as adults, the state must account for their "unique vulnerability and immaturity."
"I feel ecstatic, vindicated and pleased," said Harold Brazil, a Democrat on the District Council, who sponsored the original law four years ago. "We have given police another tool to fight crime and protect youngsters. It is very timely in the wake of all this youth violence."
Other council members, however, did not share Mr. Brazil's enthusiasm. "I am a little bit disappointed," said Phil Mendelson, another Democrat on the Council. "As a government, we have to be circumspect about laws that curtail freedom. If we want to cut crime we need to deal more with the problems associated with crime, not people being out of their homes."
Professor Jeffrey R. Henig of George Washington University, who specializes in urban policy and directs the university's Washington Area Studies Center, says that the success of the law lies in the enforcement. "If the police choose to use it as a tool, it could have some positive effects," Professor Henig said. "But having a law on the books with spotty and erratic enforcement could be worse than nothing at all."
The American Civil Liberties Union is critical of the law, viewing it as an infringement of free movement. In addition, the A.C.L.U. contends that the law intrudes on parents' rights to raise their children as they see fit.
"As long as people are not acting illegally and irresponsibly and they have their parents' permission, then they should be allowed to move freely," said a former A.C.L.U. president, Robert S. Plotkin. "The curfew presumes that all parents are making bad decisions and bad choices as a blanket rule."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
With Words, Gore And Bush Stake Out The Middle Ground

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush, declaring their candidacies for President, sound as though they are proclaiming the primary campaign over, the general election begun and the battleground designated as the moderate middle, with ideological extremes out of bounds.
Mr. Gore, who announced in Carthage, Tenn., on Wednesday, and Mr. Bush, who did so in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, last Saturday, spoke as if they were using the same pollsters and at least some of the same speechwriters. 
 There were major structural differences, to be sure. In Carthage, Mr. Gore had dozens of quite specific proposals, both because that is the sort of person he is, and because he wanted to contrast his experience with Mr. Bush's. Mr. Gore described himself as "a leader who has been tested." In Cedar Rapids, Mr. Bush said that the time had not come for "10-point plans" and that he knew being Governor of Texas "isn't the same as being President."
Mr. Bush has one singular reason to avoid specifics early: There is a large Republican field ready to pick his proposals apart.
Even though they did not engage over detail, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush were fighting over much of the same ground. Both opposed drugs in schools. Both promised to involve religious organizations in social welfare programs. Both supported foreign trade.
More generally, Mr. Gore boasted that "America now has the strongest economy in the history of the United States," but said that was not enough, but merely a foundation from which to "make family life work in America, for the issue is not only our standard of living, but our standards in life."
Mr. Bush, while saying the Clinton Administration "did not invent prosperity any more than they invented the Internet," said American prosperity had to amount to more than "simple materialism."
"Prosperity must have a greater purpose," he said. It has to provide "men and women who work hard, dream big, love their family, serve their neighbor."
The announcement speech used to be the one occasion when a would-be President could count on getting his message of why he should be President out, relatively undiluted by analysis of his motives or chances.
That exposure is less certain today, in large part because candidates seek to have so many bites of the political apple: announcing an intention to form an exploratory committee, announcing the committee, announcing the plan to announce and the announcement itself.
Indeed, Mr. Bush tried to reserve a later bite last Saturday. Even though he said, "I am running for President; there is no turning back," he also maintained, "I'll have a formal announcement sometime in the fall."
But an announcement speech still offers an opportunity to define a campaign, as Ronald Reagan did in 1979 when he quoted John Winthrop's line in establishing the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1630, "We shall be as a city upon a hill," and promised to lead the nation out of the pessimism he accused President Jimmy Carter of inflicting upon it. Or as George McGovern did in promising in 1971 to withdraw every American soldier from Vietnam, or as Bill Clinton did in 1991 saying he would "fight for the forgotten middle class."
Not only each candidate, but each kind of candidacy, has a formula.
Announcing a challenge to an incumbent of one's own party, as Mr. Reagan did in 1975 and Edward M. Kennedy did in 1979, requires saying the President has failed his party's ideal. Running against the other party's President if the economy is strong requires a speech so good no one -- certainly not Walter F. Mondale in 1983 or Bob Dole in 1995 -- has written it yet.
But the demands of running when a Vice President of an Administration with a successful economy seeks to succeed a President whose popularity is wearing thin are special -- and both speeches in the last few days owe a lot to the announcement speech of the last Vice President in such a situation, George H.W. Bush.
For example, though Mr. Gore used the word "Clinton" but twice, Vice President Bush said "Reagan" only once. Both Vice Presidents bragged on the economy.
Just as Vice President Bush was running against "an economy buffeted by incompetence and intrusion" he said Mr. Carter left behind seven years before, Vice President Gore recalled "deep recession and high unemployment," and said, "We remember what it was like seven years ago and I never want to go back."
Mr. Gore tried to distance himself from the worst part of his Administration's image, his President's scandals, by promising to use the nation's "moral leadership to fight for America's families." He said, "I will take my own values of faith and family to the Presidency."
Vice President Bush confronted the worst of the Reagan Administration's image when he said: "Where is it written that Republicans must act as if they do not care, as if they are not moved? I say to my fellow Republicans: We are the party of Lincoln. Our whole history was protecting those who needed our protection and making this a kinder nation."
Mr. Bush's son played against the Republican image, too, when he defended his own commitment to "compassionate conservatism," and asked: "Is compassion beneath us? Is mercy below us? Should our party be led by someone who boasts a hard heart? I know Republicans -- across the country -- are generous of heart."
There were other, perhaps familial, similarities. Governor Bush said "prosperity must have a purpose." His father had said "prosperity with a purpose means giving back to the country that has given you so much." The younger Mr. Bush said, "I'm running hard." The elder Mr. Bush said, "I mean to run hard."
Both Bushes and Mr. Gore, to give a message of inclusiveness, spoke a few words in Spanish.
Differences of approach will indeed become clearer as Governor Bush's policies become clearer. The most precise promise he made in his announcement speech was to see to it that Head Start, the preschool program for poor children, would "teach our youngest children phonics," the method of teaching reading that relies on the sounds of letters.
But there was a distinct difference in their attitudes toward the role of Government, though not the chasm that exists between the caricatures each party sketches of the other.
Governor Bush said, "Government can help" make schools safer and make examples of bad behavior. He said, "Government should do a few things and do them well."
And though Vice President Gore said no legislation and no President could replace parents as moral guides to their children, he offered a list of things Government should do to make life easier for families. He proposed:
*"Making high-quality preschool available to every child in every community all across the United States of America."
*Expanding "community policing, with more cops walking the beat."
*Amending the family leave law so parents could leave work for parent-teacher meetings and children's medical appointments.
*Enacting a patients' bill of rights.
*Helping "seniors pay for the prescription drugs they need."
Mr. Gore has 15 proposals for Government action in his speech.
Other Republican Presidential contenders have struck more combative, ideologically charged notes in their announcement speeches. Patrick Buchanan, the conservative commentator, urged his followers to "mount up and ride to the sound of guns," while vowing to protect the rights "of the innocent unborn." Gary Bauer, another conservative, announced his candidacy shortly after the school shootings in Littleton, Colo., and said American culture "glorifies death in a thousand ways."
Former Vice President Dan Quayle also cited the culture wars. Referring to a speech he gave as Vice President, in which he lambasted the values of American popular culture, Mr. Quayle noted, "Murphy Brown is gone and I'm still here fighting for the American family."
Mr. Gore's only Democratic opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley, has not given a formal announcement speech but has tackled broad subjects like race in his appearances. His stands on most issues do not contrast sharply with Mr. Gore's.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: RUSSIA;
Uncertainty Persists on U.S.-Moscow Dialogue

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: COLOGNE, Germany, June 19

 BODY:
When the Clinton Administration invited Russia to help it out of the war in Kosovo, the idea was that the involvement in big game diplomacy would help maintain Washington-Moscow ties, and even improve the ailing relationship.
But now, as President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia is about to make his first foreign trip in four months on Sunday and to meet here with President Clinton, as many -- if not more -- questions are hanging over the dialogue as were before the war. 
 The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said here on Friday that relations with Russia had been "strained" by NATO's air strikes against Yugoslavia but now were "reinforced" by Russia's participation in the peace settlement.
But as Mr. Berger left a briefing room after making those remarks, he pretended not to hear a question about the likelihood of Mr. Yeltsin's actually turning up in Cologne. The last time the Russian leader was abroad, for the funeral of King Hussein of Jordan in February, he cut his stay to about an hour, apparently because of illness. "No, I didn't hear it," Mr. Berger said of the query.
In some ways, by declining to answer, Mr. Berger appeared to summarize the uncertainties of the Washington-Moscow relationship, which was most recently buffeted by three days of intense arguments in Helsinki, Finland, over where and how Russian troops should operate in Kosovo.
The resolution of the Russian troop issue on Friday night was a relief for the Administration. But it remains to be seen how the plan for the dispersal of Russian troops in Kosovo will be accepted in Moscow, where politicians and the public alike felt humiliated by the NATO air strikes and where the Kosovo peace settlement orchestrated by Viktor S. Chernomyrdin was assailed as a sell-out.
Russia's Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, said at the signing ceremony in Helsinki that the agreement on the troops would benefit overall American-Russian relations. But the dispatch of Russian troops from Bosnia to the Pristina airport in the dead of night exactly a week earlier -- apparently without Mr. Ivanov's knowledge -- showed that the Foreign Minister does not always speak for all of the Russian Government.
Over all, the Russians won concessions in the way their forces will interact with NATO in Kosovo, including 16 Russian liaison officers in the field and a Russian as commander of the Pristina airport. A senior Administration official said today that the agreement gave "more broadly national Russian control" over the Russian troops than in Bosnia, where Russians also serve with NATO. If disagreements develop beyond day-to-day tactics, the Russians can dissent, the official said.
The Helsinki agreement states that "all command arrangements will preserve the principle of unity of command." But unlike the arrangement in Bosnia, the paragraph in the Helsinki accord on unity of command adds, "This presumes that the Russian side exercises full political and military control over the Russian contingent."
The Administration was eager to have the peacekeeping dispute resolved before Mr. Yeltsin's arrival here at the conference of the seven major industrialized nations and Russia, thus giving what a senior Administration official described as a "reasonable prospect of getting the core parts of the relationship back on track."
But one inescapable issue for Washington is the flagging health of Mr. Yeltsin, in whom the Administration has vested much. Asked several weeks ago whether Mr. Yeltsin would make it to the meeting in Cologne, a Russian diplomat deadpanned: "He's transportable."
The decision-making process in Russia, never crystal clear, has also become even murkier of late.
"There are deep questions in Russia, now penetrating the Administration, about Yeltsin's mental as well as physical health," said Thomas Graham, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and a former American diplomat who served in Moscow until 10 months ago.
"He is more unreliable and erratic than he was three or four months ago. There are a lot of doubts about whether he can make the flight and then function effectively for three to four hours."
Assuming that Mr. Yeltsin does arrive in Cologne, Administration officials say they will be dealing with a leader whose attitude toward the West is now pressed by increased anti-Western feelings at home.
A stark example of the anti-NATO sentiment from usually pro-Western quarters came from Boris Fyodorov, the former chief of the Federal Tax Service. Mr. Fyodorov, who helped organize a petition to stop NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia, said of the alliance, "Nobody can assume the role of a policeman to the universe, to murder people in the name of human rights."
For reformist Russian politicians who favored Russia's becoming a member of the Joint Permanent Council, an adjunct to NATO where Russia is consulted, the war in Kosovo has been a souring experience. Their argument for Russian participation in the Permanent Council was based on the notion that NATO was a defensive, not an offensive, alliance. "Those Russians feel burned," a senior Administration official said.
To try to re-energize the relationship with Moscow, President Clinton met this afternoon with the new Russian Prime Minister, Sergei V. Stepashin. Before doing so, in keeping with the Administration's disposition to lavish praise on new Russian leaders who may be open to Washington, Mr. Clinton said through an aide that he was "extremely impressed" by the Prime Minister. The two met with other leaders at dinner tonight.
With Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton plans to raise a longstanding menu of standard issues, officials said. These are arms control, economic reforms and nonproliferation, in particular what Washington argues is Moscow's continued transfer of sensitive nuclear technology to Iran.
On arms control, Washington will continue to press for the passage of the Start II treaty and will explain again the rationale for President Clinton's announcement in the State of Union address that the United States would pursue a national missile defense system. Moscow has objected to Mr. Clinton's proposal on the ground that it would violate the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.
"These are difficult issues arising at a bad time in American-Russian relations," Mr. Graham said of arms control. "Russia needs to do it for financial reasons, but Russia can't for domestic reasons."
On economic progress in Russia, the picture is not so bleak, Administration officials said. Mr. Stepashin is moving on bank restructuring, a key demand of the International Monetary Fund. "There is a sense that Russia has played, over all, a constructive role," one official said. "People are going to want to be forward-leaning and helpful, but in a responsible way."
In essence, this means that the International Monetary Fund will probably be prepared to release the first installment of a $4.5 billion loan next month, the official said. The managing director of the fund, Michel Camdessus, praised Russia this week for improved tax collections, a slowing of inflation and an increase in business activity.
If the first installment is released, there is a "common understanding" among the seven industrialized nations here, the official said, that scheduled Russian debt payments of $5.5 billion should be deferred to the end of next year.
But no decision was reached here about what to do in the longer term with Russia's total debt of $155 billion, officials said.
As for the continued transfer of nuclear technology, the United States has placed sanctions on about a dozen institutes in Russia that the Administration contends have been involved in sending scientists and selling nuclear know-how to Iran. These sanctions prevent the institutions from doing business with the United States.
This issue is one of the most difficult, American officials said, because Washington cannot understand why Moscow would want to have nearby Iran become a nuclear power. It is also difficult, officials said, to determine whether the sale of the technology to Iran is Government policy or is yet another example of the breakdown of Government control in Russia that allows economic fiefs left over from the Communist era to do what they want.

LENGTH: 1272 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: AID;
Kosovars to Get European Help For Rebuilding

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: COLOGNE, Germany, June 19

 BODY:
The European Union today announced plans to provide $1.5 billion during the next three years for the reconstruction of Kosovo as the West tried to map out a strategy that would channel money to the war-devastated area without giving financial support to a Serbia controlled by Slobodan Milosevic.
Gunter Burghardt, the director-general for the European Union's Balkan policy, said the 15-nation bloc would provide $500 million annually over three years to Kosovo "irrespective of whether Milosevic is there or not." He added that the Yugoslav President, indicted by the international war crimes tribunal last month, had to be isolated. 
 "We have to get rid of the source of the cancer that has been spreading throughout the region over the past eight years," Mr. Burghardt, "That means we have to isolate Mr. Milosevic and put democratic institutions in his place."
But on the second day of a summit meeting of the seven leading industrialized countries and Russia, sharp differences emerged between Moscow and the West on whether any aid should be given to Serbia following NATO's 11-week bombardment.
Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser, indicated that Russian objections had foiled plans to include in the group's final communique on Sunday a statement that no funds for reconstruction would be given to Serbia as long as Mr. Milosevic was in power.
"I believe the communique probably, therefore, will not address the issue," he said, adding, "I don't know whether the Russians would agree to a statement that money would not go to Serbia as long as Milosevic is there."
The dispute illustrated the ways in which Kosovo continues to complicate relations between Washington and Moscow and suggested that the agendas pursued by NATO and Russian forces in the province may not always be identical or even similar.
The European Union's announcement came on a day that leaders devoted largely to Kosovo and possible financial support for the debt-ridden Russian economy. Russia's Prime Minister, Sergei V. Stepashin, is also attending the talks, and President Boris N. Yeltsin is expected to arrive on Sunday.
French officials said Mr. Stepashin, who took office last month, had argued forcefully for aid for Serbia, saying that the conduct of Mr. Milosevic could not be allowed to prejudice millions of Serbs. Other officials said Italy, whose relations with Belgrade are better than those of most Western powers, had given some support to the Russian position, arguing that the Serbian people should not be collectively punished.
Russia's broad support for its traditional Orthodox Christian Serbian allies has been strong throughout the Kosovo war, but tempered by the fact that Mr. Yeltsin has no personal affection for Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Berger said: "We will not take part in a reconstruction program so long as Mr. Milosevic is the President of Yugoslavia." But he added that the United States would be prepared to participate in limited programs of what he called "humanitarian assistance" to Serbia through the United Nations, the Red Cross or other agencies.
It was clear today that a sea change has occurred since the 1995 Dayton peace for Bosnia, reached with Mr. Milosevic's help. There is a decisively new level of outrage against the Serbian leader.
But the exact direction of policy toward Mr. Milosevic still appeared unclear. Aggressive financial aid for Kosovo, while largely isolating the rest of Serbia as long as he remains in power, presents several difficulties, Western officials said.
These include the fact that Kosovo formally remains part of Serbia, that it has no independent financial institutions capable of negotiating for loans, that its long border with the rest of Serbia is likely to be porous, and that it cannot indefinitely survive in institutional limbo.
It may also prove extremely difficult to help Montenegro, the other surviving republic in today's truncated Yugoslavia, while avoiding support for Mr. Milosevic. The West has indicated that it wants to accentuate the isolation of the Serbian leader by supporting Montenegro's democratically inclined government.
Another problem is that it may prove extremely difficult to draw a line between the emergency aid for food, medicine and shelter that the United States today indicated a willingness to give to Serbia, and the kind of broad support for reconstruction and development that Washington wants to avoid as long as Mr. Milosevic is in power.
"There is a very important distinction to be drawn between human assistance and reconstruction," Mr. Berger said, "but where the line lies is not self-evident."
He added that food "was on one side of the line and rebuilding industry or their basic infrastructure is on the other side of the line." But he asked: "Is getting electric lights back on for the winter humanitarian, or is it reconstruction?" He said he did not know the answer.
Britain took a harder position than the United States today, saying it would not take part in a financial aid program of any kind to Serbia as long as Mr. Milosevic was in power. Charities could provide any necessary emergency assistance, British officials said.
Mr. Burghardt said that the European Union had decided to set up a special agency to deal with aid for the Balkans and that a special international donors' conference for Kosovo would be convened in July on emergency assistance, with another later this year on more detailed aid.
Joly Dixon, a senior European Union financial official, said financial support would be concentrated on Kosovo in a first stage, to be followed by other countries affected by the war and finally the Balkan region as a whole.
The Clinton Administration official said teams from the United States were already in Kosovo assessing needs for the first conference in July. Between July and the fall, he added, there would be "a more intensive effort involving the World Bank, the European Union and others."
Just how much the United States will spend on Kosovo reconstruction remains unclear, although Europe has indicated that it will bear most of the burden. In Bosnia, more than $5 billion was pledged over four years, with Europe paying more than half. But actual payments proved slow, holding back reconstruction.
It was clear in the leaders' discussions today that for the first time since the wars of Yugoslavia's destruction began eight years ago, the West has decided to approach the crisis in the Balkans in a broad way.
After a long period of hesitation, the specific prospect of membership in the European Union has been held out to Croatia, Bosnia, Macedonia, Albania and Yugoslavia itself, providing that democracy and a market economy are convincingly installed.
But just how stability can be reached while Kosovo's status and future remain so vague was an issue that none of the western powers appeared inclined to address today. In effect, the West has decided to help the province as if it were independent while adhering to a policy that says such independence will not be granted.
The leaders also devoted sometime today to the question of who should occupy the pivotal top civilian post in Kosovo, without taking a decision.
In effect, the official, to be known as the Special Representative of the United Nations Secretary General, will be a kind of pro-consul in a province marked by an extraordinary administrative void.
Among the tasks facing the administrator will be coordination and channeling of the various forms of assistance now being offered by the West, and the delicate management of any relations with Belgrade.

HEADLINE: Conde Nast's Stylish Clan Moves Into Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
With the coordination of an invading army, Conde Nast has begun moving its glossy fashion magazines into a new home at 4 Times Square, the first skyscraper built in New York City since 1992.
On Friday, workers began trundling 50 truckloads of computers, printers, files, photographs, fashion accessories and sports gear for Bride's, House and Garden, and Women's Sports and Fitness from their old office at 350 Madison Avenue to the 1.6 million-square-foot tower on Broadway, between 42d and 43d Streets. 
 Nearly 200 employees will sit down tomorrow in their new modular offices. And over the next two months, they will be joined by 400 more truckloads of equipment and 1,800 colleagues from Vanity Fair, Allure, Glamour, Self, GQ, The New Yorker and the other magazines that make up the Conde Nast empire.
Eventually, Conde Nast will inhabit floors 4 through 23 in the 48-story office tower in a once-seedy district that is now home to Viacom, Bertelsmann A.G. and Morgan Stanley. (Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the largest law firm in the city, is scheduled to take over the top half of the tower by Thanksgiving.) For the first time in decades, S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Conde Nast Publications, has brought together the 17 sleek and sometimes fractious magazines that chronicle the culture and the well-paid and carefully coiffed people of our times.
"We're all preparing to live in harmony," said James Truman, the Conde Nast editorial director, who oversaw the three-year project, "or at least under the same roof."
Real estate and construction experts estimate that Conde Nast spent $100 million on its new space. Investment banks usually set the gold standard for lavish decor; for example, when Salomon Brothers moved into 7 World Trade Center in the early 90's, estimates of its spending ran to $250 a square foot. Mr. Newhouse averaged half that figure, although he pulled out all the stops when it came to the company's cafeteria, where, executives said, spending exceeded $400 a square foot.
Mr. Newhouse hired the architect Frank O. Gehry to design a highly stylized cafeteria, with wavy walls of blue titanium and cloudlike Venetian glass panels that enclose seating areas. Mr. Gehry and the glassmakers spent a year figuring out how to bend and stretch the glass in three dimensions. Four private dining rooms and an 85-seat auditorium adjoin the cafeteria, which will not open until early next year.
Since Conde Nast signed a deal for the building nearly three years ago, Times Square has become one of the most sought-after commercial neighborhoods in the city. Reuters recently started work on its new headquarters across from 4 Times Square, and Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, is close to a deal to build its own tower nearby. ABC's "Good Morning America" plans to open a street-front studio in September at 1500 Broadway.
Conde Nast will be moving from its old-money environs on the East Side, within easy reach of Brooks Brothers, Paul Stuart and Patroon, to the hurly-burly of Times Square.
"It's a vital area that has the kind of energy we associate with our magazines," Mr. Newhouse said. "The ambiance of that neighborhood suits us just fine."
It was Douglas Durst, the developer of 4 Times Square, who persuaded Conde Nast to make the move. In 1996, Mr. Durst put together the land for the project and gambled that if he built the first office tower since the recession of the early 1990's, it would quickly fill up.
Mr. Truman, the editorial director, said Conde Nast had a choice of either leaving its longtime home on Madison Avenue for a year while the space there was renovated, or moving permanently to a new building. The company chose to bring the magazines, scattered among six buildings, into the same tower.
He said he and the design firm of Mancini Duffy briefly considered the kind of alternative office pioneered by accounting firms in which each employee is assigned a personal locker, a portable telephone and a computer on wheels. Instead, they decided on what Mr. Truman described as a democratic approach to space that would encourage teamwork and provide an element of privacy.
The design might better be described as an architectural version of George Orwell's "Animal Farm," in which some people are more equal than others. Instead of giving all the window space to ranking executives, the company has decided to let many employees labor at metallic blue workstations near the windows.
At the next level up the ladder, most editors and writers who were not relegated to workstations were consigned to interior offices with glass doors.
Mr. Newhouse's office is in the middle of the Conde Nast space, on the 11th floor rather than the 23d.
But the publisher and editor in chief of each magazine still get the trappings of rank: a corner, or near-corner, office with windows.
Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair, whose current offices at 350 Madison Avenue are the envy of the company, brought in his own architect, Basil Walter, to insure that his new space will look exactly like his old office, which was renovated by the same designer four years ago. He then insisted on a feng shui ceremony to improve the spiritual environment.
Some editors and writers complained about the corporate look of the decor at 4 Times Square and the glass doors on their offices. One top editor has refused to even visit 4 Times Square before moving in. Another expressed trepidation about moving to a building that has been plagued by construction accidents, including a scaffolding collapse last summer in which an elderly woman was killed.
But many employees of the newer magazines embraced the opportunity to join their colleagues under a single roof.
"We're thrilled," said Lucy Danziger, editor in chief of Women's Sports and Fitness, which will be leaving cramped quarters on Madison. "There's a gorgeous art department and space for kayaks, bikes and the other stuff we have."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Van Gundy Sits Atop N.B.A., But He Doesn't Realize It Yet

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THIS was at one of those off-day news conferences in San Antonio the other day, the coach of the Knicks being asked, once again, if he felt personally vindicated by making it all the way to the N.B.A. finals after being one Miami bounce of the ball from the unemployment line.
Jeff Van Gundy tried to say the right thing, to be the polished diplomat, but the longer he went on, the more the victim lurking inside him cried out to be heard. 
 "One thing you get used to, if they can get you on results, they get you on results," he said. "If they can't get you on results, they get you on relationships. So they're going to get you on something."
Sitting in the front row, without intending to, I found myself blurting out, 'Who is 'they?' "
Van Gundy suddenly looked like the napping kid in the back of the class, called on to explain the theory of relativity.
"Just in general," he stammered. "I mean, whoever -- just to be -- whoever is being critical of you. We'll just leave it at whoever. That sounds better."
Actually, it sounded absurd.
With all this talk of people out to "get" Van Gundy, does he not yet get what has happened here? Nobody got him and nobody except Tim Duncan and David Robinson is going to. Whether or not the Knicks can rally in this series against San Antonio after losing Game 2, 80-67, Friday night, Van Gundy is walking out of this season with the Life of Riley, with a huge financial score for making the finals, with the highest of leaguewide profiles.
The Knicks, on the other hand, have no enviable coaching option to turn to.
While Van Gundy's band played on, Paul Silas was re-signing in Charlotte, Doc Rivers was taking over in Orlando and Phil Jackson was ditching O'Hare for O'Neal, Bradley for Bryant. The way this tumultuous National Basketball Association season has unfolded is reminiscent of a messy Bill Clinton script.
Van Gundy has come out of the pileup of organization egos looking clean and starched, like his former boss. Everyone else has been indicted for something, except Ernie Grunfeld, who was fired.
Months ago, Van Gundy was just an insecure coach with an unfamiliar cast. Dave Checketts and Grunfeld might have saved themselves big trouble by telling Van Gundy he was not going to be judged on what he did with new players in a short season. Nonetheless, the way it has worked out, Grunfeld is the only one here with the right to say, "If they can't get you on results, they get you on relationships."
Playing the good corporate soldier, Checketts fired his "close friend" over dinner and then publicly threw himself to the news media wolves for not telling the truth about a meeting he had to take with Jackson. Marcus Camby has convinced himself that Van Gundy cost him millions on the contract he signed during his too-soft exile, and maybe he's right. Even Patrick Ewing has lost out while Van Gundy gained. Ewing was overworked early when he was out of shape, because the coach wasn't about to let the general manager "get" him for losing games with players he didn't trust, or want.
If he wasn't pushed in February, maybe Ewing is out on the floor now, defending the low post, pump-faking Duncan into a few early fouls and making this series a fairer fight. Through it all, Ewing remained a Van Gundy man, forgetting that Checketts twice unloaded bundles of cash into Ewing's account when he might have taken a harder negotiating tack.
Van Gundy has done a splendid job, steering his team through the post-season. No argument there. He beat Pat Riley and Lenny Wilkens, then coached the legend right out of Larry Bird. He was right on using Latrell Sprewell off the bench, no matter how reasonable Sprewell sounds promoting his point. But Van Gundy was better cast last season as the underdog from the fast-food drive-through, when Riley slandered him in a fruitless attempt to fire up his troops. Now Van Gundy is a full-time operator and a big-time coach. He has confided to people that he isn't terribly proud of the political games he has played this season, but he did play them, and played them well.
Grunfeld lost. Van Gundy should junk the conspiracy line. Checketts is boxed in. Camby and Sprewell are under contract. Whatever they are saying privately, at least they have been perfect gentlemen when reporters have asked about the coach. Van Gundy sounds more like a myopic player when he answers "whoever" to the "who is they" question.
Players will admit they made the wrong defensive read, a foolish pass, but when they look at the big picture, they mostly see what they wish to. The coach should know better. Next season is not the issue right now but it eventually will be, perhaps by the end of the week. It wouldn't kill Van Gundy and wouldn't hurt his standing with Camby, to name one Knick, if he just once came out and admitted that he didn't cover himself with glory back in February and March. Even if the Knicks go out in four or five against the Spurs, Van Gundy has already won. Now all he has to do is act like a winner.
