HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;
Just How Minor Should a Minor League Baseball Club Be?

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES

 BODY:
Brooklyn started to look a little ungrateful to City Hall last Monday, when the city began the long process of public approval for a new Coney Island minor league stadium.
But even before the first hearing, Borough President Howard Golden and his allies stepped up their attack on the plan, saying the stadium and a Class A baseball club were not good enough for Brooklyn. 
 Mark S. Rosentraub, the author of a new study commissioned by Mr. Golden, argues that New York City is large enough to support a more advanced minor league team in addition to its two major league clubs and the Staten Island Yankees, a new minor league franchise. The Mets have offered to bring a short-season Class A team to Brooklyn, but it would play only 38 home games, about 30 fewer than most minor league teams. A Class AAA, or top-level, club would bring in thousands of additional fans and an additional $1.3 million to $3.8 million in revenues to Coney Island, the report said.
"Brooklyn just doesn't want the smallest crumbs on the table," said Mr. Rosentraub, who is a professor at Indiana University and an expert on the economics of baseball.
If only to get a more advanced Mets team, Mr. Golden wants the city to entertain offers from other professional teams, unaffiliated with the majors, that play a longer season. (Teams that are affiliated with major league franchises are not likely candidates; the Mets and Yankees can and probably will veto a move to the city by such affiliates.)
"Brooklyn must get the best team possible," Mr. Golden said.
But city officials fear that a team unaffiliated with the major leagues might not last long. They also note that a Brooklyn Class A team would play in the same league as the Class A Staten Island Yankees, creating cross-Narrows rivalry.
Moreover, said Curt Ritter, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, "The Borough President should realize Brooklyn has been without Major League baseball for 40 years, and the fact that the Mets will come to Coney Island is an historic event."
Despite Mr. Golden's objections, the city's Parks Department and Economic Development Corporation are proceeding with their plan. They held the hearing last Monday to gather comments before the city starts an environmental review of the stadium project.
Most audience members, many of whom were Mr. Golden's appointees to Community Board 13 in Coney Island, spoke out against the stadium. They argued that it could derail an amateur athletic facility, called Sportsplex, that is proposed for the same site. That project, which would incorporate a minor league park, would create more jobs and benefit Coney Island more than the stadium alone, they said.
"The Sportsplex offers us jobs and good economic development," said Marcey Feigenbaum, a community board member. "The stadium offers us nothing."
But city officials said the complex and the stadium were not mutually exclusive. "Sportsplex can still happen," said Joshua R. Laird, director of planning for the Parks Department. "There is room."
 JULIAN E. BARNES

HEADLINE: Planning Our Population

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A June 13 editorial rightly salutes the family planning campaigns in Mexico and Colombia, which were aided by the Agency for International Development, the International Planned Parenthood Federation and the United Nations Population Fund. 
 Not all Latin American countries are as fortunate. In Guatemala, where the Government is less supportive of family planning, only 27 percent of women use modern contraception (compared with 56 percent in Mexico), and the average woman has about five children. As a result, the population in Guatemala -- where land is already scarce -- is projected to double or triple in the next 50 years.
To preserve human rights and regional stability, it would be wise and cost-effective for Congress to increase spending on international family planning and reproductive health.
 
FREDERICK MEYERSON
New Haven, June 15, 1999
 
The writer is project director at the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy.

HEADLINE: Planning Our Population

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your June 13 editorial "Latin America's Birth Surprise" underscores the critical importance of family planning worldwide. 
 Right now, about a billion people living in the developing world are in the prime childbearing years of ages 15 to 24. There are two billion more future parents right behind them.
Reproductive health services are among the most cost-effective ways to stabilize the world's health and economy. But international powers, including the United States, are failing to give enough aid to developing countries for them to keep pace with the growing need for voluntary family planning services.
The reproductive decisions that adolescents worldwide make will have a profound impact on the health of our planet, the availability of global resources and everyone's quality of life. We need to give all young people access to the information and services they need to make responsible choices about sex and reproduction.
 
GLORIA FELDT
President, Planned Parenthood Federation of America
New York, June 14, 1999

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
Duncan, a No-Frills Guy Who's Beyond His Years

BYLINE: By Mike Wise

 BODY:
On most road trips, Tim Duncan packs the toys of choice for the Y2K pro athlete: a DVD movie player and a Sony PlayStation. He likes current cinema and mindless video games, often killing time on the team plane with the young reserve point guard Antonio Daniels.
Yet every so often, an elder teammate will test his 23-year-old frame of reference. 
 Last month, for example, the veteran center Will Perdue recommended that Duncan and Daniels check out a sappy basketball movie made in the mid-1970's: "One on One," starring Robby Benson.
"They were like, 'What's 'One on One' and who's Robby Benson?' " Perdue said. "So we brought it on the plane flying to Minnesota. And they were like, 'Hey, that was pretty good.'
"Well, nobody got shot. Nobody got killed," Perdue said. "And they didn't wreck 50 cars."
They merely played basketball. What a concept.
Duncan is dominating these National Basketball Association finals, playing the game that time forgot. He uses power dribbles to move closer to the rim. He faces up his defender from 18 feet away on the wing and uses the glass to bank in shots. He uses his reach to pass to teammates cutting through the lane. He has this pretty little jump hook that is beginning to look Waltonesque.
It is an interesting dichotomy: the old-school mind controlling and nurturing a Generation X body. There are no frills to Duncan's game, no death stares after a blocked shot and no scowls after a monster dunk. In San Antonio's victories against the Knicks in the first two games, and throughout the playoffs, he has used an economy of movement and emotion.
Through circumstance and constant work, in two remarkable years he has become the game's best player. It is the kind of achievement that would usually establish a player as the example to emulate: the lanky kid from the Virgin Islands who decided to stay at Wake Forest for his senior year instead of entering the N.B.A. draft early.
And yet at a time when Commissioner David Stern is considering an age requirement for players entering the N.B.A. -- and 19-year-old Lamar Odom is confused about whether to stay or go -- Duncan is still an anomaly.
Teen-agers still want the money they have been told is owed to them by their needy support groups and families. Simply, the chance to be the Kevin Garnett of today outweighs the patience and reward of being the Duncan of tomorrow.
The single largest problem in the N.B.A. today is that young kids enter the league with a sense of entitlement, the idea that they are owed something because their university used their number on a jersey at the campus bookstore and they were not compensated for it.
Duncan did not attend an Adidas or Nike camp for gifted basketball players when he was 15 years old. He did not participate in the cattle call that most American kids are in each summer for the college and pro scouts that are salivating over their talent.
He swam in high school, took up basketball late and enjoyed the fruits of college rather than go to work right away. And when he did enter the N.B.A., he worked harder on his game than on his image.
This is the player he has become.
"Whether it's guard or forward or center, I have yet to see a guy in this age of the game that's come into the league with such fundamental soundness," Perdue said. "A lot of teams, they draft the best athlete and work on their games. In Tim's case, he was the best player and the best athlete."
In this lockout-scarred season, some of the best reasons to celebrate the game rather than denigrate it has been the transformation of young, disconnected knuckleheads into fearless competitors with passion and purpose. Whether it's Allen Iverson in the East or Jason Williams and Chris Webber out West, their scintillating play has forced Stern to view them as bona fide stars for the millennium.
Duncan, standing taller than the rest, leads the contingent. As Year 1 of the post-Michael era ends, Duncan is displaying all the qualities that made people once pay incredible attention to the game.
There are, of course, marketing kinks to work out in the future. Duncan is as quiet and introverted as he is good. Some of his teammates have taken to calling him the silent assassin. At the moment, he is not inducing any bidding war for his likeness on Madison Avenue. Maybe another week in the national spotlight and a title can change that.
Either way, he is keeping amazing perspective during heady times. According to Perdue, while Duncan has been helping save the league with his old-school game, he has also managed to keep his Gen-X priorities in order.
"He seems to be very grounded," Perdue said. "I've been with him for over two years now, and he never seems to get overjoyed about anything -- except about maybe kicking somebody's behind in Sony PlayStation. He does take a lot of pride in that."

HEADLINE: Gore: 'There Is a Hunger And Thirst for Goodness'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Vice President Al Gore's speech announcing his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President, on June 16 in Carthage, Tenn., as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service: 
 Under the policies President Clinton and I have proposed, instead of the biggest deficits in history, we now have the biggest surpluses in history. Instead of quadrupling our national debt, we have seen the creation of almost 19 million new jobs. Instead of a deep recession and high unemployment, America now has our strongest economy in the history of the United States.
We remember what it was like seven years ago, and I never ever want to go back. America always looks forward to the next horizon. I want to keep our prosperity going, and I know how to do it. I want to do it the right way, not by letting people fend for themselves or hoping for crumbs of compassion, but by giving people the skills and knowledge to succeed in their own right . . . .
But as important as prosperity is, there is more to long for. There is a hunger and thirst for goodness among us. Just visible within a generation's journey is a new horizon, a 21st-century America with stronger families, stronger communities and a more vital democracy in which we live and govern according to our highest American ideals. . . .
And so today, I ask you to join with me to keep our economy growing, and bring a new wave of fundamental change to this nation, starting with revolutionary improvements in our public schools. I ask you to join with me to build safe and livable communities where we protect our environment and restore the quality of life we deserve.
I ask for your help to strengthen family life in America, and I make you this pledge: If you entrust me with the Presidency, I will marshal its authority, its resources and its moral leadership to fight for America's families. With your help, I will take my own values of faith and family to the Presidency, to build an America that is not only better off but better. And that is why today I announce that I am candidate for President of the United States. . . .
Seven years ago, we needed to put America back to work, and we did. . . . We have closed our budget deficit. But today we find a deficit of even greater danger, one that only seems to deepen the harder we work and the better we do. These are our deficits now:
The time deficit in family life.
The decency deficit in our common culture.
The care deficit for our little ones and our elderly parents.
Our families are loving, but overstretched. . . . The crisis in the American family today knows no boundary of class or race. It is a challenge we share together, and it is one we must overcome together.
One of the best ways to help American families is by making America's public schools the finest in the world. With your help, I will bring revolutionary improvement to our public schools. And I will start by making high-quality preschool available to every child . . . .
With your help, I will reduce class sizes and establish high standards and accountability. I will make it easier for parents to save for college tuition tax free and inflation free. I will improve teacher quality and treat teachers like professionals.
We have to have schools that instill the values and character we need in the next generation. And every school in America has to be drug-free and gun-free. . . .
We must also expand community policing, with more cops walking the beat. It's not enough to support the death penalty, which I do; we must also give police new crime-fighting tools to track every lead, catch every criminal and protect every citizen.
And families deserve refuge from a culture of violence and mayhem. I will work to give parents the ability to protect their children from the marketing of cruelty and degradation. Parents also deserve help balancing work and family. I want to bring after-school programs to every community in America. And no parent should have to risk losing a job to go to a parent-teacher conference at school or to drive a child or an aging parent to the doctor. And I will expand the Family and Medical Leave Act to make sure that we do just that. . . .
All these policy choices are important, but let's remember this: No executive action can mend a broken family; no legislation can reconnect a parent to a child or a family to a grandparent. No policy proposal can change a culture that does not place family life at the top of our hierarchy of values, where it belongs.
And so today I say to every parent in America, it is our own lives we must master if we are to have the moral authority to guide our children. The ultimate outcome does not rest in the hands of any President, but with all our people taking responsibility for themselves and for each other. So my first promise is to ask you, each of you, to fulfill that American promise.

HEADLINE: Hopes and Fears of the Class of '99

 BODY:
In Westchester, the class of '99 has many faces. Here is what some of its members had to say when interviewed by Elsa Brenner.
 
Looking for a Role In Local Politics
 
WHO -- Jeremy Weinberg, 17, New Rochelle High School. 

ACHIEVEMENTS -- President of the school's chapter of the National Honor Society, member of high school's model congress, writer of poetry for the school literary publication Opus.
 
AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to enroll at Cornell University and major in policy analysis and management. I want to study government, economics and sociology with the goal of one day playing an active role in local politics."
 
THE BEST -- "The best part of high school was the kinship I developed with my classmates and, perhaps more important, my teachers. Shared interests and a collective desire to excel transformed many of my classrooms into settings that resembled a family home more than a place of learning. It was an amazing experience to learn and grow with a group of others."
 
THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was having to see peers of mine who lacked the desire and motivation to care about what they were doing. It was difficult for me to accept that some people cannot be made to take pride in achieving in the classroom. I always hate to see people who have no passion for anything."
 
THE UNEXPECTED -- "What surprised me the most in my high school experience would probably have to be my school's reaction to the verdict in the O. J. Simpson trial. Many people expected that a school as ethnically diverse as New Rochelle High School would erupt at the climax of a racially charged event like that trial. However, there was a great amount of peace after the verdict was announced. It was quite a pleasant surprise."
 
WHAT IF? -- "If I could change anything about high schools, I would make them more of a partnership between faculty, students and parents. I think that the key to success is a desire to succeed. The only way to create that desire is to establish an environment where all three of these important links feel a sense of community and a shared goal of creating a higher level of education. If parents, teachers and students work together, each can feel as if they can influence the direction that their community's education system is moving. Involvement on the local level makes all the difference. In high schools around the country, I would like to see teachers making more of an effort to establish a relationship with students and their parents outside of school. A little time and a small amount of caring on the part of educators could improve schools across America."
 
GOOD ADVICE -- "The piece of advice that is freshest in my head at the moment is one given to me at my Senior Awards Ceremony by my advanced placement government teacher, Deborah Minchin. She said, 'Never confuse who you are with the awards you have won.' "
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "The thing that excites me the most about the future is the chance I will have to run for public office and put my ideas into practice."

 THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "I am scared the most by the prospect of not being able to achieve the level of success of my father's generation. My generation has caught on to the prospect of the American Dream hook, line and sinker. We look at our parents and envy the innocent America in which they were raised. We like to think that our hard work will lead to success, but we fear that the wonderful opportunities our parents had will not be there when we grow older. I think that every generation would have the same fears at this age. However, my generation has seen our parents achieve a much greater level of financial success in America than their parents did. The bar has been raised for the children of the 90's and they fear that at some point the opportunities others had in the past will disappear in front of their faces."
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I see my life at 30 being difficult but rewarding. As much as I fear that the American and global economies will not be as friendly to me as they were to my parents, I still believe that if you work hard enough, then opportunity will always come your way. At 30, I see myself working as hard as I am now to insure that opportunities will always be at my disposal."
 
Overcoming the past To Live the Present
 
WHO -- Luis Ortiz, 21, Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services class at Rye Neck High school.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Returned to complete his education after a shooting that left him in a wheelchair; winner of the Overcoming the Odds Award given by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to go to United Cerebral Palsy to train with computers in order to get a paying job. I need training on a computer because that will be the main tool I will use when I start to work."
 
THE BEST -- "The best part of the Boces program was the fact that I had teachers who have helped me a lot. They really care about me and have helped me get the things I really needed."
 
THE WORST -- "The worst thing about school was in my old one in the Bronx. Kids would bring guns and other weapons to school. The school was more like a jail because of the metal detectors and guards in the building. They were needed in the school, but that made it feel like a prison."
 
THE UNEXPECTED -- "The biggest surprise I ever had during high school was when I received the Overcoming the Odds Award last month. It was such an honor and I was very surprised when I found out I was one of the winners. One of the prizes is going to be a laptop computer, which I really need."
 
WHAT IF? -- "If I could change one thing in all the high schools, I would bring in more computers for the students to use. Technology is changing the world, and all kids need to know how to use computers. I know it is the main thing I need to know."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice anyone had ever given me is not to do drugs. Unfortunately, I didn't listen to my mother and now I am in a wheelchair. I got involved with a bad crowd and it has left me a quadriplegic."
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "Right now I can't really think about the future. I have to concentrate on right now."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "The future scares me because I don't know what it will be like. I don't know how it will be for me. It really does scare me!"
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I don't want to think about when I turn 30. I don't look that far ahead. I only think about right now."
 
A Pursuit of Dance and Choreography
 
WHO -- Elizabeth Anne Gill, 18, Yorktown High School.

ACHIEVEMENTS -- Student council member; choreographed and performed in "Fiddler on the the Roof" and "West Side Story," and a member of Students Against Drunk Driving.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I will be attending the Alvin Ailey/Fordham University Bachelor of Fine Arts program in dance at Lincoln Center."

THE BEST AND WORST -- "The best and worst parts of high school have both come from watching me and my fellow students change in our most formative years. Growing as a person and watching my friends develop into people whom I greatly admire has been extremely satisfying. On the other hand, watching some old friends distance themselves and develop into strangers was one of the worst feelings in the world."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "Looking back at high school I was most surprised at how involved I became in the intricate workings of the school. When I first entered high school I was content to remain isolated in my studies and uninvolved in the various organizations. Over the years, I have realized that becoming a part of my high school and knowing that I will leave some bit of myself behind have become surprisingly important to me."

WHAT IF? -- "High schools need to examine the delicate relationships that can be built between teachers and students when there is a mutual sharing of knowledge. Unfortunately, many students are lost in school because they don't feel involved in their education. When students are given the opportunity to influence their teachers, just as teachers hope to influence students, then the students value the education they receive."

GOOD ADVICE -- " Some of the best advice that I have received came from my English teacher, Natalie Farina. She said to our class one day: 'Become observers of the world. Learn to really see what is happening around you and how it relates to the society around it.' I feel that this advice is especially poignant when applied to high school. Because high school students are just beginning to discover who they are, they sometimes try to project an image of how they'd like to be seen. I have found that in high school it is especially important to distinguish between the qualities you see on the surface and those that are true to someone's real self."
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "I am both excited and scared about the responsibility that I will have in the future. Most of the time I can't wait to be in New York City, getting myself around and pursuing dance. However, I am also scared when I realize that only I will be able to push myself. This responsibility means that my successes and failures will be completely my own."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS: -- "When my parents were preparing themselves for college, the Vietnam War was heating up and both feared the escalation of the war as well the possibility of losing their friends who might be sent over to fight. Since the present U.S. conflicts have not produced a draft, I have been lucky enough to live without extreme fear of war. My fears are more personal. I worry about not being a success in my own eyes. I worry about the rejection that comes with pursuing a career in such a competitive field as dance. My parents did not have the same career dreams when they were my age. I dream of being a respected dancer-choreographer."

LIFE AT 30 -- "I hope that when I am 30 years old, I will have already started establishing myself within the artistic community. I would like to have had substantial experience with dance companies by then and opportunities to display my own choreography."
 
The Goal: Opening own Florist Shop
 
WHO -- Danielle Arco, 18, Westlakes High School in Thornwood.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Majored in horticulture through a program offered by the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, receptionist in a veterinary hospital.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "My plans after high school are to get a job working with a florist and to train in that field so I can open up my own shop someday."

THE BEST -- "The best part of high school was the happy memories, the friendships and my boyfriend, Sal."

THE WORST -- "The worst part was seeing some friends come and go, and losing them."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "Looking back, the biggest surprise for me was how fast it all went by. You don't realize at the time how fast it will all be over."

WHAT IF? -- "If I could change one thing in high schools, it would be to make people set aside their differences and get along, and not belong to cliques where some people are left out because they don't dress a certain way. It didn't bother me personally so much, but I have seen many kids hurt because they weren't included."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I ever received was from my father, who always encouraged me to try new things and not to get down on myself. He helped me realize that I wanted to study horticulture and flowers."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "When I look ahead, the thing that excites me the most is the opportunity I will have to do things for myself, to be responsible for myself."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me is not knowing what to expect. Maybe it won't turn out the way I wish it will. Everyone always says that life is easy only when you're young."

LIFE AT 30 -- "Hopefully at 30, I will be happily married, have two children and own a flower shop."
 
A Lifelong Desire: Becoming a Lawyer
 
WHO -- Louise Kellie Beach, 18, Peekskill High School.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Member of National Honor Society, student council president, intern in a law office.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "My post high school plans are to attend Hofstra University and major in English, minor in science and go on to law school, ultimately practicing law."

THE BEST -- "I enjoyed being involved in many of the extracurricular activities: National Honor Society, student council, community service, cheerleading, Black Culture Club."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of my high school years was the preparation and taking of the Scholastic Achievement Test."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "I was surprised to find that the work load was not as overwhelming as I had been told."
 
WHAT IF -- "I would change the scheduling process because not all, but many, students take classes just to simply get by and receive a passing grade. I feel that each student should be challenged with a rigorous schedule to prepare them for what college life offers, because after all, high school is a stepping stone leading to college."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I received was from my grandmother, who instilled in me from a very early age that there is nothing too hard for me and that obstacles are meant to be overcome."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "What excites me the most about the future is achieving my lifelong dream. From a young age I knew my desired career goal -- a corporate lawyer. To achieve this goal would be a dream come true not only for me but for my parents also."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "I would have to say that what scares me the most are the challenges associated with college life -- being in large classroom settings, getting along with a roommate and navigating my way around campus."

LIFE AT 30 -- "At the age of 30, I will be a successful corporate lawyer, married and raising a family."
 
For the Future, Being Happy is the Goal
 
WHO -- Andrew Goldberg, 18, Hastings-on-Hudson High School.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Class valedictorian, National Merit scholar, student government participant, guitar player.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to study mathematics and computer science at Amherst College in Amherst, Mass."

THE BEST -- "Coming from a small high school, I'd say the best part of my high school experience was the close interaction between students and teachers. In a small school, there are so many opportunities available for everyone."
 
THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was the occasional stress and worrying that accompanied all of my hard work. It was hard to balance everything all the time, and sometimes my self-imposed pressure was a little too strong."
 
THE UNEXPECTED -- "My biggest surprise looking back would have to be the fact that I was able to maintain my academic performance while being busy with several clubs and activities and many other obligations. I always tried to manage my time well to make sure this was possible."

WHAT IF -- "If I could change any one thing in high schools, I would make it possible for all students to have all the opportunities they desire. Some students attend public schools which lack money and many of the resources that are available to students in other areas of the country. All students should be able to explore and branch out in many directions so that they find their niche."

GOOD ADVICE -- "I can't think of specific advice that anyone has given me, but my parents have always taught me to work toward and try to surpass my potential."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "I am most excited about going to college this fall. After growing up in such a small village, my classmates and I know each other almost too well, and it will be a great opportunity to begin again in college with an empty canvas."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me the most about the future and college is not being able to form a close-knit group of friends like I have in high school now. I bet my dreams and fears are rather similar to those of my parents when they were my age because they are fairly natural feelings. The future can be intimidating, and to have worries is completely normal."
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I don't really know what I'll be like when I'm 30. I could go through college and graduate school and wind up in a computer-related career, while I could also find new direction at college and end up somewhere totally different. Whatever I do, though, I would like to have a family and be happy when I'm 30. As long as you're happy, the rest doesn't really matter."
 
'I've Become a Role Model for Other Kids'
 
WHO -- Jerome Matthews, 18, Port Chester High School.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Co-captain of the basketball team. (Said he "learned in high school to play a sport rather than let it play him.")

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to attend Delhi Junior College in Delhi, N.Y."
 
THE BEST -- "The best part of high school was recovering from my downfalls and being in the wrong crowd. I've become a role model for other kids."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was going through some obstacles. I was cutting classes and bringing myself down. I was failing my courses, and I was left out of sports for a while."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "The biggest surprise was turning myself around academically and otherwise and finally being able to graduate with my class. I live in a low-cost housing project in Port Chester, and Earl Johnson, another basketball player who lived in my building and now attends Rutgers, encouraged me to bring up my grades."
 
WHAT IF -- "If there was one thing I could change, it would be to set up a mentor system for kids. It's important for us to have someone to look up to."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I ever received was from my grandmother and mother, who sat me down and said: "Jerome, you have to play basketball. Don't let it play you. Don't forget your studies because you have to have something to fall back on."
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "The thing that excites me most about the future is that I am one of the first people in my family who is going to college. A lot of the younger kids are looking up to me."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me is that I'll be three or four hours away from my family. What if there are problems?"
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "By the time I'm 30, I hope I am well educated and have an associate's degree, a bachelor's degree and a master's degree -- and a nice wife and two kids and a home like I did not have."
 
A Lesson Learned: 'Never Give Up'
 
WHO -- Christopher C. Ellis, 17, Archbishop Stepinac High School.

ACHIEVEMENTS -- Member of the track team, Salutatorian of graduating class, winner of the William Plunkett Award given annually to a student who has excelled academically, given exceptional service to the school and served as a role model of values.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "After caddying this summer at a golf club, I will attend Syracuse University to study communications and journalism."

THE BEST -- "The best part of high school and going from a small parochial school in Yonkers to a larger school was meeting a lot of new people, making new friends and learning from new teachers."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was having to travel so far by train and bus from my home in Yonkers to White Plains."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "I was suprised at how different high school was from grammar school and how independent I was able to be."

WHAT IF -- "If I could change something in high schools, it would be to have more teachers get more involved with students. I would like to see students having more of a say in the classroom and more opportunities to interact. Classroom teaching should not be just about straight lectures."
 
GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I ever received was from my parents who told me never to give up, even when I hit slumps either in sports or with my school work."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "I am most excited about the new independence I will experience living at college, and the chance I'll have to focus in more on a particular subject like journalism."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "I am most uncertain about what the future holds -- both in college and the job market."

LIFE At 30 -- "I want to be successful -- to have a good job, even if I am not the highest paid person -- and to have a wife who is a good person. I want to live an honest, straight life and be happy. Some people see success as making millions of dollars or driving the best car, but I don't know if that necessarily makes someone emotionally happy. I want to be settled by 30 and not stressed out."
 
First Woman To Be President, Perhaps?
 
WHO -- Erika Zauner, 17, Hackley School, Tarrytown.

ACHIEVEMENTS -- Voted most valuable player for the varsity field hockey team, editor of The Vision, the school's literary magazine.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "Before attending Princeton University in the fall, I will work for part of the summer as a volunteer for a cardio-thoracic surgeon at Cornell Medical Center in New York City. I am also working as a waitress for several weeks in Spring Lake, N.J., and will attend field hockey camp for two weeks."

THE BEST -- "The highlight of high school was working with teachers and coaches who love what they are doing and inspire students to excel at and enjoy a subject or activity."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was the cliques. Most kids are so insecure in high school and super-conscious of other people's perceptions of them, which fosters the formation of cliques."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "The biggest surprise for me in my private high school, as a student coming from public school, was the extraordinary commitment of so many teachers to a positive learning experience."
GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice ever given to me was from my grandmother, who often says, 'If you enjoy the simple pleasures in life, you will always be a happy person.' This advice has helped me to appreciate little things every day, like an intimate conversation with my sister or the sunset on my drive home from school."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "What excites me most about the future are the many opportunities created by rapid advancements in the fields of technology and science and genetics. I learned a great deal about genetic disorders in a genetics tutorial I took this year and the thought of helping people overcome a disorder or sickness, such as breast cancer, by manipulating their genes is amazing and very promising."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me the most? Although the thriving field of genetic research has many positives, the work done to manipulate genes to clone people or the possibility of altering the genetic code of fetuses so parents can choose the traits they want their child to possess is very scary. While the field of genetics possesses promising potential in helping people overcome illnesses or disorders, daunting images of a "Brave New World" society come to mind when thinking of the consequences of abusing genetics."
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I hope by age 30 to be a pediatrician or pediatric surgeon. However, I might go to Princeton and find that I'm intrigued by politics, who knows? Maybe I'll end up being a lawyer or a teacher or even the first woman President."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
One Bump in Rates Isn't a Mountain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
IS the worst over?
It's easy to think so after a week in which the Consumer Price Index for May came in unchanged from April and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, seemed to signal that the central bank may need only a modest increase in its short-term interest rate target to slow growth, deflate this year's inflation boomlet and keep the economy on track. 
 The shift in sentiment was big. A week ago, the yield on the 30-year bond jumped to an 18-month high of 6.16 percent as investors thought that two -- or even three -- rate increases were possible. By Friday, the yield had tumbled back below 6 percent, to 5.97 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished the week up 3.8 percent.
While investors may be relieved, what the Fed will do after policy makers meet on June 30 -- when they are almost certain to raise their short-term interest rate target a quarter of a percentage point -- is still up in the air.
And the spreads between yields on Treasury securities and corporate bonds, junk bonds and emerging-markets debt are still wide enough to indicate that some investors see the risk of near-term turmoil.
Mr. Greenspan signaled a rate increase when he told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress that "when we can be pre-emptive we should be, because modest pre-emptive actions can obviate the need of more drastic actions at a later date that could destabilize the economy."
Investors took their cues from "modest" and "more drastic action" and concluded that one rate increase might be enough.
But Mr. Greenspan sent other signals that can be interpreted to mean rate increases will go as far as needed to assure that economic growth slows to around a 3 percent rate.
Specifically, he said the 4 percent average annual growth of the last four years was based on a two percentage-point increase in worker productivity and a one percentage-point increase in the working-age population. The remaining point, he said, came from the shrinking of the pool of job seekers without work.
That last development "represents an unsustainable trend," Mr. Greenspan said. Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, said Mr. Greenspan has set a speed limit because he does not want a further decline in the unemployment rate. If that happens, Mr. Greenspan faces the inflationary wage increases that the Fed is determined to avoid.
"A bull would say, 'I think the economy will slow down pretty much on its own, so we are fine,' " Mr. Barbera said. "A bear would say, 'Greenspan told us rates are going up until the economy slows down.' "
STILL, the worst may be over for the average investor, who should look beyond that uncertainty. If the Fed does what is expected -- and there is no good reason to think that it won't -- then the outlook for both bonds and stocks is positive over the longer term. And market timing is not a game that smaller investors -- with long-term goals -- should play in any case.
The immediate market reaction to rate increases often ignores the long-term perspective. "The knee-jerk reaction -- one never knows. It can be bad," said Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist at Goldman Sachs & Company. "What matters is what happens after that." After the necessary rate increase -- she is not predicting how many will be needed to slow growth -- she expects the market outlook to improve, helped by what she believes will be good second-quarter earnings reports. The second quarter, Ms. Cohen added, might even be strong enough to make her increase her corporate earnings forecast, which is now 7 to 8 percent growth this year and next.
That means investors can consider picking up some bonds on the assumption that they will rally as rates fall -- in the second half of the year ---- in the wake of a Fed success. And sticking with stocks looks O.K., too, as good earnings reports should be even a better bet in the third and fourth quarters as the comparisons to 1998 get easier.
The Fed, Ms. Cohen said, "can do this in a way that does not harm the economy." As she did with the one-quarter-point rate increase in March 1997, Ms. Cohen is calling this a "flu shot." Yes, it hurts. But it staves off something worse.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes /The Gardiner-Tyler House, West New Brighton, Staten Island;
Where a President's Widow Backed the Confederacy

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
DURING the Civil War, the elegant Greek revival Gardiner-Tyler House, in West New Brighton, Staten Island, sheltered one of New York's most conspicuous rebel sympathizers, Julia Gardiner Tyler, widow of President John Tyler. When she was not involved in pro-Confederate activities, she was busy trying to reunite her family, scattered by the war. Now another family is reuniting in this grand temple-fronted house, as a new addition brings together three generations under one roof.
 Now on a small plot surrounded by modest houses, the Gardiner-Tyler house was built around 1837 as a much larger country estate, apparently by an Eliza Racey, about whom little is known.
The main entrance -- under the temple front -- faces south across a wide valley, and the house is of simple plan, with a front to back center hall. 
 The precisely carved Corinthian capitals on the four double-height columns seem more sophisticated than the heavy scrolled brackets that connect the portico to the house, but it is difficult to tell if they are later alterations -- the earliest good photographs of the house are from the turn of the century.
Early occupancy of the house is sketchy, but Robert Seager's 1963 book, "And Tyler Too," says that, according to Gardiner and Tyler family correspondence, Juliana Gardiner, Julia Gardiner Tyler's mother, bought the house in 1852.
 Juliana Gardiner was the widow of David Gardiner -- a member of the Long Island family that owned Gardiner's Island. Gardiner had died in February 1844 after a cannon exploded during testing on a ship in the Potomac River. President Tyler had also been aboard.
Already friendly with the Gardiner family, Tyler became even more friendly with Julia and married her in New York City in June 1844.
Tyler had been elected Vice President in 1840 under William Henry Harrison and became President in April 1841 when Harrison died after only a month in office. Weakened in a dispute over tariff bills with his own Whig Party, Tyler withdrew from the 1844 presidential election.
 The Tylers lived at their James River estate, Sherwood Forest, in Virginia. After 1852, Juliana Gardiner lived in the Staten Island house, called Castleton Hill. Tyler was generally identified with pro-slavery, pro-Southern policies -- he had about 70 slaves at Sherwood Forest.
In 1853 The New York Herald and other papers carried an article by Julia Tyler defending slavery, which aroused much comment. She said that the Southern slave "lives sumptuously" compared to workers in modern industrial economies. She was also an intimate of Jefferson Davis and his wife, Varina.
 AT least as early as 1857 Julia and John Tyler visited Juliana Gardiner at Staten Island, and when the former President died in 1862, Julia crossed Civil War battle lines to live at the Staten Island estate, despite her own Southern sympathies.
On Staten Island, Julia Tyler worked for the release of Southern prisoners, for the relief of occupied Southern cities and for various peace efforts.
 Julia Tyler went back and forth to her Virginia estate with a regularity that Northern patriots found suspicious. Her Southern sympathies brought conflict to the house, where she often violently quarreled with her uncle, David Lyon Gardiner, who was finally sent away by Juliana Gardiner, his sister.
During this time Julia Tyler was also trying to keep up Sherwood Forest, look after other children in the family, and come up with a way to live in the safety of her mother's house while safeguarding her teen-age sons, David and John, who were in military service -- on the Confederate side.
 In April 1865, just hours after Lincoln's assassination, three Staten Islanders forced their way into the house to retrieve and destroy what one claimed in a letter in The New York Herald was a Confederate flag, describing Julia Tyler as the "widow of the deceased rebel ex-President."
In a letter to The New York Mail, Julia Tyler denounced the "outrage committed at my house" and said the flag was only an ornamental bunting, without political significance.
 A June 1, 1865, census recorded Julia Tyler in the house with five of her children, as well as a tutor, an Irish-born coachman and two English-born servants. Juliana Gardiner died in 1868, and Julia got the Staten Island house after a venomous court fight with David Lyon Gardiner.
 Her lawyer in the litigation, William M. Evarts, was also a family friend and lent her money, taking the house as security. Julia Tyler left New York in 1871 for Washington and then Virginia, and later in the decade Evarts, who was also prominent in politics, took ownership of the house, although it is not clear if he lived there.
 IN the 1880's and 1890's the house was occupied by Douglas M. A. Brown, a wallpaper manufacturer, and in 1898 the land was divided into 157 building lots styled as "Tyler Park" in anticipation of a public auction to be accompanied by music and lunch. Included in the sale was to be the "fine house" occupied "by President Tyler," although it appears he was never more than an intermittent seasonal guest.
 After 1900 the house and most of the lots were purchased by Thaddeus J. Carlin; the 1920 census shows him in occupancy with an English servant and his 15-year-old son, Arthur. Arthur Carlin's granddaughter, Arlene Gillen McGinley, says that when her mother, Arlene Carlin, married Arthur Gillen, "the house was so large they asked the Gillens to move in with them."
The family gradually sold off the surrounding lots, and now the grand house is surrounded by low ranch houses, like Gulliver encircled by Lilliputians.
 Mrs. McGinley moved out herself when she married Terrance McGinley in 1977, but now that Mr. and Mrs. Gillen are aging, she and Mr. McGinley have purchased the Gardiner-Tyler house from them and are adding a side wing in complementary style, designed by the architect Timothy Boyland, working with the preservation consultant Mary Dierickx. Mrs. McGinley, her husband and their three children are planning to move in next month.
 The new wing will be accessible for people with disabilities, to make living there easier for her parents, and will also permit her older brother, Kevin, to visit more frequently -- he has multiple sclerosis and lives in a nursing home.
"When people hear I'm moving into that house they say, 'My gosh, that's a mansion,' " and then I have to tell them I grew up in it," Mrs. McGinley says. "I'm the fourth generation here, and my children, God willing, will live here in the future also."

HEADLINE: Media;
Old Formula For a Magazine On Fashion Is Out of Style

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
If the executives at Hearst Magazines wanted to place an ad in the newspaper for the position of editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, it might read something like this:
"Wanted: An editor with enough attitude to revitalize a magazine that was once a solid No. 2 in the field and is now wavering between No. 3 and 4; a woman (probably) who is willing to make close to $1 million a year and has the ability to answer the following question: Do American women -- and the advertisers that cater to them -- care about fashion anymore?" 
 This week, Cathleen P. Black, the president of Hearst Magazines, is expected to announce which lucky contestant will win the coveted opportunity to replace the late Elizabeth Tilberis as top editor of Harper's Bazaar. While a half-dozen names are being mentioned, executives of Hearst are mostly staying silent. (One who ventured to speak off the record would do so only after asking if a reporter was sure her phone lines were not bugged.)
But whoever takes the helm will have to contend not only with the problems at Harper's Bazaar -- dwindling advertising pages, snazzy competition and sluggish growth in fashion advertising -- but with the potential end of an era for the high-fashion glossy, as magazines that combine style and life style -- like In Style, published by Time Inc., a unit of Time Warner -- come to dominate the marketplace.
After a recession in Asian markets late last year, manufacturers of high-end apparel and makers of luxury goods, like Gucci, suffered some losses, and that translated into lower budgets for fashion magazine advertising. (These losses came on the heels of a decline the previous year; in the category of ready-to-wear clothing, manufacturers spent $539 million in magazine advertising in 1997 but only $510 million in 1998, the first dip after a precipitous rise during the previous five years.)
Other categories remained strong. The four magazines in the United States that focus on women's fashion -- Vogue, Elle, W and Harper's Bazaar -- show relatively healthy advertising figures, encompassing all categories, for this year. Harper's Bazaar was the least sprightly of the four, with just a 2 percent increase in overall advertising revenue for January through May, compared with the period a year earlier. Vogue and W are both up 13 percent, and Elle is up 3 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. By contrast, In Style is up 60 percent. But much of this year's rise can be credited to the fact that the fashion titles have followed the lead of magazines like In Style and brought in new categories of advertising, said Roberta Garfinkle, the director of print media at McCann-Erickson, a unit of Interpublic Group.
"If you're going to build your business, you're going to have go beyond the traditional advertisers in fashion and bring in new ones," Ms. Garfinkle said. "Is fashion the staple it used to be? I don't know. They're looking at automotive, at consumer electronics. If Harper's Bazaar becomes more mainstream, does it make them a better candidate for different kinds of advertising, more mass-market kinds of advertising? Or does it stay where it is, stay focused on the creme de la creme, the high-end couture, and limit themselves? That's a business decision that Cathie Black has to make."
Elle, which is published by Hachette-Filipacchi Magazines, a unit of Lagardere Group, is taking a particularly aggressive -- and increasingly common -- approach: it is starting a magazine to bring new and less frequent advertisers into the fold. This November, Elle will arrive in subscribers' mailboxes bundled with a new publication, Elle's Ultimate Road Trip, a luxury travel magazine that is being planned as a quarterly. Intended to attract advertisers in categories like luxury goods, culinary, hotels, automotive and high technology, Elle's Ultimate Road Trip has already signed up Gucci, Cartier and Chopard, the watch manufacturer.
The magazine's mission, said Elaina Richardson, the editor in chief of Elle, is to present women with what she called "a life style approach" to fashion. "It's about life style, and a sense of the good life, and this is what fashion is about now," she said. "I think we spend as much time now thinking about the thread count of our sheets as the ply of our cashmere. Fashion to women now is what's going on in clothes, but also what company or designer is making furniture, what designer is involved in a hotel. The world of fashion is connected to travel and resorts and furnishings, and it's a much bigger universe than it once was."
Among the categories that have grown most energetically in the pages of magazines this year, according to figures released this month by the Publishers Information Bureau, are technology, up 15 percent in advertising pages, home furnishings and supplies, up 14 percent, and travel, up 13 percent. Apparel has remained flat at 1.7 percent.
Advertisers, in the meantime, wait to see who will take the helm at Harper's Bazaar and how that person will shape the magazine. For much of its 132-year history, Harper's Bazaar has been strictly devoted to fashion, but in the last two years it has had more articles on other topics.
Vogue tends to be more celebrity-oriented: while Harper's Bazaar recently featured an article about houses designed by the architect Richard Neutra in Los Angeles, Vogue ran a spread on Oscar de la Renta's vacation hacienda. W, too, covers the high-living celebrity life, as well as highlighting its avant-garde photography (a recent spread showed a macho-looking Brad Pitt holding a furry rabbit) and dozens of pages of society news at the front of the magazine. Elle maintains the most middlebrow approach, featuring color-splashed fashion spreads and a particularly bawdy advice columnist.
But the success of life style magazines points to a serious issue: Do American women want to read fashion magazines? Nancy Etcoff, a psychologist at the Harvard Medical School and the author of "Survival of the Prettiest: The Science of Beauty" (Doubleday), said that American women may have grown fashion fatigued.
"The fashion magazines are about fulfilling fantasy, and they are an art form -- they are theatrical," she said. "We will always have a longing for that kind of beauty and theatricality, but I think right now, fashion magazines no longer present the most popular images, and part of the problem was that there was such a focus on the supermodel as an object and less a focus on personality. Perhaps they need to rethink their approach to women as more rounded personalities."
Ms. Richardson of Elle said: "A friend of mine used to tell me that 10, 15 years ago, she used to sit at the beach at the end of the summer and she and her friends would flip through the September magazines and do their fall clothes shopping. Now what woman has time to do that? She's faxing her office, or taking care of the kids. I don't know if she has that time or inclination anymore. I don't know if women even have time to sit on the beach."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Networks Deliver Smorgasbord to Fill Order for Young Viewers

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Remember the episode of "The Twilight Zone" when a horrified woman discovered that a book written by space visitors called "To Serve Man" was actually a cookbook? Well, a book about the 1999-2000 season for the broadcast television networks could be titled "To Serve Youth."
But now Madison Avenue is wondering whether that book will be a best seller or a recipe for failure. 
 For years, agencies and advertisers have exhorted broadcast TV to appeal to younger viewers -- 12 to 24, 18 to 34, 18 to 49 -- because they are deemed more desirable consumers than their older counterparts: more willing to spend, to try new products, to switch brands. Besides, younger consumers, particularly teen-age and 20-something males, watch less television, making those who do watch much more valuable to marketers.
And the "dot com" advertisers pitching computers, Web sites and other high-technology products and services, whose dollars are beginning to flood into TV, are licking their chops over the millions of wired consumers in Generations X and Y.
"Everyone's looking for young eyeballs," said Jamie Kellner, president of the WB network in Burbank, Calif., which is owned by Time Warner and the Tribune Company and is enjoying strong gains in ad revenue by delivering marketers audiences aged 12 to 24.
So broadcasters are racing to add programs aimed at younger viewers to their prime-time schedules for the coming season. By one count, 18 of 37 new series on the six broadcast networks will look at the world through youth-colored glasses, joining more than a dozen returning series with similar skews.
Among the newcomers: "Freaks and Geeks" on NBC, "Manchester Prep" and "Ryan Caulfield" on the Fox Broadcasting Company and "Snoops" and "Then Came You" on Walt Disney's ABC, as well as more youthful fare for WB like "Angel," "Roswell" and "Popular." UPN, owned by Viacom, will appeal to young males with a wrestling show called "WWF Smackdown!" and a Friday movie called "Blockbuster Video's Shockwave Cinema."
Even CBS, the network first in older viewers, is seeking to climb down the demographic ladder a couple of rungs, pairing younger and older cast members in new series like "Judging Amy."
But after all those entreaties to broadcasters to think young, some agency executives worry that the pendulum may be swinging too far too fast in one direction.
"It's too much of the same thing," said Paul Schulman, president of Schulman/Advanswers NY, a media services agency in New York owned by the Omnicom Group. "People are copying the WB."
A primary concern is that the broadcast networks will be diverted from an audience they ought to be pursuing: the aging baby boomers, the 76 million consumers born from 1946 to 1964 whose incomes for the most part dwarf those of younger viewers.
"Being associated with youth is a positive because people like to envision themselves as young, virile, active," said Stacey Lynn Koerner, vice president for broadcast television research at TN Media in New York, the media services arm of True North Communications. "That's our American culture. And advertisers like to be in environments where there's a perception that positive things are going on.
"But there is no reason to believe older people are less willing to try new things," she added. "And there are different levels to it. I might be 15 and want to do what my friends do. I might be 45 and want the new Mercedes my neighbor has."
The executives also warn that the youth movement may conflict with the traditional mission of broadcast TV: to reach the widest audiences possible.
"A broadcaster is exactly that, a 'broad-caster,' " Ms. Koerner said, adding: "Broadcasters can't narrow themselves to one audience and remain viable. They have to in some sense be all things to all people."
If broadcasters narrow their focus to fixate on youth, according to this school of thought, they run the risk of becoming clones of cable networks, which most commonly aim their programming at smaller, specific targets. That would then weaken the strongest argument for advertising on broadcast TV.
Broadcasting "doesn't exclude," said Bob Igiel, president for the broadcast division of the Media Edge in New York, the media services arm of Young & Rubicam Inc. "When you turn on the TV, a sign doesn't come on saying 'You're 50 and you can't watch this.' "
The rush to satisfy young viewers, the critics fret, may also exacerbate the longstanding problem the broadcast networks confront: declining ratings. Shows that seemingly exclude older viewers may send them away to alternative fare, thereby further eroding audiences.
"If two networks of six focus on youth, that's fine," said Peter Chrisanthopoulos, president for broadcast and programming in the United States at the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide agency in New York, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C., "because if viewers have enough choices, they don't always have to go to cable. "If more than two do it," he added, "they start to cannibalize one another and lose more viewers to cable."
Not surprisingly, the network that most ardently believes in the puissance of older consumers is CBS, which has the most older viewers.
"There's no strong economic reason for Madison Avenue's fascination with the young audience," said David F. Poltrack, executive vice president for research and planning at CBS Television in New York. "I've always called this the programmer's dilemma, pursuing the segment of the audience for which there is greatest competition, which watches less TV over all, because of Madison Avenue's obsession. "As the baby boomers move into an older age group," he added, "Madison Avenue will become increasingly aware that's where the money is."
The other networks say they are becoming more youth-centric simply to deliver what advertisers and agencies request.
"We're not different from any other business with a market-share war going on," said Randy Falco, president of the NBC-TV Network unit of NBC in New York, part of the General Electric Company.
So while broadcast TV is "still the only place you can reach the mass audience," he added, if "the advertising community cares about 18 to 49," those are the viewers who will receive special attention.
And "good television is about taking chances, trying to capture lightning in a bottle," Mr. Falco said. "With 'Freaks and Geeks,' we will take a chance, do something different. Every once in a while, you hit on something." That new series is about high school life in the 1980's
At Fox, a unit of the News Corporation, the focus has been on viewers 18 to 34; the network finished first in that age group for the 1998-99 season and second behind NBC in viewers 18 to 49.
"We attract a higher percentage of light television viewers, which makes our audience more valuable because it's more difficult to reach," said Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox in New York. "And that correlates with youth."
Even so, "reaching the largest possible audience is still important," he added, and Fox is looking to viewers 12 to 34 as well as 25 to 54 for potential audience gains.
"Ratings erosion is a major concern," Mr. Nesvig said, "but in general the biggest issue is better programs. You still see the audiences respond on a given night if there are good programs and we get them to the set. It's still, 'The play's the thing.' "
Come fall, Madison Avenue will be watching the broadcast ratings as closely as teen-agers watch "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" or "Dawson's Creek" on WB.
"For those of us representing advertisers," said Mr. Chrisanthopoulos at Ogilvy & Mather, "it's good if a network has a focus, a mission, and tries to fulfill its goals by focusing on the audiences it desires.
"The youth focus is good as long as they all don't do it."

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Drive-In Offers Cabbage and Promises of Popcorn

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 20

 BODY:
It is true that the men behind the first and only drive-in movie in Russia overlooked a few things, such as telling the audience that films are best viewed with headlights off. Also, popcorn. Somehow, a drive-in isn't quite the same munching on cabbage pie.
But those are nits. With a hastily built 56-by-30-foot screen and a projection booth mounted on stilts, three Moscow entrepreneurs staged a two-night dry run this weekend of the quintessentially American motion picture experience, and appeared to have a hit on their hands. 
 Indeed, once the sun set this weekend -- that is, in this northern season of bright summer solstice nights, at about 11:20 P.M. -- the Moscow Kinodrome could well have been the Kenwood in Louisville or the Moonlight in Pittsburgh instead of what it was: a deserted parking lot, hard by an equally deserted velodrome built for the 1980 Olympics.
"It's a good thing to have, just to relax," said 30-year-old Igor Martinov as he stood by his red Nissan, downing beers and smoking L&M's. "And if you have a good car with shaded windows," he grinned, "it's a very good thing for young kids to have."
Drive-ins may be a dying breed in the United States, where their number has shrunk to about 500 from 10 times that at the peak of their popularity. But the story may well be different in Moscow, a place desperately short of theaters and where the economics of moviegoing is completely different.
While most American drive-ins aim for the teen-age crowd or the family seeking a cheap night out, the backers of the Kinodrome have their sights on a slightly older, more upscale crowd. When it reopens -- the theater is in hiatus after its two-night premiere -- it will cost 195 rubles per person, or $8, for a movie and a light meal.
While the Olympic complex has seen better days, the drive-in is in one of the city's finer neighborhoods, a mile from President Boris N. Yeltsin's city apartment and not far from clusters of luxury high-rise apartments.
Aleksandr Volkov, who came up with the idea after seeing drive-ins in Hungary and Germany, said in an interview that the backers decided to expand on one partner's successful experience running 16 nightclubs.
"It's based on the idea that in Moscow in the summertime, a great number of people are living the night life," he said, "and secondly, that Moscovites love to watch films. We found that there are a great number of people who haunt these clubs during the night and prefer to sit not inside, but outside. They ask to move their tables to the open."
And so the Kinodrome sports an outdoor cafe at the rear of the parking lot, where filmgoers can buy apple, mushroom and cabbage pies, fruit-stuffed pirozhki, or pastries, American soft drinks, beer and -- soon -- vodka.
The drive-in itself is a decidedly makeshift affair. The parking lot, equipped with green gates to keep freeloaders out, holds only 150 cars and lacks a ticket booth. The screen is anything but oversized, and the cramped projection room inexplicably flies a skull-and-crossbones and is draped in camouflage netting.
Inside, the two water-cooled projectors were salvaged from the defunct October Theater, which is being gutted and turned into a multiscreen cineplex. As there are no water lines running to the lot, the projectionists' great fear -- unrealized, fortunately -- was that the evenings' feature films would catch fire.
Critics might have called that no great loss. Although the Kinodrome promises the best in Russian and foreign film, the main events Thursday and Friday were an American sci-fi potboiler, "Virus," and one of the Mel Gibson vehicles, "Lethal Weapon 4."
But the premiere audiences, lured by free tickets and the novelty of it all, didn't seem to care. College girls and boys strolled up and down the rows of obediently lined-up Audis, Mustangs and other imported cars, looking for each other. In one expensive-looking sport utility vehicle, Andrei Bezlepkin, his wife and their two children said they were there strictly on a lark.
His daughter Julia, 15, had seen three of the Lethal Weapon films, but Dad was clueless. "I think it's something like Weapons Number Four," he said when asked about the night's entertainment.
On the road by the theater, dozens more cars -- including one police cruiser -- squeezed onto the gravel shoulder on Friday night seeking their own free view. Still more people simply walked in and squatted on the pavement, straining to catch the sound track broadcast from the projection booth to car radios.
There have been some glitches. At the first showing on Thursday, drivers in the front row had to be told to switch off their headlights. Some who came on motorcycles or in cars without radios were disappointed to find that they were watching a silent movie. One walk-in, clearly there more for the beer than the movie, rose in the middle of one presentation to demand that the sound be turned up.
Nor is it a seamlessly American experience. For one thing, the brief Russian summer nights mean that the first showing doesn't end until close to 1 A.M., and the second finishes around first light. The viewing season is also brief: the Kinodrome will close for the winter in October, a projectionist said, because the oil in the projectors freezes.
Still, at least one oversight is about to be remedied. When the Kinodrome reopens later this month, Mr. Volkov said, it will serve popcorn.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Al Gore Turns the Volume Way, Way Up

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Al Gore has been trying to be more exciting on the stump -- trying so hard that if he keeps it up, he'll rupture his vocal cords before the New Hampshire primary.
The new Al Gore yells quite a lot. Caught between Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, two natural campaigners, the Vice President is trying to make up in decibels what he lacks in spontaneity. "I am not satisfied! INDEED I AM RESTLESS!" he cried in New York, announcing his candidacy for President with a list of promises about what he would do to move the country TOWARD AMERICA'S NEW HORIZONS, a goal that will involve eliminating EVERY LAST DIME OF WASTE, fighting GLOBAL WARMING and making our public schools THE FINEST AND BEST IN THE ENTIRE WORLD. 
 This is our fault. We have been carping about how boring Al Gore is, and the poor man is all but howling at the moon in an effort to sound more compelling. We are being forced to watch him go through an enormous effort to look effortless, and it is as discomfiting as looking at the underside of a swan swimming on the lake. Voters are not going to elect a President who makes them feel like nervous parents at the second-grade class play. Mr. Gore has to give up this futile attempt to become Kennedyesque and embrace the boredom.
Let Gore be Gore! Where is it written that the American people want a fun guy for President? Most of our chief executives were not people you would necessarily want to pal around with. No one ever accused George Washington of being the life of the party. "Today I dined with the president, and as usual the company was as grave as if at a funeral," reported one of his supporters.
Certainly it is a disadvantage to have to campaign in the age of mass media when the only TV star you resemble is Howdy Doody. But history shows that when America is in a period of economic boom, the public is comfortable having someone in the White House who is more stolid than the stock market. During the Roaring Twenties, the electorate fell in love with Calvin Coolidge, a monosyllabic politician who barely had the energy to get out of bed in the morning. (Coolidge was also, as far as we know, the first Vice President to serve while his boss was having sex with a woman not his wife in a room just off the Oval Office. He never felt compelled to point out that this was outrageous.)
Unlike Coolidge, Al Gore is an energetic politician, and you only have to listen to his speeches to know that there will probably be A LOT OF INITIATIVES in a Gore administration. Even though George Bush has been gloriously unspecific about his own agenda, it is already easy to see that the two front-runners for the Presidential nominations have very different outlooks. Mr. Gore, for all his worries about BUREAUCRATIC EXCESS, is a government activist, and Mr. Bush, for all his talk about being a compassionate conservative, does not seem to really have many new initiatives in mind. The best way to describe the difference between them so far is that Mr. Gore promises to make "high-quality preschool available to EVERY CHILD IN EVERY FAMILY" and Mr. Bush promises to get the Head Start classes to teach phonics.
The first time I saw Al Gore, he was running in the New York Democratic Presidential primary in 1988, a contest the Gore people thought they had wrapped up when they won the endorsement of Mayor Ed Koch. But Mr. Koch was in full-throttle third-term hysteria, having insulted or alienated almost every conceivable section of the city population. The Mayor led Mr. Gore around like a spaniel, and at almost every stop the Tennessee Senator was asked to apologize for something Mr. Koch had said or done to somebody. During that campaign Mr. Gore did not look so much stiff as numb, as if he had been knocked over the head with a bat.
The second time I saw Mr. Gore was when he returned to Manhattan for an environmental conference. He was happy as a clam, discussing dire predictions of receding shores and expanding populations. Reading the text of his remarks would probably have been pretty boring then, too. But in person, Mr. Gore was utterly at ease with himself and his audience. Even his hair looked less stiff.
Bob Olivari, who worked for Mr. Gore in that fatal 1988 primary, claims his candidate was at his best in Staten Island, the home of the nation's largest landfill, where people were actually interested in hearing him talk about solid waste. "He had a very good first day and then it went downhill," recalled Mr. Olivari last week, at a fund-raising cocktail party for Mr. Gore in Manhattan. "Maybe he should just try being who he is and things will work out."
Seize the moment, Mr. Gore. Dare to be dull.
