LENGTH: 994 words

HEADLINE: Pike Reappear, and a California City Is on Guard

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTOLA, Calif.

 BODY:
The latest bad news from Lake Davis has an all too familiar ring to it.
In the fall of 1997, the California Fish and Game Department, fresh out of ideas for ridding Lake Davis of the northern pike that for years threatened the state's crucial salmon and trout populations miles downstream, dumped more than 60,000 pounds of poisons into the lake. 
 The lake treatment, called "the poisoning" by residents of this small city in the Sierra Nevadas, was good for the state's fishing industry but disastrous for Portola, killing the pike but also eliminating one of Portola's sources of drinking water and jeopardizing its economy, dependent on tourism. The poisons, including the insecticide rotenone, killed the trout that drew tourists.
The Plumas County Supervisor, Fran Roudebush, said the poisoning cost the city and the county more than $15 million in lost tourism revenue.
Now, with the poisons dissipated, the lake restocked with trout and the region once more packed with tourists eager to fish, pike have again been spotted in Lake Davis.
Frustration and dread are back too, settling like a fog on Portola. The fear is that the state will again shut down Lake Davis and strangle the city's economy, just when Portola was showing signs of renewal and people were starting to trust the lake as a water supply.
Though officials are not yet suggesting that the lake will have to be treated with poisons again, residents are not waiting to see whether that happens.
Town meetings that include briefings on developments at Lake Davis have been packed. And, at the request of the Fish and Game Department, residents are forming an advisory group that will include department and city officials.
"This is not about a fish," Jim Murphy, Portola's City Administrator, said at a recent meeting of residents and fish and game officials. "This is about a water supply. This is about the ability of a community to grow."
Everyone still remembers the rancor that marked the poisoning, when protesters, including the man who would become Mayor two years later, were arrested after chaining themselves to a buoy in the middle of the lake.
With the railroad and logging industries that made Portola run nearly dead now, the city gains most of its revenue from tourists who come for the prime fishing in Lake Davis.
So though many residents are exasperated by the recent pike discovery, the town is officially accepting the Fish and Game Department's offer to work together.
In one sense, the city has no choice: the state has final jurisdiction over its lakes and the tributaries and rivers that flow out of them. These waterways are home to salmon and steelhead trout that bring California a billion dollars in revenue every year, Supervisor Roudebush said, and could be decimated should pike -- a razor-toothed predator known to eat snakes, rats and ducklings -- begin to live and breed in them.
Fish and game officials are using DNA tests to determine whether three fish caught at the end of May, one of which was carrying eggs that would spawn next spring, survived the chemical dump or were put in the lake by fishermen who enjoy the difficult catch and meaty taste.
But officials are sure that regardless, pike, which are native to cold waters in the Midwest, were at one time illegally introduced to Lake Davis.
They are also determined to find out who did it and when. (Pike were first found in Lake Davis in 1994.) For the last month, game wardens have been conducting an extensive search for leads into what officials call a crime of eco-terrorism.
The state and city have put up a $30,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of people responsible for planting pike in Lake Davis.
Since the latest pike were caught, more than 30 game wardens have been dispatched to knock on doors here, search catches and survey those who fish.
Other fish and game officials in Sacramento are contacting fisheries across the nation that sell pike and combing Internet chat rooms that specialize in fishing, looking for people bragging about catching pike in California.
"There are people out there who want to see pike in Lake Davis," said Steve Martarano, an information officer with the department.
Leads have turned up nothing; the closest officials came was searching a man's house after he took responsibility on a Reno radio station for planting the pike. Patrick Foy, a fish and game spokesman, said the caller had lied on the air to get attention.
Of course, the greatest concern to residents here is whether there are more pike in Lake Davis and, if so, whether the painful memories of the poisoning will have to be relived.
Local officials have gone on "electro-fishing" tours of the lake, in which fish and game officers temporarily stun fish in a small area with electric shocks and then check the surface for pike.
Options short of poisoning the lake, should more pike be found, include draining it, which would also affect tourism but would be easier to recover from, or putting strong screens or sharp gates over the lake's dam, which officials hope would prevent any pike from going downstream.
Though the focus is on the future of Lake Davis and Portola, residents here recognize the need to eliminate pike from the state.
People here also say they are dealing with an entirely new Fish and Game Department this time around.
"Last time, fish and game stepped on our throats and told us what to do," said Terri Nacar, an editor of The Portola Reporter, who sharply criticized the department in print in 1997. "This time they have a totally different attitude."
For now, residents take heart in the fact that the lake is full of fish and that even at midmorning on a weekday, a parking lot by one of the its ramps was packed with pickup trucks towing boat trailers.
"We're doing excellent, excellent, up here at Lake Davis," said Lloyd Lambeth, who works at the Gold Rush Sporting Goods Store.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Just Not You

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"Somebody's going to win the lottery," reads an ad from a public-spirited corporation, "Just not you."
That's right. If any class of gamblers qualifies as super-suckers, it's the pack of dreamers who believe what their state governments tell them about a pot of gold at the end of the numbers rainbow. 
 Media that benefit from state lottery advertising hype the one winner (not you) in a million. They ignore the bad news of all the others who blow the bread money, or feed their compulsive-gambling habit, on the worst odds of any betting in America.
 Ever since the immoralists of New Hampshire introduced a state lottery in 1964, followed quickly by New York in 1966, pusillanimous politicians have been ripping off their constituents with this "painless taxation." Now 37 states are imitating the banana republics.
The profits go to education, the gambling governors claim, as they substitute lottery money for other state education aid in a classic bait-and-switch. It's the only tax increase that conservatives support -- from zero to $43 billion in one generation -- and is the only regressive tax embraced by liberals.
The bipartisan National Gambling Impact Study Commission has issued its report. At the start, members fought over whether to call gambling "gaming," but in the end, agreement on more important matters was found: 15 million Americans are "problem gamblers." The Internet is hooking teen-agers on games of chance. "Convenience gambling" with video poker terminals everywhere is a training ground for lifelong gambling. (Even the kid in the new "Star Wars" is taught to gamble.)
After a decade of feckless harangues in this space, I have accepted reality: at least half the population enjoys betting. So if you want to feed quarters for hours on end to one-armed bandits in Las Vegas, or go broke on jackpot.com, that's your business.
But when the state becomes croupier, that's everybody's business.
The most telling part of the wake-up call is the criticism of lotteries. They are "the most widespread form of gambling in the United States." State governments have "irresponsibly intruded gambling into society on a massive scale," says the commission report, "through such measures as incessant advertising and the ubiquitous placement of lottery machines in neighborhood stores."
And they're a lousy bet. "Lotteries bring out the worst in politicians," noted Richard Leone, commissioner from New Jersey. "They are heavily and misleadingly advertised; they pay back to bettors the smallest share of the take of any legal game . . . yet lotteries have proven to be catnip for elected officials who fear taxation."
Where does any state come off urging its citizens to spend their hard-earned income or welfare checks unwisely? Who is your governor to tell you to ignore your economic self-interest and take a little flier with him or her? Government is not a game, nor should it be a casino empowered to declare itself a monopoly so it can make a profit by stimulating public avarice.
State lotteries should reduce their sales dependence on low-income, less-educated gamblers, the commission recommends, and limit advertising and sales outlets in poor neighborhoods. But that's precisely where the most business is. And because states advertise their lotteries, the Supreme Court strikes down state restrictions on advertising any gambling.
Thus does the lottery tail now wag the public-policy dog. To make a bigger profit, state-sponsored gambling must sell harder to the poor and the addicted. Your state legislator is facing the same moral conflict as the seller of tobacco and hard liquor and violent movies: trying to make what's bad for you look good to you. The difference is that the state does not permit competition in its own numbers racket.
The state belongs in the business of protecting and educating the public, not in the profitable dodge of bilking the public. Residents of Nevada have their law legalizing prostitution, but do not expect their state to run monopoly brothels advertised on local television with a small portion of the profit supposedly going to sex education.
O.K., all you family-values, faith-based types running for President and governor and whatnot. Where do you stand on state-sponsored gambling? How about a national lottery guessing the number of eligible voters not casting their ballots because they're turned off by political hypocrisy? 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BLUEPRINT;
Reform Urged as Condition For Yugoslavia to Get Aid

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: COLOGNE, Germany, June 20

 BODY:
Leaders of the seven wealthiest nations and Russia outlined a plan today for ending eight years of war in the Balkans through a vast program of aid and political support, but said Yugoslavia must undertake "democratic and economic reforms" to take part.
At the end of a three-day summit meeting, the leaders of Britain, France and Germany said that in their view, democratic reform in Yugoslavia would have to involve the departure of President Slobodan Milosevic, but in deference to Russia no explicit reference to him was included in the final statement. 
 President Clinton advocated a meeting of Western and regional leaders in the Balkans in the next few months and said he would attend. Such a meeting, unprecedented since Yugoslavia began to unravel in violence in 1991, would show a commitment to draw the Balkans into the West and highlight Mr. Milosevic's isolation, Western officials said. "The President got agreement from the leaders that there should be a Balkan conference, in the Balkans, sometime in the not-too-distant future," said Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser.
The exact amounts involved in Balkan reconstruction are still vague. The European Union has pledged $500 million a year for the next three years for Kosovo alone; Western officials say as much as $30 billion over the next five years may be needed for the region as a whole.
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, looking puffy and uncertain on his feet, joined the other leaders today for the concluding hours of the summit meeting and then talked for an hour with President Clinton.
In an effort to cast the encounter with Mr. Yeltsin in positive terms, Western leaders including Mr. Clinton avoided reference to contentious issues such as what sort of aid -- if any -- should be given to Serbia and what sort of orders were givento the Russian troops who raced to the airport in Pristina earlier this month.
As a result, there were no visible disagreements, and the meeting of the leaders of the United States, Britain, Germany, France, Canada, Italy, Japan and Russia ended about an hour earlier than expected.
The positive, sometimes patently relieved tone of the meeting seemed to reflect a growing conviction that the ethnic wars in the region that have left more than 200,000 people dead and forced millions of people from their homes may at last have exhausted themselves.
The final statement called for "the creation of a democratic, multi-ethnic Kosovo." It added: "The return of refugees and displaced persons to their homes and the assurance of security for all persons including Serb and all other minorities in Kosovo will be high priorities of the international community."
Many Serbs, afraid of reprisals from returning Kosovo Albanians, have fled since the 11-week war ended. Serbian authorities arenow urging them to go back, and several hundred reportedly did so today.
The statement said the eight countries would "fully cooperate with the work of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia," which indicted Mr. Milosevic last month. But it made no reference to the acts of Serbian forces in Kosovo during the war.
Gerhard Schroder, the German Chancellor, said of Serbia that, "Reconstruction aid, reestablishment of economic structures and reincorporation into Europe need democratization, and that is not possible with Mr. Milosevic."
But because of disagreements with Russia, which wants Serbia to receive broad assistance, the leaders' statement contained no details of how the billions of dollars of planned aid should be distributed.
In practice, the leaders of the richer nations, the Group of Seven, but not Russia, agreed that only basic emergency assistance -- food, shelter and medicine -- should be given to Serbia while Mr. Milosevic remains in power. Britain expressed the view that even this kind of aid was excessive and unjustifiable.
"I don't believe people would understand if we put money into an undemocratic Serbia under Milosevic," Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said. "Nobody can shut their eyes to the fact that thousands were butchered with unforgivable barbarism in Kosovo, and we cannot start giving money to those that perpetrated these barbarities.
"Our plea to the people of Serbia is that you can be part of a prosperous Balkan future, but first embrace values of democracy and civilization that are incompatible with having an indicted war criminal at the head of your country," he said.
Germany, which earlier this month drew up a so-called Stability Pact to aid the Balkan countries, said it had agreed to Mr. Clinton's request that it organize the Balkan summit conference.
The leaders said today that the World Bank and the European Commission would coordinate efforts to raise money for Balkan reconstruction. An initial conference on emergency aid will be held in July.
Michael Steiner, the chief diplomatic adviser to Mr. Schroder, said that money would be used as a political weapon to isolate Mr. Milosevic. Aid would be channeled to Kosovo, Montenegro and even perhaps areas of Serbia itself run or controlled by opposition parties. "Of course, there is a danger that some of this may seep to Belgrade, but that should not stop us targeting the areas we want to help, and so illustrating that democracy pays," he said.
President Jacques Chirac of France said all the countries of the Balkans could now aspire to membership in the European Union, but added that the bloc "is not prepared to import conflict into its midst."
"The countries in the area should take an example from Romania, which wants to join the European Union and has therefore resolved its problems with its ethnic Hungarian minority," he said.
Asked about Mr. Milosevic, Mr. Chirac added: "Serb forces in Kosovo probably obeyed orders and certainly responded to instincts that were inadmissible and intolerable. The Serbian people should now draw the appropriate political conclusions.

HEADLINE: Snag Arises in State Plan For Electric Competition

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 17

 BODY:
An important element of the Pataki administration's plan to lower electricity rates through competition has hit a serious snag: no state agency is legally authorized to give permission to build new power plants.
The problem could be solved with a simple piece of legislation, but in Albany these days, there is no such thing. The Pataki administration proposed a bill this week to resolve the impasse, but the bill is under attack by environmentalists and Democratic legislators. 
 Power companies have applied to build four new plants -- including a floating plant off the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn -- and expand two existing ones. A half-dozen more applications are expected in the next year. One company, U.S. Generating Company, a subsidiary of Pacific Gas & Electric, is ready to begin work on a major new plant in Athens, 30 miles south of Albany, awaiting only permits that, without the current impasse, the state could issue this summer.
But lawmakers and industry analysts say it is likely that those companies will spend the rest of the year, at least, waiting for politicians to resolve their differences. Regulators and the electric industry say new plants are crucial to the new, deregulated power market because they will promote competition and lower energy prices.
"The new plants for the next generation are going to be built in the next two years, as the market opens up," said Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, a Democrat who is chairman of the Energy Committee. "If they're blocked in New York, they'll get built elsewhere, and we will miss out on the economic benefits."
As much as anything, this is a tale of Albany foul-ups dating back more than a decade, and of the current gridlock between Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, and Democrats in the Legislature over just about every significant issue.
Under Federal law, any new power plant or expansion of an existing plant requires permits showing that it would comply with the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act. In each state, the Environmental Protection Agency delegates to a state agency the power to issue those permits.
In the 1980's, New York created a power plant siting board, and the E.P.A. gave it the authority to issue those permits. But the law was written to lapse at the end of 1988. In Albany, factions often add such "sunset clauses" to each other's bills to gain future leverage over the bill's sponsors.
Since no one was clamoring to build new power plants in the 1980's, state officials barely gave a thought to the law's expiration. Then, in 1992, lawmakers created a new siting board, assuming that it would inherit the powers of the old one.
By late last year, New York's moves to introduce competition to the electric power industry had encouraged several companies to propose new and expanded power plants, and they applied to the new siting board for permits.
But in February, the E.P.A. notified the state that the new siting board had no power to issue permits. The agency said it had given that right to the old board, and that the authority was not automatically inherited by the new board.
The E.P.A. added that it did not think the new board had adequate resources to review applications. Federal officials said they would be willing to give the state's Department of Environmental Conservation the power to issue permits, but state law reserved that right for the siting board.
The E.P.A. could issue the permits, itself, but it warned that would take two years.
"No one can quite believe the state got itself in this situation," said Cara Lee, president of Scenic Hudson, an environmental group following the power plant proposals.
Environmentalists seized on another Albany axiom, that difficult decisions are made only when related issues can be linked and a deadline is looming. As long as the state needed a new law on permitting new plants, they argued, why not attach a requirement that older power plants meet the same pollution standards as new ones?
There are no environmental standards for plants that predate the 1970 Clean Air Act, and they are a leading source of air and water pollution. Compared with the coal-fired plants built in the 1940's and 1950's, new plants produce about 75 percent less sulfur dioxide, 40 percent less nitrogen oxide, and 25 percent less carbon dioxide.
An older plant can consume over 200 billion gallons of water a year for cooling, killing millions of fish as they are sucked in, and killing still more by pumping heated water into an adjoining river or lake. A comparable new plant takes in 2 billion to 3 billion gallons a year.
But in its new bill, the Pataki administration does not deal with standards for older plants. It would give the Department of Environmental Conservation the power to issue permits for new plants, and adds some new wording to the law governing environmental standards for those plants.
"It's an insult to everybody who breathes," said Larry Shapiro, a senior lawyer at the New York Public Interest Research Group who closely follows electric power issues. "Here was this huge opportunity, and they blew it."
The Governor's office declined to comment on the bill, directing inquiries to the Public Service Commission, which oversees the power industry.
"We're willing to listen to other ideas," said David Flanagan, spokesman for the commission, "but the bottom line is, this legislation sets stricter environmental standards than have ever existed in New York State for siting power plants."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DIPLOMACY;
U.S. AND RUSSIANS STRIVE TO REPAIR FRAYED RELATIONS

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: COLOGNE, Germany, June 20

 BODY:
The reasonable face of Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin, walked stiffly, but his presence here today was enough to reassure President Clinton and other Western leaders that dialogue with Moscow was possible in the aftermath of the Kosovo war.
After weeks of tensions since the start of the war, culminating in an unnerving standoff between Russian and NATO troops at the main airport in Kosovo, the Russian and American leaders met today and decided to let bygones be bygones, according to Mr. Clinton's aides. 
 "I think we're actually in a position to have a stronger relationship with Russia in the future than before the conflict started," Mr. Clinton said after their hourlong session.
Trying to give a fresh start to the frayed relationship, the aides said, the two leaders instead focused their discussions on the Russian economy, Moscow's sharing of nuclear technology with Iran, and arms control.
Russia, in a joint statement, agreed for the first time to begin discussions on changes to the linchpin accord on nuclear weapons between the two countries, something Mr. Clinton has desired.
The encounter between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin, their first since the President was in Moscow last September, was set in the context of the summit meeting of the world's seven leading industrial nations and Russia, the so-called Group of Eight.
Russia was included in the prestigious Group of Seven several years ago as a way of showing that Moscow counted as a major power, and Mr. Yeltsin's appearance, truncated to about seven hours and uncertain until the last moment due to the precariousness of his health, was as important for him as it was for the West.
"We need to make up after our fight," Mr. Yeltsin said of the heated differences between the NATO allies and Russia over Kosovo.
Although he and Mr. Clinton set Kosovo aside in their direct discussions, together the summit leaders outlined plans for a vast program of aid and political support for the Balkans that would exclude Yugoslavia until it undertakes democratic reforms. Page A8.
The leaders were relieved and grateful today after having watched the roller coaster behavior of Russia over Kosovo -- helpful, then obstinate, over the peacekeeping role of its troops, and then helpful again in arriving at a solution two days ago.
As a traditional ally of Serbia, Russia vehemently opposed NATO's bombing campaign. But the Group of Eight has been one of the chief channels for using Russia as a bridge between NATO and the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic. Today, at least, the group's leaders appeared to reap a payback from a cooperative, engaged Mr. Yeltsin.
Appearing buoyed by today's encounter with the Russian President, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said the meeting was "one of the best" the two leaders have held.
Despite the concerns about the health of Mr. Yeltsin, who has had a history of heart ailments and appeared wooden in his movements today, Mr. Clinton described the Russian leader as "clear, concise, direct and strong," in an interview afterward with CNN.
As for the other allies, the French President, Jacques Chirac, spoke warmly of "reconciliation" between Russia and the West. But the leaders, reflecting their underlying uncertainty about Russia's political future, offered only modest economic assistance.
In the final communique today, Russia was urged to step up its economic reforms so it could meet requirements set by the International Monetary Fund for an agreement on a $4.5 billion loan. Only after the agreement with the fund was in place, should the Paris Club of creditors "act expeditiously" to reschedule Russia's debt, the communique said.
The plan for this debt relief was a "little thank you by the West" for Russia's final role in resolving the Kosovo crisis, Karl Kaiser, a German foreign ministry official, said today.
Almost half of Russia's total debt of about $150 billion is owed to Germany and further debt relief would require a "green light" from the German Government, Mr. Kaiser said. So far, such a go-ahead was not in sight, he added.
In the last several weeks, as the negotiations over Kosovo went up and down, the White House had prepared several possible outcomes for the meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin. The worst case, some officials said, would have been a total blowup.
Until almost the last moment, it looked as though the two would talk almost exclusively about Kosovo and conclude an agreement on how Russian soldiers would operate with NATO in the province. But with Mr. Yeltsin apparently giving the order to settle the talks in Helsinki before the summit meeting today, the way was cleared, according to Mr. Berger, for the two countries to be "back in business."
In their face-to-face meeting held in an bland conference room in a local hotel where the Russian delegation was staying -- a locale chosen so Mr. Yeltsin would not have to move around too much -- Mr. Clinton reiterated the position of the other summit leaders on economic issues.
Russia must meet the revenue raising requirements set by the I.M.F. in order to start the disbursement of the $4.5 billion loan, Mr. Clinton said. Mr. Berger quoted Mr. Yeltsin as saying: "I am personally committed" to completing the I.M.F. agreement.
In agreeing in the joint Russian-American statement to discuss the Antiballistic Missile Treaty between the two countries, Mr. Yeltsin acceded to a process that the Russians had previously refused to consider, Administration officials said.
The Administration wants to start the discussions because modifications to the treaty are needed if a decision is made to deploy the national missile defense system proposed by Mr. Clinton in January.
Mr. Yeltsin, the statement also said, pledged to work toward the ratification of the Start 2 treaty -- stalled by Russia's Communist-dominated Parliament, a pledge the Yeltsin Government has made many times before. The two sides also agreed to continue discussions on the Start 3 treaty, which aims to reduce both sides' nuclear arsenals.
Administration officials said Mr. Yeltsin raised the issue of Congress lifting the Jackson-Vanik Act, a 1974 law that bars an automatic grant to Russia of normal trading relations with the United States because of Moscow's Soviet-era refusal to permit freedom of emigration.
Russia has been declared eligible for normal trading relations status, even though the law remains on the books, so the law has little practical effect. Recent expressions of anti-Semitism by Communist Party politicians in Russia have made Congress reluctant to repeal the law, officials said.
When told that those Russian politicians were blocking congressional actions, Mr. Yeltsin, according to a White House official, replied: "Give me the names. I will grind them down and come at them like a ton of bricks."
On the question of Russian helping Iran with nuclear technology, Mr. Yeltsin said he wanted to be cooperative in solving the problem, Administration officials said. The Russian President said he wanted to revive cooperation between Vice President Al Gore and the former Russian Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin by including the new Prime Minister, Sergei V. Stepashin. The arms issues could be dealt with in this way, Mr. Yeltsin said.
As a special gesture to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Yeltsin presented the President with documents on President Kennedy and his assassination. The documents had been declassified by Russian military and civilian archives at Mr. Yeltsin's request in the last several years, Mr. Berger said.
In the interview with CNN's Late Edition, Mr. Clinton expanded on his thinking at the start of NATO's air campaign and on his foreign policy generally. Asked if he thought the bombing of Serbia would last 78 days before Mr. Milosevic agreed to NATO's terms, he said, "I thought that there was maybe a 50 percent chance it would be over in a week."
But he added: "I knew if he decided to take the punishment of the air campaign, it could go a long -- quite a long -- while."
Asked if there was a doctrine that best characterized his foreign policy, Mr. Clinton said it was that "whether within or beyond" a country's borders, "if the world community has the power to stop it, we ought to stop genocide and ethnic cleansing."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1857 words

HEADLINE: Episode 1: The Phantom Film Studio;
Hopes and Doubts Greet a Plan for Sound Stages at the Brooklyn Navy Yard

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
To skeptics it is too big, too far, too speculative and, coming at a time when sound stages are sitting empty across Los Angeles, altogether too much: the kind of boom-era bubble likely to pop as soon as it hits the first sharp object or dissonant breeze.
But like a particularly tangled Hollywood potboiler, the proposal to build a mammoth movie-making complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard continues to lurch along, navigating a wall of worry while it is propelled by a big-name steamroller. 
 It is still not entirely clear whether the proposal backed by Robert De Niro's TriBeCa Productions and Harvey Weinstein's Miramax Films will go forward, and what it would mean for the other sound-stage projects being proposed in New York. Potential lenders are still studying the Navy Yard proposal, which was announced in May and has commitments for less than half the $150 million in financing it needs to go forward.
But there is no question that there has never been more interest in building movie studios in New York since the industry left for California at the beginning of the century, and that the outsize aspirations of the Navy Yard project parallel the growth of the film business in the city over the last decade. Less clear is whether that growth will continue and whether there is enough business for the proposed projects.
In particular, skeptics wonder if there would be enough filmmaking for the 12 sound stages envisioned for the Navy Yard, if people would travel to Brooklyn and if the current glut in Los Angeles should be a warning for New York.
"Over the last 20 years there have been a lot of projects announced, and most of them never happened, so until someone puts a shovel in the ground, you can't be sure of anything," said Pat Scott, Commissioner of the city Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. "But we keep losing work because we can't supply the facilities, and it's absurd to have the talent and the creativity here and not have the right facilities."
There is some logic in developing some sort of studio project at the Navy Yard, which was founded in 1801, saw employment peak at 71,000 in World War II and was shut down in 1966. The city purchased the site between the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges across from Manhattan's Lower East Side in 1970, and since then employment -- in industries that include offices, ship repair and manufacturing of products that range from housing to Sweet 'n Low to shrouds -- has bounced around at a few thousand jobs. The number has been creeping up in recent years, and the city has approved $40 million to upgrade the waterfront, buildings and electrical and water systems on the site's 169 acres.
But nothing in the hodgepodge of warehouses, offices and industrial sites bears any resemblance to the ambitious plan to build a movie-making complex on 15 acres that now stand largely empty except for three hulking structures once used to store and manufacture parts for World War II battleships and aircraft carriers. The project, with a dozen sound stages and 700,000 square feet over all, would be the largest by far in the city, and would be expected to spawn spinoff businesses to create a permanent filmmaking infrastructure.
 
Numbers Show Industry Growth
The best argument for the site is the current boom in film activity in New York. City figures indicate that a record 221 films were shot in New York last year, generating $2.57 billion in economic activity. It was the fifth straight record-breaking year. The number of days films were shot in New York increased by 50 percent over the past five years, and direct expenditures on filmmaking have risen 78 percent. Over the last year alone, the number of prime-time television series filmed in New York climbed to 10 from 6.
But New York has only 600,000 square feet of sound stages for major productions, Ms. Scott said, while Los Angeles has about 3.7 million.
People in government and the industry agree that there is enormous demand for the kind of stages being contemplated, and that having people like Mr. De Niro, Mr. Weinstein and the developer Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, behind the project gives it a credibility earlier projects did not have.
"When you have people involved who can generate their own production and co-production like Tribeca and Miramax, you're just immediately on another level," Ms. Scott said.
Filmmakers tend to come to New York to shoot on location and then do indoor and post-production work in Los Angeles or increasingly in Canada, where costs are lower than in New York or Los Angeles. But if better space were available, it is likely that more would be willing to do that work in New York as well, filmmakers say. They say it makes enormous sense to do both in one place, so if, for example, bad weather scuttles outdoor shooting, a production can move indoors for the day rather than wasting it. Working in one place also cuts down on having two production offices and other expenses.
And the Navy Yard, in many ways, is a tantalizing option. It has the kind of vast expanses and room for support and satellite businesses almost impossible to find in New York or Los Angeles. Existing buildings at the Navy Yard have already been used for filming. Because of the investment approved by the city, the proposed complex would have the kind of advanced fiber optic and telecommuncations equipment needed. And as a municipally owned site it has an owner desperate to make the site work.
 
'All It Takes Is a Little Vision'
"I know I sound like a Pollyanna, but this is going to happen," said Marc H. Rosenbaum, president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, which was established by the city to run the Navy Yard, as his van skirted potholes and puddles at the site, which is as glamorous as a sewer pipe but nonetheless employs 3,000 people in 200 businesses that would coexist with the movie complex. "All it takes is a little vision."
Still, vision can be a little clouded for New York's film industry. After all, the local film business boomed in the 1970's and early 80's, collapsed in the face of disputes with unions in the late 80's and early 90's and has come roaring back in recent years. Similar deals with less high-powered backing have regularly collapsed over the past 15 years. And some wonder if the digital era will lessen the need for huge sound stages.
The most recent mega-plan, by an independent film production company, the Shooting Gallery, called for building 15 sound stages for $75 million in an old industrial park in Harrison, N.J. That was scrapped for a much more modest project in lower Manhattan. Similarly, the original proposal for the Navy Yard by two young promoters, Louis Madigan and Cory Dean Hart, foundered, and without the Miramax and De Niro names it seems unlikely that investors for the project would have been found.
Even producers who would like to see the additional space say sound stages have little appeal to lenders, who would rather build an office or apartment building than a sound stage with no guarantee that it can withstand cyclical ups and down of the movie industry.
"I think it would be great if it happened," said Ilene Landress, producer of the television series "The Sopranos," which is filmed at Silvercup Studios, at a former bread bakery in Long Island City, Queens. "But I might be retired by the time it does, and I'm not old. The problem is you need to find someone with a lot of money for a project like this, and there are so many other businesses that make more sense than building black boxes for sound stages."
There are other reasons to be wary. Filmmakers consistently express a preference for Manhattan, and an aversion to fighting bridge and tunnel traffic to Brooklyn. Even the two existing sound stage complexes in Queens, Silvercup and Kaufman Astoria Studios, have far better access to public transportation than the Navy Yard does.
Despite the city's efforts to spruce it up, the site is widely viewed as an eyesore, and is sometimes referred to as Dodge City because of the need to dodge trucks, cranes and heavy equipment. And many people are skeptical about the project's scope.
"I was struck by the notion of building 12 sound stages," said Phil Dixson, managing director of Televest, which produces soap operas for Procter & Gamble. "It sounds awfully ambitious to me. I could see three or four being booked up rather quickly. But I'm not sure how they came up with the number they did."
Compounding the uncertainties are expansion plans at other studios that could include five new studios at Silvercup, five at the proposed Hudson River Studios at Houston Street and one at Kaufman Astoria. Only Silvercup has begun construction.
Then there are the larger issues buffeting the industry.
"Right now studio space in Los Angeles is going begging, it's empty," said Tom Pollock, former head of Universal Pictures and currently the chairman of the American Film Institute. "And sound stages are not a way to make a lot of money. It's a rental business of small margins and fixed costs. You don't make money by owning the lot. You make it by owning the successful software, the successful movie."
 
Nominal Support, But No Commitment
Also in question is the need for big sound stages at a time when production can increasingly be done on computer screens.
The parties to the Brooklyn proposal are declining comment while the major potential financer, Union Labor Life Insurance Company, a union-supported pension fund, studies a potential $80 million investment in the deal. Absent that commitment, the deal remains nowhere near the financing needed to go forward. And for all their nominal support, neither Miramax nor Tribeca has made any binding commitments to use the site.
"Their announcement was the biggest non-announcement announcement I've ever seen," said one person in the film industry.
In addition to securing the rest of the money and the role of all the principals, the project must deal with Mr. Madigan and Mr. Hart, the promoters, who say they still hope to be a major part of the project.
The plan has a lot of constituencies. The New York film industry sees it as a catalyst for expansion. City officials see it as an economic development plum. Mr. De Niro and Miramax see it as a project that would make it easier for them to make movies in New York. And the the Union Labor Life Insurance Company would get both construction jobs and the possibility of future union jobs, though company officials take pains to say the project has to make economic sense on its own.
And the proposal may benefit from coming at precisely the right moment.
"The timing on this couldn't be better," said Dan Levinson, a producer and director who moved to Los Angeles from New York in 1987 and returned two years ago. "New York is hot. People really want to come here again. If the unions are smart and make some real concessions, I think New York can steal a lot of the business back from L.A. Will it happen? I don't know. But I wouldn't bet against Harvey Weinstein and Robert De Niro."

HEADLINE: Panel Calls for Study of Some Implant Risks

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
Members of an expert committee of scientists that assessed the safety of silicone breast implants formally issued their report today, calling for more research on risks of rupture and other local complications that can arise from the devices.
Although there is no scientific evidence pointing to silicone implants as the cause of major diseases, the scientists said, women who have breast implants, whether they are filled with silicone or salt water, have the right to know what the chances are that the devices will slip or deflate or lead to infections or scarring. 
 The committee was established by the Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences in response to a request by Congress in 1997. Its members had no connection to companies that manufacture implants or to lawyers representing women suing the companies and had taken no prior positions on the safety of silicone breast implants, said Dr. Kenneth Shine, the president of the Institute of Medicine.
After reviewing thousands of papers and documents submitted by scientists, implant makers and groups representing women who had implants, the group reached a unanimous consensus: the primary safety concern with implants is their tendency to cause local complications like infections, pain and scarring and the possibility that women might have to have second or even subsequent operations as a consequence.
The committee chairman, Dr. Stuart Bondurant, a professor of medicine at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, said the group heard women tell them in testimony and letters that they had not known that their implants could cause local problems.
"One of the notable things they told us is that they were told the implants would last a lifetime," Dr. Bondurant said. While emphasizing that that is the women's recollection, he noted that there were never any data to support such an assertion.
Dr. Virginia Ernster, a professor of epidemiology at the University of California at San Francisco, said that the best she could do in assessing the published data on the complications of implants was to come up with a range of risks.
Women who had implants to augment their breasts had about a 24 percent chance of needing to go back to the operating room in three to five years to repair problems or complications with implants, Dr. Ernster said. Those who had implants after a mastectomy had a 23 to 40 percent chance of needing a second operation in three to five years.
In recent years, most women who had implants have received devices filled with saline -- salt water -- rather than silicone, Dr. Bondurant said. Preliminary studies suggest that these devices have fewer complications, with just a 1 percent to 3 percent chance of deflation per year, he said, but more research is needed.
Sybil Goldrich, founder of Command Trust Network, an information clearinghouse for women with silicone problems, said in a telephone interview that rupture was "not a trivial problem."
Women whose implants rupture, she said, can "end up with a lifetime of medical bills that can be staggering."
The committee urged that women who have implants be tracked so investigators can get reliable data on the incidence of medical complications like rupture, scarring and infection. Such information "is an essential part of the informed consent process," the group said.
But the committee was insistent about what it described as its "very firm conclusions" on the diseases that some women and doctors have said were caused by implants -- a list that includes cancer, connective tissue diseases like arthritis and lupus, neurological problems, a new disease characterized by symptoms like fatigue and muscle aches and pains and diseases in the children of women with implants. These were the diseases at the heart of the multibillion-dollar product liability litigation over breast implants.
Dr. Bondurant said that the group concluded that "women with implants are no more likely than other women to develop these systemic illnesses." More than 60 women with implants testified before the committee in a public hearing and hundreds more wrote letters telling of the severe medical problems they had suffered since having their implants.
"We were very moved by the testimony we heard," Dr. Ernster said. "But it does not appear that the implants were the cause of the systemic illnesses."
Asked if another group of equally qualified and objective scientists could look at the same data and come to a different conclusion, Dr. Bondurant said, "No, I can't imagine that."

HEADLINE: Rebuilding Relations With Russia

 BODY:
Americans should be encouraged by the constructive tone of President Clinton's talks with Russia's President, Boris Yeltsin, in Germany Sunday. Moscow seems almost as eager as Washington to move beyond the tensions that resulted from NATO's bombing campaign against Yugoslavia.
But given the Russian leader's erratic policies and fragile health, there can be no assurance of things going smoothly. Both sides, but particularly Moscow, must follow through on Sunday's pledges on nuclear arms reductions, Russian economic reform, new talks on defensive missiles and curtailment of Russian nuclear cooperation with Iran. Promises have been made before, without results. 
 Russia's most urgent need is Western financial support. Mr. Yeltsin committed himself to achieve the improved tax collection and other reforms Moscow promised the International Monetary Fund in negotiations to release a new $4.5 billion loan installment. The United States and Europe are right to declare that they will reschedule their own loans to Russia only if Moscow first satisfies the I.M.F.
On arms, Mr. Yeltsin once again promised to try to get Russia's Parliament to ratify the long-stalled 1993 nuclear weapons treaty with the United States. Ratification would lead to sharp cuts in long-range missile forces and thus ease acute pressures on Russia's budget. Before the Kosovo crisis there were realistic hopes that the budgetary argument might sway enough votes to overcome nationalist and Communist opposition. That case can be strengthened if Washington and Moscow press ahead, as pledged, with talks on a new treaty authorizing even deeper nuclear weapons cuts.
Mr. Yeltsin pleased Washington by agreeing to open negotiations on modifying the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty in ways that might accommodate future American plans for a limited missile defense against countries like North Korea. He also renewed offers to work with the Clinton Administration on curbing Russian nuclear technology transfers to Iran. Over all, he seemed to recognize that Russia's own interests are best served by cooperative relations with the United States.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1767 words

HEADLINE: The Friendly Merger Banker;
At Chase, the Chairman Tries to Make All Sides Winners

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Early one morning about 10 years ago, Jack Welch, chief executive of the General Electric Company, waited for an elevator in the hallway outside his apartment in the Waldorf Towers in Manhattan.
Mr. Welch was feeling at the top of his game, bursting with confidence. Then the elevator doors opened. Deflated, he stood face to face with Walter Shipley, then head of the Chemical Banking Corporation, who at 6 feet 8 inches loomed a foot above him. 
 "I sort of stuck my thumb in my mouth and said, 'Gee, Walter, thank you for adding to all of my insecurities,' " Mr. Welch recalled in a recent interview.
Although few might have agreed at the time, given Chemical's financial woes, Mr. Welch accurately took Mr. Shipley's measure. Since that encounter, Mr. Shipley has quietly pulled off two of the biggest banking mergers in history, no mean feat in an industry that has seen many careers and companies derailed by bungled mergers. Chemical eventually became the Chase Manhattan Corporation and is now one of a handful of clear leaders in the rapidly changing financial services business.
And Mr. Shipley, who retired as Chase's chief executive on June 1 but will remain chairman for an undetermined time, now has some advice for deal meisters hoping to ride America's merger wave: slash-and-burn takeovers will come back to haunt you.
"Some people's philosophy is I win, you lose," he said. "Our philosophy is that the best is when both sides feel they've come out winners."
At first glance, Mr. Shipley, 63, is the least likely poster boy for the merger boom that has reshaped financial services and other major industries the last decade. Deliberate in his speech, modest and self-effacing to a fault and willing to share power, Mr. Shipley has not enjoyed the renown of chief executives like Citigroup's John Reed or Bank of America's Hugh McColl. But within banking circles, and in the broader reaches of corporate America, Mr. Shipley is widely admired.
"Walter has been able to do the deals he has because he has a very contained ego," said Lawrence A. Bossidy, chairman of Allied Signal Inc. "But he's also been able to get people to work very hard for him and get results. I don't think many other people in his seat could have accomplished what he's accomplished."
Perhaps most important, said executives who have worked closely with Mr. Shipley, is that he is anything but Machiavellian.
"This is a guy who is quietly capable, bright, sensitive, and a very good guy right down to his toes," Mr. Welch said. "I haven't had a dealing with him in which he wasn't completely straight up."
Certainly, despite Mr. Shipley's achievements, not all of Chase's holes have been plugged during his tenure.
William Harrison, Mr. Shipley's successor as chief executive, inherits a bank that is not big enough or profitable enough to be competitive in some key consumer businesses. On the corporate side, Chase still needs to buy an equity underwriting business at some point, though the bank said it feels no pressure to rush into a deal. Some community activists have criticized Chase's lending record in low-income areas, and Mr. Shipley himself said he wishes Chase had made greater progress in promoting women and members of minorities.
Still, Mr. Shipley leaves a formidable legacy. In 1990, the stock market collectively valued the three banks that now make up Chase -- Chemical, Chase and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation -- at about $4 billion. Today, the market values the company at more than $70 billion, testimony enough to how the bank's fortunes have changed since the dog days of the late 1970's and 1980's.
During those years, Chemical was often derided as "Comical." The bank, along with many of its competitors, suffered through a nightmare era of shoddy lending that called into question the survival of some of the country's largest banks, including Chemical -- and reaffirmed the popular image of bankers as slow-moving fumblers.
Bad overseas loans, many of them arranged when Mr. Shipley oversaw Chemical's international division, were not the bank's only problem. Deals that Mr. Shipley cut as Chemical's chief executive in the 1980's failed to meet expectations. Chemical's acquisition of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. in 1987 was seen as too pricey at the time and was undertaken shortly before Texas's high-flying oil and real estate markets collapsed. Smaller deals, like Chemical's takeover of Horizon Bancorp, a New Jersey bank, also misfired.
But as the economy began to surge in the early 1990's, and as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, adjusted interest rates to help banks recover, Mr. Shipley had the foresight and ability to place Chemical in the forefront of the merger boom. Much of his approach toward mergers was learned the hard way.
The son of a Wall Street investment banker who regularly surrounded his wife and four children with visitors from overseas, Mr. Shipley attended Williams College to study economics and political science. Although he shot hoops well enough to be named captain of the basketball team, off the court he was slipping. Bad grades forced him to leave Williams in 1956, during his junior year.
"I grew up in a family that put tight controls on kids, and so when I went away to school it was kaboom, I'm free," Mr. Shipley said. "I'd gotten through high school with ease, without ever having to really apply myself."
Mr. Shipley referred to his departure from Williams as a "wake-up call" that made him determined to prove to his family and friends that "I was better than I had demonstrated up until that time."
He joined the New York Trust Company in 1956 and later earned his undergraduate degree from New York University. In 1959, New York Trust was bought by Chemical, and many of Mr. Shipley's colleagues were shunted aside because they did not come from Chemical -- a disturbing episode he vowed not to repeat if he ever orchestrated a takeover.
"It was extremely influential in my thinking about how to do a merger," said Mr. Shipley, who rose through the ranks to become Chemical's chief executive. "If you simply work to create an environment based on meritocracy as opposed to one based on what your pedigree is, you create an environment where no one is unintentionally demotivated."
Above all, Mr. Shipley believed, mergers should be as friendly as possible. So when Chemical hitched up with Manufacturers Hanover in 1991, the deal that raised the curtain on the 1990's merger boom, Mr. Shipley agreed to take a back seat at first as president, letting John G. McGillicuddy of Manufacturers be chief executive. But he also insisted that the best people from each bank be given other top slots.
Mr. Shipley succeeded Mr. McGillicuddy in 1994 and a year later effected his second blockbuster deal, the $10 billion union with Chase, which secured the new bank's place in the top tier.
Although Chemical clearly took over Chase, Mr. Shipley adopted the Chase name and went out of his way to make a place for Chase's chief executive, Thomas Labrecque. He ultimately asserted that he and Mr. Labrecque should be considered equals.
"We wanted to create a new and better culture for a new and better bank," Mr. Shipley said. "Our idea is to create an environment where no one feels self-conscious about themselves or where they came from. I want them to feel self-conscious if their performance is not up to standard."
For those employees further down the totem pole, thousands of painful layoffs made the merger of Chase and Chemical far rockier. But the union was marked by an effort to make the job losses as humane as possible. The bank said that since the merger with Chase was completed in 1996, enough new jobs have been added so that the staff size has remained steady at about 72,000. Although plenty of higher-paying jobs were undoubtedly replaced by lower-paying ones, Chase also awarded stock options to remaining employees, options now worth tens of thousands of dollars to many of them.
Moreover, for all the drawbacks to the merger, Chase has been spared much of the prolonged turmoil of other banking mergers.
For example, when Wells Fargo & Company bought the First Interstate Corporation in 1996 in a hostile takeover, service disruptions and declining morale ate into the combined bank's profits. That forced Wells into a merger last year with the Norwest Corporation, ending Paul Hazen's tenure as chief executive.
Last year, the First Union Corporation, despite having a reputation as one of the most astute acquirers in banking and being led by a well-regarded chief executive, Edward Cutchfield Jr., badly botched its acquisition of the Corestates Financial Corporation. Profits have been hurt, employee morale is low, and First Union is now regarded as a potential takeover target.
Citigroup, while posting impressive earnings recently, is still trying to overcome the divisive turf disputes it has encountered since Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. merged last year. Other banks that have simply sat out the merger boom, including venerated titans like J. P. Morgan & Company, now run the risk of being marginalized because they are not large enough to compete.
But Mr. Shipley has recreated Chase as a true financial powerhouse with a global reach, particularly in areas like trading and corporate finance. Despite lingering skepticism among some analysts and investors about Chase's ability to maintain its robust profitability and avoid financial pitfalls -- skepticism heightened by the bank's role last year in the near-collapse of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund and its heavy reliance on volatile trading revenue -- the bank has repeatedly proved its mettle in recent years.
"Walter understands people very well, and he has built a very strong staff at that bank," said H. Rodgin Cohen, a lawyer specializing in mergers and acquisitions with Sullivan & Cromwell. "There's a very eclectic mix of people at Chase because Walter looks at people in terms of their talent, not what bank they came from."
Late last month, addressing hundreds of employees at an awards ceremony at Chase's New York headquarters, Mr. Shipley realized it would be the last time he appeared before the group as chief executive. As he digressed and told the throng how proud he was to have led them, he grew flustered. At that moment, the employees rose and gave him a standing ovation.
"I think people in the company feel good, and it wasn't always that way," Mr. Shipley said, recalling the incident. "I think people in Chase today feel proud."

HEADLINE: Budget Deficit Narrowed in May

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
The United States budget deficit shrank to $23.97 billion in May from $38.78 billion in May a year ago, the Treasury Department said today, keeping the Government on track for a second consecutive annual surplus.
In the first eight months of the fiscal year 1999, which began last Oct. 1, the Federal budget is in surplus by $40.71 billion, more than twice the $15.96 billion surplus posted in the comparable first eight months of the fiscal year 1998. 
 The Clinton Administration has forecast a surplus for the full current fiscal year of $79.3 billion. That would be up from $69.2 billion a year earlier, when the United States posted its first surplus since 1969.
Earlier this month, the Congressional Budget Office said it now anticipated the Federal surplus for the fiscal year 1999 to top its current estimate of $111 billion, but it will not give a revised figure until July.
The economy, now in its ninth year of expansion, has swelled Treasury's coffers with rising tax revenues from individuals and corporations.
If the Government records back-to-back surpluses for the fiscal years 1998 and 1999 -- as now appears certain -- it will be the first time since the late 1950's that it has done so.
Revenues in May increased to $98.59 billion from $95.28 billion a year earlier in May 1998.
At the same time, spending on all Government programs from defense to Social Security payments declined to $122.56 billion, from $134.06 billion in May 1998.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;
Job Oppty; Miracle Worker Preferred

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, June 21

 BODY:
Wanted: civil administrator for Kosovo. Employer: United Nations.
Qualifications: "Someone with high energy, with organizing skills, with vision, with the ability to communicate," President Clinton said today in Bonn, Germany. 
 Candidates: "I'd give anything if I could do it," Mr. Clinton said. "It's a wonderful job, if you think about it."
When Mr. Clinton was asked at a news conference with the German Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, who was going to get the job of running Kosovo, he almost volunteered himself.
In doing so, he was highlighting NATO's difficulties in coming up with a person who could fulfill the job description: restoring a destroyed and brutalized province to a level of economic and political well-being. The post -- akin to that of proconsul -- needs to be filled in a hurry, as Kosovo society tries to repair itself.
Mr. Clinton said Washington did not have a particular candidate. The European Union countries have made it clear that they want a European for the job. Their reasoning: Since Washington has agreed that Europe should foot the bill for the reconstruction, then a European should direct it.

HEADLINE: Microsoft's Final Antitrust Case Witness Stumbles a Bit

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation's final witness testified today that in his view of the world, the very actions that landed the company in court on antitrust charges have greatly benefited consumers, computer manufacturers and every company that is doing business on the Internet.
Richard L. Schmalensee, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is the last witness in the long- running antitrust trial, and the company is trying to use his testimony to rebut each of the principal charges the Government has raised in the last eight months. 
 He offered arguments and evidence making the case that nothing Microsoft had done had harmed consumers -- an important factor in the case. But in at least one instance, his strategy backfired.
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is hearing the case without a jury, sat impassively through the morning as Michael Lacovara, a Microsoft lawyer, tossed easy questions at the witness. But the judge stepped in with a telling question as Mr. Schmalensee was trying to demonstrate that Microsoft had not engaged in predatory conduct by including a Web browser with the Windows operating system at no charge.
Mr. Schmalensee was standing before a sketch board presenting theoretical examples of predatory and nonpredatory conduct. In his first case, a company sold a product below cost, driving another company out of business. That, Mr. Schmalensee said, was clearly predatory.
He had moved on to a more benevolent example, when Judge Jackson interrupted him, speaking up for the first time today to ask: "Why isn't what Microsoft did in this case a more egregious example of case one?"
Mr. Schmalensee stumbled for a moment but then said Microsoft gained many other benefits from including a Web browser in Windows. Later he pointed out that in classic economic theory, a predator lowers prices until the competition is weakened or destroyed and then raises them to recoup his lost profits.
But, he noted, Microsoft had not raised prices, even though Government witnesses have said the competition, the Netscape Communications Corporation, has been so greatly weakened that the browser war is over.
Outside the courtroom, Mr. Lacovara said: "He's the final witness, testifying about the whole scope of the case. And our strategy is trying to find out what is on the judge's mind so we can address it."
The last time Mr. Schmalensee took the stand, in January, David Boies, the Government's lead attorney, suggested that he was Microsoft's "house economist" and compared his testimony in this case with seemingly contradictory arguments he made in the past. The effect was to suggest that Mr. Schmalensee offered whatever opinion suited the need of the moment.
Today Mr. Lacovara tried to turn the tables. He offered as evidence a fat binder of comments, articles and opinions that the Government's economist, Franklin M. Fisher, another M.I.T. professor, had offered over the years. And Mr. Lacovara intended to have Mr. Schmalensee help him demonstrate that they included contradictions.
As Mr. Fisher sat just behind him in the audience, Mr. Boies objected, complaining that it was not fair to try to impeach Mr. Fisher's testimony after he had already left the stand. The judge appeared ready to agree when Mr. Lacovara backed down.
Later, Mr. Schmalensee quarreled with Mr. Fisher's testimony that an economist ought to consider a company's intent when determining whether it was engaging in predatory conduct. That was not proper, he suggested. But Judge Jackson told him, "You know, judging intent is what we do every day. Juries are called on to do it all the time."
At another point, however, the judge seemed to help Mr. Lacovara. The lawyer was trying to make the case that America Online, now that it has bought the Netscape company, was in a position to challenge Microsoft's dominance in browser and operating system software, despite America Online's protestations to the contrary.
He showed a document to the judge and the witness that America Online had insisted be held under seal. But the judge summarily unsealed it, saying there was no justification for the classification.
The document was the text of America Online's presentation to the board of directors for the November meeting at which the board would vote to approve the purchase. And it showed that the company planned to aggressively promote Netscape -- even though, in public, America Online executives have said the Netscape business is close to dead.
The company was "willing to spend up to $10 per download" of Netscape "via promotions, contests, incentives and advertising to stimulate downloads," the report to the board said.
Mr. Lacovara asserted that America Online would be unlikely to spend that money on a product that was dead.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
WeyerhaeuserAgrees to Buy MacMillan Bloedel for $2.45 Billion

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 21

 BODY:
Weyerhaeuser Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., one of the biggest forestry companies in western Canada, in a stock deal valued at $2.45 billion.
The acquisition, if approved by shareholders and regulators, would solidify the position of Weyerhaeuser, which is based in Tacoma, Wash., as the world's largest producer of softwood lumber and pulp and strengthen its business in fiberboard and packaging. 
 Weyerhaeuser's chairman, Steven R. Rogel, described the acquisition as "an excellent strategic combination," which will increase annual sales by about 25 percent, to $13.3 billion. Weyerhaeuser has 35,000 employees in North America, with 5,900 of them in Canada. MacMillan Bloedel, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, employs 9,500 in Canada and the United States.
Shareholders of MacMillan Bloedel will receive 0.28 of a share of Weyerhaeuser -- or the same amount of stock in a new Canadian subsidiary of Weyerhaeuser, permitting favorable tax treatment for Canadian shareholders. The boards of both companies have agreed to the acquisition.
Weyerhaeuser shares fell 3.8 percent, or $2.625, to close at $67.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. MacMillan Bloedel shares surged 23 percent, or $3.3906, to close at $17.8281 on the Nasdaq Stock Market.
Nick Majendie, a senior vice president at Canaccord Capital in Vancouver, said the acquisition by Weyerhauser was good for shareholders of MacMillan Bloedel because "in the natural resource sector, bigger tends to be better."
But he warned that British Columbia's nationalistic New Democratic Party government, which controls the province's forest resources, could fight the takeover of MacMillan Bloedel, as it has done in the past.
MacMillan Bloedel was once one of Canada's strongest forestry companies. But like others with core operations in British Columbia, it has been hurt in recent years by low commodity prices, forest policies adopted by the province's New Democratic Party government, lumber import restrictions by the United States and the economic crises of several Asian economies, which ordinarily are big buyers of North American wood products.
MacMillan Bloedel underwent a huge restructuring in 1997, cutting its work force by 30 percent and selling certain fiberboard operations. It had been seeking a buyer for its packaging division, which led to the offer from Weyerhaeuser.
The Canadian company lost $368 million (Canadian) in 1997 but earned $42 million (Canadian) last year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A Fund's Quick Slide From First to (Almost) Worst

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
In April, Janus 20 sat atop the mutual fund world. It was the best performer of any large stock fund, having doubled investors' money since the start of 1998. And it had taken in so much money so fast -- nearly $7 billion in four months -- that Janus said it would close the fund to "deliver superior performance."
Now, the fund has once more earned a prominent place on the performance charts -- this time, at the bottom. In fact, through Thursday, it ranked as the 15th-worst-performing general equity fund of 4,008 funds in the second quarter, according to Lipper, the Summit, N.J., mutual fund data company. 
 The fund's concentration in 20 to 30 stocks -- mostly big growth companies like America Online, Dell Computer, Microsoft and a handful of pharmaceutical companies -- carried it to lofty heights the last two years. But some of those same holdings proved a drag on performance this spring, when the strengthening global economy prompted investors to shift to shares of cyclical companies and other value stocks that had lagged behind the broader market.
So far this quarter, Janus 20 is down 4.4 percent, compared with a 5.2 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and an 10.9 percent gain in the Dow Jones industrial average. That was in spite of a bounce the last week that lifted the fund's return from a loss of 13.2 percent for the quarter.
The decline shows the pitfalls of buying funds that have concentrated bets in one sector, especially in a volatile area like technology. It also demonstrates what so often happens to investors who rush into a fund before it closes: They regret it. In fact, investors often pick exactly the wrong time to throw their money in.
In this case, new money had been accumulating at Janus 20, which is managed by the Janus Capital Corporation, a unit of Kansas City Southern Industries, at an average of nearly $500 million a week before the fund was closed. According to AMG Data Services, an Arcata, Calif., fund-tracking company, the inflow peaked the week ended April 14 -- the height of I.R.A. season -- with investors pouring in $654.6 million just as the fund's performance began to slide.
Fund investors "tend to be very poor buyers in terms of timing, and the more volatile the area, the worse their timing decisions usually are," said Scott Cooley, an analyst at Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund tracker. "There is a lot of risk in having all of your money pretty much in a specific style that is fairly volatile, and Janus has a lot of shareholders who have come to it recently."
Scott Schoelzel, the fund's manager, said yesterday that he was not altering his strategy. The portfolio is invested largely as it was at the start of the year, though Mr. Schoelzel said he had trimmed holdings in drug companies like Pfizer and Eli Lilly. "I should have recognized we were going to go into a period of time when the news flow from the pharmaceuticals was going to be less than upbeat," he said.
To complement the fund's biggest names, like America Online and Dell, Mr. Schoelzel said, he has been aggressively buying a few other large-capitalization growth stocks. He's also sitting on about 15 percent cash, though he says that's not a reflection of any bearishness.
"Realistically, I kind of expected there would be a period of time where the fund would have trouble," he said. "For the most part we didn't get shaken out of anything, but I've got to tell you, I have a lot more gray hair than I had in March."
The average stock in the fund is trading at close to 50 times earnings, according to Morningstar, high by almost any measure. Mr. Schoelzel's justification: Old valuation yardsticks do not mean much anymore. The market, he said, "is going to vacillate from being expensive to really expensive for a while."
He also does not buy the argument that investors ought to shift to stocks with lower valuations and cyclical stocks that rise with a strengthening economy. "It's amazing to me how panicky the market gets," he said, "to think we can change the direction" of the economy with the quarter-percentage-point rise in short-term interest rates that the Federal Reserve is expected to make at the end of the month.
Like Janus 20, many of the funds in the Janus group have their biggest positions in large-cap growth stocks, with a strong technology bent. The other funds have not taken such a beating, but as Janus 20 goes, so may they.
Janus, which is based in Denver, has a deep stable of analysts and more stock-picking talent than most firms, Mr. Cooley of Morningstar said. "But it's still very dangerous from a firm-wide perspective to have so many eggs in one basket," he added.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: PRESIDENT;
Clinton Lauds Slovenes for Resisting Serbs

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, June 21

 BODY:
This tiny new nation perched on the Adriatic was held up today by President Clinton as a shining example of what was possible if a people decided to stand up to the ethnic terror of Slobodan Milosevic.
He came here, Mr. Clinton said, to draw attention to the fact that Southeastern Europe, now the favored name for the Balkans, could produce a country that is free and prosperous. Slovenia, Mr. Clinton added, had shown that it was possible to reject "the murderous rule" of Mr. Milosevic, the Yugoslav President. 
 Serbia has to "choose the path that Slovenia has chosen, where people reach across the old divides and find strength in their differences and their common humanity," Mr. Clinton said to a crowd of several thousand in the city square who had waited for hours in the rain.
Mr. Clinton's trip to Europe has centered on finding ways to rescue the debris caused by the conflict in Kosovo, patching together plans for aid packages to Kosovo and the rest of the region and mending the relationship with Russia.
By choosing the little known country of Slovenia, Mr. Clinton was trying to stress the positive. In June 1991, Slovenia declared independence from Yugoslavia, and when Mr. Milosevic sent in the Yugoslav Army, the Slovenians stood firm under the leadership of Milan Kucan, who is now President and whom Mr. Clinton met today. After what became known as a largely bloodless 10-day war, Slovenia declared independence.
Mr. Clinton congratulated the Slovenes, saying: "Eight years ago, Mr. Milosevic triggered a military assault on your nation. But you resisted. You secured your freedom. And you proclaimed it will never be the same again."
But in singling out Slovenia, Mr. Clinton dwelled on a place with unusual characteristics in the former Yugoslavia. Slovenia, a country of two million people, is almost ethnically and religiously unified. About 2 percent of the population are Serbs, and the country is overwhelmingly Roman Catholic. The Slovenes are proud of their own language, a Slavic language written in the Roman script, dating from the 12th century.
Since separating from Yugoslavia, Slovenia's economy has bounded ahead. The European Union granted Slovenia associate status, and the country is trying to meet targets that would allow it to join the European Union early in the next century.
In some ways, Mr. Clinton's trip was a reward for a large disappointment. Slovenia had banked on joining NATO, and its rejection for membership, along with Romania, several years ago, was a severe blow. Mr. Clinton tried to assuage the blow by saying today that Slovenia was "an excellent candidate for NATO." But he promised no more. When NATO will formally decide to expand further, after accepting Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic as members this year, remains an open question.
Mr. Clinton arrived from Bonn, Germany, where he attended a meeting of the United States and the European Union on trade and other issues. Near the top of the agenda again was organizing the reconstruction of Kosovo and the Balkans.
In Bonn, Mr. Clinton said he was in favor of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's idea of bringing leaders together in Sarajevo, perhaps as early as next month, to plan for the Balkans' future. Mr. Clinton said the gathering should be modeled after the development of the Marshall Plan, when the benefactors met with the devastated countries in Europe after World War II and fashioned a far-reaching rebuilding program.
