HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE SEPARATISTS;
Rebel General Planning A New Army for Kosovo

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Kosovo, June 21

 BODY:
The chief of the general staff of the Kosovo Liberation Army already has the formation of a future army for Kosovo planned out, even as he is preparing to disarm and demobilize his guerrilla force.
The rebel official, Gen. Agim Ceku, arrived today in Pristina, the Kosovo capital, dressed in his military fatigues, the red and yellow rebel insignia on his cap and sleeve, to mark the signing of the agreement to demilitarize. 
 General Ceku, 38, has emerged in the last three months as the leading military figure of the Albanian separatist force in Kosovo. He is the man who negotiated the bulk of the agreement on demilitarization, and who will be responsible for carrying it outwith Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Jackson, the commander of the Kosovo peacekeeping force.
In an interview today, he said he had no doubt that Kosovo would need its own army for its future defense, and he mapped out his vision for such a force in detail.
He said he would seek to form "a defensive army from a small number of soldiers, respecting our economic resources, the level of danger we face and the demographics of Kosovo."
He said that under his plan, a Kosovo army would have a small active core of professional soldiers and a larger component of reserves. He said he also envisioned an "intervention unit," similar to the National Guard in the United States.
As he sees it, such a fighting force would be formed within the contours of collective security in Europe, since Kosovo would want to take part in Western European alliances, he said.
"We will respect all the standards of NATO, at the same time staying loyal to our national and historical traditions," he said.
General Ceku, a Kosovo Albanian, got his military training in the Yugoslav Army under the former Communist government. In 1991, as several of the republics that had been part of Yugoslavia declared their independence, he joined the Croatian Army and was rapidly promoted to the rank of general. He resigned his commission there to return, in March, to fight against Serbian forces with the Kosovo rebels. He was appointed their chief of staff in April.
The general said the decision to demilitarize had been a very hard one for the rebels. He said that "one of the biggest victories of the war was that for the first time" Kosovo Albanians had their own fighting force, adding: "And every decision that is made to lower the standing of the army is really hard. But all the soldiers of the K.L.A. and the people of Kosovo, we all want to be part of the democratic world, and every decision of the international community is an obligation for us too, even when it is not in our favor."
The commanders and their men would comply with the agreement to disarm, he said, because the international community had guaranteed to take into consideration the rebels' experience and role in the conflict when recruiting people for the new institutions being established in Kosovo.
Hashim Thaci, the rebels' political leader, who signed the demilitarization agreement, said today that the general was "respected by all."
"His association with the K.L.A. was from the very start of its organization in the early 1990's, and he was instrumental in structuring the K.L.A. into a more professional force," Mr. Thaci said in a separate interview today.
A Western official who had seen General Ceku in his mountain headquarters said rebel commanders had appeared deferential to the general.
The general defended his headquarters over the last three months from a major Serbian offensive.
Mr. Thaci appeared confident that the order to demilitarize would be obeyed. "A soldier did not get his weapon to keep in his hand or in his house," he said. "He got it to fight to liberate Kosovo from Serbia. That objective is realized, and our objective now is to restructure and integrate ourselves into society."
General Ceku said the rebel force had swelled to 20,000 during the last month of the conflict. Until March, when the NATO bombing began, he said, the force had consisted of 12,000 fighters and 4,000 to 5,000 unarmed volunteers.
About 1,500 rebels were killed and 4,000 wounded during the 15 months the rebels fought Yugoslav troops, he said. About 100 are missing.
The general contended that the Serbian offensive had strengthened the rebel group. "It drew more people to our ranks, and it gave us new military experience," he said, "and by surviving the offensive we gained the faith of the people. Without the bombing, the Albanian people would have suffered much more."
He said he believed that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia had planned an ethnic purge of Kosovo Albanians whether NATO had begun its bombing campaign or not.
And he said he would move down to Pristina from his mountain hideout. A headquarters has already been selected in the wealthy suburb of Kojlovica, the gate guarded by uniformed soldiers bearing no weapons.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Suffer Their Largest Decline in More Than a Week

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices suffered their biggest drop in more than a week as the Treasury and the Ford Motor Credit Company led borrowers selling at least $18 billion of debt this week.
The Government will auction $15 billion of two-year notes tomorrow, while Ford plans to issue at least $3 billion of debt, part of a program to sell multibillion-dollar blocks of bonds to international investors. 
 "It'll be tough for the market to rally before those sales," said Anne Kennedy, who helps invest $2 billion at Columbia Partners Investment Management in Washington.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 20/32 , to 89 14/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.02 percent, from 5.97 percent on Friday. Yields on two-year notes, the most actively traded securities, rose to 5.59 percent from 5.54 percent.
Ms. Kennedy said she was staying away from the Ford sale because the company would probably issue more securities this year, and that might lower the value of older Ford debt.
Last week, bonds enjoyed their best gain in eight months after a report showed no inflation and comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, convinced many investors that an expected increase in short-term interest rates next week would be pre-emptive.
In addition to the monthly two-year note auction, the Treasury sold $15 billion of three- and six-month bills yesterday and will offer $10 billion of one-year bills today.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Rise in Technology Lifts Nasdaq and S.& P. but Dow Falls

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Optimism that second-quarter earnings will be strong pushed technology stocks up for the fifth straight session yesterday. But a rise in interest rates hurt cyclical stocks, and the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average closed lower.
But paced by gains in well-known names like Microsoft, Cisco Systems, Amazon.com and Yahoo, the Nasdaq composite index soared 66.84 points, to 2,630.28, or 2.6 percent. That, after the 4.7 percent gain the index recorded last week, put the Nasdaq up just under 20 percent for the year. 
 "The expectation is that this earnings season will reflect a very strong economy in the first half, and the bargain hunters are going to technology stocks because they have the best prospects," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore.
But optimistic talk about earnings did not lead to a surge in business on the floor of the exchanges.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange remained fairly light, with only 686.6 million shares changing hands. On the Nasdaq, 895 million shares were traded.
Optimism about second-quarter earnings also helped lift brokerage stocks. A number of companies, including Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, are expected to report their second-quarter results this week.
Among brokerage firm stocks, Charles Schwab soared 8 1/4, to 98 1/4; Goldman Sachs 4 11/16 , to 69 1/2; Lehman Brothers 4 1/4, to 60 5/16 , and Morgan Stanley 4, to 99 3/4.
The rise in interest rates, which pushed long-term bond yields back above 6 percent, depressed cyclical stocks, however. Led by Alcoa, Chevron, General Electric and Exxon, which each fell more than 2, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 39.58 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 10,815.98.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.16, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,349, bolstered by gains in technology stocks, including America Online and Lucent Technologies, and finance company shares, including Chase Manhattan. America Online gained 3 3/8, to 115 3/8, and Lucent rose 2 7/16 , to 65 3/8. Chase added 3 3/8, to 83 1/2.
Small-company stocks also had a good day.
The Russell 2000 index of small- company shares rose 4.39, or 1 percent, to 449.44. And TheStreet.com's Internet stock index soared 30.17 points, or 5.4 percent, to 594.51.
Interest rates have been the dominant concern of stock traders the last few weeks. But anxiety about rising rates eased last week after the release of reassuring news about inflation and a comparatively straightforward talk by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
"Right now, the overwhelming sense is that the Fed will tighten at the end of the month, and at worst once more sometime after that," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "I think we are going to have a better tone to the bond market. If that happens, then we could have an explosive move to the upside in stocks."
Among big technology stocks, Microsoft gained 3 15/16 , to 88 15/16 ; Cisco Systems 3 3/4, to 123 1/8, and Sun Microsystems 4 1/2, to 68 9/16 .
Of the Dow stocks, I.B.M. gained 4 to 124 3/4, and Hewlett-Packard rose 2 1/8, to 93 7/8.
A drop in crude oil and gasoline futures prices hit oil and oil service stocks. Chevron, a Dow component, fell 2 1/2, to 90 11/16 ; Exxon fell 2 1/8, to 78 1/4. Halliburton slid 2 1/16 , to 43 13/16 , and Schlumberger fell 1 1/2, to 63.
Among Internet stocks, Yahoo, shot up 14 7/16 , to 158 7/8, on a report it would raise its investment in Japan.
Elsewhere, Weyerhaeuser, the big forestry company, slid 2 5/8, to 67 1/8, after it said it had agreed to buy MacMillan Bloedel of Canada for $2.45 billion.
Boeing fell 1 5/8, to 43, after the top sales executive of its rival, Airbus Industrie, said the company had risked reviving a price war.
Coca-Cola, plagued by continuing worries and official sales bans in several European countries after reports of illness among consumers last week, saw its stock slip again yesterday. At the close, Coke shares were down 1 7/8, to 61 9/16.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
All in the Family

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Jewish Jerusalem used to just be divided between secular and religious. Today the divide is so much more profound. This city is now part Teheran, part Palo Alto. It has one foot in cyberspace and the other in the Second Temple. Part of Jerusalem's youth have Bill Gates as their role model and another part the fiddler on the roof.
In Jerusalem's Har Hotzvim district, Israeli companies are designing the next generation of the Internet. Indeed, outside of Silicon Valley, Israel's Silicon Wadi is now the most dynamic producer of Internet technologies -- notably Internet security systems -- in the world. Yet a mile away from Har Hotzvim, in Jerusalem's ultra-Orthodox Mea Shearim neighborhood, wall posters now regularly appear warning residents not to have Internet-linked computers in their homes because of the worlds it might open. These ultra-Orthodox don't like windows or Windows. 
 This is why the recent Israeli election was actually two revolts at once. The first was a revolt by the secular fundamentalists -- the high priests of high tech, who are powering the dynamic, computer side of the Israeli economy. They voted in droves for ultra-secular parties, as a way of saying to the no-tech religious fundamentalists that the secularists were no longer going to let their tax dollars, generated from 21st-century innovations, be used to fund 18th-century ghetto schools, where kids are given no math, science or computing skills that might prepare them for the future. (Israel has no core curriculum, so you can teach whatever you want, even in state-financed schools.)
The counter-revolt was by the ultra-Orthodox and traditional Sephardic Jews, who rallied in droves to the Shas Party, making it the third-largest in Israel, just behind Likud. Their message was: "Once again we are being left behind. We have been here for three generations, but new Russian immigrants, many of them not really Jews, have come in with their education and skills and leapfrogged over us. So we're voting Shas to express our rejection of the yuppified, Internet-obsessed, secularizing elites, who want to keep us down and assimilate Israel into global mush."
How Ehud Barak manages these twin revolts will be the domestic drama in Israel. It will be worth watching because how modern, liberal democracies deal with such fundamentalist social-protest movements is now a worldwide challenge. We've seen three strategies: The first was used by Bibi Netanyahu (and his Labor predecessors), which was to try to buy off Shas by plying it with state funds in return for political support. But that resulted in Shas sending thousands of kids to its own schools, where they learned virtually no skills and became wards of the state.
The second is the Algerian model: Simply crush the fundamentalists. The third model was tried (and failed) in Turkey: Bring the fundamentalists into power, but set some real limits on them to force them toward modernity. This is the model that Mr. Barak will attempt by bringing Shas into his coalition.
There is one reason for hope. Shas now has an internal contradiction: It has been so successful at attracting non-Orthodox Sephardic youth (Shas won 13 percent of the army vote!) that it will have to be increasingly sensitive to their demands -- and these non-Orthodox Sephardim want better schools and skills, so they can compete with the Russians. So Shas itself needs to find a road to modernity without losing its identity.
The state has to help them do that. It should begin by changing the law that says anyone who shuns army service for religious reasons can't hold a job and must stay in yeshiva. Israel needs to let those Shas youth, who for religious reasons don't want to serve in the army, be able to work if they so choose. "There is nothing that says Orthodox people can't work with computers," says Shlomo Kalish, the Orthodox founder of Jerusalem Global, one of Jerusalem's most dynamic high-tech venture capital companies. "In fact, yeshiva graduates can make great programmers. They are used to sitting for long hours working on logic problems. But the Government has to set them free to work, even if they choose not to serve in the army."
My hope is that Mr. Barak's motto will be: "Draft Shas into the 21st century, not the army." Nothing would do more to begin healing Israel's internal divide.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2285 words

HEADLINE: STOPGAP MEDICINE: A special report.;
For the Uninsured, Drug Trials Are Health Care

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA and KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Carole Danforth's asthma had gotten the best of her. No longer did she have the energy for activities she loved, like playing with her grandchildren or doing yardwork. Some days, her breathing was so labored she could not get up from the couch. And there seemed little she could do about it: Ms. Danforth, a 51-year-old housecleaner in Taunton, Mass., had no insurance and little money for doctors or the inhalers she needed when her condition was at its worst.
Then, two years ago, her life changed. Friends told her of a doctor who was offering free examinations and drugs as part of a study of an experimental asthma medication. Perhaps, the friends suggested, the doctor could help her. 
 The doctor, Michael Lawrence, was soon providing Ms. Danforth with free diagnostic tests -- including a chest X-ray she could never have afforded -- to determine if she was eligible. Ms. Danforth was accepted for the study and within days Dr. Lawrence gave her a free, but unapproved, medication for asthma. Her breathing returned to normal.
Ms. Danforth had finally found her access to health care -- albeit one where a medicine she finds effective lasts only as long as the study. As a result, she has become one of a growing number of drug-trial nomads, wandering from study to study as they become available.
"I can't keep track of them all," Ms. Danforth said of the drug studies in which she has participated. "But I haven't felt this good in a long time."
In recent years, the need for test subjects in experimental drug trials has exploded as the industry has brought to market an ever-increasing number of new products. In response, drug companies have developed new methods of finding participants for the trials by turning to private-practice doctors who recruit from their lists of patients. But even that influx of participants has not been enough to satisfy the demand.
Filling the gap, according to industry officials and researchers, are people like Ms. Danforth: chronically ill with limited or no health insurance, relying on clinical trials by private doctors as their primary source of medical care. For these people, experiments have become treatments; clinical investigators are their specialists.
Medical experts recognize the shortcomings of this system. On the one hand, the doctors are white knights, providing a critical service that such patients cannot obtain any other way. Patients "are better off getting experimental therapy than no therapy at all," Paul Menzel, a philosophy professor at Pacific Lutheran University in Tacoma, Wash., said.
But the benefit can be fleeting or nonexistent. Chronically ill patients with no other options can be treated with an experimental medication that does not work or that even worsens their condition. Or they can end up with a placebo -- a dummy pill or treatment -- rather than the medication itself. And once the study is over, usually in a matter of weeks, they are left to their own devices. They can be barred by the rules of one clinical trial from participating in another study for months, forcing them to rely on samples of medications provided by drug companies or to go without treatment altogether.
That leaves many patients in a sad position: Having tasted, for a moment, how good life can be when their conditions are controlled, they are plunged back into a life of disabling symptoms.
"Studies are becoming like a stopgap" with the private doctors, said Dr. Richard A. Friedman, director of the psychopharmacology clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. "And that's pretty bad, taking from them what they need and then tossing them back."
That description underscores a hard fact of medical research: The subjects of drug trials are not, technically speaking, being treated for a disease. Rather, they are participating in an experiment.
"One will often hear from physicians and economists that there is always a way for them to get medical care, so this must be one of the ways," said Norman Daniels, a professor of philosophy at Tufts University who specializes in ethics and health policy. "In my view, it does not count as medical care."
 
The Trend
Uninsured Pursue Unaffordable Care
Nobody tracks how many uninsured people seek health care from clinical studies, but researchers agree that they number in the thousands and that their ranks are growing.
The result is that researchers in areas with many poor people often have the best chance of attracting research subjects. "That's one of the reasons that we have been so successful," Dr. Paul Chervinsky, medical director at New England Clinical Studies in New Bedford, Mass., said. "New Bedford has always been an economically deprived area."
Even people with insurance plans that impose significant restrictions -- like managed care programs that require pre-approval to visit a specialist -- are circumventing the gatekeepers by seeking out clinical trials, researchers said.
"A lot of patients tell me that they feel frustrated with the care that they receive from the H.M.O.," said Dr. Norman Zinner, a Los Angeles doctor who heads Affiliated Research Centers, an organization of private-practice urologists who do drug studies. "They want to know if they might be eligible for a drug study so that they could get relief."
Of course, the poor have long been participants in drug studies, usually through university medical centers. But once a study is completed those institutions often direct the patients to other university programs that provide health care to the poor -- programs that private doctors who normally see only paying patients have few dealings with.
The benefits for test subjects are obvious. For many, a clinical trial offers a rare opportunity for a full diagnostic workup by a medical specialist as well as access, at no charge, to the latest treatments.
"Arkansas is not a wealthy state, and most of the drug studies that we do provide the patient with free medication," said Lin Richardson, director of practice management at Baptist Health Systems, which operates a network of private practices in Little Rock that conduct drug studies involving a large number of uninsured patients. "It is amazing what I have seen happen for some of our patients."
 
The Ethics
Right and Wrong On the Frontier
Ethical qualms arise from the fact that clinical trials are not intended to be medical care. In this context, the doctors are investigators, not personal physicians. The drugs are often experimental, and no one knows for sure whether they work. On top of that, because many clinical trials compare an active drug with a placebo, the patients often stand as good a chance of receiving no treatment.
Clinical trials also raise a problem never experienced in true patient care: Even if a test medication improves the health of a chronically ill person, the drugs will no longer be supplied once the study ends.
Some researchers and study co-ordinators strive to avoid that outcome. "I believe it's a violation of human rights" to keep patients dangling untreated between studies, said Maria Lopez, a study coordinator for Dr. Herbert Rubin, a gastroenterologist in Beverly Hills, Calif. Dr. Rubin provides his uninsured test subjects with drug company samples between tests, a practice that Ms. Lopez said was frowned upon by the companies.
"Drug company representatives will be like: 'Remember, you have to give these to patients who will actually buy,' " Ms. Lopez said.
Other researchers refuse to allow the uninsured to use drug studies for medical care.
"It's not right that some people would give the patient the false impression that they are getting full medical care when they are not," said Dr. Thomas Littlejohn, who directs Piedmont Medical Group in Winston-Salem, N.C.
Told of the trend, medical ethicists were divided. Some expressed concern, saying that vulnerable patients were being coerced through the lure of medical care to put their bodies on the line.
"It becomes a further exploitation of the poor," John Paris, an ethics professor at Boston College, said.
But others were less certain, noting that the trend presented new options for getting care to people whose choices were limited.
"It is a nasty dilemma," Professor Menzel said. "There is no way you can win on this one."
 
The Patients
A Roller Coaster Without Relief
 When Victor Miranda saw Dr. Rubin's ad in La Opinion, a Spanish language newspaper in Los Angeles, he did not even call ahead for an appointment.
Instead, Mr. Miranda, a 37-year-old house painter from Guatemala, hopped on a bus in the morning and traveled an hour and a half to Dr. Rubin's office. He said through a translator that he had suffered from heartburn and agonizing stomach pain for two years but had not seen a doctor because he could not pay for it.
Dr. Rubin determined that he had an inflamed esophagus, an easily treatable condition, and enrolled Mr. Miranda in a study comparing drugs developed by Astra Pharmaceuticals.
The paradoxes of such experiences are not lost on patients. While most praise the doctors who conduct the research, many also resent the compromises they have to make.
"The health care they give you is really specific for what they're testing for," said Elizabeth Elder, a 52-year-old uninsured woman in Albuquerque, N.M., who has participated in a number of studies, "so it isn't really health care."
Others are simply grateful for whatever medical attention they can get.
In Lemoyne, Ohio, Roland and Linda Gladieux were looking for drug studies to get relief from a host of medical problems. They could not afford insurance; the cheapest policy they could find cost $500 a month with a $2,500 deductible and paid only 70 percent of medical costs above that.
Mr. Gladieux, a burly 51-year-old who manages a car-repair shop, has a chronic wheezing cough. He had gone to a doctor who wanted to test him for emphysema, but Mr. Gladieux declined, unable to afford the tests. So when he saw an advertisement on television late last year seeking people with chronic bronchitis, he jumped at the chance.
The ad was placed by Dr. John Winder, an asthma and allergy specialist in Sylvania, Ohio, who does drug studies alongside his private practice. The bronchitis study was already fully enrolled when Mr. Gladieux called. But Dr. Winder's recruiters told him of studies for other ailments. Learning that a heartburn study was opening, Mr. Gladieux offered his wife, who has had severe heartburn for 20 years. She got into the study.
"It was a godsend," Mrs. Gladieux said. The experimental medication cleared up her heartburn and for the first time in years she could eat foods like lasagna without suffering.
Now the heartburn study is over and the Gladieuxes are looking for other drug studies to join -- bronchitis for him, heartburn for her. Or almost anything.
"I have arthritis real bad," Mrs. Gladieux said. When she saw Dr. Winder for her last visit in the heartburn study she asked him to keep her in mind. "I told him if anything comes up, give me a call," she said.
The financial difficulties that lead patients to choose experiments for their health care are not limited to people with little or no insurance. Adriana Medina, a 24-year-old medical assistant in Tucson, Ariz., has health insurance through a health maintenance organization. The plan paid for her 8-year-old daughter, Gabriela Garcia, to see a pediatrician for her asthma. But when that failed to help, the plan would not pick up the cost of a specialist.
"She was on so many medications, and she was constantly sucking on the breathing machine," Ms. Medina said. "It was just a roller coaster ride. She was never well."
Unable to afford the specialist, Ms. Medina enrolled Gabriela in a drug study conducted by a local asthma expert, Dr. Jay Grossman. "Just hearing that it was an asthma specialist I said, 'Hey, what do I have to lose?' " she said.
The experimental asthma drug changed Gabriela's life. The trial "is allowing her to have a normal childhood," Ms. Medina said.
"My only worry," she added, "is that the study will be over and she'll be back where she started from."
The completion of a study can be a poignant moment, several doctors said, especially when the subjects, like Gabriela Garcia, finally received medical help that had eluded them. The subjects spent weeks or months sitting in waiting rooms with private patients, filling out the same forms and looking through the same magazines as everyone else. Their diagnostic tests were done in the usual exam rooms, and they received drugs just like private patients. Then the study ended and the subjects had to leave.
"They have had more medical care from me than they have had from anybody for years," Dr. Winder said. "It is hard for them to understand that they are not my patients."
In the end, if no new clinical trials are available to them, that reality can leave patients feeling frightened and abandoned. Josette Good, a 60-year-old widow, used to count on Dr. Winder to keep her enrolled in study after study for asthma. But last year, she moved to Lake Milton, Ohio, near her children but 200 miles from Dr. Winder's office.
Now, medical care has become an issue; adequate health insurance is beyond her budget, and Dr. Winder could not help her find a study in her area. She has only one inhaler left, from the last study she participated in, so she uses it sparingly, at times borrowing another from a friend. Hoping to make her inhaler last through the summer, she limits her activities, avoiding yardwork and even short walks.
"It's just so tough," Mrs. Good said. "I pray nothing happens."

HEADLINE: White House Tries to Defuse Push for SteelImport Quotas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
With the Senate poised to act Tuesday on a bill that would sharply restrict the amount of imported steel in the United States, the Clinton Administration took a series of actions today to convince Congress that it could protect the jobs of American steelworkers with far less drastic measures.
The actions, announced by Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, include an inquiry into whether cold-rolled steel is being "dumped" in the United States at unfairly low prices. The moves appeared intended to stem the number of Democrats in the Senate who have said they will vote for the steel quota bill, which would roll imports back to 1997 levels and has been pressed by steelworkers and manufacturers. The bill, which the Administration denounces as protectionist, already sailed through the House 289 to 141. 
 In the latest in a series of confrontations over trade policy with his own party, President Clinton has promised to veto the measure if it reaches his desk. But the White House desperately wants to avoid that step because it would cause enormous political pain to Vice President Al Gore, who is trying to court the votes of the United Steelworkers of America, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and voters in steelmaking states.
"This is agony for Gore," one senior Administration official said, "because it puts him in the position of angering supporters whom he needs very much. And the Republicans know it."
The White House argues -- and many trade experts agree -- that the bill's import quotas would violate global trade treaties. It is usually a violation of trade rules to set a unilateral limit on many imported goods, and the United States has protested similar actions by other countries.
There is little doubt it would be struck down if challenged before the World Trade Organization -- though the legal arguments could drag on for years.
The likely violation of America's trade commitments, however, carried little sway with the House in March. And those arguments may not overcome political pressure in the Senate. Hundreds of steelworkers plan to raise those pressures on Tuesday morning after a noisy arrival outside the Senate on a fleet of Harley-Davidson motorcycles.
"There is a convergence of agendas here," said Gary Hubbard, the spokesman for the United Steelworkers. "This is an emergency restraint measure to save high-wage jobs. And there are Republicans who want to see Vice President Gore associated with the White House position against this bill."
Mr. Daley, in the midst of a day of lobbying against the bill on Capitol Hill, announced today that as an alternative he was beginning an investigation into whether cold-rolled steel from Japan, China, Russia, Brazil, Indonesia, Thailand and other nations was being dumped in the United States. Four of those nations received financial bailouts led by the United States over the last two years and have been exporting aggressively -- in part at the advice of the International Monetary Fund -- to get back on their feet.
But that export strategy has already begun to cost a relatively modest number of jobs in smaller steelmaking factories nationwide. Mr. Daley argued today that there were ways of dealing with that job loss short of sending a message that the United States was closing its doors to imports -- and opening the way to retaliation against American goods.
"What kind of message would we send if we -- as the world's leading economic power, riding the wave of an historic sustained expansion and the one bright spot during the long months of economic turmoil elsewhere in the world -- now send the message that we intend to close our borders and violate international trading rules?" Mr. Daley asked.
As in many trade arguments, the White House has lost more Democrats than Republicans. Chief among them is Senator Jay Rockefeller, the West Virginia Democrat whose state includes Weirton Steel and other large manufacturers.
"We're doing very well putting the votes together," Mr. Rockefeller said this afternoon. "The White House is clearly scared about how far this has come, because this has everything to do with Gore's future."
However, another Democratic Senator, Max Baucus of Montana, said in an interview that he had decided to vote against the measure because "it would encourage other countries to retaliate against us, in agriculture and other areas." Mr. Baucus's state is a leading exporter of farm goods, an easy target for retaliation.
Mr. Gore has said little about the bill, apparently seeking not to anger union members and others whose support he seeks. But this evening, pressed to state a position on the bill, his office issued a brief statement:
"The Vice President believes legislated quotas on steel imports are unnecessary. The Administration has turned back the import surge through tough enforcement of U.S. trade laws, and we will continue working with the steel industry and unions on eliminating unfair trade practices, on early-warning mechanisms, on companies damaged by the import surge and other measures to deal with excess capacity."
But clearly Mr. Gore's hope is to avoid a vote altogether.
That was the strategy in announcing new dumping investigations today involving cold-rolled steel, which is used to make cars, bicycles and household appliances. But it will take months before the Commerce Department issues a final ruling on whether dumping is taking place. In the far more lucrative area of hot-rolled steel, the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission just approved punitive tariffs against Japan.
The Administration argues that its administrative actions have worked and that steel imports are subsiding. But the unions and steelmakers interpret the data very differently, and they have demanded protection.
It could turn out to be expensive protection. A study by the Institute for International Economics earlier this month estimates that restricting imports will send prices up significantly for cars, construction materials and other steel products. The report, prepared by Gary Hufbauer and Erika Wada, estimated that the bill would preserve the jobs of 1,700 workers at an annual cost to consumers of $800,000 a worker.
The bill would not ban all steel imports, but rather would limit them to 1997 levels. The Administration argues that steel imports are falling back to that level anyway. "If that is the case," Mr. Rockefeller said, "then the penalties won't go into effect and they have nothing to worry about."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

For Many, Drug Testing Is Becoming Medical Care
In recent years, the need for test subjects in experimental drug trials has exploded as the industry has brought to market an ever-increasing number of new products. In response, drug companies have developed new methods of finding participants for the trials by turning to private-practice doctors who recruit from their lists of patients. 
 But even that influx of participants has not been enough to satisfy the demand. Filling the gap, according to industry officials and researchers, are chronically ill patients with limited or no health insurance who rely on clinical trials as their primary source of medical care. For these people, experiments have become treatments. Page A1.
 
White House Tries to Stop Steel Bill
With the Senate poised to act today on a bill that would sharply restrict the amount of imported steel in the United States, the Clinton Administration took steps to convince Congress that it could protect the jobs of steelworkers with far less drastic measures. A1.
 
U.S. Clears Purchase of Prudential
Over the objections of doctors' groups and consumer advocates, the Government approved the $1 billion acquisition of Prudential Health Care by Aetna, which will create the nation's biggest managed-care company, on the condition that Aetna sell its NYLCare Health Maintenance Organization in the Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston markets. A1.

Coca-Cola Apologizes to Belgium
M. Douglas Ivester, the chairman of Coca-Cola, apologized to the people of Belgium in extraordinarily contrite newspaper ads over a contamination scare that began there more than a week ago and spread to other countries in Europe. But he stopped short of conceding that Coke products made anyone sick. Coke's efforts to end its image crisis came as officials from the European Union said they wanted to review all data on the causes of the scare. C4.
 
Hong Kong to Create Mutual Fund
The Government of Hong Kong, 10 months after plunging into the stock market to fend off what it called an improper speculative attack, said that it would sell most of its enormous portfolio of shares by creating a mutual fund that tracks the Hang Seng stock index. C4.
 
Nasdaq Surges, But Dow Slides
Optimism that second-quarter earnings will be strong pushed technology stock prices up. The Nasdaq composite index soared 66.84 points, to 2,630.28. But a rise in interest rates hurt cyclical stocks, and the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average closed down 39.58 points, to 10,815.98. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.16 points, to 1,349.00. C16.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.02 percent. C16.
 
America Online Investing in Hughes
America Online will invest $1.5 billion in Hughes Electronics as part of an alliance that will allow the on-line service to offer high-speed Internet access using the Hughes satellite data delivery system. Under the agreement, Hughes will market AOL TV, an interactive television service, to the seven million subscribers of its DirecTV satellite TV service. In turn, America Online will market DirecTV and DirecPC, Hughes's high-speed, satellite-based Internet access service, to its 16 million United States subscribers. Shares of Hughes rose $3.1875 to $56.625. C6.
 
Weyerhaeuser in Acquisition Deal
Weyerhaeuser, the forest-products company, agreed to acquire MacMillan Bloedel in a stock deal valued at $2.45 billion. C4.
 
Witness: Microsoft Benefits Many
Microsoft's final witness in its antitrust trial said that the actions that landed the company in court have greatly benefitted consumers, computer makers and companies doing business on the Internet. C2.
 
Albertson's Acquisition Closer
Federal officials have agreed that they will not block Albertson's pending $8.3 billion purchase of American Stores. C2.

HEADLINE: Funabashi Journal;
He Watched Over His Rackets; Now It's His Flock

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: FUNABASHI, Japan

 BODY:
Elaborate tattoos of a carp and mythic characters of great strength work their way from his pectoral muscles, over his shoulders, down his arms and across his upper back.
The tips of his pinkie fingers are conspicuously missing. And his teeth, capped to perfection, provide more evidence of Hiroyuki Suzuki's organized-crime credentials. 
 But while his flesh brands him a member of the yakuza, Japan's storied underworld, he now says his allegiance is to Jesus.
Mr. Suzuki, 43, formerly a member of the Sakaume gumi, a small independent crime family best known for its role in gambling, is the founder of Mission Barabbas, an evangelical Christian church in this Tokyo suburb, and a minister in the church.
Mission Barabbas features the brand of tongue-speaking, faith-healing, arm-waving Christianity popular in parts of America but a distinct oddity in Japan.
Historically, Christianity in Japan has prevailed only among a small number of highly educated people, never really reaching the masses the way it has taken root in other countries. Masaru Hayami, the governor of the Bank of Japan, is probably the most prominent Japanese Christian at the moment.
There are about 1.1 million Christians, including foreigners, in Japan, according to The Christian News, a Tokyo weekly; that is less than 1 percent of the population. Christians here typically maintain a low profile, perhaps a carryover from the days of the Tokugawa shogunate, when Christians were persecuted and the religion was all but stamped out. Since then, Christianity has spread largely through private schools and universities like Sophia University.
Mission Barabbas, on the other hand, takes its message to the streets, a practice reflected in its membership, which is divided between people who are handicapped, unemployed and otherwise outcast from Japanese society and people who would disappear in the crowd at an average train station.
"At this church, because I used to take drugs and commit crimes, people who have problems but can't talk about them anywhere else come here," he said. "It's split about 50-50 between those who change their lives and those who just drift on."
The church, which was started four years ago, has some 60 members, and its tiny, one-room sanctuary tucked away in a typical neighborhood is packed for Sunday services. "On average in Japan, one church collects about 30 or 40 followers over a 20-year period," Mr. Suzuki said. "So we're pretty pleased with our progress."
Mr. Suzuki and his handful of fellow yakuza converts use a mobile ministry, song and fiery preaching to win converts. They spent six months lugging a cross from Okinawa to Hokkaido, a march they have repeated on a tighter schedule in South Korea and Hawaii. "Rather than waiting for people to come in and find us, we decided we'd go out to the people and talk to them," he said.
He has gained enough attention to earn a speaking engagement at the President's Prayer Breakfast at the White House last year, along with President Clinton and the Rev. Billy Graham.
The story of Mr. Suzuki's conversion from gangster to minister is as much a love story as a tale of an epiphany. As a young yakuza member, he fell in love with a hostess in a bar in Osaka, a young woman from South Korea who called herself Mariko but was born Han Kumja.
The two separated many times but always found themselves reunited. They were a sad pair. Mr. Suzuki was struggling under a pile of debt accumulated in heavy gambling binges, and Mariko was deeply disappointed with her life in Japan.
She began going to a Korean church, having sought solace in Buddhism and fortunetelling but to no avail. She liked the people she met at church, Mr. Suzuki said, and found that she felt buoyed, although she could not explain exactly why.
Some time later, Mariko broke her kneecap. The minister and members of her church fasted and prayed for healing, Mr. Suzuki said, and when Mariko went to church the next Sunday, the minister put his hands on her broken knee and pronounced it healed.
She walked away from church that day, and although Mr. Suzuki regarded her religion as a silly waste of time, the recovery of her knee fascinated him.
"In gambling," he said, "you use dice. Dice are made from bone, and if God could heal her bone, I figured he could probably assist my dice and make me the best dice thrower in all of Japan."
After months of prayer, Mr. Suzuki's gambling skills did improve, enabling him to pay off his debts.
But he quickly lapsed back to his old ways, abandoning Mariko, who had become his wife, shortly after she gave birth to their boy. "At that time, I was like a stone rolling down the hill into the mud," Mr. Suzuki said.
Once again, his debts mounted, and he drank and took drugs. He fled Osaka and his young family, returning to Tokyo with his favorite bar hostess in tow. He had his girlfriend call his wife and taunt her and eventually demanded a divorce.
Eight months later, he became ill. "I thought my wife was trying to kill me with a curse from God," he said.
Figuring God had cured his wife's leg, he sought out a church wedged between a brothel and a gambling parlor in a seedy section of Shinjuku ward in Tokyo. Once there, he says, he collapsed in front of the cross, where he stayed for three days, praying and calling out to God.
"The carpet was soaked with my tears," he said.
When the minister finally approached him, Mr. Suzuki screamed out that he was beyond redemption. "I was shouting because I was hurt," Mr. Suzuki said. "I had severed two of my fingers by myself, undergone the pain of tattooing, spent two years in jail and deserted my wife and child."
The minister persisted, however, and Mr. Suzuki calmed down. He returned to Osaka to confront his wife, and her immediate acceptance of him despite his misdeeds clinched his faith, he said.
"I saw that I could start over again, which I had thought was impossible," he said. He was officially expelled from his gang when he entered the seminary in 1990, but he doesn't fear reprisal.
"Now," he said, "God is protecting me."

HEADLINE: Study Finds More School Funds Being Used for Instruction

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
A growing proportion of the budget for New York City's public schools is being earmarked for classroom instruction and other services that directly benefit students, the Board of Education reported yesterday.
Planned spending on direct services to students rose to 91 percent of the school system's $9.8 billion budget this year, from 88.5 percent last year, the board said in the latest of what it calls school-based budgeting reports. The reports offer detailed accounts of how each of the 1,144 schools and 40 community school districts and high school districts planned to spend the money allocated to them in the fiscal year ending June 30. 
 School administrators have been under pressure to show that they are not spending too much on themselves. "We are pushing constantly to increase the funding that goes into the classroom," said Beverly Donohue, the chief financial officer for the board. In 1996, the first year these detailed reports were released, the schools budgeted 87.2 percent for direct services, the board said.
Benefiting from a strong economy, the schools planned to spend $8,997 per student this year (including those in special education), up from $8,494 in last year's budget. As in the last few years, more of this money is going to students in middle and elementary schools ($8,391 and $8,365, respectively) than to students in high schools ($7,734).
Ms. Donohue said the disparity could be explained by the focus on early childhood education and the smaller class sizes in the lower grades. In most school systems, more is spent on students in the upper grades because of the need for teachers with specialities as well as laboratories and equipment.
The budgets include a significant increase for special education, to $24,313 a student from $22,294.
But little of the money allocated for the classroom is being spent on textbooks. That amount is expected to be $65.6 million, down from $119 million in 1997, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sponsored a special allocation of $70 million.
The figures made public yesterday are a snapshot of the budgets as they stood in April, after many changes throughout the school year, Ms. Donohue said. Reports itemizing actual spending will be released in January.
Actual spending does not usually differ from projected spending, said Noreen Connell, the director of the Educational Priorities Panel, a private watchdog organization.
Ms. Connell praised the Board of Education for being so forthcoming. "This is transparent budgeting like no other agency has," she said. The figures dispel the theory that the school system spends too much on administration, she said, but they also reveal the school system's principal inadequacy: a lack of money.
An average middle-income suburban school system in the metropolitan region spends about $10,500 per student, Ms. Connell said.
In New York, for example, the textbook budget equals $60 per student. In many suburban districts, the sum would be closer to $200 a student, Ms. Connell said.
Although less money is being set aside for textbooks, several categories have shown considerable gains since 1997. These are teacher training, to $169.9 million, from $133.5 million; summer and evening school, to $138.5 million, from $66 million; building maintenance, to $182.1 million, from $110.3 million; and computer support, to $106.9 million from $17.6 million .

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Pitting Woods And Irons Against The Jackhammers;
In Bronx, Rift Grows Over Plan For Water Plant at Golf Course

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Michael Zuccaire lugged his clubs to the first hole of Mosholu Golf Course in the Bronx and surveyed the tree-studded slopes and the milky blue sky. He is in his 70's and retired, he said, and his daily 18 holes at Mosholu -- he plays the nine-hole course twice -- are his greatest pleasure.
"I awake every morning with the thought of coming up here," Mr. Zuccaire said. 
 Mr. Zuccaire is one of many old-timers who have made Mosholu, which sits in the southeast corner of Van Cortlandt Park, their unofficial retirement home. The course and driving range is affordable, uncongested and, alone among courses in the region, reachable by subway.
But the bucolic area, built nearly a century ago, may soon be buried by construction dust. Today, a City Council subcommittee will hold a hearing on building an 11-acre plant under Mosholu to filter water from the Croton watershed. The proposed site has already been approved by the City Planning Commission.
While the city has promised to restore the golf course on top of the plant after completing the five-year project, the proposal is roiling passions nonetheless.
Neighborhood advocates, park lovers, environmentalists, local elected officials, and of course golfers bitterly oppose the plant, saying it would swallow precious green space, raise water rates and bring noise, pollution and traffic to a fragile urban neighborhood.
But the project's supporters are fervent as well. Most vocal are unions and contractors, who fear the loss of jobs and income if the plant, which could ultimately cost the city close to $1 billion, is built outside New York. Some environmental groups concerned about the city's clean water supply also say the filtration plant must be built, although they avoid opining on where.
Hovering over the debate is the Federal Government, which in 1992 obtained a consent decree to force the city to begin building the plant by 2001. The Environmental Protection Agency is now impatiently waiting for the city to finalize its site, which it must do by the end of July. There are currently no other sites under consideration.
The Council is to vote on the plan next week, and the lobbying from both sides will be fierce in the coming days. But the plant's opponents may face an uphill battle: the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, is leaning toward supporting the plant, his spokesman, Michael Clendenin, said yesterday.
"Some of the sites they looked at before would have been way too disruptive to the city," Mr. Clendenin said. "This seems to be the best site in the city at this time."
Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, a staunch opponent of the plant, said he hoped Mr. Vallone would reconsider. "I think this is a test of his leadership," Mr. Ferrer said of Mr. Vallone. Both men are likely mayoral candidates.
Up at Mosholu, the golfers say they will use whatever votes they have left in their lives to convey their displeasure.
"The man who proposed putting this here should be jailed," Jerry O'Shea, 73, said in an Irish brogue.
"He ought to be hanged," said Matt McNeill, 70, sitting next to Mr. O'Shea on a golf cart.
The Mosholu site was selected in December by the city's Department of Environmental Protection after years of intense and well-organized community opposition caused the city to abandon a previous site at the the Jerome Park Reservoir, less than a mile from the current proposed site. A citizen suggested Mosholu at a public hearing, and the city took up the idea. "This is not a location people objected to during the whole process" of selection, said Joel A. Miele Sr., the city's Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection.
The city wants to build a water treatment plant, a storage reservoir and a pumping station at Mosholu, and said it would minimize the impact on the neighborhood by erecting a sound barrier around the construction area and by bringing truck traffic in off the Major Deegan Expressway.
But neighborhood advocates say the addition of 300 cars and 190 trucks each day by the city's estimate, along with the blasting and drilling from construction, will exacerbate the area's asthma problems, weaken its buildings, and tear at the neighborhood's social tissue. The Norwood section is stable but poor, home to more than 20,000 people, many of whom are immigrants.
"I don't think it's the kind of neighborhood the city should mess with and change the whole quality of life here," said Monsignor Patrick Boyle, the priest at St. Brendan's Parish and the Vicar of the Northwest Bronx.
Underlying the argument is a basic issue: how to insure the quality of the city's drinking water. The Croton watershed, which covers 357 square miles in Westchester and Putnam counties, normally supplies 10 percent of the city's water and as much as 30 percent in times of drought.
Critics of the plan say the city and state have done too little to protect the watershed from the pressures of development in the Croton area, and that they have waited too long to seek alternatives to chemically filtering the water. Dart Westphal, the president of the Bronx Council of Environmental Quality, said the city should be seeking to keep the water from getting dirty in the first place. Filtering, he said, provided a "false sense of security and license to pollute."
Mr. Ferrer agreed. "This is not about not wanting an industrial facility in the Bronx," he said. "This is really about the long-term protection of our drinking water." Mr. Ferrer also cited the high cost of building the plant, and said it would increase the bills of homeowners and small businesses throughout the city.
But Mr. Miele said the city had done a good job protecting its water source, and had been exploring alternatives to filtering the Croton water. Construction on the plant is supposed to begin in 2001, and Mr. Miele said that if additional studies show that avoiding filtration is possible, the city would approach the Federal government to renegotiate its agreement.
But Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the Environmental Protection Agency, said that the agency was adamant that the city filter its water.
"That is absolutely not on the table," she said of avoiding filtration. "E.P.A.'s position is that Safe Drinking Water Act requires the city to build a filtration plant for Croton."
Some environmental groups agree. "Neither the city nor anybody else has ever proven that filtration is unnecessary," said David Gordon, a senior attorney at Riverkeeper Inc.
While the E.P.A. is forcing the city to build the plant -- at the risk of exorbitant financial penalties if it does not -- it has no say or interest in where the plant is built. Critics of the Mosholu site say the city has not tried hard enough to find a less disruptive location.
At least two Westchester towns, Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant, have expressed interest in the plant, which would be built on industrial land in those towns. But Greenburgh's Town Supervisor, for one, said that New York did not seriously pursue negotiations. The Supervisor, Paul Seiner, said that he had written and tried to reach New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani many times, but, "The administration was never interested."
Mr. Miele said operating and security concerns made putting the plant in the city the wiser choice. Building the plant in Westchester also would be more expensive, officials agree.
But there are also powerful political forces pushing to keep the plant in the city, namely contractors and unions that stand to reap business and jobs from the construction. Union leaders and rank-and-file members have turned out in force at public hearings, and have been lobbying elected officials.
Their argument is simple: If the plant must be built, build it here, rather than sending the money upstate. The plant could create 4,500 jobs, said Francis X. McCardle, the managing director of the General Contractors Association, who added that most of those jobs would go to workers living in New York City. And the jobs, he said, would be well-paying -- $50,000 a year in salary and benefits.
"Prevailing wage jobs of this kind are the backbone of so many communities in New York," Mr. McCardle said, pointing out that large numbers of construction workers live in the Bronx and spend their wages there.
Thomas P. Maguire, the president of Local 15 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, agreed. "Why should we use New York City taxpayers' money to build a plant in Westchester -- especially with the commuter tax repeal?" he asked. "Why reward noncity residents again?"
But on East 213th Street, which is just across Jerome Avenue from the park, there is a certain skepticism that the jobs would benefit local residents.
"All those construction jobs they bring -- they won't hire people from here," said a 45-year-old unemployed resident who would only identify himself as Negus. "They will be from Yonkers, Staten Island, Long Island. They will come and work and earn and go."
He and other residents said they were most concerned about how construction would affect air quality in a neighborhood already heavily afflicted with respiratory problems. "Almost every kid in this neighborhood has asthma," Negus said.
But many residents also said they knew nothing about the proposed plant. And that, said one resident, Basilio Rivera, 42, a car service dispatcher, was exactly the problem.
"The vast majority of people here are not informed," he said. "They do not know what resources are available and how to go about fighting it. I hate to look at it in terms of black and white, poor and money," he continued, "but it always seems to end up that way."

"That is absolutely not on the table," she said of avoiding filtration. "E.P.A.'s position is that Safe Drinking Water Act requires the city to build a filtration plant for Croton."
Some environmental groups agree. "Neither the city nor anybody else has ever proven that filtration is unnecessary," said David Gordon, a senior attorney at Riverkeeper Inc.
While the E.P.A. is forcing the city to build the plant -- at the risk of exorbitant financial penalties if it does not -- it has no say or interest in where the plant is built. Critics of the Mosholu site say the city has not tried hard enough to find a less disruptive location.
At least two Westchester towns, Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant, have expressed interest in the plant, which would be built on industrial land in those towns. But Greenburgh's Town Supervisor, for one, said that New York did not seriously pursue negotiations. The Supervisor, Paul Seiner, said that he had written and tried to reach New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani many times, but, "The administration was never interested."
Mr. Miele said operating and security concerns made putting the plant in the city the wiser choice. Building the plant in Westchester also would be more expensive, officials agree.
But there are also powerful political forces pushing to keep the plant in the city, namely contractors and unions that stand to reap business and jobs from the construction. Union leaders and rank-and-file members have turned out in force at public hearings, and have been lobbying elected officials.
Their argument is simple: If the plant must be built, build it here, rather than sending the money upstate. The plant could create 4,500 jobs, said Francis X. McCardle, the managing director of the General Contractors Association, who added that most of those jobs would go to workers living in New York City. And the jobs, he said, would be well-paying -- $50,000 a year in salary and benefits.
"Prevailing wage jobs of this kind are the backbone of so many communities in New York," Mr. McCardle said, pointing out that large numbers of construction workers live in the Bronx and spend their wages there.
Thomas P. Maguire, the president of Local 15 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, agreed. "Why should we use New York City taxpayers' money to build a plant in Westchester -- especially with the commuter tax repeal?" he asked. "Why reward noncity residents again?"
But on East 213th Street, which is just across Jerome Avenue from the park, there is a certain skepticism that the jobs would benefit local residents.
"All those construction jobs they bring -- they won't hire people from here," said a 45-year-old unemployed resident who would only identify himself as Negus. "They will be from Yonkers, Staten Island, Long Island. They will come and work and earn and go."
He and other residents said they were most concerned about how construction would affect air quality in a neighborhood already heavily afflicted with respiratory problems. "Almost every kid in this neighborhood has asthma," Negus said.
But many residents also said they knew nothing about the proposed plant. And that, said one resident, Basilio Rivera, 42, a car service dispatcher, was exactly the problem.
"The vast majority of people here are not informed," he said. "They do not know what resources are available and how to go about fighting it. I hate to look at it in terms of black and white, poor and money," he continued, "but it always seems to end up that way."

HEADLINE: A Great American Wine Swirls In Turmoil

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: HEALDSBURG, Calif.

 BODY:
THE question sounds like a line from an old radio script:
Can a minuscule winery, started by a couple of ornery, rough-hewn rural Californians, find continuing happiness as part of an international combine owned by a big-time venture capitalist from Wall Street? 
 The winery is Williams Selyem, whose pinot noirs have moved to the head of the table in the years since the first was made in a garage in 1981. Fewer than 8,000 cases a year are produced. Almost all go directly to people on the Williams Selyem mailing list, which is as hard to crack as the guest list for a royal wedding. (Two of the winery's seven full-time employees are officially designated as "keepers of the list.") For the rest of us, happily, the stuff shows up from time to time on top restaurant wine lists, like Montrachet in Manhattan.
Smoky, voluptuous, intensely flavored, Williams Selyem pinot noir is among the most coveted American wines. Part of its cachet is scarcity, but by no means all; it is surely one of the best of its type, along with Calera and Domaine Drouhin and a few others. Now, the winery has been sold and the wine world is watching intently to see if standards will be maintained. Nobody knows the answer, because no outsider has tasted the new Williams Selyem yet.
The new owner is John Dyson, a scion of the Hudson River squirearchy. A former New York State Agriculture Commissioner and a former Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development under Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Dyson is often credited with creating the I <heart> New York advertising campaign.
Last year, he paid Burt Williams and Ed Selyem $9.5 million for the operation, which came onto the market because Mr. Selyem developed a serious back problem after years of hefting wine cases. One of the unsuccessful bidders was Joe Montana, the onetime San Francisco 49'ers quarterback.
Mr. Dyson said he sees Williams Selyem as "a job of stewardship, to be enhanced, not exploited."
But Mr. Dyson's big bucks bought him no vineyards; Williams Selyem has always been made from grapes purchased under handshake agreements. Many of those agreements continue, but not the most important one, which covered the grapes produced on Joe Rochioli's prize plot in the Russian River Valley, his so-called West Block. Those grapes went into Williams Selyem's Rochioli pinot noir, one of the wines produced under the ancien regime from grapes of single vineyards. It usually commanded the highest ratings and prices, and it was the winery's benchmark.
Nor did Mr. Dyson get the long-term services of Mr. Williams, the winery's gruff winemaker, who once told a visiting Canadian journalist: "We were friends with most of the growers, so I knew we could get great fruit. Then it's just a matter of not messing it up."
Mr. Williams agreed to continue after the winery sale, and Bob Cabral, the new winemaker, says he made the 1998 vintage "under Burt's direction." That wine -- only 4,200 cases, owing to sparse fruit production -- rests in oak barrels, awaiting release next year. So far, it seems promising.
But the two men came from different generations and different cultures. Mr. Williams, 57, is self-taught, for example, and Mr. Cabral taught winemaking at Santa Rosa Junior College. People who worked with them both say that they didn't mesh very well.
So for this year's vintage, Mr. Cabral, a heavyset, unassuming 37-year-old, is more or less on his own. Mr. Williams "has kind of backed out," Mr. Cabral said, spending most of his time on his fishing boat in Santa Barbara. Mr. Selyem spends summers in Alaska, winters in Hawaii.
Mr. Dyson installed Jean L. Arnold, a respected wine executive who helped put Jordan Vineyards on the viticultural map, as president of Williams Selyem, but she, too, found it a difficult place to work and left. The conflicts between Ms. Arnold and Mr. Dyson reportedly centered on questions of marketing strategy for Mr. Dyson's wines.
Adding to the turmoil, a 20-year-old winery worker, Taylor J. Atkins, was accidentally asphyxiated on Jan. 7 in a bottling tank full of deadly nitrogen. It was as if some kind of curse hung over Williams Selyem.
Finally, rumors began flying that Mr. Dyson planned to double, triple or quadruple Williams Selyem's output to recoup his investment -- rumors that Mr. Cabral denies. The present winery, he said, will never produce more than 15,000 cases a year, which is the target for the 2005 vintage, and "anyway, the place is very profitable as is."
AT its best, pinot noir can be a captivating wine: rich, complex and sensuous, with the scent of cherries and chocolate and sometimes leather. But the grape that makes it is capricious and demanding, so much so that Marq de Villiers called his book about the Calera Wine Company, a California pinot noir specialist, "Heartbreak Grape" (HarperCollins West, 1994).
Even in France, its homeland, it reaches greatness only in a few small plots in Burgundy, and there only in the hands of gifted winemakers like Henri Jayer and Armand Rousseau. For decades, New World winemakers tried with limited luck to duplicate the subtlety and silkiness of fine Burgundy.
The key, as it turned out, was a cool climate, and it is in such climates that pinot noir has finally succeeded in the United States -- in Oregon, in certain areas near Santa Barbara, in the Carneros district, between the Napa and Sonoma valleys, and in the Russian River Valley, northwest of Santa Rosa in Sonoma County. In most of them, coastal breezes and fogs keep the temperatures down; other successful pinot noir vineyards are cool because they are planted at high altitudes, like Chalone, founded by Richard Graff near Pinnacles National Park in central California in 1960.
Williams Selyem was a leader in developing and perfecting California pinot noirs with Burgundian characteristics. Its best wines have always been made from cool-climate grapes. Some have come from the Russian River Valley -- the Rochioli West Block, identified as Rochioli on the label; the Rochioli River Block, identified as River Block on the label, and the Allen vineyard, also farmed by the Rochioli family. Some have come from nearby lowland vineyards, like Olivet Lane. And some have come from the coastal mountains near Fort Ross, west of here, including the Hirsch, Precious Mountain and Summa vineyards.
Other suppliers are Ferrington Vineyards in the Anderson Valley, near Ukiah, and the Coastlands vineyards of Diane and David Cobb, east-facing plots above the fog line.
Neither Summa nor Olivet Lane will be available to Williams Selyem in the future. But the loss of the West Block, which was planted in 1969 and 1970, hurts most of all.
"I was faithful," Joe Rochioli said, sitting on a terrace overlooking his vines and a tree line that blocked the meandering Russian River from view. "I gave Williams and Selyem grapes from the West Block even after my son, Tom, joined me and started making wine, even when Tom ran short. But when Burt sold out, it was our chance to get back the fruit we needed."
Relaxed and genial as he may appear, Mr. Rochioli is a man possessed in the vineyard, determined, as he said, "to grow better grapes than anyone." He and his workers painstakingly thin the vines and discard less-than-perfect clusters, concentrating all the plant's energy on a small amount of fruit. The results are yields of two to three tons an acre, against eight for some rivals.
"I love it," he said. "I'm up at 4 A.M., then out in the vineyard. I don't owe anybody anything. I built my own house, plumbing, electricity, everything. I don't own a suit. I hate vacations. For me, farming is all about pride, not money."
Mr. Rochioli is stocky and vigorous at 65, with forearms the size of fireplace logs. His father grew hops on this land; now, he is considered one of the world's best grape growers by his peers. He is careful to praise both Mr. Dyson and Mr. Cabral as "good men," but he has serious doubts about expanding Williams Selyem's output and especially about bringing pinot noir grapes from other areas to the Russian River Valley to make wine. "Different nose, different flavors," he said.
Just down Westside Road from the glamorous Rochioli spread, the Williams Selyem winery occupies a cluster of small, utilitarian-looking buildings, including a modest new office. There is no visitor center and no tasting room on the dusty site. Nor is there any elaborate landscaping or any sign out front, only a discreet street number, 6575.
There are 10,000 customers on the Williams Selyem mailing list, including the White House, but not many make their way here.
Mr. Cabral, the son of grape-growing parents, worked for seven years at De Loach Vineyards, another well-regarded Russian River Valley operation. He greeted me warily, well aware, as he put it, that "everything I do here is under a microscope." Before joining Mr. Dyson he worried, he said, about whether he could maintain Williams Selyem's reputation for quality.
"I had my doubts," Mr. Cabral said. "I still do, sometimes."
So do others.
Robert M. Parker Jr., the wine critic, said recently that he feared that the new owners might try to make money by living off the winery's name.
One of California's leading sommeliers, Larry Stone of Rubicon, a San Francisco restaurant, has been a Williams Selyem fan for years. The 1991's and 1992's were brilliant, he told me, "complete wines, fleshy and complex, way beyond anything seen in California before." The 1996's are fine as well, he added, "really masterful products of intuitive artisans."
But the future, Mr. Stone argues, is an unmapped road.
"I don't know who's in charge," he said. "Dyson has paid a long price, and it remains to be seen whether he can deliver. He bought a lot of good will, but that will evaporate if he can't put the goods in the bottle. What kind of enterprise is this going to be? How big?"
Absentee owners are not necessarily bad, especially if they have deep pockets. In 1986 when a wealthy Japanese group bought Ridge Vineyards, a renowned specialist in powerful zinfandels and cabernet sauvignons, it pumped money into the property and permitted its winemaker, Paul Draper, to do exactly as he wished. Ridge has gone from strength to strength.
Mr. Cabral is no Paul Draper, but he has developed a formula that he hopes will produce both quality and quantity in years to come.
He envisions making as much of the single-vineyard wines, the top of the line, as he can, "and trying to keep them extraordinary." The grapes for those will come from the longtime suppliers that remain on the Williams Selyem roster, plus the first vineyard the winery has ever owned, a 38-acre tract near Guerneville that it bought several months ago.
Most of the growth will come in less expensive blends labeled Russian River Valley, if all the grapes come from vineyards in this area; or Sonoma Coast or Sonoma County, if the grapes come from broader areas. Will those bottlings dilute the value of the carefully nurtured Williams Selyem brand?
And what if Mr. Dyson decides to put the Williams Selyem label on wines made from grapes grown elsewhere? His Pebble Ridge Vineyards and Wine Estates owns Milbrook Vineyards in upstate New York, which produces some of the best wines east of the Mississippi; Villa Pillo Estate in Tuscany, and Mistral and Vista Verde Vineyards on the central California coast. Last year, he brought grapes from the Hollister area, south of San Francisco, to the winery here and made wine from them. But Mr. Cabral said that no decision had been made yet about releasing the wine.
If Williams Selyem stumbles, plenty of able competitors are waiting to lure its customers. Some are newcomers, relatively speaking, like the ambitious Walt and Joan Flowers and the tiny Quail Hill Vineyard. A bottle of Quail Hill's emphatic Lynmar reserve pinot noir impressed several of us at dinner in Santa Rosa recently when tasted against a group of Russian River rivals.
Then there are well-established figures like Tom Dehlinger and Gary Farrell, as well as our old friend Tom Rochioli, to whom it will now fall to make his father's prized West Block grapes into pinot noir. Will he be the next pinot noir superstar?

HEADLINE: Bull-Market Blind Spot

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Though I don't consider myself a proponent of "unfettered economic development," I believe that Portland's deal with Intel to limit job creation and thus to stop suburban sprawl displays both arrogance and foolishness ("In Oregon, Jobs vs. Trees," letter, June 18). It seems as if the folks in the Portland area and the entire country have forgotten two things during the bull market of the 1990's. 
 First, there are poor people out there who have received little to no benefit from the good economic times: a growth-limiting proposal is insulting to them.
Second, the boom won't last forever. I hardly await the day the bubble bursts, but it won't be a surprise.
 
ANTHONY C. LAVECCHIA
Island Park, N.Y., June 18, 1999

HEADLINE: Commerce Report Describes Economic Benefits From Internet

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The financial benefits of the Internet and high technology extend beyond the quick riches they have brought high-profile entrepreneurs and investors in recent years to the nation's economy as a whole, a new Government study shows.
The information technology industry -- which includes everything from the Dell Computer Corporation's PC's, to the Microsoft Corporation's software, to Cisco Systems Inc.'s routers -- generated at least a third of the nation's economic growth between 1995 and 1998, the Commerce Department said in a report released today. During that period, the gross domestic product rose 22 percent, to $8.7 trillion. 
 Those goods and services also got cheaper and allowed businesses to become more productive, cutting inflation by seven-tenths of a percentage point in 1996 and 1997, the report says.
"The improvement in technology, in productivity, is what has made the economy so incredibly attractive in the last couple of years," William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said in a speech in New Jersey today.
Today's Commerce Department report, the second in a series of three on technology, does not provide figures measuring total spending on high technology. Instead, it focuses on growth of on-line businesses and companies that cater to the technology industry. For example, it says almost half of all American workers will be employed in high-technology industries or at companies that rely heavily on technology by 2006.
Workers in information technology have been at least twice as productive as other workers from 1990 to 1997 and earn 78 percent more than other workers, the report said.
The report "provides fresh evidence that our nation's massive investments in these sectors are producing gains in productivity and that these sectors are creating new and higher-paying jobs faster than any other," Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said in the report.
Meanwhile, those who invested in high technology have reaped rewards that outpaced the market as a whole. The Standard & Poor's High Technology index rose more than five times since June 1994, while the broader S.& P. 500 stock index tripled. Spending on information technology has quadrupled over the last decade, rising as a share of all business spending on equipment to 53 percent from 29 percent, according to the Commerce Department in a separate report.
"Internet activity is driving deflationary boom conditions," said Ed Hyman, an economist for the ISI Group in New York. "It's official."
