HEADLINE: Microsoft's Final Witness Asked to Rebut U.S. Case

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
A Microsoft lawyer today led the company's final witness at its antitrust trial through the long chain of charges that the Government has thrown at Microsoft through eight months of trial and asked him to rebut each of them.
Not surprisingly, the witness, Richard L. Schmalensee, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Microsoft's expert economist, agreed that there was no substance to any of the charges. 
 He asserted that the Microsoft Corporation did not hold a monopoly in personal computer operating system software, that it faced vicious and serious competitors charging from every direction. And he said there were no significant barriers preventing other companies from selling operating systems that competed with Windows.
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is hearing the case without a jury, had nothing to say about most of the testimony. But he grew animated when the discussion turned to the barriers to entering the operating system business.
The Government contends that Microsoft's operating system monopoly is protected by what is known as the applications barrier to entry under which software companies will spend the money to write programs only for the dominant operating system, not for start-ups.
To make the case that the barrier does not exist, Mr. Schmalensee began using an analogy involving competing grocery stores. As he spoke, the judge was shaking his head.
"I have trouble with the grocery story analogy," he said at last. "You have a grocery," and then a smaller, competing market opens. "So you build a mega-market, and the potential competitor is always playing catch-up."
That set off a long discussion of grocery stores as an analogy to Microsoft and operating systems, and Mr. Schmalensee found himself talking about a mega-market that constantly adds features to stay ahead of the competition. "That's what competition is about," he said.
But the judge disagreed. "That's a benevolent despot," he said. "A monopoly."
As the trial nears its end -- the last day of testimony is likely to be on Thursday -- Judge Jackson seems quite ready to speak his mind, perhaps even show his hand, though David Boies, the Government's lead lawyer, made the point this evening that reading too much into a judge's remarks is dangerous. In any case, most of the judge's remarks have not been flattering to Microsoft.
Late in the day, however, a line of argument pursued by a Microsoft lawyer, Michael Lacovara, seemed to strike a chord. He and Mr. Schmalensee were raising the specter of competition to Microsoft from Web-based applications -- software programs like calendars or even spreadsheets that reside on the Web and are used while on line. This, the two of them said, was a serious threat to Microsoft's power.
Judge Jackson asked several questions about the phenomenon, including whether anyone on the Web could get access to his Web-based calendar. Mr. Schmalensee said access would probably require a password.
Finally, the judge, obviously enthusiastic, said, "The concept, to me, sounds very attractive, and I can't understand why" software vendors "aren't writing applications in droves."
That clearly cheered Mr. Lacovara, who has said that he likes to hear what interests the judge so he can address it. With Mr. Schmalensee back on the stand for more discussion with Mr. Lacovara Wednesday morning, it appeared likely that Judge Jackson will hear a lot more about Web-based applications.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Late Round of Selling Helps Depress the Main Indicators

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices staged a broad retreat yesterday as a further rise in long-term interest rates and a late round of selling depressed the main market gauges.
On Monday, optimism about coming earnings reports helped to lift stocks in sectors like technology and financial services. 
 Yesterday, however, analysts said they were troubled by the way the market reacted to quarterly results from Lehman Brothers.
The securities firm reported second-quarter earnings that were substantially above Wall Street's expectations. But the stock, which rose more than 7 percent on Monday, fell 3 11/16 yesterday, to 56 5/8, and dragged shares of other big brokerage firms down with it.
"Sometimes numbers can be too good," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads his own stock research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "But the market's reaction to Lehman's huge profits was a little disappointing."
For a second day, a rise in long-term interest rates helped to push down cyclical stocks, which depend on a growing economy to generate profits.
The drop in cyclical stocks was largely responsible for a decline in the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 94.35 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 10,721.63. Companies like DuPont, Alcoa and International Paper led the blue-chip index lower.
Technology stocks, which had rallied for five consecutive sessions, pulled back yesterday and dragged down the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index.
The S.& P. 500 lost 13.12 points, or just less than 1 percent, to 1,335.88. Stocks like Microsoft, Lucent Technologies, Cisco Systems and America Online, which all gained ground on Monday, fell back yesterday.
Some of those same stocks helped to pull down Nasdaq. After a strong opening, sellers emerged and by the end of the session the index had fallen 50.02 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,580.26.
Although stock traders appear to have accepted that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point next week, Christopher Durbin, chief investment strategist at J. P. Morgan Investment Inc., which manages more than $300 billion, said the central bank would most likely have to increase rates much more than that to slow the economy.
At a luncheon with reporters in New York yesterday, Mr. Durbin said short-term interest rates would probably rise a full percentage point over the next year.
Based on his forecast for interest rates, and what he called the market's sky-high valuations, Mr. Durbin said Morgan was advising investors to shed United States stocks and bonds and buy stocks in Japan, Europe and the emerging markets.
Traders said the rise in long-term interest rates yesterday was caused by positioning in front of a heavy calendar of coming corporate debt issues. And the rising rates probably did not help brokerage stocks.
Aside from the slide in Lehman's stock, Goldman Sachs, which is expected to report earnings today, fell 1 1/2, to 68. Merrill Lynch dropped 2 1/2, to 75 3/4. And Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette fell 2 3/8, to 55 3/4.
Among Dow stocks, DuPont fell 2 7/16, to 67 3/4. International Paper lost 1 7/8, to 52 5/8. And Alcoa fell for a second day, dropping 1 1/8, to 62 1/4.
Elsewhere, shares in Alza, the maker of sustained-release drugs, gained 1 1/2, to 47 3/4, after Abbott Laboratories said it would buy it for $7.3 billion in stock. In what was generally a good day for drug stocks, Abbott fell 1 1/16, to 43 1/2.
Oil stocks were weaker.
Chevron, a Dow component, fell 9/16, to 90 1/8, after it said a fire at its refinery near San Francisco would cut second-quarter profits by about 15 cents a share.
Mobil dropped 1 7/16, to 98. Exxon fell 1 1/4, to 77. And BP Amoco dropped 1 1/16, to 110 1/2.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Yield Rises To 6.06% For 30-Year Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices for Treasuries fell yesterday as corporate borrowers prepared to sell about $10 billion in debt. Traders and analysts also said that expectations continued to weigh on the market that the Federal Reserve will increase short-term rates at its two-day policy meeting next week.
For the second consecutive day, the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond stayed above 6 percent as market participants had more reasons to sell securities than to buy them. The supply of debt easily outstripped demand and the Government and corporate issuers came to market at the same time and found themselves competing for cash. 
 By the close of the New York cash market, the yield on the 30-year bond was 6.06 percent, up from 6.02 percent on Monday; its price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 1 5/32, to 88 31/32.
The Ford Motor Credit Company, Avis Rent a Car and other companies are getting ready this week to sell debt before the Fed raises short-term rates. Typically, underwriters issuing corporate debt sell Treasuries from their portfolios as a hedge until their corporate deals are done -- and thus put the Treasuries market under pressure. After the corporate deals are completed, the securities firms then buy back Treasuries and return them to their portfolios.
Ford is expected to sell $3 billion to $6 billion worth of debt in blocks to international investors. Neither the precise size nor the timing of the sale has been set, but traders expect the deal to occur this week.
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Burlingame, Calif., said that the coming corporate and Government issues had the bond market focusing on the lack of demand and higher rates. "So with the Fed close to raising short-term rates, it's not surprising why no one wants to step up and buy new supply," he said.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $10 billion of a new 52-week bill, and it will auction $15 billion of a new two-year note today. By late in the afternoon the note was being offered at a price to yield 5.65 percent.
The bill auction yesterday was described as mediocre at best, with the bills awarded at a rate of 4.89 percent, worse than expected. The bid-to-cover ratio, or the number of bids compared with the amount being sold, was 2.6 to 1, only marginally better than the ratio last month but far less than the average ratio of 3.14 to 1 for the last 12 auctions.
Treasuries were also being hurt by concern that the dollar may decline in the coming months. This concern came after the release earlier this month of figures that showed the Japanese economy grew a greater-than-expected 1.9 percent in the first quarter.
A weaker dollar makes Treasury securities less appealing to international investors who see their investments lose value when they convert them into other currencies.
Elsewhere, Mexico sold its first euro-denominated issue, raising 400 million euro, or about $412.6 million, through J. P. Morgan & Company and Paribas. The yield on the seven-year bond was 9.625 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a new one-year bill:

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Meets Refugees, and Pledges to Aid Kosovo

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: STANKOVIC CAMP, Macedonia, June 22

 BODY:
In the shadow of Kosovo, President Clinton came today to meet face-to-face with the people on whose behalf he had fought the war. He heard their stories of brutality and vowed that he would help make their homeland safe.
The visit to this muddy refugee camp, now emptying at the rate of more than 1,000 people a day, was planned while the NATO air attacks were at their peak and an end to the war seemed far away. 
 But today, this camp, the first established in Macedonia and once overflowing with 30,000 refugees, was in the throes of closing down and in several weeks will most likely be an empty, trash-strewn field.
Mr. Clinton could have made this visit a stirring conclusion to a conflict that caught the imagination at home only fitfully but represented survival to the Kosovar Albanians who escaped Serbian brutality to find shelter here.
Instead, standing on a crude wooden box and without the trappings of the White House podium, Mr. Clinton spoke in muted tones to a crowd of several hundred refugees, their faces now brighter at the prospect of going home, though often to homes burned and looted by the Serbs.
"We are committed not only to making Kosovo safe but to helping people rebuild their lives, rebuild their communities and then helping Kosovo and all the countries of the region," he said during his speech of a few minutes.
Accompanied by Hillary Rodham Clinton, who was here last month, and Chelsea, Mr. Clinton stopped by a selected group of refugees whose well-spruced tents were at the entrance to the camp. He heard first-hand a version of a story that had been told repeatedly on television and newspapers since nearly one million Kosovar Albanians were forced over the borders in late March.
Idriz Macastena, 29, his wife, Nerimane, 26, with their son, Besart, 4, described their escape from their home near Podujevo, in northern Kosovo, soon after the NATO bombing started.
Mr. Macastena described how they fled to a nearby village in the mountains, and then how, as they tried to leave in a convoy of cars and tractors for Pristina, the capital, the Serbs attacked. "Sixty people were massacred," Mr. Macastena said.
In his account to reporters, before Mr. Clinton arrived, Mr. Macastena, a carpenter, said the Serbs took one man from each of the vehicles in the second half of the convoy and killed them.
After reaching Pristina, Mr. Macastena told Mr. Clinton, his family stayed for five weeks. Soldiers of the Yugoslav Army surrounded the building where they were staying, he said, beat many of the Kosovar Albanians and threatened their son, Besart, with a knife and a lighted cigarette held to his neck.
When Mrs. Clinton told Mr. Macastena's wife, Nerimane, that her son -- decked out in clean white jeans and a vest for the occasion -- was a "beautiful boy," the mother replied: "He's still very much afraid. He has suffered very much. He has seen people killed and wounded."
Like many of the refugees at the camp, some of the Macastena family had already returned to Kosovo, the couple told the Clintons.
Besides the refugees, Mr. Clinton had other business here: dealing with the leaders of Macedonia whose country was economically battered by the war. Mr. Clinton met with the President, Kiro Gligorov, and pledged as Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright had done 10 days before, that the West would help restore the economy.
Mr. Clinton announced a gift of $12 million in food commodities, assistance that some officials described as modest given the dramatic economic decline here and the attention paid by Mr. Clinton's visit.
Mr. Clinton said that the clothing manufacturer, Liz Claiborne, would reopen Macedonian factories so that 2,000 to 3,000 Macedonians could work again.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: This Bud's for Them;
Anheuser-Busch Takes Closer Aim at Foreign Markets

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
When Anheuser-Busch decided to go full throttle into the Argentine beer market, it looked around for advertising opportunities and found one in the form of Marcelo Tinelli, Argentina's answer to Jay Leno with a little "Candid Camera" thrown in. Mr. Tinelli is on the air five nights a week, cracking jokes, interviewing guests -- and, in recent months, sipping Budweiser from a can in front of millions of viewers.
Thanks in part to the magic of product placement, Budweiser's sales in Argentina soared 61 percent in the first quarter of the year. 
 Argentina is just one of many overseas markets -- the others include Britain, China, Ireland and Japan -- where the Anheuser-Busch Companies is pouring it on with its flagship brand. Through aggressive marketing to a young, upscale and better-educated slice of the world's population -- the same people who drink imports, as it happens, back in St. Louis, where Anheuser is based -- the company is hoping to turn Budweiser into a truly global brand, something no other beer has ever pulled off.
Anheuser is intensifying its marketing abroad at a time of great strength at home. After a long and nasty price war with its closest rival, the Miller Brewing Company unit of the Philip Morris Companies, Anheuser has remained the leader in the United States, with a 45 percent market share, slightly more than it had five years ago.
Volume has risen slightly in recent months, and the company has used the promise of extra marketing funds to entice many distributors to deal exclusively in its products.
Having conquered the American market, Anheuser is now hoping to follow in the footsteps of the Coca-Cola Company and the Gillette Company, and burnish its stock, which has been something of a sleeper lately, through overseas expansion.
For all the risks of such a global strategy, from the potential for economic turbulence in emerging markets to publicity nightmares like Belgium's ban on Coke last week, analysts say it is about time. While Coke, the undisputed worldwide king of cola, was selling one million cases of its products a year in Shanghai back in 1926, Anheuser did not even form an international division until 1982. "They were so late to this game, it was just unbelievable," said Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst for Salomon Smith Barney.
Getting a late start is the least of the company's problems. Selling American beer to finicky foreigners is tough going. After all, most of the world acknowledges America as the land of the soft drink and the home of the technologically advanced razor blade. But outside of the United States, beer lovers tend to be fiercely loyal to local brands, many of which date back hundreds of years, and scorn American beer as boredom in a bottle.
Even the master brewers of Europe have a hard sell when they stray too far from home. For example, about 62 percent of the beer made by Heineken, the Dutch brewer, and 70 percent of the volume produced by Carlsberg A.S. of Denmark is sold in the European Union, according to Frank Walters, the director of research at Impact, a trade newsletter in New York. If it is tough for them, people in the industry say, it will be doubly hard for Anheuser.
"They are a small international force now, and they will work very hard to become a major force," said Dan Tearno, a spokesman for Heineken USA. "But I would say they have their work cut out for them."
Along with the task of building the brand abroad, there is the sticky matter of a decades-old trademark dispute that prevents Anheuser from using the name Budweiser in many European countries. Budweiser Budvar, a Czech brewery, claims rights to the name stretching back to medieval times and has vigorously challenged Anheuser's use of it, with several lawsuits pending in countries like France and the Netherlands, where Anheuser's beer is labeled "Bud."
Anheuser "would try to persuade the world (and perhaps themselves as well) that Budweiser is a fantasy trademark which does not have its roots in Budejovice but is exclusively connected with America," a note on the Budweiser Budvar Web site, www.budweiser.cz, says. Ceske Budejovice, the town where Budweiser Budvar is brewed, is Budweis in German.
Anheuser is playing hardball in return. "Periodically, some of their beer has leaked in here," Steven J. Burrows, the chief executive of Anheuser International, said of the other Budweiser, "and as soon as we know about here or anywhere else where we have clear rights to the name, we go right after it."
Mr. Burrows said the disputes were confined to Europe and had little effect on Anheuser's overseas sales. "In some markets, we coexist," he said. "In some markets, we have gained the right to use 'Budweiser'." In one market -- the Czech Republic -- Anheuser's beer is banned outright.
Anheuser has tried to acquire a minority stake in Budweiser Budvar on several occasions, most recently in 1992, provoking further animosity.
Anheuser's recent stepped-up effort abroad may have been inspired by the dimensions of imported beer's growth in the United States. Imports accounted for 8 percent of the United States market of 193 million barrels last year, up from 5.5 percent five years ago on similar consumption, and surged by 21 percent in the first quarter of this year even as overall beer consumption barely increased, Mr. Walters said.
But although beer is not Coke, Anheuser has been able to borrow certain pages from the Coca-Cola playbook. It is concentrating its efforts around its flagship, Budweiser, and playing up its product's American cachet. It is also adapting its packaging to the demands of international markets, introducing one-liter bottles in Argentina and China, for example, in addition to the 12-ounce single-serving cans and bottles that are more popular in the United States. And in another echo of Coke strategy, Anheuser says it understands the need to make large investments of money and patience overseas before sales take off.
Unlike Coke, though, Anheuser is new to the global way of thinking. "It's taken Anheuser some time to genuinely admit that people make beer outside of St. Louis," said Ms. Solomon of Salomon Smith Barney. "There's always been this idea that beer is such a regional business that American beer is for American customers."
That mentality is changing. Anheuser knows that the United States, where the beer-chugging population of men in their 20's will increase over the next few years, remains its core market. Still, Mr. Burrows said, "the opportunity for long-term growth and increasing shareholder value will come from expanding our business beyond the U.S."
Recently, that expansion has slowed. After shooting up more than 13 percent in both 1996 and 1997, the company's total overseas beer sales rose just six-tenths of 1 percent last year, largely as a result of the recession in Japan, according to the company's annual report. And overseas sales reached just 7.1 million barrels last year, around 7 percent of the total, with profits around 6.7 percent of Anheuser's total beer profits.
Foreign expansion is a costly exercise. Like Coca-Cola, Anheuser believes that a key to winning converts is making a product that tastes exactly the same everywhere in the world. So it sends brewmasters to its overseas plants to supervise the making of Budweiser from ingredients that are mostly imported from the United States. "If you don't have a consistent product, you can't build up brand loyalty," Mr. Walters said.
Anheuser was forced to modify its strategy in Japan last year. In the last three years, as the country's economy has been mired in recession, a cheaper beer type known as happoshu has emerged, supported by a reduced Government tax on such beer, which is less than 25 percent malt, Mr. Burrows said.
Anheuser sat out the first round, watching as Suntory Ltd. cornered the market for products priced about 30 percent below the 200 yen, or $1.75, that most premium beers are sold for. When Suntory's share went from zero to 18 percent in the category, Anheuser had a change of heart and began marketing its own brand of lower-malt beer, called Buddy's.
"We thought it was important to compete," Mr. Burrows said. Earlier this year, Anheuser also introduced a beer called Budweiser Fine Malt, intended for the older consumer, with a flavor that Mr. Burrows described as "slightly more bitter, fuller, darker, consistent with a Japanese beer profile." In other words, not a lager. Anheuser reported selling about 500,000 barrels of beer in Japan last year.
China has become Anheuser's fifth-largest overseas market since Budweiser was introduced there in 1993. Sold largely in hotels, discos and restaurants in coastal cities like Shanghai and Guangzhou, Bud is known locally as Baiwei, which Mr. Burrows translates as "100 magnificents."
Even so, China has been a complex frontier. Budweiser is priced two to three times higher than local premium beers, and distribution is a piecemeal arrangement. A price war among international beer makers in China during the last half of 1998 cut into sales because Anheuser did not lower its prices and volume declined, Mr. Burrows said. A lower-priced beer is being sold this year in test markets there, also under the Buddy's brand.
The largest foreign market for Budweiser is Canada, where 1.7 million barrels, brewed under arrangement with the Labatt Brewing Company unit of Interbrew of Belgium, were sold last year. It has also been successful in Ireland, where a 1986 distribution arrangement with Guinness, a Diageo P.L.C. subsidiary, has made Budweiser one of the top three beers. (Guinness, meanwhile, is still No. 1, followed by Budweiser or Heineken, depending on who is counting.)
Anheuser is aiming at younger people overseas because they are more likely to experiment with new brands. To lure them in Japan, for example, the company peddles Budweiser clothing and other products on the Web, and hands out free samples in bars.
Anheuser has been able to export many of its other tried-and-true marketing devices as well. The famed frogs appear in commercials in Ireland, England and on ESPN broadcasts around the world. The "Budweiser girls," spandex-clad representatives at various company-sponsored events, have their overseas incarnations as well. In China, generally a more conservative place socially, the women often turn up at bars dressed in skirts, vests and tennis shoes, Mr. Burrows said, although miniskirts are not unheard of. "It's whatever people in the market are most comfortable with," he said.
In Argentina, per capita beer consumption has risen to 9.275 gallons a year from 7.95 over the last 15 years, while wine consumption has declined. Budweiser signs have cropped up on venerable restaurant facades across Buenos Aires, including that of Los Inmortales, a shrine to tango, which now has four big red-and-white Bud signs. A major factor in Budweiser's advance has been the partnership with Compania Cervecerias Unidas, an established distributor that had long wanted to increase its sales in Argentina and was willing to compete against Quilmes, the most popular local beer, although Budweiser is priced higher.
Anheuser has also tried to affiliate its brand closely with popular sports events. Budweiser is the exclusive beer sponsor for the Copa America soccer competition in South America, for example. It also sponsors horse races in Ireland and American football matches in England.
As it tries to drive Budweiser sales overseas, Anheuser has made equity investments in other beer makers, notably Grupo Modelo S.A. de C.V., which makes Corona, the top-selling import in the United States. Anheuser holds a $1.6 billion, 50.2 percent stake in Modelo, profiting every time a Corona is sold even though it does not own the brand. And the company has an 8 percent stake in C.C.U. Argentina, its Argentine distributor, which, if one takes the long view, may carry Anheuser beyond Argentina. "Argentina is next to Brazil," Emanuel Goldman, a global consumer-products analyst for Merrill Lynch, pointed out, "and on a long-term basis, Brazil is very much in Anheuser's plans."

HEADLINE: Cecilia Danieli, 56, Is Dead; Developer of Steel Minimills

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, June 22

 BODY:
Cecilia Danieli, who helped revolutionize the world steel industry by developing the compact steel mills known in the industry as minimills, died last Thursday of cancer. She was 56.
Though women made broad strides in Italian business in her lifetime, Ms. Danieli was one of a handful who reached the top in the male domain of heavy industry. Her presence at the top, she once said, meant that Danieli consistently boasted a higher percentage of women in management posts than Italian companies of comparable size. 
 The company she ran, Danieli Group, founded by her grandfather in the family's hometown of Buttrio in Northern Italy, developed in the 1950's from a small manufacturer of scissors and shears to a supplier of compact steel mills to small Northern Italian steelmakers that mainly supplied the steel reinforcing bars that were the sinews of postwar Italian reconstruction.
Beginning in the 1970's, the company began shipping its engineers abroad to build mills in places like Mozambique to produce steel bars or rolling mills in the United States. These mills revolutionized steelmaking and tilted the market away from the developed world by giving scores of countries in Africa, South America and the East Asia the means to produce steel cheaply and efficiently. They ultimately led, in highly industrialized countries like the United States, to the decline of traditional big steel mills and their replacement by smaller, more flexible minimills.
Ms. Danieli, one of four sisters, was forced to take charge of the family company founded by her grandfather in 1914 in the mid-1970's, when the oil price increases in the first half of that decade drained the capital to invest in steel and scuttled further expansion. In 1976, the company posted its first loss ever. That year, she assumed the top position of managing director next to her father, Luigi, who remained president of the company but concentrated on the engineering side of the business.
She quickly rejuvenated Danieli's management, then gained a major breakthrough when the company captured a $240 million contract for a steel mill in the former East Germany from its nearest competitor, the giant Krupp group of the former West Germany. She also expanded sales in North and South America, Asia and the former Soviet Union.
In addition to its Italian headquarters, the company, with roughly 3,000 employees, had affiliates in Youngstown, Ohio, and in Sweden.
In 1984, to keep the company financially as well as technologically fit, Ms. Danieli took the unusual step for Italian family-run companies, and against the opposition of her more traditional father, of listing Danieli on the stock exchange. About 54 percent of the company remained controlled by her and Gianpietro Benedetti, her companion, with whom she shared management of the company in recent years.
Ms. Danieli entered the company in 1969 after earning a degree in economics at nearby Trieste University. A fluent English speaker, she once worked as a student for a summer on a truck farm near Schuylerville, N.Y. She avoided the limelight often favored by Italian executives. But Danieli's business success reflected her drive for technical superiority and her untiring sales efforts. A passionate student of history and a mountain climber, in the mid-1990's she once spent Christmas Day in the mountains of Iran to negotiate a sale.
She is survived by Mr. Benedetti and three children.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Dealer To Take a Charge

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS PARK, Minn., June 22

 BODY:
The Metris Companies, a marketer of credit cards to people with bad or limited credit histories, said today that it would take a one-time charge of $152.4 million for the conversion of preferred stock by a big investor.
Metris said the Thomas H. Lee Company, a Boston-based buyout specialist, had converted its existing holdings of preferred stock, warrants and notes into new preferred stock. Converting the investment created a one-time charge because the fair value of the new preferred stock is greater than that of Lee's original $300 million investment. 
 Shares of Metris rose $4.3125, or 12 percent today, to $38.3125. They have gained more than 50 percent this year.
Metris makes money by selling credit cards and related products like credit insurance and travel club memberships to consumers that bank lenders usually do not seek. In exchange for taking the higher risk, Metris charges higher interest rates, often in excess of 20 percent, and fees.

HEADLINE: An Old Solution, One-Time Revenue, Is Again Placed on the Budget Table

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 22

 BODY:
Despite a $2 billion surplus, Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature plan to resort to one-time sources of money, like selling assets or tapping little-known state funds, to resolve their differences on the state budget, the lawmakers and their aides said today.
Officials in both parties said the maneuvers were meant to bridge the gap in spending between the plans of Mr. Pataki and the Legislature, while allowing the Governor to cling to his contention that the budget increase is within the rate of inflation. Mr. Pataki has railed against one-time budget gimmicks in the past and has greatly reduced the state's reliance on them. 
 Also today, the Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said that his house would not consider anything but emergency bills for the rest of the year, apparently ruling out action on a wide range of issues, from campaign finance reform to the question of where to build new power plants, on which there are differences between the two houses.
"Any of these issues that we have two different versions of, we'll take up in January," he said.
Mr. Bruno's comments came as a surprise to interest groups and legislators pushing for a variety of laws -- like making it a crime to block access to abortion clinics and increasing penalties for hate crimes -- and set his aides scrambling to assure reporters and others that some of these issues may still be alive.
He insisted that with the 1999 legislative session having reached its scheduled conclusion last week, the Senate would focus on the budget, now nearly three months overdue.
But the Senate has been reduced to a spectator's role in budget talks, as the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, and Mr. Pataki try to reach a loose agreement on how much the state should spend. Once an overall figure is set, the two houses of the Legislature will convene conference committees to work out the details.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, has proposed a $72.7 billion budget, while the Senate's Republican majority is calling for $1.1 billion more. Mr. Silver, a Democrat, after earlier insisting on much higher spending, has all but agreed to the Senate figure, but he wants assurances that the Governor will not veto large parts of the budget, as he did last year.
Today, Mr. Bruno confirmed that there was talk of taking money from special state accounts and of selling or leasing some state assets to increase revenues. "We are open and receptive to utilizing funds that are available," he said.
Legislative aides in both houses said that using the money was the Governor's idea, and was agreed to by Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno. Lawmakers would put the money into a special fund for a specific purpose, so that it would not be counted in the state's $35 billion General Fund, allowing Mr. Pataki to assert that the General Fund had not grown faster than the rate of inflation.
Using one-time revenues would also allow the Governor to raise spending this year while keeping his promise to set aside all of the state's $2 billion surplus to insure that the state will be able to pay for property tax cuts scheduled for next year.
Top aides in both houses, said that at the Governor's suggestion, lawmakers planned to take money -- perhaps hundreds of millions of dollars -- from a fund created in the 1980's to help doctors pay for medical malpractice insurance, which has a large surplus. The state has tapped into the fund before, during the recession of the early 1990's.
But when asked, Mr. Pataki insisted, "We're not going to raid funds."
He acknowledged that he was looking at raising money through privatization, like the state's plan to turn Stewart Airport over to a private operator. He and his aides refused to say what assets he had in mind.
Independent budget analysts have long criticized the state for relying on "one shot" revenues, and they were again critical of the plan today. "The budget's outrageously late, but it would be even more outrageous to resort to gimmicks to balance the budget in this economy," said Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission.
Aides to Mr. Pataki insisted that the money would be used to pay for one-time expenses, not recurring needs.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Two New Airline Alliances Are Aimed at Sharpening Competition

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Two new airline alliances were announced yesterday, between Delta Air Lines and Air France, and among AMR's American Airlines, Swissair and Sabena World Airlines of Belgium.
While both accords are expected to integrate flight schedules and frequent-flier programs between partner airlines, the Delta-Air France long-range plan is to bring other partners into their fold, so they can better compete with the eight-member Star Alliance, led by UAL's United Airlines, and the eight-member One World alliance, led by American Airlines. Both the Star Alliance and One World consist of at least one airline from Europe, Asia, South America and Australia. 
 Airline partnerships, an outgrowth of the "open sky" agreements that have pried open aviation markets around the globe, have accelerated tremendously since Northwest Airlines and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines linked up in 1993. Eleven European airlines from seven nations banded together last year under the name of the Qualiflyer Group, and now serve more than 300 destinations. Austrian Airlines, Sabena and Swissair are members of the Atlantic Excellence partnership, as is Delta -- which said yesterday that it would continue as a member.
Many airlines belong to one or more alliances, because each one is thought to confer different strengths. Later this year Continental Airlines is expected to join the Wings alliance, which currently consists of Alitalia, KLM and Northwest. Yet Continental is already allied with Northwest and Alitalia, and Alitalia is a partner with KLM. And several Asian airlines that are not yet committed to existing alliances -- as Singapore Airlines appears committed to the Star Alliance -- have talked about forming a regional alliance.
Smaller airlines benefit from alliances by being able to expand their reach with the help of their partners, a reach that otherwise would be financially prohibitive. And bigger airlines benefit by being able to offer their passengers seamless travel and flights on partner airlines to destinations to which they could never afford to fly on their own.
Early results suggest that alliances can be profitable. Last month, both United and Lufthansa said that their membership in the Star Alliance -- which also includes Air Canada, Air New Zealand, Ansett of Australia, Scandinavian Airlines System, Thai Airways and Varig of Brazil -- contributed significantly to their respective bottom lines. United said the alliance contributed about $200 million, or about 10 percent, of its $2.3 billion profit in 1998. For Lufthansa, the alliance contributed about 18 percent, or $265 million, of its 1998 operating profit of $1.5 billion.
 
Travel in the Balkans
The end of the NATO bombing campaign in the Balkans will not revive the region's travel or tourist industry anytime soon. But Austrian Airlines has already restored its daily flight between Vienna and Skopje, Macedonia, and is evaluating whether to restore service to Tirana, the capital of Albania. Both flights were suspended after the bombs began falling on March 24.
Two months ago PricewaterhouseCoopers estimated that the fighting in the Balkans could cost hotels, travel agencies, airlines and cruise ships as much as $100 million. The conflict certainly seems to have taken a heavy toll on travel to Western Europe.
"Regardless of whether you think of it as 'Clinton's War,' 'NATO's War,' 'Our War' or 'Their War,' there is no question that the American-led nightly bombings of Yugoslavia have brought the annual summer invasion of American tourists into Europe to a near halt," Joel M. Abels, the editor and publisher of Travel Trade, wrote in that trade publication's issue of June 14. With few exceptions, he added, "travel agents, tour operators, cruise lines and airlines watched as the booking season was stopped practically dead in its tracks."
Most travel industry analysts think that situation will improve, now that the bombing has ended -- especially since airlines, cruise ships and European hotels are dangling attractive discounts. British Airways and American Airlines are currently offering two round-trip economy tickets to London for the price of one, with certain restrictions. And cruise lines are dangling upgrades and substantial discounts on their Mediterranean cruises. Windstar Cruises is offering as much as 50 percent on its European itineraries, plus a ship-board credit of $100 for guests who book by July 19.
 
Order for New Ships
Princess Cruises, which is owned by the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, has ordered four new ships for delivery between October 2001 and May 2004.
Two of the ships, which will carry 1,950 passengers each, will be built by Chantiers de l'Atlantique of France. The other two, which will each accommodate 2,600 passengers, will be built by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan. P & O Cruises, a sister company, has also ordered a 2,600-passenger ship from Fincantieri of Italy. The five ships will cost approximately $2 billion.
Including three ships already under construction and scheduled for delivery through 2002, the Princess fleet will grow from 9 ships currently to 16 and the number of berths will more than double to 30,000.

HEADLINE: World Bank and Treasury Nominee at Odds Over Loan to China

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
In a rare public conflict between Washington and the World Bank, Treasury Secretary-designate Lawrence H. Summers said today that the United States would vote against a disputed loan to China that would resettle poor Chinese farmers to land that Tibetans claim as their own.
Despite the Clinton Administration objections, World Bank officials said they expected that the loan would probably be approved at a meeting of the bank's board on Thursday. Originally, the vote was to take place today, but it was delayed so that James Wolfensohn, the bank's president, could preside over what has become an highly politicized dispute over the institution's role in China. 
 If the United States opposes the loan, as Mr. Summers indicated it will during his confirmation hearing today, it will probably further strain relations with Beijing. Chinese officials have said American efforts to block the loan are interfering with China's internal affairs.
It would also put Mr. Summers in open disagreement with Mr. Wolfensohn, a strong-minded former investment banker who was the Administration's choice to run the bank -- a job Mr. Summers once sought. He has resisted pressure to change terms of the loan, arguing that it aids some of China's poorest people, exactly what the bank's anti-poverty programs are intended to do.
World Bank officials say the effects of the voluntary resettlement of 58,000 farmers on the ethnic makeup of the region has been vastly exaggerated by pro-Tibet groups. Their complaints have carried the day in Congress, however, where Tibet's resistance to Beijing's mandates are a popular cause.
"The United States will be voting to oppose the project because of concerns in the environmental areas and concerns in the resettlement areas," Mr. Summers said today.
The Treasury Department represents the United States on the bank's board, where Washington holds 18 percent of the votes -- not enough to block a loan unless it wins over many allies. "I think this may pass over the American objections," one senior member of the bank's board said today.
Under the plan the bank would lend China $40 million to move the farmers from an overcrowded and badly eroded area in the northeastern corner of Qinghai Province to a sparsely populated, somewhat less poor region in the province 300 miles west.
Qinghai, just north of the Tibet Autonomous Region on the Tibetan Plateau, was settled by Tibetans and Mongolians. Today, however, most of its five million residents are ethnic Chinese.
The Tibetan groups that have campaigned against the World Bank project say that it will help Beijing dilute Tibetan culture. American officials clearly have their doubts about that argument, but they were unwilling to defend the loan and appear to be siding with Beijing. Forty percent of the proposed settlers would be ethnic Chinese, while the rest would be Hui Muslims and others, including some ethnic Tibetans. The bank says it believes that effects on Tibetan culture would be negligible.
While the United States often abstains from voting for World Bank projects, especially those involving China, it is rare for Mr. Wolfensohn and the Administration to be caught in such open discord over China policy. The fight could be costly: support for both the bank and its sister institution, the International Monetary Fund, is scarce in Congress.
American opposition to the loan may also inflame opinions in China, where anti-American demonstrations following NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last month led to claims that the United States is trying to undercut the Beijing Government. China already regards the whole debate as an effort to back followers of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader.

HEADLINE: Budget Finale in Albany

 BODY:
Without the pressure of deadlines, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature would be arguing about this year's New York State budget until Halloween. But since a raft of previously enacted Medicaid cost reductions are due to expire next Wednesday, wiping out savings that state and local governments were counting on, a strong incentive exists for all sides to reach an agreement soon. In a welcome step, Sheldon Silver, Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, has scaled back his spending demands. It remains for Mr. Pataki to compromise by dropping proposed cuts in school aid and health care payments and promising not to veto at least some of the items desired by the lawmakers. 
 The stalemate results from an unusual set of financial circumstances. Prosperity, particularly on Wall Street, has created a state budget surplus of at least $2 billion. But because the Governor and the Legislature have enacted budgets in past years with tax cuts and expenses that balloon in size, the state is projecting multibillion-dollar deficits in the future. Mr. Pataki was thus in the odd position of demanding austerity for the lean years ahead at a time when the state is flush. However prudent his position might seem fiscally, it has not succeeded politically. Even the Republican-controlled Senate has made it clear it would reject his proposed cuts in health and education.
The Governor's $73 billion budget, announced in January, was punitive in many respects. It reneged on commitments to help New York City, and its cuts in school aid, college tuition assistance and payments to hospitals, nursing homes and health clinics hit New Yorkers of modest means the hardest. Mr. Silver has been right to oppose the worst of these cuts, but his opening bid of adding $2.6 billion in spending was too much for the Governor and the State Senate. His request is now said to be in the range of $1.1 billion.
That seems like a reasonable number for Mr. Pataki to accept without resorting to gimmicks or raiding independent state funds. The first priority should be schools, especially in the city. The Governor and the Legislature should then make sure that Medicaid reimbursement rates are sufficient to maintain health care for the poor and uninsured. There should be some funding also for vital mental health programs, especially for potentially unstable people released from mental hospitals.
New Yorkers wondering why any cuts at all are necessary in prosperous times need look no further than the enact-now, pay-later strategy of their elected leaders. The Governor's zeal for cutting taxes is appreciated by voters, and he has indeed forced a fundamental change in New York's fiscal policy. But New Yorkers have also never been given an honest accounting when it comes to tax cuts. At some point they will have to realize that the price for tax cuts may be unacceptably large spending cuts in areas of vital interest. First the Governor and the Legislature have to get through this year. A spirit of compromise would help.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Measure to Limit Imports Of Steel Is Killed by Senate
The Senate killed a bill that would have sharply restricted imports of foreign steel to the United States, a blow to unions and steelmakers and a victory for President Clinton, who had warned that the legislation would revive protectionism.
The bill, which became a divisive argument over the merits of free trade and the economic wisdom of protecting steelworkers at the expense of raising prices on a range of everyday goods, would have rolled back imports of steel to the levels before the Asian economic crisis, ending a surge that began as countries sought to export their way out of trouble. Page A1. 

Lehman Brothers Posts Solid Profit
Lehman Brothers, which has been broadening from its traditional base as a bond house into equities and investment banking, reported second-quarter earnings that were far above analysts' expectations. But despite the unexpectedly high profits, shares of the company fell $3.6875, or 6.11 percent, to $56.625, on volume of more than four million shares -- more than four times the daily average. C2.
 
3Com Results Beat Expectations
3Com reported fourth-quarter earnings a penny above analysts' expectations based on strong growth in products used to manage data flow over networks. C2.
 
Stock Prices in Broad Retreat
Stock prices staged a broad retreat as a further rise in long-term interest rates and a late round of selling depressed the market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 94.35 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 10,721.63. Technology stocks dragged down the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index. The S.& P. 500 lost 13.12 points, or just less than 1 percent, to 1,335.88. Nasdaq fell 50.02 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,580.26. C14.
 
Bond prices fell as corporate borrowers prepared to sell about $10 billion in debt. The yield on the benchmark 30-year issue rose to 6.06 percent from 6.02 percent. C14.
 
Senate Panel Approves Summers
The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved the nomination of Lawrence H. Summers, left, to be the next Secretary of the Treasury, clearing the way for a confirmation vote by the full Senate as early as next week. But the majority leader, Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, said a final vote could be pushed back because Democrats were threatening to add health care reform and other initiatives to spending bills over Republican objections. C2.
 
Europeans to Inspect Coke Plants
The 15-nation European Union announced plans for health inspections of its own in Coca-Cola's plants in Belgium and France that had produced soft drinks blamed for outbreaks of illness early this month. C11.
 
Ford Plans Factory in Russia
Ford Motor announced a preliminary agreement with the Russian Government to begin construction in July of an automobile factory near St. Petersburg. C11.
 
New Proposals on Fund Directors
The mutual fund industry's leading trade group, the Investment Company Institute, is expected to recommend sweeping new rules tomorrow to strengthen the role of independent directors, going beyond earlier proposals by Arthur Levitt, the S.E.C. chairman. C8.
 
Technology Said to Enrich Economy
The financial benefits of the Internet and high technology go beyond quick riches for high-profile entrepreneurs and investors to the nation's entire economy, according to a Commerce Department study. C8.
 
Last Witness Appears for Microsoft
Microsoft's final witness at its antitrust trial, Richard L. Schmalensee, dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, contended there was no substance to any of the Government's charges and that Microsoft, far from holding a monopoly in personal computer operating system software, faced vicious and serious competitors. C8.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2018 words

HEADLINE: Lagging on Year 2000 Bug, Russia Starts Major Effort

SERIES: COUNTING TO 2000: The Russian Riddle

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 22

 BODY:
Armed with thick repair manuals and rosters of experts, Russian officials have opened an all-out campaign to expel the so-called year 2000 bug from the nation's eight million computers, their microchips and their programs.
But 60 miles south of the Kremlin in the little town of Stupino, Mike Tuffs is not waiting for the victory party. Mr. Tuffs, regional technology manager for Mars Inc., the American candy maker, asked the regional government and utility officials last year how they planned to deal with the bug. 
 What he found was that many did not know that their equipment was vulnerable and that others believed -- wrongly -- that they were already protected.
Mars has since outfitted its two Russian factories so that they can continue some production during power and water breakdowns, and it is stockpiling raw materials in anticipation of transportation and customs problems.
"Our greatest concern is for public utilities and state organizations," Mr. Tuffs said. "It would appear that many public organizations are not aware of the equipment that they use and how they interact and how a failure in one area will affect another."
What worries Mr. Tuffs also rattles the technology chiefs of other companies, as well as computer experts and consultants. They say Russia has awakened to the year 2000 threat too late, spread the alarm too thinly and has far too little money to perform much more than digital triage on the Government and economy.
"There's a potential for major damage to the infrastructure," said Andrei N. Terekhov, a mathematician from St. Petersburg and the general director of Lanit-Terkom, a business that works on year 2000 problems.
The difficulties arise from longtime reliance of computer programs on two-digit date fields for any year, with 19 presumed to be the preceding digits. Many programs were custom written by people who have died, dropped out sight or have moved to Western Europe or the United States and are working on the problem there. "There are obsolete applications on which, very often, entire factories, banks and real-time critical systems depend," Mr. Terekhov said.
There is also the potential that not much will happen. Government officials say they are addressing all problems in critical areas like atomic energy and nuclear missiles. American officials said they were confident that human safeguards would prevent accidental launchings. The semiprivate companies that supply power, gas and other essential services say they are at work, too.
In addition, Russia enjoys a peculiar advantage. Because it has been slow to adopt computer technology, many functions like factory processes can be run manually.
Alexander Miasnikov, a representative here of the Gartner Group, technology consultants from Connecticut, said in an e-mail posting that most major Russian companies would solve year 2000 problems in their central operations, but that "in remote branches there can be some problems."
The Government predicted in April that even if its assault on the year 2000 bug proceeded as planned, up to a fifth of all computers would malfunction in January. With 56,000 Government computer systems, 16,000 of them critical, officials worry about everything from inoperative elevators to a freeze-up in the network that is supposed to tabulate the vote in the parliamentary election on Jan. 12.
"I can't and shouldn't say either that something is not going to happen or speak of catastrophic outcomes," said Aleksandr Krupnov, the chairman of the state Committee on Telecommunications and Information Technology, which is leading the effort on the year 2000. "I stick to something in the middle."
The Government effort began in earnest in the fall. Regional centers were set up to certify technicians whom businesses could hire. A Government-wide inspection of equipment and new backup plans were ordered. American officials familiar with the plans said Moscow was serious and focused. Nevertheless, the problems are huge. An estimated two-thirds of the desktop computers need repair. But most owners cannot be warned. Many manufacturers are out of business or lack sales records.
Many programs used outside big businesses are bootlegged, illegally copied. Hundreds of military and industrial tasks rely on programs that are decades old, written by programmers who may have left Russia. And nearly everyone is too broke to spend on a nebulous bug, anyway.
The Government said its repairs would cost $1 billion to $3 billion. That is up to one-seventh of a Federal budget that already cannot pay some pensions and debts.
Most agencies have been told to raid their budgets to solve the problems. One expert here said some businesses were having trouble because the Western suppliers whose equipment needs upgrading have yet to be paid, and they are refusing to make repairs until they receive their money.
Much of the nation is uninterested or unaware of the threat. An informal survey of 50 civic leaders in Irkutsk, a city of 500,000 on the Mongolian border, showed that 20 had heard of year 2000 defects.
Ron Lewin, a computer consultant here who also heads the technology committee of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia, said:
"At this point, contingency planning is the most important element, developing plans on what to do if there is no water or no electricity. There's not a lot of time left, and there's a high likelihood of failure for some of the utilities."
 
$4 Million to Repair Weapons Systems
The one area where catastrophe seems all but impossible is in nuclear weapons. Officials say most crucial military computers, including those in the nuclear force, use programs that are not date sensitive, rendering them immune to year 2000 problems.
Russian and American officials allow that in a worst-case scenario early warning systems could send false signals as the satellites on which they rely drift slowly out of alignment. But because such errors have been anticipated, the chances that they would lead to a nuclear strike are all but nil.
Any remaining problems are so small, officers contend, that they can be erased with the installation soon of a mere $4 million worth of new computers and programs.
Washington and Moscow have also proposed exchanging radar information and other figures this winter to diminish the risk of misinterpretations. Russia has said it is suspending cooperation on year 2000 problems to protest the United States' role in the NATO attack on Yugoslavia. But that seems highly unlikely to affect nuclear weapons seriously.
Experts appear to believe that midwinter losses of electricity or other basic services will cause hardship in many areas, but stop short of human catastrophe. Brownouts and other breakdowns could cause millions of dollars in damage to industrial complexes like smelters and steel mills that depend on continuous power supplies. Telephone and data-transmission disruptions could leave businesses without the basic information that they need to compile bills and settle accounts.
The experts also are concerned about nuclear reactors and other highly complex sites. The fear is that workers usually adept at handling problems could be overwhelmed by four, five or six minor failures at once.
Russia does not depend on technology as much as the West, meaning that the damage could be limited. Soviet administrators sharply restricted the use of computers. The seven million desktops, 150,000 servers and several thousand mainframes in use are not extensive for such a technologically muscular country.
Although many factories operate with 1950's-technology hand switches and analog gauges, the industrial spine -- oil and gas pipelines, electrical grids, telephone systems and transportation networks -- all rely on microchips and computers to run smoothly.
Much of Russia and Europe's natural gas flows through the Siberian pipeline that belongs to Gazprom, a monopoly that the Government still largely owns. The Central Intelligence Agency says the mainframe computers at Gazprom almost certainly require revamping, as may be the case with microchips at hundreds of remote pumping stations.
Gazprom officials say they can handle any problems, perhaps by placing workers at the remote pumping stations. But the utility has not released details.
The electricity monopoly, Unified Energy Systems, said this month that 17,000 of its 50,000 computers had failed to meet year 2000 standards.
"We think that by September we will be able to replace the most important and vital parts of the system," a press release said. "We will try to renovate the rest by the end of the year."
 
Challenge for Airlines And Air Control
The Government says that it is renovating the only two major air-traffic-control centers that depend on digital computers, in Moscow and Rostov-on-Don, and that others do not require upgrades.
But most of the 400-odd Russian aviation companies have computers with year 2000 problems. The International Civil Aviation Organization is asking the Russian airlines and plane manufacturers for information on their preventive measures. In the spring, Russian insurance companies raised the rates charged airline companies in anticipation of year 2000 risks.
The Gartner Group, the consulting firm, ranks Russia among the worst prepared nations for the year 2000 transition. Gartner predicts a month of turmoil in Russian financial markets, two months for utilities and hospital and three months for transportation and telecommunications.
Other American specialists, though, say they believe that the Russians will weather whatever January brings by virtue of two proficiencies. One is their expertise in programming and maintaining computers, a skill honed by years of military spending. Russia may be poor, those experts say, but it has a corps of computer technologists deserving of any Westerner's envy.
The other advantage is the ability to deal with adversities. Suspensions of power, water and telephone service would cripple most Western cities. In much of Russia, such breakdowns are a fact of life.
 
International Firms Make Their Own Plans
But many multinational companies that have conducted their own research -- Nestle, British Petroleum and Global One, an international telecommunications concern -- have elected to prepare for trouble.
Mars candy executives say they expect power and telephone blackouts in early January, followed by weeks of scheduled brownouts. To avoid any tieup of imports and exports in customs offices, Mars will suspend international shipments around Jan. 1.
The company also has begun to educate local officials and businesses about the problem, part of a longstanding effort to maintain good relations with Moscow and the region. The need is there, Mr. Tuffs said. In some cases, Mars has received written assurances from officials outside Stupino that the area is ready for the new year, even when the company's examination proved otherwise.
Executives at Global One said the long-distance networks were safe, but planned to beef up emergency power supplies at a computer center downtown. Most local calls are routed and timed by a switch whose maker no longer exists, according to Lawrence Haw, a telecommunications consultant here.
"It's not year 2000 compatible," Mr. Haw said. "There's nobody to work on this switch. There haven't been any software upgrades. There's no vendor for the switch any more. So who's going to do the upgrades?"
Against this backdrop of possible chaos and uncertainty, more than a few Russian experts bridle at the notion that their efforts may not meet Western standards. When a top computer specialist at the Russian Federal Aviation Service, Boris V. Mikhailovich, was asked by a reporter whether year 2000 preparations at air-traffic-control centers were adequate, he had a ready response.
"What do you think I am?" he asked. "An enemy of my own people?"

Counting to 2000
 Articles under this heading throughout 1999 will examine efforts worldwide to prepare computers for the year 2000.

HEADLINE: 32 Receive Grants From MacArthur Foundation

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
The annual grants popularly known as the genius awards announced yesterday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation were heavily weighted toward the New York area, home to about a third of the 32 recipients.
"There is a clump there this year because we just couldn't pass them up," said Daniel J. Socolow, director of the MacArthur Fellows program. 
 The New York City area recipients included a community organizer, a couple who are both architects, a reporter, a history professor, a computer scientist and several artists.
The grants, awarded this year to 17 men and 15 women, ranged from $235,000 to $375,000, depending on the age of the recipient. The youngest recipient was 28 and the oldest was 66. Since 1981, when the program started, 563 Fellows have been named.
Rather than genius awards, the foundation prefers to think of them as grants to experts who are particularly gifted in their fields. The recipients are selected anonymously -- there is no application -- and given the money over five years to pursue whatever interests they desire. Recipients do not have to produce anything for the foundation, and they get free health insurance.
The winners were these:
Jillian F. Banfield, 39, Madison, Wis., an associate professor of geology and geophysics at the University of Wisconsin, has contributed fundamental insights into the physical and chemical forces that shape the earth's surface, $290,000.
Carolyn R. Bertozzi, 32, Albany, Calif., an assistant professor of chemistry at the University of California at Berkeley, has made important contributions to understanding how cells interact, $255,000
Bruce G. Blair, 51, Washington, a foreign policy analyst at the Brookings Institution, is a leader seeking to reduce the risks of nuclear engagement in a rapidly changing geopolitical environment, $350,000.
John Bonifaz, 33, Boston, a public interest lawyer and executive director of the National Voting Rights Institute, uses innovative litigation to re-examine campaign finance reform arguments typically debated on First Amendment grounds, $260,000.
Shawn Carlson, 39, San Diego, a physicist, educator and the founder and director of the Society for Amateur Scientists, has worked to make the scientific process less mystifying and more comprehensible to non-scientists, $290,000.
Mark Danner, 40, New York and Berkeley, Calif., a staff writer at The New Yorker and former story editor at The New York Times Magazine, specializing in foreign affairs, offers a new perspective on the state of human rights and the role of the United States in the international community, $295,000.
Alison L. Des Forges, 57, Buffalo, a writer, researcher, and human rights advocate, has documented and brought to light the causes of genocide, $375,000
Elizabeth Diller, 45, and Ricardo Scofidio, 64, New York, have created an alternative form of architectural practice that unites design, performance and electronic media with cultural and architectural theory and criticism, $375,000.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Protectionism and American Steel

 BODY:
The Senate refused yesterday to go along with the House of Representatives in voting to impose import quotas to protect the steel industry. That is a welcome rebuff to protectionist impulses that remain strong even while the American economy is booming. 
 A procedural vote in the Senate showed that supporters of the quota bill, which was passed by the House overwhelmingly earlier this year, do not have enough support to push the bill through. Only 42 senators voted to cut off debate and force a vote, far fewer than the 60 needed.
The bill would have imposed quotas on steel imports, in direct violation of the country's obligations as a member of the World Trade Organization. It would be likely to damage the nation's economy both by provoking retaliation and by hurting the exports of American products that include steel.
The steel industry nonetheless has scored some major successes in its efforts to keep out inexpensive foreign steel that flooded into this country after the Asian economic crisis slashed demand for steel in other countries. Responding to the pressure, the Clinton Administration has aggressively sought to enforce anti-dumping laws, which allow high tariffs on items sold either below the cost of production or for less than the exporting country charges at home. This week, Commerce Secretary William Daley announced more dumping investigations. The result of these efforts, combined with incipient Asian recovery, has been a sharp fall in steel imports.
The threat of world recession has eased since last summer. But such countries as Argentina, Brazil and Indonesia, which are targeted in the latest round of dumping investigations, are in recession, and efforts to dampen their exports could weaken their economies even further. While the Commerce Department should enforce the law, it should take care not to act unfairly just to pacify a politically powerful domestic steel industry.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1140 words

HEADLINE: Senate Kills Effort to Impose Tight Limits on Steel Imports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The Senate killed a bill today that would have sharply restricted imports of foreign steel to the United States, a blow to unions and steelmakers and a victory for President Clinton, who had warned that the legislation would revive protectionism.
After some furious last-minute vote-switching, supporters of placing tight quotas on imported steel -- both Democrats and Republicans from steelmaking states, which have been hit by Asian imports -- attracted 42 of the 60 votes required to end debate and move toward a vote on the actual legislation. 
 The bill would have rolled back imports of steel to the levels before the Asian economic crisis. As countries have sought to export their way out of their economic trouble, they have been shipping low-priced steel to the United States.
After the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved the import quotas in March, the debate over steel quotas took on far greater dimensions. It became a divisive argument over the merits of free trade, and the economic wisdom of protecting steelworkers at the expense of raising prices on a range of everyday goods -- from American-made cars to housing, airplanes and farm equipment.
In the end, Mr. Clinton won the day by allying with key Republicans, including the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, who had earlier indicated that he might support the legislation but took to the floor of the Senate just before the vote today to warn his colleagues that "the consequences would be dire indeed" if the measure passed."
Mr. Lott, who a few days ago seemed to be enjoying the Administration's discomfort on the issue, sounded today surprisingly like a member of the White House economic team. He argued from the well of the Senate that the bill would "adversely affect our businesses and farmers who depend upon access to the international market."
"There's no question that this bill will undercut the economic growth that we enjoy today," he said.
The action also removed Vice President Al Gore from a political quandary. He had been caught between the Administration's free-trade instincts and the United Steelworkers of America, whose support he seeks in his Presidential bid.
On Monday night Mr. Gore, siding with the White House, called the legislation unnecessary, but he was reluctant to join in working actively for its defeat. That was left largely to members of the Cabinet, especially the outgoing Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, and Commerce Secretary William M. Daley. Mr. Daley contended that a series of actions he had taken to prevent the "dumping" of steel in the American market -- including placing retaliatory tariffs on Japan, South Korea and Brazil -- was already succeeding. On Monday Mr. Daley announced a new set of investigations into shipments of cold-rolled steel into the United States, a last-minute effort to convince Congress that the Administration was cracking down on countries that might be violating dumping laws.
The Senate's brief but heated debate today on the steel quotas showed the degree to which the economic prosperity of the 1990's has changed the nature of political discourse. While senators from many steel-producing states argued passionately about the need to protect the jobs of their constituents, they were outnumbered by those who concluded that an industry that employs 170,000 workers should not be protected by raising the price of steel for virtually every American consumer.
One estimate, put together by the Institute for International Economics, suggested that each job saved by the import quota would cost consumers $800,000, an assertion that the steel lobby never addressed.
Several senators from both parties warned that the bill, while it might protect steelworkers, risked repeating what is now considered one of Congress's greatest economic blunders of this century: the Smoot-Hawley Act of 1930, a set of tariffs that many economists now contend deepened the Great Depression. While economic conditions today are the exact opposite, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, warned that passage of the bill would result in "an immediate reaction" around the world, as countries imposed retaliatory restrictions on American products.
In the end, last-minute lobbying by agricultural interests, which would probably have been the first victims of any retaliation, turned the vote around. "They came on big time," said Senator Rick Santorum, the Pennsylvania Republican who served as the floor manager for the defeated bill. "And the White House lobbied hard. They saw this as a big political loser for Al Gore, and they wanted to protect him."
In fact, that appears to be exactly what happened in the last 90 seconds or so of voting, when senators are free to approach the clerks and quietly switch sides. Several Democrats, realizing that the import quotas were going down to defeat, changed their vote to support the White House, where the expectation on Monday night had been that the vote would be extremely close.
"Two weeks ago," one senior Administration official said, "we thought this bill might pass with a veto-proof majority."
The vote clearly left a residue of anger, though, within Democratic ranks. Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota said: "The White House is saying that the steel crisis is over, and so they pulled all the stops to defeat this bill. Well, last weekend I was on the Iron Range in northeastern Minnesota. I talked to some of the workers who just got laid off at Evtac Mining in Eveleth, Minn., and to some of the workers who are going to be laid off at the end of this month. For them, the steel crisis is not over. For their husbands and wives and children, the steel crisis is not over."
If overall unemployment were on the rise, such arguments would probably carry far more weight. But the remarkable economic expansion of the last few years apparently led a number of senators to buy the argument that the retaliation by other nations would be far more costly to other American workers.
"This bill will kill jobs," Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican, said. "Since we are the greatest beneficiary of international trade, we will lose more than anyone else."
President Clinton, in a statement released by the White House, acknowledged that "the surge in steel imports has created a significant hardship for many steelworkers and communities."
"But quota legislation was the wrong approach and would have weakened our economy and undermined our ability to tear down unfair trade barriers in foreign countries," the statement read.
In the next few weeks the Senate seems likely to take up an alternative to the quota bill that would strengthen American anti-dumping laws, giving the Commerce Department more weaponry to fight imports that are priced below manufacturing costs.
