HEADLINE: Salinger Letters Are Sold And May Return to Sender

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
The saga of the hermitic author, the confessional writer, the love letters and the auction block came full circle yesterday and ended, at least in theory, happily for everyone.
Fourteen letters written 27 years ago by J. D. Salinger to Joyce Maynard, a young writer and star-struck admirer, were sold at Sotheby's for $156,500 to the software entrepreneur and art collector Peter Norton. Mr. Norton then announced that he was going to return them to Mr. Salinger. 
 The sale would seem to wrap up a story that has fascinated the literary world with a Shakespearean denouement. Mr. Salinger, a world-famous recluse who has sued in the past to keep his words private, presumably will be content to have the letters back. Ms. Maynard, who said she needed to sell them to raise tuition for her children, now has enough for four years at an Eastern Ivy League college, before taxes.
And Mr. Norton, a philanthropist, is pleased to be of service.
"A lot of people I admire," he said in a telephone interview, "share the opinion that if the letters have to be sold they should fall into sympathetic hands."
"My intention is to do whatever he Mr. Salinger indicates to me he wants done with them," he continued. "He may want them returned. He may want me to destroy them. He may not care at all."
Mr. Norton, who sold his software business to Symantec in 1990 and collects contemporary art and runs his foundation from Santa Monica, Calif., said he does not know the 80-year-old author of "The Catcher in the Rye" and other works and has not been in touch with him. But he indicated that he respected Mr. Salinger's desire for privacy.
Since Mr. Salinger last published in 1965, he has vigorously guarded his seclusion, and he has not been heard from during what in gentler times would have been called a literary scandal. Ms. Maynard, who published a memoir last year that included an account of her nine-month romance with Mr. Salinger, has been roundly taken to task for her decision to sell the letters.
Some accused her of violating Mr. Salinger's privacy and trading on his name. The National Review termed her an "opportunistic onetime nymphet."
But Mr. Norton defended her decision to sell the letters. "This woman also had a right, really a duty to herself and her children to safeguard her economic security," he said.
Ms. Maynard, 45, is the divorced mother of three children.
Mr. Norton said the sale was fraught with "moral ambiguity."
"I thought, 'Gee, it's a shame this is happening,' " he said. "I had the means to be a contender."
He did not attend the auction but said he placed an "order bid" with Sotheby's beforehand, setting an upper limit to the amount he would pay. Presale estimates for the letters ran between $60,000 and $80,000. The final price includes a commission to Sotheby's, so Ms. Maynard will receive about $140,000.
The auction, which was held at Sotheby's New York headquarters on York Avenue at 72d Street, had an air of anticlimax, with the room only half filled. Marsha Malinowski, a vice president in the department of books and manuscripts and the expert in charge of the sale, said there were at least four bidders for the letters, including Mr. Norton. The opening bid was $50,000. Bruce Gimelson, a book dealer who was the underbidder, was present in the room, bidding on behalf of a private collector. Mr. Gimelson stopped bidding at $130,000.
Mr. Norton, 55, made his fortune as the inventor of a set of computer programs called the Norton Utilities. One of them, UnErase, can recover deleted computer files. In 1995, he was the underwriter for an exhibit at the Whitney Museum, "Black Male: Representation of Masculinity in Contemporary American Art."
The sale represented an ending of sorts to a story that began in 1972, when Ms. Maynard, then a student at Yale, wrote an article, "An 18-Year-Old Looks Back on Her Life," in The New York Times Magazine, published with a photograph of its doe-eyed author. Mr. Salinger, then 53, wrote the 18-year-old a fan letter, "in strictest privacy, if you can bear it," offering her fatherly advice and warning her not to let herself be exploited for her talent.
The letters continued with Mr. Salinger offering seductive praise for her writing abilities and saying they were soul mates. He told her how much he craved isolation from the world and expressed disillusionment with his relatives and the publishing industry.
Eventually, the tone became one of a lover. Ms. Maynard left Yale and moved into his home in Cornish, N.H. But the relationship was troubled. After less than a year, Mr. Salinger broke it up. On Aug. 17, 1973, he wrote Ms. Maynard one last, distant letter.
For 25 years, Ms. Maynard kept silent about their connection, until her memoir, "At Home in the World," (Picador USA). She said that one reason she wrote the book was to put the past to rest. She also said, in a statement written on the eve of the auction, that she was motivated to make public the couple's intimacy by her discovery that Mr. Salinger had carried on similar correspondences with other young women.
Ms. Maynard had originally planned to attend the auction, but at the last minute changed her mind when she realized that much of the attention would be focused on her. "This will sound naive," she said in a telephone interview the day before the auction, "but it didn't occur to me that anyone would watch me." She said she had hoped that people "would look at the letters themselves, instead of focusing the attention on my violation."
She said she felt little emotion about finally parting with Mr. Salinger's letters. "I don't shed a tear. The sale of the letters really was a business decision," she said. "I'm really finished with it. I feel a burden lifting for me."
Because of copyright restrictions, the letters were only on view at Sotheby's from July 17 to July 21 in a private room under guard. They could be seen only by people judged by Sotheby's to be prospective buyers.
Mr. Salinger had turned to legal action in the past to prevent letters or significant portions of them from being published. Under copyright law, letters are the property of the owner, but the content belongs to the writer. In 1987, Mr. Salinger successfully stopped the author Ian Hamilton from quoting from his copyrighted letters in a biography of him.
A man who answered the telephone at the office of Phyllis Westberg, Mr. Salinger's agent, said that neither she nor the author would have any comment about the sale.
Earlier, a letter written by John Adams three days before the signing of the Declaration of Independence sold for a record price of $635,000. In the letter, Adams warned that freedom from England would be won "at great expense of blood."

HEADLINE: 32 Receive Grants From MacArthur Foundation

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

 BODY:
The annual grants popularly known as the genius awards announced yesterday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation were heavily weighted toward the New York area, home to about a third of the 32 recipients.
"There is a clump there this year because we just couldn't pass them up," said Daniel J. Socolow, director of the MacArthur Fellows program. 
 The New York City area recipients included a community organizer, a couple who are both architects, a reporter, a history professor, a computer scientist and several artists.
The grants, awarded this year to 17 men and 15 women, ranged from $235,000 to $375,000, depending on the age of the recipient. The youngest recipient was 28 and the oldest was 66. Since 1981, when the program started, 563 Fellows have been named.
Rather than genius awards, the foundation prefers to think of them as grants to experts who are particularly gifted in their fields. The recipients are selected anonymously -- there is no application -- and given the money over five years to pursue whatever interests they desire. Recipients do not have to produce anything for the foundation, and they get free health insurance.
The winners were these:
 
 Jillian F. Banfield, 39, Madison, Wis., an associate professor of geology and geophysics at the University of Wisconsin, has contributed fundamental insights into the physical and chemical forces that shape the earth's surface, $290,000.
Carolyn R. Bertozzi, 32, Albany, Calif., an assistant professor of chemistry at the University of California at Berkeley, has made important contributions to understanding how cells interact, $255,000
Bruce G. Blair, 51, Washington, a foreign policy analyst at the Brookings Institution, is a leader seeking to reduce the risks of nuclear engagement in a rapidly changing geopolitical environment, $350,000.
John Bonifaz, 33, Boston, a public interest lawyer and executive director of the National Voting Rights Institute, uses innovative litigation to re-examine campaign finance reform arguments typically debated on First Amendment grounds, $260,000.
Shawn Carlson, 39, San Diego, a physicist, educator and the founder and director of the Society for Amateur Scientists, has worked to make the scientific process less mystifying and more comprehensible to non-scientists, $290,000.
Mark Danner, 40, New York and Berkeley, Calif., a staff writer at The New Yorker and former story editor at The New York Times Magazine, specializing in foreign affairs, offers a new perspective on the state of human rights and the role of the United States in the international community, $295,000.
Alison L. Des Forges, 57, Buffalo, a writer, researcher, and human rights advocate, has documented and brought to light the causes of genocide, $375,000
Elizabeth Diller, 45, and Ricardo Scofidio, 64, New York, have created an alternative form of architectural practice that unites design, performance and electronic media with cultural and architectural theory and criticism, $375,000.
Saul Friedlander, 66, Los Angeles, a professor of history at the University of California at Los Angeles and a scholar of the Third Reich and the Holocaust, has transformed our understanding of this period by weaving into a coherent whole the perspectives of the participants: ordinary Germans, party activists, military and political figures, victims and survivors, $375,000.
Jennifer L. Gordon, 33, Brooklyn, a lawyer and community organizer who founded the Workplace Project in 1992 as a worker's center to fight employment abuse and discrimination against immigrant workers, $260,000.

HEADLINE: Plotting Corporate Futures;
Biotechnology Examines What Could Go Wrong

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Whether he is writing books, lecturing at universities or lobbying regulators and politicians, Jeremy Rifkin never misses a chance to argue that the biotechnology industry is leading the world toward environmental and social disaster. If he thinks it will help slow the industry down, he is quick to file lawsuits and promote boycotts or moratoriums.
But last week, the activist who was once described by critics as the "abominable no-man" took on another role. Intrigued by an invitation to an industry meeting at one of biotechnology's inner sanctums, he happily trekked to the headquarters of the Monsanto Company here to offer up his vision of the future. "I've never been to a meeting like this in the 23 years I've been talking about these issues," he said. 
 It was not Monsanto's idea to seek his input, as the company was quick to tell anyone who asked. The 54-year-old Mr. Rifkin was called in by Ulrich Goluke, a consultant hired by Monsanto and 13 members of the World Business Council for Sustainable Development, to help them paint a portrait of the biotechnology landscape of the year 2030 and how it evolved.
The exercise, known as story building, or more formally as scenario creation, is a specialized form of crystal-ball gazing that big corporations in the United States and abroad are increasingly turning to as an early warning system for how their strategies could go astray.
"Every child knows you get the really big issues across with stories," Mr. Goluke said.
In contrast to more common corporate planning tools like forecasting, story building typically results in two to four contrasting visions of the future. Each turns on assumptions about public reactions to political surprises, industrial accidents or social disruptions that never show up in today's spreadsheets and five-year business plans. Outside participants like Mr. Rifkin, who was reimbursed for his expenses but received no compensation, are known as provocateurs by those designing the projects.
"Our aim is to think the unthinkable and speak the unspeakable, not to say what we think will or should happen," said Patricia Solaro, a public affairs executive from Hoechst A.G. of Germany who attended the four-day meeting. Scenario creation was originally developed for the Federal Government in the 1950's at the Rand Corporation to study how nuclear wars might start. It was popularized as a business tool by Shell Oil in the 1970's. Shell's planners, armed with descriptions of how consumers and countries might react to oil shortages, for example, were better equipped than many of their competitors to deal with the shock of the oil crisis of 1973 and its aftermath.
Biotechnology companies see plenty of reason to worry about unpredictable setbacks these days. While genetically engineered crops like soybeans and corn and a number of drugs have been commercial hits, critics are stepping up their efforts to portray the advances as fraught with threats to human health and the environment.
Just last month, they seized on a report suggesting that the monarch butterfly caterpillars and some beneficial insects might be much more vulnerable to a natural pesticide produced by genetically engineered corn than the industry had acknowledged.
And food scares in Europe over "mad cow's disease," dioxin and Coke, though unrelated to biotechnology, have fanned consumer worries about food purity and given a boost to the organic-food movement.
The result has been a crisis of confidence in the industry. The companies still believe in the promise of the technology but now wonder whether they will be able to convince regulators and the public that the benefits outweigh the risks.
The meeting here was a follow-up to a session in April at Hoechst's headquarters in Frankfurt. Participants included not just biotechnology giants like Monsanto, DuPont and Novartis, but also newcomers like International Paper and Norsk Hydro, as well as Zurich Financial Group and Swiss Re from the insurance sector and the consumer products heavyweights Procter & Gamble and Unilever.
The scenarios being developed will not be finished before the end of this summer. The job of polishing them into compelling narratives of about two pages has been handed to Betty S. Flowers, a University of Texas poetry and literature professor.
Mrs. Flowers, who studied with the late Joseph Campbell, the noted authority on myths and stories, is highly sought after in scenario circles for her ability to shape the jargon of engineers and executives into crisp, easy-to-recall narratives that highlight turning points in each vision.
The companies meeting here turned down a reporter's request to sit in on the discussions, but Mr. Goluke, Mrs. Flowers and several other participants shared some of their impressions afterward. Three basic stories are being developed, they said.
In the first, none of the critics' warnings about health and environmental hazards prove warranted and biotechnology products gain widespread acceptance. It is not a happily-ever-after story for the companies, though, because success brings wide-ranging consequences and challenges.
This scenario may include examples of the social and political impact of large numbers of people living past the age of 100, such as pressures to divert public spending and product development to the needs of the elderly. Some biotechnology products in the story might become unprofitable because they become so widespread that they turn into low-margin commodities.
A second scenario is likely to reflect chaos theory, which holds that complex systems can be changed radically by tiny disruptions that have dramatic ripple effects. This story might turn on an event such as publication of a small research report attributing an environmental setback to genetically engineered crops. This in turn could kick off a string of public reactions leading to drastic regulations that stifle many biotechnology applications. A Presidential candidate who is courting environmentalists could be cast as the leader of the anti-biotech charge.
One plot twist to this story proposed in last week's conference was to make the perceived threat to the environment the result of faulty research. The lesson for the industry: the same science that serves you so well can trip you up in the hands of critics.
In the third story, which might be summarized as "thanks but no thanks," consumers and financial markets decide that most biotechnology applications simply are not as appealing as the alternatives. Insurers balk at liability risks and investors flee the industry's meager returns. Agricultural biotechnology markets shrink as farmers and consumers embrace organic food. Biotechnology becomes a tool to improve breeding techniques rather than to move genes among different species.
At the same time, health care companies conclude there is limited profit in engineering new drugs and in harvesting organs for transplants in humans from genetically engineered animals. Instead, they use their expertise to analyze people's vulnerability to certain diseases and then reap profits from advising people how to avoid getting sick.
The practical value of creating such stories is hard to prove. Skeptics say it is so speculative as to be almost meaningless. Some say scenarios are most useful if they focus on near-in challenges, such as what happens if a big contract goes to a competitor.
"It's rare that they become a core part of the internal decision-making process, which tends to end up looking at things like return on investment," said Kevin Coyne, a consultant at McKinsey & Company.
But proponents argue that unlike forecasts well-designed stories of the future can alert business and political leaders to warning signs they might otherwise miss.
"If you are working on things that take 10 to 15 years to develop, you want to think about what the public policy environment will be when those investments are supposed to pay off," said Thomas Jorling, a senior policy executive at the International Paper Company who attended the Monsanto talks.
The World Business Council, the Geneva-based coalition of 125 multinationals that organized the Monsanto conference, is a major forum for corporate story-building. It currently has other scenario groups looking at energy and electronics. The General Motors Corporation is leading 25 companies in a council project focused on sustainable growth in the United States.
Other consulting firms are marketing similar projects. Global Business Network, a scenario specialist based in Emeryville, Calif., and the accounting firm of Ernst & Young are currently recruiting participants for a biotechnology scenario project looking out just 10 years. Monsanto, Eli Lilly & Company and Cargill Inc. are among the early sponsors, according to Peter Schwartz, the chairman of Global Business.
Northeast Consulting in Boston specializes in scenario work for information-technology companies. Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., is known for energy and political scenarios, like its look at Russia in 2010. The Institute for the Future, based in Menlo Park, Calif., pioneered such work for nonprofits.
Mr. Rifkin said he found the process fascinating but was unsure what to make of it.
"I have to say I was really impressed by the ability of the people here to put aside their assumptions," he said. But he did not expect it to signal the end of his battles with the industry or bury their mutual scorn.
As he headed off to Washington, where he is president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, Mr. Rifkin predicted that the "thanks but no thanks" story of biotechnology's decline was closest to the mark and that most of the biotechnology giants in the group that met here would fail to adapt in time to avoid being pushed aside by nimble upstarts.

Lately, corportions have borrowed an apporach used by the Federal Government during the cold war to try to make sense of the future.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Solutions can becomeproblems for mental illness insurance.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
THE White House conference earlier this month on mental illness highlighted the Administration's campaign, led by Tipper Gore, to achieve "parity for all" -- requiring health insurers to provide the same coverage for mental illness that they provide for physical illness. Bills in Congress would do the same.
The call for parity raises two questions. Is coverage of mental health the same as that of physical health? And who should decide? 
 Almost all employer-based policies impose higher co-payments and other stricter limits on coverage of mental illness. Critics often blame bias -- an irrational stigma attached to mental problems -- or ignorance, misjudging the plight of the "worried well" or glibly dismissing the value of "taking cures."
Bias and ignorance are only a small part of the story. A new study by Richard G. Frank of Harvard University and Thomas G. McGuire of Boston University shows that powerful economic forces compel plans to discriminate between physical and mental health. Congress may still want to proceed. But markets will counteract parity in ways that advocates will almost surely not like.
About 30 percent of Americans experience some diagnosable mental disorder in a typical year. Only about 25 percent of them receive treatment. About 4 percent of the population suffers in any year from the most severe problems: schizophrenia, manic depression and major depression. But only between 30 and 55 percent of them receive treatment. Given the yawning need, why don't employers offer parity?
The Frank-McGuire study offers two economic reasons. First, adverse selection. A plan that offers generous coverage of mental health would attracts people with expensive mental health problems. In health care, a few patients always account for a large fraction of expenditures. The disparity is exaggerated for mental health, where 5 percent of such patients may account for 30 percent or more of costs. So a plan whose lavish benefits attract the sickest mentally ill people invites bankruptcy.
One way to diminish adverse selection is for government to impose parity. That way, plans could not easily tailor their benefits to push the chronically mentally ill onto other insurers. But health plans that offer equal physical and mental benefits would butt up against a second insurance problem, moral hazard: changes in behavior that are caused by the presence of insurance.
People with health insurance buy more medical treatments than do the uninsured. But studies of patients in fee-for-service plans show that the impact of insurance on demand for treatment was twice as large for treatment of mental problems as for physical problems, Mr. McGuire said in a recent interview. Part of the reason can be traced to the fact that nonsevere forms of mental illness are hard to diagnose and leave therapists wide discretion over course of treatment. He concludes that some of the insurance-induced demand is for mental health services that patients did not deem very valuable when asked to pay themselves.
Here's a sobering estimate: about 12 percent of the population with no diagnosable mental disorders receive treatment and account for nearly a third of all visits for mental health. If parity drives up mental health costs and premiums, the danger is that more employers will drop coverage and more workers will turn it down because it will have become too expensive.
The Frank-McGuire study, then, decisively concludes that coverage of mental health is different from that of physical health. So should insurance coverage treat the two types of patients differently? Mr. Frank and Mr. McGuire used to think so, at least for patients with nonsevere mental problems.
But they have changed their minds, for a reason advocates will find upsetting. The difference between then and now, they say, is the explosive rise of managed care. Under managed care, contractual niceties, like co-payments, deductibles and lifetime limits lose their importance because every expenditure, regardless of contractual obligations, is subject to second-guessing. So managed care has all the tools it needs to control costs even if Congress requires parity.
"Parity," Mr. Frank said, "is affordable only because managed care exists." But making parity work by driving patients into the scrupulous oversight of managed care is probably not what many of its advocates have in mind.
There are grounds for government to dictate the list of benefits that every private plan offers as one way to dull their ability to tailor benefits to drive away the chronically ill. But the prospect of legislators selling priority of place to medical specialities bearing campaign gifts is hardly inspiring. Perhaps a better idea would to turn the task over to a blue ribbon panel that would hand its recommendations over to legislatures for an up and down vote without amendment. That would put politicians in charge, but mute the craven features of the current system.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
LateTrading Moderates Early Losses in a Mixed Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday after late buying lifted the main gauges from their daily lows while long-term interest rates continued to climb.
With Federal Reserve policy makers expected to decide next Wednesday to raise the rate on overnight loans between banks by a quarter- point, investors and traders debated the growing possibility that one such increase might not be enough to head off inflation. 
 "It's a weight on equities," said John Manley, a strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, referring to competition from bonds for investors' cash. "We actually think there may be three increases before it's all over."
Financial stocks bore much of the brunt of the uncertainty over rates in a week with little other economic news and with companies not scheduled to report second-quarter profits until next month.
J. P. Morgan, down 4 3/8, to 130 5/8, and American Express, down 2 1/8, to 122 5/8, were the two biggest factors in the 54.77-point loss in the Dow Jones industrial average, which finished at 10,666.86, down five-tenths of a percent. At midday, the Dow's slump was nearly 105 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.82, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,333.06.
On the other hand, the Nasdaq composite index pushed into positive ground, with a gain of 17.86, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 2,598.12.
This reflected strength in high-technology issues, which have regained favor despite the run-up in interest rates. Cisco Systems climbed 2 3/8, to 61 7/8. Altera rose 4 5/8, to 40 5/16 after an analyst raised the semiconductor company's target price. Beyond.com jumped 7 1/4, to 32 7/8, on speculation that it would be bought by Amazon.com.
3Com warned of lower revenue in coming quarters and slumped 4 3/8, to 27 1/8, apparently benefiting the shares of Cisco, its larger rival.
With little else beside the uncertainty over the Fed's action and corporate profit warnings to focus on, analysts said it was not surprising that the markets tended to be defensive.
"The chances of an upside surprise are low relative to the chances of a bigger correction," said Al Kugel, senior investment strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham in Chicago.
Another company warning of a weaker performance was Crown Cork and Seal, which cited sluggish European economies in lowering expectations for the second time in nine months. The stock skidded 3 1/2, to 28 15/16. Goldman Sachs reported earnings that far surpassed expectations, but the stock fell 3, to 65, in a mixed brokerage group.
Oil stocks advanced with crude prices after inventories fell unexpectedly. Chevron, recommended by Banc of America Securities, climbed 2 1/2, to 92 5/8, while Mobil and Exxon gained 1 1/2 and 1 1/8, respectively. Drug issues were mostly lower.
Vulcan Materials, one of three stocks to be added to the S.& P. 500, jumped 4 1/4, to 46 15/16. Network Appliance rose 3 1/2, to 48 5/16, and Best Buy was up 2 9/16, to 63 5/16.
On the New York Stock Exchange volume grew to a still-moderate 731.8 million shares, with declining issues surpassing advancing ones 1,760 to 1,259. New lows outnumbered new 52-week highs by 67 to 50.

Treasury Prices Fall
 By Reuters
 Interpreting Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is usually a daunting task, and the bond market is re-evaluating its initial reading of Mr. Greenspan's Congressional testimony last week, when his message seemed crystal clear: a "modest" interest rate increase was in store.
The market's initial euphoria over Mr. Greenspan's testimony has turned to despair. In a matter of days, expectations of a small rise in rates have been replaced by forecasts of aggressive Fed tightening.
Consequently, the Treasuries market has fallen back. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 1 2/32 yesterday, to 87 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.14 percent, from 6.06 percent on Tuesday.
Corporate issuers have been plentiful, though the Ford Motor Credit Corporation's planned offering was postponed until July because of market conditions.

HEADLINE: Pataki Avoids Budget Issue In a Speech About Policies

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki went to Detroit yesterday to promote his economic policies as a model for the nation, detailing his record of cutting taxes and reducing the size of government but skirting mention of the standoff back home over the state budget, now nearly three months overdue.
Speaking before the Detroit Economic Club, Mr. Pataki called for reducing Federal income taxes an average of 13 percent over seven years, eliminating the capital gains tax and changing Social Security to allow people to invest some of the money they now contribute. He proposed a Constitutional amendment that would require a two-thirds vote in Congress to raise taxes. 
 He said he favored increasing Federal spending on defense and education, while scaling back the bureaucracy by abolishing the Departments of Commerce and Energy, repealing burdensome regulations and selling some government assets.
He said his proposals would save hundreds of billions of dollars. "But in a broader sense, this plan isn't about numbers," he said. "It's about freedom. It's about people. It's about restoring certain inalienable rights."
The speech before the club, a traditional stop for politicians eager to proclaim the success of their stewardship, marked the latest effort by Mr. Pataki to seize the national spotlight. It comes, though, at an awkward time for him. After flirting for several months with a long-shot bid for the Presidency, Mr. Pataki took himself out of the running last month when he endorsed Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for the Republican nomination.
So at best, the speech was an attempt to help his standing as a potential vice presidential nominee.
Asked about those aspirations before the speech yesterday, Mr. Pataki said, "I don't think that you think about the Vice Presidency or cabinet positions. You have to first get the nomination and win the election. That's where we are going to be focused, doing that for Governor Bush."
In Albany, the state government remains paralyzed by the dispute over the state budget. Perhaps unsurprisingly, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, made a pointed reference yesterday to the Governor's trip.
"Wherever he chooses to be, that's his priority and I think the people of the state will eventually respond to each and every one of our priorities," Mr. Silver said.
Aides to Mr. Silver, Mr. Pataki and the leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, continued budget negotiations yesterday, but without substantial progress.
While the sides are relatively close to a compromise, the deadlock remains over Mr. Silver's insistence that Mr. Pataki agree not to veto spending items proposed by Assembly Democrats. The Governor has refused to provide such a promise.

HEADLINE: Seeking Little League Skills at $70 an Hour

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 23

 BODY:
Hoisting a bat that looked huge on a 10-year-old, Benjamin Gold stood nervously at the plate under his floppy orange Orioles cap.
His parents watched from lawn chairs behind the backstop. His tutor studied the play from behind the first-base line, pointing a video camera at Benji for a post-game critique. 
 "He's moving around too much in the box -- and dropping his hands," the tutor, Mark Venditti, had noticed during Benji's first at-bat. Between innings, he had talked to the boy about making an adjustment.
Benji took a mighty swing and tapped the ball toward the pitcher's mound, then scampered toward first base. It was good enough for an infield hit. And the runner on third base made it home, so Benji was credited with a crucial run batted in, an R.B.I.
But his success has come at a price.
In another sign that American childhood has become a serious venture, parents like Loren and Debbie Gold are paying $70 an hour, sometimes more, to private coaches to sharpen the skills of their Little League ballplayers.
For the Golds, who harbor no illusions about athletic scholarships or big money in the professional leagues, hiring a tutor seemed a logical way to help a child whose heart was broken into pieces with every strikeout.
"We did it for his self-esteem," said Mrs. Gold, a 43-year-old employee recruiter. "He was getting to the point where he just wanted to quit."
Benji agreed, saying: "It was hard last year. When you strike out, you know, and people say you should be off the team."
Parents find themselves in a spot these days. The increasingly competitive nature of childhood makes parents feel practically obligated to give their children every possible edge in academics and athletics.
And yet, the rigors of self-improvement for children -- preschoolers now go to foreign language camps -- can take an exacting toll.
"The message used to be, 'Be the best you can be," said Cynthia Kowa-Basler, a middle-school counselor in Dixon, Ill. "Now the message is simply, 'Be the best.' "
Ms. Kowa-Basler said one eighth-grade student sat and wept in the counselor's office because he did not believe he could live up to his parents' expectations. The counselor scheduled a meeting with the parents to deliver her professional advice in the bluntest of terms: "Back off."
The Golds, who have two children, share the ambivalence of many other parents. On one hand, they want to encourage Benji and their daughter, Samantha, to take piano lessons, play sports and participate in social activities. But they fear an overload.
Samantha, who is 11, has talked about feeling "stressed out" by all of her activities.
Her mother said, "When an 11-year-old starts talking about being too stressed, it makes you stop and wonder."
Bernard Beck, a sociologist at Northwestern University, said child rearing had taken a more management-style approach, especially among parents who were well-educated and successful. In some ways, Mr. Beck said, children have come to be seen a bit like growth stocks.
"In an earlier generation, parents were younger, going at life without much of a plan, a little courageous and a little foolhardy, a kind of what-the-heck attitude," Mr. Beck said. "But many of today's parents are more serious. They put off having children for a career. And having had success in their careers, they use the same goal-oriented principles when it comes to raising their kids. They study what's needed for success. They look at the competition. It's all a very rational, very market-oriented approach."
In his novel "Wobegon Boy," Garrison Keillor suggested that parents of an earlier time seemed to have better things to do than obsess about their children.
"They did not read books about parenting, and when they gathered with other adults, at Lutheran church suppers or family get-togethers, they didn't talk about schools or about the prevailing theories of child development," he wrote. "They did not weave their lives around yours. They had their own lives, which were mysterious to you."
In part, parents have become more intimately involved in the activities of their children because they now must act as chauffeurs, carting their children from piano lesson to tennis court to soccer match, driving minivans to the league games that have replaced the unchaperoned pickup games of the old neighborhoods.
Today's crop of parents can scarcely take sole blame for the image of the overzealous Little League parent. Accounts of bothersome parents ranting from the bleachers go back to the days before the 60-year-old Little League.
But today's frenetic competition among children, and among the parents of children, has turned up the pressure to win. It is perhaps not surprising then, in a service economy where almost anything can be taught and anyone trained, that Junior's batting flaws are something to be repaired by a service that advertises in the Yellow Pages.
When a child goes into a slump, plenty of parents pick up the telephone and call Grand Slam USA, one of the many places around the country that now provides baseball instructors to boys and girls.
"On Monday morning, we get the frantic calls from parents," said Leland Fisher, an owner of Grand Slam, in suburban Palatine. "They'll say, 'It's an emergency -- the boy struck out twice on Saturday -- we need help right away.' "
While the average young ballplayer still relies on pals or a parent, private tutoring has become a familiar part of the social landscape around the country, said Lance Van Auken, a spokesman for Little League Baseball Inc., in Williamsport, Pa.
"There's not any doubt that there's a lot more private instruction out there," said Mr. Van Auken, who noted that a big portion of the students were girls, trying to win college scholarships in softball. "There are no hard numbers, because it's privately done by parents. But you hear a lot of anecdotes."
The demand for instruction has also popularized baseball camp. A handful of such camps a generation ago has grown to a big business, Mr. Van Auken said, with dozens and dozens of camps around the country, especially in the South.
When Michael Hlavacek, 14, practices batting, he takes tips from an instructor who works as a professional scout. The help has paid off. The boy, who just graduated from the eighth grade in the Chicago suburbs, has red-hot batting average of over .500.
His sister, Allison, who is entering her senior year of high school, takes lessons for fast-pitch softball. She has also been an outstanding ballplayer, and hopes to play on a college team.
To their father, Jerry Hlavacek, who pays more than $100 a week for the lessons, the private instruction has helped their talents soar.
"If you want to play the sport at a higher level, this is the only way you're going to get there," said Mr. Hlavacek, a business executive. "How do you think Ken Griffey learned to hit? Somebody taught him, that's how."
Many parents and children say it works better to have a professional as coach, rather than a parent.
"The confrontation that normally happens between a father and son -- it doesn't happen," Mr. Hlavacek said.
His son, Michael, agreed.
"You don't really listen to your dad," he said. "He sometimes yells. And sometimes, he doesn't know what he's talking about."
Hiring a coach also helped domestic relations in the McEnerney home in Mount Prospect, northwest of Chicago.
"My husband didn't want to get into any more arguments with my son," said Maureen McEnerney, whose 14-year-old son, Matthew, and 17-year-old daughter, Christie, take private lessons. "My kids now love the game even more. Plus they get along better with their dad."
Mrs. McEnerney, a hairdresser, and her husband, William, an electrician, get the impression that other people think hiring sports tutors seems excessive.
"But you know, it's like playing a musical instrument," Mrs. McEnerney said. "It's a mechanical thing. It's a matter of studying and learning."
 The day after his latest ball game, Benji went to the ball park to train under the eye of Mr. Venditti, a 26-year-old software salesman who played two seasons with the Zanesville (Ohio) Greys in the independent Frontier League. Mr. Venditti tutors four players on Benji's Orioles team. In all, he works with about 20 players, from age 8 through high school.
"Atta boy, Benji," Mr. Venditti called out, as Benji swatted a line drive. "You're doing great."
Mrs. Gold and her husband, Loren, watched the practice from their lawn chairs, praising their son afterward. "Nice lesson, Benji," they said.
Mr. Gold, a 45-year-old electrical engineer, said he worked long hours and could not spare much time to play with Benji himself.
But even if he had time, Mr. Gold would not be much help. "I was no ballplayer," he said smiling.
Not all fathers bow out like Loren Gold. Around the batting cages of the league are fathers who strut like Babe Ruth, sounding as if they know everything about the game.
Mr. Fisher, the owner of Grand Slam in Palatine, says he cringes at what he sees.
"The kid will be crying, 'I don't want to play, I don't want to play,' and the father is pulling him along," Mr. Fisher said. "Sometimes, the biggest thing the instructor does is simply build up the kid's confidence. After all the criticism from the parent, they need to be told they're all right."
In some cases, Mr. Fisher said, the instructors will turn the tables and give an overbearing father a taste of his own medicine. The instructor will ask the father to step into the cage and try his luck with a bat.
"Then he's liable to see that it's not so easy, after all," Mr. Fisher said.
Or he must face the fact, he added, that the child's lack of skill was just an inherited trait.

HEADLINE: Rift Threatens Tax Program Aiding Co-ops

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
A dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Sheldon Silver, the State Assembly Speaker, is jeopardizing a property tax break for owners of co-ops and condominiums, whose tax bills will increase by an average of $580 this year if the matter is not resolved soon.
The tax break, which needs approval from both houses of the State Legislature, was part of the $35.3 billion budget that the City Council adopted earlier this month. But the Mayor, a Republican, took a calculated risk when he sent the property tax bill to Albany for legislative approval: he combined it with another bill that Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, strongly opposes. 
 The second bill would make it harder to challenge property assessments in New York City. Mr. Giuliani says that the city stands to lose more than $1 billion a year in property tax revenue under a recent change in state law, which gave owners of commercial and large residential buildings a new method of fighting assessments.
But Mr. Silver insists that the Mayor's proposal would make it too difficult for property owners to challenge assessments, which are important because they determine property tax bills. So while the State Senate, whose Republican leaders are close to Mr. Giuliani, passed the combined bills without delay, the Assembly has approved only the tax break.
For the tax break to take effect, the Senate would have to take it up again and vote on it as a separate bill. But Mr. Giuliani has quietly instructed them not to, according to people familiar with the legislation, apparently hoping the public outcry over the delay will force Mr. Silver -- who is already under attack for helping push through the repeal of the city's commuter tax last month -- to give in and pass the assessment bill.
Meanwhile, the owners of about 280,000 condominium and co-op apartments are getting property tax bills this month that do not reflect the tax break, which is actually a continuation of a three-year property tax relief program that expired in June.
Without the abatement, the new bills are up to 25 percent higher than last year, aides to Mr. Giuliani said.
The aides say that if the tax break is not approved in the next few weeks, the city will probably not be able to reflect it in the bills that go out in the fall, either.
"The longer it takes to get the application process rolling, the more it keeps pushing back our ability to execute the program," said Adam L. Barsky, the director of the Mayor's Office of Operations. He added that the city would most likely reflect the abatement in next year's bill, retroactively, if the legislation eventually passes.
But since neither Mr. Giuliani nor Mr. Silver appears willing to compromise, the tax break could be held up indefinitely.
John McArdle, a spokesman for the State Senate, said yesterday that the Senate would not go back and pass the tax break as a separate bill unless Mr. Giuliani and the City Council asked them to.
Aides to Mr. Giuliani, however, said they had no intention of doing so.
For his part, Mr. Silver told reporters in Albany yesterday that he did not want to pass Mr. Giuliani's bill because he was opposed to the provision affecting challenges to assessments. The provision would strip property owners of an important means of fighting unfair assessments, he said.
"We are not interested at this point in two totally separate issues coming together in one bill," Mr. Silver said.
The Legislature approved the tax relief program in 1996 to narrow the gap between the relatively low property taxes on one-, two- and three-family homes, and the generally higher taxes levied on co-ops and condominiums. A recent study by the city's Independent Budget Office found that the abatements produce the biggest savings in Manhattan, where they range from about $340 a year in the East Village to $1,200 in TriBeCa.
The logjam comes only a month after the Legislature infuriated Mr. Giuliani by repealing the commuter tax for New York State residents, which will cost the city at least $210 million a year. The unexpected loss of revenue led Mr. Giuliani and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, to abandon a number of tax cuts they had proposed for city residents.
"The Assembly showed no inertia in passing a commuter tax repeal for people who live outside New York City," Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said yesterday. "We are baffled by their refusal to pass a bill that will help all property owners who live in the city."
Mr. Lhota said that if the Legislature does not tighten the rules for challenging property tax assessments, the city will have to overhaul its entire system of assessing buildings. The recent change in state law allows owners of large residential or commercial buildings to use the sales prices of comparable properties to challenge their assessment. But the city does not use comparable sales as a factor in assessing those buildings.
If the city started assessing buildings based on comparable sales, the assessments would fluctuate with the city's volatile real estate market, Mr. Lhota said. In a strong economy, assessments -- and property taxes -- could increase sharply, he said.
But Assemblyman Martin A. Luster, a Democrat from Ithaca who heads the committee in charge of property tax policy, said tightening the rules by which people can challenge assessments would not be fair. If Mr. Giuliani really wanted the tax break for co-op and condominium owners, he would not have attached it to the more controversial assessment provision, Mr. Luster said.
All of the finger-pointing has led owners of co-ops and condominiums to throw up their hands in disgust as they prepare to pay their steepest property tax bills in at least three years. Without the tax break, most condominium owners would pay more in monthly mortgage payments, which usually cover property taxes, said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives. Most owners of co-ops would also end up paying more in monthly maintenance fees, she said.
"We're confident that our lawmakers all believe this is important legislation," Ms. Rothman said. "But they need to agree on this to make it real. We are the victims of their inability to get along."

HEADLINE: After Kosovo, Clinton Faces Domestic Issues

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
With the conflict in Kosovo more or less behind him and impeachment a fading memory, President Clinton is eager to reassert himself in the familiar realms of domestic policy and politics.
White House aides described the President, who returned from a weeklong trip to Europe early this morning, as eager to shed the unaccustomed mantle of wartime commander and to devote his full energies over the next several weeks to what he truly loves: verbally punishing Republicans over domestic policy matters like gun control and health care. 
 After more than a year of war and scandal, Mr. Clinton has had little space lately in which to exercise his powers of public persuasion on domestic issues.
But starting on Friday with an address to a group of Presidential scholars, Mr. Clinton hopes to focus public attention on a long list of pent-up proposals from an increase in the minimum wage to tax credits for poor neighborhoods. As his tenure in office winds down, the President is returning to more traditional Democratic themes that he had until now largely muted in an effort to fashion a third way between the orthodoxies of the dominant parties.
"For the first time in a long time, the decks are clear for resetting the agenda and defining the universe of the possible," said Joel P. Johnson, the newly appointed senior adviser to the President for policy and communications.
Over the next three weeks, Mr. Clinton plans to unveil a Medicare proposal with a popular new prescription drug benefit and to travel the country recycling a number of tax-cut proposals and spending initiatives from his State of the Union Message in January. Presidential aides expressed hope that the Republican-run Congress will enact some of Mr. Clinton's proposals, but they seem perfectly content to use legislative gridlock as a weapon of partisan advantage.
Some of the proposals the President plans to reintroduce, like a big school-construction tax credit, have already been rejected by Congress and there appears little prospect for passage now. But the White House hopes to salvage a compromise gun-control measure from two very different bills passed this month by the House and Senate.
Republicans plan to propose their own Medicare plan with less generous benefits than the President's and also hope to enact a broader set of tax cuts than the President supports.
As Mr. Clinton pushes his own agenda, he will also be trying to advance the political ambitions of his wife and his Vice President, as well as raising millions of dollars to help Democrats regain control of Congress.
The most significant initiatives that the President will push in coming weeks are a plan to try to insure the long-term solvency of Medicare and a series of proposals to bring private sector investment to the nation's poorest regions.
Sandwiched between promotion of those policies will be several fund-raising forays, visits with leaders from South Korea, Egypt and Israel, announcement of the removal of the bald eagle from the list of threatened species and an undetermined number of photo opportunities to attack Republicans for quashing a gun-control bill in the House and for bottling up new regulations governing health maintenance organizations in the Senate. The White House sees those as hanging curve balls that Mr. Clinton intends to swat out of the political park -- repeatedly.
In his State of the Union address , Mr. Clinton proposed setting aside 15 percent of anticipated Federal budget surpluses over the next decade to shore up Medicare, the Government health plan for the elderly and disabled.
But the Administration has delayed release of its plan as it struggles to reconcile competing political and financial interests behind one of the most popular programs of guaranteed benefits to all who qualify.
Mr. Clinton is set to release his plan next Tuesday, meeting his self-imposed deadline of the end of June by one day. Aides were stingy with details, saying the President had not yet approved the final provisions of the plan.
"We want to have a universal, affordable benefit that will ask Medicare beneficiaries to pay a modest premium for benefits that are substantially better," John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview.
The "modest premium" is a monthly cost that Medicare beneficiaries will be asked to pay for prescription drug coverage, expected to fall somewhere between $20 and $90 a month, with a partial subsidy for the poorest recipients. But Mr. Podesta would not be more specific about the cost of the program or the mechanism for helping the poor afford the new benefit.
The drug benefit seems popular with the elderly and abhorred by the pharmaceutical industry, which sees it as a wedge for Government price controls. It is certain to set off a ferocious fight on Capitol Hill that will almost certainly continue well into the 2000 campaigns for Congress and the White House.
Mr. Clinton, eyeing his legacy, will spend four days in early July touring depressed regions of the country, traveling from eastern Kentucky to the Mississippi Delta to a South Dakota Indian reservation to the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles. The trip comes late in his second term because Mr. Clinton has not been willing before now to draw attention to the pockets of poverty that belie the nation's general prosperity.
The aim of the President's anti-poverty plan is to inspire private businesses to increase investment in what the President likes to call "untapped markets" within the nation's borders. He has proposed a set of tax initiatives to help companies open businesses in depressed areas and bring the fruits of the economic expansion to the regions it passed by.
A subtext of those visits is the nation's continuing racial friction and the uneven economic performance of minorities in America.
"This is a real reflection of how the President looks at the world," Mr. Podesta said. "He wants to use the mechanism of Government to encourage partnership with the private sector to spread the benefits of the great economy we have."
Mr. Podesta said these programs, modeled on Federal programs to spur private investment in less-developed nations overseas, attract bipartisan support and have a chance to win passage in this Congress.
Mr. Podesta also said that the President intended in coming weeks to press ahead with some promises from the State of the Union and other policy-setting speeches. Among them are a planned lawsuit against tobacco companies to recover billions of dollars in Federal health care costs related to smoking, proposed tax credits for child care and medical costs arising from long-term illnesses and a $5 billion program to finance school construction.

KOREAN LOANS SOLD

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
A Texas-based investment partnership, Lone Star Fund L.P., bought 1.04 trillion won ($896 million) of South Korean bad loans, in the country's biggest single sale of bad debt to date. Lone Star paid an average 50.6 percent of the loans' face value, a better price than expected. The sale, by the Korea Asset Management Corporation, indicates foreign investors are betting South Korea is recovering from its worst recession since the 1950's. Kamco raised $455 million from the sale, which consisted of 8,100 nonperforming loans from 3,100 borrowers.

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD: PERSONAL VISIONS;
In a Glass Box, Secrets Are Hard to Keep

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
HOW could a structure as transparent as the Farnsworth House hold a secret?
Yet there it was, on the caption of an old blueprint that had sat untouched in my father's library in Chicago over the decades since his death -- "Bld'g: Dr. E. B. Farnsworth Residence / Location: Plano, Illinois / Architect: Wm. Dunlap." 
 William E. Dunlap? Architect of the iconic Farnsworth House?
What about Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, that towering figure from the Bauhaus whose disciples remade Chicago at mid-century? Wasn't it Mies who designed this sublime archetype of the International Style, this crystalline wafer of space framed by two horizontal planes, stripped of ornament, serenely afloat, its every line apparently dictated by pure reason?
Yes. But he did not account for the mosquitoes. They were left for my father.
Dr. Edith B. Farnsworth, an internist, commissioned Mies to design a weekend retreat 60 miles southwest of Chicago, on the Fox River. As the house neared completion in 1951, they had a bitter falling out.
The secret I had never known -- and this, after 20 years of covering architectural landmarks -- was that as a result of that fight, my father put the final touch on one of the most famous buildings of the 20th century. This was not a story he told me, perhaps because it involved a deception on his part. Rather, I learned of it by finding blueprints of his design for a nine-and-a-half-foot-high, bronze-and-steel screening system, with elegantly pivoting doors, that once enclosed the deck of the house.
Knowing of my father's role, I see the house differently now. In fact, I can almost hear the house, or rather the effervescent voices of my parents visiting the place as a young couple. Around them, I imagine America hitting its stride as the darkness of war and Depression subside: buildings sparkle with a newfound openness and clarity; Mies, who has made Chicago his home, is the leading architect of this transformation, and my parents are luckily, happily, in his orbit.
Despite the austerity of the Farnsworth House, I can now see its "aura of high romance," to borrow the words of Lord Palumbo, a London real estate developer, who bought the house in 1972 and opened it to the public two years ago.
I see something else: No amount of architectural refinement can disguise the building's quirks, its frailties, its very human provenance -- "my Mies-conception," Dr. Farnsworth called it in her unpublished memoirs -- all of which go into making it that much more resonant.
Begin with the fact that its floor slab hovers five feet above ground, held in the air by eight wide-flange steel piers, as if on stilts. The practical point of this extravagant esthetic gesture was to protect the house from flooding.
But though Mies researched previous flood levels, he miscalculated badly. The house has been inundated several times; catastrophically in 1996, when the river reached a height of 4 feet 10 inches inside the house, shattering window walls, scattering artwork and badly damaging the central core, within which are concealed two bathrooms and the mechanical systems.
Another Fox River phenomenon that Mies underestimated was the mosquitoes. Even today, they are fierce enough to be a source of constant complaint in the guest register.
In Mies's design, the only way to circulate air through a house whose walls were made of solid glass was to open two small windows at one end and the front door at the other. Without screens around the deck, this was an invitation to bugs.
One summer was all that Dr. Farnsworth could take.
There was no going to Mies for help, however. In 1951, he sued her, claiming she owed him money. She countersued, claiming she had been overcharged. The house cost more than $70,000, or about $450,000 today, allowing for inflation. While that is a lot of money, something deeper must have accounted for their animosity.
"If it is simplistic to say that Farnsworth wanted the house and Mies, and Mies wanted the house and the next client, such a summation comes as close to the heart of the matter as any other," the architectural historian Franz Schulze wrote in a history and guide to the house.
My parents, in their mid-20's when the house was built, were somewhere in the middle. My father had studied and taught under Mies at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago. My mother, Beth, was a patient of Dr. Farnsworth's. They socialized with her at parties and jazz clubs. They visited the house in Plano during construction. And as it neared completion, they stayed overnight.
They did not exactly sleep there, however, since they were kept awake all night while Dr. Farnsworth's poodles, in an amorous mood, chased around the central core as if they were on a travertine dog track.
"Isn't that cute?" Dr. Farnsworth said, when my mother told her of the disturbance the next morning. While the two women talked, just before the architectural historian Henry Russell Hitchcock arrived for a visit, my father recorded the scene with his Kodak Vigilant 620 camera.
He caught a moment of weekend-in-the-country informality wonderfully at odds with the house's formalism: my mother is in pajamas, Dr. Farnsworth in slacks; they lounge on the cantilevered front steps, with cups of coffee and poodles nearby.
A few months later, Dr. Farnsworth asked my mother, "Do you think Bill would design the screens?"
My father was then drafting part time at $1 an hour, supported by my mother's income as a fashion illustrator for Women's Wear Daily. Learning of the prospect, he said, "I'm going to call Mies and tell him there's a way to finish the screens without going to someone else."
Unknown to Dr. Farnsworth, my father then shared his drawings with Mies, to be certain they met with the master's approval. At least once, Mies was reviewing blueprints in my parents' apartment just before the client arrived to do the same thing -- requiring some logistical dexterity to prevent a collision between the two warring parties in the alleyway.
The screens were installed in April 1952, three weeks before I was born.
Then the battle between Mies and Dr. Farnsworth played out in court. It appeared that my father's photographs might be called into evidence. Sending the negatives to Mies's office, he wrote, "Beth and I personally have no quarrel with Edith and we'd prefer if possible that you don't use any of the shots with Beth in them."
"Please return when the smoke clears," he added.
The smoke did not clear, however. After Dr. Farnsworth learned that my father had collaborated with Mies, she never spoke to him again. And my father, who joined the firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, did not speak to me or my brother of his work at the Farnsworth House. He was the partner in charge of Sears Tower at the time of his death in 1973, so there were truly bigger things to talk about.
Mies died in 1969 and Dr. Farnsworth in 1977, having sold the house to Lord Palumbo. One of the first things he did was install an unobtrusive air-conditioning system and remove the screens. "While they had a practical value in terms of mosquitoes, they interrupted the flow of space and closed in an area that was intended to be kept open," he explained in a telephone conversation from London.
After the disastrous flood of 1996 and a lesser one in 1997, Lord Palumbo restored the house, working with the architect Dirk Lohan, who is Mies's grandson. The central core was rebuilt, and its blond primavera wood panels were replaced.
It was also in 1997 that I happened to be rooting through papers in the Chicago apartment where my family has lived for 40 years. That was when I found 20 Farnsworth blueprints, some with my father's name, others bearing Mies's architectural stamp. I found tracing-paper sketches, correspondence with the metal fabricator, 60 photos and a handwritten budget: $4,566.75, including $389.25 for the struggling young architect. My mother filled in the story.
I found no trace of my father's work when I visited the Farnsworth House recently for the first time. But I saw abundant evidence that the Palumbos use the place when they are in town. Sculptures come and go. An antique maple rocking chair sits exotically among the svelte Mies furnishings. Wine bottles fill the stainless-steel kitchen counter. A black Trimline telephone rests on the bedside shelf. Family pictures line the bathroom walls. Neckties are draped decorously inside the teak wardrobe. (Pardon the intrusion, milord.)
"It's not an intrusion," he reassured me, "because it shows the human side of the house."
He used to keep house more ascetically, Lord Palumbo said, but that created a problem. "It was becoming a shrine," he said. "It was beginning to take itself too seriously. I thought it needed livening up."
Judging from comments in the guest book, the bric-a-brac is second only to the mosquitoes as a source of annoyance. "It is overcluttered -- I accept that," Lord Palumbo said. "But from a human dimension, if you want to get the flavor -- for better or worse -- of the people who own it, there have to be things around."
As for me, I delight in signs that the place is inhabited, that it is not frozen as a museum but rather breathes with the needs and whims of its owners. After all, Mies designed a monument, but my father first made it possible to live in.
The Farnsworth House is at 14520 River Road in Plano, Ill., about a 90- minute drive from Chicago. Hours: Thursday through Tuesday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; closed on Wednesday. Admission: $15, including a tour of the grounds, which were landscaped by Lanning Roper. There are sculptures by Harry Bertoia, Anthony Caro, Andy Goldsworthy, Ellsworth Kelly, Wendy Taylor and others. Telephone: (630) 552-8622; Web address: www.farnsworthhouse.com. Reservations are advised, as is mosquito repellent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil OustsBank Board That Opposed Tax

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 23

 BODY:
In an effort to reassert control over unruly factions in the Government bureaucracy, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has dismissed the board of one of the largest Government-controlled banks after it opposed an important tax.
Mr. Cardoso on Tuesday evening ousted the 10 highest-ranking executives of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo S.A., known as Banespa, including the president, Joao Alberto Magro. The bank had sought a court order aimed at freeing itself from paying a 0.38 percent tax on financial transactions. 
 The tax, which this year is expected to raise at least 7 billion reais -- now $3.9 billion -- is considered essential in containing the nation's budget deficit, a lingering worry among investors concerned with the long-term health of the Brazilian economy.
"You don't want people questioning this tax in the courts," said Walter Molano, head of Latin American research at BCP Secutities in Greenwich, Conn.
The latest source of dissent, from a bank ranked as Brazil's sixth largest and controlled by national authorities, came at a time when the President's ability to limit crises within the Government has been called into question.
"This was an extreme example of how Cardoso can't control his executive branch," said David Fleischer, a political science professor at the University of Brasilia.
In recent days, Mr. Cardoso has had to deal with the resignation of the appointee to head the federal police after the candidate was accused of torture during military rule in the 1970's. That episode followed a dispute between high-ranking aides on economic development policy and a scandal over the freewheeling use of military jets by Cabinet ministers for personal trips.
Although the President's popularity rating has slipped to its lowest level since he took office in 1995, his swift move against Banespa is seen by some as a turning point. Earlier this week, the President promised "zero tolerance" of dissent within the Government in an effort to strengthen his hand.
Banespa has been a burden, with a history of bad loans. It is scheduled to be privatized in October.
Brazil's largest privately owned banks, along with several foreign institutions, are preparing bids for Banespa. "Barring strong opposition from unions, there is every indication Banespa will be sold this year," said Erivelto Rodrigues, head of Austin Asis, a banking-analysis firm.

HEADLINE: Long View From the Waterfront;
Developer Has Pursued a Brooklyn Dream for 20 Years

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Samuel J. LeFrak owns more buildings, Mortimer B. Zuckerman wields more political clout and Donald J. Trump boasts a higher profile. But no New York developer is more persistent than David C. Walentas.
For 20 years Mr. Walentas has pursued a singular vision: the rebuilding of a tiny neighborhood of turn-of-the-century industrial buildings and Civil War-era warehouses tucked unobtrusively between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges on the Brooklyn waterfront. 
 Many developers, Mr. Walentas among them, have converted old factories into loft residences and trendy shops in areas like SoHo, NoHo and TriBeCa in the last two decades. But no one has taken control of almost a whole neighborhood of dilapidated factory buildings and tried to transform it into a contemporary carnival of riverfront condominiums, offices, cafes, galleries, artists' studios and stores.
The first time Mr. Walentas dared to think so big, in the early 1980's, his plan was derailed by city officials who grew skeptical of his ability to realize his dream. They said he lacked sufficient financing, but he contended that he had been undone by a deputy mayor with a personal vendetta. The neighborhood was then known as Fulton Landing.
Now, 15 years later, Mr. Walentas is back. This time the neighborhood is called Dumbo -- for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass -- and his plans are even more ambitious. He wants to build a luxury hotel, a 16-screen multiplex, a shopping mall, a marina, parking garages and an expanded waterfront park, almost all on government-owned land. For a while, the chances for success seemed brighter, in part because of New York's vibrant economy. But senior city officials have recently made ominous noises about potential problems with the plan.
Mr. Walentas is not easily deterred. He is described, by friend and foe alike, as tenacious. To admirers, that means smart and relentless; to critics, that means stubborn, if not intransigent.
An old friend, Pierson G. Mapes, who ran the NBC network's sales and marketing division for more than a decade, called him "a great visionary."
"He's got a passion for real estate, he understands the marketing very well, he understands balance sheets and he's very focused," Mr. Mapes said. "He's got the patience of Job."
But some former city and state officials who worked with Mr. Walentas on his first plan say his tenacity does not always serve him well when dealing with government. William J. Stern, who ran the state's economic development agency for much of the 1980's and who supported Mr. Walentas's first proposal, said he could be uncompromising.
"Walentas is very determined, and in his line of work that is very important," Mr. Stern said. "But I don't think he has the flexibility necessary when dealing with government. Just a little bit of c'est la guerre. He just did not have that. He's a man on a mission."
Mr. Walentas, an informal man who wears jeans and open-necked shirts in the office, does not hide his self-confident sense of mission.
"They're always calling me tenacious," he said. "But the problem with development is that the process is long term and the benefits are long term. And politics is a short-term process. Politicians can't take long-term views. None of them are going to be around when I'm finished."
Mr. Walentas, 60, is a wiry, energetic man with a thick shock of gray hair. He is direct, open and focused, many of his friends said, perhaps to a fault. "He is, to put it mildly, direct about everything," said Donald A. Pels, a retired broadcasting executive who has known Mr. Walentas for 25 years. "He's more likely to twist the tiger's tail than to duck questions."
Mr. Walentas and his wife, Jane, have an apartment with panoramic views in one of his waterfront buildings and a house on a horse farm in Bridgehampton, where he spends weekends riding and playing polo. He has amassed a considerable fortune in real estate -- like most big-time developers, he will not say exactly how large -- but his roots are in a very different world.
And his life history has repeatedly taught him the virtues of perseverance and risk-taking. (In case he should forget, the lesson is emblazoned in bold letters on the left cuff of each of his custom-made, button-down shirts: "No guts, no glory.")
Mr. Walentas grew up in a working-class family in Rochester. When he was 5, his father, a postal worker, suffered a stroke that left him paralyzed. His mother, overwhelmed, sent Mr. Walentas and his older brother, Peter, to live for the next six years with families on farms outside Rochester, under circumstances he described as "somewhere between foster homes and indentured servitude."
When he returned home, at a time his mother was working nights at the post office, bright and ambitious young David earned money nights and weekends assembling boxes at local department stores. He won a scholarship to the University of Virginia, where he earned a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering and a graduate degree in business administration.
In 1966, after stints working in Greenland, Australia and Japan to pay off student loans, he came to New York City to fulfill a longstanding dream.
"I always wanted to be in the real estate business," he said. "I don't know why. Some people have musical talent, some people have dance talent. Real estate was something that I just always understood."
He worked days as a management consultant and spent nights and weekends scouting properties. With two young partners, he bought his first building in 1967, an apartment house on Manhattan Avenue on the Upper West Side. "I made a classic mistake," he said. "I bought the best building in a bad neighborhood."
Then he and his partners got smarter. It was not long before they turned their attention to SoHo, where they bought old factory buildings and converted them to residential lofts. Some of Mr. Walentas's other ventures included co-op conversions on lower Fifth Avenue and West 58th Street, renovations of low-income apartment buildings in the Bronx and the purchase of apartment complexes in Queens, Baltimore and Atlanta.
Mr. Walentas knew nothing about Brooklyn until a day two decades ago when he ventured there to check out a listing for a vacant factory near the East River. He lunched at the River Cafe, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, and then meandered through the faded industrial neighborhood to the north.
He took in the Empire Stores, a vacant warehouse built just after the Civil War, the scruffy state-owned riverfront park and the dozen or so large factory buildings sandwiched between the two bridges, the river and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Transfixed by the spectacular views of Manhattan and contemplating the lessons of SoHo, he had a brainstorm.
"I thought, 'Wow, what a neighborhood!' " he recalled. "I thought I shouldn't buy just one building; I should buy as many as I could."
Within short order, he had done just that. By 1982, Mr. Walentas owned almost all of the neighborhood's major buildings, 10 in all, and he began pushing to redevelop the government-owned waterfront.
The project bogged down in 1984, when Kenneth Lipper, then a deputy mayor, blocked the plan, saying that Mr. Walentas had failed to obtain adequate financing. Mr. Walentas contended that Mr. Lipper was motivated by a personal agenda, that he wrongly held Mr. Walentas responsible for the suicide a few years earlier of Mr. Walentas's real estate partner, J. Frederic Byers 3d, who had also been a friend of Mr. Lipper.
Mr. Lipper declined to comment on the matter, but many former city and state officials said his decision had been made on the merits.
"I did not see substance to Walentas's accusations," said Mr. Stern, who supported the plan at the time as chairman of the State's Urban Development Corporation. "Every issue Ken raised, in my judgment, was a solid, substantive issue."
Mr. Walentas held onto his buildings -- and his dream. After getting permission two years ago to convert some of his factory buildings, he rebuilt the tallest one, with a dramatic clock tower, into large condominium loft apartments with proverbial million-dollar views and price tags to match. He is renovating two smaller vacant factory buildings into rental apartments.
He remains dedicated to the idea of a major entertainment, shopping and cultural complex along the river, which, of course, would enhance the value of his property. "It's just such a great waterfront that it has to get developed," Mr. Walentas said.
While the architecture of the proposed hotel has won praise, many community groups have criticized the overall plan as too commercial, too large and a potential traffic nightmare. Mr. Walentas dismisses such concerns as misguided. "People are afraid of change," he said.
City and state officials have selected him to develop the waterfront, but his plan has not yet received a formal nod from the City Planning Department to begin the long, arduous land-use review and approval process.
It may have already hit a snag. A mayoral adviser said last week that there were "some serious problems" with the proposal, which the adviser declined to specify. "It just might not pass muster," the aide said.
Mr. Walentas, however, remains confident that a version of what he is proposing will be built, perhaps soon or perhaps later. Mr. Walentas continues to think long term: If he cannot complete the project, his son Jed, who is 24 and works for his father, will.
"Frankly, this is my last shot," he said. "Jed will take the next one. He was 4 when we started this."
