HEADLINE: Microsoft's Final Witness Is Questioned on Payments

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
A Government lawyer began cross-examination of Microsoft's final witness in its antitrust trial today and quickly prompted him to disclose that Microsoft had paid about $250,000 for his testimony and related work.
The witness was Richard L. Schmalensee, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Microsoft's expert economist for the trial. He said that over the last two years he has charged Microsoft $800 an hour for his trial work. In addition, the private company through which he bills Microsoft paid him a $200,000 bonus last year, double that of the previous year, presumably because of the Microsoft income. 
 A fee of $800 an hour is not an unusual retainer for an expert witness of this sort. But David Boies, the Government's lead trial lawyer, apparently hoped the disclosure would further his broad effort to impeach Mr. Schmalensee's testimony. The last time Mr. Schmalensee was on the stand, in January, Mr. Boies suggested that he was Microsoft's "house economist."
Expert witnesses are routinely paid for their testimony. And Mr. Boies posed his questions long after the Government's own expert economist, Franklin M. Fisher, another M.I.T. professor, had left the stand, giving Microsoft's lawyers no opportunity to pose similar questions to him. Testimony while Mr. Fisher was on the stand suggested that he, too, stood to profit handsomely from participating in the trial.
Michael Lacovara, a Microsoft lawyer, ended his friendly examination of Mr. Schmalensee this morning with a long series of questions about Web-based applications -- software programs that reside on the Web and are used while on line.
He showed several examples of new entrants in this budding market and observed that the trend suggested Microsoft did not have a durable monopoly in personal computer operating systems. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is hearing the case without a jury, had shown interest in the subject Tuesday evening, saying he imagined software companies were writing these programs "in droves."
This morning, Mr. Lacovara introduced as evidence an Internet news article published just two hours before Judge Jackson's remark, headlined "Web-based applications debut in droves."
"Sometimes, Your Honor, we get lucky," Mr. Lacovara said, and the judge smiled appreciatively.
But when Mr. Boies's turn came, he asked Mr. Schmalensee if it was not true that to use a Web-based application, a user needed a Web browser and an operating system -- in most cases, Windows. Mr. Schmalensee reluctantly agreed. The unspoken question was: How does this phenomenon threaten Windows if a Windows computer was needed to use the programs?
In quick succession, Mr. Boies also managed to discredit two charts that Mr. Schmalensee had offered as evidence on Monday and, by implication, to raise questions about the validity of a wide range of statistics the witness had offered as evidence.
The charts were meant to show that the Netscape browser was growing and thriving, despite Microsoft's efforts to crush it. Mr. Boies quickly pointed out that the chart was flawed, the conclusions exaggerated. Mr. Schmalensee, clearly flustered, stammered a bit as he said: "A comparison here suggests there's a difficulty. One of these things is wrong, that's apparent."
Later, Microsoft offered a corrected version of the chart. But then Mr. Boies set about attacking the underlying data. He showed several E-mail messages in which a survey company had told Microsoft that one of the key questions used to derive browser market share was badly flawed, resulting in unreliable answers. But Microsoft had not accepted the company's suggestion to change it.
Mr. Schmalensee said he had not even been aware of the discussion, though the private company with which he is associated was a party to the E-mail dialogue. In any case, the witness said, "I'm not a specialist in writing surveys, and wouldn't have felt competent to evaluate it." Besides, he added, "I don't consider it particularly material."
Then Mr. Boies showed that one key question was so badly designed that 20 percent of the answers were demonstrably unreliable. "A 20 percent figure inconsistency -- wouldn't that bother you?" he asked Mr. Schmalensee.
"It would really depend on the exact question asked," the witness replied.

HEADLINE: Chamber Music as It Was

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
Chamber music, as its name implies, is music meant to be performed in chamber-size rooms. Historically, such performances were informal. When Mozart and some friends got together to play string quartets, they were taking part essentially in sight-reading sessions for the musicians involved, with sometimes an extra listener or two. And they were usually playing in someone's living room. Even when the idea of chamber music concerts took hold, these still tended to be private affairs in smaller spaces, at most a wealthy musical amateur's elegant salon with chandeliers, satin sofas and floor space for additional chairs.
The concert halls where chamber music is typically performed today are too large. Alice Tully Hall, which was built for chamber music, is much too large at 1,096 seats. Merkin Concert Hall, which seats about 450, is better. The rotunda at the Frick Collection, which can accommodate about 175, is better still, though the sound of the room is rather bright. 
 But is there any place where music lovers can experience the intimacy of chamber music as it was in the days of Mozart and Mendelssohn and as it should still be today?
Yes. On a 102-foot solid steel barge docked on the East River in Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, practically underneath it.
Since 1977, this has been the home of Bargemusic, which may be the most prolific chamber music series in the world, since it offers at least two concerts a week -- on Thursday evenings and Sunday afternoons, and during certain periods one more on Friday nights -- all year round. The founder and director of Bargemusic is the 80-year-old Olga Bloom, a wizened, soft-spoken yet indomitable amateur violinist who is also something of a local character among her maritime neighbors. She owns the barge, which she bought in the 1970's for $10,000, and until about 15 years ago she lived on it as well. "I was a peculiar apparition around here," she said on Sunday after an all-Schubert concert on the barge. "I was happy living here. But the city was getting so many inquiries from other harbor people who wanted to live on the river that they kicked me off." She bought a Civil War-era home in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn for $6,000 and lives there still.
She might as well be living on the barge for all the time she spends there. It's nothing fancy, just your basic barge, with a 10-foot high ceiling and a narrow metal gangplank. But inside, the walls are paneled with lovely cherry wood, which Ms. Bloom carted over in her car from Staten Island and installed herself with help from family and friends. There are the requisite amenities (a restroom and such), and a pantry to prepare snacks and drinks for sale. Using folding chairs, the space can accommodate about 130 comfortably, though the Fire Department has given clearance for 179.
The barge may be spare, but the view it affords of lower Manhattan across the river is spectacular, and it can be enjoyed not just from the rooftop deck, where the audience wanders during intermission, but from inside during the concerts: the musicians play on a slightly raised platform against a rear wall of windows that overlooks the river.
It's not the room's acoustical properties that make it so ideal for chamber music. Actually, the space has some acoustical quirks. The piano, a lovely Steinway, sounds imposing up close, yet somewhat under-powered on the far side of the room. But it doesn't matter. The intimate space draws you into the midst of a performance. On Sunday, when a group of fine musicians played Schubert's "Trout" Quintet, the resonance of the bass seemed to travel right through the floorboards, and the brilliant piano writing in the high register of the keyboard jangled in the ears. It was positively symphonic. And that's the point. Heard up close, chamber works become enormous musical statements.
 
A Spiritual Goal
The idea of chamber music on a barge may seem peculiar, but Ms. Bloom points to a precedent. When King George I of England asked Handel to write music for a royal water party, legend has it that the musicians played for the revelers on a barge floating up the Thames. "If it was good enough for a king, it is good enough for us," Ms. Bloom says.
But her inspiration was as much spiritual as musical. "We are strangling in plastic," she says. "It has been my sad fate to watch electronic developments increase the profitability of music in certain areas and diminish the sensitivity of human response in general." She wanted to create at least one small place where people can come together, audiences and musicians, and realize that they have shared values.
Sometimes, for gala events, Ms. Bloom will participate in a performance. Mostly she plays chamber music in the traditional way: with friends at home in the darkness of the night, she says.
Ms. Bloom was born in Boston to immigrant parents. Her Russian father, an ardent Communist, "played the violin atrociously," she says. Her mother, of Slavic descent, sang beautifully. Their relationship survived the turbulent 1920's by their shared love of nature and music. Ms. Bloom's violin teacher, Jacques Hoffmann, was the associate concert master of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the time. When the Depression came, he kept teaching her free of charge. When Ms. Bloom realized that a professional career as a violinist was not in her future, she still felt a need to give something back to music.
 
Wood, Steel and Waves
Getting Bargemusic going was a formidable undertaking. She owned two barges before settling on the current one. The first was a "glorious thing," Ms. Bloom says, with massive beams. But the four-inch-thick flooring just soaked up the sound. Moreover, a wooden barge was uninsurable, she learned. So public concerts would have been prohibited. The second barge was solid steel, but the particular type of steel was spongy and brittle. "If you poked your finger in the hull, it started to give way," she explains. Over the years Ms. Bloom has put some $100,000 into renovating the current barge, which has proved reliable and inviting.
A large circle of excellent and loyal musicians have been involved with Bargemusic. The remarkable cellist Ronald Thomas, who is based in New York but is also the artistic director of the Boston Chamber Music Society, participated in Sunday's program and serves on the seven-member Resident Artists Committee, which picks the programs. "So many of us have played with each other over the years, not just here but in other places, that it feels like we are regular partners," he said after the concert. "Yet there is a comradeship, a spirit of informality that allows us to take musical risks that we might not in some Manhattan hall."
Of course, the musicians must deal with the shifting of the barge, which rocks gently up and down every time a ferry, tugboat or cargo ship passes by. "You can count on having a slip, or two or three in every piece," Mr. Thomas said. "But it doesn't matter." Ms. Bloom thinks that a little sense of danger makes the atmosphere more romantic and helps the audience pay attention.
The musicians take risks not just in interpretations but in programming, which is adventurous. A concert tonight, part of a special Friday series sponsored by the Nakamichi Foundation, offers a piano trio composed in 1984-85 by the Argentine-born composer Maurizio Kagel and the Brahms Piano Quartet in G minor. A program on Sunday afternoon at 4 will present the fine Hungarian pianist Peter Nagy in a recital of works by Messiaen, Bartok and Schubert.
 
A Different Notion
Programs frequently mix the old and the new in enticing ways. But even standard repertory programs, like Sunday's all-Schubert concert, are freshly thought out. The "Trout" Quintet was preceded by an Adagio and Rondo for the same group of unusual instruments (violin, viola, cello, bass, piano), a little-known work that sounds like a sketch for a mini piano concerto. Mr. Nagy also gave an eloquent account of one of Schubert's least-heard piano works, the five-movement Sonata, D. 459.
New musicians keep getting drawn into the Bargemusic circle. In February the pianist Peter Serkin played there for the first time with a group of exemplary performers including two members of the Artists Committee: the violist Paul Neubauer and the cellist Fred Sherry. The program offered recent works by Oliver Knussen and Toru Takemitsu and a pair of Haydn piano trios in big-gestured performances that, heard up close, seemed a rebuke to the notion that Classical era chamber music should be refined.
 Change is coming to the Bargemusic schedule in January. Ms. Bloom's board has just given her the go-ahead to offer regular concerts on Saturday evenings. The idea would be to have one program played on Thursday nights and Sunday afternoons, and another on Friday and Saturday nights. This means that the rental of the barge for catered events on Saturdays, which in the past has provided one-third of the organization's income, will cease. "The hell with it," Ms. Bloom says. "Everything in life is a risk. Let's go for it."
 
Harbor Dredging
Ms. Bloom must be the only presenter of chamber music around who has to worry about the dredging of New York Harbor. Plans for this environmentally essential work are under heated discussion between the Coast Guard, the Army Corps of Engineers, the Port Authority of New York and the Department of Economic Development, she explained. It will be a huge project, and no agreement has yet been reached about how to proceed. Silt and sediment have accumulated in the riverbed to the point that during low tides the barge sometimes rests on rock, which is terrible for its hull.
But Ms. Bloom remains irrepressible and committed to her barge as a site for chamber music. She is even feeling more hopeful about the economic future of struggling musicians, something that pained her for decades. "Finally, there seems to be a growing awareness that we in this society are being blunted spiritually and personally beyond redemption," she says. "The arts can heal us, and I think there is a new awareness of this. I think there is a change in the tide."
She may be right. Ms. Bloom is an authority on the tide.

HEADLINE: A Model for Penn Station Is on View at the Modern

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
A model of the proposed design for the new Pennsylvania Station has been placed on view at the Museum of Modern Art. The display will remain on the fourth-floor landing outside the museum's architecture and design galleries until Aug. 1.
The presentation revives the Preview series, an exhibition program initiated in 1993 by Terence Riley, chief curator of the Modern's department of architecture and design, as a showcase for individual buildings before construction. Projects previously featured in the series include the Tokyo International Forum, designed by Rafael Vinoly; the Austrian Cultural Institute in Manhattan, by Raimund Abraham, and the Nara Convention Hall, by Arata Isozaki. 
 Designed by David M. Childs of the New York office of Skidmore Owings & Merrill, the new Penn Station is to be housed in the James A. Farley Building, the Beaux-Arts post office on Eighth Avenue between West 31st and 33d Streets. The design includes a new ticketing hall, two blocks long, housed beneath a dramatic, curving space frame of metal and glass. The framework, 150 feet high, also contains the main entrances to the train station, which will be on 31st and 33d Streets between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Waiting areas and shops will occupy a series of platforms, or trays, that step down from street level to the train platforms four stories below ground.
The $486 million project, the most important public work undertaken in New York in more than a generation, will include the Manhattan terminal of a rail link to Kennedy Airport, in addition to hubs for Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and the Long Island Rail Road. A rail link to Newark Airport is also planned.
For now, the United States Postal Service will continue to operate in the 1935 annex to the Farley Building, which was designed in 1913 by McKim, Mead & White, the architects of the original Penn Station. The postal service will also maintain its existing retail operations in the lobby on the Eighth Avenue side of the building.
In an interview, Mr. Riley said, "The Preview series will resume at a steady beat, focusing on newsworthy projects as they break." He said he expected New York building projects to be a regular feature of the museum series. "For the last three decades, New Yorkers with an interest in architecture have had to settle for mediocre developer work as the homegrown product," Mr. Riley said. "The Skidmore, Owings & Merrill design for the new Penn Station is mercifully an exception, and hopefully is the beginning of renewed interest in the city and in architectural excellence."
The Penn Station project faces economic and political obstacles before construction can proceed. About $80 million of the projected cost has yet to be secured. Supporters of the project were dismayed when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declined to attend an unveiling ceremony last month. Though the city has committed only $25 million -- roughly 5 percent of the total cost -- Mr. Giuliani has the power to veto the spending of funds already obtained from Federal and state sources.
The Mayor has also expressed reservations about Mr. Childs's design. At a news conference, he likened the new ticketing hall to a side alley. For the next few weeks, visitors to the Modern will have the opportunity to see for themselves.

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Even in Fog, That City On a Hill Dazzles

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
More than any other, this is the city that Americans fantasize about. No one leaves his heart in Salt Lake City. No one calls Baltimore Baghdad by the Bay, as Herb Caen, the city's six-day-a-week poet laureate for more than 50 years, called San Francisco.
For me San Francisco has always been a paradox: a thoroughly worldly place, yet remote and somehow detached from world capitals like New York and London; a little indifferent to the mundane business of trading shares and casting votes; in other words, a bit smug. (The good Mr. Caen, who before his death in 1997 did for San Francisco what Samuel Pepys did for London, once quoted a local citizen who, upon reaching heaven, reported back to friends here that "it's nice, but it isn't San Francisco.") 
 Yet San Francisco looms large in the imagination of everyone who knows it, myself most decidedly included. Like Paris, Venice and Hong Kong, it is a city without peer, a city of myth and magic.
I can't think of the place without thinking about sourdough bread and Alice Waters, who revolutionized American cooking; Joe DiMaggio, the fisherman's son, and A. P. Giannini, another Italian-American, who built the world's largest bank; Turk Murphy and San Francisco jazz; Alcatraz and San Quentin; the hairpin bends on Lombard Street and the sudden watery vistas.
The weather I could do without. Fog veils the city so often that a local radio station has adopted the call letters KFOG. Fog bleaches the color from the perky paint jobs on the Victorian frame houses that march up and down the city's distinctive hills. When the fog finally lifts, when everything sparkles in the sun, it is an occasion for celebration. Yes! A five-bridge day, with all the spans from the Golden Gate almost down to Palo Alto clearly visible.
But fog has its uses. Several years ago, crossing the Bay Bridge from Oakland to San Francisco at dawn, my wife, Betsey, and I watched bug-eyed as the Transamerica pyramid and the city's other towers rose bronzed and beautiful from their cloudy bed. Nothing, in truth, not fog or rain or fire or quake, ever quite masks San Francisco's beauty or quenches its exuberance. Its setting rivals Rio's. Its charm compares with Boston's. Its joie de vivre nearly matches that of New Orleans; it lacks only the last Latin measure of heedlessness.
Characters from Nob Hill and Telegraph Hill, Chinatown and the Tenderloin have walked straight into the pages of Bret Harte, Jack London, Frank Norris, Dashiell Hammett, Tom Wolfe (who found the essential San Francisco experience in "roaring up hills or down hills, sliding on and off the cable-car tracks") and John Steinbeck, who loved San Francisco, as he wrote, when "the afternoon sun painted her white and gold, rising on her hills like a noble city in a happy dream."
San Francisco is on something of a cultural tear lately, cementing its position as the West Coast's cultural capital, although Los Angeles is by no means the pothole full of philistines many San Franciscans see when (if) they take the plane south.
The San Francisco Opera is the nation's second largest, after the Met, and it has the largest budget of any West Coast arts organization.
An old autocrat named Kurt Herbert Adler built the opera's reputation, bringing singers of the caliber of Tebaldi, Schwarzkopf and Fassbaender to the United States for the first time. Lotfi Mansouri, the current general director, has gradually lengthened the season, and during the 10 months from next September through July 2000, 11 different operas will be performed.
At the moment, the opera is in the midst of four cycles of Wagner's immense "Ring of the Nibelung" at the War Memorial Opera House (the place where the United Nations Charter was signed on June 26, 1945, by representatives of 50 nations). The 15-year-old production was reshaped by Andrei Serban, the Romanian-born stage director, who had never seen a complete "Ring" until his own. Jane Eaglen, Deborah Voigt and James Morris are among the gods, demigods and giants onstage. The final cycle ends on July 3.
 
A Genuine Celebrity
Not to be outdone, the city's orchestra is just concluding an ambitious Stravinsky festival, exploring the master's work in Russia, Paris and Los Angeles, where its music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, then in his 20's, knew him at the end of his long, hugely productive career. Successor to luminaries like Monteux and Krips, the lithe, lean Maestro Thomas is one of only three American-born music directors of major American orchestras, along with Leonard Slatkin in Washington and Andrew Litton in Dallas. M. T. T., as the local papers call him, is one of San Francisco's genuine celebrities these days, a Pied Piper leading the young back into the concert hall.
If the critics grumble once in a while, the public has responded warmly to his programs in his nearly four years here, and even a Vienna audience would have been impressed, I think, by his powerful but never bombastic Bruckner Ninth in Davies Symphony Hall early this spring.
As ever under Mr. Thomas, there will be a lot of American and modern music next season, plus a tasty rarity, Elgar's "Dream of Gerontius."
The San Francisco Ballet is in the hands of an old New York favorite, Helgi Tomasson, who has transformed a regional troupe into a fine classical company since taking over as artistic director in 1985. I won't prattle on here; it's enough to quote Anna Kisselgoff of The New York Times, no easy mark, who proclaimed the company "world class" after watching it last year.
All three companies perform in San Francisco's Civic Center, whose most prominent building is the newly, grandly restored City Hall, with an enormous, echoing rotunda. (Don't miss it, even if this stuff usually leaves you cold as a musher's nose in midwinter.) Nearby stands the new public library, and by 2002, now that a knot of litigation has seemingly been untied, the Asian Art Museum is scheduled to open in the old library building, adapted by Gae Aulenti, the Italian wizard who turned a Paris train station into the Musee d'Orsay.
Comparisons are odious, if entertaining, but I would argue that the Asian museum is San Francisco's best. Built around the collection of Avery Brundage, it contains Japanese, Korean and Indian works, but the Chinese material is supreme. When the Chinese leader Jiang Zemin visited the museum, he was dazzled by a gilded image of the Buddha from A.D. 338. I'll bet you will be, too.
For the moment, the Asian museum shares a quake-weakened, obtrusively buttressed building in Golden Gate Park with the M. H. de Young Museum, which has raised $65 million for a new home, to be designed by Herzog & de Meuron, architects of the new Bankside building for the Tate Gallery in London. The strength of its collection lies in American painting, from George Caleb Bingham's "Boatmen on the Missouri" through Frederic E. Church's "Rainy Season in the Tropics" to Grant Wood's "Dinner for Threshers," a plain-faced group portrait that outshines the over-familiar "American Gothic." Many of the choicest pictures came in a 1978 gift of 175 items from Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d.
The de Young's sister museum, the California Palace of the Legion of Honor -- together they are known as the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco -- was rebuilt and reinvented several years ago, reopening in November 1995. It occupies a picturesque site in Lincoln Park, overlooking the great rust-red pylons of the Golden Gate Bridge, an iconic structure that embodies this city's spirit the way the Statue of Liberty embodies New York's.
Founded by the flamboyant Alma de Bretteville Spreckels, whose rich, indulgent husband, Adolph, inherited a sugar fortune, the museum's collection centers on European art, especially French art. The "Old Woman" by Georges de la Tour, a Monet "Waterlilies," a powerful off-center portrait by Degas, "The Impresario," and some 70 Rodins are in the collection.
Yet another arts district has sprung into being in recent years in the redeveloped area south of Market Street, known as SoMa. At its core is the Yerba Buena Center, designed for the many small-scale arts organizations in the Bay Area. It includes galleries by the Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki, sheathed in corrugated aluminum siding but still somehow delicate, and a theater designed by James Stewart Polshek, dark and angular on the inside but more like a jaunty piece of de Stijl sculpture outside.
 
More of the Arts
Around the perimeter are a children's entertainment and education center, complete with carousel; the brand-new $85 million Metreon, Sony's urban version of a Disney theme park, with an "environment" by Maurice Sendak, which is expected to attract five million visitors a year; the Ansel Adams Center for Photography, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Still to come are a new Jewish Museum designed by Daniel Libeskind, who did a similar project in Berlin, and a new building for the Mexican Museum.
The big cheese, of course, is the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which is housed in Mario Botta's four-year-old landmark building, whose truncated cylindrical tower lets the light flood in. A bequest from Elise S. Haas, of the Levi Strauss family, brought it several pictures once owned by Sarah Stein, the sister-in-law of Gertrude, including a breathtaking Fauve Matisse, "Femme au Chapeau." Phyllis C. Wattis, the San Francisco cultural world's Brooke Astor, gave $20 million in 1998 to buy 13 Rauschenbergs and other works.
Donald G. Fisher, the founder of the Gap clothing chain, paid $1.9 million in May for an Alexander Calder wood-and-wire sculpture called "Constellation." It appears to be headed for the modern art museum, too. But because of the need to rotate pictures, Bay Area artists like Richard Diebenkorn and Sam Francis are sometimes underrepresented on the museum's walls.
The Yerba Buena area is the epicenter of modern architecture in the city. Elsewhere, the pickings are slimmer, despite Frank Lloyd Wright's building on Maiden Lane, now the Circle Gallery, which was a precursor of the Guggenheim in its use of a spiral ramp, and his Buck Rogers-style civic center in Marin County.
Architecture buffs will want to see something of Bernard Maybeck, the individualist who foreshadowed the California Arts and Crafts movement. (The templelike Palace of Fine Arts, left over from the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition, and the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Berkeley are his masterworks.) A glacier-white Richard Neutra house, cantilevered over a cliff with a picture-postcard view of the Bay Bridge, is at 56 Calhoun Terrace. And the excess of San Francisco's Gilded Age is wonderfully displayed in Alma Spreckels's Beaux-Arts mansion on Pacific Heights, with 26 bathrooms. It now belongs to Danielle Steel, the romance novelist.
 
Striking It Rich
Hemmed in by bay and ocean at the tip of a narrow peninsula, San Francisco is relatively small. It ranks only 13th on the list of American cities, with a population estimated at 735,000 in 1996; Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose are all bigger. But the metropolitan area surrounding the bay, with 6.6 million people, is the nation's fifth largest.
San Francisco was built on three stout economic legs: silver from the Comstock Lode, the transcontinental railroads and the port, once dominated by Harry Bridges, the militant leader of the longshoremen.
George Hearst struck it rich in the mines; his son, William Randolph Hearst, struck it richer in yellow journalism, which he helped to invent; the younger Hearst's granddaughter Patty was kidnapped in 1974 by the Symbionese Liberation Army, but survived. The circulation of Hearst's flagship, The San Francisco Examiner, whose logo proclaims it "Monarch of the Dailies," has shriveled, but it may yet swallow its larger rival, The San Francisco Chronicle, whose owning families could give lessons to the Hatfields and the McCoys.
W. R. Hearst may have been satirized by Orson Welles in "Citizen Kane," but the men who built the Central Pacific, mostly on the back of Chinese coolies, were reviled in their own time as profiteers. They were called the Big Four: Leland Stanford, Collis P. Huntington, Charles Crocker and Mark Hopkins. According to one contemporary account, they made a $63 million profit on a $121 million investment.
It once seemed that San Francisco got by on beauty, charm and the spending of strangers. But that has changed, and radically.
Silicon Valley, just to the south, is the land of memory chips, software and freshly coined millionaires, which attracts a third of all the venture capital invested in the country. Five of the best 20 places to earn a living in the United States, a survey by Forbes magazine recently found, are within an hour and a half's drive of downtown San Francisco.
No wonder people want to live here. No wonder the median price for a single-family house in the Bay Area has risen 14.2 percent in the last year to $334,590. (In Atherton, a tony suburb, it hit $2.5 million.)
But off in a corner, with no share in this orgasm of prosperity, are the city's omnipresent homeless, begging for money at freeway offramps by day, rolling out their sleeping bags by night in the doorways of expensive stores and other buildings, hoping the police won't notice.
If the police do move in, some of the homeless people whip out their cellular phones and call television stations to come film the action.
As early as 1883, Robert Louis Stevenson remarked on the city's cosmopolitan character, detecting "the airs of Marseilles and Peking" in its streets. Writing in the same vein 50 years later, another traveler, John Gunther, called San Francisco "brilliant, polyglot and sophisticated," and said it "will tolerate everything, including the intolerable."
San Francisco has an established social order and lots of Old Money, even a mini-Wall Street. It has a fondness for clubs -- the Olympic; the Bohemian, with its encampments on the Russian River north of town, and the Pacific Union, whose brown sandstone clubhouse atop Nob Hill once belonged to the silver millionaire James Flood. It is bracketed by two universities of world stature -- the University of California at Berkeley, east of the bay, and Stanford University at Palo Alto, an hour south of the city.
But this has always been a city that embraces rule-breakers. From its beginnings as an R & R stop for Gold Rush pioneers through the wide-open era of Barbary Coast saloons to the heyday of North Beach topless bars, featuring the silicone-boosted charms of Carol Doda, San Francisco has been a good-time town, ready to live and let live.
 
A Town of Tolerance
As a result of its tolerance, the city has always had more than its share of characters, notably Joshua Norton, who proclaimed himself Emperor of the United States in 1859 (and advanced the obviously loony idea of a bridge connecting San Francisco and Oakland). I saw one of his spiritual descendants this spring, a portly fellow with full beard and flowing hair, dressed in overalls and railroad engineer's cap, ambling along, blowing soap bubbles.
Countercultures have flourished here since World War II. In the 1950's, Columbus Avenue gave birth to the Beat Generation and its bards Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg. In the 1960's came the hippies of Haight-Ashbury, preaching Flower Power, dreaming multicolored dreams and packing Bill Graham's rock concerts, and the student rebels of Berkeley, led by Mario Savio. In the 1970's, Huey Newton, from Oakland, made the Black Panthers a militant voice for the dispossessed of the nation's ghettos.
Gay men and lesbians were given an honored place in San Francisco when they were still swept under the carpet elsewhere. It was perhaps inevitable that the American AIDS epidemic hit first and hardest here, but horrifyingly unexpected when the gay activist Harvey Milk, whose election as a Supervisor in 1977 had thrilled gay San Franciscans, was assassinated in 1978 along with the city's Mayor, George R. Moscone.
Now the Mayor is Willie L. Brown Jr., a black boulevardier who started life as a sharecropper's son, a man with the charm of Cary Grant, the audacity of a high-wire artist and lots of political smarts. Willie, as they say here, never bothering to specify his last name, "is a piece of work." Some people bridle at his Italian suits, flashy cars and pretty girlfriends, but few will bet against him when he stands for re-election this fall. Many nights, he attends a half-dozen political functions before meeting a friend for a late dinner, and then at midnight he stands on the street outside the restaurant, greeting and teasing a few of the tourists who throng to his city.
His most reliable supporters are San Francisco's Chinese.
 
Delights by the Bay
 
Here is information about visiting San Francisco:
 
Where to Stay
 
CAMPTON PLACE, 340 Stockton Street, (415) 781-5555. A polished little gem of a hotel, ideally situated just off Union Square, marred only by a few overly snug bedrooms. The multinational, multilingual staff will jump through hoops to make you comfortable. A half-dozen of San Francisco's best chefs have presided in the dining room over the last quarter-century. Double room: $260 to $400.
 
MANDARIN ORIENTAL, 222 Sansome Street, (415) 885-0999. In the heart of the Financial District yet close enough to Union Square, Chinatown and SoMa, this is a spectacular sibling of one of Hong Kong's finest hotels. It occupies floors 38 to 48 of a skyscraper, guaranteeing great views. Double room: $415 to $570 weekdays; $255 to $550 weekends.
 
REX, 562 Sutter Street, (415) 433-4434. Like Paris, San Francisco is blessed with affordable hotels, and the Rex is among the most charming. A vaguely clubby lobby with a bar and rooms with luxury-hotel amenities -- voice mail, dataports, movies -- dispel any hint of slumming. Double room: $165 to $245.
 
RITZ-CARLTON, 600 Stockton Street, (415) 296-7465. As ritzy as they come, this is the city's premier hotel, a worthy successor to the grandes dames of the past like the St. Francis, the Clift and the Fairmont. Perched on the side of Nob Hill, it is fairly stuffed with marble, crystal and brocade, and the bedrooms are luxurious in size as well as decor. We ate an impeccable Thanksgiving dinner one year in the pretty restaurant. Double room: $309 to $3,500 for a suite.
 
W, 181 Third Street, (415) 777-5300, is a sassy new spot in the Yerba Buena arts district. An octagonal three-story lobby adjoins a "living room" with smart modern furniture. Royal blue and chocolate brown are the colors of choice upstairs and down. The restaurant is called XYZ, natch. Double room: $239 to $319.
 
Where to Eat
 
CHEZ PANISSE, 1517 Shattuck Avenue, Berkeley, (510) 548-5525. What to say? Alice Waters only gets better, buying superlative ingredients from small farmers and handling them with reverence. Every night, a six-course set menu, balanced and seasonal, is served in an old Craftsman house half hidden by trees. In the final week of May this year, the menus emphasized fava beans, morels, king salmon and asparagus. The atmosphere is a little worshipful for me, but who cares when everything looks and tastes so beautiful?
 
MASA, 648 Bush Street, (415) 989-7154. For decades now, Masa has been the town's top French restaurant, a subdued, formal place with subtle, complex cooking. Julian Serrano, who made it what it is, has followed the yellow brick road to Las Vegas, but Michael Bauer, The San Francisco Chronicle's exigent food critic, detects no decline in standards.
 
OLIVETO, 5655 College Avenue, Oakland, (510) 547-5356. Close your eyes, and Paul Bertolli will whisk you to the Umbrian countryside. He marries peasant heartiness with city-slicker lightness: homemade noodles with delicate sand dabs, gossamer gnocchi with sage and brown butter, moist roast pork bathed in rich pan juices, with fleshy white beans on the side. One of our companions called the dense chocolate tartuffo "heroin on a plate."
 
POSTRIO, 545 Post Street, (415) 776-7825. This is Wolfgang Puck's Northern California outpost, a trilevel showplace designed by the celebrated Pat Kuleto. Puckish pizzas at the bar; more substantial fare downstairs, notably roasted leg of lamb with garlic mashed potatoes (aaah) and nicoise olives. Or try the fine grilled quail. They serve breakfast, too.
 
RUBICON, 558 Sacramento Street, (415) 434-4100. The room is airy, the food solidly Californian, the management by Drew Nieporent watchful. But it is Larry Stone, California's best sommelier, who pulls in the winos, myself included. Can't find Grace Family cabernets? He has them (at a price, to be sure), as well as small-grower Burgundies and many other goodies.
 
SLANTED DOOR, 584 Valencia Street, (415) 861-8032. You will find no better Vietnamese food anywhere in the United States (or, I dare say, in Vietnam). The neighborhood is proletarian (no parking), but classic dishes like spring rolls and caramelized shrimp are executed with all the finesse of Alain Ducasse. The spicy squid and chili green beans aren't bad, either.
 
TADICH GRILL, 240 California Street, (415) 391-1849. Born with the Gold Rush, Tadich's turns 150 this year. Fabulously fresh fish, simply prepared, is the house specialty: sand dabs and petrale sole, grilled or pan-fried; the tomato-based seafood stew called cioppino, and peerless Dungeness crab in the shell, in a cocktail or in a salad. Go for lunch.
 
TON KIANG, 5821 Geary Boulevard, (415) 387-8273. Think you know dim sum? Ton Kiang will teach you a thing or two about greaseless frying, translucent dumpling skins and the use of chives, spring onions and ginger to point up flavors. This is a favorite of the chef Barbara Tropp, which speaks volumes, and it earns a tip of my hat for its smiling, efficient service.
 
ZUNI CAFE, 1658 Market Street, (415) 552-2522. A friend of mine calls Judy Rogers's Spartan cafe, with copper bar and roaring wood-burning oven, "the soul of San Francisco." So it is, in its delicious simplicity, whether you order a pristine martini and a plate of oysters at the bar, or a Caesar salad fit for a Caesar or, if you go late, an unlisted treat: a princely hamburger made from brined beef ground when you order and served on focaccia.
 
Attractions
 
SAN FRANCISCO OPERA, War Memorial Opera House, Van Ness Avenue and Grove Streets, (415) 864-3330. Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelung," through July 3. Box office: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tickets: $30 to $190. Last production until September.
 
SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY, Civic Center Complex, Davies Symphony Hall, 201 Van Ness Avenue, (415) 864-6000. Through tomorrow, "A Stravinsky Festival"; sold out. Thursday through Aug. 1, the San Franciso Symphony presents its Summer in the City pops concert series, with special guests. The first concert is on Thursday and next Friday, with Patti LuPone. Tickets: $10-$48. Fall season begins on Sept. 8.
 
SAN FRANCISCO BALLET, Civic Center Complex, War Memorial Opera House, 301 Van Ness Avenue, (415) 865-2000. The ballet tours in the summer. Fall season begins in December with "The Nutcracker."
 
ASIAN ART MUSEUM, Tea Garden Drive, off John F. Kennedy Drive, Golden Gate Park, adjacent to the M. H de Young Memorial Museum, (415) 379-8801. About 200 pieces of Chinese jade from the Avery Brundage collection are on view through next summer; "The Unending Path: Paintings by Harold Wong From 1957-1997," through Oct. 17; "From the Rainbow's Varied Hue: Textiles of the Southern Philippines," through Aug. 15. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Admission (includes the M. H. de Young Museum): $7; $5, the elderly; $4, children 12 to 17; free, children under 12 and members.
 
M. H. DE YOUNG MUSEUM, 75 Tea Garden Drive, Golden Gate Park, next to the Asian Art Museum, (415) 863-3330. "The Art of Craft: Contemporary Works From the Faxe Collection," tomorrow through Oct. 17. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: See Asian Art Museum.
 
CALIFORNIA PALACE OF THE LEGION OF HONOR, 34th Avenue and Clement Street, Lincoln Park, (415) 863-3330. "Francis Bacon: A Retrospective Exhibition," through Aug. 2; "The Treasury of Saint Francis of Assisi," July 24 through Nov. 14. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.. Admission: $8; $6, the elderly, $5, children 12 to 17; under 12 is free.
 
YERBA BUENA CENTER, 701 Mission Street, at Third Street, (415) 978-2787. Through tomorrow night, "Sleazoid Express Film Festival." Admission to films and exhibitions: $6; $3, students and the elderly. Summer highlights include the Summerstage free lunchtime series in the Gardens, featuring a weeklong dance festival (July 19-23); San Francisco Butoh Festival (July 31); San Francisco Mime Troupe (Aug. 1) and noontime concerts.
 
METREON, Fourth and Mission Streets, (415) 369-6000 or (800) 638-7366. A four-story complex of theaters, shops and restaurants in the Yerba Buena Gardens area. Hours: Daily, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Admission: $7; $5, children. Web site: www.metreon.com.
 
ANSEL ADAMS CENTER FOR PHOTOGRAPHY, 250 Fourth Street, (415) 495-7000. "Innovation/Imagination: 50 Years of Polaroid Photography," through July 18; "Ansel Adams: Selections From the Permanent Collection," through July 10. HEADLINE: U.S. Move Has Hong Kong Worried It Will Lose Trade

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 24

 BODY:
Fears about Hong Kong's future as an Asian trading post have grown here in the days since the United States Senate moved to tighten controls on exports to this former British colony in response to a Congressional report on military espionage and China.
The Senate on Tuesday approved legislation that would impose more stringent controls on the export of equipment and technology with military uses to Hong Kong and Macao -- a Portuguese colony that will be returned to China in December -- unless both territories allow the United States to verify that sensitive shipments end up in the right hands. 
 The bill, sponsored by Senator John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri, follows assertions in the Congressional committee report that Hong Kong is a staging ground for the acquisition of military technology by China. "Prudence demands that if China diverts sensitive U.S. technology, we impose on Hong Kong and Macao the same export controls that govern sales to China itself," Mr. Ashcroft said in a statement.
It may be prudent for Washington. But for Hong Kong, which has $56 billion a year in trade with the United States, it could mean deep trouble.
"This is an extremely serious issue," said Victor Fung, chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council. "It would affect a major area of development for us, which is moving up the food chain into high technology."
Like many people here, Mr. Fung disputes the accusations in the Congressional report from a committee led by Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California. And he is angry that some in Congress want to strip Hong Kong of its status as an autonomous trading entity within China. Though it reverted to Chinese sovereignty two years ago, Hong Kong polices its own borders and is a member of the World Trade Organization. "It is manifestly unjust not to honor Hong Kong's status," Mr. Fung said. "You don't do that to a member of the W.T.O."
Hong Kong plays only a minor role in the Cox report, which asserts sweeping theft of American military technology by China. But it does come in for criticism as a teeming bazaar in which sensitive technology imports can be diverted to the mainland. The report asserts that a "sizable number of Hong Kong enterprises" are fronts for the People's Liberation Army. The army has a garrison here and regularly moves equipment to and from mainland China. The report says Hong Kong is not allowed to inspect army vehicles crossing the border -- making them a perfect way to smuggle goods.
Officials in Hong Kong said they had the right to inspect Chinese army vehicles. But the procedure is cumbersome: Customs authorities must call the garrison if they suspect an illegal shipment. The garrison then sends soldiers to conduct the inspection under the scrutiny of customs officers. Hong Kong concedes it has not inspected a single army vehicle since the handover.
"So far, we've had no grounds to suspect a breach of Hong Kong laws," said Yvonne Choi, Hong Kong's acting Secretary for Trade and Industry. "But that doesn't mean it won't happen in the future."
Hong Kong's Security Bureau is investigating a report published in a Chinese-language newspaper here that an army truck recently entered the enclave without making a full declaration of its cargo.
Ms. Choi declined to comment on the incident. But she said Hong Kong had an exemplary record of policing exports and imports. She argued that the examples cited in the Cox report -- including one in which parts for an air-to-air missile were found on a commercial flight arriving in Hong Kong -- illustrated the vigilance, not the laxity, of local authorities. "We consider it unfair to treat our successful enforcement actions as a cause for concern," she said.
Hong Kong's government plans a lobbying campaign to try to persuade lawmakers in the United States that its customs standards are adequate, and that Congress should not change Hong Kong's trading status. Officials recently invited Mr. Cox to visit Hong Kong to judge its controls for himself.

HEADLINE: Durable-Goods Orders in May Rebounded With a 1.4% Rise

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Orders placed with factories for durable goods rose in May for the second time in three months, further evidence that manufacturing is pulling out of last year's slump, Government figures showed.
Orders for items that last several years, such as automobiles and appliances, rose 1.4 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase primarily reflected gains in demand for aircraft and autos and came after a revised 2.3 percent decrease in April. 
 The durable goods statistics and two reports showing that jobs remain plentiful suggest that the economy is rolling toward a record expansion early next year. That raises concern the economy is growing too fast and may ignite inflation, which some analysts say increases the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise rates more than once.
The gain in durable goods orders "says to the Federal Reserve that once again they are not seeing what they want to see, which is a significant slowing in economic growth," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston in New York. "And therefore they are likely to hike interest rates at their next meeting and possibly another couple of times before the end of the year."
In a separate report, the Labor Department said today that first-time claims for state unemployment insurance rose 3,000, to a level of 302,000. Also, the Conference Board's index of help-wanted advertising rose 2 points, to 89, in May.
May's increase in durable good orders was led by a 9.5 percent gain in orders for all types of transportation equipment. Orders for civilian aircraft rose 37.8 percent, the first increase since a 137 percent surge in January. Excluding transportation equipment, orders fell seven-tenths of a percent in May after rising nine-tenths of a percent in April and 2.3 percent in March.
Manufacturing is "making its way back," said Bryan Jordan, economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. "Slowly but surely, the world economy is starting to make its way back. Exports are slowly starting to pick up."

HEADLINE: China to Get World Bank Loan Despite U.S. Objections

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The World Bank overruled the United States today and approved a $160 million antipoverty loan for China. However, it agreed to delay financing for the resettlement of 58,000 farmers in a traditionally ethnic Tibetan area until an independent review board determines whether the program meets the bank's environmental and resettlement standards.
The decision to postpone payment for that portion of the loan was in part a last-minute effort by the president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, to keep the United States from opposing the loan. 
 In a phone call Wednesday evening, however, Mr. Wolfensohn apparently failed to convince the Treasury Secretary-designate, Lawrence H. Summers, that American objections to the resettlement program had been fully addressed. The United States, in an unusual breach between the Bank and its largest shareholder, still voted against the project, as did Germany.
Rarely has such a small World Bank program, especially one aimed at helping some of the world's poorest farmers, attracted such controversy. In this case, the plan to move farmers who earn roughly $40 a year to more fertile land ran afoul of objections from pro-Tibetan groups, whose cause -- autonomy or independence for Tibet -- has become a rallying call for opponents of China's Communist Government.
The groups said that the voluntary resettlement of the farmers would dilute the population of ethnic Tibetans in western Qinghai province, which lies on the Tibetan Plateau north of the Tibet Autonomous Region. The farmers, about 40 percent of whom are ethnic Chinese and the remainder Hui Muslim and other minority groups, would be moved from the northeastern part of Qinghai.
Statistics compiled by the World Bank and the State Department suggest that, in fact, the ethnic composition of the area would not change radically. But the issue quickly caught the attention of Congress, came up during Mr. Summers' confirmation hearings, and became enmeshed in the tensions between Washington and Beijing.
World Bank officials said today that they expected the program would ultimately go ahead, but only after substantial modifications to assure that several environmental objections have been addressed -- and to insure that China does not use the program to dilute the presence of Tibetans in the area.
"Even the harshest critics of China should prefer this solution to having the entire project canceled," Mr. Wolfensohn said in an interview this afternoon, after he had flown back from a trip to Europe to quell the dispute over the project.
"China didn't need our $40 million to resettle these farmers," he said, referring to the portion of the loan that would go to this move. "But now they have agreed to a further study, and to allow foreign visitors into the area, unattended by Chinese officials, to assess what is happening. That is a big breakthrough."
Mr. Wolfensohn's proposal for an independent inspection of the project by a three-member fact-finding body, appointed by the bank's board, was supported by the Chinese Government. But only hours earlier, Beijing had accused Washington of interfering in Chinese domestic affairs by seeking to block the project.
A spokeswoman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Zhang Qiyue, said that the American concerns were politically motivated "on the pretext that this will undermine the status of Tibetans."
The compromise, however, apparently did not convince either pro-Tibetan groups or the United States. They said that the project had been rushed through the Bank's review process, largely because later this month China will lose its eligibility for the 40-year-long, no-interest loans provided to the world's poorest nations. Now classified as a richer country, China will have to compete for loans at interest rates closer to what commercial banks charge.
The Clinton Administration insists that, in its haste, the Bank never conducted satisfactory environmental studies of the effects of moving the farmers. But the real objections centered on the concern that the Tibetan influence in the region would be watered down.
"We feel this project never should have gone to the board," said John L. Ackerley, the president of the International Campaign for Tibet. "We don't think the bank has any business diluting ethnic populations."
The bank argues that its poverty reduction program would benefit 1.7 million of China's poorest people. It was designed, the bank said, to help farmers escape eroded lands where malnourishment is common. It would also improve health, education and employment opportunities for people in some of the country's most inaccessible villages, bank officials said, by providing farmers with seeds and fertilizers, basic roads and clean drinking water.
And, though the bank never says so, it also provides Western aid workers and observers with an outpost in a remote and politically sensitive corner of the country.
"These are some of the best projects in the bank," said Mr. Wolfensohn, an Australian-born former investment banker who was appointed to his post by the Clinton Administration. "I've seen barren areas transformed to look like they are as lush as Switzerland."
After the independent board reports its findings, the bank's board of directors will determine whether to release the $40 million portion of the loan that was frozen today. The United States has about 18 percent of the voting power on the board. But apart from Germany, it had no allies today in its effort to stop the China loan.

HEADLINE: American Steel Imports Rose 30% in May

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Steel imports into the United States jumped 30 percent in May, the Commerce Department said today, two days after the Senate rejected a quota bill partly on the ground that imports were headed down.
Whether the May numbers will give new life to quotas is unclear. Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, who had argued that quotas could start an international trade war, said the latest figures should not be cause for worry. 
 "One month is not reason to suddenly believe it's a trend," he said. "We didn't gloat on the month-to-month basis when a one-month statistic showed a drop in imports."
But Representative Ralph Regula, Republican of Ohio, chairman of the House steel caucus, said of the report, "This just demonstrates that predictions that the steel crisis is over were premature at best."
May's increase was the second in seven months. The Commerce Department said it was driven primarily by shipments from Brazil, Mexico and Russia.
Foreign countries shipped three million metric tons of steel to the United States in May, according to the preliminary figures. That was 30 percent higher than the final 2.3 million figure for April, but still 18 percent below November's levels.
From Jan. 1 through May, steel imports totaled 12.4 million metric tons, only a slight increase from the 12.3 million metric tons imported during the corresponding period in 1997, before the Asian economic crisis lowered demand for steel and persuaded foreign producers to find outlets in a healthy American economy. In the corresponding period of 1998, the imports totaled 13.2 million metric tons.

HEADLINE: Rising Costs Pushing Film Production Abroad, Study Says

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 24

 BODY:
About 27 percent of American movies and television series made last year were filmed outside the United States to save money, costing the nation the equivalent of 23,500 full-time jobs and more than $10 billion, according to a study being released on Friday by two Hollywood unions.
The report, commissioned by the Directors Guild of America and the Screen Actors Guild, is apparently the first to try to quantify the extent of "runaway production," the movement of film making to lower-cost countries that many film industry workers say has cost them their jobs. Both unions have hired Washington lobbyists and are expected to use the study's results to push for Federal tax breaks to keep film production in the United States. 
 The report said that 34 percent of television productions last year were made outside the United States for cost reasons, as opposed to script requirements, up from 14 percent in 1990. Most of that increase came from movies made for television. About 139 films, or 45 percent of television films, were made outside the United States in 1998, virtually all of them in Canada. The number of television series and miniseries -- each of which was counted as one production -- made abroad for cost reasons was 46 in 1998, or about 35 percent of the total number of series.
About 19 percent of theatrical films last year were made abroad for cost reasons, mostly low-budget movies. Still, that was up from 14 percent in 1990. And 24 movies with budgets of more than $25 million were made outside the United States in 1998, compared with none in 1990.
"We're starting to witness an accelerating trend here," said Mark Lubkeman, the project leader at the Monitor Company in Cambridge, Mass., which conducted the study. "We're starting to see some larger productions start to run away."
The economic effect, however, is considerably smaller than the percentage of productions would suggest because television movies have lower budgets than series or feature films. About $2.8 billion was spent abroad on such productions in 1998 out of a total production budget of $17.6 billion for the films and television series surveyed. Including indirect effects of the lost spending, the study estimated a loss to the nation's economy of $10.3 billion out of a total economic impact of $74.3 billion.
The report said that producing in Canada was about 25 percent less expensive than in the United States because of tax incentives and the weak Canadian dollar. Some studio executives say that union contracts are partly responsible for the high costs in the United States, but Mr. Lubkeman said that even if wages were cut significantly it would not erase the cost gap with Canada.
Getting tax breaks in Washington could be difficult because of the controversy over violent movies. Moreover, the report itself notes that movie and television production has continued to grow in the United States.
To gain support in Washington, the unions are trying to show that runaway production is a problem for the whole nation. The report said that Los Angeles and New York had experienced growth in film making over the last few years while North Carolina, Washington, Texas and Illinois, which rely on low-budget productions, had seen significant cutbacks.
Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, which represents the large studios, said today that he had not seen the report. But he said that some productions had always gone abroad and that the movement to Canada could reverse if the Canadian dollar strengthened. Also, some of the job pressures being felt by film workers came from cutbacks in the number of films being made.
Mr. Valenti said he would favor investment tax credits for production in the United States but cautioned that Hollywood could not be too nationalistic because 42 percent of its revenue now comes from foreign markets. "We can't say, 'We want to enter your market but we won't let our people produce in your country,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Taking the Fed's Measure;
Focus Shifts to the Central Bank's Long-Term Agenda

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Is it 1994 all over again, the beginning of a prolonged series of interest rate increases intended to wring inflationary pressures out of an economy that is threatening to overheat?
Or is it 1997, when the Federal Reserve bumped interest rates up once just to let everyone know it was on the case, and then let the economy go on its rip-roaring way? 
 Economists and investors are all but certain that the Fed will push its benchmark lending rate up by a modest quarter of a percentage point next week in a pre-emptive strike against the possibility of resurgent inflation. And while neither 1994 nor 1997 provides a precise analogy for the current situation, what everyone wants to know is whether the central bank will be content with a tap or two on the monetary brakes to reassert its inflation-fighting credibility, or whether the Fed will embark on a more vigorous series of rate increases.
Uncertainty about the Fed's intentions could be seen on Wall Street today, where stock and bond prices fell on concern that next week's likely rate increase will not be the last.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, hinted in Congressional testimony last week that the central bank itself did not know yet how far it would have to go to deny inflation a foothold, and would decide based on how the economy performed in coming months.
"What we try to do is make the best judgments we can at the particular time that we meet, or if it is relevant, between meetings," Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee. "I don't recall ever having a sense that we are going to do a series of increases or decreases."
Still, assuming no significant acceleration or slowdown in economic activity the next few months, the odds now seem to favor an in-between scenario in which the Fed tightens its benchmark Federal funds target rate by a quarter-point next week, to 5 percent, and then perhaps once more by another quarter-point later in the summer, before shifting back into neutral.
Although the economy has repeatedly proved to be far stronger than analysts predicted the last several years, many economists think the combination of two modest rate increases by the Fed, combined with the rise the last few months in long-term rates set by the bond market, should be enough to slow the economy to a point where inflation recedes as a threat.
"The view the market has now, and we agree with it, is that another rate hike is coming, but that this round of tightening will not have to be aggressive," said James Glassman, an economist at Chase Securities in New York. "The market now seems priced for another quarter-point move in August, and that's it for a while until we see how things work out."
The judgments made by Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues in coming months will be among the trickiest they have faced in several years. While they now appear comfortable shifting their attention from global financial conditions back to the situation in the United States, Mr. Greenspan in particular will have to balance his oft-expressed belief in the inflation-dampening power of increased productivity against his fear of endangering the domestic price stability of the last few years.
For all the obvious comparisons, policy makers may draw little guidance from their experiences raising rates in 1994 and 1997. While the Fed, for example, also acted in 1994 to head off inflation before it took root, it started at a time when monetary policy was far looser than it is today. The Fed funds rate stood at just 3 percent when, in February 1994, the central bank made the first of seven increases that over the course of a year doubled the rate to 6 percent.
The Fed's immediate goal this time around is not so much to squelch inflation, because there is almost no inflation, as it is to head off the forces that can create inflation. Although a rebound in oil prices has helped push the Consumer Price Index up somewhat this year, the one-month spike in April of seven-tenths of a percent is now widely viewed as an aberration, and by most measures prices remained stable last month.
"For the time being, inflation remains exceptionally quiescent, with the year-over-year increase in consumer prices, excluding food and energy, falling to 2.1 percent, the lowest rate in more than 30 years," economists at Goldman, Sachs told clients in a report this week.
The Fed's somewhat more nebulous target is demand for goods and services, which has been running at consistently robust levels. In the view of most Fed officials, the combination of strong demand growth and extremely low unemployment is potentially combustible. Left unchecked, they say, strong demand will force companies to bid up wages to find the employees they need in a dwindling pool of available workers -- and rising wages could ultimately lead companies to raise prices, setting off an inflationary spiral.
But the trick for the Fed will be to temper demand without setting off a destabilizing rout on Wall Street, where ever-higher stock prices have left many consumers feeling flush and willing to spend. And the Fed will have to act in the face of opposition from some members of both parties who say the central bank is sacrificing jobs and wage increases in pursuit of a problem that does not exist.
"If we make policy on the basis of the fear of inflation, we will inevitably forgo the very benefits that have been so crucially important to working families these last three years," John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., told a news conference on Capitol Hill today.
One way that Fed officials and economists generally are framing the debate is to compare the economy and monetary policy last summer to conditions today.
Last summer, before the global financial crisis became acute and began threatening markets in the United States, the Fed's benchmark Federal funds target rate stood at 5.5 percent -- three-quarters of a percentage point higher than today's -- and the central bank was leaning toward pushing rates higher. Only the need to stabilize markets at home and around the world led the Fed to reverse policy and cut rates three times in the fall in quarter-point increments.
Now, with the global crisis apparently past and demand from both Europe and Japan likely to pick up, one camp of economists makes the case that if a Fed funds rate of 5.5 percent or higher was appropriate last summer, it is appropriate now.
After all, unemployment, which was 4.5 percent last August, has declined to 4.2 percent. Growth in gross domestic product, which was 3.7 percent in the summer quarter last year, jumped to 6 percent later in the year and remained a torrid 4.1 percent in this year's first quarter. And the Dow Jones industrial average, which stood at around 8,500 just before the financial crisis flared last August, closed today at 10,534.83, a jump of nearly 24 percent.
John H. Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, said a series of rate increases now could be seen as a continuation of a tightening policy that began not last summer but as far back as March 1997, when the Fed pushed rates up by a quarter-point, to 5.5 percent. Only the initial outbreak of the Asian crisis in the summer of 1997 and the steady spread of financial problems around the world the next year, he said, kept the Fed from tightening further in that period.
"This string of unprecedented financial shocks can be viewed as an interruption in a Fed process of tightening in response to strong U.S. demand growth initiated over two years ago," Mr. Makin said in a recent report. "Given that it was on track to tighten in spring 1997, the Fed would be reasonable to contemplate taking back the 75 basis points of easing last fall in response to systemic risk."
But another group of economists, influenced in part by Mr. Greenspan, points out that the economy today is not the same as last summer's -- that the most significant changes since then are an increase in the growth of productivity, or output for each hour worked, and a deceleration in the pace of wage increases despite the declining unemployment rate.
Both factors suggest that the economy is less inflation prone than it was last summer. The rise in productivity means companies can offset cost increases with improved efficiency rather than price increases. And the drop-off in wage growth suggests that workers are not using the leverage of a tight labor market to win big raises, possibly because of a deeply ingrained fear that they could lose their jobs to global competition and possibly because employers are compensating workers with performance-based bonuses.
"There's less skepticism now than last summer about the favorable inflation outlook," Mr. Glassman said. "The more we see what's happening around the globe, and the more we see what's happening with productivity, the more open-minded people are about the economy's ability to sustain low inflation. That argues that the Fed does not have to push rates back up to where they were."
Mr. Greenspan made clear in his Congressional testimony last week that his primary concern is not the heady level of the stock market, as worrisome as that is to him, but the possible effect of continued strong domestic demand on wages.
But it is difficult to make an ironclad case these days that rising wages will lead to a general increase in prices. So far, productivity gains have more than offset rising wages and other costs. The problem, as Mr. Greenspan has noted repeatedly, is that policy makers cannot count on productivity growth to continue to improve forever. At some point, the productivity growth rate could level off, or wage growth could accelerate, and the seeds of inflation would then take root in the form of rising cost structures within companies.
Yet even if that happens, it is by no means certain that companies will be able to pass on their higher costs to consumers because competition is so intense that producers have proved to be willing to give up profits to maintain or gain market share.
Moreover, there is little evidence of any acceleration in wage increases in the first place.
"The pressure on labor costs is milder than we thought it would be, despite the fact that the economy is stronger," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities in New York.
Mr. Rippe said there were other reasons why the Fed was unlikely to raise rates aggressively the rest of the year. The domestic economy is already showing some tentative signs of slowing.
While the global crisis appears past, the recoveries in many countries are fragile and could be hurt by higher rates in the United States. And Mr. Rippe said the Fed would like to avoid driving the value of the dollar higher, which would be likely if interest rates in the United States rose substantially. While a stronger dollar would help contain inflation by holding down import prices, it could also lead to a further expansion of the trade deficit, which is not yet a major problem but could ultimately become one.

HEADLINE: Student Strike in Capital Jarring All of Mexico

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 24

 BODY:
The student strike at Mexico's biggest university began on April 20 as a protest against a plan by the administration to make those who could afford it pay tuition.
Seven long weeks later, the university's president, Francisco Barnes de Castro, admitted defeat and agreed to make all tuition payments voluntary. 
 Most people thought that would put an end to the protests, but to the shock of the administration, the strikers at the National Autonomous University of Mexico, the largest institution of higher education in Latin America, were still not satisfied.
The strike, which closed down classrooms for 270,000 students, is now in its third month and shows no sign of moving towards resolution. Mobilizations for and against it have spilled over from the campus into the streets of the capital city. The strike movement has escaped the control of national political and intellectual leaders.
A sizable core of angry students are seeking to use the strike to gain new power within the university and resist Mexico's decade-old shift away from a costly welfare state towards lean government and private enterprise. Many of Mexico's most prominent scholars, however, have turned against the shutdown and warned that it could permanently cripple the university.
Today President Ernesto Zedillo made it clear that the strike at the university, known by its Spanish initials as the U.N.A.M., has become a pressing national concern. He called it "brutal aggression" against the university that is "hurting the enormous majority who want to study to get ahead." But Mr. Zedillo said he would continue to support the administration in seeking to solve the strike peacefully.
Mr. Barnes's original plan was to require U.N.A.M. students with economic means to pay about $150 tuition for a year. The current fees amount to only a few cents. But even though a governing council at the university voted to cancel any obligatory tuition payments, the strikers refused to lift the shutdown until all fees were eliminated. Many financially-strapped departments collect small fees for the use of laboratories and computers.
The strikers are also demanding elimination of recently-instituted admission and graduation examinations, and lifting of the limits on the time students can remain enrolled before graduating. They also want to restore automatic admission for students from a network of high schools linked to the U.N.A.M., which was canceled in 1995.
Their most ambitious demand is to convene a congress to "refound" the U.N.A.M., giving students equal power in decisions with the administration and faculty.
"For us, education is not a commercial service -- it is one of the social rights we won in Mexico over the last decades," said Higinio Munoz, a science major who is a spokesman for the students' strike committee. "Now the Government wants to take that away from us with a stroke of the pen."
Both sides resorted this week to public displays of strength. On Wednesday some 15,000 high-spirited strikers, many with their faces grease-painted in the red and black strike colors, broke into the university stadium and held a rally to proclaim their determination to continue the shutdown.
At one point two dozen young men stood up in a chorus line in the bleachers, each with a letter painted on his naked chest forming the words "Long live the strike!" They raised a frenzy of approval when they turned around, spelling a vulgar insult to the mother of the university president, Mr. Barnes.
Also on Wednesday a group of faculty women at the university hung banners from overpasses on a major highway through the capital, calling on drivers to turn on their headlights if they opposed the strike. Thousands of cars lit up.
This morning another student crowd, slightly smaller and more heavily middle class than the crowd of strikers, turned out in a central plaza downtown to call for the strike to end.
"We have already done our part," Mr. Barnes told them in a resolute speech. "We already reached the agreements that could end this conflict. There are no more excuses. The strike has got to stop."
In a communique marking the end of two months of the strike on June 22, the protest leaders laid out their worldview, at once cocky and defensive. They described Mr. Barnes and the Mexican Government as tools of a campaign by global organizations like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to destroy public education in Mexico.
They accused the administration of building a "repressive police apparatus" within the U.N.A.M., pointing to a network of video cameras recently installed around the campus. Administration officials said the cameras were to help combat the wave of common crime which has swept the capital city.
The strike has become a problem for Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, the left-of-center opposition Mayor of Mexico City, who is expected to run for president in national elections next year.
At first, leaders of Mr. Cardenas's Party of the Democratic Revolution, several of whom were once student activists themselves, openly supported the strike, although they denied that they aided it with resources from the city government.
But on June 10 the strikers, led by some of their most militant leaders, went outside the U.N.A.M. campus in street marches that snarled traffic for hours on several of Mexico City's busiest thoroughfares. Many city residents, already skeptical about the strike, were furious at Mr. Cardenas, believing that he encouraged the disruption.
Mr. Cardenas and other leaders of his party seem to have lost the influence over the strikers they once enjoyed. Increasingly, the huge all-night assemblies where the students decide their moves have been dominated by activists from small socialist groups, dubbed "ultras" by other students within the strike movement.
Thousands of students continued their studies in off-campus classrooms.
University officials said that at least 162,500 students, or about 65 percent of the undergraduates, were able to complete their work for the semester.
