HEADLINE: Some Doctors See Relief In Plan for A.M.A. Union

BYLINE: By EMILY YELLIN 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, June 24

 BODY:
The weekly managers' meetings at the Family Physicians Group, a private practice here, almost always include a lot of angry discussion about the increasing frustrations of dealing with health maintenance organizations and other managed-care insurance companies.
But at this morning's meeting, the anger was tempered by hope, said Dr. Charles J. Woodall, the group's medical director, in light of the American Medical Association's decision on Wednesday to form a union for doctors. 
 Doctors have long been hamstrung "by managed-care regulations that require needless procedures and don't cover useful procedures," Dr. Woodall said. "So I am quite pleased that the A.M.A. has taken it upon themselves to bring these problems to the forefront."
None of the doctors in his group could join an A.M.A. union because they do not work for health maintenance organizations or hospitals.
But Dr. Woodall said the A.M.A. move signaled a push by doctors across the country to address growing feelings of helplessness in the face of managed-care restrictions on services doctors are permitted to provide, and the accompanying paperwork the companies require for simple procedures. In the past five years, he said, his group of 15 doctors has hired 42 employees who deal solely with the paperwork required by managed-care companies.
Dr. Woodall said of the A.M.A.'s decision, "It's a start, and the fact that the A.M.A., a credible national organization, has stepped in shows that these are far-reaching problems which don't just affect doctors in larger cities and larger states, but now affect doctors in places like Memphis and rural Tennessee and Mississippi."
Barry Levine, 59, an internist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, also supported the A.M.A. "We're fighting to control the control that the insurance companies have over us," he said. "We really do need some representation, or it's going to be the M.B.A. types who are telling us how to practice medicine."
But not all doctors interviewed today agreed that a union would solve their problems.
"I don't think the unions are the prescription," said E. William Rosenberg, 69, a Memphis dermatologist and professor of medicine at the University of Tennessee medical school. "I don't think the unions are the illness either. I think they're a symptom of the changing economics of medical care. And while I'm not opposed to them, I don't think they are the answer."
Jack Needleman, an assistant professor of economics and health policy at the Harvard School of Public Health, also questioned unionization.
"I see the unionization push as a first-cut response to a very real set of problems for the profession in terms of economic power," Dr. Needleman said. "It just doesn't feel to me like it will be ultimately the response that prevails."
In California, where doctors' unions have long been in place, Charles Goodman, 40, a pediatrician in private practice in the West Hills section of Los Angeles, joined the Union of American Physicians and Dentists, a 6,000-member division of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, about one and a half years ago.
"It has been a good idea for me and a direct help for many of my patients as well," Dr. Goodman said.
As with roughly two-thirds of the 620,000 practicing physicians in the nation, the A.M.A. union will not be able to bargain on Dr. Goodman's behalf because he is in private practice and bargaining for him would violate antitrust laws. But he said his union had helped him and his patients in other ways.
"If I have a problem with an H.M.O., I can ask a union to step up to bat for me," he said. "When the union calls, the H.M.O.'s take it a little more seriously. It gives you more clout than if you were alone against these enormous multibillion-dollar companies."
As a fourth-year resident at the University of Tennessee Medical Center in Memphis, Cindy Woodall would qualify for membership in an A.M.A. union.
"I am learning to be a doctor in this world of managed care, and it has kind of burst my bubble to see how it works against the patients," Dr. Woodall said. "So if a union could address that and help us provide better care for our patients, then I would definitely want to join."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Courtroom Testimony Ends In Microsoft Antitrust Case
The heated accusations of monopoly, the lively E-mail flavored with capitalist aggression and the spirited testimony alleging and denying misconduct came to a close as the last witness stepped off the stand in Microsoft's antitrust trial, eight months after proceedings began.
The Government argues that it has more than proved its case, but Microsoft, while conceding that the Justice Department put on an impressive performance, says the facts do not add up to a violation of antitrust rules. The legal reckoning that matters, however, will be made by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who will rule without a jury. Page A1.
 
A Government lawyer introduced as evidence a comment by William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, that knocked the legs out from under his legal team's most important defensive strategy. C4.
 
Unraveling Mystery in Fraud Case
The story of Martin R. Frankel begins in Toledo, Ohio, and goes through the South and into Connecticut, where his trail disappears. He is suspected of looting insurance companies of $335 million, wiring the money abroad and leaving behind notes that show he was seeking a foreign country that does not have an extradition treaty with the United States. A1.
 
Rumors Swirling on Internet Deals
A recent spate of rumored Internet combinations shows the menagerie of potential products and deals that companies and investors must face to find a few that might pay off someday. Compaq Computer confirmed that it was interested in trading its Alta Vista Internet service for stock in CMGI. The computer maker Gateway declined to comment on speculation that it would buy Earthlink, an Internet service. And those rumors forced Mindspring, another Internet service, to publish a cryptic statement that it was in talks about possible combinations. Market Place. C9.
 
Morgan Stanley Beats Forecasts
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, demonstrating strength in its securities trading and credit card businesses, posted second-quarter results that beat analysts' expectations. C3.
 
Interest Rates Push Stocks Lower
Stocks tumbled as long-term interest rates jumped. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 132.03 points, or 1.24 percent, to 10,534.83. The Nasdaq composite index fell 44.13 points, or 1.7 percent, to 2,553.99, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 17.28 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,315.78. C9.
 
Pearson to Sell Lazard Holdings
The British media company Pearson said that it was selling its holdings in three Lazard investment houses in a deal that analysts said would enable both Pearson and Lazard to become more competitive by focusing more closely on their primary businesses. C2.
 
New Editor at Harper's Bazaar
Katherine Betts, left, the fashion news director at Conde Nast's Vogue, who was the heir apparent to Anna Wintour, resigned and will take over as editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar on Sept. 1. The announcement ends months of speculation in the notoriously gossipy magazine world about whom Cathleen P. Black, the president of Hearst Magazines, would choose as editor. C3.
 
Film and TV Work Moving Overseas
About 27 percent of American movies and TV series made last year were filmed outside the United States to save money, costing the nation the equivalent of 23,500 full-time jobs and more than $10 billion, according to a study by two Hollywood unions. C7.
 
American Airlines Under Scrutiny
Federal safety officials plan to investigate why American Airlines has had more accidents in the last six years than any other major domestic carrier. A16.
 
Orders for Durable Goods Up 1.4%
Orders placed with factories for durable goods increased 1.4 percent in May, the second rise in three months, further evidence that manufacturing is pulling out of last year's slump, Government figures showed. C3.

HEADLINE: $19.5 Billion Budget Set By Lawmakers in Trenton

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 24

 BODY:
Blessed with a robust economy and more than $450 million in unexpected revenues, the New Jersey Legislature today approved a $19.5 billion budget that provides modest property tax rebates, increases school spending and sets aside $98 million in state funds to preserve open space.
The budget, which was passed with relative ease, contains $358 million in additional spending over what Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed in January. It is 7.7 percent higher than the budget signed into law last July, but also includes a $778 million surplus, an increase over last year's $700 million surplus. 
 The Governor is expected to use her line-item veto to cut some of the $60 million in pet projects added by legislators and then sign the measure into law by the time the new fiscal year begins July 1.
"This has been a very collegial budgeting process, so I expect there will be very little use of the red pen," said Peter McDonough, the Governor's communications director. "But there will be some cuts."
Approval of the spending plan is the last significant action the Legislature is expected to take before beginning the summer recess next week. And while the Legislature will reconvene in September, lawmakers are unlikely to tackle any divisive issues until after the November elections, when all 80 members of the General Assembly face re-election.
The timely and relatively orderly passage of the budget comes in sharp contrast to the situation in Albany, where a standoff between Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Democrats has left the budget 85 days overdue with no resolution in sight.
The New Jersey State Constitution requires that legislators pass a balanced budget by the end of the fiscal year -- June 30 -- or face the dire political consequences of shutting down the government and laying off state workers. Unlike their counterparts in Albany, Trenton lawmakers have rarely missed that deadline in recent years and have been reluctant to use emergency spending bills to skirt a budget impasse and avert a shutdown.
The approval of New Jersey's budget marks the unofficial end of a turbulent legislative season in which lawmakers deregulated the state's $9 billion energy market and passed the first significant restrictions on abortion rights in New Jersey in nearly two decades.
Both the Senate and the General Assembly today gave final approval to the abortion measure, which requires parents to be notified before a girl under 18 can have an abortion. The Governor has said she intends to sign it into law. A co-sponsor of the parental notification bill, John E. Rooney, said the measure would help Republican Assembly candidates win votes from conservatives in November because it showed a concern for New Jersey families.
Despite a flurry of public pressure for gun control in the two months since the high school massacre in Littleton, Colo., legislators blunted an attempt to make New Jersey the first state to mandate that all handguns be equipped with computer chips that prevent them from operating for anyone but their owners.
Asserting that the so-called smart gun technology is not yet available, Republican legislative leaders have instead put forward compromise proposals to require trigger locks on all handguns and to encourage the development of smart guns without legally requiring them.
But the most dramatic and contentious debate of the session surrounded the Senate's confirmation vote on Governor Whitman's nominee to the State Supreme Court, former Attorney General Peter J. Verniero. For weeks, Democrats criticized the Governor's selection, saying that Mr. Verniero lacked the judicial experience. During two days of rancorous public hearings, Democratic Senators bitterly criticized Mr. Verniero for what they contended was his failure over two years to investigate complaints of systemic racial discrimination by state troopers.
After a furious lobbying campaign, Republicans rallied behind the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, and Mr. Verniero won approval by the narrowest of margins and without a single Democratic vote.
Governor Whitman today congratulated legislators on the budget and said she was gratified that the plan would help reduce local property taxes by providing $6.4 billion in school aid, an increase of $457 million. It will also grant $1.9 billion in municipal aid to New Jersey's local governments, including $40.5 million in emergency funds for the troubled cities of Camden, Jersey City, East Orange, Irvington and Paterson.
Lawmakers also set aside $6 million to pay for prenatal hospital care for immigrant mothers whose babies become United States citizens and dedicated $21 million to upgrade the firearms used by New Jersey State Troopers.
The biggest new expense is Governor Whitman's $170 million property tax rebate program, called New Jersey Saver, which will save homeowners an average of $120 this year. The program is scheduled to grow to $1 billion per year by 2004 and eventually offer homeowners a $600 annual rebate. But some Democratic leaders, voicing themes they are likely to repeat on the campaign trail, said they opposed the plan because it did not cut property taxes nearly enough.
Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Democratic minority leader, said that even with the rebate, New Jersey had the highest property taxes in the country. Assemblyman Joseph Charles Jr. said the $170 million reduction was insufficient because last year alone, New Jersey's property tax levy increased by $460 million.
"Our property taxpayers are being buried under an avalanche and this administration is tossing them a teaspoon to dig their way out," said Mr. Charles, of Jersey City, who voted against the plan.

HEADLINE: City Board Approves Increases for Rent-Stabilized Apartments

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted 5 to 4 last night to approve a 2 percent increase for one-year leases and a 4 percent increase for two-year leases on rent-stabilized apartments, the same increases approved for four of the last five years.
The board sets rent increases for the approximately one million New York City apartments in buildings operating under rent stabilization, whose rules date back to 1943. 
 The vote by the board reflects a staff recommendation in May for 2 to 4 percent increases, which are tied to the Price Index of Operating Costs, a landlord price index compiled by the city. That measure, which reflects costs like heating oil, was 0.03 percent last year, down from 0.13 percent in 1997. Landlords criticize the index because they say it does not reflect long-term costs.
The meeting began with a protracted debate among board members, who include two landlord representatives and two tenant representatives, and was punctuated by the jeering of tenant advocates, who made up the majority of the hundred or so audience members and continually yelled, "Jerk," "Sleazy," and "You're insane!"
Edward S. Hochman, 46, the chairman of the rent guidelines board, expressed frustration with both the debate and the loud protest.
"The numbers legitimately made for a narrow range," Mr. Hochman said in an interview during a recess, referring to the landlord price index. "It was never going to go below 0 and never go above 2 percent for one-year leases, and never go below 1 and never go above 4 percent for two years. But tonight was like the Battle of Stalingrad, where the battle loses any real military purpose."
Mr. Hochman requested that two police officers stand at attention in front of the stage at the Grand Hall of Cooper Union and had a third officer circulate through the audience to request quiet.
Vincent S. Castellano, 37, a landlord and real estate broker from the Rockaways, in Queens, who is one of two landlord representatives on the board, said, "If you can't raise rents when economic times are good, when tenants are working, when income is going up, then when would you suggest we raise rents?"
Mr. Castellano cited city statistics that 116,000 jobs were created last year and personal income, adjusted for inflation, rose 3.5 percent. Meanwhile, apartment buildings continue to age, repairs continue to mount and become more expensive and the city government continues to impose new requirements, like fire sprinklers and removal of lead paint, he said.
David D. Pagan, 55, a tenant representative on the board and an administrator at the Southside United Housing Development Fund Corporation in Brooklyn, said the board vote was "extremely disappointing." He said the landlord price index was "next to nothing, and we were willing to give a little on the second year." He had proposed a 0 percent increase for one-year leases and 1.8 percent for two-year leases.

HEADLINE: Medicare Drug Plan Worries Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Medicare officials said today that they had told the White House that its initial hope of offering coverage of prescription drugs for a premium of no more than $25 a month was unrealistic.
At the same time, House Democrats said they had become nervous about the plan being drafted by President Clinton to revamp Medicare, because they feared that the prospect of higher premiums could alarm elderly voters. 
 Medicare generally does not cover prescription drugs for people outside the hospital, even though elderly people fill an average of 18 prescriptions a year.
Federal health officials and actuaries who work for the Medicare program said the premium for new drug benefits would have to be at least as high as the existing premium for coverage of doctors' services, $45.50 a month.
House Democrats said they worried about being drawn into an election-year battle over details of the Medicare plan that Mr. Clinton intends to announce next week.
Senior House Democrats conveyed their concerns to John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, at a meeting on Wednesday night in the office of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader. And they elaborated on their concerns in interviews today.
The lawmakers said they were frustrated at their inability to confirm details of the plan, even though they would be expected to defend it.
The gist of the Democrats' message, as described by one lawmaker, was: "Don't make us walk a plank that will blow up on us."
To date, White House officials have refused to rule out the idea of charging higher Medicare premiums to high-income beneficiaries. House Democrats said they had told Mr. Podesta that the President would be courting political disaster if he proposed "income-related premiums."
They said that such a proposal reminded them, and could remind many elderly voters, of the surtax that Congress adopted in 1988 as part of a bill to provide catastrophic health insurance coverage under Medicare. It provoked such an outcry from the elderly that it was repealed a year later.
Mr. Podesta and Gene Sperling, assistant to the President for economic policy, asked for the new cost estimates, which were prepared by Medicare actuaries led by Richard S. Foster, the chief actuary of the Health Care Financing Administration. The actuaries have sent many spreadsheets and tables to the White House in the last 10 days.
Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, said the House Democrats had told the White House that Mr. Clinton's proposal, if not carefully designed, could create a ripe political target for Republicans and could damage Vice President Al Gore's Presidential hopes.
Our message to the White House was, 'Don't sell us out,' " Mr. Stark said. "I have heard from people inside the Administration, including high-level health-policy makers, who worry that the President will cut a deal with the Republicans on Medicare in October."
Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, said: "If the President provides too many specifics, he will simply give the Republicans ammunition for an endless battle over the future of Medicare. That would be wasteful and stupid."
Since the President returned to the United States from Europe early Wednesday, White House aides have been scrambling to get his approval for details of his Medicare plan.
Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary, said today that Mr. Clinton would announce his proposals next week even though there still remained several unresolved questions about the financing and the scope of benefits. Asked if the President's plan would be "comprehensive," Mr. Lockhart declined to characterize it that way.
Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut, said, "I was delighted that Mr. Podesta came up to solicit our views, and I expressed my opinion that Medicare should not be means-tested in any way."
Likewise, Representative Jan Schakowsky, Democrat of Illinois, said, "The President's Medicare plan must not include premiums based on income, and must not increase out-of-pocket costs for seniors."
Ms. Schakowsky, a former director of the Illinois State Council of Senior Citizens, said she told Mr. Podesta: "Don't do it. It's bad policy, and it's very bad politics."
In 1989, elderly people from Ms. Schakowsky's group jeered Dan Rostenkowksi, then a Democratic Congressman from Illinois who was chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, because they held him responsible for the surtax, or "supplemental premium," that was to have financed prescription drug coverage for about one-sixth of Medicare's beneficiaries.
In the Senate, William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that he intended to move Medicare legislation through his committee this fall.
"He wants to put together a bipartisan Medicare bill," said Ginny Flynn, a spokeswoman for Mr. Roth. "He wants to include a drug benefit for the sickest elderly and for low-income elderly people."

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 709 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Slaves, Stay Out

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Very quietly, without a word about it on paper, the United Nations is creating a new human rights policy for the organization and putting it into operation one step at a time.
If it were a document, honestly and clearly written, it would read so: 
 "The U.N. will honor and from time to time try to uphold the human rights of oppressed countries and peoples -- provided that they have reasonable power of their own or effective help of nations with economic and military strength. If not, the U.N. will not be of use to victim-nations, and in some cases will increase the power of the oppressor."
In the past week alone, while still pondering the lessons of the war over Kosovo, the beneficiary of all-out Western support, the U.N. used its power against the interests of two of the most persecuted, isolated and abandoned peoples on earth -- one Asian, the other African.
In Washington, the World Bank, a U.N. agency that distributes low-interest loans to countries desperately in need of money for health care, food and water supplies and other causes, approved another loan to China, this one of $160 million.
Stated purpose: to help Chinese in particularly poor districts, and to move some of them to areas where they might live better. Of the 58,000 who would be moved, at a cost of $40 million, all would go from China to Tibet, the Qinghai area.
This infuriated supporters of Tibet and set off a dispute in the bank, headed by James D. Wolfensohn, a much-respected man in Washington.
Americans can take pride that the U.S. voted against the loan, joined only by Germany in the 24-nation bank board. The loan is the deliberate use of U.N. money that will speed the steady increase of the Chinese population of Tibet since the Chinese Communist invasion in 1949.
It is also a judgment that the occupation is permanent, worthy of international U.N. support. And it is one more shackle to the work of the Dalai Lama, since he fled Tibet in 1959, to keep Tibetan nationhood and religion strong in his people's hopes.
Tibet is claimed in its entirety by Beijing -- despite 3,500 years as a nation broken by a total of 400 years of domination by China, Mongolia and Britain.
No country except India, where he lives in refuge, has helped the Dalai Lama. By world leaders, Tibet is mentioned only for brief spurts of hypocrisy.
But enough people of good heart raised so much protest about the loan helping China occupy Tibet that the World Bank ordered an "inquiry" before the $40 million is actually spent. Mr. Wolfensohn said that the project would be entirely "transparent."
The delay does not satisfy Tibet's supporters, at all. But at least the protests tell Tibetans they are not alone, not entirely.
In Africa, a U.N. human rights committee removed voice and representation from Sudanese who have been defending themselves against their own Government. Khartoum is carrying out a civil and religious war aimed largely at Sudanese Christians and followers of native African religions.
The committee refused to hear the appeal of the resistance leader, John Garang. The offense was writing his request on his letterhead instead of the stationery of Christian Solidarity International, his sponsor for the meeting. Then the organization was disaccredited.
The Swiss-based group had the status of "non-governmental organization" at the U.N. Hundreds of such help organizations, each with a specialization in fields like medical relief, human rights, the welfare of children and aid to refugees, have a forum at the U.N. They are allowed to speak, but not vote, at specified U.N. committees or the special agencies that supervise U.N. action and spending in world health, banking, agriculture, aviation and other major U.N. fields.
Christian Solidarity International was impudent enough to prove the existence of slavery in Sudan by buying 1,000 people, and of course setting them free. By disaccrediting the organization the "human rights" committee established the penalty of ouster for incurably forthright groups, and for itself the punishment of infamy.
If allowed to stand, the decisions on Tibet and the Sudanese resistance will live on as a U.N. message to nations weak, isolated and persecuted: Slaves, stay out.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 4205 words

HEADLINE: A FUGITIVE'S PATH:A special report.;
Phantom Insurance Empire Yields Puzzles (and $335 Million Loss)

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN; Contributing to this report were: David Barboza, Bill Dedman, Kurt Eichenwald, Katherine E. Finkelstein, Alessandra Stanley and Joseph B. Treaster.

 BODY:
On April 28, with the sun setting outside their elegant Hilton Hotel conference suite in downtown Jackson, Miss., the key figures in what was, on paper, a vast philanthropic and insurance empire gathered together for the first and last time.
Those present included two Tennesseans who managed the Franklin American Corporation, operator of a string of insurance companies in five states. Also attending, after a long flight from Rome, were two elderly Roman Catholic priests representing the charitable foundation that owned the Franklin company. 
 The guest of honor, and the man who controlled the empire, was a pasty 44-year-old who variously introduced himself as a genius bond trader, a multimillionaire and an amateur student of Catholic theology. They had known him by different names -- including Eric Stevens and David Rosse -- but his real name was Martin R. Frankel. That day, he appeared in person for the first time to many people in the room.
None of the people at that meeting would ever see him again. Soon after that glimpse behind the curtain, Mr. Frankel's mystique, like that of the Wizard of Oz, melted away.
Mr. Frankel did not show up the next day when the group met Mississippi regulators in an attempt to persuade them that the companies' books were in order.
Days later, Federal prosecutors said in court records, Mr. Frankel wired as much as $334.6 million in insurance company money from Franklin American to foreign bank accounts, burned documents in one of his several mansions in Greenwich, Conn., and fled. He left behind notes that show he was researching which foreign countries have no extradition treaties with the United States.
Investigators suspect that Mr. Frankel looted at least seven insurance companies in several states of money they had given him to invest. While no charges have been brought against him, a warrant has been issued for his arrest in what the authorities believe is one of the largest insurance frauds in history.
Mr. Frankel also left behind a trail of questions that the authorities are still trying to answer. Why did so many people ignore what appeared, in hindsight, to be clear signals of fraud? Were the people who gathered at the Hilton unwitting dupes, as they or their lawyers now maintain, or did they have some inkling of what was going on? And, finally, where is Mr. Frankel?
Those mysteries will not be solved any time soon. But what does emerge from court documents and interviews with friends, business partners and neighbors is a picture of Mr. Frankel as a brazen but wily con man, a master puppeteer whose dealings spanned the globe, from Franklin, Tenn., to rarefied Lake Avenue in Greenwich, to the British Virgin Islands and the Vatican.
He began defrauding investors at least a decade ago and the authorities suspect he never stopped. Although he was investigated once, in 1991, by the Securities and Exchange Commission and agreed not to associate himself with the securities business again, he promptly disregarded that ban. And as he expanded his business reach, he drew in more and more characters.
His main and most recent target appeared to be the Vatican. Born to a middle-class family in Toledo, Ohio, he at times portrayed himself as a Jew interested in Catholicism. He flattered Catholic elites on both sides of the Atlantic and promised millions for Catholic charities to get into the good graces of the church hierarchy. He courted prominent Catholics, offering them trips on his private jet or tickets on the supersonic Concorde.
Perhaps most spectacularly, Mr. Frankel persuaded Msgr. Emilio Colagiovanni, who edits a Rome-based journal on canon law, to sign a sworn statement indicating that the Holy See financed and stood four-square behind an organization Mr. Frankel headed. Monsignor Colagiovanni acknowledged in an interview in Rome today that the statement was "misleading," but denied he had engaged in any wrongdoing or knew anything about the fraud.
In any case, the affidavit helped persuade the prominent law firm of Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld to continue representing the foundation. The foundation hired the firm after it was introduced to its most famous partner, Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic national chairman and former ambassador to the Soviet Union. Over time, the firm collected several hundred thousand dollars in fees working on possible acquisitions of insurance companies, none of which came to pass, according to a person who has reviewed the billings.
"Hundreds of people were conned by Marty Frankel, Eric Stevens, David Rosse -- whatever his name was," said Aubrey B. Harwell Jr., a Nashville lawyer who represents the two Tennessee businessmen who attended the April 28 meeting. "It's a classic Ponzi scheme."
There were plenty of red flags. Mr. Frankel mixed and matched his aliases so boldly that guests at his dinner parties in Greenwich sometimes knew him by different names. His intermingling of charity and commerce was befuddling to many who dealt with him. He bestowed gifts on friends so lavishly that many said they considered him reckless with his money, as if it did not belong to him.
Mr. Frankel also led an eccentric, even dark, personal life. He turned his luxury Greenwich estate into a fortress, traveled with a bevy of bodyguards when visiting his hometown. He met and lived with several women he found by trolling the Internet and scouring personal ads, according to a statement he gave Greenwich police after a woman was found hanged at one of his Connecticut homes in 1997.
 
The Childhood
A Prodigy Falls For Wall Street
Martin Richard Frankel was born on Nov. 21, 1954, into a middle-class family of lawyers and public servants. His father, Leon, worked as a referee at a domestic relations court in Toledo, and his mother, Tillie, was a clerk in the Toledo city government.
Marty, as he was known, was the youngest of four children. By all accounts, he was a bright youngster, even brilliant, friends say. Almost 6 feet tall, Mr. Frankel was thin, weighing 135 pounds, and, friends say, awkward and introverted.
"He didn't have many friends when he was growing up," said Bradford Dolgin, who attended Whitmer High School with Mr. Frankel. "He was pretty eccentric."
His political views were left-wing and unconventional, one faculty member recalled.
For all his high intelligence, though, friends and faculty members say Mr. Frankel had trouble finishing what he started. He seemed to have a phobia about taking exams, and rarely turned in class papers, they said.
He graduated from high school in three years, near the top of his class. But despite taking college courses at the University of Toledo in the late 1970's and early 1980's, he never earned a degree. His academic record is under privacy seal, at his request, according to the school's registrar.
It was during his college years that Mr. Frankel fell in love with Wall Street. No one knows exactly what touched off his interest in investments, but Mr. Frankel's passion for things financial soon became all-consuming.
"Marty was kind of a jack of all trades, master of none," said George J. Windau, a college friend of Mr. Frankel. "And then he became a master of one: the stock market, commodities, currencies."
He became a day trader, rapidly buying and selling stocks, often many times a day.
He took his first professional crack at the securities business at the Toledo branch of a New York brokerage firm, Dominick & Dominick. And he soon plunged into controversy. Details are sketchy, but John Schulte, who headed the branch, says that he dismissed Mr. Frankel in 1987 for failing "to produce."
Other tensions emerged between Mr. Schulte and Mr. Frankel. Mr. Schulte said his marriage with his wife, Sonia, fell apart and she began a long relationship with Mr. Frankel. According to police records, the three at times tussled over allowing Mr. Schulte time to visit his two daughters.
Those confrontations, friends say, caused Mr. Frankel to grow increasingly fearful that Mr. Schulte would retaliate against him. It was, some friends believe, one reason he left Toledo and turned to aliases.
Even before he left, friends and neighbors say he began to install security equipment at home and hired a man named David Rosse, who would later travel with him to Greenwich as his security guard and whose name Mr. Frankel would appropriate as his own.
When Mr. Frankel returned home last November for the funeral of his father, who died at the age of 87, he came with a small army of security guards. "It was like something out of a Mafia movie," Jon Frankel, a relative, told The Toledo Blade.
 
Early Failure
An Agreement to Stay Away From Securities
 By the late 1980's, Mr. Frankel had struck out on his own, setting up a money management firm he called Frankel Fund, which he operated from a room in his parents' home..
As the fund grew, he moved to West Palm Beach, Fla., seeking to strengthen his business with retirees. Friends say that he moved at the suggestion of Douglas I. Maxwell, a Tennessee man who formed a partnership with Mr. Frankel called PDS Securities Inc. The partnership raised at least $1 million for the Frankel Fund, according to securities regulators.
Jeff Creamer, the lawyer for two Ohio retirees who sued Mr. Frankel, said he boasted of living an extravagant life and of having attracted a Romanian queen and the king of Yugoslavia as investors. "He was a kind of Woody Allen character, kind of goofy," Mr. Creamer recalled. "It's kind of disarming."
But the venture did not last long. At least one of Mr. Frankel's clients raised questions and soon Mr. Frankel was back in Toledo, telling investors that his partner, Mr. Maxwell, had bungled their investments.
The Securities and Exchange Commission had another view. In 1992, it froze the accounts of the Frankel Fund. In an settlement, Mr. Frankel agreed to stay away from the securities industry forever as punishment for his having lied about the fund's performance, his own experience and even how the proceeds would be used.
The S.E.C. sanction proved to be merely a hiccup in Mr. Frankel's scheming, the authorities now believe.
At the same time the S.E.C. was cracking down on the Frankel Fund, Mr. Frankel was teaming up with John A. Hackney, a Tennessee bank executive, to buy insurance companies. It is an industry that is regulated by the states, not by Federal agencies like the S.E.C. Mr. Frankel appears to have picked as targets small, troubled insurance companies that were vulnerable to embezzlement.
Mr. Frankel and Mr. Hackney did not actually meet until eight years later, in the Mississippi hotel. But over the phone, Mr. Hackney became fast friends with the man he came to know as Eric Stevens, who portrayed himself as an experienced bond trader eager to employ a novel and lucrative trading strategy to improve the returns on insurance company assets, according to Mr. Harwell, Mr. Hackney's lawyer.
The lawyer said that Mr. Hackney was paid a straight salary for managing insurance companies that he bought on Mr. Frankel's behalf and had no other interest in Mr. Frankel's dealings.
Mr. Hackney did agree to steer the insurance companies' investment business to Mr. Frankel's Liberty National Securities.
To make their first acquisition, of the Franklin American Corporation, the two partners set up Thunor Trust, named after the Germanic god of thunder and lightning. Mr. Frankel's name was not associated with the trust, but several acquaintances are identified in state documents as investors who put up the $3.8 million in start-up funds.
They were Sonia Schulte, the Toledo girlfriend; Edward Krauss, a Frankel family friend who now lives in Columbus, Ohio, and Mark C. Shuki, an acquaintance from Chicago. Mr. Krauss said in an interview that he had nothing to do with Thunor and did not willingly lend his name. The others could not be reached for comment. It is unclear where the seed capital actually came from.
Thunor grew rapidly. In half a dozen transactions between 1993 and 1995, it acquired controlling stakes in at least seven insurance companies, including some based in Mississippi, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Missouri.
All of the companies sent their money to be invested by Mr. Frankel through his company, Liberty National. The address sounded impressive, 82 Wall Street, Dept. 1105, but it was just a mail drop. Mr. Harwell said Mr. Hackney was not aware of that fact.
Mr. Frankel's Liberty National appeared to be doing an outstanding job managing Franklin's assets, according to financial statements the securities firm sent to Mr. Hackney. When Franklin needed money back for some reason, Liberty National readily provided it.
"There was every appearance of legitimacy," Mr. Harwell said. They thought Mr. Frankel "was a guru," he said. The companies' statements from Liberty National showed they were earning outsized returns, as much as 25 percent more than average, on simple-sounding investments in United States Government bonds -- performance that would have been remarkable from Wall Street's perspective.
Liberty National was operating from Mr. Frankel's mansion in Greenwich. He moved to the wealthy New York suburb in 1991, around the same time he plunged into the insurance business. According to associates and neighbors, Mr. Frankel converted his home into a full-fledged trading floor, with 80 computers, satellite dishes and direct links to the New York Stock Exchange. He later bought another residence in the area.
But the major splash Mr. Frankel made had little to do with his reputed trading prowess.
One afternoon in August 1997, Arnold Courier, an elderly Greenwich resident, heard a woman's screams echo through Lake Avenue. The commotion seemed to be coming from the home of a reclusive neighbor that he knew as Martin King, another alias for Mr. Frankel.
Soon after, Mr. Courier said, he and other neighbors learned that something horrible had happened at 881 Lake Avenue.
A woman had hanged herself. The police arrived on the scene to find Frances Burge, a heavy-set 22-year-old, lying dead on the ground outside the house.
The death was ruled a suicide. Days later, when the Couriers read about what had happened in the local newspaper, they asked their lawyer, Gregory Saum, to get in contact with the police to tell the story of the chilling screams. Mr. Saum relayed their story to the Drug Enforcement Administration, fearing that the death may have been related to narcotics activity. D.E.A. agents made inquiries, but these did not appear to have led to any action.
The incident is among the many bizarre events that unfolded at the Frankel houses on Lake Avenue throughout much of the 1990's, as Mr. Frankel used the money that the Government now says was stolen to create a lavish life style. Interviews with people who knew him and visited his homes paint a vivid picture of a reclusive and paranoid man, obsessed with his physical safety.
Mr. Frankel turned his properties into armed camps, posting gun-toting guards, and erecting a six-foot metal fence complete with cameras and floodlights perched on top.
But associates also described a man who had trouble meeting women and who scoured the Internet and placed ads in The Village Voice in search of dates. Some of the women who befriended him were from far-flung locations, like Switzerland, Alaska and Russia, the associates said. Several ended up living in Greenwich homes that Mr. Frankel rented for them, for prices ranging from $4,000 to $10,000 a month, according to local real estate agents.
Pornography and sexual fetishes were prominent features of the house. According to police reports, during a search of the house following the death of Ms. Burge, the authorities discovered a leather riding crop, ropes and sadomasochistic literature and videos. Similar items were found by the police in the days following Mr. Frankel's disappearance, along with a number of pornographic videotapes. On the computers scattered about the residence were sexually explicit images downloaded from the Internet, according to people who have seen them.
When the police interviewed him about Ms. Burge's death, he spoke openly about how he found women in personal ads, invited them to his home and often paid them to live with him or nearby. "The girls do not get paid a salary, but I give them money as they need it," he told the police.
To some who knew him, Mr. Frankel seemed odd rather than dangerous. These people described him as a compulsive talker, who flitted from topic to topic, one moment holding forth on astrology and the "cosmos" and the next discussing the intricacies of Greenwich real estate. A compulsively fussy eater, they said he had two live-in chefs who worked around the clock, accommodating his nocturnal schedule and his desire for gourmet food.
But some neighbors said they worried about what was really going on at Mr. Frankel's Lake Avenue residences. The driveway bristled with fleets of BMW's and Mercedes- Benzes, as people traipsed in and out of the Lake Avenue homes 24 hours a day.
Tensions erupted. In one case, when Mr. Frankel's fence cut off a public riding trail, a representative of the Greenwich Riding and Trails Association rang the doorbell at 881 Lake Avenue, only to hear an electronic recorded voice: "Who are you and what do you want?" She fled.
 
The Church
Finding Friends In the Vatican
 Though he was raised Jewish and expressed fervently pro-Israel political views to friends, Mr. Frankel aggressively courted the Catholic Church and the Vatican religious hierarchy beginning last summer.
Accounts of his involvement with Catholic priests and the Vatican differ, but one thing seems certain: Mr. Frankel promised lavish financial contributions to Catholic charities in return for support from their leadership.
Mr. Frankel told the priests he met with that his interests were purely charitable. But from the moment last August when the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation was founded in the British Virgin Islands with the motto "To Serve and Help the Poor and Alleviate Suffering," he used it as a vehicle for business transactions.
It is not clear why. One explanation advanced by associates of Mr. Frankel is that a foundation backed by the Vatican might lend him credibility in buying additional insurance companies that would keep his scheme alive. Others suspect that he may also have seen an advantage to creating another layer between himself and the companies he controlled.
Whatever his motives, he pursued his quarry with ardor. He stacked the shelves of the library in his Greenwich home with Catholic literature, including histories of the saints and papal encyclicals, visitors to his home said. He familiarized himself with the life of St. Francis of Assisi, renowned for helping the poor. He told people he had repeatedly watched the Franco Zefferelli movie about St. Francis.
The books and the knowledge of the saints helped Mr. Frankel win the trust of Thomas A. Bolan, a New York lawyer and supporter of Catholic causes who became a foundation trustee. Mr. Frankel told Mr. Bolan, who was the law partner of the late Roy Cohn, that he planned to give at least $50 million to Catholic charities immediately, and wanted Mr. Bolan's help in arranging an audience with senior Catholic clerics to discuss the gifts, said Mr. Bolan's lawyer, Maurice R. Nessen.
Mr. Bolan introduced Mr. Frankel to another well-connected American Catholic, the Rev. Peter Jacobs, who would also become a trustee of Mr. Frankel's foundation. Mr. Jacobs, despite having had run-ins with the Catholic Church hierarchy in America, had connections in Rome, where he lives in retirement.
It was Mr. Jacobs who introduced Mr. Frankel to his most important religious contact, Monsignor Colagiovanni, 80, who serves as president of the Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation, an educational organization that has ties to the Vatican.
Monsignor Colagiovanni, now retired, had served as a judge on an important church tribunal, the Roman Rota. As president of the Monitor Ecclesiasticus, he served at the behest of the Vatican Curia, or Senate. Vatican officials said there was no connection between the Monitor organization and the Vatican but declined to answer further questions.
Monsignor Colagiovanni recalls being impressed with Mr. Frankel's determination to help the poor, as well as his knowledge of St. Francis of Assisi. "If I cannot trust the Catholic Church, who can I trust?" the monsignor recalls Mr. Frankel asking him.
The church officials say they were also dazzled by Mr. Frankel's personal generosity. While negotiating with the Vatican, he bought Mr. Bolan tickets on the Concorde, and flew Mr. Jacobs across the Atlantic in first-class cabins after the priest said he declined offers to fly on Mr. Frankel's private jet. When Mr. Frankel learned that Mr. Bolan's son was dying of multiple sclerosis, he paid for a nurse to attend to the son at home, Mr. Bolan's lawyer said.
The courtship paid dividends. Mr. Jacobs and Monsignor Colagiovanni arranged for the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation to have access to an account at the Instituto per le Opere di Religione, the Vatican bank, which is off-limits to outsiders.
But perhaps most helpful to Mr. Frankel were two affidavits, drafted by Mr. Frankel's lawyers and signed by Monsignor Colagiovanni, several people directly involved in the process confirmed. The first, issued last November, contended that the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation was an organization within the Holy See, meaning that it carried the imprimatur of the Pope.
A second, issued three months later, backed off that assertion. It said the Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation contributed $1 billion to the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation, and further contended that the money emanated from "various Roman Catholic tribunals and Roman Catholic cultural institutions."
Both statements are now widely doubted. Monsignor Colagiovanni's lawyer now calls the affidavits a "mistake" and ascribes his error to misplaced trust in Mr. Frankel.
But though Mr. Frankel clearly expected the religious overlay he put on his operation to help him expand his empire rapidly, the purported link to the Vatican ties did not, apparently, do him much good. They might even have contributed to his demise.
Last August, the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation began taking control of Thunor Trust and, by extension, Mr. Frankel's growing network of insurance companies. Mr. Frankel, however, quickly discovered that invoking the name of the Vatican raised red flags everywhere.
Negotiations for two new purchases of insurance companies, one in Colorado and another in Washington State, fell through after Mr. Frankel arranged for the St. Francis foundation to become the purchaser instead of Thunor Trust. Foreign ownership, prohibited by some state insurance regulators, was one stumbling block.
"St. Francis was telling us that they were ultimately controlled by the Vatican, but if that was the case, then they could not buy Capital Life," said Joseph L. Blattner, president of the Capital Life Insurance Company of Denver, which negotiated with Mr. Frankel's organization for nearly six months before the talks collapsed.
Meanwhile, by late 1998, regulators were beginning to catch up with Mr. Frankel. Tennessee state examiners questioned why the Franklin insurance companies that they oversaw had placed so much money in one pot -- Mr. Frankel's Liberty -- and worried about rapid turnover of the Liberty accounts. Liberty reported trading volume in 1998 of about $14 billion, in exchange for earning a negligible $40,000 in commissions. Mr. Frankel dodged a bullet when he transferred assets back to Tennessee before a deadline.
He had a harder time fending off Mississippi officials a few months later. Regulators in that state questioned the same trading patterns. But Franklin's answers made matters worse. They revealed that the change in ownership from Thunor to the St. Francis foundation had not been reported, as required, to local authorities. That is what prompted the late April gathering in Jackson, where many of Mr. Frankel's colleagues saw him in person for the only time.
Court records show that Mr. Frankel may have known the end was near. Even before that meeting, Franklin subsidiaries had transferred large sums to Liberty National or other accounts directly controlled by Mr. Frankel, including $161 million from Mississippi insurance companies and $117 million from affiliated companies in Missouri. The court records suggest that most of that money was transferred into foreign bank accounts by early May.
On May 7, two days after firefighters responded to a fire caused by burning documents in the Greenwich mansion, Mr. Hackney, Mr. Jacobs, Mr. Bolan, Monsignor Colagiovanni, legal officers at Akin, Gump, regulators in several states and many others were told that Mr. Frankel had disappeared.
"It all seemed so good, like Brooke Astor," Mr. Jacobs said, referring to the New York benefactress as he reflected on his ties to Mr. Frankel. "Only he turned out to be the Devil."

Chart: "Fanfare for a Con Man"
In the late 1980's, when he was soliciting investors from his hometown of Toledo, Ohio, Martin R. Frankel (shown here in his high school yearbook, 1970) wrote up his life story for potential clients. Despite the grandiose descriptions of his ability, in a matter of years Mr. Frankel was barred from the industry because of lies he told customers. Among the statements he made about himself:
 
'During his early elementary school tenure, he was tested, without preparation, using the Stanford-Binet IQ test, on which he received a score of 194, one of the highest scores ever registered by a child on this popular IQ test.'
 
'When he graduated from Whitmer High School in 1971, he was at the time the only student in Whitmer history who had ever been allowed for reasons of academic excellence - to graduate after attending only three years.'
 
'On several exams at the University of Toledo, he scored higher than any student had ever scored.'
 
'Marty Frankel has unearthed a method he uses to predict the movement of financial instruments...His work in this field has been confirmed, in part, by the work of leading economists and psychologists at Yale, Cornell, Stanford and the University of California at Berkely.'
 
'Marty Frankel's prowess at investing is powerful. For five years, Marty Frankel has placed in the top rank of money managers in the United States.'
 
'His finest hour possibly came in 1987, when he predicted the October crash...Frankel was one of the very few money managers in the country who was 100 percent in cash during the Great Crash of 1987.'
 
'Frankel believes the job of money management is a sacred profession, like that of a doctor, and he approaches his clients with this same degree of care.'
(pg. C6)
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW;
Romuald Hazoume

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:

The Project
421 West 126th Street
Harlem
Through July 25
This show marks the first United States solo of Romuald Hazoume, 37, an artist from Benin in West Africa who has recently appeared in several international biennials. All the work -- seven paintings and around two dozen sculptures -- was produced in New York during an extended visit by the artist just before the show. 
 The sculptures are constructed from industrial or commercial materials that he found or bought in the gallery's Harlem neighborhood. They all suggest faces, and many of them bring to mind traditional African masks.
Mr. Hazoume is a deft and witty assemblagist. The masks are fashioned from plastic detergent jugs, videocassette casings, hand irons and lengths of hosing or strips of metal chrome. These shapes are supplemented by others. Electric fan blades serve as ears, shoe brushes as tufts of hair, crushed soft drink cans as eyes.
Conceptually, the sculpture touches many bases. It has sources in so-called tribal objects, though it replaces their organic materials with nonbiodegradable substances. It turns a third world economy of recycling into gallery art. It refers to the pervasive reach of Western-generated consumer culture, which includes the high-price collecting and museum stockpiling of pre-colonial Africa art. Finally, this site-specific work reflects its New York environment. In a pair of faces titled "Before, After," one has crack vials for eyes, and the other is scorched and half melted.
By contrast to these dense improvisations, Mr. Hazoume's paintings look airy and light. Each is made from layers of earth, brought from Africa or elsewhere, and rubbed into stretched canvas. On ocher and cinnamon-red grounds, the artist paints linear emblems, usually one per painting, of oracular and personal significance.
More than the sculptures, the paintings have (to Western eyes, at least) an "African" look, and seem to require a very specific symbolic decoding. But they are visually beguiling, and there's no question that Mr. Hazoume's debut is a welcome addition to a New York season in which contemporary art from Africa -- diverse in media, forms and ideas -- has had an unusually strong presence.
 HOLLAND COTTER 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: City Board Approves Increases for Rent-Stabilized Apartments

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted 5 to 4 last night to approve a 2 percent increase for one-year leases and a 4 percent increase for two-year leases on rent-stabilized apartments, the same increases approved for four of the last five years.
The board sets rent increases for the approximately one million New York City apartments in buildings operating under rent stabilization, whose rules date back to 1943. 
 The vote by the board reflects a staff recommendation in May for 2 to 4 percent increases, which are tied to the Price Index of Operating Costs, a landlord price index compiled by the city. That measure, which reflects costs like heating oil, was 0.03 percent last year, down from 0.13 percent in 1997. Landlords criticize the index because they say it does not reflect long-term costs.
The meeting began with a protracted debate among board members, who include two landlord representatives and two tenant representatives, and was punctuated by the jeering of tenant advocates, who made up the majority of the hundred or so audience members and continually yelled, "Jerk," "Sleazy," and "You're insane!"
Edward S. Hochman, 46, the chairman of the rent guidelines board, expressed frustration with both the debate and the loud protest.
"The numbers legitimately made for a narrow range," Mr. Hochman said in an interview during a recess, referring to the landlord price index. "It was never going to go below 0 and never go above 2 percent for one-year leases, and never go below 1 and never go above 4 percent for two years. But tonight was like the Battle of Stalingrad, where the battle loses any real military purpose."
Mr. Hochman requested that two police officers stand at attention in front of the stage at the Grand Hall of Cooper Union and had a third officer circulate through the audience to request quiet.
Vincent S. Castellano, 37, a landlord and real estate broker from the Rockaways, in Queens, who is one of two landlord representatives on the board, said, "If you can't raise rents when economic times are good, when tenants are working, when income is going up, then when would you suggest we raise rents?"
Mr. Castellano cited city statistics that 116,000 jobs were created last year and personal income, adjusted for inflation, rose 3.5 percent. Meanwhile, apartment buildings continue to age, repairs continue to mount and become more expensive and the city government continues to impose new requirements, like fire sprinklers and removal of lead paint, he said.
David D. Pagan, 55, a tenant representative on the board and an administrator at the Southside United Housing Development Fund Corporation in Brooklyn, said the board vote was "extremely disappointing." He said the landlord price index was "next to nothing, and we were willing to give a little on the second year." He had proposed a 0 percent increase for one-year leases and 1.8 percent for two-year leases. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: June 29, 1999, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about increases for rent-stabilized apartments in New York City misstated the history of the law. Rent stabilization was enacted in 1969; it is the rent control law that dates from 1943. The article also referred imprecisely to the working of the newer law. It regulates individual apartments, not buildings.
