HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Even in Fog, That City On a Hill Dazzles

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
More than any other, this is the city that Americans fantasize about. No one leaves his heart in Salt Lake City. No one calls Baltimore Baghdad by the Bay, as Herb Caen, the city's six-day-a-week poet laureate for more than 50 years, called San Francisco.
For me San Francisco has always been a paradox: a thoroughly worldly place, yet remote and somehow detached from world capitals like New York and London; a little indifferent to the mundane business of trading shares and casting votes; in other words, a bit smug. (The good Mr. Caen, who before his death in 1997 did for San Francisco what Samuel Pepys did for London, once quoted a local citizen who, upon reaching heaven, reported back to friends here that "it's nice, but it isn't San Francisco.") 
 Yet San Francisco looms large in the imagination of everyone who knows it, myself most decidedly included. Like Paris, Venice and Hong Kong, it is a city without peer, a city of myth and magic.
I can't think of the place without thinking about sourdough bread and Alice Waters, who revolutionized American cooking; Joe DiMaggio, the fisherman's son, and A. P. Giannini, another Italian-American, who built the world's largest bank; Turk Murphy and San Francisco jazz; Alcatraz and San Quentin; the hairpin bends on Lombard Street and the sudden watery vistas.
The weather I could do without. Fog veils the city so often that a local radio station has adopted the call letters KFOG. Fog bleaches the color from the perky paint jobs on the Victorian frame houses that march up and down the city's distinctive hills. When the fog finally lifts, when everything sparkles in the sun, it is an occasion for celebration. Yes! A five-bridge day, with all the spans from the Golden Gate almost down to Palo Alto clearly visible.
But fog has its uses. Several years ago, crossing the Bay Bridge from Oakland to San Francisco at dawn, my wife, Betsey, and I watched bug-eyed as the Transamerica pyramid and the city's other towers rose bronzed and beautiful from their cloudy bed. Nothing, in truth, not fog or rain or fire or quake, ever quite masks San Francisco's beauty or quenches its exuberance. Its setting rivals Rio's. Its charm compares with Boston's. Its joie de vivre nearly matches that of New Orleans; it lacks only the last Latin measure of heedlessness.
Characters from Nob Hill and Telegraph Hill, Chinatown and the Tenderloin have walked straight into the pages of Bret Harte, Jack London, Frank Norris, Dashiell Hammett, Tom Wolfe (who found the essential San Francisco experience in "roaring up hills or down hills, sliding on and off the cable-car tracks") and John Steinbeck, who loved San Francisco, as he wrote, when "the afternoon sun painted her white and gold, rising on her hills like a noble city in a happy dream."
San Francisco is on something of a cultural tear lately, cementing its position as the West Coast's cultural capital, although Los Angeles is by no means the pothole full of philistines many San Franciscans see when (if) they take the plane south.
The San Francisco Opera is the nation's second largest, after the Met, and it has the largest budget of any West Coast arts organization.
An old autocrat named Kurt Herbert Adler built the opera's reputation, bringing singers of the caliber of Tebaldi, Schwarzkopf and Fassbaender to the United States for the first time. Lotfi Mansouri, the current general director, has gradually lengthened the season, and during the 10 months from next September through July 2000, 11 different operas will be performed.
At the moment, the opera is in the midst of four cycles of Wagner's immense "Ring of the Nibelung" at the War Memorial Opera House (the place where the United Nations Charter was signed on June 26, 1945, by representatives of 50 nations). The 15-year-old production was reshaped by Andrei Serban, the Romanian-born stage director, who had never seen a complete "Ring" until his own. Jane Eaglen, Deborah Voigt and James Morris are among the gods, demigods and giants onstage. The final cycle ends on July 3.
 
A Genuine Celebrity
Not to be outdone, the city's orchestra is just concluding an ambitious Stravinsky festival, exploring the master's work in Russia, Paris and Los Angeles, where its music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, then in his 20's, knew him at the end of his long, hugely productive career. Successor to luminaries like Monteux and Krips, the lithe, lean Maestro Thomas is one of only three American-born music directors of major American orchestras, along with Leonard Slatkin in Washington and Andrew Litton in Dallas. M. T. T., as the local papers call him, is one of San Francisco's genuine celebrities these days, a Pied Piper leading the young back into the concert hall.
If the critics grumble once in a while, the public has responded warmly to his programs in his nearly four years here, and even a Vienna audience would have been impressed, I think, by his powerful but never bombastic Bruckner Ninth in Davies Symphony Hall early this spring.
As ever under Mr. Thomas, there will be a lot of American and modern music next season, plus a tasty rarity, Elgar's "Dream of Gerontius."
The San Francisco Ballet is in the hands of an old New York favorite, Helgi Tomasson, who has transformed a regional troupe into a fine classical company since taking over as artistic director in 1985. I won't prattle on here; it's enough to quote Anna Kisselgoff of The New York Times, no easy mark, who proclaimed the company "world class" after watching it last year.
All three companies perform in San Francisco's Civic Center, whose most prominent building is the newly, grandly restored City Hall, with an enormous, echoing rotunda. (Don't miss it, even if this stuff usually leaves you cold as a musher's nose in midwinter.) Nearby stands the new public library, and by 2002, now that a knot of litigation has seemingly been untied, the Asian Art Museum is scheduled to open in the old library building, adapted by Gae Aulenti, the Italian wizard who turned a Paris train station into the Musee d'Orsay.
Comparisons are odious, if entertaining, but I would argue that the Asian museum is San Francisco's best. Built around the collection of Avery Brundage, it contains Japanese, Korean and Indian works, but the Chinese material is supreme. When the Chinese leader Jiang Zemin visited the museum, he was dazzled by a gilded image of the Buddha from A.D. 338. I'll bet you will be, too.
For the moment, the Asian museum shares a quake-weakened, obtrusively buttressed building in Golden Gate Park with the M. H. de Young Museum, which has raised $65 million for a new home, to be designed by Herzog & de Meuron, architects of the new Bankside building for the Tate Gallery in London. The strength of its collection lies in American painting, from George Caleb Bingham's "Boatmen on the Missouri" through Frederic E. Church's "Rainy Season in the Tropics" to Grant Wood's "Dinner for Threshers," a plain-faced group portrait that outshines the over-familiar "American Gothic." Many of the choicest pictures came in a 1978 gift of 175 items from Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d.
The de Young's sister museum, the California Palace of the Legion of Honor -- together they are known as the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco -- was rebuilt and reinvented several years ago, reopening in November 1995. It occupies a picturesque site in Lincoln Park, overlooking the great rust-red pylons of the Golden Gate Bridge, an iconic structure that embodies this city's spirit the way the Statue of Liberty embodies New York's.
Founded by the flamboyant Alma de Bretteville Spreckels, whose rich, indulgent husband, Adolph, inherited a sugar fortune, the museum's collection centers on European art, especially French art. The "Old Woman" by Georges de la Tour, a Monet "Waterlilies," a powerful off-center portrait by Degas, "The Impresario," and some 70 Rodins are in the collection.
Yet another arts district has sprung into being in recent years in the redeveloped area south of Market Street, known as SoMa. At its core is the Yerba Buena Center, designed for the many small-scale arts organizations in the Bay Area. It includes galleries by the Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki, sheathed in corrugated aluminum siding but still somehow delicate, and a theater designed by James Stewart Polshek, dark and angular on the inside but more like a jaunty piece of de Stijl sculpture outside.
 
More of the Arts
Around the perimeter are a children's entertainment and education center, complete with carousel; the brand-new $85 million Metreon, Sony's urban version of a Disney theme park, with an "environment" by Maurice Sendak, which is expected to attract five million visitors a year; the Ansel Adams Center for Photography, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Still to come are a new Jewish Museum designed by Daniel Libeskind, who did a similar project in Berlin, and a new building for the Mexican Museum.
The big cheese, of course, is the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which is housed in Mario Botta's four-year-old landmark building, whose truncated cylindrical tower lets the light flood in. A bequest from Elise S. Haas, of the Levi Strauss family, brought it several pictures once owned by Sarah Stein, the sister-in-law of Gertrude, including a breathtaking Fauve Matisse, "Femme au Chapeau." Phyllis C. Wattis, the San Francisco cultural world's Brooke Astor, gave $20 million in 1998 to buy 13 Rauschenbergs and other works.
Donald G. Fisher, the founder of the Gap clothing chain, paid $1.9 million in May for an Alexander Calder wood-and-wire sculpture called "Constellation." It appears to be headed for the modern art museum, too. But because of the need to rotate pictures, Bay Area artists like Richard Diebenkorn and Sam Francis are sometimes underrepresented on the museum's walls.
The Yerba Buena area is the epicenter of modern architecture in the city. Elsewhere, the pickings are slimmer, despite Frank Lloyd Wright's building on Maiden Lane, now the Circle Gallery, which was a precursor of the Guggenheim in its use of a spiral ramp, and his Buck Rogers-style civic center in Marin County.
Architecture buffs will want to see something of Bernard Maybeck, the individualist who foreshadowed the California Arts and Crafts movement. (The templelike Palace of Fine Arts, left over from the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition, and the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Berkeley are his masterworks.) A glacier-white Richard Neutra house, cantilevered over a cliff with a picture-postcard view of the Bay Bridge, is at 56 Calhoun Terrace. And the excess of San Francisco's Gilded Age is wonderfully displayed in Alma Spreckels's Beaux-Arts mansion on Pacific Heights, with 26 bathrooms. It now belongs to Danielle Steel, the romance novelist.
 
Striking It Rich
Hemmed in by bay and ocean at the tip of a narrow peninsula, San Francisco is relatively small. It ranks only 13th on the list of American cities, with a population estimated at 735,000 in 1996; Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose are all bigger. But the metropolitan area surrounding the bay, with 6.6 million people, is the nation's fifth largest.
San Francisco was built on three stout economic legs: silver from the Comstock Lode, the transcontinental railroads and the port, once dominated by Harry Bridges, the militant leader of the longshoremen.
George Hearst struck it rich in the mines; his son, William Randolph Hearst, struck it richer in yellow journalism, which he helped to invent; the younger Hearst's granddaughter Patty was kidnapped in 1974 by the Symbionese Liberation Army, but survived. The circulation of Hearst's flagship, The San Francisco Examiner, whose logo proclaims it "Monarch of the Dailies," has shriveled, but it may yet swallow its larger rival, The San Francisco Chronicle, whose owning families could give lessons to the Hatfields and the McCoys.
W. R. Hearst may have been satirized by Orson Welles in "Citizen Kane," but the men who built the Central Pacific, mostly on the back of Chinese coolies, were reviled in their own time as profiteers. They were called the Big Four: Leland Stanford, Collis P. Huntington, Charles Crocker and Mark Hopkins. According to one contemporary account, they made a $63 million profit on a $121 million investment.
It once seemed that San Francisco got by on beauty, charm and the spending of strangers. But that has changed, and radically.
Silicon Valley, just to the south, is the land of memory chips, software and freshly coined millionaires, which attracts a third of all the venture capital invested in the country. Five of the best 20 places to earn a living in the United States, a survey by Forbes magazine recently found, are within an hour and a half's drive of downtown San Francisco.
No wonder people want to live here. No wonder the median price for a single-family house in the Bay Area has risen 14.2 percent in the last year to $334,590. (In Atherton, a tony suburb, it hit $2.5 million.)
But off in a corner, with no share in this orgasm of prosperity, are the city's omnipresent homeless, begging for money at freeway offramps by day, rolling out their sleeping bags by night in the doorways of expensive stores and other buildings, hoping the police won't notice.
If the police do move in, some of the homeless people whip out their cellular phones and call television stations to come film the action.
As early as 1883, Robert Louis Stevenson remarked on the city's cosmopolitan character, detecting "the airs of Marseilles and Peking" in its streets. Writing in the same vein 50 years later, another traveler, John Gunther, called San Francisco "brilliant, polyglot and sophisticated," and said it "will tolerate everything, including the intolerable."
San Francisco has an established social order and lots of Old Money, even a mini-Wall Street. It has a fondness for clubs -- the Olympic; the Bohemian, with its encampments on the Russian River north of town, and the Pacific Union, whose brown sandstone clubhouse atop Nob Hill once belonged to the silver millionaire James Flood. It is bracketed by two universities of world stature -- the University of California at Berkeley, east of the bay, and Stanford University at Palo Alto, an hour south of the city.
But this has always been a city that embraces rule-breakers. From its beginnings as an R & R stop for Gold Rush pioneers through the wide-open era of Barbary Coast saloons to the heyday of North Beach topless bars, featuring the silicone-boosted charms of Carol Doda, San Francisco has been a good-time town, ready to live and let live.
 
A Town of Tolerance
As a result of its tolerance, the city has always had more than its share of characters, notably Joshua Norton, who proclaimed himself Emperor of the United States in 1859 (and advanced the obviously loony idea of a bridge connecting San Francisco and Oakland). I saw one of his spiritual descendants this spring, a portly fellow with full beard and flowing hair, dressed in overalls and railroad engineer's cap, ambling along, blowing soap bubbles.
Countercultures have flourished here since World War II. In the 1950's, Columbus Avenue gave birth to the Beat Generation and its bards Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg. In the 1960's came the hippies of Haight-Ashbury, preaching Flower Power, dreaming multicolored dreams and packing Bill Graham's rock concerts, and the student rebels of Berkeley, led by Mario Savio. In the 1970's, Huey Newton, from Oakland, made the Black Panthers a militant voice for the dispossessed of the nation's ghettos.
Gay men and lesbians were given an honored place in San Francisco when they were still swept under the carpet elsewhere. It was perhaps inevitable that the American AIDS epidemic hit first and hardest here, but horrifyingly unexpected when the gay activist Harvey Milk, whose election as a Supervisor in 1977 had thrilled gay San Franciscans, was assassinated in 1978 along with the city's Mayor, George R. Moscone.
Now the Mayor is Willie L. Brown Jr., a black boulevardier who started life as a sharecropper's son, a man with the charm of Cary Grant, the audacity of a high-wire artist and lots of political smarts. Willie, as they say here, never bothering to specify his last name, "is a piece of work." Some people bridle at his Italian suits, flashy cars and pretty girlfriends, but few will bet against him when he stands for re-election this fall. Many nights, he attends a half-dozen political functions before meeting a friend for a late dinner, and then at midnight he stands on the street outside the restaurant, greeting and teasing a few of the tourists who throng to his city.
His most reliable supporters are San Francisco's Chinese.
 
Delights by the Bay
 
Here is information about visiting San Francisco:
 
Where to Stay
 
CAMPTON PLACE, 340 Stockton Street, (415) 781-5555. A polished little gem of a hotel, ideally situated just off Union Square, marred only by a few overly snug bedrooms. The multinational, multilingual staff will jump through hoops to make you comfortable. A half-dozen of San Francisco's best chefs have presided in the dining room over the last quarter-century. Double room: $260 to $400.
 
MANDARIN ORIENTAL, 222 Sansome Street, (415) 885-0999. In the heart of the Financial District yet close enough to Union Square, Chinatown and SoMa, this is a spectacular sibling of one of Hong Kong's finest hotels. It occupies floors 38 to 48 of a skyscraper, guaranteeing great views. Double room: $415 to $570 weekdays; $255 to $550 weekends.
 
REX, 562 Sutter Street, (415) 433-4434. Like Paris, San Francisco is blessed with affordable hotels, and the Rex is among the most charming. A vaguely clubby lobby with a bar and rooms with luxury-hotel amenities -- voice mail, dataports, movies -- dispel any hint of slumming. Double room: $165 to $245.
 
RITZ-CARLTON, 600 Stockton Street, (415) 296-7465. As ritzy as they come, this is the city's premier hotel, a worthy successor to the grandes dames of the past like the St. Francis, the Clift and the Fairmont. Perched on the side of Nob Hill, it is fairly stuffed with marble, crystal and brocade, and the bedrooms are luxurious in size as well as decor. We ate an impeccable Thanksgiving dinner one year in the pretty restaurant. Double room: $309 to $3,500 for a suite.
 
W, 181 Third Street, (415) 777-5300, is a sassy new spot in the Yerba Buena arts district. An octagonal three-story lobby adjoins a "living room" with smart modern furniture. Royal blue and chocolate brown are the colors of choice upstairs and down. The restaurant is called XYZ, natch. Double room: $239 to $319.
 
Where to Eat
 
CHEZ PANISSE, 1517 Shattuck Avenue, Berkeley, (510) 548-5525. What to say? Alice Waters only gets better, buying superlative ingredients from small farmers and handling them with reverence. Every night, a six-course set menu, balanced and seasonal, is served in an old Craftsman house half hidden by trees. In the final week of May this year, the menus emphasized fava beans, morels, king salmon and asparagus. The atmosphere is a little worshipful for me, but who cares when everything looks and tastes so beautiful?
 
MASA, 648 Bush Street, (415) 989-7154. For decades now, Masa has been the town's top French restaurant, a subdued, formal place with subtle, complex cooking. Julian Serrano, who made it what it is, has followed the yellow brick road to Las Vegas, but Michael Bauer, The San Francisco Chronicle's exigent food critic, detects no decline in standards.
 
OLIVETO, 5655 College Avenue, Oakland, (510) 547-5356. Close your eyes, and Paul Bertolli will whisk you to the Umbrian countryside. He marries peasant heartiness with city-slicker lightness: homemade noodles with delicate sand dabs, gossamer gnocchi with sage and brown butter, moist roast pork bathed in rich pan juices, with fleshy white beans on the side. One of our companions called the dense chocolate tartuffo "heroin on a plate."
 
POSTRIO, 545 Post Street, (415) 776-7825. This is Wolfgang Puck's Northern California outpost, a trilevel showplace designed by the celebrated Pat Kuleto. Puckish pizzas at the bar; more substantial fare downstairs, notably roasted leg of lamb with garlic mashed potatoes (aaah) and nicoise olives. Or try the fine grilled quail. They serve breakfast, too.
 
RUBICON, 558 Sacramento Street, (415) 434-4100. The room is airy, the food solidly Californian, the management by Drew Nieporent watchful. But it is Larry Stone, California's best sommelier, who pulls in the winos, myself included. Can't find Grace Family cabernets? He has them (at a price, to be sure), as well as small-grower Burgundies and many other goodies.
 
SLANTED DOOR, 584 Valencia Street, (415) 861-8032. You will find no better Vietnamese food anywhere in the United States (or, I dare say, in Vietnam). The neighborhood is proletarian (no parking), but classic dishes like spring rolls and caramelized shrimp are executed with all the finesse of Alain Ducasse. The spicy squid and chili green beans aren't bad, either.
 
TADICH GRILL, 240 California Street, (415) 391-1849. Born with the Gold Rush, Tadich's turns 150 this year. Fabulously fresh fish, simply prepared, is the house specialty: sand dabs and petrale sole, grilled or pan-fried; the tomato-based seafood stew called cioppino, and peerless Dungeness crab in the shell, in a cocktail or in a salad. Go for lunch.
 
TON KIANG, 5821 Geary Boulevard, (415) 387-8273. Think you know dim sum? Ton Kiang will teach you a thing or two about greaseless frying, translucent dumpling skins and the use of chives, spring onions and ginger to point up flavors. This is a favorite of the chef Barbara Tropp, which speaks volumes, and it earns a tip of my hat for its smiling, efficient service.
 
ZUNI CAFE, 1658 Market Street, (415) 552-2522. A friend of mine calls Judy Rogers's Spartan cafe, with copper bar and roaring wood-burning oven, "the soul of San Francisco." So it is, in its delicious simplicity, whether you order a pristine martini and a plate of oysters at the bar, or a Caesar salad fit for a Caesar or, if you go late, an unlisted treat: a princely hamburger made from brined beef ground when you order and served on focaccia.

HEADLINE: Retrain Steel Workers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Although you rightly conclude that we should resist import quotas to protect the steel industry, you do not mention the most practical argument for opposing such legislation (editorial, June 23). 
 Placing limits on imported steel would raise the cost of every product that Americans buy that uses steel. All Americans, including steel workers, would pay more money for steel-based products, like cars, in order to save a few thousand jobs. While saving jobs is a laudable goal, wouldn't it make more sense to craft legislation that would train steel workers who become unemployed with new skills applicable to industries that need workers rather than subsidize their work in an industry that is increasingly noncompetitive?
 
SAMUEL GURKA
Bronx, June 23, 1999

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: For the High-Minded, It's Blah, Blah, Blah;
Talks Are Cheap for Seekers of Ideas Who Are Willing to Listen

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
With Old World rivals like Paris and Berlin and New World rivals like Seattle and Silicon Valley, New York City can hardly claim to be the brain capital of the world.
But you wouldn't necessarily know that from all the talking going on. Call them seminars or lectures or discussions, but the city is truly brimming with forums for the thinking man, woman and child. In any given week an intrepid idea-seeker can find serious discussions about everything from the growing presence of Islam in America to the social history of popcorn. 
 Want to know how to cross-hybridize corn? There are talks at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. How about an in-depth look at democracy in Cuba? Check out the Brecht Forum on Tuesday.
In the age of Barnes & Noble and other super-size bookstores, literary discussion groups are meeting regularly to chat about Vietnam novels and science fiction and New Age tomes. Then there are the literary fan clubs, societies devoted to the work of late great authors like Yeats and Dickens.
Last week alone a New Yorker could find dozens of people sitting down to learn about Surrealist film, beach erosion and the history of marriage from a feminist perspective. There were appearances by seminar stars like Stephen Jay Gould, the historian, who can pack a room on a topic like "The Impossibility of Historical Prediction," and celebrity lecturers like the composer Philip Glass, whose talent for artful digression rivals that of many more experienced speakers.
All of this tossing about of ideas gives rise to a curious question: could one, by visiting many of these lectures and listening closely enough, pick up some sense of the city's intellectual zeitgeist?
The short answer is no. To be sure, there is plenty of millennial reflection going on right now, and more than a few speakers tossing around words like "calendric" and "fin de siecle."
But rather than indicating a common theme, this profusion of talkers and listeners testifies instead to the city's enormously varied intellectual appetite. It also shows off the city as a place where people with specific interests -- sometimes, exceedingly specific -- can find like-minded folk to commune with.
What follows is an account of a weeklong survey of the city's educated chatter.
The first stop, as any lecture junkie will tell you, was bound to be a big-time bookstore. Hoping to lure buyers into the stacks, chains like Barnes & Noble and Borders Books have been aggressive about scheduling authors with new books to discuss and read from their work.
On Monday, the choices included a speaker on the history of coffee at Barnes & Noble on the Upper East Side and a discussion of the work of Bernhard Schlink at the Barnes & Noble in Forest Hills, Queens.
No. And no. Instead, my choice was a lecture by Paul Levinson, a professor of communications history and philosophy at Fordham University, whose most recent book is "Digital McLuhan," a look at the lasting influence of Marshall McLuhan in the age of the Internet. The locale was a Borders at the World Trade Center, with an audience of about 40, including a man who slept before, during and after the event.
Mr. Levinson, flanked by stacks of photography books and others merely labeled "Art," expounded on likenesses between the futuristic visions of Mr. McLuhan, who invented the term Global Village, and today's World Wide Web.
"Mr. McLuhan was not able to write on the Web, but his approach was Web-like," Mr. Levinson said, citing Mr. McLuhan's propensity for short chapters and nonlinear thought in his books. The comments drew a round of emphatic nods.
"What would Marshall McLuhan have said about the Internet and the Web?" Mr. Levinson said. "It's impossible to say." He paused and added with a laugh: "Except that he would have had a lot to say about it."
Tuesday's schedule was to begin early, with a 7:30 A.M. talk with the television commentator Cokie Roberts at the 92d Street Y. But upon arriving, I discovered a sacred rule of the intellectual set: they like to sleep late. The event had been canceled.
The 92d Street Y is one of the city's premier temples of talk, a list that includes the New York Public Library, the Asia Society and the Pierpont Morgan Library, which has a series of afternoon discussions. And while summer may be a slow time for the city's colleges and universities, they generally offer countless lectures that are open to the public.
Many churches and museums also offer issue-oriented events. Ms. Roberts, in fact, would make an appearance at Trinity Church later that afternoon, speaking on religion and politics.
For true intellectual heft, however, perhaps few spots can rival the Brecht Forum, where Mr. Gould spoke on Tuesday night. The first words I heard upon entering were "imperialist dialectic interpretation of history."
The forum is on the 10th floor of 122 West 27th Street in Chelsea, a loft space where papier mache wall hangings and pamphlets jockey for visitors' attention.
Mr. Gould had drawn a standing-room-only crowd dotted with older men with ponytails, older women with spectacles and graduate student types scribbling notes on legal pads. The amiable Mr. Gould, with a pair of glasses hung around his neck, hit upon Karl Marx's funeral ("Only nine people were there"), the year 2000 ("a wonderfully arbitrary transition") and Yogi Berra's wisdom ("The future ain't what it used to be") before finally alighting on his thesis: that people, especially scientists, are terrible at predicting the future.
As an example, Mr. Gould told the story of an early chairman of Mercedes-Benz who once predicted that Europe would never sustain more than a million cars. The reason? That the Continent's citizenry could only ever produce a million chauffeurs.
Mr. Gould's point was that the underlying biases of class, race and economics often skewed any possibility of prognostication. "Scientific biases prevent accurate prediction," he said. "And always have."
There was much scribbling as I left.
The next stop was the Kitchen, the venerable experimental theater space on West 19th Street, the site of a batch of summertime lectures by members of the Kitchen's artistic family.
The seats were nearly all filled with a younger crowd than that at the Brecht Forum. The lights dimmed theatrically as Mr. Glass approached a small table draped in black and lighted by a single overhead spotlight. He immediately said that his lecture, titled "Collaboration and the New Technology," presented a problem.
"I made up the title months ago," Mr. Glass said. "Now, I've had to figure out what it was about."
Speaking in a voice barely above a burble, Mr. Glass touched on the miraculous technology of the piano (see lecture title), and his artistic collaborations (see lecture title) with everyone from Jerome Robbins to Martin Scorsese. But the most absorbing moments came when Mr. Glass's focus strayed a bit.
"CD-ROM is already on the way out," he said at one point, seeming alarmed and amused all at once. "Did you know that?"
Or: "I've noticed my cat doesn't watch television. Does yours?"
Or: "The only place the composer is the boss is in the opera house. That's why I write so many operas."
At evening's end a young composer asked Mr. Glass's advice about the profession. Mr. Glass puzzled for a bit and finally answered: "Think what you could do that would make your teachers really angry. That would probably be the most interesting thing to do."
The following night I tried a couple of the city's newer venues, the two-year-old Newseum and Joe's Pub, the recently opened cabaret spot at the Public Theater.
The Newseum auditorium is a sleek Madison Avenue lecture hall popular with that famously loquacious breed, the journalist. Booking reporters as speakers has its drawbacks, of course; a talk on Monday by the photojournalist Harry Benson was canceled when he was called away on assignment.
Helen Thomas, veteran White House correspondent and recent author of a memoir, spoke about her experiences. Beltway reminiscences ensued: of Lyndon B. Johnson, who "couldn't stand anybody speaking for him"; Hillary Clinton, who "just hates the press"; and President Clinton, who "has been very nice to me."
The crowd, unswayed by Ms. Thomas's assertion that reporters shouldn't be celebrities, ate it up.
Joe's Pub, which usually presents music, turned literary Wednesday with a selection of readings from The New Yorker's latest fiction issue. Special attractions included celebrity readers, girls in slinky dresses looking to impress New Yorker editors and lots of cocktails.
The final evening of talk, Thursday, highlights what may be the seminar scene's most important contribution to the city's intellectual landscape: bringing together people with particular interests. At the Lesbian and Gay Community Center in the West Village, for example, E. J. Graff, a writer, discussed same-sex marriages.
Then at Borders Books at East 57th Street and Park Avenue, four African-American authors gathered to discuss the topic of "The Importance of Writing About Contemporary Black Life." The audience was almost exclusively black, a marked change from most of the other events I attended. One at a time, each author discussed pressing issues for black artists, including stereotyping by publishers and the complications of success for blacks in America.
"I started writing because I wanted to write about where we are now," said Benilde Little, a novelist. "We are the most educated, most affluent, and probably the most confused."
Events like this, she said, offer an opportunity to reflect on those confusions.
"You have to have a community where we can be ourselves," Ms. Little said, "drop the masks and let our hair down."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Copper Hits a One-Month High On News of U.S. Mine Closings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Copper rose yesterday to a one-month high after the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the world's second-biggest producer, said that it would close unprofitable United States mines in a move aimed at shrinking a global surplus.
Broken Hill will close mines that account for about 1.7 percent of global production because they lost money as prices slumped last month to a 12-year low. The drop reflected a glut caused by rising output from low-cost producers in Latin America and a slowdown in Asian demand, analysts said. 
 "We'll see prices recover a bit, but it's unlikely they'll go much higher from here," Kevin Norrish, minerals economist at Barclays Capital in London, said. "More production cutbacks are required."
Copper for July delivery settled up 2.65 cents, or 3.99 percent, to 69.00 cents a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices are still almost 8 percent lower than a year ago. On May 28, copper fell to 60.8 cents a pound, the lowest since 1987.
The jump in prices helped lift shares of copper mining companies, like the Phelps Dodge Corporation and Asarco Inc. Metals companies were the biggest gainers in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, with the S.& P. index of five metals companies up 6 percent at 191.18.
Broken Hill, an Australian company, said it would close the mines in Arizona and Nevada in August, including a smelter, where it costs about 65 cents to produce a pound of copper. Codelco of Chile, the world's biggest copper mining company, produces at a cost of 45 cents to 50 cents a pound.
Copper prices rallied 16 percent during April on signs of improvement in Asia and possible output cuts, only to retreat in May.

HEADLINE: Consumers Give Economy Another Boost

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Torrid consumer spending helped the economy grow at a brisk annual rate of 4.3 percent in the first quarter of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
Economists believe growth has slowed to about 3.5 percent in the current quarter, but they say that is probably not enough to dissuade the Federal Reserve Board from raising interest rates as a caution against inflation. 
 The 4.3 percent increase from January through March in the gross domestic product -- the nation's output of goods and services -- was slightly better than the 4.1 percent rate estimated a month ago, the Commerce Department said.
The improvement reflected a slight revision in the trade deficit, which, while still at a record high, was $6.5 billion lower than the Government estimated earlier.
The economy's robust first-quarter pace was far above expectations. That has bolstered expectations that the Fed, at its meeting next week, will push up short-term interest rates to keep the expansion from igniting inflation.
In a separate report, the National Association of Realtors said today that sales of existing single-family homes plunged 4 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.04 million units. That was the lowest level in six months. The drop coincided with rising mortgage rates.
In the first quarter, consumer spending continued to power economic growth, rising at an annual rate of 6.7 percent, the best showing in more than a decade, the Government said.
Financial markets have grown increasingly nervous in recent weeks that the Fed will raise interest rates.
The gross domestic product report indicated that inflation remained low. An inflation gauge tied to the gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent in the first quarter, compared with the 1.1 percent previously estimated.
The gross domestic product report showed that business investment, that is, spending on new equipment and plants, rose at an annual rate of 8.5 percent in the first quarter, even better than the estimate last month of 7.9 percent growth. Corporate profits, meanwhile, rose in the first quarter to an annual rate of $47.1 billion, a turnaround from a drop of $5.3 billion in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Filling School Gaps

 BODY:
Now that Chancellor Rudy Crew has removed so many administrators from New York City's worst schools, he faces the far more difficult task of replacing them. Finding good candidates to do these thankless jobs will not be easy, which is why he has hired a headhunting firm from Washington State to scout for replacements. But the Chancellor and his vocal critic, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, will now have to address the underlying problem -- the educator brain drain, particularly to the suburbs.
Each year the city loses some of its best educators to softer and better-paying jobs elsewhere, while the pool of replacements, especially administrators, grows steadily smaller. There were only about a dozen applicants for the top job at Manhattan's elite Stuyvesant High School. At less prestigious schools, the number of applicants can be as small as three or four. A major reason is that the principals' union and the city have been bogged down in contract negotiations for more than three years, despite a city proposal that salaries would go up almost 30 percent if principals gave up tenure. Educators who gamble on these high-wire managerial positions do not need tenure, but they deserve a hefty salary boost. If the union continues to balk, the State Legislature should break this stalemate, ending principals' tenure with a law. 
 Teachers, whose contract will expire next year, are also increasingly hard to find. The rate of new teachers leaving after a few years is almost twice what it is in other big cities. Moreover, the city's classrooms are increasingly run by uncertified teachers as many of the best educators are set to retire over the next four to five years.
With their annual pay at midcareer a dismal $41,000 a year in comparison with almost $60,000 in richer suburbs, city teachers still received some promising news this week. Dr. Crew and Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, negotiated a package for extra pay and benefits to certified teachers willing to tackle jobs in failing schools. This city-union partnership, as well as Ms. Weingarten's willingness to be flexible for this experiment, bodes well for these needy schools. The good will generated by this agreement also raises hopes that teachers' salaries will be substantially raised next year, at least enough to keep the best from fleeing the city.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Profit Reports Help Equities Post First Gains in a Week

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average yesterday eked out its first gain in a week after a report showed first-quarter profits rose almost 50 percent faster than previously estimated with little sign of inflation.
Alcoa, the No. 1 aluminum producer, and Phelps Dodge, the copper company, rose on optimism that rising prices would increase their earnings. America Online declined after negative comments from Henry Blodget, a Merrill Lynch analyst. 
 Trading was the slowest since Dec. 30 as investors waited for the meeting Tuesday and Wednesday of the Federal Open Market Committee. Investors expect the Federal Reserve's policy-making panel to raise short-term interest rates a quarter percentage point to head off inflation. The question is whether the Fed will signal that it plans additional increases this year.
Investors are waiting "to see if they give an indication that they're going to do another increase in August," said Robert Streed, a money manager for the Northern Trust Company. "You might as well wait and see what happens. It certainly hasn't paid to be heroic" and buy stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.73 points, to 10,552.56. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.47 point, to 1,315.31. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.34 points, to 2,552.65.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 4/32, to 87 26/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.15 percent from 6.16 percent on Thursday.
With investors leaving early on a summer Friday, some 623 million shares changed hands on the Big Board, below the three-month average of 778 million. "Everybody did what they had to do by 11 o'clock Eastern time, and the market's been very quiet since," said Todd Clark, managing director of listed trading at Schwab Capital Markets and Trading Group in San Francisco.
Alcoa rose 2 1/4, to 62 5/8, after another Merrill Lynch analyst, Daniel Roling, reiterated his buy rating on the aluminum producer and said the stock could reach 75 in 12 months, up 15 percent from his previous target. Mr. Roling cited cost improvement and better-than-expected aluminum prices for the quarter.
Phelps Dodge rose 3 5/16, to 61 11/16, after Broken Hill Proprietary, the copper producer, said it would shut its United States mines, helping cut a global glut of copper. Broken Hill's American depository receipts rose 1/2, to 22 9/16.
America Online fell 3 5/16, to 102 13/16. Mr. Blodget said the on-line service provider might not be able to exceed analysts' earnings estimates by as wide a margin as in the past because of the growth of free Internet access in Europe.
Other Internet stocks also fell. The service provider Mindspring Enterprises lost 4 9/16, to 77 9/16, and E*Trade Group lost 1 3/4, to 36 7/16.
After-tax corporate profits rose a revised 6.2 percent in the first quarter, up from the previously estimated 4.3 percent gain, after falling 1 percent in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department said. The report contained little to suggest that the Fed would raise interest rates by more than the half percentage point the market is expecting by the end of the year.
The Fed committee said after its last meeting that it was leaning toward raising interest rates to head off inflation.
The Goldman, Sachs strategist Abby Joseph Cohen told Bloomberg Television that next week's likely interest-rate increase by the Fed was already reflected in stock prices. The nation's economy shows no signs of overheating and companies are showing strong increases in quarterly earnings, she said.
"Federal Reserve action will not be harmful to the stock market," she said, although she noted that a temporary decline was possible in the aftermath of the news. "To the extent that the Federal Reserve convinces folks that they're focusing on inflation and taking actions to ensure that the cycle lasts as long as possible, it could be helpful."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Latin America And Europe To Talk Trade

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 25

 BODY:
In an effort to increase trade and gain a counterweight to American global economic dominance, leaders of the world's second- and third-largest trading blocs are to meet here this weekend and early next week in the first Latin American-European Summit, one that is already proving contentious on several basic issues.
The gathering will bring together heads of state from 33 Latin American and Caribbean countries and their counterparts from the 15 nations of the European Union. The centerpiece of the meeting is the prospect for negotiations for a free- trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur, the six-nation South American bloc. 
 With a population of more than 200 million and a combined economy of more than $1 trillion a year, Mercosur is the largest trading bloc after the North American Free Trade Agreement group -- comprising the United States, Canada and Mexico -- and the European Union. Mercosur's full members are Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. Bolivia and Chile are associate members.
"There are really going to be two meetings going on, one with all of Latin America and the Caribbean present, which will be largely rhetorical," said Helio Jaguaribe of the Institute for Political and Social Studies, a research group here. "But there will also be a meeting within the meeting between Europe and Mercosur, where the real business will take place."
For Latin America, the conference offers a rare opportunity to gain concessions from the United States and Europe by playing them off against each other.
At the December 1994 Summit of the Americas in Miami, the United States and 32 Latin American and Caribbean nations agreed to establish a Free Trade Area of the Americas and set 2005 as a deadline. But that process has stalled, and many nations in the region have shifted their focus to reaching agreements among themselves and with European and Asian nations.
"From the Brazilian point of view, we are not putting too much pressure on the hemispheric free-trade-area idea," Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the President of Brazil, said in a recent interview.
The idea for the European-Latin American summit meeting emerged from a visit to Brazil in 1997 by Jacques Chirac, the President of France. The notion was endorsed by Brazil and its Mercosur partners, who see stronger ties to Europe as offering the only possible counterweight to the United States' historical hegemony.
But as talks for an agenda for the conference advanced, France has proved to be the main obstacle to beginning formal negotiations aimed at a free-trade pact. The Mercosur group wants nothing excluded, while the French, fearing that a flood of meat, grain, sugar and even wine from Mercosur would ruin its heavily subsidized farmers, have been insisting that agriculture be excluded.
"Europe has to make a decision," Mr. Cardoso said. "If it really believes that it has a role to play, it has to take into account that the interests of other parts of the world include agriculture."
But if Europe insists on its current agricultural policies, he said, "Well, then we always have the Free Trade Area of the Americas."
The French position has been resisted both by Germany, the European Union's biggest member, and Portugal and Spain, which have built on their historical linguistic and cultural ties to become, along with Britain and Italy, large investors in the region. "Europe must understand that it is strategic for its global position to deepen relations with Mercosur," Portugal's Prime Minister, Antonio Guterres, said recently.
In a meeting in Luxembourg on Monday, the European Union agreed to grant its delegations here the power to authorize formal talks. Mercosur officials said that step was no guarantee that there would be success here.
Had Europe failed to grant that authority, it would have created "a very awkward, very difficult, incomprehensible situation," Manuel Marin, a Spaniard who is the European Union's top expert in Latin American affairs, told reporters. "I can't propose marriage and then 20 days before the wedding say, 'I don't like you,' " he said.
There has also been some disagreement about a timetable for negotiations. The Latin Americans are eager to begin talks immediately and want to set a deadline of 2005 to coincide with the schedule of the hemispheric free-trade talks, while the French have been suggesting a delay.
"For the United States, the best thing that could happen would be a postponement" of talks between Europe and Mercosur, said Gilberto Dupas, coordinator of the International Affairs division of the Institute for Advanced Studies at the University of Sao Paulo. "The tracks are already being laid for the Free Trade Area of the Americas, and once you have that in place, it is easy for the locomotive to start moving."

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton Looks Home

 BODY:
After an all-consuming detour to press the war in Yugoslavia, and with only 18 months left in office, President Clinton has returned to his domestic agenda. Its emphasis, Mr. Clinton indicated yesterday at his news conference, is to get a budget deal with Congress that shores up Medicare and Social Security, while passing gun control and protections for patients in health maintenance organizations. He will also work to alleviate poverty in parts of the country that have not benefited from the economic boom. The President's new drive on these issues is welcome. It is not clear that the partisan rancor left over from impeachment, and extending into the recent gun control debate, will allow for compromise. But with the distraction of the war fading, it will be worth a try.
The President reached out repeatedly to Republican leaders to work with him on various issues. His renewed request for campaign finance reform was especially encouraging. On the budget, Mr. Clinton seemed to suggest a willingness to accommodate Republican demands for using at least some of the surplus for tax cuts. His gesture may have been a tacit recognition of reports that the Congressional Budget Office will raise its estimates of the budget surplus, making more money available for possible tax cuts, increased defense spending, debt reduction and rescuing the big national retirement programs from future insolvency. 
 Reaching consensus on these issues will not be easy with a campaign heating up. That was clear as Mr. Clinton was asked repeatedly about political matters, including the possible Senate run by his wife in New York. He seemed to be defensive about his relationship with Vice President Al Gore, who sharply criticized Mr. Clinton's moral lapses in announcing his own campaign for the Presidency.
Despite Mr. Clinton's intentions to concentrate on domestic issues, NATO's attempts to pacify Kosovo may well continue to demand his attention. The President became most animated and reflective yesterday when he was asked about the war in the Balkans. To questions about why he had not gotten a "bounce" in his approval ratings, Mr. Clinton said he did not much care. Then he narrowed his eyes and flashed his temper in declaring that Serbs would not get "one red cent" of reconstruction aid until they "get out of denial" on their ethnic rampage in Kosovo and replace Slobodan Milosevic as President.
As for Congress, Mr. Clinton seemed to agree when reminded that some Democrats and Republicans would rather run on their disputes over domestic issues than reach bipartisan agreement for legislation. He was right to say that everyone does better in elections when there are results to run on.
