HEADLINE: Excerpts From the President's Remarks on Kosovo and National Issues

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today by President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:
 
Prepared Remarks
 Earlier today, in a speech at Georgetown University, I discussed the opportunities now before our nation. Before I take questions, let me just take a moment to recap what I believe is America's agenda in the coming months. 
 Our trip to Europe advanced America's ideals and interests. Working with our partners, we won an agreement to ban abusive child labor everywhere in the world, took new steps to strengthen the global economy, agreed to triple the debt relief provided for many of the poorest nations, and to strengthen democracy and reform in Russia.
We also worked together to put in place the building blocks of peace in Kosovo, and to put the Balkans on a shared path to a prosperous, united future. I will meet with the region's leaders later this summer to give the process further momentum.
I met with Kosovar refugees in Macedonia who are planning to return home. They thanked America and our allies for giving them a chance to reclaim their lives on their native land. I also met with and thanked some of the American airmen and women who achieved this success, and with some of our and other NATO troops who are going into Kosovo now to make sure we win the peace. They know that they're doing the right thing, and I am very proud of all of them.
While America is enjoying success abroad, it is important that we keep pushing forward on our challenges here at home. This is a time of great hope for our nation. Yesterday we learned that the Americaneconomy grew at 4.3 percent in the first three months of this year. America plainly is on the right track. But we will be judged by what we do with this opportunity, whether we seize it or squander it in petty bickering and partisan animosity. There will be plenty of time for politics in the months to come. This summer should be a season of progress.
We should start by acting quickly on issues where most lawmakers, Democratic and Republican, agree. Legislation to let disabled Americans keep their Medicaid health insurance when they go to work. An increase in the minimum wage. Campaign finance reform. A strong and enforceable patient's bill of rights. I was heartened that earlier today the House overwhelmingly passed legislation making sure that foster children are not cast out in the cold when their time in foster care ends. This is a vital issue, one that Hillary has championed for many years, and I am very pleased by the House action.
Then we must turn to broader ways and in some ways more difficult challenges facing our nation.
First, we have a duty to maintain the fiscal discipline that has produced our prosperity and use it to strengthen Social Security and Medicare for the 21st century, and to pay down our national debt. On Tuesday I will propose the detailed plan to modernize Medicare, cutting cost, improving service and helping senior citizens with their greatest growing need -- affordable prescription drugs.
Second, we must widen the circle of opportunity by investing in education while demanding accountability and insisting that Congress keep our commitment of last year to finish hiring 100,000 more teachers, to lower class size in the early grades.
Third, in two weeks I will be joined by corporate, civic and political leaders of both parties on a four-day tour of America's new markets, the places in our country which have not yet felt the surge of our prosperity, to mobilize the private sector to bring jobs and growth to our poorest neighborhoods, and to build support for our new markets initiative, to give tax credits and loan guarantees to those who invest in America on the same terms we give to those invest in developing economies overseas.
And fourth, in the wake of the tragedy at Littleton, we must continue to meet the challenge of youth violence. Hillary and I are developing a national campaign on youth violence, working with parents, educators, the entertainment industry and others, but we also must take sensible steps to take guns out of the hands of criminals and away from children. We can't expect young people to stand up to violence if Congress won't stand up to the gun lobby.
I proposed, and with a tie-breaking vote by Vice President Gore, the Senate passed the measure to close the gun show loophole. The Senate also passed legislation to require child safety locks, to ban large ammunition clips for assault weapons, to ban violent juveniles from owning handguns as adults. Two weeks ago, the Republicans in the House blocked that measure. They would even weaken the current law by letting criminals store their guns at pawn shops.
Now, there is still time for Congress to act. The Republican leaders could appoint legislators as negotiators to craft a bill thatincludes the tough Senate provisions. I hope they will do that and send me a strong bill. Plainly, the country wants that. Again, I say, this is sort of like the patient's bill of rights -- it's really not a partisan issue anywhere but Washington, D.C. I hope they will send me a strong bill. If they send me one that weakens current law, I will send it back to them and keep working until we get the job done right.
Now this is, admittedly, an ambitious agenda, but it can all be done in the coming months. I will use all the powers available to me as President, working with Congress and with my executive authority. I will summon the citizens of our country to help us to solve these problems. This is a good time for America, but we will be judged by whether we make the most of it. I look forward to making the effort. . . .
 
Questions and Answers
 Q. Mr. President, this morning and again just now, you made references to a summer of progress, and you were calling for bipartisanship to try to accomplish things in the next few months. I'm just wondering, with the 2000 campaign obviously heating up and growing in intensity, do you feel there's more of an urgency to act right away, within the coming months?
A. Well, I think----. For one thing, I think it would be to everyone's advantage to continue to make progress.
As I always tell Republicans and Democrats, no matter how much we do, there will still be plenty of things on which there is honest disagreement over which the next election can be fought; that is, it's just in the nature of things. That's healthy. That's good. That's the two-party system in America.
But we are all hired by the American people to work here, day in and day out, week in and week out, and we make a grave mistake -- and it's almost never good politics -- to do the wrong thing; that is, to take a pass on making progress when you can do it.
And this is a very unusual moment, where we have sustained prosperity, the longest peacetime expansion in our history. We've gone from having the biggest deficits in history to having the biggest surpluses in history. And yet we have these looming demographic challenges of Social Security and Medicare. We have----. And we have these big issues that are right before us now, the ones I mentioned, on which there is basically broad agreement. So I think that it would be good for America and therefore good for everyone involved if we go ahead and do this.
And I think that obviously, the closer you get to the election, perhaps the more difficult it will be. But I expect -- I'll make you a prediction here -- I expect that we'll get some good things done in the year 2000 before the Congress recesses finally for the election then. I expect to keep working right up to the very end, and I think that we will continue to make progress. But the most important thing is the attitude of the main players in Congress, insofar as Congress has to play a role in this.

 Q. Sir, I'd like to ask you about Medicare and your plans that you are going to be announcing next week.
This is a program that tens of millions of Americans depend on. And yet in 15 years, it will be effectively bankrupt. And you are about the propose what could be a very costly additional benefit in the prescription benefit. Why are you going to do that, sir? Isn't that going to make the problem worse, not better?
A. No. For one thing -- but let me remind you that we have taken a lot of very tough positions to reform Medicare since 1993. When I took office, Medicare was supposed to go broke this year. And now it is out to -- what is it? 2015 or so. So we have taken a lot of important positions already.
And as a matter of fact, as I am sure you are all aware, a lot of the health-care providers -- particularly rural hospitals, nursing homes, home-health providers, a disproportionate share of hospitals -- that's the funding -- for the folks listening to us, that is basically inner-city hospitals and teaching hospitals that have a whole lot of poor folks they take care of who aren't reimbursed; a lot of those people believe that our savings are too great. But we've taken some very tough actions to try to lengthen the life of the Medicare Trust Fund.
When I make my proposals on Tuesday, there will be more to lengthen the life further, to make sure that we get through the first quarter century and maybe more of this -- of the new century with Medicare alive and well.
But if you look at the long run, I think it's important that we propose a prescription drug benefit, because life expectancy is going up, drugs are being constantly developed which help to improve the quality as well as the length of life, and if they are properly taken, they can actually reduce long-term hospitalization and other medical costs.
Now it is absolutely true that if we design this wrong, it could wind up being a lot more expensive than rosy scenarios suggest. But if you look at my record here over the last six and a half years, I've tried to be quite conservative in my budget projections and quite responsible in handling the budget of the country. And you will see that, I think, reflected in the way I make this proposal, including the prescription drugs.
But I don't really think there's any alternative here. You've got 15 million Americans, seniors out there, without any kind of coverage for their medicine. You've got millions and millions of others with inadequate or highly expensive coverage. And I just -- I really believe that this is the most significant health care need that senior citizens have today.
And I believe that over the long run, the proper availability, properly priced, of prescription medicine will actually not only lengthen lives and improve the quality of life of our seniors and improve their security, their state of mind, but it will also, long, long term, save medical costs because it will keep people out of hospitals and out of more expensive treatments.
Q. What is your strategy now, Mr. President, for a comprehensive campaign finance reform, to really make it pass?
A. Well, I think the best strategy is to get, you know, a clear majority of the House of Representatives to demand that it come up, and then try to put enough pressure on to get the Senate leaders to let it come up. Basically, the Republican leadership in the Senate has said that they're just not going to permit it to come up because they don't want their people who will vote against it to have a recorded vote on it, and they don't want to run the risk that they've got enough of their folks that would vote with all of ours -- see, all of our people are for it. We've got 100 percent of the Democrats in the Senate for it.
And so what I think we have to do is to keep it on the front burner enough so that the discomfort level rises high enough that an actual vote is allowed. All I'd really ask for here is a vote. If we'd just get a vote on the bill, I will be very well satisfied, and I think it will come out just fine.
 
 Q. When Vice President Gore announced officially for President, he chose a date when you were going to be out of the country. And according to Mrs. Clinton's supporters, if she announces her exploratory committee in the next couple of weeks, it would be at a time when you've got a commitment to go out to South Dakota. Do you think your personal behavior has made you something of a liability to those who are running? And did you take any -- take it personally when Vice President Gore made his announcement and seemed to set himself so clearly separate from you when it came to issues of family?
A. Well, first of all, I thought, as I have said repeatedly, I thought the Vice President had a great announcement. And what he really said in his announcement -- I actually heard it, so I don't have to have it characterized for me -- what he said in his announcement was that he had had more experience than anybody running, which is true, that he would put forward more specific ideas about what he would do if he were elected President than anyone has to date, by far, which is true, and that the choice before the American people was whether we would build on the progress that we've made for the last six years or turn around and go backwards, which is what I think the real choice will be before the American people. So I approved of that.
And as far as his doing it when I was out of the country, I thought that was a good thing. Very often, you'd be amazed how many times over the last six and a half years, we have planned for certain announcements to be made by the Vice President when I was out of the country because that way, it gets -- I mean, far be it for us to try to maneuver the press, but he gets more -- he gets better coverage and I get better coverage. I'm out of the country, so -- and he gets better coverage. So I thought that was a good thing. . . .

Q. It seems to me that one of our big issues is parenting. That causes divorces, and it causes unhappy children and the break-up of families. Is there any way that we can design a national program to correct or to educate people to be better parents?
A. You know, it is interesting. To go to your point, when Hillary and I decided that we ought to have this grass-roots campaign to try to protect children against violence and we began to talk to parents who started the Mothers Against Violence movement in Washington State and others, one of the things that we learned, obviously, is that a lot of young people wind up being -- especially really troubled young people can often be almost strangers in their own homes.
And we assume that people ought to just know how to do the most important jobs in life. And they're very often reluctant to ask for help, but I think one of the things that we have to try to do is to develop the kind of supports that parents need to do a better job. And it's a much harder job now than it used to be, especially since the average parent is away from his or her children for 22 hours a week more than was the case 30 years ago. So I do think that we need to do some more. . .
Q. Sir, we're told that next week the Administration will announce that the Federal budget surplus is even larger than you had previously projected. Given that, and given your words today about bipartisanship, do you think now it might be possible to tackle Medicare and Social Security reform, and perhaps reach out to Republicans and open the door to a larger tax cut than you have discussed previously?
A. First, I'm not against tax cuts. I'm not against giving the American people some of this money back from our present prosperity right now.
The question is, what kind of tax cut? Who benefits from it? How should it be designed? And how should it be handled to guarantee that we're going to take care of first things first -- strengthening Social Security and Medicare, paying down the debt, continuing to secure the health of the American economy? Keep in mind, what produced the surplus was the strength of the American economy, the fact that we had the will to do the very tough things in 1993 and that we followed it up with a balanced budget act in 1997.
So my plan has tax cuts. The U.S.A. accounts are worth literally hundreds and hundreds of dollars to most families every year. They could be worth a quarter of a million dollars to a family over their lifetime, the most progressive inducement to save in the history of the country. We had-- --. We have tax cuts fully paid for already for long-term care, for child care, for school construction, for investing in the inner cities. So I'm not against tax cuts.
We have had tax cuts in the past, big tax cuts for tuition tax credits for college, the Hope scholarship tax cuts, tax cuts for working families with modest incomes, the child-care tax credit, $500 per child. We've had lots of tax cuts. I am not opposed to that.
What I want to do is to make sure that before we go off and start cutting taxes by some arbitrary, large amount, we take care of first things first. We need to know that we're going to modernize and strengthen Social Security for the 21st century, that we're going to modernize and strengthen Medicare for the 21st century, and that we're going to do it in a way that will enable us to continue to pay the debt down.
There will still money for a tax cut, and a sizable one. Will I work with the Congress on that? Of course, I will. If I want to pass it, I have to work with them. They are in the majority. Of course, I will.
But first things first. We have got to get our priorities in order here.
The American people plainly expect us, first of all, to keep the economy going. And the best way to do that is to send a signal to the markets that we have resolved Social Security, we have resolved Medicare and we are paying the debt down. That is the most important thing we could to guarantee long-term economic growth.
And secondly, the only other point I want to make is, I do not believe that it is responsible to have a tax cut if the impact of the tax cut, plus the defense increases that we have had to adopt, plus the highway expenditures that the Congress wants to adopt, is to cut education or cut health care or cut our investments in the environment. So there is enough money to do all these things and to do it really well with great discipline, but we have to have our priorities in order.
Q. The polls are also showing that although people do acknowledge that they're doing better in the economy and that they're doing well personally, they show a deep concern for the nation's moral fabric and, actually, that concern seems to be growing. What responsibility do you, personally, take for that? And what can you in the White House do to address these moral problems that seem to be cropping up more and more in the polls?
A. Well, I think people are worried about, I think the most important thing on that is what happened, the shattering effect that Littleton had. In terms of what happened to me and the impeachment issue, I did what I could by telling the American people what I was going to do; that I was going to go back to work being the best President I could be, and I was going to go back to work to try to repair my family life. I have worked very hard for a year to do that. And the public, at the time, had a strong response to that. That's all I can do and that's what I have done. I have done that very faithfully. So I don't think that's what's going on.
I think people are worried when they see, you know, the fabric of life still under great strain, in spite of the fact that we have quite a large amount of prosperity. And I think what we all have to do is to ask yourselves what can we do to reinforce the ability of families to raise their children, to teach them right from wrong, to increase the chances that they'll be able to live strong, whole lives. And I believe, therefore, that there is in that sense a moral component to the debate we're having over guns.
I mean, basically, we know now----. Let me just give you one example. We know from the experience with the Brady bill that if we do background checks, thousands of people at gun shows, thousands of people who shouldn't buy guns won't get them. Now, we know that. I think that's a positive moral value.
But people on the other side essentially say, "Yeah, but we don't want to be inconvenienced." And when people see inconvenience elevated over the life of a child, in this context I think that causes some problems. We know that in the case of the patient's bill of rights, that people think it's a moral issue if they need to see a specialist or they need -- if they get hurt in an accident and they can't go to the nearest emergency room. They know that. And when they see, in effect, someone else's convenience elevated over that, I think that's a problem for them.
So I think that there are lots----. This is a complicated thing. But my own view of that is what we have to do is not pretend that the Government can solve all the moral questions, not evade what people have to do personally in their own lives with their own families, but neither can we take the dodge that the Government has no responsibility.
And that's why -- I tried so hard after that Littleton incident -- that is why I am so disappointed in what Congress did in the House on this gun issue -- because I tried so hard after that Littleton incident not to play politics, not to point the finger at anybody, not to say, "Oh well, it is this, that or the other thing"; you know that I went to Hollywood; I challenged the entertainment community, even though they had done far more to try to move the ball forward than anybody in the gun community until the gun manufacturers started helping. And they have done a good job, too, a lot of them.
And I still believe that people think that there is too much of "everybody for himself" and that people can get away with what they do because of they -- their position they'll do it.
And you know, I think what I tried to do was to acknowledge that, to whatever extent I had done that, it was dead wrong, and I was going to spend the rest of my life trying to rectify that, which is all anybody can do. And that's why -- and I think most people accept that. They'd rather have somebody do that than go around trying to give a lot of speeches about how good they are and then open the door for the gun lobby to run the Congress. . . .
Q. Mr. President, wartime Presidents, even the great ones -- Lincoln, Wilson or Roosevelt -- all discovered that wars never went exactly the way they planned it. In Kosovo, what surprised you or went a way that you didn't expect? And what lessons did you learn in Kosovo?
A. The bombing went on----. I had two models in my mind on what would happen with the bombing campaign. I thought it would either be over within a couple of days, because Mr. Milosevic would see we were united, or if he decided to sustain the damage to his country, that it would take quite a long while for the damage to actually reach the point where it was unsustainable. It took only a little longer than I thought it would, once we got into the second model.
But I was surprised about some of the things. I was surprised that it took----. I was surprised, on the one hand, that we only, that we lost no pilots. I was surprised by that. I was surprised that we lost only two planes and no pilots. I know that from your point of view, there were a lot of civilian casualties, but that's because you got to cover them, as opposed to covering the civilian casualties of the Gulf War. If you talk to any military person who was involved in both conflicts, they will tell you that there were far, far more civilian casualties in Iraq -- I mean many more, by several times as many.
I was a little surprised that we had no more problems than we did in maintaining our allied unity, given the enormous pressures that were on some of our allies. And I think that gives you some indication about the depth of conviction people had that this was right.
And let me just say this: I think one way to understand this----. I almost never see this, but let me just----. I say, one way to understand this, about why we all did what we did when we did, even when a lot of folks thought we were crazy, or at least thought we couldn't prevail, is I don't think I can even----. I was----. I was surprised and heartbroken that the Chinese Embassy was hit because of the mapping accidents. I mean, that did surprise me. I had no earthly idea that our system would permit that kind of mistake. That was the biggest surprise of all.
But let me just say one other thing. I think that when you look at this conflict and you seek to understand, "Well, why did President Clinton do this, why did Tony Blair do this, why did Jacques Chirac go along, why did the Germans get in there with both feet so early, given their history and all this?" I think you have to see this through the lens of Bosnia.
And keep in mind, in Bosnia we had the U.N. in there first in a peacekeeping mission, and we tried for four years, you know, 50 different diplomatic solutions, all those different maps, all that different argument, and in the end of it all, from 1991 to 1995, we still had Srebrenica.
We still had -- you know, and when it was all said and done, we had a quarter of a million people dead and two and a half million refugees. And I think what you have to understand is that we saw this through the lens of Bosnia. And we said we are not going to wait a day, not a day if we can stop it. Once he had----. Once we knew there was a military plan, they had all those soldiers deployed, they had all those tanks deployed, you know, we knew what was coming and we decided to move.
So, yes, there were surprises along the way. I'm terribly sorry about the embassy. We made our report -- I've gotten a report and the Chinese got -- I made sure the Chinese got essentially the same report I did. We didn't put any varnish on it. And I'm sorry about it.
But our pilots, on the whole, did a superb job and we did the right thing. And I hope that the American people, as time goes on, will feel more and more strongly that we did. . . .
Q. Mr. President, you have been very much involved in the last few weeks in an attempt to create a Balkan reconstruction program. Many people, including yourself, have referred to the Marshall Plan after World War II as kind of a comparison to what you want to accomplish. And yet, you and Administration officials have insisted that Serbia cannot be involved in this until Milosevic is out.
Given the nature of the Balkan economy, which is a very integrated area with the electricity networks, the transportation networks, the Danube River, which is a unifying force which unites the entire region, isn't it a folly to try and conduct a program of this nature by excluding Serbia, and really economically impossible; without Serbia as a part of the picture, you cannot really get the whole economy moving?
And secondly, is there not a danger -- I realize that you have said that the reason for excluding Serbia was to try and get the Serb people to reject Milosevic, but isn't there a danger that they may indeed coalesce around Milosevic, feeling themselves as victims, and support him in spite of his own personal character simply because of the bitterness toward the West after the bombing and the sanctions and now what they feel is disappointment over the reconstruction?
A. Well, to answer your question, first of all, I don't think it's folly or impossible to think we can have a Balkans reconstruction plan, a Southeastern Europe reconstruction plan without Serbia; but it would be terribly unfortunate and more difficult.
What will happen is that new networks will be formed and the relative importance of Serbia will be diminished if they're not a part of it. But it will be much more difficult and it will be very unfortunate.
Now, having said that, what the Serbian people decide to do, of course, is their own affair. But, you know, they're going to have to come to grips with what Mr. Milosevic ordered in Kosovo. They're just going to have to come to grips with it. And, you know, they're going to have to get out of denial; they're going to have to come to grips with it. And then they're going to have to decide whether they support his leadership or not; whether they think it's O.K. that all those tens of thousands of people were killed and all those hundreds of thousands of people were run out of their homes and all those little girls were raped and all those little boys were murdered. They're going to have to decide if they think that is O.K., and if they think it's O.K., they can make that decision, but I wouldn't give them one red cent for reconstruction if they think it's O.K. because I don't think it's O.K. and I don't think that's the world we're trying to build for our children.
So I think it's simple, and I'm -- you know -- look, I met with Mr. Milosevic in Paris, I shook hands with him, I had lunch across from the table from him. It was a delightful and interesting lunch. And I thought, well, you know, maybe he had some distance between the extreme activities of the Serbs in Bosnia. And then he went right out and did it all over again, and I mean with people directly under his control. And I do not believe we should give them any money for reconstruction if they believe that is the person who should lead them into the new century. I do not, and I will not support it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Nasdaq and S.& P. Decline; Dow Jones Rises 17 Points
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.34 points, to 2,552.65, as trading was slow and investors awaited the meeting Tuesday and Wednesday of the Federal Open Market Committee. Investors expect the Federal Reserve's policy-making panel to raise short-term interest rates a quarter percentage point to head off inflation.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.47 point, to 1,315.31, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.73 points, to 10,552.56. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined to 6.15 percent from 6.16 percent on Thursday. Page C3.
 
Economy Growing at a 4.3% Rate
Torrid consumer spending helped the gross domestic product -- the nation's output of goods and services -- grow at a brisk annual rate of 4.3 percent in the first quarter of the year, the Commerce Department reported. C4.
 
Priests Say They Were Duped
In Rome, two priests, the Rev. Peter Jacobs, 73, an American, and Monsignor Emilio Colagiovanni, 79, a scholarly Italian, provided a clerical cloak of respectability for a money manager who authorities suspect embezzled more than $300 million from American insurance companies. Both men insist they were duped by Martin R. Frankel, who disappeared last month and is wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. A1.
 
Campbell Earnings to Fall Short
Campbell Soup said that earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter would fall 8 cents to 10 cents a share below analysts' forecasts of 38 cents a share and that it planned to reorganize its soup operations. Mark M. Leckie, the president of the company's domestic soup division, will leave the company. He will be succeeded at the new North American division by F. Martin Thrasher, now the company's president of European and Canadian operations. C4.
 
Nissan's Western-Style Meeting
In Japan, where annual shareholders' meetings, are traditionally closed affairs, Nissan Motor moved to Western-style openness, allowing news coverage. But the reward for the troubled company's president, Yoshikazu Hanawa, left, was a scolding gadfly shareholder who identified himself only as Mr. Tamura and demanded his resignation, saying, "You've made mistake after mistake." Next Tuesday, 1,374 companies, or 88 percent of Japan's listed companies, are to hold their meetings. C2.
 
Latin-European Trade Meeting Set
Seeking to increase trade and gain a counterweight to American global economic dominance, leaders of Latin America and Europe, the world's second- and third-largest trading blocs, are to meet in Rio de Janeiro this weekend and early next week. Their summit meeting, their first, has already proved contentious on several basic issues, notably French insistence that farm products be excluded from any free-trade pact. C2.
 
In Indonesia, a Step Toward Health
In Indonesia, the agreement this week between PT Astra International and its creditors on how the big company, which assembles Toyota utility vehicles and Honda motorcycles, will pay back more than $1 billion in debt is being heralded as evidence that the nation is on the mend. But Indonesia is by no means well. C2.
 
BBC's New Head Stirs Controversy
The British Broadcasting Corporation stirred passionate debate by appointing as its new head Greg Dyke, a millionaire Labor Party supporter associated with "Baywatch" and a puppet called Roland Rat. He has been head of Pearson Television, but the Conservative opposition focused on his Labor ties. A3.
 
Covance and Parexel Halt Merger
Covance and Parexel International, two drug-development companies, called off their planned merger, originally valued at more than $600 million. C3.

HEADLINE: F.B.I. IS PROPOSING A SPECIAL DIVISION FOR HUNTING SPIES

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The F.B.I. is proposing to create a division devoted solely to rooting out spies, part of a Government-wide review of counterintelligence following suspicions that China tried for two decades to steal nuclear secrets, Government officials said today.
After the cold war and the breakup of the Soviet Union, American intelligence agencies increasingly focused on fighting terrorism, believing that espionage would become less of a threat. As a result, counterintelligence efforts dwindled, according to experts inside and outside the Government. 
 At the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for instance, the national security division added counterterrorism operations to its traditional emphasis on fighting espionage. Officials said there was a sense that as the battle against terrorism became more important, counterespionage operations were given less priority.
Now officials are proposing new ways the Government should organize to make sure that there is an emphasis on both threats, the officials said. Some aspects of the review were first reported by The Los Angeles Times.
The F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, has proposed splitting the national security division into two divisions, one to fight terrorism and the other to root out spies, both led by assistant directors, the officials said. Attorney General Janet Reno has approved the request and forwarded it to the White House, they added.
The Government-wide review also includes the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency and is expected to lead to an overhaul of all counterintelligence efforts.
The review is a tacit acknowledgment that the Government has failed to keep pace with new forms of espionage, in a world of scientist-to-scientist contacts and academic conferences. The United States faces not only efforts to steal military secrets, but also economic espionage aimed at stealing technology or getting information that would help a country's goods compete against American products. The espionage is conducted not only by foreign governments and military intelligence services, but also by corporations.
The review represents the first time the three agencies have collaborated on a systematic assessment of espionage threats.
A new division of the F.B.I. devoted solely to counterintelligence would add agents and analysts to the efforts against foreign espionage, increasing the agency's staff.
The bureau is likely to revise its traditional system of assessing threats and allocating budgets on a country-by-country basis, known as the National Security Threat List, officials said. The bureau will broaden its assessments of risk, including threats from corporations and even international criminal organizations.
At the Pentagon, the review will focus on threats to the military and the risk that contractors, academics and research laboratories that work with the agency could provide important information to other nations, said Kenneth Bacon, the Defense Department spokesman. "The review will analyze the threat and determine whether our response is adequate," he said.
At the C.I.A., officials said that only preliminary discussions had been held to review counterintelligence operations. George J. Tenet, the Director of Central Intelligence, and Mr. Freeh testified on Wednesday before the Senate Intelligence Committee about the review.
The Government is changing procedures at the country's nuclear weapons laboratories. Those changes, including special squads of F.B.I. agents at the labs, are being handled by officials at the bureau and the Energy Department. The reorganization plan is a reaction to criticism of the Government's handling of suspected Chinese espionage at the labs.
Some lawmakers said the F.B.I. and the Justice Department had failed to investigate aggressively possible instance of Chinese espionage including cases like that of Wen Ho Lee, the nuclear scientist suspected of helping the Chinese acquire advance thermonuclear technology. Mr. Lee has denied that he ever spied for China, and Chinese officials have denied stealing nuclear secrets.
F.B.I. officials said the Lee case showed how hard it was to insure the safety of American security secrets in an environment of informal contacts between scientists working in exotic disciplines that are often hard to ferret out and evaluate.
Some law enforcement officials have said the increasing focus on counterterrorism cases, including both domestic and international investigations, had drawn attention of senior managers away from the ongoing and often unglamorous counterintelligence work of keeping track of foreign visitors and Americans traveling abroad.
Reorganizing counterintelligence operations represents the latest step in the long and often troubled relationship between the agencies primarily responsible for catching spies, the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. Throughout most of the cold war era, the two agencies were often at odds over counterintelligence policy, jealously guarding their turf.
F.B.I. agents and C.I.A. officers recruited their own informants and often refused to share leads and information about potential cases. At times, the counterspy operations seemed to spin out of control. James J. Angleton, the counterintelligence chief at the C.I.A., conducted zealous hunts for suspected moles at the agency, an effort that threatened to bring the agency to standstill and ruined the careers of loyal agency employees.
Fledging cooperative efforts in the 1980's culminated in the successful prosecution of the Aldrich H. Ames, the C.I.A. officer who in 1993 pleaded guilty to spying for Moscow after an investigation concluded that he had turned over to the Russians the identities of more than a dozen East bloc officials who were secretly spying for the United States.
After the Ames case, a shattering experience for the C.I.A., new rules were adopted to require the agency to report possible security breaches to the F.B.I. The two agencies have exchanged personnel to work on counterintelligence matters, and Mr. Freeh and Mr. Tenet have sought to forge a better relationship.
Specific events have helped, like the F.B.I.'s arrest in Pakistan in 1997 of Mir Amal Kansi, who was returned to the United States and convicted of killing two people in 1993 outside C.I.A. headquarters.

Energy Official Resigns
 By The New York Times
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The first senior Government official to lose his post in the furor over Chinese spying charges resigned today. Victor Reis, an Assistant Secretary of Energy who oversaw the nuclear weapons laboratories, submitted his resignation to Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, an Energy Department spokeswoman said.
Mr. Reis was one of many Energy Department and lab officials to come under fire for counterintelligence problems at the Government's weapons labs. He had also angered Mr. Richardson by aligning himself with Republican senators who have proposed legislation that would create an agency in the department to handle the nuclear weapons programs.
The department's inspector general is conducting an investigation into the handling of the spy case. It is expected to be completed in about a month, when Mr. Richardson is expected to announce disciplinary action against other officials, possibly including dismissals.

HEADLINE: How 2 Priests Got Mixed Up In a Huge Insurance Scandal

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, June 25

 BODY:
As priests, they make an unlikely pair. One is an affable, worldly American bon vivant who zooms around Rome on a raffish blue motorbike and defied his New York archbishop in the 1980's by running a trendy Manhattan restaurant to raise money for the poor. The other is an owlish Italian canon law scholar who serves as an emeritus judge on the Roman Rota, the court of appeals of the Holy See.
Together, the Rev. Peter Jacobs, 73, and Msgr. Emilio Colagiovanni, 79, provided a clerical cloak of respectability for a Greenwich, Conn., money manager who authorities suspect embezzled more than $300 million from insurers across the United States. Both men insist they were badly duped by Martin R. Frankel, who disappeared last month and is wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 The priests say they knew Mr. Frankel as David Rosse, a middle-aged tycoon who claimed descent from the Jewish King David and said he was eager to give at least $50 million to the church.
They supported the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation, a charity Mr. Frankel set up and then tried to use to buy several American insurance companies . He named Father Jacobs president of that foundation. Monsignor Colagiovanni, who had his own foundation, said he went a step further, giving Mr. Frankel's charity power to move funds in and out of the Vatican bank account of Monsignor Colagiovanni's foundation.
With Federal investigators in the United States scouring the records of Mr. Frankel's intricate financial transactions, those actions have left both priests exposed and vulnerable. And it has turned both into virtual pariahs inside the Vatican.
The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said there was no link whatsoever between the Vatican and Mr. Frankel. He also denied any connection between Monsignor Colagiovanni's Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation and the Vatican.
Yet before the scandal erupted, senior Vatican officials were also intrigued by Mr. Frankel's professed desire to shower riches on church charities. At least two senior Vatican officials met with Mr. Frankel's American lawyer, Thomas A. Bolan, and tried to help his client set up a charitable foundation that would be part of the Vatican.
Mr. Bolan, a former law partner of the late Roy Cohn, met in Rome to discuss the foundation with Bishop Francesco Salerio Salerno, and Monsignor Gianfranco Piovano, top Vatican officials, according to his lawyer, Maurice R. Nessen, and the two priests. Reading from his notes of what Mr. Bolan recollects, Mr. Nessen said tonight that the meetings in Rome centered on how an outside philanthropist could channel money through the Vatican to support religious causes.
Church officials have been highly sensitive to any hint of a banking scandal since the 1980's, when the Vatican bank was badly tainted by its ties to the Banco Ambrosiana, which collapsed after a huge financial scandal.
Bishop Salerno is now secretary of the Apostolic Signatura, the supreme court of the church. At the time of the meeting with Mr. Bolan, he was secretary of the Prefecture for the Economic Affairs of the Holy See. In an interview today, Bishop Salerno said he had denied ever discussing the foundation with Mr. Bolan, though he said he did so with Monsignor Colagiovanni. "I could not refuse Monsignor Colagiovanni, he is a judge on the Roman Rota," he explained.
 
Hypothetical Approval For an American Role
Monsignor Salerno said he told other Vatican officials that "hypothetically" nothing would legally prevent an American financier from opening a charitable foundation in the Vatican. "The Vatican is a sovereign state, anything can be done, but the question is will it be authorized," Bishop Salerno said.
Mr. Nessen, Mr. Bolan's lawyer, said that his client had a later meeting with Monsignor Piovano, an assistant Vatican Secretary of State, who disagreed with Bishop Salerno, pointing out that Mr. Frankel could not be allowed to control a Vatican foundation's assets, especially since Mr. Frankel also wished to invest in insurance companies in America.
Eventually, however, the two sides worked out a compromise: the Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation, Monsignor Colagiovanni's cultural and charitable organization, could act as "founder" -- in legal terms as "settlor" -- of a new, independent foundation controlled by Mr. Frankel. According to Mr. Nessen, the new foundation would be named after St. Francis of Assisi and could claim links to the Vatican, as Mr. Frankel desired. Mr. Nessen said that Monsignor Salerno was aware of and approved this arrangement in advance. Asked in writing to respond, Bishop Salerno did not reply.
But after Mr. Frankel's suspected embezzlement schemes came to light, the Vatican sought to distance itself from the American -- and his associates in the church.
Mr. Navarro-Valls described Monsignor Colagiovanni, who as president of Monitor Ecclesiasticus edits a Vatican-approved canonical law quarterly and also runs its charitable arm, as a "pensioner." Mr. Navarro-Valls said he knew nothing about Father Jacobs, but volunteered that he was an "ex-Jew."
Bishop Salerno also pointed out Father Jacobs's Jewish roots after the scandal surfaced. Surprisingly, neither he nor Mr. Navarro-Valls nor others mentioned the fact that Father Jacobs was formally rebuked by the Roman Catholic Church in 1983, after he ignored an archbishop's order to cease operating his New York restaurant, The Palantine. Father Jacobs's right to perform priestly duties was suspended at that time because he violated church rules about business transactions.
Father Jacobs, who continues to serve mass and perform weddings, said in an interview that he believed his suspension was reversed in 1987 after he gave up the business. According to his archdiocese in Washington, however, the suspension was reversed, but not the ban on giving sacraments.
"Priestly faculties are like a medical license, and Father Jacobs's were never restored," Monsignor William E. Lori, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of Washington, explained on Thursday. "The sacraments he performed since 1983 are not valid."
Father Jacobs was born in New Hampshire, the son of a Jewish father and an Catholic mother. Father Jacobs was baptized as a Catholic, but he only began practicing his faith while serving in the Navy during World War II. He was ordained in 1955.
In his long, colorful and highly unorthodox career as a priest, he has made interfaith marriages a specialty. It was, in fact, an interfaith society wedding that brought Father Jacobs and Monsignor Colagiovanni together in 1994.
They first met, Monsignor Colagiovanni recalled in an interview, at the Vatican bank, known as the Istituto per le Opere di Religione. Monsignor Colagiovanni's foundation has an account there. Father Jacobs said that he was there visiting old friends who worked in the bank.
"He is a very social fellow," Monsignor Colagiovanni said of Father Jacobs. Soon after that meeting, Father Jacobs sought out Monsignor Colagiovanni's expertise in arranging a Catholic church wedding for a divorced Jewish man and a Catholic woman. Monsignor Colagiovanni said he had no idea at the time he was helping one of America's wealthiest men, Edgar Bronfman Jr. president of the Seagram Company, marry Clarissa Alcock, the daughter of an oil executive, in Caracas, Venezuela. Father Jacobs said he officiated at the service, alongside a local priest and a rabbi, over the objections of the local cardinal. An associate of the Bronfman family said that this was untrue, and that the local priest had officiated, with Father Jacobs serving as a "greeter."
 
Famous Connections Around the World
Father Jacobs, who has worked in the slums of New York and Washington, also hobnobs with European aristocrats and counts the late Princess Grace of Monaco, Walter Cronkite and Arrigo Cipriani and a restaurateur among his many friends. Another was Mr. Bolan.
In August of 1998, Monsignor Colagiovanni said he got another call from Father Jacobs when he was on holiday in Cleveland. "He told me there was a Jewish millionaire who wanted to do good things for the church and the poor," Monsignor Colagiovanni recalled.
He flew at Mr. Frankel's expense to New York, where he and Father Jacobs and Mr. Bolan had dinner at Cipriani's. Father Jacobs said he had known Mr. Bolan for 30 years and had helped him through a variety of family crises.
Soon after the dinner, all three men drove to Greenwich, Conn., to meet the aspiring benefactor. Both priests said they were surprised and impressed by Mr. Frankel's library, which was crammed with books on Catholicism, ranging from Papal encyclicals to hundreds of tomes devoted to St. Francis of Assisi. "He had actually read the encyclicals," Father Jacobs said. "Even I haven't read them all."
But the priest also noticed Mr. Frankel's weird side, particularly his obsessive fear of germs. "He reminded me of the Jack Nicholson character in 'As Good as it Gets,' who kept washing his hands over and over," Father Jacobs said.
Msg. Colagiovanni, like Father Jacobs, received from Mr. Frankel a 13-page autobiographical sketch that laid out his financial credentials and his piety, including his self-professed hero worship for Albert Schweitzer and St. Francis of Assisi. It said he was smitten by Franco Zefferelli's "Brother Sun, Sister Moon," which he said he saw "every day for five weekdays."
Msg. Colagiovanni said he was convinced of Mr. Frankel's good intentions, but he said that when Mr. Frankel explained his desire to give $50 million dollars to Catholic charities by setting up his own foundation at the Vatican, he told him that was impossible. "I explained no lay person could bank there," Mr. Colagiovanni said.
He said he encouraged Mr. Frankel to start his own private foundation. But Mr. Frankel was apparently so keen to bank at the Vatican that he dispatched his lawyer, Mr. Bolan, to Rome by Concorde to meet with Vatican officials and explain his offer.
The two sides eventually settled on the compromise and founded the St. Francis Foundation. Mr. Jacobs said that he learned that he was appointed a trustee and president of the St. Francis foundation after seeing his name on a document.
Mr. Frankel also ardently pursued celebrities to add legitimacy to his organization. Lee A. Iacocca, the former Chrysler chairman, rejected Mr. Frankel's overtures to serve on the St. Francis foundation board. But Mr. Frankel did not readily accept no for an answer: He paid for Mr. Iacocca to fly on a leased Gulfstream IV executive jet from Los Angeles to Milan, Italy, where Mr. Iacocca attended to some business, a spokesperson for Mr. Iacocca said.
And Mr. Frankel may have pressured Mr. Jacobs to use his own connections. Walter Cronkite said that he had received and rejected a request from Father Jacobs to serve on the advisory board. Mr. Cronkite heard nothing more about the matter until early May.
"Father Pete called and left a very cryptic message" at my office, Mr. Cronkite said. "He said 'the man who has given a billion dollars has apparently absconded with the money, the whole thing is a mess. I'm sorry I listed you as a member of the board of advisors. I hope it doesn't cause you any problems.' "
Msg. Colagiovanni said that he told Mr. Frankel he did not want to be involved with collecting funds or investing money. He signed over to Father Jacobs, president of the St. Francis Foundation, the right to use the bank account of the Monitor Ecclesiaticus Foundation, which is in the Vatican bank. But Mr. Frankel apparently never tapped that source: both priests said that Mr. Frankel never sent any money to either foundation.
Mr. Frankel instead used Mr. Colagiovanni's connections in a different way. Msgr. C said that the American financier persuaded him to sign a November 1998 affadavit that stated that funds contributed to the St. Francis Foundation came from "funds of the Holy See." Mr. Frankel's lawyers used that document to support their claims that Mr. Frankel's charity and business dealings had the approval of the Vatican.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
G.O.P. Looks for Ways To Seize on the Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The nation's long run of prosperity has left the Republican Presidential candidates with a crucial strategic choice: embrace the strong economy as their own, look for the dark side or change the subject.
But even as they grudgingly acknowledge that a strong economy helps the incumbent party in national elections -- and grapple with why their signature economic issue, tax cuts, does not seem to be lighting any fires among the increasingly well-off middle class -- the Republicans are unwilling to cede the issue to Vice President Al Gore. 
 The economy could still turn down in the 16 months before Election Day, and the Federal Reserve's likely decision to raise interest rates next week has given a case of jitters to the most visible indicator of confidence, the stock market. Moreover, polling suggests that voters in the early going are not giving Mr. Gore credit for the economy or much of anything.
Still, no one knows the political power of the economy better than the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. He watched a strong economy help his father, then Vice President, win the Presidency in 1988, and watched again as a weakened economy contributed to his father's loss to Bill Clinton four years later.
As he begins his campaign, Governor Bush is openly celebrating the nation's prosperity. But he is arguing that the American people, rather than Mr. Clinton or Mr. Gore, deserve the credit. And he is asserting that it is his policies that can best nurture the expansion and harness it to Republican ends -- while positioning himself to attack should the economy falter before the election.
Elizabeth Dole's campaign is betting that good times mean character and personality will eclipse the economy as an issue. Steve Forbes says a solid economic foundation provides the opportunity to address fundamental issues like taxes. Patrick J. Buchanan continues to pound away at the theme of economic nationalism, saying the global economy is leaving many Americans behind.
Struggling like his fellow Republicans to move from defense to offense on the issue, Lamar Alexander is trying a variant on the question that Ronald Reagan used to skewer Jimmy Carter in the 1980 election: Are you better off than you were four years ago?
"Today the question is whether we will have a better country four years from now," Mr. Alexander said in an interview, all but conceding that the original formulation of the question would blow up in the face of Republicans. "The answer is that we won't if our standards have sunk to a new low, if we have substandard schools, if taxes are higher and regulations grow."
Mr. Gore, of course, is aggressively laying out the case for why he, along with the President, should be rewarded for the current combination of steady growth, low unemployment, dormant inflation and a stock market that will not quit. Democratic strategists say the economy -- if it remains on track -- is one issue on which Mr. Gore should be all but invulnerable.
History gives the Republicans little hope.
In the 13 Presidential elections since World War II, there have been four cases where an incumbent, or a Vice President running to succeed him, suffered through recessions that extended to within less than two years of Election Day. In every case -- Richard M. Nixon in 1960, Gerald R. Ford in 1976, Mr. Carter in 1980 and George Bush in 1992 -- the incumbent or Vice President was beaten by the challenger.
(Mr. Nixon and Mr. Reagan cut the rule awfully close in two re-election campaigns. Mr. Nixon presided over an 11-month recession that ended in November 1970, but went on to an easy victory in 1972. Mr. Reagan presided over a 16-month recession that ended in November 1982, and went on to a landslide in 1984.)
By the same token, incumbent Presidents, or Vice Presidents running to succeed them, have won six of the seven elections since World War II in which they have been able to claim stewardship of a long-growing economy. The exception was Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey in 1968, when the Vietnam War overshadowed all other issues.
Cast in the role of challenger, Governor Bush is clearly looking for a way to turn the situation to his advantage.
His slogan "Prosperity With a Purpose" hints at a strategy of acknowledging the obvious and looking to use it both to advance traditional Republican goals like lower taxes and as a basis for his advocacy of "compassionate conservatism."
"The purpose of prosperity is to leave no one out, to leave no one behind," Mr. Bush said in announcing his candidacy. Mr. Bush said that prosperity "is not a given," that it was not invented by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore "any more than they created the Internet" and that policies he supports like tax cuts, restrictions on lawsuits, free trade and a partial privatizing of Social Security would help keep the good times rolling.
"Governor Bush has developed an economic program that will be good for the country whether the current cyclical upswing continues or the economy falters," said Michael J. Boskin, a Stanford University economist who was President Bush's chief economist and is now advising Governor Bush.
"If the economy softens notably, which is possible but not the base case, that will hurt Gore," Mr. Boskin said. In any event, "most likely the economy and economic policy and what Presidents do about it will be a plus for Bush, because his view is closer to where most voters are."
Mrs. Dole's advisers say that to the degree that voters feel economically secure, their interests will turn to other issues.
"Gore's got big problems," said Ari Fleischer, Mrs. Dole's communications director. "And the irony is that the strong economy is one of them, because it's making people decide who to vote for on the basis of character and personality."
Mr. Forbes said the real credit for the strong economy should go to President Reagan, for cutting taxes and checking the growth in the size and influence of the Federal Government. And with the basics taken care of for most people, he said, now is the time for consideration of far-reaching changes like simplifying the tax code and giving parents more choice in where their children go to school.
"People can say, 'O.K., I have a job or the prospect of a job,' " Mr. Forbes said in an interview. "But what is the quality of life? Why can't two incomes do the job that one income used to do? Why can't we spend more time with the kids? Why are our schools lagging those of other countries?"
On economic policy, most of the Republican candidates find it easier to draw distinctions between themselves and Mr. Gore than among one another. The exception is Mr. Buchanan, whose message of gloom could become more appealing to the front-runner, Mr. Bush, should the economy turn down.
"Factories leaving, communities uprooted, high-paying jobs for the middle class leaving the country," Mr. Buchanan said. "Economic insecurity has become a pre-existing condition of the American middle class."

HEADLINE: Clinton Prods Congress Over a Four-Bill Package

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
President Clinton challenged Republicans today to work with him on domestic legislation so "this summer should be a season of progress," but made clear that he was just as willing to blame them for failure as to share credit for success.
In a speech at Georgetown University and in a news conference later, Mr. Clinton identified four bills as available for quick action because of broad bipartisan agreement. But one, campaign finance legislation, is strongly opposed by Republican leaders, and a second, the so-called patient's bill of rights, has Democrats seeking very broad application and a right to sue health maintenance organizations, two features opposed by most Republicans. 
 The two other bills -- one that would allow disabled people returning to work to retain Federal heath benefits, the other a raise in the minimum wage -- are measures that Republican leaders seem ready to accept.
Jim Nicholson, the Republican national chairman, attacked the President's comments, saying he "passed up an opportunity to work for real bipartisan solutions to America's problems."
"He chose instead," Mr. Nicholson said, "to create issues for the election campaign of Al Gore and other Democrats."
House Republicans, eager to leave town for the weekend before the late-afternoon news conference, held a rally this morning to urge the President to back a major tax cut, a national missile defense and legislation to allow states to spend Federal education dollars more freely. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert attacked inheritance taxes and the income-tax feature known as the "marriage penalty," which subjects some married working couples to higher taxes than they together would pay if they were single.
Mr. Clinton was asked about only one of the Republican proposals, use of money from the Federal budget surplus to cut taxes. "I'm not against tax cuts," he said, but Medicare and Social Security must be dealt with first. And he opposed any tax cuts whose result would be "to cut education or cut health care or cut our investments in the environment."
The President spoke at Georgetown about his desire to proceed in a spirit of "honorable compromise" on issues where the parties' approaches differ, as on Medicare and Social Security. But at the news conference he assailed House Republicans for their action on gun control legislation, saying they had voted to weaken "current law by letting criminals store their guns at pawnshops." A provision that would have eliminated background checks when guns are retrieved from pawnshops was included in the gun bill that the House defeated last Friday.
Mr. Clinton called on Republican leaders to appoint conferees who would adopt the gun controls passed by the Senate. Those provisions included a mandate that licensed dealers sell child safety devices with every handgun, a ban on the import of large ammunition clips and a requirement that all purchasers at gun shows be subjected to background checks that vendors would have up to three business days to complete.
"It's really not a partisan issue," he said, "anywhere but Washington, D.C."
His Georgetown speech also dwelled on the subject of partisanship.
"I think that those of us who work here now," he told the assembled students, "will be judged primarily by whether we choose to seize this opportunity to insure your future -- not just the short term, but the long term -- or will it be squandered with petty arguments and animosities and special-interest politics? I regret to say that the atmosphere in Washington has become increasingly poisoned by bitter partisanship. I don't understand exactly why, since we keep doing better and better and better in America. It may be that some people believe they have the luxury of engaging in shortsighted partisanship because the country is doing so well."
Some in Washington, he said, "really believe that because the Presidential election season has already started, the battle for Congress has already started -- even though it's a year and however many months away -- that the best politics is just to run out the clock and wait for the next election and hope that the country is doing so well and we enjoy the lazy days of summer so much nobody will notice."
At the news conference he was reminded by a questioner that some Congressional Democrats also favored inaction, thinking their best chance of victories next year lay in accusing the Republicans of running a do-nothing Congress.
Mr. Clinton conceded in his reply how widespread that feeling was, but said: "Not all Democrats believe that. You see a number in the House, and I think probably a majority in the Senate, do not agree with that."
Reporters repeatedly asked him about polls, which they said showed a lack of support for him, and he replied that the polls he had seen showed support for his policies.
Asked whether he understood why he generated such antagonism from his opponents, he said he was not sure. But he added that "the right wing -- you know, I've been accused of murder and all kinds of things -- and it seems, it's almost that the better the country got, the madder some of them got."
Then, citing the bitter attacks encountered by Franklin D. Roosevelt, he said that "generally, in our country's history, the people who are progressive, people who try to change things, people who keep pushing the envelope, have generally elicited very strong, sometimes personally hostile, negative reaction."
The President was asked whether he thought his "personal behavior" had made him a liability to Democrats like Mr. Gore and the First Lady, a likely Senate candidate.
"All elections are about the future," he replied, "and all candidates are judged on their own merits. And I believe that is the case here. But I think that the American people know that the country is in good shape, and that not only our economic policies, our crime policies and our welfare policies, but our family policies are good for their efforts to raise their children. And the best thing that I can do, it seems to me, is to do the right thing by my country, to just keep working at being a good President, and they'll do fine."
Mr. Clinton defended his intention to propose a prescription drug benefit for Medicare. "I don't really think there's any alternative here," he said. "You've got 15 million Americans, seniors out there, without any kind of coverage for their medicine. You've got millions and millions of others with inadequate or highly expensive coverage."
To help finance their Medicare plan, White House officials had considered charging extra premiums that would have increased with the incomes of beneficiaries. But Administration officials said today that Mr. Clinton had decided not to include that idea in his proposal.
The idea has encountered fierce resistance from members of both parties in the House of Representatives. Democrats told the White House that the prospect of higher premiums could alarm elderly voters and undermine support for Medicare. Republicans denounced the extra premiums as a tax increase.
In the past, Mr. Clinton has proposed that Medicare beneficiaries with incomes over $90,000 a year pay higher premiums, and a White House official said Mr. Clinton would still be open to the idea in negotiations with Congress. But, the official said, Mr. Clinton decided to omit the idea from his own Medicare proposal because "he was concerned that it would distract attention from the rest of the package."
The only element of his four-bill package on which reporters pressed him was the campaign finance measure. Mr. Clinton said his strategy on that bill, which would ban soft-money contributions and curb "issue" advertisements, was to "keep it on the front burner so that the discomfort level rises high enough that an actual vote is allowed."
He identified Senate Republican leaders as the obstacle, saying that "they don't want their people who will vote against it to have a recorded vote on it, and they don't want to run the risk that they've got enough of their folks that would vote with all of ours" and pass the bill.

HEADLINE: Easing Strain, North Korea Releases Tourist to Seoul

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 25

 BODY:
North Korea today released a South Korean tourist detained earlier this week on charges of trying to lure North Koreans to defect. The move is expected to ease Korean tensions, which have been rising since a clash of warships in the Yellow Sea last week.
The tourist, a 35-year-old woman who was taken into custody on Sunday during a tour of the Mount Kumgang resort in North Korea, was handed over to officials of the Hyundai Group, the South Korean conglomerate that operates the tour, South Korean officials said. 
 "She appears to be in good health," a Hyundai spokesman, Lee Young Kyu, said. "Our doctors in the North will give her a brief medical checkup, and then she will leave for the South on a Hyundai tugboat."
North Korean security authorities said the woman, Min Young Mi, had tried to persuade a North Korean tour guide to defect to the South. The North's official Korean Central News Agency said the Government had decided to release her because she admitted that she had "preached defection" to the guide. The news agency said that the woman "begged for lenient forgiveness for her criminal act." It was impossible to verify the account.
The detention once again raised tensions between the Koreas, which have never signed a peace treaty formally ending the 1950-53 Korean War. Last week, the two countries' skirmish in the Yellow Sea resulted in the sinking of a North Korean boat and the deaths of at least 20 North Korean sailors.
Officials of North and South Korea held long-awaited talks in Beijing on Tuesday to discuss reuniting families divided by the war, but those discussions ended with both sides trading accusations over which was responsible for the marine conflict. The talks resumed on Saturday, Agence France-Presse reported.
 It remains unclear exactly what North Korea hoped to accomplish in detaining the South Korean tourist. South Korean officials, who spoke by telephone from Seoul, interpreted the detention as a response to the sinking of the North Korean vessel.
The detention severely tested President Kim Dae Jung's policy of engaging North Korea despite its confrontational nature. At home and abroad, particularly in the United States Congress, critics say Mr. Kim's policy of social and economic engagement is largely ineffective because North Korea remains hostile.
He had threatened to halt the tourism program, which is the countries' largest joint commercial venture, and a major source of income for North Korea, if the woman was not released. Mr. Kim has faced growing criticism
A spokesman for Mr. Kim, Park June Young, applauded the release, calling it "a result of our Government's firm position to guarantee the safety of our tourists in the North."
"We urge the North to take foolproof measures in the future to guarantee the safety of South Korean tourists," he said.

American Detained
 WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters) -- An American has been arrested in North Korea and charged with "alleged violations of law," the State Department said today.
The Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said the charges against the American, whom he refused to identify, "have something to do with their efforts to build a hospital and a garment manufacturing business in North Korea, is my understanding." The United States does not have an embassy in North Korea, and Mr. Rubin said that the North Koreans had confirmed to Swedish officials, who represent American interests there, that an American was arrested on June 17.
The United States was urging North Korea to provide Swedish diplomats with quick and early consular access to the detained American.

HEADLINE: City Sells Harlem Building Sought for Culinary School

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Community organizers in East Harlem say the city has shattered their dream of establishing a local cooking school that would prepare low-income people for careers in the flourishing food-service industry.
For two years, they say, they worked closely with officials from the city's Economic Development Corporation and other city employees to develop plans to house the Harlem Culinary Institute in the Corn Exchange Building, a city-owned 19th century landmark at 125th Street and Park Avenue that has been vacant for two decades. 
 But the city sold the red-brick building at an auction last month to a group of investors that included Elie Hirschfeld, the son of Abe Hirschfeld, the real estate developer. The proponents of the cooking school say the sale took place without their knowledge and after they had received repeated assurances from city officials that the Corn Exchange Building was not on the auction block. They say they plan to sue next week, challenging the sale on the ground that the bidding was not open.
"We believe that the Mayor contravened the city charter by not having an open bid process," said David W. Weschler, a Legal Aid Society lawyer who represents Resurgence, the group seeking the culinary school.
Ethel Bates, one of the leaders of the effort to create the cooking school, said that had she known about the auction, her group would have bid on the building. She said that she had been told repeatedly by city officials that the property would not be sold, even though it was listed for a public auction on May 12. She said she suspects that her project got caught between the conflicting agendas of different city agencies.
City officials declined to comment on the situation. The Mayor's press office, the city Economic Development Corporation and the office of Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for operations, did not respond to repeated requests for information over the last few days.
The Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which oversaw the auction, issued a statement that said it "sells surplus commercial property through auction. We do not have the authority to negotiate directly. This property was deemed surplus and sold at auction."
Mr. Hirschfeld, whose group paid $535,000 for the building, also declined to be interviewed. But through an assistant, he said his group had not decided what to do with the building and had been unaware of the proposal for the culinary institute.
The sale of the Corn Exchange Building has left many people disappointed. "We thought we had this thing in the bag," said Ms. Bates, who made a name for herself by leading the effort to clean up Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem and who has been leading the drive for the cooking school. "I've spent so much time, and there was so much hope going into that building."
Ms. Bates said she came up with the idea for the institute after learning that the food industry expected to face a labor shortage within a few years. To help defray her costs, she lined up several prospective tenants -- among them, Ark Restaurants, the company that owns Lutece.
Michael Weinstein, the president of Ark, had written a letter expressing interest in leasing space from her for an uptown version of his popular West Side restaurant, the Columbus Bakery, to operate in conjunction with the cooking school.
Lewis Rudin, the real estate developer and civic leader, helped Ms. Bates with the project. He said he had participated because he wanted to see the building turned over to Harlem residents. "They were prepared to do what had to be done to make this into a valuable asset for the community," Mr. Rudin said. "They would be training people in a profession that is constantly growing."
Without the Corn Exchange Building, plans for the culinary institute cannot go forward, Ms. Bates said, because a major selling point for prospective commercial tenants was the landmark status of the building and its reputation as one of the most beautiful structures in Harlem.
Mr. Weinstein of Ark Restaurants said the Corn Exchange project offered an opportunity to enter an underserved market at an affordable rent. He said he had expected his restaurant to cater to Harlem residents.
For the new owners, getting the Corn Exchange Building into shape will be a major undertaking.
Constructed in 1883, just as Harlem was being transformed from a village into an urban residential neighborhood, the building has bay windows and trim made of sandstone, terra cotta and metal. It is described by the City Landmarks Preservation Commission as an outstanding example of both the Queen Anne and Romanesque Revival architectural styles of the 19th century.
Originally, the two bottom floors of the six-story building served as the headquarters for the Mount Morris Bank (which merged with the Corn Exchange Bank in 1913), while the upper floors were an apartment house known as the Morris.
The city took over the building in 1972. A fire destroyed the roof in 1997, forcing the removal of the two upper stories.
The New York Landmarks Conservancy, a private organization, has estimated that it will cost more than $7.5 million to rehabilitate the building. The owners will be required to work with the Landmarks Preservation Commission to make sure that the exterior is properly restored and that nothing is done inside the building that may damage the outside, said Terri Rosen Deutsch, a spokeswoman for the commission.
The site is likely to prove attractive to commercial tenants because of its convenient location, Ms. Bates said. It is across the street from the Metro-North railroad station at 125th Street and a block away from a new Pathmark supermarket.
David Givens, the chairman of Community Board 11 in East Harlem, said he hoped that the new owners would consult with his organization before deciding what to do with the building.
