HEADLINE: For the High-Minded, It's Blah, Blah, Blah;
Talks Are Cheap for Seekers of Ideas Who Are Willing to Listen

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
With Old World rivals like Paris and Berlin and New World rivals like Seattle and Silicon Valley, New York City can hardly claim to be the brain capital of the world.
But you wouldn't necessarily know that from all the talking going on. Call them seminars or lectures or discussions, but the city is truly brimming with forums for the thinking man, woman and child. In any given week an intrepid idea-seeker can find serious discussions about everything from the growing presence of Islam in America to the social history of popcorn. 
 Want to know how to cross-hybridize corn? There are talks at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. How about an in-depth look at democracy in Cuba? Check out the Brecht Forum on Tuesday.
In the age of Barnes & Noble and other super-size bookstores, literary discussion groups are meeting regularly to chat about Vietnam novels and science fiction and New Age tomes. Then there are the literary fan clubs, societies devoted to the work of late great authors like Yeats and Dickens.
Last week alone a New Yorker could find dozens of people sitting down to learn about Surrealist film, beach erosion and the history of marriage from a feminist perspective. There were appearances by seminar stars like Stephen Jay Gould, the historian, who can pack a room on a topic like "The Impossibility of Historical Prediction," and celebrity lecturers like the composer Philip Glass, whose talent for artful digression rivals that of many more experienced speakers.
All of this tossing about of ideas gives rise to a curious question: could one, by visiting many of these lectures and listening closely enough, pick up some sense of the city's intellectual zeitgeist?
The short answer is no. To be sure, there is plenty of millennial reflection going on right now, and more than a few speakers tossing around words like "calendric" and "fin de siecle."
But rather than indicating a common theme, this profusion of talkers and listeners testifies instead to the city's enormously varied intellectual appetite. It also shows off the city as a place where people with specific interests -- sometimes, exceedingly specific -- can find like-minded folk to commune with.
What follows is an account of a weeklong survey of the city's educated chatter.
The first stop, as any lecture junkie will tell you, was bound to be a big-time bookstore. Hoping to lure buyers into the stacks, chains like Barnes & Noble and Borders Books have been aggressive about scheduling authors with new books to discuss and read from their work.
On Monday, the choices included a speaker on the history of coffee at Barnes & Noble on the Upper East Side and a discussion of the work of Bernhard Schlink at the Barnes & Noble in Forest Hills, Queens.
No. And no. Instead, my choice was a lecture by Paul Levinson, a professor of communications history and philosophy at Fordham University, whose most recent book is "Digital McLuhan," a look at the lasting influence of Marshall McLuhan in the age of the Internet. The locale was a Borders at the World Trade Center, with an audience of about 40, including a man who slept before, during and after the event.
Mr. Levinson, flanked by stacks of photography books and others merely labeled "Art," expounded on likenesses between the futuristic visions of Mr. McLuhan, who invented the term Global Village, and today's World Wide Web.
"Mr. McLuhan was not able to write on the Web, but his approach was Web-like," Mr. Levinson said, citing Mr. McLuhan's propensity for short chapters and nonlinear thought in his books. The comments drew a round of emphatic nods.
"What would Marshall McLuhan have said about the Internet and the Web?" Mr. Levinson said. "It's impossible to say." He paused and added with a laugh: "Except that he would have had a lot to say about it."
Tuesday's schedule was to begin early, with a 7:30 A.M. talk with the television commentator Cokie Roberts at the 92d Street Y. But upon arriving, I discovered a sacred rule of the intellectual set: they like to sleep late. The event had been canceled.
The 92d Street Y is one of the city's premier temples of talk, a list that includes the New York Public Library, the Asia Society and the Pierpont Morgan Library, which has a series of afternoon discussions. And while summer may be a slow time for the city's colleges and universities, they generally offer countless lectures that are open to the public.
Many churches and museums also offer issue-oriented events. Ms. Roberts, in fact, would make an appearance at Trinity Church later that afternoon, speaking on religion and politics.
For true intellectual heft, however, perhaps few spots can rival the Brecht Forum, where Mr. Gould spoke on Tuesday night. The first words I heard upon entering were "imperialist dialectic interpretation of history."
The forum is on the 10th floor of 122 West 27th Street in Chelsea, a loft space where papier mache wall hangings and pamphlets jockey for visitors' attention.
Mr. Gould had drawn a standing-room-only crowd dotted with older men with ponytails, older women with spectacles and graduate student types scribbling notes on legal pads. The amiable Mr. Gould, with a pair of glasses hung around his neck, hit upon Karl Marx's funeral ("Only nine people were there"), the year 2000 ("a wonderfully arbitrary transition") and Yogi Berra's wisdom ("The future ain't what it used to be") before finally alighting on his thesis: that people, especially scientists, are terrible at predicting the future.
As an example, Mr. Gould told the story of an early chairman of Mercedes-Benz who once predicted that Europe would never sustain more than a million cars. The reason? That the Continent's citizenry could only ever produce a million chauffeurs.
Mr. Gould's point was that the underlying biases of class, race and economics often skewed any possibility of prognostication. "Scientific biases prevent accurate prediction," he said. "And always have."
There was much scribbling as I left.
The next stop was the Kitchen, the venerable experimental theater space on West 19th Street, the site of a batch of summertime lectures by members of the Kitchen's artistic family.
The seats were nearly all filled with a younger crowd than that at the Brecht Forum. The lights dimmed theatrically as Mr. Glass approached a small table draped in black and lighted by a single overhead spotlight. He immediately said that his lecture, titled "Collaboration and the New Technology," presented a problem.
"I made up the title months ago," Mr. Glass said. "Now, I've had to figure out what it was about."
Speaking in a voice barely above a burble, Mr. Glass touched on the miraculous technology of the piano (see lecture title), and his artistic collaborations (see lecture title) with everyone from Jerome Robbins to Martin Scorsese. But the most absorbing moments came when Mr. Glass's focus strayed a bit.
"CD-ROM is already on the way out," he said at one point, seeming alarmed and amused all at once. "Did you know that?"
Or: "I've noticed my cat doesn't watch television. Does yours?"
Or: "The only place the composer is the boss is in the opera house. That's why I write so many operas."
At evening's end a young composer asked Mr. Glass's advice about the profession. Mr. Glass puzzled for a bit and finally answered: "Think what you could do that would make your teachers really angry. That would probably be the most interesting thing to do."
The following night I tried a couple of the city's newer venues, the two-year-old Newseum and Joe's Pub, the recently opened cabaret spot at the Public Theater.
The Newseum auditorium is a sleek Madison Avenue lecture hall popular with that famously loquacious breed, the journalist. Booking reporters as speakers has its drawbacks, of course; a talk on Monday by the photojournalist Harry Benson was canceled when he was called away on assignment.
Helen Thomas, veteran White House correspondent and recent author of a memoir, spoke about her experiences. Beltway reminiscences ensued: of Lyndon B. Johnson, who "couldn't stand anybody speaking for him"; Hillary Clinton, who "just hates the press"; and President Clinton, who "has been very nice to me."
The crowd, unswayed by Ms. Thomas's assertion that reporters shouldn't be celebrities, ate it up.
Joe's Pub, which usually presents music, turned literary Wednesday with a selection of readings from The New Yorker's latest fiction issue. Special attractions included celebrity readers, girls in slinky dresses looking to impress New Yorker editors and lots of cocktails.
The final evening of talk, Thursday, highlights what may be the seminar scene's most important contribution to the city's intellectual landscape: bringing together people with particular interests. At the Lesbian and Gay Community Center in the West Village, for example, E. J. Graff, a writer, discussed same-sex marriages.
Then at Borders Books at East 57th Street and Park Avenue, four African-American authors gathered to discuss the topic of "The Importance of Writing About Contemporary Black Life." The audience was almost exclusively black, a marked change from most of the other events I attended. One at a time, each author discussed pressing issues for black artists, including stereotyping by publishers and the complications of success for blacks in America.
"I started writing because I wanted to write about where we are now," said Benilde Little, a novelist. "We are the most educated, most affluent, and probably the most confused."
Events like this, she said, offer an opportunity to reflect on those confusions.
"You have to have a community where we can be ourselves," Ms. Little said, "drop the masks and let our hair down."

HEADLINE: Fred C. Trump, Postwar Master Builder of Housing for Middle Class, Dies at 93

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
Fred C. Trump, one of the last of New York City's major postwar builders, died yesterday at a hospital in Queens. He was 93 and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.
Although Mr. Trump was stricken with Alzheimer's disease six years ago, he still retained his title of chairman of the board of Trump Management, a title he held since the company was formed in the mid-1960's. 
 Mr. Trump, like Sam LeFrak, another master builder, helped change the face of Brooklyn and Queens with thousands of homes for the middle class in plain but sturdy brick rental towers, clustered together in immaculately groomed parks. Although overshadowed in the news for the last two decades by his flamboyant son Donald, Mr. Trump, a self-made man, built more than 27,000 apartments and row houses in the neighborhoods of Coney Island, Bensonhurst, Sheepshead Bay, Flatbush, and Brighton Beach in Brooklyn and Flushing and Jamaica Estates in Queens.
His estate has been estimated by the family at $250 million to $300 million, but Mr. Trump did not believe in displays of wealth -- with one exception. For decades, he insisted on a Cadillac, always navy blue, always gleaming, and always replaced every three years, its "FCT" license plate announcing its owner wherever he went.
He was a frugal man. According to his sons, he would routinely drive his Cadillac to one of his many construction sites after the day's work was over. Wearing a natty suit -- with his chiseled features and wide grin, he resembled a silent-film star -- he would walk through the studs and across the plywood floors, picking up unused nails to hand back to his carpenters the next day.
Frederick Christ (pronounced Krist) Trump was born in New York City in 1905. From World War II until the 1980's, Mr. Trump would tell friends and acquaintances that he was of Swedish origin, although both his parents were born in Germany. John Walter, his nephew and the family historian, explained, "He had a lot of Jewish tenants and it wasn't a good thing to be German in those days."
His father was a barber who arrived from Kallstadt, Germany, in 1885 and joined the Alaska gold rush. By the turn of the century, he owned the White Horse Restaurant and Inn in White Horse, Alaska, while also supplying food and lumber to the miners. He went back to Germany to court his neighbor Elizabeth Christ and married her in 1902. When they returned to New York, they settled down in a single-family house in Woodhaven, Queens. They had three children; when Fred C. was 13, his father died of pneumonia.
Two years later, at 15, he started his own construction business while continuing his high school education. He knew he was too young to build entire houses, so he thought of building housing for the new mode of transportation then sweeping the nation; after all, those newfangled automobiles needed garages. Too young to sign checks, he became partners with his mother, Elizabeth: they called their company E. Trump & Son. His mother, who was a dynamo in her own right, was the partner who signed the checks.
Their business was a success, and one of the things he did with his earnings, his sons said, was to help send his younger brother John to Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, then to Columbia for his master's and then to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he received his Ph.D.
When he started at Brooklyn Poly, John Trump was planning to become an architect and to go into business with his brother Fred. The two actually built one or two houses together, Mr. Walter said, but before long, they realized they had two very different philosophies.
"They laughed about it together later," their nephew said. "John designed the house, and before it was finished, Fred wanted to sell it; you know, that's what you do when you're in real estate. But John was a scientist; he wanted to wait until it was totally done. After about a year, my uncle John switched to electrical engineering."
As he grew older, Fred Trump began building single-family houses in the late 1920's -- most of them in Queens -- which were sold for $3,990 each. The concept of supermarkets was new back then, too, and when Mr. Trump built Trump Market in Woodhaven in the middle of the Depression and advertised, "Serve Yourself and Save!" it was an instant hit. About a year later, Mr. Trump sold the store for a profit to the King Kullen chain.
In World War II, Mr. Trump builtbarracks and garden apartments for the Navy in Chester, Pa., Newport News, and Norfolk, Va. When the fighting was over and apartments for returning servicemen and their families were in short supply, he branched out into middle-income housing; he built Shore Haven in Bensonhurst in 1949 and Beach Haven near Coney Island the next year for a total of 2,700 apartments. In 1963, he put up the 3,800-apartment Trump Village in Coney Island -- five years after his contemporary, Mr. LeFrak, began Lefrak City in Queens.
"He made a great contribution; he filled a very big hole in the market," Mr. LeFrak recalled. "We took Queens; he did more in Brooklyn. He was a great builder who rallied to the cause like we did; he built housing for the returning veterans. I guess you could say we're the last of the old dinosaurs."
In 1936, Mr. Trump married Mary McLeod, who had come to this country when she was 19 from Stornoway, Scotland. Miss McLeod had two sisters who lived in New York; shortly after she arrived, her sisters took her to a dance, where she met Fred Trump. They had five children. In addition to his wife and his sons Robert and Donald, he is survived by two daughters, Maryanne Trump Barry of New York City, who is a Federal judge, and Elizabeth Trump Grau of New York City. Another son, Fred Trump Jr., died in 1981. Both his brother John and his sister, Elizabeth Trump Walters, are dead.
Mr. and Mrs. Trump liked to assist young people who hungered for a career in real estate. Richard Levy, now a senior vice president at Tishman Real Estate, said that when he was in his early 20's, he remembers going to Mr. Trump's office, a reconverted dentist's office in the Beach Haven development near Coney Island. "I felt like Custer," he said. "There were all these huge wooden Indians all over the place." Mr. Levy looked at a wall "covered with plaques from every organization and pictures with Presidents, and here's this giant of a man -- he was well over six feet -- and he just stuck out his hand and said 'Hi. My name is Fred.' "
Mr. Trump then started to discuss a baseball game played the night before. When Mr. Levy left, he said to Robert Trump that he was surprised to find the elder Trump was such a baseball fan. From young Trump he learned, "He wasn't a fan at all, but he knew I was."
In the recession of the 1970's, Mr. Trump, who retained ownership of most of the rental buildings he built, started buying up apartment buildings from other builders, who had run into trouble keeping up their properties. According to Edward S. Gordon, a commercial real estate executive, Mr. Trump amassed the buildings in a "very quiet way." Mr. Gordon praised Mr. Trump's business acumen, saying, "Most smart men and women paid attention to the ball; Fred Trump focused on the shadow of the ball."
Mr. Trump was a demon for controlling costs. Besides collecting unused nails, Mr. Gordon said, Mr. Trump often performed the exterminating chores in his buildings by himself. "He became an expert," Mr. Gordon said.
When it was time to order the thousands of gallons of disinfectant necessary for his thousands of apartments, Mr. Trump gathered samples of all the available floor cleaners on his desk. "Then he sent them out to a lab and found out what was in them and had it mixed himself," Donald Trump recalled. "What had cost $2 a bottle, he got mixed for 50 cents." And he knew how to get the most of his workers when they used those chemicals. "He would walk up to some little guy polishing something, and say: 'Wow, this is the best shine I've ever seen,' " Mr. Levy said. "And that guy promptly started scrubbing away like crazy."
In the mid-70's, Mr. Trump lent support -- and a small amount of money -- to his son Donald's aspirations of becoming a developer. "But what he lent was mostly knowledge; Donald really did it on his own, along with whatever boost he got from being Fred Trump's son, of course," Robert Trump said.
Recently, Donald Trump said he was happy his father stuck to Brooklyn and Queens. "It was good for me," the developer said, chuckling. "You know, being the son of somebody, it could have been competition to me. This way, I got Manhattan all to myself!"
Fred and Mary Trump donated the pavilion that bears the Trump name to the Jamaica Hospital Medical Center in appreciation of the care received there by Mrs. Trump. They gave a two-building rental complex in Brooklyn to the National Kidney Foundation of New York/New Jersey and to Community Mainstreaming Associates of Great Neck, an organization that provides homes for functionally retarded adults. Mr. Trump gave another building to the Cerebral Palsy Foundation of New York and New Jersey, which has since turned it into co-op. He also supported the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan, the Long Island Jewish Hospital and the Kew Forest School in Queens, where his children went to school.
Mr. Trump liked to be surrounded by familiar things and familiar people. He still employed Amy Luerssen, his secretary for 59 years. And he and his wife of 61 years still lived in the red-brick Colonial they built in 1951 on a half-acre lot in the leafy, middle-class suburb of Jamaica Estates, in Queens.

An obituary of the real estate developer Fred C. Trump on June 26 misstated the location of the White Horse Restaurant and Inn where his father supplied food and lumber to miners in the gold rush. It was in the Yukon Territory, not in Alaska.

SECTION: Section C;Page 1;Column 1;Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: How 2 Priests Got Mixed Up In a Huge Insurance Scandal

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

DATELINE: ROME, June 25

 BODY:
As priests, they make an unlikely pair. One is an affable, worldly American bon vivant who zooms around Rome on a raffish blue motorbike and defied his New York archbishop in the 1980's by running a trendy Manhattan restaurant to raise money for the poor. The other is an owlish Italian canon law scholar who serves as an emeritus judge on the Roman Rota, the court of appeals of the Holy See.
Together, the Rev. Peter Jacobs, 73, and Msgr. Emilio Colagiovanni, 79, provided a clerical cloak of respectability for a Greenwich, Conn., money manager who authorities suspect embezzled more than $300 million from insurers across the United States. Both men insist they were badly duped by Martin R. Frankel, who disappeared last month and is wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 The priests say they knew Mr. Frankel as David Rosse, a middle-aged tycoon who claimed descent from the Jewish King David and said he was eager to give at least $50 million to the church.
They supported the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation, a charity Mr. Frankel set up and then tried to use to buy several American insurance companies . He named Father Jacobs president of that foundation. Monsignor Colagiovanni, who had his own foundation, said he went a step further, giving Mr. Frankel's charity power to move funds in and out of the Vatican bank account of Monsignor Colagiovanni's foundation.
With Federal investigators in the United States scouring the records of Mr. Frankel's intricate financial transactions, those actions have left both priests exposed and vulnerable. And it has turned both into virtual pariahs inside the Vatican.
The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said there was no link whatsoever between the Vatican and Mr. Frankel. He also denied any connection between Monsignor Colagiovanni's Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation and the Vatican.
Yet before the scandal erupted, senior Vatican officials were also intrigued by Mr. Frankel's professed desire to shower riches on church charities. At least two senior Vatican officials met with Mr. Frankel's American lawyer, Thomas A. Bolan, and tried to help his client set up a charitable foundation that would be part of the Vatican.
Mr. Bolan, a former law partner of the late Roy Cohn, met in Rome to discuss the foundation with Bishop Francesco Salerio Salerno, and Monsignor Gianfranco Piovano, top Vatican officials, according to his lawyer, Maurice R. Nessen, and the two priests. Reading from his notes of what Mr. Bolan recollects, Mr. Nessen said tonight that the meetings in Rome centered on how an outside philanthropist could channel money through the Vatican to support religious causes.
Church officials have been highly sensitive to any hint of a banking scandal since the 1980's, when the Vatican bank was badly tainted by its ties to the Banco Ambrosiana, which collapsed after a huge financial scandal.
Bishop Salerno is now secretary of the Apostolic Signatura, the supreme court of the church. At the time of the meeting with Mr. Bolan, he was secretary of the Prefecture for the Economic Affairs of the Holy See. In an interview today, Bishop Salerno said he had denied ever discussing the foundation with Mr. Bolan, though he said he did so with Monsignor Colagiovanni. "I could not refuse Monsignor Colagiovanni, he is a judge on the Roman Rota," he explained.
 
Hypothetical Approval For an American Role
Monsignor Salerno said he told other Vatican officials that "hypothetically" nothing would legally prevent an American financier from opening a charitable foundation in the Vatican. "The Vatican is a sovereign state, anything can be done, but the question is will it be authorized," Bishop Salerno said.
Mr. Nessen, Mr. Bolan's lawyer, said that his client had a later meeting with Monsignor Piovano, an assistant Vatican Secretary of State, who disagreed with Bishop Salerno, pointing out that Mr. Frankel could not be allowed to control a Vatican foundation's assets, especially since Mr. Frankel also wished to invest in insurance companies in America.
Eventually, however, the two sides worked out a compromise: the Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation, Monsignor Colagiovanni's cultural and charitable organization, could act as "founder" -- in legal terms as "settlor" -- of a new, independent foundation controlled by Mr. Frankel. According to Mr. Nessen, the new foundation would be named after St. Francis of Assisi and could claim links to the Vatican, as Mr. Frankel desired. Mr. Nessen said that Monsignor Salerno was aware of and approved this arrangement in advance. Asked in writing to respond, Bishop Salerno did not reply.
But after Mr. Frankel's suspected embezzlement schemes came to light, the Vatican sought to distance itself from the American -- and his associates in the church.
Mr. Navarro-Valls described Monsignor Colagiovanni, who as president of Monitor Ecclesiasticus edits a Vatican-approved canonical law quarterly and also runs its charitable arm, as a "pensioner." Mr. Navarro-Valls said he knew nothing about Father Jacobs, but volunteered that he was an "ex-Jew."
Bishop Salerno also pointed out Father Jacobs's Jewish roots after the scandal surfaced. Surprisingly, neither he nor Mr. Navarro-Valls nor others mentioned the fact that Father Jacobs was formally rebuked by the Roman Catholic Church in 1983, after he ignored an archbishop's order to cease operating his New York restaurant, The Palantine. Father Jacobs's right to perform priestly duties was suspended at that time because he violated church rules about business transactions.
Father Jacobs, who continues to serve mass and perform weddings, said in an interview that he believed his suspension was reversed in 1987 after he gave up the business. According to his archdiocese in Washington, however, the suspension was reversed, but not the ban on giving sacraments.
"Priestly faculties are like a medical license, and Father Jacobs's were never restored," Monsignor William E. Lori, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of Washington, explained on Thursday. "The sacraments he performed since 1983 are not valid."
Father Jacobs was born in New Hampshire, the son of a Jewish father and an Catholic mother. Father Jacobs was baptized as a Catholic, but he only began practicing his faith while serving in the Navy during World War II. He was ordained in 1955.
In his long, colorful and highly unorthodox career as a priest, he has made interfaith marriages a specialty. It was, in fact, an interfaith society wedding that brought Father Jacobs and Monsignor Colagiovanni together in 1994.
They first met, Monsignor Colagiovanni recalled in an interview, at the Vatican bank, known as the Istituto per le Opere di Religione. Monsignor Colagiovanni's foundation has an account there. Father Jacobs said that he was there visiting old friends who worked in the bank.
"He is a very social fellow," Monsignor Colagiovanni said of Father Jacobs. Soon after that meeting, Father Jacobs sought out Monsignor Colagiovanni's expertise in arranging a Catholic church wedding for a divorced Jewish man and a Catholic woman. Monsignor Colagiovanni said he had no idea at the time he was helping one of America's wealthiest men, Edgar Bronfman Jr. president of the Seagram Company, marry Clarissa Alcock, the daughter of an oil executive, in Caracas, Venezuela. Father Jacobs said he officiated at the service, alongside a local priest and a rabbi, over the objections of the local cardinal. An associate of the Bronfman family said that this was untrue, and that the local priest had officiated, with Father Jacobs serving as a "greeter."
 
Famous Connections Around the World
Father Jacobs, who has worked in the slums of New York and Washington, also hobnobs with European aristocrats and counts the late Princess Grace of Monaco, Walter Cronkite and Arrigo Cipriani and a restaurateur among his many friends. Another was Mr. Bolan.
In August of 1998, Monsignor Colagiovanni said he got another call from Father Jacobs when he was on holiday in Cleveland. "He told me there was a Jewish millionaire who wanted to do good things for the church and the poor," Monsignor Colagiovanni recalled.
He flew at Mr. Frankel's expense to New York, where he and Father Jacobs and Mr. Bolan had dinner at Cipriani's. Father Jacobs said he had known Mr. Bolan for 30 years and had helped him through a variety of family crises.
Soon after the dinner, all three men drove to Greenwich, Conn., to meet the aspiring benefactor. Both priests said they were surprised and impressed by Mr. Frankel's library, which was crammed with books on Catholicism, ranging from Papal encyclicals to hundreds of tomes devoted to St. Francis of Assisi. "He had actually read the encyclicals," Father Jacobs said. "Even I haven't read them all."
But the priest also noticed Mr. Frankel's weird side, particularly his obsessive fear of germs. "He reminded me of the Jack Nicholson character in 'As Good as it Gets,' who kept washing his hands over and over," Father Jacobs said.
Msg. Colagiovanni, like Father Jacobs, received from Mr. Frankel a 13-page autobiographical sketch that laid out his financial credentials and his piety, including his self-professed hero worship for Albert Schweitzer and St. Francis of Assisi. It said he was smitten by Franco Zefferelli's "Brother Sun, Sister Moon," which he said he saw "every day for five weekdays."
Msg. Colagiovanni said he was convinced of Mr. Frankel's good intentions, but he said that when Mr. Frankel explained his desire to give $50 million dollars to Catholic charities by setting up his own foundation at the Vatican, he told him that was impossible. "I explained no lay person could bank there," Mr. Colagiovanni said.
He said he encouraged Mr. Frankel to start his own private foundation. But Mr. Frankel was apparently so keen to bank at the Vatican that he dispatched his lawyer, Mr. Bolan, to Rome by Concorde to meet with Vatican officials and explain his offer.
The two sides eventually settled on the compromise and founded the St. Francis Foundation. Mr. Jacobs said that he learned that he was appointed a trustee and president of the St. Francis foundation after seeing his name on a document.
Mr. Frankel also ardently pursued celebrities to add legitimacy to his organization. Lee A. Iacocca, the former Chrysler chairman, rejected Mr. Frankel's overtures to serve on the St. Francis foundation board. But Mr. Frankel did not readily accept no for an answer: He paid for Mr. Iacocca to fly on a leased Gulfstream IV executive jet from Los Angeles to Milan, Italy, where Mr. Iacocca attended to some business, a spokesperson for Mr. Iacocca said.
And Mr. Frankel may have pressured Mr. Jacobs to use his own connections. Walter Cronkite said that he had received and rejected a request from Father Jacobs to serve on the advisory board. Mr. Cronkite heard nothing more about the matter until early May.
"Father Pete called and left a very cryptic message" at my office, Mr. Cronkite said. "He said 'the man who has given a billion dollars has apparently absconded with the money, the whole thing is a mess. I'm sorry I listed you as a member of the board of advisors. I hope it doesn't cause you any problems.' "
Msg. Colagiovanni said that he told Mr. Frankel he did not want to be involved with collecting funds or investing money. He signed over to Father Jacobs, president of the St. Francis Foundation, the right to use the bank account of the Monitor Ecclesiaticus Foundation, which is in the Vatican bank. But Mr. Frankel apparently never tapped that source: both priests said that Mr. Frankel never sent any money to either foundation.
Mr. Frankel instead used Mr. Colagiovanni's connections in a different way. Msgr. C said that the American financier persuaded him to sign a November 1998 affadavit that stated that funds contributed to the St. Francis Foundation came from "funds of the Holy See." Mr. Frankel's lawyers used that document to support their claims that Mr. Frankel's charity and business dealings had the approval of the Vatican.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 17, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on June 26 about the religious connections of Martin Frankel, the fugitive money manager from Greenwich, Conn., referred incorrectly to restrictions imposed by the Archdiocese of Washington on the Rev. Peter Jacobs, a Roman Catholic priest involved in Mr. Frankel's dealings. In 1983 the archdiocese suspended Father Jacobs's authorization to function as a priest, an action that invalidates marriages he may have performed since then. The action did not invalidate other sacraments possibly performed by Father Jacobs, like baptisms or the celebrations of Mass.
The article also misstated the clerical title of William E. Lori, an official of the archdiocese who described the restrictions. He is a bishop, not a monsignor.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BRIEF INTERVIEWS WITH HIDEOUS MEN, by David Foster Wallace. (Little, Brown, $24.) In their depictions of characters whose deviant behavior puts them an angstrom away from undiluted sociopathy, these stories employ an incisive moral sensibility to dissect WASP-y male self-absorption.
 
A CLEARING IN THE DISTANCE: Frederick Law Olmsted and America in the Nineteenth Century, by Witold Rybczynski. (Scribner, $28.) How a modest man with no formal training in landscaping became a symphonist of public space, designing Central Park and other scenic masterworks.
 
A GIFT IMPRISONED: The Poetic Life of Matthew Arnold, by Ian Hamilton. (Basic Books, $24.) This portrait of the poet as a young man argues that beneath the foppish facade of drinking, gambling and nude bathing lay a tortured artist for whom the act of composition was tantamount to self-evisceration.
 
JUNETEENTH, by Ralph Ellison. Edited by John F. Callahan. (Random House, $25.) Assembled by his literary executor from mountains of notes, this story of a racist white senator raised as black may or may not be construed as Ellison's long-overdue second novel.
 
LAST THINGS, by Jenny Offill. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A quirky first novel follows its 7-year-old protagonist as she observes the descent into madness of her mother, who has built them a private cosmos filled with signs and wonders.
 
LAYOVER, by Lisa Zeidner. (Random House, $24.) This novel's heroine, who has endured maternal loss and marital betrayal, simply fails to come home one day, embarking on a parallel life of free (read illegal) hotel rooms and relentless sexual conquest.
 
MATISSE: Father & Son, by John Russell. (Abrams, $39.95.) In a biographical diptych informed by previously unpublished (and revealingly intimate) family correspondence, Matisse pere and Matisse fils emerge as twin titans, one at making art, the other at selling it.
 
TIMBUKTU, by Paul Auster. (Holt, $22.) Bereft of his longtime companion, this novel's flea-bitten protagonist longs for nothing more than a bed, a bone and a biscuit but will settle for perpetual enlightenment.
 
TIPPING THE VELVET, by Sarah Waters. (Riverhead, $25.95.) Suffused with eros, this picaresque first novel chronicles a wide-eyed Victorian girl's ardor for a music-hall actress, her life in London's mean streets and her eventual redemption.
 
TOUGH, TOUGH TOYS FOR TOUGH, TOUGH BOYS, by Will Self. (Grove, $23.) Short fiction, at once amusing and appalling, that glories onomatopoetically in the yucky and unmasks revulsion as a species of the genus Desire.

LENGTH: 1117 words

HEADLINE: Right Out of the Closet

BYLINE: By David Brooks; David Brooks is a senior editor at The Weekly Standard.

 BODY:

PARTY CRASHER
A Gay Republican Challenges Politics as Usual.
By Richard Tafel.
253 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $25. 
 During the 1980's it appeared the Republican Party was about to grow a gay wing. There were a number of talented gay conservative writers working their way through the ranks. There were several more or less openly gay members of the Reagan Administration. George Bush is said to have won around 40 percent of the gay vote in 1988. It seemed only a matter of time before some foundation would shell out for a gay conservative journal, a gay conservative think tank, dull but worthy conferences and all the other accouterments that go with being a bona fide faction on the American right.
 But it hasn't worked out that way. In 1996 Bob Dole returned a donation from gay Republicans. The Senate leader, Trent Lott, told an interviewer that homosexual sex was sinful. And most significant, several of the prominent gay conservative writers have broken, often bitterly, with their former soul mates.
 So now the question is: Is it even possible to be a gay Republican, or are the two labels inimical? In his lively book, "Party Crasher," Richard Tafel argues that the breach can be healed. Tafel is the executive director of the Log Cabin Republicans, the gay organization that tried to give that $1,000 check to the Dole campaign. Now he spends his days as a campus speaker, press releaser, television talking head and grass-roots organizer. His book is part memoir -- how he emerged from the Harvard Divinity School into his quixotic role -- and part political statement.
 The best sections of the book simply describe what it is like to be a gay Republican, which seems to be akin to standing in the middle of a field with a hurricane hitting you from one side and a tornado slamming you from the other, while you look up hopefully for blue sky. From the right comes complacent prejudice. It seems that every gay Republican has found himself with a group of conservative types in which somebody starts referring to "queers." From the gay left comes public demonization. Apparently, every gay Republican has had a gay friend tell him that voting for the Republicans is like a Jew voting for the Nazis.
 Why would anybody volunteer for such abuse? Many Log Cabin members, Tafel writes, were aware of themselves as Republicans before they became aware of themselves as gay. Most believe in limited government, and many admire the way Ronald Reagan fought the cold war. But for many there is a special fervor, as if they were on some gay Peace Corps mission to the country clubs. They want to make sure homosexual voices are heard in both major parties, and to make sure that homosexuals in turn hear Republican ideas about economic liberty. One of Tafel's colleagues tells him: "From the day I accepted Harvard's scholarship I have never forgotten the words of one of my interviewers: 'You will be expected to give back in your life what we are giving you today.' . . . I am giving much more of my time and money to Log Cabin than I had ever expected to, but I consider my work in the gay community as part of my solemn duty to make this world a better place."
 It certainly takes thick skin. "I didn't get involved in politics to be liked," Tafel quotes himself saying. And it is clear that one reason Tafel can take the abuse is that he is generously coated with self-esteem. This book could have been called "Arguments I Have Won," for all the passages in which Tafel describes himself coming back with just the right retort, or scoring yet another klieg-light conquest. Living in Washington, I thought I was inured to self-admiration, but passages here would leave Narcissus gaping and applauding.
 The important issue is whether there is actual intellectual ground for a gay Republican to stand on, or are gay Republicans just another set of oxymoronic oddities for talk show bookers? Tafel argues that gay political thinking falls into three main strains. There are the assimilationists, who hold black-tie dinners and hope to establish that gay men and lesbians are just like everyone else. Then there are the liberationists, heavily influenced by Marxism, who view gay issues as "one of a cluster of social justice issues that required comprehensive societal change." Finally, there are libertarians, who see sexual orientation as one facet of their lives, but rarely the most important one. Libertarians reject group labels, believing each person is responsible for his or her own destiny. And of course libertarians are suspicious of the state, believing government should stay out of economic as well as private life. Tafel is a libertarian.
 He makes an outstanding case that some homosexuals should call themselves libertarian and maybe sometimes vote for Republican candidates. He doesn't make a good case that homosexuals should call themselves Republicans. Because the Republican Party, for all its commitment to limited government, has never been and never will be a libertarian party. It is a conservative party, believing that government should shore up middle-class moral standards. If gay people are to become a vital fixture in the Republican coalition, somebody will have to demonstrate that being gay is not an affront to middle-class morality, a case that should be possible to make.
 Tafel seems to sense this, and yet the large and maybe most revealing failing of "Party Crasher" is that he can't bring himself to endorse middle-class morality, or to defend its institutions. One section of his book is entitled "Understanding the Religious Right," but nowhere does he really try to understand the religious right, or its concerns about family breakdown. And in his section on the limits of moral relativism, he pats himself on the back for daring to say that it is immoral knowingly to infect another with the H.I.V. virus. This is the start of a morality, one supposes, but it's not a very ambitious start.
 Tafel seems unable to make comprehensive judgments about different life styles: to say that homosexuality is not a choice, but how you live is; to say that monogamy is better than promiscuity, and that anybody -- straight or gay -- who has more than five sex partners in a year is probably doing something sleazy. In short, Tafel has a developed set of arguments to champion the cause of economic liberty, but only apologetic, half-formed instincts when it comes to the moral demands of gay life. The person who can write compellingly about liberty and traditional morality will have laid the foundation for a principled gay Republicanism, ground that will be worth defending against homophobes and amoralists alike. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1969 words

HEADLINE: The End of the World

BYLINE: By Tony Judt; Tony Judt is the Erich Maria Remarque Professor of European Studies at New York University.

 BODY:

THE FIRST WORLD WAR
By John Keegan.
Illustrated. 475 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $35. 
 It is not easy to convey to Americans, especially young Americans, the experience of World War I and its significance for our century. To be sure, the United States took part in that war and 114,000 American servicemen died -- twice the number killed in Vietnam. But more Americans were killed in World War II (292,000), and both figures pale beside the casualties of the Civil War (in excess of 600,000). American involvement in World War I lasted just 19 months; as a result, although the rate of American deaths per month was high, the experience was brief. And the war was fought a long way away, its echoes only belatedly reaching these shores.
 British military losses in World War II were comparable to those of the United States -- 265,000 servicemen and women killed. But they pale into relative statistical and human insignificance against the horrors of the earlier conflict. On a small hill above the northern French village of Thiepval, 20 miles south of Arras, there is a poignant memorial listing the names of the 70,000 British soldiers missing or unidentified following the battle there in the summer of 1916.
 Thiepval lies in the valley of the Somme River, athwart the trench lines of the Western Front. The countryside today is soft and green, the villages peaceful (and all reconstructed after 1918). But at the Battle of the Somme, which was just one of dozens of major and minor confrontations along this front during the four years of war, the British suffered 420,000 casualties, the French 195,000, the Germans 600,000. On the very first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1, 1916, in just 24 hours, 20,000 British soldiers were killed and a further 40,000 wounded.
 This was, as John Keegan writes in "The First World War," "the greatest loss of life in British military history." Together with the third Battle of Ypres, in July 1917 (better known as the Battle of Passchendaele, from the name of the Belgian village where it took place), where 70,000 British soldiers were killed and 170,000 wounded, the Somme broke the back of the old British Army, and more besides: "The Somme marked the end of an age of vital optimism in British life that has never been recovered."
 But the British won World War I, a war fought on foreign territory in which fewer than 2,000 British civilians were killed. The significance of the war for the Germans, who lost it and with it some two million men, or for the French, upon whose land it was fought and who lost 1.7 million men in action, can only be imagined. In 1918 there were 630,000 war widows in France, and many tens of thousands of single women who would never marry -- they could still be seen as late as the 1960's, grown old, working at menial tasks in the public sector (clipping subway tickets, cleaning toilets), a gloomy reminder of the Great War, like the memorials to the dead on virtually every village square in the land.
 That is how World War I was experienced in western Europe. In eastern Europe the carnage was equally bad. In Serbia some 15 percent of the population was killed; the Russians lost at least as many men as the French (though a much smaller proportion of the population); and the Turkish losses were never even calculated, though there were certainly many hundreds of thousands. If the memory of World War I is less present in the east, it is only because the military (and especially civilian) losses there during World War II were even worse. But the war in eastern Europe was like previous wars there, with men and horses traversing vast landscapes -- it would have been recognizable to Napoleon in its scale and movement. In the west it had descended into 475 miles of trenches by November 1914 and remained there for nearly four years. That is why the classic image of World War I in Britain and the United States is of an infantry soldier living, or dying, in a muddy puddle, and why, when we think of the Great War, we think of the Western Front.
 John Keegan is a military historian, perhaps the best military historian of our day, and his new history of the war exemplifies his many strengths. It is elegantly written, clear, detailed and omniscient. As a narrative it is outstanding, telling the story of how the war began, how it was fought, why it was won by the Allies. Above all, Keegan conveys how it felt. To our eyes World War I can seem mysterious: Why did such a pointless war take place? How could such useless carnage have lasted so long? Why did men continue to serve, and fight, in such unspeakable conditions? Keegan never plays down these concerns, but he addresses them in terms contemporaries would have understood.
 The war began with a series of incidents and decisions, taken with little thought for their consequences; and no one, least of all the German generals responsible for urging it upon their rulers, expected it to take the form it did or last so long. In that sense, Germany's military leaders can hardly be held responsible for having begun what became the Great War, since they never intended it. Of the professional soldiers who fought its early battles, Keegan writes that they "died in their thousands at Ypres not because of an ideal of self-sacrifice but because it was expected of them and, in any case, there was no alternative."
 The conscripts, who by 1916 formed the overwhelming majority of the armies, fought and died with a resolution and courage hard to understand today; but by 1917, following Passchendaele and the disastrous French offensive ordered by Gen. Robert Nivelle in April of that year, they had reached their limit. Forty-nine French divisions mutinied that summer; they would continue to the end to defend their lines and their land, but they would resist further calls to attack. Something comparable happened to the Russian Army, too, and to the German Army following the unsuccessful spring offensive of 1918. The spirit, and the social order, of the European 19th century collapsed and died in the muddy catacombs of Flanders and the Argonne.
 Keegan explains better than most just why the Western Front was so murderous. In one sense it was an old-fashioned war: the Germans mobilized 715,000 horses, the Austrians 600,000. The French cavalry in 1914 wore breastplates similar to those it had worn at Waterloo a century before. Communications at sea were conducted by flag hoist, on land by messengers or hand signals. Nelson and Wellington would have recognized the scene.
 Weaponry, on the other hand, had been transformed. A handful of machine guns could wipe out a regiment in a matter of hours. The only way to win an engagement was to send infantrymen forward to attack other infantrymen in trenches a few hundred yards away, and the only way to insure that they would get there was to destroy the opposing trenches and their occupants. The British artillery lobbed three million shells into the German lines before the Somme offensive.
 But the artillerymen had no means of knowing whether they had achieved their objective, and the infantrymen who marched forward to occupy the shattered ground had no means of telling the artillery where to aim and when to fire. In World War I, in short, the generals had murderously destructive technology at their command but no way of deploying it effectively in attack. In earlier wars they could see the progress of their troops; in later wars they had instant communication by radio and telephone. Between 1914 and 1918 they were caught in a technological gap, and their men paid the price.
 TO understand is not to forgive. Keegan maintains a fine line between condemning general staffs for circumstances beyond their control and excusing them for their failure to understand and adapt to a new sort of war. Erich von Falkenhayn at Verdun and Douglas Haig at Ypres had no strategy beyond bleeding the enemy to death. On the subject of Haig, commander of the British armies at the Somme and Passchendaele and an object of execration for two generations of British survivors and commentators, Keegan is unambiguous: in his "public manner and private diaries no concern for human suffering was or is discernible." At the Somme "he had sent the flower of British youth to death or mutilation; at Passchendaele he had tipped the survivors into the slough of despond." The generals, like the politicians, were in a war they had not expected and did not understand; but the insouciant enthusiasm with which they sent hundreds of thousands of young men to their death retains its power to shock and nauseate a century later.
 Keegan's book has certain weaknesses. He is very good at explaining how the war began, and why it was in so many ways an accident -- only the Serbian nationalists who sought to dismember Hapsburg power in the Balkans and the German general staff, which had a "plan" to eliminate France and then smash the Russians, actively sought a conflagration. He rightly plays down the "war aims" of the great powers, which were cobbled into being in the course of the conflict but did not bring it about. Yet Keegan's account of how and why the war ended is weak, and this weakness reflects a larger failing. In a book written from a distinctively British angle, the emphasis is understandably on the war as something experienced and remembered by soldiers. In British memory, therefore, World War I was a victory bought in blood, a conflict whose successful outcome does not suffice to excuse its human cost. But its institutional and political significance was slight.
 In Continental Europe, by contrast, the legacy of the war went farther. The way in which the war was lost is what counted for German memory, which is why the political developments of 1918, shortchanged in this book, were so significant. In France the lessons of Verdun, the Nivelle offensive and the mutinies bore sour fruit in the depressed, morbid squabbling of interwar politics and the catastrophe of 1940. Over much of the rest of the Continent the war spelled the end of economic stability, social order, imperial authority. The history of World War I in the lands of central, eastern and southeastern Europe is inseparable from the collapse of the home front and a series of bloody revolutions and counterrevolutions.
 Keegan makes this point for the Russian case but neglects its application elsewhere. When Poles or Ukrainians later wrote or spoke of the war, they were remembering not just the experience of the set-piece battles in Galicia or East Prussia but also, and perhaps especially, the civil wars and vicious partisan fighting (and pogroms) that began before the armistice of November 1918 and lasted for years to come. In Turkey the war, the peace, the political revolution of Ataturk and the conflicts with Greece that followed in the immediate aftermath form a single whole. A history of the war that limits itself to the organized fighting on the main fronts and comes to an end in 1918 has a story to tell, certainly; but it is not the whole story.
 For, in the words of a wounded Indian soldier writing home from the Western Front in 1915, "This is not war, it is the ending of the world." And so it was. The world that died in the fields of Europe, along with more than nine million men in the course of just 52 months of fighting, was something beyond the sum of its stricken parts. The new world of Europe that would emerge from the experience was quite different: darker, more violent, more polarized, more cynical, less sure of itself and less given to confident assertions of its own superiority and prospects, except in a poisonous ideological form. In short, the European 20th century, whose memory and aftershocks are with us still.

LENGTH: 1033 words

HEADLINE: Typical Americans

BYLINE: By Jean Thompson; Jean Thompson's most recent book is "Who Do You Love," a collection of short stories.

 BODY:

WHO'S IRISH?
Stories.
By Gish Jen.
208 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $22. 
 IF the American immigrant experience is most often construed as a process of merging and gradual assimilation, like traffic on a freeway, then Gish Jen's version resembles a busy intersection with everybody laying on the horn. Her novels, "Typical American" and "Mona in the Promised Land," and now the stories of "Who's Irish?," portray cultures in splendid confusion and outright collision. There is no monolithic mainstream here but rather a conglomeration of Others, a dynamic, free-for-all, often loopy national motorcade.
 Jen mines this material for equal measures of pathos and wry fun. She has a clear-eyed affection for people who struggle to find their places in the world. Readers of the novels will re-encounter, in two of the eight stories in "Who's Irish?," the Changs -- the resolutely non-American father, aggravated mother and perceptive daughters. For Ralph and Helen, the older generation, the ancestral homeland is a fading memory, but Ralph retains an indelible, stubborn sense of separation that resists any tempering by the melting pot. Helen is more adaptable: "She had opinions about how downtown should be zoned; she could pump her own gas and check her own oil." The narrator here is Callie, the older and more anxious girl. She and her sister, Mona, act as mediators and witnesses when wars erupt between their parents, and between Ralph and America in general.
 In "The Water Faucet Vision" the conflict is marital. Ralph and Helen argue in Shanghainese, a dialect the girls don't speak, and in the universal language of throwing things. Callie, "the kind of girl who grows morbid in Catholic school," practices ostentatious piety and prays for miracles of reconciliation. Later Helen leaps out a second-story window, shocking everyone with the sudden enormity of events.
 "In the American Society" chronicles Ralph's misadventures as the obstinately hapless owner of a pancake house. The undocumented Chinese immigrants he hires clash with the Latino cook. The family's country club application is given the same politely dismissive treatment afforded those of African-Americans. And Ralph is badgered by a drunken party guest who keeps demanding, aptly enough in this maze of fractured identities, "Who are you?" Throughout it all, Ralph maintains a dignity borne of belligerent incomprehension. "Your father doesn't believe in joining the American society," Helen explains. "He wants to have his own society."
 Just as "Mona in the Promised Land" advanced the saga from one generation to the next, "Who's Irish?" moves beyond the Changs to other characters, although family remains a unifying theme. In the title story a Chinese grandmother attributes her granddaughter's misbehavior to the Irish side of her parentage. The ensuing battles over how, or even if, to discipline the child divide along generational rather than ethnic boundaries. Ultimately the two grandmothers, Chinese and Irish, align themselves, a reconstituted family unit that achieves a harmony of nations on a small, human scale.
 Other stories take up the diverse paths followed by the children of immigrants, hypersuccessful bourgeois or rebels, either "full of Asian consciousness" or, like one enigmatic soul, a serious North Woods type who eschews electricity. "Duncan in China," one of the best and richest offerings, sends this new generation back to China in search of a now-distant heritage. Duncan is a failure in America; he dreams of "the China of the scholar-officials, the China of ineffable nobility and restraint." Predictably, he finds nothing of the sort. The new China is a place of physical discomforts and spiritual and social mysteries, where every appearance is misleading. Duncan's jovial colleague insults him with a smile. The lovable students in his English class may be spies. The woman Duncan falls in love with has other plans for him.
 Duncan's cousin, impoverished and physically broken by the Cultural Revolution, is both pathetic and gratingly importuning. Family, in this case, provides only a disturbing image of a life Duncan himself might have lived. This is a splendid story, encompassing yearning, humor and tragedy.
 The structure of "Who's Irish?" is eccentric, if we define a story as a piece of prose of some predetermined length. There are brief narratives and expansive ones, a sense of material struggling to find its proper form, sketches that have grown or novels that have been recast or perhaps never made it off the ground. If we dismiss length as an arbitrary consideration, we still expect from stories focus, balance, momentum and the satisfaction of a tale told both completely and economically.
 "House, House, Home," which makes up a third of the book, reads more like a compressed but low-key novel. Chinese-American Pammie marries her art history professor, the maddeningly self-absorbed Sven. Although the writing is nothing if not witty, the story bogs down in the lengthy intellectual and emotional skirmishes that attend the inevitable breakup of the marriage. ("How she had been wifed, how she had been fetishized, how she had been viewed as Orientalia.")
 When the stories better fit inside their skins, the results are inspired. "Birthmates" (included in the recent, exhausting volume "The Best American Short Stories of the Century") tells of Art Woo, a struggling businessman. His wife has left him after the loss of their unborn child. He's bedeviled by a wisecracking trade rival who speaks a dialect Art calls Mainstreamese. By mistake Art books himself into a welfare hotel on a business trip; the resulting misadventures are ironic and genuinely mournful. The story moves fluidly between action and thought, building a structure that conveys all the hopefulness and longing of Art's life.
 Jen's gift is for comedy that resonates, and sadnesses that arise with perfect timing from absurdities. Her subject matter is so appealing, it almost obscures the power and suppleness of her language. "Who's Irish?," at its considerable best, finds words for all the high and low notes of the raucous American anthem.

HEADLINE: Company Woman

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle covers economics for The Times.

 BODY:

NEW WORLD, NEW RULES
The Changing Role of the American Corporation.
By Marina v. N. Whitman.
261 pp. Boston:
Harvard Business School Press. $29.95. 
 How can anyone complain about corporate practices when the economy seems to be working so well? Instead of criticism, the American model for doing business is offered to the world as the template for national prosperity. Apply the template, Europe and Asia are told, and you will prosper, too.
 Large corporations, according to the American model, should no longer be the chief source of social benefits. And in the United States they no longer are. Job security, community loyalty, raises, health insurance, pensions -- all these are much more optional now. Freed of such costly burdens, companies see themselves as more successful in the intensely competitive global marketplace.
 For better or worse, companies everywhere are applying this template. Prosperity, of course, is the chief prod. Success is convincing, and this is reflected in the mainstream literature on corporate behavior, once so devoted to extolling the Japanese way. Certainly Marina v. N. Whitman, a professor of business administration and public policy at the University of Michigan, embraces the American model in "New World, New Rules," which barely mentions Japan, now so mired in recession.
 "Nations on every continent and at every level of development have paid us the ultimate compliment of imitation," she writes. "They emulate our form of economic organization in hopes of achieving the economic riches that Americans enjoy and take for granted."
 Whitman is understandably partisan. She was an economist in the Nixon Administration and a vice president and chief economist at General Motors from 1979 to 1992, when the nation's giant corporations were evolving into their current more global, less patriarchal form. She is a friend and colleague of the politicians and executives who preach the wonders of the American model.
 Perhaps that is why she shares with her readers almost none of what she witnessed at G.M. or felt in those stressful years. At a farewell party early in her tenure, she praised a departing executive for his outstanding contribution to the company, only to be criticized by her superiors for praising someone "who had demonstrated his disloyalty by leaving" the company. "By the time I left G.M. a decade later," she writes, "we were all gaining weight attending a constant series of farewell parties for departing colleagues," all encouraged by G.M. to get out.
 That is about as personal as Whitman gets. Absent are the anecdotes, the feelings, the judgments shaped by her own experience that could have lifted "New World, New Rules" to the level of original, significant history. What she offers instead is first-class Cliffs Notes: abstract, dry, nonjudgmental, textbook-dull, but fairly scrupulous in listing the standard pros and cons of the market-driven American model, with its aversion to regulation.
 There are sections, for example, praising workplace changes in which middle managers have disappeared and workers operate in self-motivated teams. What is missing is the more troubling observation offered lately by people like the New York University sociologist Richard Sennett, who argues that the teams, far from empowering workers, alienate and control them.
 Whitman is at her best in recognizing that the American model will survive as a beacon only if it weathers the inevitable next economic downturn. Corporate America, not government, she argues, must provide the social programs that can protect workers in harder times. And she lists such ideas as job training, portable pensions and temporary work to ease the transition from one job to the next.
 She also insists that income inequality must not widen in the next downturn, exacerbating social tensions. The world will prosper only if the American model endures, she asserts. But in her guarded prose, she never manages to convince a reader that she herself believes it will, in fact, endure.
