SECTION: Section 6; Page 30; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 8312 words

HEADLINE: Eclipsed

BYLINE: By Bill Keller; Bill Keller is the managing editor of The Times. He would like to acknowledge the assistance of Maxim Tarasenko, a young Russian space expert, who was killed by a hit-and-run driver on May 14.

 BODY:
If you can't get to the moon, Baikonur is not a bad approximation. The rocket range that bills itself as "the Biggest Cosmodrome in the World" is a bleak expanse of pitted flatlands, unbearably cold except when it is unbearably hot and impossibly remote.
The features that make it a wretched place for humans were all points in its favor when Baikonur was chosen as the main testing facility for Russia's missiles and space rockets. It is possible to fire a test rocket 5,000 miles without landing in China or Turkey or Japan and with little danger of bombarding a major city. The skies are usually clear. The terrain is ideal for retrieving misfires. And there is no one around to snoop. 
 In the depths of the cold war, battalions of engineers, scientists and generals converged here to astonish the world. It was from Baikonur, in the span of 43 months, that the Soviets launched the first satellite, the first dog, the first rocket to hit the moon and the first man in space.
When I visited Baikonur this spring, it took a constant effort to recall that this barren sweep of steppe had been a front in one of the greatest battles in the history of the cold war -- indeed, of nationalist-inspired adventure. Today on the wind-swept test range, whole blocks of apartment buildings sit deserted. The network of launching stations that once blasted 150 civilian rockets into space each year now handles only 20 or 30. In fact, the cosmodrome is not even in Russia anymore; thanks to the dissolution of the Soviet Union, it is now part of Kazakhstan, a sovereign country that suffers the Russian presence somewhat grumpily.
Bundled against a searing wind, I rode with Russian escorts past banks of tracking radar and rusting tanks of liquid oxygen and kerosene to a destination now usually closed to outsiders -- Area 110, which was built to be the scene of the greatest Soviet space triumph, the launching of a giant booster rocket that would deliver the first man to the moon.
For an hour, my companions and I ambled about the long-abandoned apparatus, circling the great flame pits and the metal tracks on which the servicing tower was slowly wheeled into place for launches. Sagebrush poked through cracks in the concrete. The old transporter that took the rockets to their pad sat like an upended metal cockroach. Surveying the ruin, the Russians joked that it was as if aliens had landed, built a civilization and then suddenly flown away.
On a lark, we huffed up the stairs of the old service tower and stood on a platform 150 feet above the launch pad.
"There you are," said Sergei Solovyov, the deputy director responsible for this artifact, saluting the view with a sardonic flourish. "It's like visiting the pyramids of Egypt."
On July 20, 1969, 30 years ago next month, Apollo 11 set down in the Sea of Tranquillity. The story of how the Americans won the moon race is known to earthlings around the globe. The story of how the Russians lost -- and how close they came -- has remained well buried in the wreckage of the Soviet experiment.
The secrecy enveloping the Soviet space program in its time was pathological. The identities of the chief rocket designers were literally state secrets. The Soviets worked in isolated communities, their scientific works were unpublished, their successes were anonymous, their failures were covered up. That the Soviet Union was striving to land men on the moon was not only withheld from the public but also officially, categorically denied. And when the Russian moon program was finally abandoned, the Kremlin spent considerable effort to expunge it from history.
In the past decade, however, the tale has leaked up from its grave. A Government-sanctioned version of the Soviet moon project was published in 1989. Since then, several space veterans have picked at the official account in memoirs of their experiences. Earlier this year, when I went to interview the octogenarian survivors of the Soviet moon mission, it was like sitting in on an argument that had suddenly been resumed after a 30-year interruption, an outpouring of ancient but vivid memories colored by some score settling and self-vindication. On the American side, where the Soviet moon effort was a topic of copious spycraft and speculation, the C.I.A. has gradually declassified many secret satellite photographs and intelligence reports from the period.
From all of this, we learn that the Russians entered the moon race grudgingly, that many Russian rocket makers doubted the race was winnable, or even worth winning -- what was this contest, anyway, but a monstrously expensive exercise in political vanity? We also learn that in this competition the Soviets were as much at war with themselves as with us. Most of all, we learn that despite it all, they gave us a race, a real race.
On April 12, 1961, John F. Kennedy received the news that the Soviet Union had sent the first human into orbit around the earth. The ferociously competitive young President directed his Vice President, Lyndon Johnson, to survey expert opinion and report back what America could do to regain its plummeting prestige.
"Do we have a chance of beating the Soviets by putting a laboratory in space, or by a trip around the moon, or by a rocket to land on the moon, or by a rocket to go to the moon and back with a man?" Kennedy asked in a memo to the Vice President. "Is there any other space program which promises dramatic results in which we could win?"
Wernher von Braun, the German rocket inventor who joined the American effort after World War II, told the Vice President that the Americans had "a sporting chance" of flying men around the moon first, but that he felt the best bet was to try a manned moon landing. Such a feat would require a monster rocket, 10 to 15 times as large as the one that had lofted the cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin into orbit. The U.S. Air Force had done considerable work on such a rocket.
On May 25, Kennedy told Congress that we were going to the moon, that American stature depended on it. In the years to come, supporters of the space venture would articulate a variety of justifications for Kennedy's undertaking: the romantic notion of manifest destiny, the scientific yearning for knowledge, the stimulation of new technology, even delusional schemes to create a military outpost on the moon. But the first and fundamental reason the Americans decided to go to the moon was simple: we thought we could get there first.
The moon was not on the Soviet agenda, but it did tantalize the one man responsible for the apparent Soviet dominance in space: Sergei Pavlovich Korolev. Korolev (pronounced kor-ul-YOV) was the most influential of the chief designers who presided over Soviet aerospace. His rocket-design campus, based at a former artillery factory outside Moscow, had given the world Sputnik and the first man in space, not to mention the first intercontinental ballistic missile.
Long before Kennedy's speech, Korolev had set his sights on the moon -- not as a geopolitical prize, or even as a destination, really, but as a platform for more ambitious missions to the planets beyond. Already he had launched the first rocket to hit the moon; it smashed into the surface with a cargo of Soviet souvenir dog tags, thus setting a record for cosmic tackiness that would stand until 1971, when Alan Shepard of Apollo 14 hit golf balls across the lunar fairway. Another of Korolev's spacecraft had sent back the first photographs of the dark side of the moon.
Korolev had few illusions about the system he served. When he was 31 and a promising engineer at a rocket-design institute, Stalin's goons knocked at his door early one morning and took him away from his wife and sleeping 3-year-old daughter. A victim of the Soviet leader's systematic purge of the intelligentsia, Korolev was confronted with testimony extracted from three colleagues and beaten until he confessed to preposterous charges that he had conspired in aid of German rocket designers. He was cast into the lowest circle of Stalin's hell, the frozen pit mines of Kolyma, where he felled trees and pushed wheelbarrows in the excruciating cold. He had lost his teeth and damaged his heart by the time, a year later, he was summoned to less brutal custody -- a prison aerospace-design facility run by the secret police. For another six years, Korolev helped design aircraft and rockets for the war effort while confined with other purged intellectuals.
Soviets of Korolev's generation tend to minimize the psychological impact of Stalin's terror; with the arrest of something like five million of the country's brightest in just one spasm of paranoia in 1937 and 1938, unjust persecution hardly qualified as an exceptional experience. "We were absolutely indifferent to the camps," insisted Boris Raushenbakh, one of many rocket makers who, like Korolev, survived the hardships of forced labor. "They were like natural events." Korolev's daughter, Natalya, the keeper of a trove of her father's memorabilia, said he refused ever to talk of his experiences as a prisoner.
Yet there were aspects of Korolev that were, at the least, reinforced by his brush with the brutality of the Soviet state. Though he would later mouth the platitudes of the Communist Party, friends say he did so without much pretense of conviction. Though he gave his country a formidable arsenal, his real allegiance seemed always to be to a less nationalistic dream, humankind's dominion in space. And he was unmistakably blessed with some of the skills that this horrid system bestowed on many of its citizens -- including a capacity to swallow suffering and a gift for wily improvisation.
After the war, Korolev was absolved of his charges, commissioned a colonel and sent with a military delegation to Germany to mine whatever records of the German weapons program had not already been snatched up by the Americans. They brought back the blueprints of the German V-2 missile, which under Korolev's guidance evolved into a family of Soviet rockets so successful that they are still in use today.
By 1961, when the moon race began, Korolev dominated the landscape of Soviet rocketry. James Harford, whose biography of Korolev, the first in English, was published in 1997, ranks Korolev ahead of von Braun among the greats of space, not just for the litany of his space spectaculars but also because in a short life he excelled across the entire range of space achievement.
Korolev was less a technical wizard than a visionary and a master director -- a bit of H.G. Wells, a lot of Orson Welles. He had the kind of bluff, rules-be-damned charisma that stands out in a nation of bureaucrats. Pictures (made public, of course, only after his death) show a broad-shouldered, bull-necked, square-faced man with riveting black eyes. Sometimes he is shown tieless, sleeves rolled up, with a rakish fedora shading his brow. His salesman's charm was irresistible -- to the rocket makers he urged and bullied through 16-hour days, to an array of women and to the political leaders on whom his program depended.
In his memoirs, the Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev recalls the rocket chief's visit to the ruling Politburo shortly after Stalin's death. The party luminaries gathered and stared in disbelief as Korolev displayed his rocket models and explained how the wingless, cigar-shaped contraptions could reach America -- or Mars. "I don't want to exaggerate, but I'd say we gawked at what he showed us as if we were a bunch of sheep seeing a new gate for the first time." Khrushchev became a regular visitor to the rocket-design bureaus, where he inspected each new device with childish delight.
In 1964, Korolev would persuade the Kremlin to let him draft a trustworthy newspaper reporter and a television newscaster into his corps of cosmonauts, in hopes that the ensuing publicity would inspire greater support for space exploration. This was decades before NASA realized the public-relations value of sending schoolteachers and senators into space.
"Actually, he wanted to send a poet, a Lermontov, but that was out of the question," recalled Yaroslav Golovanov, the newspaper correspondent who trained for a spaceflight but never made it.
On Dec. 5, 1962, the C.I.A. completed its top-secret annual assessment of the Soviet space program. The agency's verdict was that an American victory was no sure thing. "Given their ability to concentrate human and material resources on priority objectives," the agency contended, "we estimate that with a strong national effort the Soviets could accomplish a manned lunar landing in the period 1967 to 1969."
The American view of the Soviet Union at the time was one of wonder and suspicion. Kennedy had campaigned against Richard Nixon with the claim that the Soviets enjoyed a menacing lead in nuclear warheads. (One missile-gap alarmist put the Soviet advantage at 3,000 weapons.) After Sputnik, American schoolchildren were drilled for the possibility of nuclear attack, and the backyard bomb shelter became a cottage industry.
In hindsight it is clear that the Soviet Union was actually a Wizard of Oz state, straining to maintain its superpower status. At the time of Kennedy's challenge, the country was 15 years past a war that killed 27 million of its people, eight years past the vicious rule of Stalin. Its economy was a clumsy, musclebound extension of the state bureaucracy. It had no nimble private industrial base -- no General Electrics, no Lockheeds, no Boeings.
Moreover, by at least the end of 1961, satellite intelligence had shown Kennedy that the missile gap was, in fact, very much in America's favor. The C.I.A.'s most generous estimate was that the Soviets had a mere 25 missiles capable of reaching American soil -- Russian experts today put the number as low as 4 -- and they required so long to be fueled that they could be caught on the ground if America struck first.
All of this Khrushchev knew, and he waged an effective public campaign of bluster and bravado to prevent the world from seeing the little man behind the curtain. When Kennedy, a month after his space challenge, proposed to collaborate with the Russians on a lunar venture, Khrushchev declined. Loath as he might have been to enter into a costly moon race, he did not want to be seen as America's junior partner in the venture -- and he did not want Americans to see how much the Soviet image was built on a bluff.
"My father rejected it because, he told me, 'If we will try to work together then they will know how weak we are, that we have no missiles,"' said Sergei Khrushchev, who has been the main curator of his father's records and memoirs.
Like Khrushchev, Soviet space scientists approached Kennedy's moon challenge warily. What he proposed would demand an effort, the scale and expense of which was far beyond anything Korolev had undertaken to date.
"Our first thought," said Boris Chertok, the brilliant engineer who designed most of Korolev's guidance systems, "was, Is this a bluff, or is he serious? Our impression was it was not a bluff. The feeling within the engineering community was that it was realistic and could be done. And it gave us a sense of satisfaction, because we were sure it would force our leadership to pay more attention to the Soviet space program."
Within the secret network of scientists and engineers, there was at first no consensus that it made sense to rise to the American challenge. Some engineers, like Boris Raushenbakh and Konstantin Feoktistov, say they argued at the time that the Soviets could not match America in a spendathon and should instead build an orbiting space station, which played to their strengths and would create an impressive and lasting redoubt in space. Others, especially the scientists, argued for focusing on unmanned space exploration, which would be cheaper and less risky.
Korolev, however, embraced Kennedy's challenge as a justification for his own dream of manned space travel and rallied the rocket makers around him. Look what we have already accomplished against long odds, he exhorted. Think how we could dazzle the world.
"Later, space would become just a job," said Raushenbakh, who, like most of the engineers, was soon won over. "In that first decade, it was a romance."
Korolev faced more serious resistance from the political leaders, and especially the generals, who were alarmed by America's flourishing arsenal.
Throughout the attempt to land Soviets on the moon, the space program would compete for money with an array of military initiatives. Precise comparisons are almost impossible because the systems were so utterly different, but in the end the Soviets would spend no more than half of the $25 billion America invested in the Apollo program, and the fraction may have been much smaller.
The battle for time was even more taxing than the battle for money. Unlike the United States, whose civilian space program was largely independent of the military, the Soviet Union employed the same engineers, factories and launching pads for both the arms race and the space race. Soviet engineers were simultaneously laboring to match the Americans in intercontinental ballistic missiles, cruise missiles, antimissile defense weapons, bombers and fighter planes, plus brainstorming a variety of more outlandish ventures, like an orbiting military space station.
"We could only undertake a lunar program as a sideline," said Chertok, the guidance engineer. "Not one of us was freed of our military responsibilities. The problem was not only the burden on the work force and the production facilities, but on the brains as well."
Moreover, since Soviet industry was organized on the company-town model, with every public service an outgrowth of the factory, Korolev was in effect the ward heeler for the little town called Podlipki on the edge of Moscow where his work force lived.
"Unlike von Braun and NASA, Korolev had to worry about the building of this whole municipality, about kindergartens and schools and hospitals and health care for his employees," Chertok said when I visited him at Podlipki, which was recently renamed Korolev. "He had to lobby the Government to make sure the food allotments to his workers were up to Moscow standards."
Korolev pleaded and badgered and connived to keep the program moving. To win over the ruble-conscious political leaders, Korolev low-balled his estimates of what a moon program would cost. To win over the military, he promised that his moon program would deliver an array of strategic advantages.
"Korolev was always doing his space work on the backs of the military," recalled Gen. Kerim Kerimov, who was the military's watchdog over Korolev. "When the military asked for a rocket to send up spy satellites, which required a lift of three tons, Korolev made a rocket capable of lifting seven tons and sent Gagarin."
The military complained constantly to Dmitri Ustinov, the Minister of Armaments, but the powerful Ustinov had been an early patron of Korolev.
"Ustinov would sigh and say, 'You are probably right, we will take measures,"' Kerimov chuckled. "But he loved Korolev."
When it came to his big moon rocket, which was called the N-1, Korolev again rolled the military. Boris Dorofeyev, who supervised the design of the rocket, said the early proposals sent to the Kremlin billed the N-1 as a vehicle for lofting military spy satellites, for carrying multiple warheads around the globe, even for putting a nuclear battle station into orbit.
"There was some vague wording about 'investigation of the moon and planets,' but there was not a word about landing a man on the moon," Dorofeyev told me over his dining-room table in Podlipki.
As the project evolved, and the military realized that the slow-fueling rocket would be a sitting duck on a launch pad, the putative military uses dropped off one by one, until the N-1 no longer pretended to be anything but the vehicle to get a Russian to the moon.
Reluctant as Khrushchev was to enter into another spending duel with the United States, he was also not prepared to lose. In February 1962, Khrushchev invited the rocket designers to his country retreat in the Crimea, and after a day of feasting and conversation authorized the designers to proceed with their moon rocket. The commitment was a little vague, and it would take another two years of cajoling to get it into bankable form.
Finally, in 1964, with Khrushchev on the verge of being ousted from power, Korolev drafted a letter to the party's second in command, Leonid Brezhnev. The document, published only last year, was a brazen appeal. In it, Korolev claimed that the American program, with its powerful Saturn rocket, had leapt so far ahead that the Americans stood a good chance of landing on the moon as early as 1967, in time to spoil the 50th anniversary of the Russian revolution.
That somewhat exaggerated warning seemed to get the Kremlin's attention. In August 1964, the party issued a decree formally establishing the goal of sending a man to the moon. It was somewhat more equivocal than Kennedy's -- and it was secret -- but the Soviet rocket makers now felt they were fully in the game.
"At that time, it still seemed possible," Chertok said. "We thought we could be the first to circumnavigate the moon, and that we could at least hold our own in the race for a lunar landing."
In a race that would last 98 months, from Kennedy's speech to Armstrong's landing, the Soviet Union was 39 months behind. Korolev was starting late. But he was wasting no time. By October 1964, an American Corona spy satellite passing over Baikonur photographed a huge hangar and the first excavations of a large, new launch pad. For the Americans, it was the strongest evidence yet that the Soviets had decided to take on J.F.K. "They knew then," said Charles P. Vick, an expert in the Russian space program, "that something big was going on."
Getting there was not the challenge of a lunar expedition. Both sides had shown they could slam a rocket into the moon. The problem was getting back. In order to make a round trip, you have to lug the spacecraft in which a crew would orbit the moon, a vehicle for descending to the surface, the fuel to get off the moon and sufficient shielding to protect the passengers when they re-enter the earth's atmosphere. Throw in a lunar rover and this is heavy freight indeed, on the order of 100 tons. There were many other complications -- the intricate choreography of a rendezvous in lunar orbit, for example -- but the single biggest hurdle was the need for that monster rocket.
To complicate matters, the Soviets needed a rocket with extra lift to compensate for their geographic disadvantage. The gateway to lunar orbit is through the Southern Hemisphere. Because the Soviet Union sits so far north on the globe -- and because Korolev and company were reluctant to risk firing rockets south across China -- they launched on a northern trajectory, which required them to shimmy from one earth orbit to another for the best access to the moon.
And to make the challenge even more daunting, the Soviets were compelled to mount this effort not with a unified team of scientists and designers but with a rocket industry riven by divisions personal, professional and bureaucratic.
Thanks to the kind of wasteful whimsy that shaped much of the Soviet economy, aerospace was split into parallel industrial complexes. After World War II, the Soviets at first thought to put rockets into the Aviation Ministry. But the Aviation Minister of the time sneered at rocketry as an unfit match for the manly business of piloting airplanes. The shrewder Dmitri Ustinov, by now Stalin's Minister of Defense, recognized the potential of missiles and adopted them into his branch of the Government -- as artillery. Since Aviation had no interest in sharing with Artillery, Defense built its own duplicate network of aerospace contractors and subcontractors: for engines, guidance systems, fuels.
The situation was thus ripe for conflicts, the most fateful of which developed between Korolev and the Soviet Union's leading maker of big rocket engines, Valentin Glushko.
Glushko had preceded Korolev into the labor camps, and according to documents published last year, Korolev knew that Glushko was one of the three colleagues who had given testimony against him -- testimony extracted by torture, no doubt, but perhaps not the foundation of a trusting friendship. Glushko, for his part, had never quite got over the fact that during their years together in the forced-labor aerospace facilities, he had outranked Korolev in the prison pecking order. The engine maker was a proud and prickly character, with sufficient status in the Balkanized world of Russian rocketry that he could say no, even to Korolev.
By the beginning of the 60's, Glushko was in great demand for military projects. He had developed a series of ingenious engines based on a storable propellant that could sit for months in a silo and fire in short order. This fuel solved the sitting-duck problem of Soviet nuclear missiles, but it had a serious defect for a rocket intended to carry human cargo. The fuel was powerfully toxic and in an accident would be likely to spray the cosmonauts and anyone nearby with lethal fumes. Korolev pressed Glushko to come up with a more powerful engine based on a safer formula of kerosene and liquid oxygen. The headstrong rocket maker refused. Thus Korolev began his most ambitious undertaking without the services of the country's top engine maker.
Korolev turned to an aircraft-engine designer, who did not have the experience or facilities to build a giant engine. While the engine the designer came up with was a masterpiece of engineering -- so reliable that two American companies now import it -- it was also so small that it required a ring of 30 of them to lift the N-1 moon rocket.
No one, before or since, has built a rocket with more than 10 engines. For Korolev's rocket to succeed, it would have to depend on highly sophisticated electronic choreography. The engine vibrations had to be synchronized to prevent catastrophic fits of shaking. Moreover, the designers had to assure that if one engine in the circle failed, its opposite number would switch off to keep the thrust balanced and prevent the rocket from tilting to the side. This would have been a lot to ask of engineers anywhere, but the Soviet Union was famously weak in the kind of miniature electronics required.
Roald Sagdeev, a physicist who for a time ran the Soviet Space Research Institute, said microelectronics never had the dazzle it took to capture the interest of the political leaders, who were, in effect, the C.E.O.'s of all Soviet industry.
"Under the czars, the bells always had to be big," said Sagdeev, who now teaches at the University of Maryland. "The same thing with the Politburo. They loved the big pieces of hardware. Tiny things like small electronic brains -- who would pay attention to that?"
Right up to the finish line, the Soviets toyed with a variety of scenarios for reaching the moon, but by late 1964, Korolev had settled on an approach not unlike the one chosen by the Americans -- a launch into earth orbit, then a second leap into lunar orbit, from which a module would descend to the lunar surface. While the American module was equipped for two men, the Soviet version would have deposited a single cosmonaut on the surface. To further cut the weight, there would be no air lock connecting the lunar orbiter to the landing craft -- the cosmonaut would spacewalk from one vehicle to the other. Later, the Soviet scheme was refined to include an advance ship, an unmanned moon flight that would drop off a spare escape module, in case the cosmonaut's landing craft failed to take off.
While the two countries vied to perfect their powerful rockets, they competed simultaneously to develop spacecraft for a moon voyage -- vehicles that could endure for days, carry a crew of astronauts, navigate through space, dock in orbit. Throughout the early 60's, Korolev's designers labored on a family of spacecraft: the Vostok, which took Yuri Gagarin into space, a clunky upgrade called the Voskhod and the more elaborate, two-compartment Soyuz. Repeatedly they beat the Americans by coming up with new space maneuvers.
The Soviets embellished their technical feats with propaganda flourishes, like sending the first woman into space (proof that the Communist utopia had achieved equality of the sexes!). And they were not beyond a little sleight of hand. In August 1962, for example, the Soviets became the first nation to send up two manned space capsules at the same time. They fired one Vostok into orbit, and then, when it sailed over Baikonur a day later, they launched a second into orbit alongside it. The two capsules cruised past American tracking stations about three miles apart, creating the impression that the Soviets had somehow maneuvered them together. According to Vasily Mishin, Korolev's deputy, the Soviets were happy to help the Americans fool themselves.
The pressure of the space race sometimes drove the Soviets to push their luck. In 1964, knowing the Americans were on the verge of sending up a spacecraft with two astronauts, Khrushchev called Korolev and -- according to Mishin -- demanded the launch of a vehicle with three cosmonauts as quickly as possible.
Since the Voskhod spacecraft they were testing was too small to fit such a crew in full regalia, the Soviets decided to launch the cosmonauts without space suits -- and without ejection seats.
"Was it risky?" Mishin said to James Harford. "Of course it was. For approximately 20 seconds of flight prior to insertion into orbit, the crew did not have any means of escape in the event of an emergency." In October, the three unprotected cosmonauts -- including Konstantin Feoktistov, who helped design the cramped vehicle -- succeeded in making 16 orbits of the earth, beating the American two-man flight handily.
In the next Voskhod flight, five months later, Aleksei Leonov had a more gut-wrenching experience while racing to beat the Americans in the first spacewalk. The space suit for the first extravehicular adventure was a rush job; the only time the empty suit was sent into space for quality testing, the delivery vehicle self-destructed. Then an unmanned Voskhod test flight, intended to gather crucial data for the humans to follow, exploded. With only one Voskhod left in the hangar, Korolev and his cosmonauts decided to chance a manned flight anyway, and it was nearly a calamity. The moment Leonov emerged from the capsule into the great vacuum of space, his soft suit ballooned until he resembled the Pillsbury Doughboy. He discovered he could not manipulate the gloves or bend his legs, and his inflated suit would not fit back through the hatch. At the risk of giving himself a lethal case of the bends, he depressurized his suit enough to slither back inside.
Then, on the return trip, the automatic re-entry system failed, requiring Leonov and his partner to steer in manually. Afraid of landing in a city's electrical lines or, worse, in China, they aimed for the Ural Mountains, where they landed wedged between two fir trees in deep snow, and waited overnight for a rescue. Naturally, none of the mishaps were made public for a quarter of a century. The first spacewalk was hailed as yet another advance on the Americans.
Leonov, now a glad-handing executive at one of Moscow's private banks, shrugs off the danger. "We went into it with our eyes open. My job was test pilot, after all. And extreme caution would have meant we lost the race."
As Korolev's moon program gained traction in 1965, he had to worry not only about the Americans -- whose big rocket, the Saturn, was already showing promise in suborbital flights -- but also about rival designers eager for a piece of the action.
The most notable of these was Vladimir Chelomei, who ran a design bureau under the Aviation Ministry specializing in cruise missiles. A possessive and ill-tempered technical wizard, Chelomei spent most of his life making missiles for the military and thus lived and died in an even tighter shroud of secrecy than Korolev.
In March, I negotiated a corkscrew of back roads through the remaining winter snow and slop outside Moscow to visit the cruise-missile factory where Chelomei presided, and to hear his side of the story from one of his top designers, Vladimir Polyachenko.
Polyachenko took me to an outlying guest house and unpacked a sheaf of tidy, handwritten notes, which he had copied for the occasion from historical documents in the factory archive. ("These are not classified," he explained, when a Russian space expert accompanying me expressed his excitement at these documents. "They are just not available.")
Over the course of two hours, my host made a strong case that Chelomei's plan for the moon was, in fact, technically superior to Korolev's. This is not a viewpoint that has been argued much, in part because Korolev's heirs are the ones writing memoirs. I don't claim to be qualified to judge, but by the time Polyachenko was done, I wondered if the Soviets, charmed by Korolev, had not bet on the wrong genius.
Within the design fraternity, Chelomei was outspokenly contemptuous of Korolev's 30-engine moon rocket. A specialist in dynamics, he contended that it was nearly impossible to synchronize the vibrations of so many engines. But since Korolev had locked up the lunar-landing franchise, Chelomei concocted an alternative proposal to fly men around the moon. It involved using a large, nearly perfected rocket called the Proton, based on Glushko's toxic-fueled engines, to launch a great vehicle on a circumlunar trajectory.
In late 1965, an expert commission endorsed the scheme, with 47 scientists and engineers supporting it and only three, all from Korolev's shop, dissenting.
"We thought going around the moon was more realistic, given the short time," Polyachenko said. "We believed a lunar flyby was easier to achieve and would help solve the harder problem of landing on the moon."
Chelomei was not a complete illiterate in the political arts. He had the wit to hire Khrushchev's son, Sergei, as a rocket engineer. But he was no match for the manipulative wile of Korolev.
A month after the report came out, Korolev held a meeting at his headquarters in Podlipki and unveiled his latest scheme. Now Korolev wanted to expand his program to include a flight around the moon -- using a hybrid of Chelomei's booster and his own N-1, with his own spacecraft mounted on top. Chelomei, in effect, would provide the truck that would deliver Korolev's payload around the moon. In late 1965, this plan was added to Korolev's mandate, and Chelomei -- though he continued to promote his rocket for lunar flights -- was essentially out of the moon business.
In co-opting his rival, though, Korolev had spread himself even thinner. "These two programs consumed a lot of resources and effort, and they were not linked technologically," said Chertok, the engineer, who at 87 is writing about this period for the fourth volume of his memoirs. "They had nothing in common except one stage of the rocket -- different spaceships, different guidance systems, different engines and so on. So we were chasing two rabbits."
Within the Kremlin, there was growing irritation that the Americans seemed to be acting more Soviet than the Soviets. Korolev's newly published records include notes he took at a stormy meeting of top party leaders, in which they railed in exasperation at the rival rocket czars for putting "private interests" above "common state interests." Just look at how the Americans seemed to have mastered their "capitalist antagonisms," one party leader exclaimed.
This may be the most delicious paradox of the space race: while the Americans, those free-market gladiators, assembled a huge bureaucracy and frog-marched their industry in a great mobilization, the ostensibly single-minded command economy of the Soviet Union devolved into a greedy squabble.
In 1966, Soviet space aspirations suffered a disorienting blow. Korolev died in a Kremlin hospital while having a cancerous tumor removed from his intestine. He was 59. In death his identity was declassified. He was buried with other heroes of the Soviet state in the Kremlin wall, maps were redrawn to add his name to streets, towns, even a crater on the moon. The burden of continuing the race fell to Korolev's deputy, Vasily Mishin, a solid engineer utterly lacking in his boss's charisma or political gifts.
The United States, meanwhile, was enjoying a spurt of innovation in space. In March 1966, the Americans were the first to dock two spacecraft in orbit, and through the year they perfected the art of the rendezvous in space. The Russians, still tinkering with the Soyuz spacecraft, went the full year without a manned flight.
American intelligence reports now speculated that the Soviets probably had no hope of putting a man on the moon before 1970 and were more likely to try a manned flight around the moon to, in the C.I.A.'s top-secret estimation, "offset some of the propaganda value of a successful U.S. lunar landing."
But in January 1967, the Americans suffered a harrowing setback. An electrical fire ignited the oxygen-rich atmosphere in the Apollo 1 capsule, incinerating three astronauts taking part in a training exercise. The tragedy meant the Apollo program would stand down for months, and quickened Soviet hopes of taking the lead. They soon reinforced their own optimism by successfully testing Korolev's hybrid circumlunar rocket in an eight-lap jaunt around the earth.
While the technicians tinkered with the machinery, Russian cosmonauts were training intensively for the moon, both for a landing and for a face-saving flyby.
To prepare cosmonauts for the possibility of visual navigation through the southern sky, Aleksei Leonov told me, the Soviets flew them to Somalia, a country then friendly with Moscow.
"We had to be proficient with the southern sky, in case the landing controls failed and we had to navigate manually," Leonov said. "They took us into the desert at night, far away from any city lights, and we lay on our backs, studying the constellations. In the morning, we had to draw the stars from memory."
To simulate the hazards of landing a moon vehicle, Leonov said, cosmonauts ascended over a training field in helicopters, then turned off the engines and practiced bringing the choppers to earth manually.
In April 1967, however, the Soviets were slowed by a disaster of their own. A cosmonaut sailed into orbit for a critical test of the Soyuz spacecraft, which was to be part of a moon-landing mission. The plan was to launch a second craft and carry out the Soviets' first manned docking. But the first spacecraft malfunctioned, and during an attempted early return the parachute wrapped around the re-entry vehicle. It crashed to earth, killing Vladimir Komarov, the cosmonaut on board. It would be 18 months before the Soviets chanced another Soyuz launch.
There is debate to this day about whether the Russians raced with less regard than the Americans for the risks to human passengers. It is true that Russia is not a Ralph Nader culture, as anyone who has flown the slovenly skies of Aeroflot can attest. American astronauts have been appalled, upon visiting the Russian Mir space station, to see cables draped casually through air locks that are supposed to seal off hazardous modules in case of a fire or other emergency.
Still, the Russians have lost fewer lives in their space program than the Americans. Moreover, after the fatal Soyuz crash, more conservative rules were set in place requiring a series of error-free unmanned flights before men would be launched around the moon.
Mark Wade, who runs the on-line Encyclopedia Aeronautica (solar.rtd.utk.edu/ mwade/spaceflt), argues that this new safety regimen may have prevented the Russians from beating the Americans in a scene-stealing flight around the moon. A Soviet spacecraft that circled the moon and splashed down in the Indian Ocean in September 1968 might have had cosmonauts on board if the Soviets had not turned cautious after the earlier Soyuz disaster. Instead, it traveled without passengers.
Three months later, three astronauts aboard Apollo 8 orbited the moon 10 times -- radioing back a Christmas message and photographing that unforgettable scene of an earthrise over the lunar surface.
At the drawing board and in the design shop, the competition never slowed -- even as the Americans seemed to be pulling away. Korolev, always impatient to get to the launch pad, had never placed much stock in static testing of his components -- and the policy continued after his death. Constructing the apparatus to test-fire a rocket engine on the ground was time-consuming and expensive. Build the rocket, blast off, monitor the mistakes, then build the next rocket better -- that was the Korolev way.
In contrast, Apollo engineers tested every component on the ground, producing rockets that generally flew the first time. So did Korolev's rival, Chelomei.
"Korolev was a gambler," said Sergei Khrushchev, who worked for Chelomei. "He told me: 'You are working wrong, step by step. I build the rocket and push the button."'
On Feb. 21, 1969, knowing the Americans were months away from a moon launch, Korolev's successors pushed the button on the first unmanned test of the giant 30-engine booster rocket intended to take cosmonauts eventually to the moon.
It lifted majestically from the pad. But 68 seconds into the flight, violent vibrations broke a fuel pipe. Hot propellant poured into the tail section, shorting the wiring and shutting down all the engines. The rocket crashed 34 miles away.
On July 3, the Russians tried again. This time, as the rocket was getting to its full thrust, one of the engines apparently inhaled a stray bolt and exploded. As the huge rocket lifted from the pad, a safety system began shutting down the other engines one by one, but a single rocket remained lighted, enough to tip the rocket on its side. It toppled to the ground in a huge ball of flame that left the launch pad a charred ruin.
There was one last-ditch attempt to steal some of America's thunder in the face of the impending American moon landing.
In the first months of 1969, a team of engineers labored almost without sleep to finish work on an unmanned probe they hoped would, for the first time, scoop up a sample of the moon and bring it back to earth. The robot probe, called Luna, was the 15th in a series, and at liftoff July 13 every bug seemed to have been worked out of the craft. But the probe could not get its landing equipment to work and it was stuck in lunar orbit on July 20, when Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon. The next day the little robot crashed to the lunar surface.
That third week of July, the race was finally over. The American moon landing, the live television event of the century, was blacked out in the Soviet Union, except for a special few -- the generals and party big shots and top members of the Soviet lunar team. Ordinary Russians would get a brief account of the trip on the nightly news, where it was the fifth item, following a salute to Soviet metalworkers and the celebration of Polish Liberation Day.
At the rocket design center in Podlipki, the Russian rocket engineers and cosmonauts who had dominated the cosmos for most of the young space age gathered around flickering black-and-white monitors to observe their rivals' ultimate triumph.
As the landing module descended softly into the Sea of Tranquillity, and a translator rendered Neil Armstrong's words into Russian, there was a hush compounded of awe and disappointment, envy and suspense.
Chertok tamped down his sadness and embarrassment by thinking about where this would lead. His mind was already drifting to the next round of competition, to surpass the American feat by building a permanent lunar base. Surely, he thought, this was just a new beginning.
When the news of its success reached the Russian public, it inspired a mix of reactions -- excitement, whispered questions about why the Soviets had not made it there first and the kind of self-effacing jokes that are part of the charm of Russian stoicism.
"Bad news, comrade: now even the Chinese have landed on the moon. But there is good news, too: all the Chinese."
After the explosion that destroyed the N-1 launch pad, it took two years to build a new one nearby. From there, the Russians fired a third test in June 1971. It crashed 10 miles away, blasting a deep crater in the salty soil, where bits of the rocket still lie. You can harvest them, like fragments of the Berlin wall, as souvenirs.
In November 1972, a fourth rocket lofted high into the sky, and Russian hopes soared for 107 seconds, until an explosion in the tail destroyed the rocket.
Many veterans of the program and some Western experts think Korolev's experts were close to making the dance of 30 engines work, and a fifth test might have succeeded.
Delegations of rocket makers pleaded that it was still possible to trump the Americans, to build a lunar base, a way station to the planets. But the politicians had run out of patience. The rocket program drifted until 1974, when Valentin Glushko, Korolev's sullen rival, was put in charge; he promptly ended the program and set about obliterating it from the public record. Though he made one last effort to revive his own moon rocket, it was unsuccessful, and he died in 1989.
The unfired N-1 rockets were dismembered and used as scrap. Around Baikonur their remnants have been recycled as playground sandboxes, shades for picnic tables and feeding troughs for pigs.
"Our leaders wouldn't listen to us," Mishin, Korolev's successor, said. "When we said we were prepared to do it better -- later, but better -- than the Americans, they said no."
Mishin was made the fall guy for the moon defeat. He was called before the Central Committee for a reprimand and fired. His name was omitted from the Soviet space encyclopedia.
For Americans, the wonder of Apollo had waned by Dec. 19, 1972, when Eugene Cernan, the last of 12 Americans to visit the moon, blasted off with a graceless farewell -- Let's get this mother out of here." No human has set foot on the moon since, and there are no plans to return.
If the Apollo program won by mounting the kind of command performance that was supposed to be the strength of the Communist system -- if, as Korolev's heirs like to say, we won by doing it their way -- then the demise of the Apollo program fits with the classical dimensions of the story. Like the whole Soviet experiment, Apollo was an audacious, crisis-driven, quasi-military undertaking that could not be sustained once it had no enemy to compete with.
These days the Russian space program is a shell of its ambitions, crippled by the general economic decline, by the lack of public interest, by political stresses. Baikonur is participating in the assembly of a new, American-led international space station, but the Russian role is widely viewed as a kind of welfare program to help prevent the complete collapse of Russia's economy. Those Russians who are not indifferent now tend to regard spaceflight as a costly Government folly or, worse, as yet another arena in which the arrogant Americans lord it over their defeated cold war rivals.
Among the Russian veterans of the moon race, wistfulness about the space program is inseparable from a larger disenchantment. They talk with bitterness about the loss of purpose, the squandered human potential, the humiliation before the West.
Mishin, the scapegoat, has devoted the past decade to vindicating himself. He lives, at age 82, in a cavernous but shabby apartment above a flagrant reminder of American hegemony -- the Beverly Hills Casino and Disco. His spirit seems curdled by resentment.
"I was accused of failing to beat the Americans," Mishin fumed in March. "But everyone knew from the beginning the Americans would win. By the time Korolev died, it was already absolutely clear."
At the end of our interview he lapsed into a nostalgic reverie for the days of Stalin, whose harsh ways, Mishin assured me, had really been much exaggerated. The new international space station, Mishin theorized, was probably disguising some new American military advantage.
Feoktistov, the engineer-cosmonaut, is robust, thick-haired and wry at 73. He lives comfortably in a housing complex built for cosmonauts, with a picture window looking onto snowy forests and a military guard to keep out trouble. Although he continues to teach at a technical school, he now professes to regard the long-running Olympics of manned spaceflight as a laughable folly.
"We had a lunar program because the Americans had a lunar program," he said. "When I speak of the stupidity of the Soviet program, the same applies to the American program. These decisions were not made by scientists. They were made by politicians. And for what?"
The single most intriguing discovery about the moon itself, Feoktistov said, the possible presence of water at the lunar poles, which could sustain an eventual lunar colony, has come from an unmanned probe 26 years after the last human left the moon.
"From an engineering standpoint, the Apollo program was quite an accomplishment," Feoktistov mused. "But what was the result? They brought back a few hundred kilograms of rocks. We got absolutely no information about the origin of the moon, for example. The Americans wasted $25 billion for prestige. For $25 billion, they might have done something more interesting."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 16; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-27-99: On Language;
Faith-Based

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
'Government should welcome the help of faith-based institutions," Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said in 1996. In April of this year, a spokesman for his brother, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, told The News and Record of Greensboro, N.C., "The Governor supports faith-based initiatives."
"For too long," said Vice President Al Gore to the Salvation Army in Atlanta last month, "faith-based organizations have wrought miracles on a shoestring." He welcomed "the voices of faith-based organizations." 
 In covering Gore's speech, John Harwood of The Wall Street Journal noted "both political parties' growing acceptance of faith-based solutions since Republicans began promoting the idea several years ago." But Kevin Sack of The New York Times, though reporting Gore's usage in direct quotation, did not use the suddenly popular phrase in his own writing; instead, he used the more traditional noun in discussing "government financing of religion-based welfare-to-work initiatives."
Faith-based is hot enough to be enshrined in the official canon. In Wisconsin, the Joint Legislative Council established the Special Committee on Faith-Based Approaches to Crime Prevention and Justice. Assembly Speaker Scott Jensen's legal counsel defines those approaches as "the acknowledgment of and faith in a higher power," the belief that social pathologies include "conditions of the soul" and that treatment involves "a fundamental transformation of character."
The earliest use of this modifier now so in vogue was in criticism, not affirmation, of religion in public life. In 1981, Clarence Martin, a lobbyist for the Association for the Advancement of Psychology, wrote that scholars of the social sciences, heirs to Darwin, Marx and Freud, "are the empirical left who may challenge the views, or more importantly reject the faith-based values, of the creationists, the moral majority, the laissez-faire industrialists, the economic determinists, the sexists, the militarists, the coalition who put Reagan in office."
The linguistic mystery: why are political figures all using faith-based rather than religion-based or, more simply than that adjectival compound, the old-fashioned adjective religious?
Religion (probably from the Latin religare, "to restrain") is a set of beliefs; faith, (from fidere, "to trust") is the unquestioning trust in the truth of those beliefs.
American political tradition, following its metaphor of "a wall of separation between church and state," shies away from "religion in politics" but not away from religious values in public life. By substituting faith (trust in the truths) for religion (the organized set of beliefs), the new compound adjective gets around the traditional objection. The Rev. Bill Callahan of the Quixote Center in Hyattsville, Md., says, "The language of faith-based signals to people our motivation while separating us from the institutions."
-Based is a hot formative suffix. Though broad-based is two centuries old, zero-based took off around 1970 and missile lingo gave us land-based, sea-based and space-based. A discussion of this particular parasynthetic derivative is based-based.
 
Dismilitarize?
Few people are for unilateral disarmament. Most Koreans and Americans are familiar, after four decades, with a demilitarized zone, or DMZ. Now, from the war that brought us nonpermissive environment, we have a distinction drawn between disarm and demilitarize.
The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, said on ABC's "This Week": "We never said that we were going to 'disarm' the K.L.A. We used the term 'demilitarize."' The Wall Street Journal editorialized on its meaning to the Kosovo Libercation Army: "This distinction apparently means they can keep their hunting rifles, relying on a U.N.-supervised force to protect them from Serbian tanks."
The distinction, more finely put, is this: disarm means "to divest of weapons; to deprive of the means of attack." Demilitarize means "to close a military organization; to remove the military power or potential."
Now we're into the trickiest kind of semantics. How disarmed do you have to be to call yourself demilitarized? I think it depends, first, on the power of the weaponry: if you carry a rifle or a pistol, you are armed but not necessarily militarized; if you are in an armored personnel carrier or in a choppering gunship, You're in the Army Now. But how about an automatic rifle, a small mortar or a light machine gun? If that's not militarized, what about a little howitzer or a heavy machine gun or shoulder-mounted missile? This has yet to be determined.
The second part of the meaning of demilitarized deals with organization. Can a demilitarized group call itself an army? (The Salvation Army would say yes.) Are a buncha guys hanging around in civvies and calling one another "Mister" demilitarized if they practice maneuvers and draw a table of organization in the sand?
The Pentagon spokesman, Ken Bacon, informs me: "Disarm means to take weapons away from an army. Demilitarize means to disband the army." As I get it, the K.L.A. will be disbanded but not disarmed, which suggest its members can keep all their arms as individuals but may not assemble or otherwise get organized.
The current meaning will be worked out at the negotiating tables and on the field, then passed to lexicographers. Meanwhile, we are in a very gray area. I asked a top soldier-diplomat if he would like to set me straight on the latest specific meaning of demilitarize. I am not sure if he replied, "No, thanks" or "No tanks."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1849 words

HEADLINE: The Rise and Fall of Edward Doyle Sr.;
A Teamsters Icon Who Could Deliver Votes Is Forced to Resign His $172,000-a-Year Post

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

DATELINE: ELMSFORD

 BODY:
FOR 15 years, Edward Doyle Sr. has been the most powerful labor leader in Westchester, treated with adulation by truck drivers proud that they earn more than $50,000 a year and with deferential regard by the county's leading contractors and political leaders who crave his good will.
When Mr. Doyle holds a golf tournament for a charitable foundation named for his parents, the guest list reads like a "Who's Who in Westchester," said State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, the county's Republican leader. (And Mr. Spano does not play golf.) 
 When Mr. Doyle threw his support in the tight 1993 race for county executive behind the incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, it assured defeat for the Democratic contender, Assemblyman Richard E. Brodsky.
"I would say that anyone who runs for office in Westchester comes to see Eddie Doyle," said the union's lawyer, Roy Barnes, in a matter-of-fact remark that other political leaders echoed more privately. "Eddie can deliver votes and can deliver manpower and contributions."
This month, the 59-year-old Mr. Doyle lost an important perch on the county's Olympus when, facing the threat of lifetime exile from the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, he agreed to a seven-year suspension and resigned the $172,000-a-year presidency of Local 456.
His comedown resulted not from sour labor negotiations or reckless political dealings, but from his purchase of two used cars at discounted rates from the same Yonkers car dealer from which his local bought new cars for its officers and business agents. Charging embezzlement and bribery, investigators for a board that monitors corruption within the Teamsters said he got the favorable rates for his two personal cars because the Teamsters were paying top dollar for their new cars. The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan is delving into the same set of circumstances.
But his departure from the Teamsters does not mean he has lost all his footholds as a power broker. The Teamsters, which Mr. Doyle's critics say he ran like a family candy store, will now be run by his younger brother, Bernard, 55, and by a seven-member executive board that also includes his son, Edward Jr., and his brother-in-law, George Graff. A 20-minute ovation that a thousand Teamsters delegates gave the departing Mr. Doyle on June 14 suggested how long his influence will linger.
Mr. Doyle will also remain as head of the Westchester-Putnam Building and Construction Trades Council, with 35,000 members, whose delegates unanimously reaffirmed his leadership on June 15. Under his stewardship, the council, an umbrella group of 17 construction unions like carpenters, steam fitters, bricklayers, plumbers and heavy equipment operators, has locked up 95 percent of the county's nonresidential construction and maintained a decade of labor peace. By hammering out "project labor agreements," it has assured an absence of strikes and a more reliable pace of work on $2 billion worth of new construction since 1994.
"He's out of the Teamsters, but his role in Westchester won't be that much different," Mr. Barnes said.
Still, his dethroning as head of a 3,500-member local has wounded a man who, intimates say, lived and breathed the union in which he had been bred by his father, also Edward Doyle, who was president of the local from 1940 until his death in 1960. The plain-spoken, steel-willed Mr. Doyle had tears welling in his eyes as he spoke of his loss in an interview at union headquarters, based in a squat dark glass building here.
"My members don't want me to leave here, no way at all, but what choice do I have," he said. "They told my attorney if I go to fight it they might not only ban me for life but possibly try to have me criminally indicted. What kind of choice is that? They say I resigned; sure I resigned. They said sign this thing that I wasn't under no coercion. They gave me five minutes to make a choice for my whole life." He added, "I didn't get where I was by being a choir boy, but I've never been dishonest."
The three-member Independent Review Board, which includes William H. Webster, former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was set up under a 1989 consent decree between the Teamsters and the Federal Government stemming from a settlement of a civil racketeering lawsuit. Mr. Barnes said the board began investigating Mr. Doyle after an incidental allusion to him on tapes recorded during an investigation of John A. Gotti, the acting Gambino family crime boss. Mr. Barnes said that Federal investigators were never able to find any link between Mr. Doyle and organized crime.
The board accused Local 456 of buying 12 cars for its officers and business agents costing a total of $377,630 -- roughly the manufacturer's suggested retail price -- from Park Lincoln Mercury of Yonkers and trading in their old cars for less than they were worth. In exchange for this arrangement favorable to the dealer, the investigators said, Mr. Doyle and other union executives were able to repurchase the union's used vehicles for their private use at sharply discounted rates, saving themselves a total of $18,335.
He was negotiating a price favorable to himself rather than to the local, said Charles M. Carberry, chief investigator for the review board.
In Mr. Doyle's case, he was able to buy a used Lincoln Continental in 1995 for his wife, Linda, for $14,500, $2,000 below what the local received on the trade. Then in 1998, his wife bought another used Lincoln for $14,500, exactly what the local had received on the trade-in -- and without a dealer markup. Such discounts, the board said, constituted a bribe for future union business. The discounted cars, the board observed, were not available to anyone except officials selected by Mr. Doyle.
In interviews, Mr. Doyle and his lawyer rejected the board's logic. They argued that in calculating the price of the new cars the board neglected to count options like CD players and sun roofs. In analyzing the trade-ins, Mr. Doyle said, the board relied on a used-car price guide different from one used by all metropolitan New York area dealers.
Mr. Doyle, a muscular man with silver hair swept back in 1950's rock-star style, has been a member of the Teamsters for 40 years. As a teen-ager, he learned the union business sitting in with his father on negotiations and driving with him to construction sites. He became a truck driver at 18, hauling coal and concrete and servicing oil burners.
Mr. Doyle's legacy is that he recognized that the union, more than knuckling its way in with picket lines, needed to gain a seat at the political and legislative table, where larger economic decisions are made. The Teamsters' office is sprinkled with dozens of political trophies -- he recently received a proclamation from County District Attorney Jeanine Pirro -- and photographs of him with Gov. George E. Pataki and dignitaries like John Cardinal O'Connor.
Democrats and Republicans describe Mr. Doyle as an unadorned man who, in Nicholas Spano's words, "will give you a straight answer and you will always know where he stands." Mr. Brodsky, whose Assembly campaigns Mr. Doyle has backed, said, "He became the single most influential figure in the local economy and local politics because he's disciplined and tough."
Mr. Doyle described his own leadership talent as a knack for knowing what his members need and sensing how hard to press.
"I know how far to push an employer and when to stop," he said. "I could push for a little more, but I could also lose my members their jobs. Without those employers, where are we going to go?"
Mr. Doyle defends the domination of the local executive board by his relatives, saying each relative was a veteran truck driver who joined with him in the battle to take over the union's leadership. Ken Paff, a national organizer for Teamsters for a Democratic Union, the reform movement inside the 1.4 million-member national union, says such family fiefdoms are not surprising in a national union that is still run by a Hoffa.
Local 456 represents not only drivers of fuel trucks and dump trucks but also hundreds of workers at the county's cities and villages and a contingent of 300 administrators, doctors, lawyers and financial officers who work for Westchester County or the county hospital. Andrew P. O'Rourke, the former county executive, said these managers unionized in the late 1980's after the County Board of Legislators refused to grant them a raise.
Mr. Doyle has not only won salaries for drivers that surpass that of teachers but also such perquisites as a $5-an-hour retirement annuity.
Mr. Doyle has also enhanced the county's business climate. Mr. O'Rourke said when builders wanted to build The Westchester mall, a project crucial to the revival of business in White Plains, Mr. Doyle negotiated a contract that assured that all the work would be carried out by unionized workers in exchange for a promise not to strike and for an agreement that all unions would abide by the same hours and other working conditions
"We got the guarantee that the project would be completed in time and it has been tremendous for Westchester," Mr. O'Rourke said.
Part of Mr. Doyle's clout in dealing with figures like Mr. O'Rourke has come from the vote-pulling sway of the local and building trades council. While still a young truck driver in Yonkers, Mr. Doyle figured out that he would wield much more influence by joining the Conservative Party, whose ideology did not dovetail with his but whose votes often swung victory to either the Democrat or the Republican. He has taken that pragmatic strategy to county and local elections. He supported the Republican Mr. O'Rourke in his re-election bids, but in the last election he backed the Democratic favorite, Andrew J. Spano, for county executive.
"When Eddie Doyle says he's going to help you he delivers," said Nicholas Spano, who is no relation to Andrew Spano. "During the campaigns, where we may need 20 or 30 volunteers to help put up signs or construct signs or hand out literature, Eddie has always been a phone call away."
Mr. Doyle is often praised for his long resistance to mob figures who tried to penetrate the local. Mr. Doyle says that in the early 1950's, during his father's tenure, a local executive, John Acropolis, was shot and killed in the battle to organize the garbage industry and keep the mob out. Around the same time, his father was run off the road and left with a heart condition that later proved to be the cause of his death. Mr. Barnes said it was ironic that a board charged with rooting out organized crime has forced out a leader who did just that.
When he looked at the case against Mr. Doyle, Mr. Paff observed that it had been personal failings rather than mob ties that have most often proved the undoing of Teamsters leaders.
"Most of the people removed from the union were not charged with organized crime association," Mr. Paff said. "They were charged with things like this: confusing the union treasury with their own bank account."

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk
