HEADLINE: Keeping Up With Jones Beach;
A City on the Sand for 8 Million, Silicone Singles to Kite Flyers

BYLINE: By DAVID WINZELBERG

DATELINE: JONES BEACH STATE PARK

 BODY:
THERE are more than 1,200 miles of shore on Long Island, but for millions of people who come here to frolic in the sand and surf there is only one beach.
For the last 70 years, Jones Beach has been the summer playground for generations of Long Islanders. A uniquely suburban refuge (where else are beaches named for parking lots?), it boasts six and a half miles of oceanfront within its 2,413 acres and a slew of other features, including miniature golf, shuffleboard and even an unofficial nude beach. 
 One of the most popular summer destinations in the country, Jones Beach State Park recorded nearly eight million visitors last year, outdrawing Yosemite and Yellowstone National Parks combined. State parks officials are expecting to eclipse that number this year. More than 320,000 people lay blanket to blanket at Jones Beach during the recent Memorial Day holiday, the largest opening weekend crowd in 20 years.
With a beach in his own backyard, Ruben Sierra travels here from Far Rockaway, in Queens. "You have pools, a nice boardwalk, nice restaurants, a clean beach and good security," he said. "They don't put up with nonsense. It's much safer and you can really enjoy yourself."
Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Conventions and Visitors Bureau, estimated that Jones Beach brings in around $50 million a year to the Long Island economy. "A majority of the visitors are now from New York City and New Jersey," he said. "It draws more people than the Jersey Shore. It's less commercial and away from civilization. You wouldn't even know where you were if somebody flew you in."
Though flying in is not an option, it probably would be the transportation of choice for those who have been bumper to bumper on the Meadowbrook Parkway on a sweltering Sunday morning. Most of the 23,000 parking spaces at Jones Beach fill up fast, especially on peak weekends. Field 6, with the shortest walk from asphalt to ocean, is usually filled by 9 A.M.
For those who want to avoid the traffic, Jones Beach is served by buses originating from Jamaica, Hicksville, Wantagh and the Freeport L.I.R.R. station. The bicycle path that runs alongside the Wantagh Parkway from Cedar Creek Park, just south of Merrick Road, provides another alternative. Some cyclists and skaters actually use it to get to the beach; the park provides storage racks and a bike lifeguard on the lookout for thieves.
Like any large town, even one where no one spends the night, Jones Beach has developed a demographic pattern. And like any large town, the pattern includes a kaleidoscope of groups: singles, families with children, retirees, the steroid and silicone crowd, gays, walkers, joggers, boaters, beachcombers, surfers, bellyboarders, fishermen, kite flyers, chess players, nudists, nature lovers, suntan freaks and on and on.
Field 5 on shallow, surf-free Zach's Bay attracts young families with toddlers. Distant West End 2, known for its singles scene, also lures nature lovers and its wide beach allows for extra personal space. "We like it because it's quiet and has a great shower house," said Karin Fern, from Manhattan.
Robert and Jana Guskin, from Plainview, married after meeting at West End 2, 25 years ago. "I was there with my friends and she was there with her friends," said Dr. Guskin. "She was shiny from baby oil. Nobody knew from melanomas back then."
Sometimes called Muscle Beach, Field 4 displays a large collection of hardbodies. "We come here for the mostly naked girls," said Sean Foronjy, 18, from Westbury. Looking out over the central mall beach from the boardwalk steps, Santina Dignoti of Elmont said, "It's a meat market."
The largest contingent of kite flyers is at Field 6, among the hard-core beachgoers who have to arrive early before the parking lot fills up. The park police call them the Sandinistas because they keep to the sand.
The other subgroup at Field 6, dubbed the concretions, are mostly retirees who never leave the concrete patio area behind the concession stand.
Martha and Jack Kasner, from Island Park, have been coming here for 30 years and station themselves on beach chairs on a narrow strip of cement in the shade of the lifeguard shack. "They call this spot Martha's Vineyard," Mrs. Kasner said. She said that she came to the beach only on weekends, but that her husband was here every day, even in the winter. "They turn the West Bathhouse into a senior citizens center," Mr. Kasner said. "We play cards."
Sitting at a table on the patio, Clarence Dahl, from Wantagh, and Barry Lorber, from Massapequa, both retired, said they had made dozens of friends at Field 6 over the years. "We like this beach because of the convenience and the pretty girls too," said Mr. Dahl, nodding approvingly toward a bikini-clad blonde about 40 years his junior.
"This is a crossroads," said Mr. Lorber. "It's kind of like Times Square here."
And two miles to the east, sometimes known as Field 6 1/2, although without its own parking lot, is a nude beach with a predominately gay clientele. "We don't recognize it as such," said Frank Kollar, park superintendant. "It's remote. You have to go way out of your way to get there."
Although there is a state law prohibiting nudity, members of the park police usually ask the offenders to move a few yards to the east, just outside the park and toward the Town of Oyster Bay beach. The small park force, which numbers less than 100, including 50 seasonal officers, primarily concentrates on traffic control and lost children. Officers Paul Marcel and Ed Wahl said they located about a dozen lost children each day.
"We've found them up to two miles from where they were reported," said Officer Wahl, a retired Nassau County police lieutenant who has worked the last 12 summers here.
Deeply tanned and armed with easy smiles, the patrol team of Officers Wahl and Marcel are more like beach ambassadors than crime fighters. Park regulars call them by their first names.
Officer Marcel, who moonlighted as the voice of Frankie the Frog on a compact disc for children, said most park police tasks were service-oriented, like the rescue of a stranded fisherman when the tide came up and covered part of the West End jetty. But the park police said officers sometimes went undercover to make drug arrests, and insisted, all evidence to the contrary, that the police were also diligent in keeping people from bringing alcoholic beverages onto the beach.
Equipped with all-terrain vehicles, bicycles and personal watercraft, the park police also handle car break-ins and altercations fueled by all that alcohol that isn't being consumed on the beach. But the police report that such incidents are down over the last few years. "It's not like Baywatch at all," said Lieut. Stephan Kowal, an 18-year park police veteran.
Officer Wahl, whose father was a state trooper who patrolled the beach when the park first opened in 1929, recalled a recent lifesaving effort of an 18-month-old child. "I was riding my A.T.V. in the middle of the beach and a man came running with a package in his arms. He said, 'My baby stopped breathing!' I gave him mouth-to-mouth while I was driving. After a minute, the kid threw up all over me."
While the park police protect the crowds on land, the 275 lifeguards at Jones Beach watch over the people in the water. Every year, 2,500 to 3,000 rescues are performed here, including about 500 in the park's two swimming pools.
During a busy day, as many as 25,000 people can be in the water at once, according to Joe Scalese, director of lifeguards. Mr. Scalese said that dangerous riptides were rare, but that a milder undertow called a sea puss was a frequent problem.
"We keep a close watch on the tide and the sweep," said Mr. Scalese, 54, a lifeguard here for 38 years who has lost his leathery tan now that he has a desk job. "We take a preventative approach."
Jones Beach lifeguards, who range in age from 17 to 72, occupy the 50 lifeguard stands from Memorial Day weekend to Labor Day. Despite their vigilance, there is a drowning death every two or three years, said Mr. Scalese, mostly outside the green-flagged areas that denote sections monitored by lifeguards. "It's usually people that aren't beach savvy that are the problem," he said.
Lifeguards come on duty at 9:45 A.M. and stay until around 8 P.M. But some beachgoers don't know when to leave. "We pull hundreds of people off the beach at night," said Bill Hroch, a lifeguard at Field 6.
Beside lifeguards there are 25 emergency medical technicians at the park's six first aid stations, who treat everything from splinters to heart attacks. The state hires 650 seasonal workers to help the 59-member year-round staff maintain the park. High school and college students make up the summer employees who help pick up 35 tons of garbage each day. Every morning beginning at 5 A.M., crews comb the beach with tractor-drawn surf rakes, which clean out shells, wood, bottle caps and other debris.
Lisa Solina, a surf rake operator, said the crews started at Field 6 and worked their way west, raking the sand from the water's edge to the high-tide line.
Most of their haul is seaweed, Ms. Solina said. There have been no doubloons or diamond necklaces. "I should be so lucky," she said. "We couldn't keep anything anyway. It would have to be turned in."
Tiaras lost on the beach are the grand prize for beachcombers, the most dedicated of whom use metal detectors to locate buried treasure. Dozens of gizmo-equipped treasure hunters, allowed on the beach by permit only, can be found sweeping the beach in the morning or evening following a weekend day, listening for the detector's beeping through headphones. "I always hope for jewelry," said one occasional beachcomber, "but I mostly get tin foil and a bunch of bottle caps."
Other areas of Jones Beach State Park feel less like Beach and more like Park. Walkways in the central mall and other areas are planted every spring with 48,000 annuals. At a nursery at the east end of Zach's Bay, park staff grow 12,000 mums for fall planting.
The central mall is dominated by the Jones Beach water tower. Modeled after the campanile of St. Mark's Cathedral in Venice, the 200-foot high water tower could be the most recognizable edifice in Nassau County. It holds a 315,000-gallon water tank, which is supplied by three 1,000-foot wells.
On a busy day, the park will go through up to half a million gallons of water. Jones Beach has its own sewage and water treatment plants to handle the use of its 1,400 bathroom fixtures. Since last year the park spent $2.5 million in plumbing improvements, including the renovation of the women's comfort station at the central mall and replacement of water mains that had not been changed since it first opened.
As the water takes its toll on the plumbing, the ocean waves take a toll on the beaches. About every five years, the Army Corps of Engineers dredge the Fire Island Inlet and replace sand back onto Jones Beach that was eroded with the tide. Since the 1950's some 18 million cubic yards of sand has been restored to the beaches here, according to Henry Bokuniewicz, a professor of oceanography at Stony Brook.
The jetties at Fire Island Inlet to the east and the Jones Inlet to the west block the natural movement of sand, making a big difference in the size of the beaches (and thus the length of your hike from the car to the water). At high tide the beach is nearly 1,400 feet wide at West End 2 and less than 400 feet at Field 6.
Before it became a pet project of Robert Moses, head of the Long Island State Park Commission, Jones Beach was an undeveloped coastal barrier island about five miles from the mainland, used only by an occasional fisherman.
The long, narrow spit of sand and marsh was named after Maj. Thomas Jones, an Irish mercenary and part-time pirate who preyed on merchant ships in the Atlantic. Major Jones married Freelove Townsend in 1696 and settled some 600 acres in what is now Massapequa. A few years later he laid claim to the offshore barrier island, where he established a whaling station. The beach and marshland remained mostly uninhabited until Moses envisioned a public recreation opportunity two centuries later.
Over 40 million cubic yards of sand was the main ingredient when construction of the park began in December 1926. More than 25 miles of the Great South Bay were dredged to deepen the waterway and provide the sand to cover up channels and shore up the beaches. Millions of sprigs of dune grasses were planted by hand to keep the sugary bay-bottom sand from blowing away. By the time it opened, Jones Beach was an environment utterly transformed.
"If someone was to propose today what Robert Moses did decades ago, it's highly unlikely they would get the necessary environmental permits to do so," said John Turner, a legislative director of the state's Water Resource Commission. "But to Moses' credit, this was a noble gesture which provided a huge public benefit."
As with most of his other projects in a career that transformed Long Island, Moses brokered deals that garnered the cooperation of local governments to build the park and its access roads. When a causeway contractor ran out of money, Moses reportedly borrowed $20,000 from his mother so the project would be completed in time.
"He wanted every New Yorker to have a piece of this beautiful coast without having to have a mansion," said Bernadette Castro, the state Parks Commissioner. "Originally the park workers wore sailor uniforms, because Moses wanted people to feel like they were aboard their own ocean liner."
The sailor uniforms are gone, but many architectural details with a nautical motif -- the trash cans hidden in reproductions of shipboard air scoops and the boardwalk railings copied from cruise liners -- are still around. And in place of bygone features like the archery range, the roller skating rink, calisthenic classes and the adult play area where people rode grown-up-sized tricycles, new additions have been made. A children's playground opened three years ago. In August, the Theodore Roosevelt Nature Center for environmental education opens at West End 1. And just-completed beach volleyball courts, built not on the beach but back behind the miniature golf course, are to be augmented by locker rooms and bleachers in an effort to attract professional and amateur events, Ms. Castro said.
Despite contributions from the private sector, (local Saturn retailers gave $100,000 for the playground and the Ford Motor Company gave the same amount for the nature center) the state raised park fees this season. Admission to the pools went from 50 cents to $1 for children and from $1 to $2 for adults. The vehicle use fee went from $5 to $7 per car. Last year, the state spent more than $6.5 million on Jones Beach and took in about $4.3 million in revenue.
The nature center was built near a new nesting area of endangered piping plovers and will stress the importance of maintaining the fragile beach environment.
While the endangered birds are left undisturbed, other birds make their presence known. "We usually leave by four o'clock, because the sea gulls come and they're very aggressive," said one beachgoer. "They'll grab a sandwich right out of your hand."
The gulls have a lot to choose from. There are 11 permanent food service locations, including newly renovated concessions at Field 6 and the West Bathhouse, as well as 13 new portable kiosks on the boardwalk that sell drinks and ice cream. To help reduce the long lines that slowed service last summer, the concession staff has increased from 75 to 250, according to Patrick Liebler, a general manager with Delaware North Park Services, concessionaire for all the food outlets in the park. And so far, business is good.
"Our business was up 75 percent from last year's Memorial Day weekend," Mr. Liebler said. "We're excited for a big summer. If Memorial Day was any indication, we're expecting a home run."
On their way for some french fries at the central mall, Fidias Peralta and Nicole Lago, both students at Nassau Community College, said they had been coming to Jones Beach for years. "I remember playing baseball on the beach with my cousin when I was 5," Mr. Peralta said. "I used to love sliding into the sand."
"I like the boardwalk and the people," Ms. Lago said. "It's big. It's pretty. I enjoy it."
 
Boardwalks Don't Roll Up at Night
 
LONG after the umbrellas have been furled and the scent of cocoa butter has faded, Jones Beach comes alive again.
People flock to the two-mile boardwalk after the sun goes down to feel the ocean breezes, socialize with friends or just walk off a big meal. "If you've gone out to dinner and it's Saturday night, it's just a nice place to go for a walk," said Esther Drexler of Bethpage. "We watch the guys play paddleball and the dancing in the bandshell. I love going there."
Miniature golf, shuffleboard and volleyball are a few of the activities available under the lights. Beginning next Saturday until Labor Day, there is live music and dancing in the bandshell at the Central Mall from Tuesday to Sunday nights. Country line dancing, square dancing and traditional ballroom dancing are included in the program each week.
One of the biggest attractions under the stars are the shows at the Jones Beach Theater, originally built in the 1930's. It had an island stage.
"I remember going to see shows like 'Song of Norway' and they would use a big boat floating by in front of the audience," said Richard Berkenfeld of Bayside.
Years later, when acts like Guy Lombardo were replaced by Bon Jovi, the moat became a problem. "People kept diving into the water trying to swim to the stage," said the concert promoter Ron Delsener of Delsener Slater Entertainment. "We had to get a lifeguard."
The moat has been filled in since then and replaced by more seating. Last spring, a $22 million balcony was added, increasing the number of seats to 14,200. Mr. Delsener said that since 1983, his group has spent $30 million renovating the theater.
"It's my whole life," he said. "I love that it's on the water. It's easy to get in and out. As a summer venue, it's a real treat." DAVID WINZELBERG

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 17; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Westchester Takes Second Place in School Budget Rejections

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to rejecting school budgets, Westchester is No. 2 -- second only to Erie County in the number of school districts where voters overturned spending plans this year.
In Erie, eight budgets were rejected while in Westchester voters turned down seven, said Mary Ellen Clark, a spokeswoman for the state Education Department's Division of Management Services. 
 How did many opponents of the budgets feel? "It's not that we're opposed to education, but as taxpayers we're starting to feel overwhelmed," said Bernard Mindich, a member of Citizens Organized for Responsible Education, a newly formed property owners' group in the Katonah-Lewisboro school district. "Like everything else in life, there's a limit."
The result has been a recurring ritual of spring for taxpayers and school officials in some districts. Voters go to the polls in May and either accept or reject a budget. School officials generally go back to the drawing board and decide either to resubmit the original budget, if it was rejected, or a scaled-down spending plan to a second vote; in many places, citizens' groups used to the period between the two votes to make their cases, both pro and con, on the proposals.
If the budget is defeated a second time, the district adopts what is known as a contingency budget or, as the state calls it, an austerity budget, which is based on state formulas.
In the first round of elections this spring, voters in Katonah-Lewisboro, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon, Valhalla, Greenburgh, Tuckahoe and North Salem turned down school spending plans. Out of the 35 districts in Westchester, only 27 hold budget votes. Some of the remaining districts were created by special acts and are special education districts, not required to hold budget votes. Another is the city of Yonkers, which according to its own laws, does not hold a public vote.
Of the 27 districts that do hold votes, only Eastchester and Greenburgh 7 failed to pass their budgets in 1998. The previous year, 1997, only Greenburgh 7 and Mount Pleasant failed to pass their budgets.
"Increasingly, property owners are asking themselves how long they can keep doing this, and their answer is, 'We can't anymore,' " said Donald McKenzie, the superintendent of the Putnam-Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services.
The pressure from voters may be to curb budgets, but at the same time, educators are struggling to balance growing demands from Albany for mandated school programs, decreasing state aid and growing student populations, said Stacy J. Holmes, the superintendent of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services.
In Westchester, the problem of property taxes versus school budgets is especially acute because taxes are already high and state aid is proportionately lower than in other counties. In determining aid to education, the state factors in the income of residents, as reported on tax returns and through statewide computerized income figures.
As of 1995, Westchester ranked second in the state to New York City in terms of personal income per capita, according to the most recent figures presented in the County Department of Planning's Databook. The average per capita income in the county in 1995 was $40,696.
As a result, the county's school districts have placed near the bottom of the list of those meriting state aid, and the onus of paying for public education in Westchester has fallen increasingly on property owners, who according to the state's calculations, can afford to shoulder it.
That's a conclusion that a lot of people question.
James Maisano, a Republican County Legislator representing parts of New Rochelle, Pelham and Pelham Manor, said that in New Rochelle, the state's policies were pitting parents of school-age children against the elderly. "This is an unhealthy situation forced upon us by a vacuum of leadership from the state," Mr. Maisano said. "It's time for all sides to lobby for reform in educational funding."
Linda E. Kelly, the superintendent of schools in New Rochelle, explained that in 1991, 25 percent of New Rochelle's educational budget was paid by the state, compared with 13 percent this year, and during that period the enrollment was up by 2,000 students to a total of 10,000.
In May, the district's $124.4 million budget was turned back. It was resubmitted on June 18 -- "as it was because there was no fat to cut," Ms. Kelly said -- and passed, signaling an 8.8 percent tax increase.
If, however, that budget had been rejected and a contingency budget had been adopted, taxes would still have risen 5.9 percent, said Kathy Hagendorf, a member of a citizens' group called Yes for Schools.
In Tuckahoe, a $12.8 million proposed school budget, which carried a 9.9 percent tax increase, was narrowly rejected by voters in May. As in New Rochelle, the Tuckahoe budget was also resubmitted in its original form this month and was approved, Board of Education President Leon Waskiewicz said.
He said it passed because of "a grass-roots effort on the part of the P.T.A. and the district to get out the vote." Mr. Waskiewicz said the cost of holding the second vote was about $2,000, which was paid by the Board of Education.
In the Katonah-Lewisboro Union Free School District, Mr. Mindich joined about 60 other citizens at a meeting of Core after voters in May spurned a $57.6 million spending plan and three other propositions related to the schools, which would have raised taxes 15 percent.
"The accumulated effect of tax increases over the years had people up in arms," he said.
Alfred B. Del Bello, a former state Lieutenant Governor and a Democratic County Executive in Westchester, said the citizens group, of which he is also a member, "wanted to send a message to the school board to get more efficient." He added, "If you compare the schools to businesses or to government, you can see the rate of the tax increases is not in line with the rest of the economy."
Rankling at any suggestion that the schools were profligate, Karen McCarthy, Katonah-Lewisboro's superintendent, said: "We are not providing kids with Cadillacs. This is just a Chevrolet kind of budget, and we should be getting a pat on the back, not criticism for it."
A revised budget of $56.8 million was approved in an extremely close vote -- 1,878 to 1,876 -- this month. But at the same time, voters turned down separate proposals to restore $582,000 in spending cuts and $512,000 for new school buses.
As is the case everywhere in the state, a second defeat would have meant that by law the district would have had to adopt an austerity budget -- in this case $55.9 million, which would have eliminated 25 teaching positions and 3 administrators and reduced spending for transportation and operations.
Used to budget failures, Greenburgh Central School's Board of Education adopted a contingency budget, based on state standards, and asked voters to approve three separate propositions, adding $430,000 in additional spending for buses, playground equipment and a school elevator.
All three were defeated, but the elevator will be built anyway, for $250,000, because it is mandated by the state. In large part the money will come from the state.
In Mount Vernon, Superintendent Ronald O. Ross cited "people who are just getting reactionary" as the reason that voters in his city turned back a $108.6 million budget with an 8.7 percent tax increase. Citizens will vote on a revised budget of $107.9 million on Tuesday.
Dr. Ross said, "I take full responsibility for not getting the message out on the budget." He explained that after the vote, the Board of Education revised the budget before returning it to the voters for a second vote.
After North Salem's school budget was defeated, the Board adopted a $20.1 million contingency budget, cutting $475,842 from its original plan. On Monday, voters approved a special allotment of $188,000 for buses and vans.
And in Valhalla, a revised $18.5 million budget -- down $299,867 from the original proposal -- was finally accepted by voters earlier this month.

HEADLINE: First a Hatchery, Now Hope for Oysters

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY

 BODY:
THE state is establishing a shellfish hatchery in the Noank section of Groton in an attempt to save Connecticut's indigenous stocks of oysters and an economically significant industry.
Two parasites, harmful to oysters but not to humans, have virtually destroyed Chesapeake Bay's oyster industry and have infected Connecticut's most productive oyster grounds, reducing the catch and harming the state's $50 million industry. The state hopes the hatchery can produce oysters resistant to the parasites 
 "The initial focus of the hatchery will be on the production of oyster seed that are disease resistant," said John H. Volk, director of the State Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Aquaculture. "The oyster seed will be made available to municipal shellfish commissions and small oyster industries that have been hard hit by the devastation of the MSX and Dermo oyster parasites."
The hatchery will breed and grow oysters that have demonstrated resistance to the two parasites and that have evolved to thrive in the particular conditions of the state's different estuaries and inshore waters that produce natural growths of oysters, Mr. Volk said.
Dermo is caused by a single-cell protozoan called Perkinsus marinus and is the slower acting of the two, taking up to three years to kill an infected oyster. Its name was derived from a fungus previously thought to be the cause of the oyster disease. MSX (for multinucleated sphere X), caused by the protozoan Haplosporidium nelsoni, kills within three to six weeks. Because oysters take three to five years to reach marketable size, either parasite can wipe out the market.
"A useful strain of oysters must not only be resistant, but locally adaptable," said James Markow, an owner of Aeros Cultured Oyster Company. The company operates a shellfish hatchery in Shirley, N.Y., and has worked with the Groton Shellfish Commission for the past seven years on a variety of oyster propagation projects.
"Something that might work in one place, all year might not work there the next year," Mr. Markow said. "With aquaculture you've got to always adjust."
MSX was first detected in Long Island Sound in 1985. Production fell from over 243,000 bushels in 1984 to 69,721 bushels in 1987, says Dr. Inke Sunila, a state shellfish pathologist.
In 1992, MSX returned to Long Island Sound. In that year, about 900,000 bushels of oysters were harvested in Connecticut waters with a wholesale value of about $42 million. By 1994 only about 600,000 bushels of oysters were harvested in state waters with a wholesale value of about $32 million.
In 1996 Dermo spread to Long Island Sound, but no known mortality associated with Dermo has occurred in Long Island Sound, Dr. Sunila said.
At the state hatchery, oysters will be grown from microscopic swimming larvae to the size of a pin head by feeding them a special blend of marine algae, said Karen Rivara, president and an owner of Aero. They are then moved to an oyster nursery where they are placed in nutrient-rich water pumped from the adjacent estuary.
The juvenile oysters are held in mesh-bottomed containers that protect them and provide a constant flow of water. When large enough, the oysters are placed in cages, which resemble lobster pots, and placed in the waters of Fishers Island Sound, where they will continue to grow until ready for market.
Aero will contribute $65,000 in nursery and other equipment and also the use of the George Billo, a 1905 oyster harvest boat. Under its contract with the Groton Shellfish Commission, Aero will then have access to about half the seed oysters that the hatchery produces in its first year (about 2 1/2 million seeds).
The plan for the hatchery's first year of aquaculture calls for the production of five million seed oysters. About 1 1/2 million of the oyster seeds will be turned over to the Groton Shellfish Commission, which conceived and is implementing the plan for the hatchery. The shellfish commission will run the hatchery in cooperation with the aquaculture division and private businesses and it will use the oyster seeds for recreational oyster programs. One million seeds will be sold to other commercial oyster companies.
The hatchery plan calls for the formation of new partnerships with other private shellfish businesses, other municipal shellfish commissions and marine educational and vocational agencies, said the Groton Shellfish Commissioner Neil Brown. The plan calls for the inclusion of businesses, educational programs, and shellfish commissions that can benefit from the association with the hatchery and can, in turn, benefit the hatchery, Mr. Brown said.
"Finding a solution to Dermo and MSX will not be a one-shot deal," said Mr. Markow. "These parasites will come back in slightly different form. It will not be as much of a problem in Long Island Sound as it is in the Chesapeake, because Long Island Sound has great flushing and colder water.
"It takes two to three years to grow an oyster to market size the old-fashioned way," Mr. Markow added. "Along comes a disease that wipes you out just as you're ready to harvest. With a hatchery/nursery we figure we can get them out in one and a half years. The faster you grow out, not only is it faster to market, but you're cutting your exposure to risk."
The long-term mission of the hatchery will be to assist the state's existing aquaculture businesses and help incubate new aquaculture businesses just as the state Agricultural Experiment Station assists and incubates Connecticut agricultural businesses, Mr. Volk said.
"An important mission of the hatchery will be education and training," said Stephen Jones, a maritime writer and Groton Shellfish Commissioner. "Students from the Regional Vocational Aquaculture School in Bridgeport, the Sound School in New Haven, and Project Oceanology will work in all parts of the hatchery operation," said Mr. Jones, a professor at UConn and the hatchery's education coordinator.
"The intent of the education and training program will be to give these young people the experience and ability to establish new aquaculture businesses or to find employment in existing aquaculture businesses."
After the hatchery fulfills its first mission of producing stocks of MSX and Dermo resistant oysters, it will be used for the cultivation of other shellfish stocks such as scallops, Mr. Volk said.
In the 19th century, scallops were harvested by recreational and commercial shell fishermen off Stonington, Clinton Harbor, and in the Niantic River. Scallops became scarce and have just been re-introduced in Clinton Harbor. Although there is limited recreational scalloping in the Niantic River, commercial scalloping no longer exists in Connecticut.
The idea of the hatchery began when the Groton Shellfish Commissioner, Roger Sherman, and the Commission chairman, Ronald Chappell, learned that the two-storied, brick building near the mouth of the Mystic River was about to be sold. The building had been used by UConn as a research laboratory focused on lobsters and blue fish from 1955 until 1998, when a new complex was built for the university's maritime expansion program at Avery Point Campus.
The brick building had been built as an engine factory at the turn of the century when Noank was still a fishing and ship-building village. Later, it housed a velvet-making mill. Following the hurricane of 1938, it replaced the state lobster hatchery, which had been situated about half a mile down the Mystic River and had been washed away by the storm, Mr. Jones said.
The thing that is unusual about the Groton Shellfish Commission, said Mr. Volk, is the institutional memory of its members. Many of the shellfish commissioners are watermen who are retired from private industry. They have the experience of their professions as well as the continuity of experience from their many years as shellfish commissioners, he said.
UConn initially wanted $500,000 to transfer ownership of the property to the state aquaculture division. But State Representative Lenny Winkler, a Republican of Groton, worked with Thomas Q. Callahan, an associate vice president at UConn, and the State Department of Agriculture Commissioner Shirley C. Ferris, who is also a UConn trustee, to agree to transfer the property to the state aquaculture division for free. UConn's compensation has yet to be determined, Mr. Winkler said.
"Right now all hatchery shellfish stocks are coming from out-of-state," Mr. Winkler said. "There's no need for this. There was no need to sell the property and there was no need for one state agency to pay another state agency to do something so beneficial."

HEADLINE: Shaker Simplicity Comes to Wilton

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN

 BODY:
THE simple, graceful lines of Shaker furniture holds great appeal for the contemporary eye. Chairs, tables, cabinets, desks and household objects made in the 19th century by members of this unique communal sect fetch handsome prices at auctions and antique shows and continue to influence designers and craftsmen.
Yet the men and women who fashioned these prized objects were not inspired by ideals of beauty or of style. They were following the principles of their church, which called for order, simplicity and the avoidance of ornamentation. 
 "All work done, or things made in the Church for their own use, ought to be faithfully and well done but plain and without superfluity," wrote Father Joseph Meacham of Enfield, the first American-born Shaker.
The relationship between the religious tenets of the Shakers and the products of their temporal labors is examined in the exhibition, "Hands to Work, Hearts to God; The Shakers and the World Around Them," now at the Betts-Sturges-Blackmar House in Wilton. Presented by the Wilton Historical Society and the Hancock Shaker Village, a museum in Pittsfield, Mass., the show introduces a comprehensive view of Shaker life and features objects drawn from the museum.
"What I realized as I pursued my interest in the Shakers as a cultural group was that people who were attracted to joining the Shakers came from rural New England communities that were very much like the ones in our area," said Marilyn Gould, director of the Wilton Historical Society. "Then I was eager to find out what relationship there might be between the goods people produced once they became Shakers and what was being made elsewhere at that time.
"What I found out was that the Shakers started out with the same basic forms that everyone was using -- the chairs, the candlestands, the cases of drawers," she said. "But then their desire to simplify took over. Take the candlestand, for example. In the worldly form, the shaft would be elaborately turned and shaped, as would the legs, whereas the Shakers would shape a more simply and more gracefully turned shaft."
The principles and traditions that governed Shaker life were brought to the American colonies in 1774 from England by a small group of Shakers, who then traveled throughout the colonies as missionaries, led by their mentor, "Mother" Ann Lee. By the mid-19th century, at the peak of the movement, there were 6,000 Shakers and they formed 18 communal villages stretching from Maine to Kentucky.
Their aim was to devote their lives to God and to create a "heaven on earth." Although their true name was the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearance, they were called Shakers because of the religious dances they performed in their meetinghouses.
They built their communities by hand, meetinghouse first, with men and women assigned to different tasks and living separately, as celibate Brothers and Sisters. Married couples who joined the Shakers gave up their relationship and lived in communal families, consisting of as many as 100 men and women.
They raised their own food, made their clothing, produced medicines and developed trades like chair manufacturing and seed production.
The exhibition, which was supported by a grant from the Connecticut Humanities Council with the financial assistance of the Wilton Bank, emphasizes the work produced by the communities of Hancock and Enfield, Conn., the only Shaker village in this state.
The introductory room, where the history and beliefs of the Shakers are shown, features a 12-foot dining table set for eight. The men would sit on one side, the women on the other, with large ironstone platters set in the center, so all could help themselves without breaking the ordained mealtime silence.
The Brethren's Room displays a meetinghouse bench made in New Hampshire in 1830, a graceful rocking chair and two candlestands, one in the snake-foot and one in the spider-foot style -- two of the finest pieces in the show, Ms. Gould said.
"Each piece is totally simple and devoid of decoration but incredibly elegant," Mrs. Gould said. "They took basic furniture forms from "the world" -- their term for nonbelievers -- and then refined them" she continued. "When you consider how much furniture they had to produce to furnish their dwelling houses, I don't know how they did it."
The men's "retiring rooms" were usually built for four or six people and the massive case of drawers on display was no doubt meant to serve them all. Standing some eight feet tall, it is composed of eight large drawers topped by four smaller ones, with plain corners and base and simple wooden pulls.
Woodworking was considered men's work, and that included the now classic oval nesting boxes dubbed by Mrs. Gould "the Tupperware of the day." Displayed in a range of colors -- blue, brown, red or tan -- they were designed for storing pantry goods and were among the Shakers' most popular sale items.
Shaker women made most of the clothing for the community, as well as cooking, cleaning, working in the dairy and poultry house and taking care of the elderly and the sick in the Nurse Shop. After the mid-19th century, as male membership decreased, the women played an increasingly important role in the community's economic ventures, even making sales trips to market their goods.
They developed new products, such as a special wrinkle-resistant fabric, and distinctive clothing styles, like the hooded cloak with shoulder cape that is prominently exhibited alongside a simple, elegant go-to-meeting dress with white kerchief. The red wool "Dorothy Cloak," named for Sister Dorothy Durgin who designed it, became so popular among ladies of fashion that it was worn by the wife of President Cleveland at his second inauguration.
By the end of the 19th century, women assumed responsibility for the chair business, one of the most successful Shaker ventures. The chairs, some of which are on display in a range of sizes, could be ordered with woven, taped or upholstered seats and backs.
The concluding section of the show compares traditional New England styles of furniture like candlestands, cases of drawers, ladder back chairs, wash stands and tables with the Shaker furniture and analyzes the similarities and the differences between them.
Mrs. Gould planned the show in conjunction with the society's curator, Susan Gunn, while Hancock Shaker Village was represented by Sharon Duane Koomler, the show's guest curator, and her assistant, Deborah Caiola.
"Hands to Work, Hearts to God" will be on view at the Betts-Sturges-Blackmar House, 224 Danbury Road, Wilton, until Sept. 30. Exhibition hours are Monday through Thursday, 12 to 4 p.m., Sunday, 1 to 4. Admission: $5 for adults, $3 for seniors and members of the historical society, free for children under 12. For information about special events including talks, demonstrations and a special tour of Hancock Shaker Village, call (203) 762-7257.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: They Are to Rise, at Last, on 42d St. Between 11th and 12th;
The 15-Year Story Of 2 40-Story Towers

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
How does a developer measure time, when time just seems to stretch on and on and on?
"Well, I have six grandchildren I did not have when I bought the property," said Larry Silverstein, whose River Place -- a monumental rental and retail project on a full block of West 42d Street at the Hudson River -- is just now beginning to rise, after 15 years of waiting. 
 Mr. Silverstein, now 68, has secured a $140 million construction loan and has already finished the foundation for the first of his two 900,000-square-foot, glassed-in 40-story towers, which -- running counter to the emphasis on family-sized apartments in other locations -- will contain 921 smaller apartments: studios, one- and two-bedroom units. The first building, he said, is to be ready by the fall of 2000, and the second by 2004 -- exactly 20 years after he started.
Looking back, it is a scenario of the pitfalls and frustrations of Manhattan development.
Mr. Silverstein bought the site, bounded by 41st and 42d Streets and 11th and 12th Avenues, in 1984. When he bought it, the site was zoned for single-story industrial use. Mr. Silverstein needed 10 times that. By the time he got the zoning, it was 1989. Although the stock market had suffered its sharp skid two years before, the real estate market was still soaring. Mr. Silverstein figured he'd be digging in a few weeks.
But the day he got the zoning, the city was sued over the change, Mr. Silverstein said, grimacing at the memory. Mr. Silverstein said he tried to negotiate, but it was fruitless. By the time the dust cleared -- the developer won -- it was 1992. The real-estate recession had arrived in all its fury, and there was no money to borrow.
"The market was down the tubes and I thought I would die," said Mr. Silverstein, who built 7 World Trade Center, with its 2 million square feet of offices, and who owns 140 Broadway, with 1.2 million square feet of offices.
People suggested he sell his block. "Who would buy it?" he replied.
And so, he continued, he "sat there and crunched numbers and gnashed teeth and kept saying the nightmare will end, the sun will rise again."
But even when the real estate market began its recovery, the nightmare continued. By 1995, things were looking good: Mr. Silverstein had hired Costas Kondylis, the well-known designer of residential towers, to plan his towers, his health club and his tennis courts overlooking the river.
In 1997, he said, he was ready to "put the shovel in the ground," when word came down from Gov. George E. Pataki's office: Stop.
The Governor's office was promoting the site for expansion of the Javits Center. Finally, after a year, the word came down: Build the towers. It took six months to arrange another loan; the last 18-month delay cost him $10 million, Mr. Silverstein said. "But here I am, at last, building my towers," the developer said. "I guess you'd call it a saga." TRACIE ROZHON

HEADLINE: Foreclosures Spur A Volume Business In Refurbishing And Selling Homes;
Buyers get benefit of easier terms, but some charge deception.

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
SO far so good," said Sandra Kingston, evaluating her five months of experience as a first-time homeowner.
Ms. Kingston, a clerical worker in her 40's who works for Kings County Hospital, was able to buy a one-family house for $219,000 in the St. Albans section of Queens last January, making a 5 percent down payment and getting a 30-year fixed-rate 7.5 percent mortgage insured by the Federal Housing Administration. 
 "I'm cutting it very close, to the borderline of affordability, but my utility bills aren't as high as they used to be," Ms. Kingston said.
The previous resident, however, had gone over that borderline of affordability, and had lost the house in a foreclosure proceeding. Ms. Kingston bought it from a private company that acquired it at auction from a lender, rehabilitated it at a cost it said came to $30,000, and resold it to her.
With banks often reluctant to make the investment in time and money necessary to recover the full potential value of a foreclosed property, which can be a particularly trying process in New York City, private companies have emerged to do this work. Now they are doing it on a volume basis -- and sometimes encountering a backlash from buyers who feel they were misled into purchasing a house with more problems than they had bargained for.
The concept of buying, upgrading and reselling foreclosed housing is hardly new. Usually the job is done by local contractors or brokers, or people planning to live in the house. Few companies have attempted to carry it forward on a volume basis in the city, buying property even while former owners or renters are still in occupancy. But with the emphasis in Federal housing policy on strengthening home ownership opportunities across a wide income spectrum, the necessary home mortgage financing for new buyers is available, and entrepreneurs see an opportunity.
The seller to Ms. Kingston, Better Homes Depot Inc., is a two-year-old company with a storefront office on Rockaway Boulevard in the Ozone Park section of Queens. Better Homes Depot says it sold 518 houses last year, about 20 in Nassau but the rest in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. It expects to sell more than 600 houses this year. The company says that three-quarters of its sales were of homes that it bought in foreclosure sales.
Another practitioner is Keith Kantrowitz, president of Best Express Inc., based in Great Neck, N.Y., and also president of Power Express, a mortgage-banking company. In 1978 Mr. Kantrowitz started representing banks in selling off their inventory of foreclosed homes. He established his own business in 1981.
"If anyone had told me 20 years ago that I would own $16 million in inventory today I would have said they're nuts," Mr. Kantrowitz said. The figure represents what Best Express paid for the 320 houses it currently owns, he said. The company expects to sell 420 houses this year in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties.
The prospect of maintaining an adequate inventory of houses to resell in the years ahead looks promising to these companies. One reason is that easier access to credit in the 90's has made it possible for less creditworthy purchasers to buy a house. It is also easier for homeowners to borrow money, using their home as security for the loan. Often the purpose is to relieve other financial problems. The ongoing problems of these borrowers have contributed disproportionately to the nation's growing foreclosure rate.
Home ownership reached a record 66.3 percent of American households last year, up from 65.4 percent only two years earlier. Simultaneously, the national foreclosure rate hit 0.36 percent last year, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, up from 0.34 percent two years earlier, an unusually high figure for a period of low unemployment.
But with housing credit easily available, there is no shortage of companies seeking to get consumers to use it. Only last week, Delta Funding Corporation, of Woodbury, L.I., agreed to a settlement to avoid a lawsuit planned by State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer over practices that allegedly enticed minority homeowners into borrowing more money than they could repay.
In Queens, Jamaica Housing Improvement Inc., a nonprofit company that assists moderate-income owners, hears in anguished detail of the problems some borrowers have. Jamaica Housing Improvement is part of NeighborWorks, a national network of community organizations chartered by the federally chartered Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation, in Washington. The Queens group serves South Jamaica, South Ozone Park, St. Albans, Hollis and Springfield Gardens.
Over the last year, 74 complaints have been lodged by homeowners or home buyers, said Storm Russell, executive director. Some of the complaints have involved defects in newly purchased homes, but most concern home-improvement work or aggressive or deceptive practices by financial firms, brokers, salespeople, contractors, lawyers or appraisers, Ms. Russell said.
"Sometimes people are encouraged to borrow too much, and sometimes the homeowner's true income is misrepresented in order to qualify them for the loan," she said. "People often think that when a house is appraised, that that is its true value. They don't hire inspectors to find out whether they're going to need more money. They move in and almost immediately the roof leaks."
"If anyone wants money for anything," Ms. Russell added, "there is always someone out there who will give it to you."
Overextended homeowners are likely to show up first among the "subprime" borrowers. Nationally, one in every five to six loans that were made to buy a house last year was a subprime loan, made at higher-than-normal interest rates and often made to less-creditworthy home buyers, according to David Olson, president of David Olson Research Company in Columbia, Md. Subprime loans, also provided for home improvement work and for owners seeking additional financing on their house, could spell more-than-usual housing trouble in an economic downturn.
In general, the ratio of people's debt to the value of their house has risen over the last few years, Mr. Olson said, so that if the borrower's income diminishes it will be less likely that payments will continue on the loan. Since in a recession home values typically decline, people with high loan-to-value ratio mortgages can find themselves with more housing debt than their house is worth.
All these factors lead some entrepreneurs to foresee a longterm business in buying, upgrading and reselling distressed homes before they fall into a lender's hands. "We foresee that the leniency in lending practices over the last few years will provide us with an abundance of property to resell for the next 5 to 10 years," said Eric Fessler, president of Better Homes Depot.
MANY people have taken loans of as much of 125 percent of the true value of their house, he said, and their consequent lack of an economic stake in the house may provide them with little incentive to avoid delinquency in mortgage payments during a period of economic stress.
On the positive side, the houses themselves, once upgraded, may emerge as a buying opportunity in the marketplace. Certainly Marc and Ayana Robinson in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, and Kirk and Sandra Leon in Crown Heights, have seen it that way. Both bought houses from Better Homes Depot, whose buyers typically have incomes in the range of $50,000 to $80,000 a year, the company says.
Mr. Robinson, 27, an Adelphi University graduate, is a computer specialist with I.B.M. His wife, 25, went to Rutgers University, worked for an insurance company and now goes full time to New York Law School. Married in January, they bought a newly rehabilitated four-family house last October for about $300,000 on Rockaway Parkway in what Mr. Robinson said was one of the most desirable sections of Brownsville, near the Crown Heights line.
They were so pleased with this investment that in March they bought another four-family around the corner on East 92d Street, from the same seller at about the same price. They have been able to rent out seven apartments in the two houses for $600 to $900 a month each, providing income that offsets their mortgage payments.
"As in any construction project you have to supervise the work closely," Mr. Robinson said. "We got ceramic tile floors, all new bathrooms, a finished basement with a laundry room. The location is very good -- five minutes from a subway." The couple shopped for houses over eight months, mainly in Brooklyn, before they bought.
The two-family house that Kirk and Sandra Leon bought on Brooklyn Avenue, paying in the high $200,000's, is a classic Crown Heights brownstone, set amid a strip of well-maintained homes a block from St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church. A renter was still living in a garden-floor apartment when the Leons first saw the house last winter, Mrs. Leon said.
When the Leons moved in in May the parlor-floor bathroom had been replaced and there had been plumbing and wiring upgrades. They did not hire their own inspector, but were content to rely on the inspection done for the lender.
"I was amazed that it had a second staircase directly to the kitchen," said Mr. Leon, a security officer in the New York City hospital system who was encountered at the house one day in May as he was moving in. The Leons moved to Brooklyn from the Grand Concourse in the Bronx.
Mrs. Leon, an administrator with the city's Human Resources Administration, said that she expected no trouble in being able to afford the house. She has no plan to rent out its apartment, which a family member may use. "They say the first year of ownership is the hardest," she said.
But not all buyers have been satisfied.
A series of reports broadcast on UPN-9, WWOR-TV, between February and June highlighted the problems of buyers who had purchased homes from real estate sales companies, including Better Homes Depot. The most common complaint was the discovery of plumbing, roofing and other housing defects soon after moving in. Three persons interviewed on the programs said they were encouraged to falsify their true income on a mortgage document.
One buyer, Keith Robinson, 40, said in a telephone interview a few days ago that he wasn't in his house on East 48th Street in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, for more than a few weeks before he experienced a leaky roof and clogged drains.
Mr. Robinson, a deliveryman for a pharmacy whose wife is a social worker, said that to save money he bought the house in as-is condition, for $183,000. Some improvement work had been done on the house, "but to tell the truth I didn't know what they did, and I didn't have it inspected." But he closed anyway, using legal services provided by the seller. The house needs $10,000 more in repair work, he said, and he cannot afford it.
More than a dozen complaints have been received by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs about Better Homes Depot's sales practices, said Commissioner Jules Polonetsky, mainly from owners who say they closed with a promise from the company that work would be done, and that it was either not done or improperly done. "We are looking into whether there is a pattern of deceptive trade practices," Commissioner Polonetsky said.
Mr. Fessler said he met with Consumer Affairs officials three months ago about these complaints. About half of them have since been withdrawn, he said, and the others are in dispute. "But we've closed over 1,000 transactions," he said, asserting that the percentage of dissatisfied buyers is remarkably low.
The Better Homes Depot business represents a new try in life for the 39-year-old Mr. Fessler. A Long Island native who attended Hofstra College, he became a loan officer for Kadilac Funding Ltd., then a mortgage company in Flushing, Queens, in 1980 and its president in 1986 at the age of 26. But he said he was convicted of income-tax evasion in 1992 over a failure to report $165,000 in commissions received for placing mortgages and title insurance. He served a nine-month sentence at Allenwood Federal Prison in Pennsylvania, until August 1993.
Subsequently he worked for Madison Resources Ltd., a licensed finance company in Lake Success, N.Y., that makes loans for home improvements. Madison Home Equities, a licensed mortgage banking company under the same ownership, is the main lending source for Better Homes Depot buyers. It has provided Better Homes Depot with an $8 million line of credit to facilitate its purchase-and-resales program.
"Two years ago mortgage bankers were not typically giving a line of credit to investors," said Nadine Malone, president of both lending companies. "But now a lot of people are doing it because there are so many foreclosures and the houses need repairs before they can be resold." Last year Better Homes Depot accounted for about 20 percent of the mortgages Madison Equities originated, Ms. Malone said.
On a recent Saturday morning at the Ozone Park office of Better Homes Depot, the waiting room was filled with people awaiting appointments with salespeople. The income-qualified customer who is ready to buy is escorted to a room to discuss the specifics, including the price, with Mr. Fessler or Steve Cymbrowitz, the office manager. About 30 percent of the customers will ultimately prove unqualified for a mortgage, Mr. Fessler said.
A status board in a rear room shows how various sales teams are progressing in moving the inventory. Salesmen earn a flat commission of $3,000 a house after a closing, regardless of the sale price, Mr. Fessler said. The star salesman is Glen John, a residential broker with a serious, calm manner who has been selling homes for 18 years. He said he had sold 240 houses in the last 12 months, mainly in Brooklyn and Queens. The average price for a one-family was $190,000, and for a two-family it was $249,000, he said.
Overseeing the operation is Mr. Fessler himself, who must deal with 40 salespeople and assistants, working for the company as independent contractors fulltime, as well 25 independent contracting companies working fulltime to rehabilitate Better Homes Depot houses. Ten on-staff lawyers handle landlord-tenant and contract work. Eight "buyers" working on a commission basis work full time to acquire properties.
Can one individual manage these disparate activities? "It's not easy," Mr. Fessler said.
A prominent part of the company's sales pitch is that it will absorb closing costs up to 6 percent of the selling price. "Most of our buyers would be unable to buy if they had to pay their own closing costs," Mr. Fessler said. These costs cover the city's mortgage recording tax -- 1.75 percent of the mortgage amount in the boroughs outside Manhattan -- the title search, the appraisal fee and other fees and charges.
At the closing, buyers are asked to sign a form saying that they are satisfied with the house. A pre-closing inspection is required by the lender for its protection, but only about 60 percent of buyers take the precaution of getting their own inspection, Mr. Fessler said. "We prefer that they get their own, but it's their choice," he said.
At Best Express, Mr. Kantrowitz said that he had created his company because banks, left with foreclosed houses, could not handle the disposition process. "The banks can't control the contractors, and they can't handle evictions," he said. His new buyers typically have incomes of $60,000 to $90,000, and get their mortgages through Power Express, his mortgage company.
As Mr. Kantrowitz sees it, one of the principal causes of foreclosures in New York City has been an owner's inability to collect rent from a tenant in a two-family house. The owner cannot afford the tedious and expensive housing-court procedure, and must abandon his house or sell at a distressed price, he said.
Another problem is that the owner has borrowed excessively on a credit card, used the home as collateral to consolidate and ostensibly reduce debt payments, but then emerged in a worsened predicament when the new loan goes into default. "We buy many houses before they go under the foreclosure hammer," said Mr. Kantrowitz.
Best Express, with 50 sales agents and a support staff of 25, buys and sells about 300 houses a year, he said. Before rehabilitation tenants are evicted. "To do a proper renovation the house has to be empty," Mr. Kantrowitz said. "And if people are putting their life savings into a house, they should have the choice of who their tenant is."
Figures assembled by the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit development company based in Hauppauge, N.Y., show that the number of houses in Nassau and Suffolk County with mortgage delinquencies has grown, reaching 2,136 in Suffolk County last year and 1,580 in Nassau County. Nine percent of the Suffolk total came from Brentwood, and 6 percent came from Central Islip. In Nassau, Hempstead, Elmont and Freeport had the highest totals.
OF all the 16 million home mortgage loans originated last year, Federal data indicate, about half were for the refinancing of an existing mortgage rather than for the purchase of a new home. And according to data from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nation's largest providers of mortgage funds, about half the refinancings were aimed at raising cash rather than paying off housing debt.
Hoping to avoid problems with the loans it has insured, the Federal Housing Administration, which is an agency of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, initiated a computer-aided "credit watch" in 1995 to identify mortgage originators whose default rate is above normal. It is the F.H.A.-insured portion of outstanding mortgage loans that has shown the sharpest gain in foreclosures recently, rising to 0.65 percent last year from 0.58 percent two years earlier.
In April HUD said that it would drop as accredited lenders those with a default record at least triple the average within a given metropolitan area. Fifty lenders across the country received termination notices in a letter that went out June 1, the department said, but it declined to identify any of them since they still have the right to appeal. Neither Madison Home Equities nor Power Express received such a notice, the companies said.
Concerned about the risks for first-time urban buyers, nonprofit organizations emphasize the importance of buyer education. They generally applaud the effort to increase ownership opportunities in moderate-income neighborhoods, but they worry about excessive loans and buyer ignorance.
Francine C. Justa, executive director of Neighborhood Housing Services of New York City, said that the nonprofit company was giving home-ownership training courses to about 2,000 families a year across the city.
"Many of the buyers in New York City are former renters," Ms. Justa said. "We started our training courses after I heard about a buyer who moved into a home and wanted to know when someone was coming around to cut the grass."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1492 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Julien J. Studley;
Finding a Way to Figure Out the Real Cost of Leases

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IN the late 1980's Julien J. Studley, the chairman of the brokerage firm that bears his name, noticed an unusual development: even though demand for office space was weak and landlords were clamoring for tenants, the asking rents for properties kept rising. "For two years the market fell, but rents seemed to keep increasing," he said.
But the seeming paradox was easily explained. Although the asking rent figures were bumping up, building owners were giving larger and larger concessions packages -- periods of free rent and contributions to the cost of interior construction -- to attract tenants. 
 The result was that the effective rent that tenants were paying was declining -- as it should in a soft market.
But some owners, Mr. Studley said, had an interest in maintaining the fiction that the market was still strong and rents increasing so that they could complete financing arrangements that let them pull most or all of their investment out of a property. "A lot of lenders who did not look closely enough at these deals ended up taking back the buildings" when owners could not cover their debt payments, Mr. Studley said.
Something of a reverse happens in rising markets. Landlords typically prefer to shrink the concessions package, rather then scare tenants off with big increases in asking rent, although the effective rents reflect the shift in the supply-demand equation.
But while the asking rent figure does not tell the whole story, Mr. Studley said, it is the only easily available number in a highly fragmented and competitive business. Real estate has no equivalent of a stock market, where prices are determined continuously in an open market and are widely disseminated to all that are interested.
So, Mr. Studley said, he decided to compile what he called an effective rent index, one that would reflect concessions packages as well as expenses that tenants incur, such as the cost of electricity. The idea was to give a clearer year-to-year comparison of what was happening to rents and to provide an easy comparison between the central business districts in a dozen major cities.
The report found that midtown Manhattan is the most expensive market in the country for tenants, but that high costs hold down landlords' income. Rents for tenants in downtown Manhattan and New Jersey are close, but again higher costs in New York mean landlords there keep a lower portion of their rents than do building owners in New Jersey.
Although others may challenge his results and methodology, the Studley effective rent report represents an interesting attempt to cut through the complexity and clutter that make it hard to get a clear picture of what is happening in important commercial real estate markets. "The only information that's available is asking rents," Mr. Studley said. "Now you can take the asking rent and apply a discount, but the discount changes, so that is unreliable as well. In some market conditions, the taking rent exceeds the asking rent." That means that the demand for space in certain locations is so great that tenants bid the rent above what the landlord originally asked.
Although Mr. Studley's firm usually represents tenants, he said it is important to understand what a landlord actually has in his pocket after paying operating expenses, taxes on a property, concessions and commissions, but before debt service. Because financial structures are complex and vary from property to property, they would make year-to-year and city-to-city comparisons difficult and unreliable.
Also excluded is the so-called loss factor, the difference between the amount of space a tenant is paying for under the lease and the amount he can actually use. This is part of the twilight zone of real estate, in which steel and concrete buildings change in size as they are remeasured. "Buildings in New York grow larger as they age -- like people," Mr. Studley observed.
The result of this figuring leads to two separate indexes, the tenant effective rent and the landlord effective rent. The tenant effective rent is the estimate by the Studley firm of what a tenant actually pays after concessions are amortized over the length of the lease.
The landlord effective rent is the estimate of what a building owner has after paying the costs, although some costs, like electrical power, are passed on to the tenant. "We are developing a figure for a free and clear cash flow," said Mark Stewart, a managing director at the Studley company who compiles the report.
Because owning property is largely a fixed-cost operation, seemingly modest increases in rental income, which is customarily stated in dollars per square foot per year, can produce big changes in the owner's income. "If you have a $32 a square foot, operating expenses, taxes and so forth will typically consume $26 a foot, leaving the owner with $6 a foot in income," Mr. Studley said. "But if the rent increases to $38 a foot, he doubles his income."
According to the Studley company's figures, the landlord effective rent in downtown Manhattan increased from a slender $8.69 a square foot to $13.76 a square foot from the end of 1997 to the end of 1998. This increase was caused both because the tenant effective rents increased somewhat -- from $25.51 a square foot to $31.32 a square foot -- and because concessions decreased, from $77 a square foot in 1997 to $60 a square foot the following year. The concessions are a one-time expense to the landlord and are amortized over an assumed 10-year lease in making the calculations.
Meanwhile, operating costs and taxes were rising, so that landlords' cash flow rose $5.07 a square foot, even though the tenants' effective rent had increased $5.81 a square foot.
The story in midtown was somewhat different. The concessions package remained constant at $55 a square foot while the tenant effective rent increased from $43.47 a square foot to $47.16. Although that represented an increase of $3.69 a square foot, landlords got only an increase of $3.33 a square foot, once again as a result of higher operating expenses and taxes.
Across the river in New Jersey, concessions stayed the same, at $20 a square foot, while tenant effective rents increased $1.18 a square foot, from $28.59 a square foot to $29.77. But landlords got only an increase of 91 cents a square foot because of higher operating and electricity costs.
A big part of any concessions package is a period of free rent, which was originally thought of as the time a tenant could not use the space while its offices were being constructed. In periods of slack demand, landlords will extend this period from a few months to years as an incentive.
Mr. Studley said this type of concession has special appeal for tenants, particularly in tough economic times. "Tenants look at transactions on a discounted cash flow basis," he said. "The dollars up front are the most important to them. Owners are more willing to take up-front costs than tenants."
THE effective rent report also allows for easy comparisons of different markets. It will probably come as no surprise that midtown Manhattan is the most expensive market for tenants, with a rental rate of $47.16 a square foot after adjustment for the free rent period and construction allowance, followed by San Francisco at $42.10 a square foot and Boston at $39.89. Downtown Manhattan is in the middle of the pack for tenants at $31.32 a square foot, with downtown Los Angeles the cheapest at $19.54. The New Jersey office market is only slightly cheaper than downtown Manhattan, at $29.77 a square foot.
But high costs in New York reduce the landlords' effective rent in midtown to $25.97 a square foot, well below the $29.12 a foot building owners collect in San Francisco. Similarly, lower costs mean that landlords in New Jersey get $17.68 a square foot compared to $13.76 in downtown Manhattan.
Part of the high cost of New York is real estate taxes, which are usually passed through to tenants and which stood at $9.30 a square foot in midtown Manhattan, compared to $8.08 in Chicago and $6.35 in downtown Manhattan. Downtown Los Angeles levies just $1.96 a square foot in taxes.
In the other suburban areas of New York, the report found that tenant effective rents increased 9 percent year to year in Westchester County to an average of $24.48 a square foot, and 7.5 percent, to $26.62 a square foot, in Long Island. But tenant effective rents actually dropped 4.7 percent to $30.93 a square foot in Fairfield County, Connecticut, following a strong market in 1997.
One other area where Manhattan leads the nation is in the cost of electricity, which is calculated at $2.20 a square foot both midtown and downtown.
Mr. Studley warned that the price of electricity is not the same in all buildings because some landlords tack on a markup to improve their own effective rents. "In most cases, tenants are better off with their own meter," he said.

HEADLINE: Audrey Thurm, Edward Seiler

 BODY:
Audrey Ellen Thurm, a daughter of Carol Thurm and Dr. Joel Thurm of Davidson, N.C., is to be married today to Dr. Edward James Seiler, a son of Rochelle and Felix Seiler of Netanya, Israel. Rabbi Chaim Stern is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.
The bride, 28, is a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in clinical child psychology at DePaul University. In the fall she is to begin as a visiting research fellow at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. She graduated from Cornell University. Her father is a urologist in Salisbury, N.C. Her mother is a certified public accountant in Davidson. 
 The bridegroom, 33, is a postdoctoral fellow in economics at Hebrew University, from which he received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in agricultural economics. He received a Ph.D. in economics from the University of Chicago, where he was a Fulbright scholar. His parents are pharmacists in Netanya for the Kupat Holim, a health service.
