HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Closing Down an Empire, Gracefully

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
As a managing partner at a major accounting firm in the early 90's, Alan J. Bowers had done his share of swimming with the sharks of leveraged buyouts and arbitrage on behalf of corporate clients. He usually watched from a safe distance and was never part of the food chain himself.
That changed in 1995 when he became president of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company with the goal of rehabilitating this former stalwart of the insurance industry under the watchful eye of state regulators, courts, policyholders and creditors. 
 The company, the nation's 18th largest insurer with assets then valued at $13 billion, was insolvent in what remains the largest bankruptcy of an insurance company in the country. Waiting on his desk on his first day was a letter from a corporate creditor telling him that his name had been added as a defendant in a suit seeking millions in damages for Mutual's years of profligacy. Suddenly the then 39-year-old accountant had an inkling of what a feeding frenzy was like.
Five years later, things have changed. Mutual Benefit Life has pulled itself out of the depths of insolvency. The lawsuit in which Mr. Bowers was named, along with scores of others, has been dissolved. The company has held on to most of its 600,000 policyholders, paid creditors and made itself attractive enough to have its business and assets acquired by a major financial services company, SunAmerica.
SunAmerica, in turn, was acquired by a financial services giant, American International Group, placing policyholders who had once lined up outside of the offices of Mutual Benefits Life in a position to cash in their policies with a blue chip, global company.
Consequently, Mutual Benefit Life, which was at the center of one of the industry's most raucous and loudly contentious insolvencies, as well as its successor company, MBL Life Assurance Corp., will pass out of existence next month with barely a whisper six months before the December 1999 deadline set by the state in 1991.
Mr. Bowers will relinquish the post of president, chief executive and member of the board. While he will continue to serve as a consultant until December, he will also give up the spacious, fifth-floor office in the company's 18-story headquarters, which stands out like a large granite thumb in the city's skyline. His office is down a majestic hallway of black marble and golden oak paneling that is hung with portraits of his somber-faced predecessors over the last 154 years, all arrayed in dress ranging from wing collars and blue serge to spread collars and gray flannel.
There is no portrait among this collection of steely stares and pompous poses of Mr. Bowers, still boyish-looking at 44. For him, that is a point of some pride.
"While some of these men were doing the right thing, others didn't know what the right thing was," Mr. Bowers said as he strolled down the gantlet of portraits. "Much of what was done was done in the interest of empire building and ego gratification. It was an ugly past."
By most accounts, Mr. Bowers came in to administer a rehabilitation plan that was already set up by state regulators, the courts and Palmieri and Company, which specializes in turning around financially distressed companies. To this he added a determination to work in the open for creditors and policyholders to see. He smoothed the ruffled feathers of most of the principles involved and bought time for the company to sell off troubled real estate investments just as the market was turning upward, and to dispose of the stock it had acquired in its foreclosure on troubled businesses.
Mr. Bowers took the job four years ago amid controversy over his compensation and his ties to the administration of Governor Whitman. He had worked as a volunteer in her 1993 campaign, served on the transition committee and was chairman of the Governor's master plan commission after she took office. In addition, Mr. Bowers is friends of the Governor's husband, John, who is an investment banker.
State Senator Richard Codey, the Democratic minority leader, fought a losing battle to block the appointment as a political decision rather than a wise business move. He continues to be critical of the process, which he termed secretive, and the compensation package, which with salary, bonuses and incentives could net Mr. Bowers $1.34 million for each of the last four years.
"He has done a decent enough job, a reasonable job as a caretaker," said Mr. Codey. "But the truth is that he had a lot of help from a good economy."
Mutual Benefit's problems began in the 1980's, when its investments began to rely too heavily on speculative real estate loans and paper from dozens of equally risky leveraged buyouts. It was all long-term, illiquid investments that did not fit in well with the short term, high yield and easily withdrawn financial instruments that Mutual Benefit Life had added to its product mix of pension funds and whole life policies.
In 1991, as the recession deepened and the real estate market softened, Mutual was left with too many nonperforming loans; it foreclosed on some of them and took equity positions in other firms. The company became owner of Fisher and Williams Islands off the Florida Coast, scheduled for the development of condominiums; a macadamia nut farm; a manufacturer of baby clothing and a string of home-improvement stores in the Midwest.
"We had a small company of 600 just to oversee the development on the two islands," said Mr. Bowers, who after working as a consultant for Palmieri was chosen in 1995 to become the president of Mutual Benefit Life and oversee the continuing rehabilitation. "I saw a lot that suggested that management had been negligent."
The company continued to pay insurance benefits as they came due and put in place a plan that allowed those who wanted to cash out their policies or keep them in force through the rehabilitation with the guarantee of earning five percent interest annually and the possibility of greater benefit down the road.
Only 30,000 of the company's 495,722 policyholders took the cash offer by the deadline in 1994, about 6.2 percent of the total and valued at $101 million in payouts.
The last four years have been good ones for the company. Mr. Bowers observed early in his tenure that Mutual Benefit Life would have to be lucky and smart to come through successfully. The luck was in the upturn in the economy, which propped up most of the once-sagging real estate holdings. The smart part came, Mr. Bowers said, in the decision to broker a detente between the creditors and policyholders, who were jockeying in court for the proceeds from whatever sales were made.
Mr. Bowers said that he decided to end the secrecy and talk to everyone in separate meetings about the rehabilitation process with one caveat: that they leave their lawyers home. By 1996 he persuaded all parties to agree to a set of "guiding principles" that called on them to drop their suits in exchange for a guarantee that the policyholders would get 30 percent of the post-rehabilitation value and creditors 70 percent.
"The company had failed in a hugely colossal way in front of the whole world and I didn't want to work out the final deal in a backroom somewhere," he said.
With the final disposition of the company, the faithful policyholders will be getting $245 million over the next three-and-a-half years and the creditors will get a total of $573 million, or 95 percent of their original investments when they once feared that their best outcome would be 30 cents on the dollar.
"The only constituency that was not served well was the employees," said Mr. Bowers, who noted that employment had plummeted from 3,150 in 1991 to about 375 now in the waning weeks of MBL Life Assurance. "We were able to create so much value that we were able to offer them gain-sharing benefits, severance packages and outplacement services. But there was no opportunity for them to continue their careers here."
As for himself, Mr. Bowers said that he would finish his consulting in the final months of the company's existence and let the work he did speak for itself as he fields job offers.
"I'm a relatively young guy at 44 years old and I have a career ahead of me," he said. "I didn't want to be associated with a backroom deal which everyone questioned."

HEADLINE: A Culture of Trial, Despite Error

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
LOU L. PAI'S last assignment at Enron had all the hallmarks of a career maker.
As the chairman and chief executive of Enron Energy Services, Mr. Pai led the company's charge to become the nation's premier marketer of electricity to residential customers as states like California deregulated their utility industries.
Oops. After an intensive, two-year campaign that sent Enron's stock on a roller-coaster ride, the company has declared retail electric sales a dead end for now. 
 A career breaker? Not at Enron, said Mr. Pai, 51. Top executives concluded that the company had just been premature. "You're going to make mistakes," Mr. Pai said. "You can't sit there and punish people for trying."
It doesn't hurt that the company's senior officers have known failure. Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's president, recalled that he and Mr. Pai were part of group in 1990 that developed a financial instrument called a Gas Trust, intended to let investors speculate on natural-gas prices. Enron promoted the trust around the country, but quickly abandoned it when investors showed little interest.
Now, instead of being reined in by his superiors, Mr. Pai has been encouraged to push ahead and take even more risks. His unit is spending heavily to persuade large industrial and commercial customers to sign up for long-term contracts under which Enron will supply them with low-cost electricity and natural gas, along with an array of services to cut their energy costs. The start-up costs are expected to reach $300 million by the end of the year, and Mr. Pai hopes that the new business will begin to generate operating profits by fall.
That makes the gamble much bigger than Enron's retailing efforts, which began in April 1996, when the company sent 30 salespeople to set up an office in Peterborough, N.H., a village of 5,300. New Hampshire had a pilot program to introduce competition into electricity sales, and as part of it, Enron beat back a score of rivals to be selected as Peterborough's new energy supplier.
The company then spent $30 million on television commercials -- some featuring happy customers in Peterborough -- intended to make itself a household name. By the fall of 1997, Mr. Pai and his group had carried the banner to California, which as the first state to fully deregulate would be a much bigger market to tap.
Enron sent out hundreds of thousands of fliers offering customers two weeks' free electricity, and it blanketed the state with advertising. But the response was tepid: The company ended up with about 50,000 customers, or 1 percent of a potential pool of five million accounts.
After spending $15 million in a few months, Enron pulled out of California -- and left Peterborough, too, as New Hampshire's deregulation efforts flagged. "It's a marketing game," explained Mr. Pai, who studied economics at the University of Maryland and worked at Conoco as a trader before joining Enron in 1987. "We're not a marketing company. That's not our expertise."
His current thrust -- going after larger customers to supply electricity and natural gas in big quantities -- is more familiar ground for Enron. But there are challenges: knitting together disparate services to provide energy audits, billing and centralized heating and cooling controls for hotel chains or sports stadiums or a company's factories.
There is also ample competition -- and the certainty that for all the leeway Enron affords, the market's discipline will be swift and severe if Mr. Pai and his group have miscalculated on the long-term supply agreements.
"If we don't execute," he said, "we're toast."

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
For Retailers in Some City Centers, Gentrification Is a Four-Letter Word

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
FOR 70 years, Hippodrome Hatters has sold handmade hats to fashion-conscious shoppers from a small store on North Eutaw Street on this city's West Side. Lou Boulmetis, who took over the business from his grandfather, has seen the area, once the center of Baltimore's retail trade, suffer through a long decline: the departure of old-line department stores, a rise in crime and the erosion of once-glorious retail facades.
But it is the so-called revival that has Mr. Boulmetis worried. His shop is in a building, built in 1810, that is now scheduled for demolition in a sweeping city program to remake the shopworn 18-block retail district, whose patrons are now mostly African-Americans. The project could displace more than 100 small businesses, many of them owned by African- or Korean-Americans, as roughly 100 properties are condemned and leveled. 
 "Beauty is in the eye of the beholder," said Mr. Boulmetis, 47, a scrappy, bantamweight hat maker with no patience for "yuppification," as many opponents derisively refer to the sprucing-up of urban neighborhoods to appeal to wealthy, young, mainly white professionals. "We've been here through everything, and now they want to remake the place for the educated class on the backs of the people who are already here."
The planned $350 million redevelopment of the West Side includes 2,000 new housing units, splashy retail stores, renovation of a theater and new parking structures, reflecting the growing confidence among investors in the economic health of city centers. Neighborhood revival plans are usually catnip to local business people, and in cities across the country merchants have organized business improvement districts to improve neighborhoods and attract new shoppers and investment.
But for many people, projects like Baltimore's that call for sweeping demolition harken frighteningly back to the huge redevelopment projects of the 1950's and 60's and threaten to destroy everything they are meant to revive: the unique fabric and traditions of neighborhoods.
In some cases, including Baltimore's West Side, redevelopment also threatens to obliterate a historic part of the city's architectural heritage. This has made the planned demolition a cause celebre with preservationist groups like Baltimore Heritage and the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which earlier this month named the West Side one of the nation's 11 most endangered places. (Baltimore has also drawn criticism recently for its sweeping demolition of row houses, a staple of the city's working-class neighborhoods.)
IN some city neighborhoods, preserving architecture has mattered less than fighting off the numbing sameness that increasingly characterizes urban retail districts. Storied places like Old Town in Pasadena, Calif., Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass., and Chelsea -- among other neighborhoods -- in New York City are in some ways becoming victims of their own success as they attract wealthier urbanites and the national specialty chains that cater to them.
"We used to be a place no one heard of, and if they did, they never would want to move to," said Robert Trentlyon, a longtime Chelsea resident and the former publisher of a neighborhood newspaper, The Chelsea Clinton News. "Then we got discovered about 10 years ago," and rents and land values soared, he noted; Federal-era town houses that sold for $10,000 in the 1950's now fetch $1.5 million.
In the process, one of New York's more eclectic shopping districts, with antique shops, thrift stores and local restaurants, is being transformed into yet another homogenized urban neighborhood.
Old Town Pasadena has already arrived where Chelsea seems to be headed, and where many on the West Side of Baltimore fear to go. When Old Town was first redeveloped in the early 1980's, it attracted adventurous independent merchants, while the larger chains stayed on the sidelines. But as the area caught on, attracting an increasingly prosperous customer base, the national chains poured in.
Rising rents and landlords' preference for financially secure corporate tenants have all but driven out the small and unique shops, according to one of Old Town's original redevelopers, Joseph Paggi.
"The guys who came in originally, the independents, end up losing economically," said Mr. Paggi, now chief operating officer of Center Trust, a real estate investment firm in Manhattan Beach, Calif. "The change to the Crate and Barrels and Barnes & Nobles puts everything into the stratosphere."
Mr. Paggi says Old Town's evolution leads him to think that successful urban shopping districts are destined to be "pasteurized" sooner or later. "We'll have a Banana Republic on every corner and a Starbucks right next to them," he predicted.
TO officials leading the redevelopment of Baltimore's West Side, that's no bad thing, and may even be indispensable. M. J. Brodie, president of the quasi-public Baltimore Development Corporation, says new investment is needed in areas like the West Side to attract middle-income shoppers and residents back to the urban core. To save some old buildings, he said, there may be a need to replace others with new structures like parking garages.
Mr. Brodie's efforts are strongly backed by Baltimore's political elite, many of whom are African-American, including the outgoing Mayor, Kurt L. Schmoke, and a majority on the City Council. (Peter Angelos, a powerful real estate developer who owns the Baltimore Orioles, is also on board, as are Nationsbank and the Weinberg Foundation, which owns large chunks of West Side real estate.) Mr. Brodie chafes at the assertions by Mr. Boulmetis and other local merchants that the project's real goal is to replace the area's mainly black shoppers with a more "upscale" population drawn from young professionals and the University of Maryland campus nearby.
"Whenever you try to improve something, there's a trade-off," Mr. Brodie said. "We want to create a success story that includes all kind of people, working class, African-American, WASP's."
Mr. Brodie, who led the recent redevelopment of Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, says demolishing old buildings and relocating tenants is a price worth paying to revive the West Side.
But many merchants say the price he is willing to pay is their destruction. To fight the project, they have enlisted William Donald Schaefer, who was Mayor of Baltimore from 1971 to 1987, then Governor of Maryland, and remains one of the city's most respected political figures. Mr. Schaefer has said he favored improving the West Side using more imagination and less of a "bulldozer mentality."
With his support, and a threatened lawsuit, Mr. Boulmetis and other West Side merchants still hope to stave off the wrecker's ball. "This area evolved because it serves the market," Mr. Boulmetis said. "Let it evolve. Not everything has to be the same, like any suburban mall.
"It's not just a matter of pretty buildings," he continued. "It's our livelihood."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
States Chasing Sales Taxes Down the Internet Highway

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is one of the more vexing economic issues of the Internet age: how to insure that state sales tax revenues are not eviscerated by the shift to on-line retailing, where borders are all but meaningless and sales tax collection is spotty at best.
The question has riled both state and local governments, which fear that their tax bases will disappear down a phone line at 56 kilobits a second, and electronic retailers and Internet service providers, which fear that revenue-hungry governments will view electronic commerce as a cash cow to be milked every which way. 
 The basic problem has been around as long as mail-order catalogues. When consumers order books, compact disks or flowers from an out-of-state retailer, they are technically liable to pay sales taxes. Companies, however, are bound to collect the taxes only from consumers in states where the company has a physical presence. Although some merchants collect the tax even where they are not required to do so, most do not.
So for orders by mail, or phone -- or the Internet -- consumers can end up with a tax-free purchase. That reality has left traditional retailers complaining of a competitive disadvantage. And it has left state and local governments worried that technology is leaving tax policy far behind. Denied reliable sales taxes, they may have to look elsewhere for revenue, with unpredictable consequences.
It is not too hard to come up with potential solutions. But don't look for them to be agreed upon and implemented quickly.
Last week saw a flurry of attention to the issue, but no consensus on anything. The Clinton Administration issued a report on the "breathtaking" growth of electronic commerce and the technologies that make it possible, suggesting that the nation is only starting to get a handle on all the ways the Internet is changing the economy and necessitating adjustments to public policy.
Some of the biggest names in business weighed in with a report about lost sales tax revenues that suggested the states have gotten themselves in a lather about nothing.
And the Advisory Commission on Electronic Commerce, established last year by Congress to help sort out the taxation issue, held its first meeting and quickly got into a heated debate about . . . office space.
The Administration's report, prepared by the Commerce Department, acknowledged that the Government was only starting to collect and analyze information looking specifically at the quantity and composition of electronic commerce. But while it cited only vague estimates of the size of that business -- between $7 billion and $15 billion last year, growing to as much as $80 billion in 2002 -- it included a set of examples that made clear how powerful a force electronic commerce has become:
* The on-line sales of Dell Computer more than doubled last year, and by next year the company expects them to account for half its revenue.
* Quicken Mortgage, an on-line mortgage provider from Intuit, arranged $400 million in loans in the first quarter of this year, a pace far ahead of the $600 million in all of 1998.
* US-Style.com recently started a service allowing Japanese consumers to buy American goods through a Japanese-language Web site. The report said the service highlighted the global nature of electronic commerce and the potential for it to become a trade issue.
BUT what has all that activity meant for sales tax collections? Not much, according to the study done by Ernst & Young for a coalition that included America Online, Cisco Systems, Microsoft, Time Warner and Wal-Mart.
The study found that state and local governments lost $170 million in sales tax revenue last year because of Internet commerce, or one-tenth of 1 percent of total sales and use tax collections.
"The 'revenue crisis' from Internet sales has not materialized," it concluded. "The Advisory Commission on Electronic Commerce, state and local government and Congress have time to carefully deliberate on the appropriate taxation of E-commerce."
That is good news for the commission, which spent a portion of its first session last week debating whether its executive director had created a conflict of interest in accepting free office space from an electronics-industry lobbying group that employs her husband. (Like any good commission, it opted to study the matter further before making a decision.)
There are technical and political hurdles to creating a system that would automatically add the appropriate sales tax to Internet purchases and funnel the revenue to the proper government. But none of them are insurmountable; the electronic payment systems used by the credit card companies and banks are the obvious model.
The real problem is whether the commission, Congress and the Administration can work quickly enough to get ahead of the Internet wave, or whether public policy is doomed always to paddle in its wake. Given the libertarian ethos that has always pervaded cyberspace, perhaps the latter is just the outcome that the E-commerce industry and Internet users want. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 3; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 2560 words

HEADLINE: Not Just Another Working Girl

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
GROWING up, Elise Henning did all the right things. She attended the Ethel Walker School, made her debut at the Junior Assembly, spent her junior year in Geneva and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. When she returned to her parents' home in New Canaan, Conn., she asked her father, a Wall Street commodities trader, if she could go to law school.
"Elise, you don't need to go to law school," she recalls him saying. "Your brother does." His advice: "Catch a good man, make him happy and you'll be taken care of for the rest of your life." 
 That was almost 30 years ago, and Ms. Henning ended up marrying a lawyer, settling with him in Palm Beach, Fla., and socializing in all the right circles. She entertained, became active in the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea and had a daughter who attended Palm Beach Day School.
It was just as Father had said. Until her husband left, moving to Vermont. He paid no child support after the divorce in 1992, she said, relating the story over iced tea at the Hotel Carlyle.
She didn't know what to do.
Not wanting her status in life to change, and most important, not wanting her daughter, who was 12 at the time, to feel deprived in any way, she assessed her skills. She had had no career, but she did have a knowledge of fine homes. (She and all her friends had always lived in them.) She knew how to entertain and dress tastefully, and she had many rich and social friends.
So Ms. Henning became a real estate broker at Martha A. Gottfried Inc., selling luxury properties to the social and the trying-to-be-social. By night, she was a Palm Beach party planner, helping women create "beautiful parties" for around $200 a guest. (In between, by telephone, she helped her daughter with homework). "I was so out there, networking, meeting more people," she said. "The jobs gave me an income, access and a great reason, as a single woman, for being at all the parties."
Ms. Henning, who has since moved to Manhattan to sell real estate at the upscale Stribling & Associates, went the classic employment route of upper-class former wives -- both divorced and widowed -- in their 40's and 50's. Reared to expect husbands to be their providers, they are left without careers of their own, and usually with a financial settlement too meager to maintain the life they are accustomed to.
But many can turn to careers in glossy fields for which their particular credentials -- high-maintenance tastes and a network of rich and social friends -- make them ideally suited. These include luxury real-estate sales, interior decorating, event planning and "client liaison" at the Sotheby's or Christie's auction houses, where they help the best clients decide what to buy and which of their houses to put it in.
A not-so-incidental benefit of these glamour jobs is that they put women in the right circles to meet the next multimillionaire husband, if that's what they have in mind.
Mark Simone, 44, a man about town with homes in Manhattan and Greenwich, Conn., has dated many such women. "My first line is, 'Are you a real estate broker or a decorator?' " he said, laughing. "They always say, 'I'm a real estate broker, but I was a decorator. How did you know?' "
Sugar Rautbord, a socialite author in Palm Beach, said the upper-class divorcee has two options (neither including the possibility, exercised by at least some women, of returning to college or professional school to prepare for a new career). For one, she can go to Sotheby's. "That's where part of the mythic lure is that you sit behind the desk or have some knowledge of French antiquities, and a gentleman will materialize in front of you, purchase a catalogue and ask for your hand in marriage," she said.
Option 2 is to sell real estate. She recalled that a "multi-asseted single man" she knows was home-shopping in Palm Beach, where an army of leggy, attractive divorcees was competing over him. One day, she said, he called a broker he had been working with, and a colleague said the woman was out of the office with a terminal illness, but she would be happy to take him to dinner. "The first broker had a dentist's appointment!" said Ms. Rautbord, whose latest novel, "The Chameleon" (Warner Books, 1999), is about a middle-aged woman who changes her life and moves on by remarrying.
Of course, the difficulties of re-entering the dating world and the workplace are common to all divorced women whose husbands supported them, regardless of economic status. A 1996 study in the American Sociological Review found that women's standard of living after divorce fell 27 percent, while men's rose 10 percent.
But Lenore Weitzman, the author of "The Divorce Revolution: The Unexpected Social and Economic Consequences for Women and Children in America" (Free Press/ Macmillan, 1986), said the economic slide for stay-at-home wives from affluent households is greater than average, because there is such a discrepancy between what the husband made and what the wife can earn.
"For the ladies-who-lunch set, in divorce they end up with a skimpier lunch than when they started," said Raoul Felder, the celebrity divorce lawyer.
Enter the glamour job. The access to financial information about home buyers -- and in the New York world of co-op sales, social and personal references -- makes luxury real estate sales the most popular field for the once and hopeful wealthy wife. (For those who might not be in it to stalk a husband, of course, it doesn't hurt that the work can pay quite handsomely.) Taylor Stein, an owner of the clubby Brown's restaurant on the Upper East Side, who used to sell real estate at William B. May, said: "Think about it: when you get a customer who calls and he tells you he's looking for an apartment that is $5 million, guess what, he's rich enough for you. And if it's a co-op, you have access to the most intensely personal information -- W-2's, reference letters."
Ms. Henning agrees, to a point. "The application still doesn't tell you about his character, his values," she said. You also have to sniff around, maybe look up divorce records. "If the guy is from Darien, go up to Darien and read the circumstances of the divorce," she said. That way you won't end up, like one friend of hers, dating a man with excellent financial references who was also cross-dressing in Miami.
MS. HENNING, who is in her early 50's, has gone out on a date or two with men she met through her jobs, but "nothing's worked out," she said. Either they didn't ask her out again, or they didn't live up to her expectations, which are high. "When they ask me to pay half the check," she said, "I cross them off my list."
There is also the problem of dealing with the towering egos of the middle-aged bachelors some women in New York refer to as "the billionaire boys' club."
Ms. Henning recalled dating a retired executive worth $80 million who was used to people's bowing and scraping. "He had a level of self-absorption that was scary," she said. "When I would talk, he would say, 'Shut up.' He would only relate as if I were a corporate secretary." She made him a needlepoint pillow that said, "It ain't easy being king," and then ended the relationship.
Nancy Pearson, a divorced woman in her 40's who still looks a bit like the cheerleader she was in college, also has high standards. She would be thrilled to fall in love with a man with five houses and a horse farm, though she acknowledged she would make do with less: "I just want a country house."
Ms. Pearson, who was divorced in her 20's, bounced around in some not-so-glamorous jobs -- as an art director for CBS, then for Hearst magazines -- before landing in the bona fide glamour field of decorating. "At CBS, I was working so hard, weekends, nights, I never met anyone externally," she said. "I sat at my desk all the time. It was not the right existence, so I quit."
Ms. Pearson said that in 1997, she ran into a handsome, recently divorced man at a fund-raiser for the very social Henry Street Settlement. He was moving from Greenwich, Conn., to Manhattan and asked her to help him find an apartment and to decorate it. She found a place on the Upper East Side for him, then moved in with him and started to decorate. The relationship was moving along -- she had met his family, and had even gone camping with his mother -- but just as the window treatments were delivered, her beau said the relationship was too serious and asked her to move out.
"I guess I had finished my job," she said ruefully.
Now, Ms. Pearson said, she has a rule not to date clients. Or at least not until her work is finished. It is part of the courtship dance between the glamorous working woman and the wealthy bachelor -- a working relationship full of moments of professional intimacy, which allow the rare bloom and the buzzing bee to size one another up.
R. Couri Hay, a society columnist for Hamptons magazine, said that all of the men and women who meet this way have something the other wants. "These women are looking for an American billionaire," he said, "and a man wants glamour, prestige, social connections that he doesn't have. A man who has money and doesn't have class wants to get himself a glamour girl."
Dr. Steve Pearlman, 43, a plastic surgeon, was a client of Ms. Pearson's, though they never dated. He has gone out with a real estate broker who showed him apartments. He said a man can learn a lot about a potential mate in such professional encounters. "You see their taste, their attention to detail, their attention to budget," he said. "Are they realistic? Are they frivolous?"
Ms. Pearson's white-blond hair and trim figure (she works out three or four times a week) mark her as virtually the universal type among the glamorous divorced women of the Upper East Side. She and many others tend to favor a uniform of Adolfo and Chanel at lunch, classic 18-karat jewelry and, for lounging with friends, white cotton blouses that seem chosen so the buttons gape slightly across the chest. Most look far younger than their years, an effect achieved through meticulous grooming and, in many cases, the magic of a surgeon's knife.
They are well aware that in looking for romance with men their age, they are competing with women a decade or two younger.
"It's hard," said Mary Meehan, a stunning blonde from Dallas, crossing her long legs on a blue velvet Louis XV couch in her New York apartment. "Men in their 50's . . . there aren't that many for us 50-year-olds." She is a student of the fashionable theories of evolutionary psychology.
"Men are instinctively drawn to young women of childbearing age, and women are drawn to men who can take care of them, with power," she said. "It's instinct."
Ms. Meehan, who has been divorced four times, is a decorator who works and socializes hard. (Nina Griscom and Dr. Dan Baker are close friends.) She takes decorating jobs only for $500,000 and up. In her own apartment, a modernist white box, she spent many hours adding moldings and gilding, upholstering the walls with Fortunylike fabric to give it the look of a European chateau.
"I learned my work ethic in my 40's," she said. "I wish I had it in my 20's."
Growing up with wealthy parents, Ms. Meehan thought she would never have to work. "Proper young ladies got married," she said. Her first husband hunted and fished, she said, living off inherited money. After her latest divorce, from Michael Meehan, a former partner at Salomon Brothers, he got the Southampton house, and their nine-room apartment on East 72d Street was sold to satisfy the settlement terms.
Ms. Meehan traded down to a two-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue in the 60's, and she had to go to work nearly full time. Fortunately, her life of privilege had given her exquisite taste. At 19, her father sent her, her mother and a sister to Paris to shop for antiques for a year. Her decorating projects have been published in Architectural Digest, which has won her the attention of bachelors, though not always the most ideal ones. After publication, she said, she received letters from men in prison -- avid readers of the magazine, it turned out.
At Park Avenue tea parties, the popular theory is that a divorced woman has five years from the time her settlement comes through to meet the next husband.
The deadline reflects the reality of modern divorce, which rarely grants a woman long-term alimony. Most states, including New York, award "equitable distribution" of assets in a divorce, which means a greater share goes to the bigger contributor; wives often receive a lump sum.
Even some of the richest, most high-profile women can find the financial carpet pulled out from under them. After her divorce from the billionaire Henry Kravis, Carolyne Roehm lost his backing for the fashion company she ran, so she took flower-arranging classes to prepare for a new career writing books about flowers. "I went from running seven houses to running one, my own," Ms. Roehm said.
Barbara de Portago said there is a difference between the hard economic reality of the divorced woman and the myth of "the divorcee, with that accent on the first e." Being a divorcee, she said, "means that you're heavily subsidized by the former husband, swathed in haute couture -- you're bejeweled. Of course, a divorcee has no children, is massaged in oil and is lolling about on the French Riviera or Gstaad."
Ms. de Portago, thrice divorced, wouldn't mind being such a figure. Instead, she works for glamorous employers -- Sotheby's, Christian Dior and the Versailles Foundation -- largely trading on the taste and connections acquired during a life in the beau monde. "My work is all social," she said, mostly "conducted over lunch" -- La Grenouille, Le Cirque 2000, Le Bernardin.
Over Evian at the Pierre, Ms. de Portago said she did not want to talk about her three former husbands (Anthony de Portago, a son of Carroll Petrie; Jason Grant, a playwright, and William Tabert, an investment banker), but she was happy to talk about work. As a consultant to Christian Dior, which supplies her with a wardrobe, she entices friends to buy the house's clothes. She gives a lunch twice a year at Le Cirque for 150 women, all of whom must wear Dior.
Ms. de Portago grew up in the palace of Versailles. Truly. Her stepfather, Gerald Van der Kemp, was the curator.
At Sotheby's, where she works in client relations, she advises new customers -- many of them newly wealthy -- on what and how to buy at auction. She said that men fly her to their country homes, introduce her to more people and, oh yes, sometimes propose marriage. "They say, 'Please marry me, Barbara -- you could be such an asset to me,' " she said, then added, "There are so many men out there, but no one I want yet."
While Ms. Henning, the real estate broker who moved to New York from Palm Beach, encouraged her daughter, Cornelia, now 19, to make her debut at the Junior Assembly, she is now warning her not to follow her own example of neglecting a career and marrying for security. Two years ago, after Cornelia left for Vanderbilt University in Nashville, she called home and said, "Mom, all the girls here want is their M.R.S."
Within a year, Ms. Henning brought her daughter to Manhattan and urged her to enroll at New York University, where she is now studying filmmaking.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
Supporters Use Sardines to Fish for a New Subway

 BODY:
A sardine sandwich was the center of attention at Ratner's restaurant on Delancey Street on Thursday afternoon. Garnished with black olives, sheaves of iceberg lettuce and pickles, the fish, on a bagel, glistened as television cameras tried to capture its essence.
As Robert Harmatz, a third-generation owner of the 94-year-old restaurant explained, the bagel represented New York City. The sardines symbolized the Lexington Avenue subway line, because, Mr. Harmatz said, "people are always complaining that it is so crammed." 
 The Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, organized the lunchtime gathering to build support for construction of a Second Avenue subway as a way to relieve pressure on the Lexington Avenue line. Last week, Mrs. Fields traveled around Manhattan trying to persuade her constituents and local officials of the need for the line, which has been planned for nearly 70 years. She has asked people to sign yellow postcards urging the city to follow through, and on June 30 she intends to take those postcards -- she said she had 17,000 -- to a meeting of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The transit authority has submitted a plan to the Federal Government for a Second Avenue subway that would run between 125th and 63d Streets, connecting to the N and R lines. But Mrs. Fields is campaigning for a subway line that would run all the way to the Bowery, with a spur to the Lower East Side.
"The Lower East Side is devoid of subway service," Mrs. Fields said. "The economic revitalization of East Harlem demands that this area be served as well."
Upon entering Ratner's and looking at the platters arrayed before her, Mrs. Fields said, "I like olives," and popped one in her mouth. She looked at the sardine sandwich and said, "I don't have to eat the whole thing, do I?"
Then she took a bite, and winced slightly. "Mmm," she said through her teeth. "This is symbolic of how people are being crammed into the subway like a sardine can. But people crammed in the subway don't taste nearly as good as this sandwich."
The day before, Mrs. Fields had testified at a transit authority hearing, at which the agency was reviewing its request for Federal financing for fiscal year 2000. While the request included nearly $2.8 billion in capital improvements for New York City and suburban transit, no money was sought specifically for the Second Avenue subway line.
Mrs. Fields estimated that the full-length line she envisioned would cost $10 billion and take at least 10 years to complete.
A. Gifford Miller, a City Councilman from the Upper East Side, also testified before the transit agency on Wednesday. "If you see the subway lines as the city's circulatory system, the Lexington Avenue line is a totally congested artery that is likely to cause a major heart attack in the near future," he said. NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH;
Gregory M. DePrince and David E. Tierney: Harbor Value Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
GREGORY M. DePRINCE, a portfolio manager at DePrince, Race & Zolo in Orlando, Fla., says he barely knows David E. Tierney, a managing partner at Richards & Tierney in Chicago. That is not surprising -- until you consider that the two men jointly manage the $185.5 million Harbor Value fund.
Indeed, Mr. Tierney says he isn't even familiar with the stocks picked by Mr. DePrince, who in turn describes their relationship this way: "I've met him, but I'm completely unaware of what he's doing." 
 An odd relationship, to be sure, but a rewarding one. Harbor Value returned 21.8 percent, annualized, for the three years ended June 18, compared with 15.5 percent for its peer group of mid-cap value funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index returned 28.7 percent.
"The fund's structure is somewhat unusual, but it's worked quite well," said Emily Hall, a Morningstar analyst. (It's also unusual that Harbor Capital Advisors, the fund's manager, is owned by the packaging giant Owens-Illinois.)
How does the arrangement work? To fill the 70 percent of the fund he runs, Mr. DePrince scours the markets for values among mid- and large-capitalization companies -- but more on that shortly.
As for the remainder of the fund, Mr. Tierney receives a quarterly list of about 500 stocks from which Mr. DePrince plans to select his part of the portfolio. Because Mr. Tierney knows the sector weightings and other attributes of that universe, he can use a computer to pick 150 stocks that -- when combined with Mr. DePrince's universe -- are meant to match the Russell 3000 value index in terms of attributes like price-to-earnings, dividend yield, sector weightings and volatility.
"We're the risk controllers," he said, because of the diversification and balance he brings to the fund.
Mr. DePrince's job, meanwhile, is to pick stocks that will distinguish the fund from any index. It's a three-part process. First, he screens 6,000 publicly traded securities for those with above-average yields, market capitalizations of at least $1 billion, and sufficient liquidity. That gives him the diverse list of stocks that is passed on to Mr. Tierney.
Second, Mr. DePrince whittles down that list to 200 or so by looking for issues that are undervalued both historically and relative to the index. He uses four proxies for value: price-to-earnings and price-to-book ratios, price-to-cash flow and a stock's yield relative to the S. & P. 500 over time.
Then he and two analysts make the final cut, to 75 stocks, by looking for a catalyst that will cause investors to put a higher valuation on the stock. Catalysts may include the start of a new product cycle, a change in the pricing cycle of a company's business or a restructuring.
He now sees the most value incyclical stocks, especially paper, chemicals, metals and machinery companies. "After a three-year run on growth stocks, these areas have become very undervalued," he said. "And on the fundamental side, we have the bottoming of the Asian economies, the continuing strength in the U.S. economy and relatively stable conditions in Europe."
A FAVORITE is Boise Cascade, the paper company. The stock yields 1.41 percent, and Mr. DePrince says it has a price-to-book ratio of 1.8, in the bottom third of all stocks. The catalyst for improvement, he said, is rising demand for two key products -- uncoated freesheet and liner board, which should result in higher prices. He first bought shares in July 1998, at $29.25, and has a 12-month price target of $48. The stock now trades at $42.625, or 28.7 times analysts' 1999 earnings estimates of $1.49 a share.
Also last July, he bought shares of Emerson Electric, the electrical equipment maker. Emerson, which yields 2.02 percent, acquired Westinghouse Process Controls in the third quarter of last year. "We like the acquisition, because it gives Emerson the opportunity to cross-sell all their other electrical equipment products" to Westinghouse's customer base, he said. Emerson's recently announced acquisition of Daniel Industries, which makes measurement control devices for the oil and gas industry, will provide a similar opportunity, he added.
Mr. DePrince has a 12-month price target of $89 on the stock, which now trades at $64.4375, or 21.49 times the earnings of $3 a share that analysts estimate for 1999. Its price-to-book multiple is 4.7.
In September, he acquired shares in Bank of America of Charlotte, N.C., which yields 2.56 percent. "The Nationsbank acquisition of BankAmerica provides enormous cost-cutting opportunities, on top of the successful integration with Barnett Banks in Florida and Boatmen's Bancshares in Missouri," he said.
His 12-month price target is $86; the stock now trades at $70.375, or 2.6 times book value and 14.89 times analysts' 1999 earnings estimates of $4.73 a share.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Rough Turf, Even for the Streetwise

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
THE Imperial Credit Commercial Mortgage Investment Corporation, a real estate investment trust, has properties spread from a suburb of Paris to sun-drenched Las Vegas, Nev. But its fate is likely to hinge on what happened earlier this month in a conference room at a Marriott hotel in Torrance, Calif.
REIT's lost their stock market glitz in late 1997 and nearly became a boneyard last fall when investors shunned their risks after the Russian debt crisis. Since then, it has become fashionable to insist that the field offers rich pickings for individual investors looking for bargains. 
 But when H. Wayne Snavely, chairman of Imperial Credit Commercial Mortgage Investment, called a shareholder meeting to order at the Torrance Marriott on June 18, value-happy individual investors were scarce. Instead, he faced about a dozen financially muscular portfolio managers, or their lawyers. Many were there to protest the proposed acquisition of the trust by its publicly traded management company, which is also run by Mr. Snavely.
The management company, Imperial Credit Industries, has offered to buy the trust for $11.50 a share, about 25 cents more than its current trading price and $2.50 less than book value. The institutional investors contend that the trust's assets could fetch at least $13 share in a liquidation or in an auction that was not tilted in favor of the management company.
Mr. Snavely says the trust and its management company will cooperate fully with any competing bidder -- as a shareholder, he said, he too wants the best price for his shares -- but he disagrees that a liquidation will produce anything like the bonus that his institutional investors predict.
The dispute shows the challenge for small investors these days in the REIT market, where the best motto might be: REIT's are for professionals. Don't try this at home.
While the market is filled with trust shares that look cheap by historical standards, those that are also safe are much harder for even professionals to find. By law, such trusts must pay out virtually all their income to shareholders, even when it is more prudent to retain capital. The challenge is to find a trust whose portfolio can withstand that steady outflow of cash without collapsing into debt or excessively diluting the stakes of existing investors.
And even if you find one, the industry is so beset by conflicts of interest that you may need to speak up to protect your interests -- and it is far easier to be heard when you own a million shares or so.
That is about the number of the Imperial trust's 28.5 million outstanding shares that are owned by Third Avenue Funds, which is run by Martin J. Whitman, a value investor who has never been shy about speaking out.
In late May, the trust's independent directors got a polite letter from Michael H. Winer, co-manager of the Third Avenue Real Estate Value fund. He urged the independent directors overseeing the auction to reject the management company's bid and consider instead "an orderly liquidation" of the trust's assets, arguing that bidders are more likely to pay top dollar if they are bidding only for assets they really want. And he questioned the size of the termination fee the management company will get as part of the deal, which some analysts estimated could be as much as $50 million.
Then he made his plans to spend June 18 in Torrance.
About the same time, Gary Frohman was packing his briefcase, too. Mr. Frohman is a portfolio manager for the Alan J. Steinberg L.P. in Coral Gables, Fla., a small investment partnership with about 300,000 of the trust's shares under management.
"We are concerned that the management company is trying to buy the trust at a below-market price," Mr. Frohman said.
Mr. Snavely, wearing his hat as trust chairman, said in an interview that he "appreciates the input of our investors" but disagrees that a liquidation is better than selling the trust intact.
Then he donned his hat as the management company's chairman and explained that the termination fee, which will be set by an independent appraisal, has been capped voluntarily at $35 million.
That is about five times the annual management fee and 10 percent of the market capitalization of the trust, an arrangement Mr. Winer thought "ludicrous"; Mr. Frohman considered it merely "ridiculous."
In any case, the termination fee should be nailed down quickly, Mr. Frohman said, because "it will be difficult or impossible for a third party to make their best bid without knowing what this obligation will be."
The fee dispute shows how the management company's insider status could discourage other bidders, several big shareholders said. But Mr. Snavely said he was confident that adequate due diligence by an outside bidder would keep the field level.
The management company and its officers own about 12 percent of the trust's shares, he pointed out, so "if somebody wants to pay more, we will appreciate it." But he is not optimistic, he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2764 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Trading In Bonds On Line, At Last

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
IT was a bold experiment in cyberspace finance, and at 11:30 one recent Tuesday morning, it was about to be tested in the real market.
Robert A. Schoch, business manager of the Lancaster, Pa., school district, huddled around a computer screen with Louis J. Verdelli and other advisers here, waiting to see if anyone would bid over the Internet for $29.2 million of the district's bonds. 
 Five minutes, then 10, went by without a bid. Mr. Schoch grew apprehensive. Then, just as the noon deadline for the auction was drawing near, the screen came alive. Offers appeared from as far away as Utah.
At last Mr. Schoch allowed a smile to crease his poker face. The district's first Internet financing had succeeded.
The Lancaster auction was one small part of an accelerating electronic revolution. The bond market -- both for new issues like Lancaster's and for trading in existing bonds -- is being dragged out of the dark ages of fragmentation and opaque pricing, and thrown into a fiercely competitive and still ill-defined future.
"There's a thick veil of secrecy in the bond market," said Marilyn Cohen, president of Envision Capital Management, a fixed-income specialist in Los Angeles. "It's one of the last dinosaurs to fall."
By replacing old bonds with new through the electronic auction, Lancaster will save $1.1 million, plugging an immediate budget hole and allowing the city, the thrifty heart of Amish country, to avoid raising taxes next year. Lancaster's advisers say the savings come from the bigger market created by the Internet, which drew distant underwriters who had rarely vied for Pennsylvania school bonds.
"We think the impact of that is to lower their interest rates," said Mr. Verdelli, senior managing consultant at Public Financial Management, the adviser who arranged the bidding on a system run by a Pittsburgh-based creature of the Internet, MuniAuction.
Click-of-the-mouse bidding on new issues is a striking leap forward from past practice in the bond industry. Like most issuers, both municipal and corporate, Lancaster used to negotiate bond deals with a single underwriter; in many places, bidders must still show up in person to drop a written bid into the equivalent of a ballot box.
And the upheaval in the secondary markets, where dealers, brokers and investors trade bonds after they are issued, is bound to prove more profound. After all, some $350 billion of bonds and other debt securities are traded daily, 12 times the volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
Most stock trades are executed on exchange floors or through Nasdaq's electronic dealer network, and each trade's volume and price is immediately displayed to all. Not so with bonds, which change hands much as they have for most of the century, mainly through a patchwork of private channels. Bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange is trivial, confined mainly to small lots.
"If there was ever a market that needed liquidity and transparency, it's fixed income," said Douglas M. Atkin, president of Instinet. His firm, a unit of Reuters, operates the biggest private stock-trading service for institutions. And later this year, Instinet plans to start a dealer-to-dealer bond-trading service, initially for United States Treasuries.
 
Unheard Upheaval
While there are big changes under way in the bond business, they have attracted far less attention than the more advanced revolution in stocks, where instantaneously available prices have made possible a frenzy of speculative activity and driven even Merrill Lynch to announce a plan for cut-rate commissions.
But the impact could be just as far-reaching. Already, spreads -- the difference between the prices at which professionals buy bonds and the prices at which they sell them -- are beginning to narrow, eating into bond dealers' profits. So, naturally, the dealers are trying to hold off the electronic tide. And brokers, the middlemen between investors and dealers, worry about survival in a world where investors have new power.
Changes in how bonds trade are not always visible to ordinary investors, most of whom own bonds only through mutual funds. But ruptures in the system tend to echo loudly.
An example was the virtual paralysis of the market for any bonds other than Treasuries in the latter part of 1998, when foreign turmoil touched off a ferocious flight to quality. The Federal Reserve found itself obliged to engineer a rescue of a big hedge fund that had bet disastrously on historic relationships among various types of bonds. Surging interest rates shook stock markets.
But while prices of securities can move at the speed of light, market structures have been slow to change, and then only under duress, as when industrywide fixed commissions for stocks were abolished in 1975.
Back then, Congress charged the Securities and Exchange Commission with overseeing the creation of integrated markets for both stocks and bonds. The bond part of the mandate has largely been ignored.
But now the pace is picking up: Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the S.E.C., is pushing bond market openness. And this month, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed a bill that would direct the commission to adopt rules for collecting and publishing price, volume and other transaction data for corporate bonds, and to enforce the rules within a year. (The measure has no Senate counterpart yet.)
Initially, modernizing bond markets will benefit mainly institutional investors, but consumers stand to gain indirectly through their stakes in mutual funds, pensions and retirement accounts. Taxpayers will gain in places like Lancaster that exploit the new systems. And within a few years, retail customers are very likely to be in possession of basic information about bonds like transaction charges and meaningful market prices. Until now, ignorance has cost them more than $20 billion a year, by one estimate.
"The fixed-income investor is the odd-man out in the market," said Arthur F. Goat, a retiree in Short Hills, N.J. "You're flying blind."
Dominated by the giant dealers who benefit most from the status quo, the Bond Market Association, the industry's chief trade group, has lobbied hard to slow and restrict the modernization process. The industry has pledged to improve transparency in the corporate bond markets, but says it is concerned that the costs involved might outweigh the benefits by impeding trading activity and harming market liquidity.
But, prodded by regulators and some in Congress to fill the market's information vacuum, even the trade group sees the writing on the wall.
"Electronic trading systems are rapidly becoming essential tools in the portfolio and trading operations of both sell-side and buy-side participants in the United States fixed-income securities markets," the association's director of research, Andy Nybo, acknowledged in his survey of 1998 industry developments.
 
Buying Debt in the Dark
As a result of the market's fragmentation, even professional investors face serious disadvantages in trading corporate and municipal bonds. To get a market price, they must conduct an unwieldy and imprecise shopping expedition among a dozen or more dealers, or rely on what one dealer tells them -- or, for less active issues, fall back on what may be little more than a wild guess.
Individual investors, who hold only 5 percent of corporate but 30 percent of muni bonds, have even less clout.
In municipal bonds, for example, the best an individual investor can do is to view the prior day's prices for 1,300 or so issues that may have traded, out of 1.4 million outstanding, on a Web site run by the bond association (www.bondmarkets.com). Some of those -- there is no telling which -- are dealer-to-dealer prices unavailable to ordinary investors.
With comparison shopping so difficult, dealers can charge large markups, especially on lesser-quality bonds, and generally get the better of any bargain. Quoted prices can be all over the map. On Friday afternoon, for example, different dealers were offering Ford Motor Credit 5 3/4 percent notes due in February 2004 at anywhere from $95.472 (yielding 6.9 percent) to $96.034 (yielding 6.75 percent) per $100.
"Price competition is at the heart of the free-market system," said Representative Michael Oxley, an Ohio Republican who heads a House subcommittee that held a hearing on bond trading last September. "And you can't have true competition if people have a hard time figuring out exactly what they're paying."
That is a big reason the industry has dragged its feet: dealers' fear that the traditionally wide spreads in bond trading will shrink.
"The people who are living off the spreads, their profits are going to come down," said Frank D. Korth, a portfolio manager at the National City Investment Management Company in Cleveland.
 
Squeezing Intermediaries
Threatened, too, are the firms that advise issuers and underwrite bond issues. "The intermediaries are scared to death," said Myles Harrington, a founder of MuniAuction, the firm that owns the system used in the Lancaster auction. Last month, the company drew a $6 million investment from the Carlyle Group, a private Washington investment firm whose principals include former Treasury Secretary James Baker 3d and Frank Carlucci, a former Defense Secretary.
As with Merrill Lynch's belated decision to embrace on-line stock trading, bond dealers are being forced to weigh what they would lose in narrower spreads against the risk of losing business to upstarts and the possibility that trading volume would rise if investors found the market less treacherous.
An early effort to breach the wall was Capitalink, J. P. Morgan's 1989 venture into direct sales of corporate bonds to institutional investors, bypassing other financial institutions.
Traditional bond market players howled. "The competitive threat Capitalink poses to our industry cannot be overemphasized," a Merrill Lynch official, Richard Fuscone, wrote in a memo quoted in a 1996 paper by Robert J. Kauffman of the University of Minnesota and Arthur R. Kennedy 3d of Morgan. After Merrill bought an entire issue of Deere & Company notes at a dog-in-the-manger price to pre-empt its trading on Capitalink, Morgan gave up.
In the early 1990's, Larry E. Fondren, an entrepreneur who ran a sort of computer-dating service for insurance companies -- arranging joint ventures and advising on mergers and reinsurance -- tried his hand. He set up Intervest Financial Services, which allowed clients to trade anonymously with one another and with dealers, and tried to negotiate a deal to link it to computer terminals of Bloomberg L.P., then on 60,000 clients' desks.
Mr. Fondren struck a deal in 1995, but Bloomberg pulled the plug after six months, partly relented, and then cut Intervest off for good in 1998, said Mr. Fondren, who has filed a breach-of-contract suit.
In court papers, Mr. Fondren said Bloomberg told him it had acted at the insistence of bond dealers, because clients were getting too much price information.
A spokesman for Bloomberg, which is partly owned by Merrill, said that Intervest was dropped because of low trading activity and that the allegations were groundless.
Merrill itself has had a change of heart since it helped thwart Capitalink. "Ten years ago, we did not believe electronic distribution was in the best interests of clients or the industry," said Timothy Gilles, a Merrill spokesman. But the markets and technology have evolved, and Merrill now backs electronic trading, he said.
In any event, the concept is back with a vengeance. The Bond Market Association says there are now more than two dozen electronic systems for marketing or trading bonds. At the start of 1998, there were 11. "It's a brave new world out there," said Edwin McGuinn, president of Limitrader Securities, one dealer that has hung out a cybershingle.
Entrants in the electronic race include individual entrepreneurs, banks, securities dealers, bond brokers and information purveyors like Bloomberg and Reuters. Most focus on attracting institutional buyers of bonds, whose high volume they hope will make their systems viable.
Just last week, a consortium of seven giant financial-services companies announced a new trading system for dealers, called Brokertec.
So far, most of the electronic systems are bulletin boards for dealers to post offerings; final prices are set when trades are consummated by phone. In a few cases, buyers and sellers see prices on the screen at which they can count on executing a trade. Other systems bring dealers and institutions together for real-time trading or periodic order-matching sessions, with traders' anonymity a big selling point.
Then there are the new-issue auction systems like MuniAuction, which make possible innovations like bidding on selected maturities out of a series that formerly had to be bought in its entirety
Moreover, bidders see where their offers rank (though not their rivals' specific bids) and are free to raise their bids repeatedly, as some did in the Lancaster auction. In traditional auctions, bidders get just one shot.
Lancaster's electronic auction of new bonds is one of about 200 such municipal borrowings since Muni Auction's first deal in late 1997. As for corporations, many now routinely market commercial paper -- short-term i.o.u.'s -- directly to investors, bypassing broker-dealers, and there are systems being developed for selling longer-term corporate debt this way. The Government's Treasury Direct program allows investors with as little as $1,000 to bid for new bills, notes and bonds.
 
A Certain Inevitability
But while the old methods are crumbling, the process is likely to take several years -- and it may never make bonds as transparent as stocks.
Micah S. Green, executive vice president of the Bond Market Association, told a House panel in March that he supported the goals of the proposed legislation. He said, too, that his group would soon add to its Web site the previous day's dealer-to-dealer prices for 100 or so of the most active investment-grade corporate bonds. (The new data are due to make their debut this week.)
But he sought to persuade lawmakers that there were key differences in bond and stock markets. For instance, he said, most bonds do not trade actively: only 4 percent of about 400,000 corporate issues outstanding in 1996 traded even once that year. He also contended that too much transparency could increase volatility in thin markets.
"Revealing prices and trading volumes instantaneously could hurt market liquidity," Mr. Green said, by, say, making it obvious when someone was trying to unwind a large position piecemeal. He asked Congress to choose evolutionary change, led by the private sector, over Government-mandated change.
Whichever path is chosen, it is clear that the bond business is galloping toward an automated future with fewer intermediaries.
Until recently, "if you wanted to sell a block of $10 million in municipal bonds, you'd call up 20 brokers and ask them to give you a bid," said Peter J. Allegrini, managing director of Prudential Investments, who runs a portfolio of high-yield municipals. "Today, you plug your bonds into the Bloomberg and press a couple of buttons, and the whole process is down to 15 minutes."
In a few years, perhaps one-third of trades in Treasury debt will take place electronically, said F. James Claire, director of taxable fixed-income trading for a unit of First Union Bank in Charlotte, N.C.
But if Mr. Claire's attitudes reflect those of many bond traders, electronic trading will develop more slowly in markets for corporate and tax-exempt bonds, where trading is thinner.
There simply is no substitute in a decentralized market, he said, for communicating by voice with the other players. "You want to be able to talk to a guy and hear noise in the background; you need that color to hear what's going on," Mr. Claire said. "You're not going to get any color looking at the screen."
Moreover, he said, screen updates sometimes lag when trading action heats up, and electronic screens do not leave behind as solid a transaction record as do telephone calls, which are routinely recorded.
So, much of Mr. Levitt's lament about the least-liquid sectors of the bond market seems likely to linger. "The sad truth," he said, "is that investors in the corporate bond market do not enjoy the same access to information as a car buyer or a home buyer or, dare I say, a fruit buyer. And that's unacceptable."

Chart: "Behind From the Start"
When retail investors buy bonds directly, they pay high transaction costs, without the discount trading channels available for stocks. They also pay higher prices than institutions do for the same bonds, reducing their effective yield.
 
Example: Stocks vs. Bonds
$25,000 Revlon stock
870 shares at $28.75 bought on the New York Stock Exchange. The investor pays a commission on the trade.
 
Full-service broker:
Merrill Lynch: $421
 
Discount broker:
Quick & Reilly: $120
 
Internet trading:
E*Trade: $15
 
$25,000 Revlon bonds
25 bonds of $1,000 face value due Feb. 1, 2008, paying 858%, bought from dealer inventory. At the recently quoted price of 96.5, the investor pays $965 for each $1,000 of face value; the spread, or dealer's profit, is one point or $10.
 
Cost to investor: $250
 
Example: Individuals vs. Institutions
State of California noncallable general obligation bonds, 514%, due Oct. 1, 2009. A dealer recently offered $1.5 million in bonds at $104.85 for each $100 of face value, equivalent to a yield of 4.65%.
 
An institutional investor bidding for 200 bonds ($200,000 in face value) would typically get these results:
 
Yield: 4.70%
Price: $104.432 per $100 face value
 
A retail investor bidding for 25 bonds ($25,000 in face value) would typically get these results:
 
Yield: 4.50%
Price: $106.10 per $100 face value
 
Over all, the retail investor pays $417 more on a $25,000 investment.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
A Shoe on the Other Foot

BYLINE: By JIM SCHACHTER 

 BODY:
Dennis D. Dammerman, the longtime General Electric finance chief who recently became chief executive of the relentlessly profitable GE Capital Services unit, has a no-nonsense, tough-guy reputation.
But on Thursday in a talk at the Japan Society in Manhattan, he took pains to speak warmly about Japan, its economic reforms and its companies, in which GE Capital has invested about $14 billion lately. 
 When a Japanese reporter dared to ask, though, whether rising unemployment there was spurring nationalistic resentment toward companies like G.E. that are going on shopping sprees, it was the rougher Dammerman who responded.
"Hey, my Manhattan office is in 30 Rockefeller Plaza," he shot back, calling to mind the 1989 purchase of the building by the Mitsubishi Estate Company as a flush Japan collected trophy properties across America. "There was a little resentment here, too." ("Thirty Rock" returned to American hands in 1996.)
Mr. Dammerman's more measured response was that he did not expect an anti-American backlash among Japanese consumers. JIM SCHACHTER

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
George W. Bush Crams for the White House

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

 BODY:
When meeting with his policy experts, many of them alumni of his father's Presidency, George W. Bush is said to project an air of confidence if not entitlement. "I am going to be the next President," he declares, according to one adviser. "I need your help, not to become President, but to be a good President." By all accounts, the Texas Governor who studied at Yale and Harvard is not only running hard for the White House. He is also cramming for it like someone facing the ultimate final exam.
For now, the faculty of George Bush University is just getting to know its prized student. But one thing is already clear. Though there are many Bush veterans, they are of a different cast from those who advised his father: more conservative in foreign policy and more moderate domestically than Republican leaders in Congress, a fact that has begun to alarm many on the right. 
 The foreign policy team assembled by Governor Bush is headed by Condoleezza Rice, the departing provost of Stanford University and a specialist on the Soviet Union on President Bush's national security staff. In what almost seems like a generational revolt by the Governor, the team conspicuously lacks the main players surrounding President Bush, like former Secretaries of State James Baker and Lawrence Eagleburger, and Brent Scowcroft, the Bush national security aide.
Yet when you talk to the Governor's people about foreign policy, there is a tone of restoration that comes through, as if they aim to get back to the values of strength and firmness of the Republican White Houses of old. The Governor's foreign policy people say Mr. Bush will be more skeptical than his father toward the United Nations and other multinational organizations and more willing to embrace explicitly the idea of American global supremacy. He is said to favor a tougher stance toward rogue states like North Korea and Iraq, and to see China and Russia more as rivals than partners, another contrast with his father.
It is not, most Bush aides hasten to say, that the Governor is repudiating the teachings of his father. Rather, they say, times have changed and the glow of friendship and cooperation in the aftermath of the cold war is gone. But those looking for a generational grudge match might find it in Mr. Bush's particular disdain for Strobe Talbott, President Clinton's Deputy Secretary of State, who is the Administration's apostle of establishing a working relationship with Russia and Boris Yeltsin. "Strobe Talbott has been wrong for 30 years," an adviser quoted the young Mr. Bush as saying. "I knew him at Yale."
President Bush seemed to love nothing more than meeting with heads of state. Governor Bush has hardly met any, at least by himself. On domestic affairs, he is said to have strong views, and they are distinctly more moderate than the ones heard in Congress these days. Lawrence Lindsey, the former Federal Reserve Board member who is his chief economic adviser, and Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis reflect that attitude. On tax cuts, Mr. Lindsey talks of cutting the marginal rates, but emphasizes the importance of tax cuts for the lower end of the economic spectrum. Asked by The Weekly Standard whether he embraced the traditional conservative position of lowering or eliminating the capital gains tax, Mr. Lindsey said: "Maybe it's the populist in me, but capital should be taxed."
In Congress, the Republican leadership has almost nothing good to say about the role of government in public life. But at his inaugural speech as Governor last January, Mr. Bush said: "Government can't solve all our problems. Economic growth can't solve all our problems. In fact, we're now putting too much hope in economics, just as we once put too much hope in government." Mr. Bush favors more government spending for schools and, to help people get off welfare, for day care. Contrast that with the recent speech by Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, citing day care as a factor in the decline of American values.
The difference with Congress is so great that Mr. Bush had to reassure Republicans in Washington last week that he would not, as some fear, run against them in the election. Those words could be put to the test if Congress proceeds with punitive budget cuts in coming weeks. At the photo session Mr. Bush did not appear with the two Texans most associated with hard-line conservatism, Mr. DeLay and Dick Armey, the House majority leader.
As Mr. Bush moves to flesh out what he means by "compassionate conservatism," a phrase that both the left and the right find condescending, his views may rankle people in some unlikely quarters -- the believers in global interdependence who surrounded his father and the believers in less government at all costs who now dominate the party in Congress. It could turn out to be a much more interesting campaign than even the Republicans have bargained for.
