HEADLINE: CLINTON PLANNING TO CUT LONG-TERM COST OF MEDICARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
President Clinton will try to reconcile two seemingly contradictory goals next week when he unveils a plan to cut the long-term cost of Medicare while expanding the program to cover prescription drugs, Administration officials said today.
His plan would make structural changes in Medicare to encourage competition and efficiency in the care of the elderly and the disabled. It would also require major new infusions of cash from the Federal Treasury, said officials who are putting final details of the plan in place. 
 The officials said Mr. Clinton would insist that the Government offer drug coverage to all 39 million Medicare beneficiaries. Drug coverage should be "universal, voluntary and heavily subsidized," a White House official said.
By contrast, Republicans and some Democrats in Congress want to start gradually, by covering medicines for the lower-income beneficiaries who most need assistance.
Regardless of what happens to his proposal, Mr. Clinton will reshape the debate simply by demanding that coverage of prescription drugs be made available to all Americans over the age of 64 and to those of any age who are severely disabled.
"Saying that the benefit has to be universal is a major contribution to the debate," said Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons.
Though often lost in the hubbub over new benefits, the original reason for trying to redesign Medicare was to avert a financial crisis. Administration officials said the President's plan would keep Medicare solvent in these ways:
*The Federal Government would steer Medicare patients to certain hospitals that promise to give the Government a deep discount on complicated, expensive procedures like heart bypass surgery and hip replacement operations. Many studies have found a higher quality of care at hospitals that perform a large number of such procedures.
*Medicare would use competitive bidding to buy a wide range of goods and services, including hospital beds, wheelchairs and other medical equipment. The Government would also try to negotiate prices far below those set in existing fee schedules.
*Medicare would get a huge infusion of cash from the Federal Treasury: $700 billion, representing about 15 percent of Federal budget surpluses anticipated over the next 15 years.
A remarkable transformation seems to have occurred in the last year. The question now is not whether Medicare should cover prescription drugs, but how.
Disagreements over that question, including the sheer complexity of designing a benefit affordable to both elderly people and to the Treasury, could easily stymie efforts to provide drug coverage in this Congress. But the issue will become more urgent as 76 million baby boomers qualify for Medicare over the next three decades.
Chris Jennings, the President's health policy coordinator, said: "The desired outcome is to cover prescription drugs for everybody. That's the approach we're contemplating. Large numbers of middle- and upper-income Medicare beneficiaries have little or no drug coverage, but high out-of-pocket drug costs. If you target the solution to low-income people, you're not taking care of the problem at all.
"Beneficiaries have paid for Medicare throughout their working careers," Mr. Jennings said. "If you say that certain people on Medicare can have drug coverage and others don't, you will undermine the broad support that exists for the program."
Mr. Clinton will depict drug coverage as one element in a comprehensive plan to shore up Medicare, White House officials said. But health policy experts and politicians doubt that Medicare can be "fixed" by the passage of one bill, however comprehensive. In the next two decades, they predict, Congress will continually tinker with the program, searching for ways to enhance benefits while trimming payments to hospitals, doctors and other health care providers.
Almost every type of health care provider is pleading with Congress to restore Medicare money cut just two years ago by the Balanced Budget Act. Thus, beneficiaries, eager for drug coverage, and health care providers have competing claims to the same pot of money.
Administration officials said they were ready to portray the coming debate over Medicare as a struggle between needy beneficiaries and a greedy health care industry. So far, they said, the 1997 cuts appear to have done more harm to the financial condition of the industry than to the health of beneficiaries.
Nursing homes, home care agencies and health maintenance organizations have been complaining bitterly about the cuts. But Mr. Corry of the A.A.R.P. said, "There has not been a spontaneous outcry among beneficiaries, or an upsurge in complaints about denial of access to home care, nursing homes or hospitals."
Mr. Clinton describes affordable prescription drugs as "the greatest growing need of seniors." And he notes that drugs have become an integral, indispensable part of modern medical care.
Elderly people use one-third of all prescription drugs sold in the United States. On average, each Medicare beneficiary has more than 18 prescriptions filled each year.
But the White House says that 15.5 million Medicare beneficiaries have no insurance for prescription drugs, and 6 million of those beneficiaries have incomes more than twice the official poverty level. The poverty level this year is $8,240 for an individual and $11,060 for a couple.
Virtually every member of Congress has heard pleas from constituents unable to afford medicines they need. "The public in America is getting gouged," said Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada. "That's what our constituents tell us."
But Congress is cautious, and the reason can be summarized in one word: cost.
From 1992 to 1997, national spending on prescription drugs grew by an average of 11 percent a year, which is more than double the 5 percent rate for health care spending over all. The increase reflects the development of new, more expensive, more effective drug therapies and greater use of prescription drugs, driven in part by more aggressive marketing aimed directly at consumers.
Insurers and health maintenance organizations report that drugs are their fastest-growing cost.
Medicaid, the Federal-state program for poor families, does cover prescription drugs, and even though it gets substantial discounts from manufacturers, Medicaid now spends more on drugs than on doctors' services.
Kevin W. Concannon, the Commissioner of Human Services in Maine, said the state's Medicaid program spent $140 million a year on prescription drugs, compared with $40 million on doctors' services.
Stephen J. deMontmollin, vice president of Avmed Health Plan, a large nonprofit H.M.O. in Florida, said drug spending for his members rose 33 percent last year, to $115 million.
At a Congressional hearing this week, Republican Senators like William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and John H. Chafee of Rhode Island expressed support for Medicare coverage of drugs, but said it should be provided first to the neediest beneficiaries. Moderate Democratic Senators like John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Max Baucus of Montana agreed.
Mr. Grassley, the chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, expressed the view of the Republican majority. He cautioned against "any rich new benefit" and said, "A targeted approach, focusing on low-income seniors, is the best solution."
Senator Breaux was chairman of a 17-member commission that was supposed to advise Congress and the President on the future of Medicare. The panel did not agree on much, but did provide authoritative bipartisan backing for the view that Medicare is antiquated because it does not cover prescription drugs.
Mr. Breaux proposed drug coverage for 3 million low-income beneficiaries, and he said it would cost the Government $60 billion over 10 years. The White House rejected the proposal as "inadequate and inefficient."
Liberal Democrats, led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representatives Henry A. Waxman and Pete Stark of California, agree with President Clinton that drug coverage should be available to all beneficiaries.
Medicare beneficiaries now pay a premium of $45.50 a month. Under current law, with no change in benefits, the monthly premium is expected to double in a decade, to $101 in 2009. Any premium for prescription drug coverage would be added to that.
John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, said the poorest people would not have to pay the full premium for drug coverage under Mr. Clinton's plan. "Some people will get help with the premium at the lower end of the scale," he said.
Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a consumer group, said, "It makes sense for seniors to pay a significant part of the cost through a premium." But, he said, it is "absolutely essential" for the Government to pay the premiums for Medicare beneficiaries with incomes as much as 35 percent above the poverty level.
"Administration officials told me they were willing to pay the full premium on the drug benefit for people with incomes up to 120 percent of the poverty level," Mr. Pollack said. "I urged them to do better than that, to go to 135 percent."
Low-income beneficiaries are already eligible for Federal assistance in paying their basic Medicare premiums. But in studies going back to 1991, Mr. Pollack has repeatedly documented the failure of the Federal Government and the states to locate the people eligible for such subsidies.
Medicare officials have told the White House that if Medicare begins to cover prescription drugs, many more low-income people would have an incentive to step forward and claim the Federal subsidies to which they are entitled.

HEADLINE: A Drought Emergency Is Declared In Arizona

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, June 26

 BODY:
With grazing lands parched after Arizona's third-driest winter in a century, Gov. Jane Dee Hull has declared a statewide drought emergency so that struggling ranchers can qualify for tax breaks.
A lack of snow through the winter and too little rain since have stunted grazing grass and dried up ponds and other surface water sources, forcing many ranchers to haul feed and water to their livestock or take the animals to market early. 
 In New Mexico, which provides 60 percent of the nation's base chili products, including powdered chili and paprika, chili stands in some fields are so sparse that farmers are considering plowing them under.
Economists are still weighing the financial impact of a dismal growing season, but they estimate losses for chili farmers could reach $30 million, half the value of last year's crop.
Similar problems are facing farmers in the East. Portions of the South, Midwest and Northeast are being slowly strangled by a spotty, but tenacious, drought that has been spreading for several months.
In New England, crops are withering in the fields or simply failing to sprout, while firefighters keep an eye out for brush fires and forest fires. The Southeast is suffering its second-driest spring in a century.
Mrs. Hull's declaration, issued Wednesday, will help ranchers qualify for reduced taxes on livestock sales forced by the drought.
Heavy summer rains would be a better solution, said Jeff Menges, whose family has ranches near Clifton and Safford in southeastern Arizona.
"We need the relief right now," said Mr. Menges, whose family has already sold 15 percent of its herd. "We didn't get any growth in the spring and winter because it is just too dry. We're hoping that the summer monsoon will just bail us out."
Arizona's winter precipitation this year was the third-lowest since 1895, the Eastern Arizona Counties Organization said.

HEADLINE: From High School to Real World;
For Graduates Skipping College, the Future is Now

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
For most high school seniors, the months leading up to graduation mean decisions about where to go to college. But for Johana Santos, Anthony Rose, Angel Ramos, Michael Loza and Coreen Reid, all seniors at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx, the decisions they had to make were about what to do instead.
As their high school days waned, the five seniors found themselves among a distinct minority of New York City students -- those finishing high school but, for reasons of money or temperament or ability, not going on to college. 
 Each year, according to Board of Education surveys, fewer than 20 percent of graduating seniors say they do not plan to go on to college in the fall, although the board keeps no data on how many students actually enroll.
For Ms. Santos, 17, and Mr. Rose, 18, both dedicated members of the Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps and both unable to afford college, the choice was simple: for her the Air Force, for him the Army.
For Mr. Loza, 18, the family cook and a student of culinary arts, the choice was to find a way to the French Culinary Institute, or find a job on a cruise ship or in a restaurant.
For Ms. Reid, 19, who has been an intern for two years at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx, it was to seek vocational training to become a nurse's aide.
For Mr. Ramos, 18, the future stretches before him like an empty essay page.
"I've got a lot of thinking to do this summer," he said several weeks ago.
With at least a stab at college now an American rite of passage, the economic and psychological pressures on students like those at Evander Childs seem to have only increased. For such graduates, finishing high school can be a little like letting go of one trapeze bar before the next one is in sight: scary, unstructured and rarely exhilarating.
"It's finally hit me," Mr. Loza said. "I'm getting out of here and I'm not going to have this place to protect me."
Their decisions not to pursue college can be traced to a mix of shared circumstances and individual concerns. Some of the students lacked confidence or had a mind or temperament unsuited to academic pursuits -- or much better suited to something else. For others, being the first member of their generation in their family to graduate from high school was accomplishment enough.
And for all of them, money was a driving factor: either as a bar to higher education, or as an impetus to start working now to secure their own income.
Mr. Ramos, whose mother is a nurse's aide and whose father is dead, said he had wanted to go to college and study computer engineering, but he did not apply because he was unsure that he would pass his Regents Competency Tests. He is the only one of his friends to successfully complete high school, but he still feels as if the train is leaving the station without him.
He decided not to go to Friday's graduation ceremony anyway, he said. But if he were going to college, he said, toughness and sadness fighting for mastery of his thin face, "I would go on a long cruise or something. I'd be thinking different."
Mr. Rose, a lanky, serious youth whose father is a carpenter and whose mother does not work, said he did not want to have to work and study at the same time. After boot camp, he will work for the Army as an operating room specialist in Oklahoma. Eventually, he hopes to go to college and study computer engineering.
Ms. Reid, whose mother, a widow, is a home care aide, said she had hoped that the military would pay her way to college, but she did not pass the test for the Army.
Mr. Loza, the son of a nurse and a carpenter, said that for now, he wanted to do something he enjoyed, like cooking. He said he would go to college and study psychology "later in life, when I'm planted with a car and family."
Ms. Santos is a sparkling, confident 17-year-old. Her mother cares for six foster children; her father, with whom she does not live, owns delicatessens and convenience stores. She said financial obstacles made college impossible right now.
Yet for young adults without a college degree, career options continue to shrink. In New York City, the unemployment rate for those with only a high school diploma is double that for those with a college degree. Many jobs in the city, like those on the police force, now require some college education. And the number of other jobs, like those in manufacturing, have dwindled. High school graduates are increasingly consigned to service, sales or administrative jobs that may offer little chance of upward mobility. That is particularly true in the Bronx, where unemployment is nearly double the city average and there is fierce competition for low-skilled jobs.
Unsurprisingly, those jobs tend to pay far less than those that workers with even some college education can fill. A New York City high school graduate's mean weekly earnings in 1997 were $486, compared with $808 for a college graduate, according to the City Housing Authority.
But there still are acceptable jobs for those without a college education, including in traditional trades like plumbing and in several branches of the Civil Service, like the Fire Department.
And with the right training, said Steven Feldman, the director of the Board of Education's School to Career office, some students can go straight from high school into highly specialized, well-paying jobs -- $45,000 per year to make computer networks run, for example.
There are 20 vocational high schools in New York City, and many more that offer occupational training of all sorts -- travel and tourism, agriculture, dental assistant work, and so on. The schools are increasingly trying to link with industry, so that graduates will not only meet industry standards but also be able to move from school straight into work. The models are programs like Project Pathways, through which about 200 high school graduates become construction union apprentices each year.
To different degrees, the Evander Childs graduates have benefited from programs intended to prepare them for the workaday world. Mr. Loza, for example, has been taking classes in the culinary arts program at the School of Cooperative Technical Education in Manhattan for a year and a half.
But Evander Childs's principal, Richard Urovsky, said he did not believe that the schools were doing enough to prepare students not headed to college.
He is among many principals and guidance counselors who are questioning how the new graduation standards being phased in statewide will affect the students uninterested in college or unable to pursue it. Now that each student has to pass five Regents exams, he said, everyone will be on a college track.
"What if someone doesn't want to go to college? Does it prepare him for a job?" he asked of the standards.
Critics of the new standards say students unlikely to go on to college may not only have the hardest time meeting the new requirements and obtaining a high school diploma, but also may have less time for vocational training.
"The Board of Education is making a major error in putting everyone into a 'one size fits all' category -- that's not the way the world works," said Robert Yurasits, the retiring principal of the School of Cooperative Technical Education, where about 800 high school students undertake part-time study in trades like welding, horticulture and air-conditioner repair.
Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Board of Education, said board members hoped that the new standards would leave students better prepared for college and therefore more would choose to go.
And Mr. Feldman said students who were not planning on going to college needed the same basic skills as those who were.
Mr. Ramos seemed to agree that the current standards have not adequately prepared him, even in basic skills. "I want to get my diploma so I can pay a tutor to teach me to read," he said.
The ambitions of the Evander Childs graduates are shaped partly by what they know -- what their parents and siblings have accomplished, or not accomplished -- and partly by what they do not know: material wealth and luxury.
Ms. Santos wants to be a lawyer, a Senator and the first female Secretary of the Air Force.
Mr. Loza said he wanted to open a restaurant in downtown Manhattan, "something nice, classy." He wants to be able to buy a $50,000 Lexus.
Ms. Reid is one of eight children, almost all of whom went to work early to help support the family. Her 13-year-old sister is already working as a day care aide.
Beyond getting to college one day and becoming a nurse, her dreams are simple: "I want to move into a three-family house," she said, with room for parties for her big family. "I want a basement you could turn into a playroom."
Mr. Rose's goal, he said, is to own a computer business "like Bill Gates." But, he was quick to add, "I don't want to be too rich and not associate with poor people."
Mr. Ramos also thinks about starting a business, most recently a pizza parlor. "I could forget about college if I had enough money to open a business," he said. "I could live off the profits."
It is not an unrealistic goal -- in 1996, 40 percent of small-business owners had only a high school diploma, according to Federal statistics. But it is not an easy goal either, particularly in the economically insular world of the Bronx.
More than any of the other graduates, perhaps, Mr. Ramos reflects that isolation. He is clearly bright, yet beyond a supportive guidance counselor, Isabel Scherz, he has few guides to life beyond school.
His friends, he said, have all dropped out of school and are hanging out on the streets. He cannot talk to his mother, he said, because "when I go to school she's sleeping, when I come home she's at work."
"I'm by myself," he said. "I'm by myself."
Of the five, only Mr. Rose and Ms. Santos attended Friday's graduation ceremonies.
At the ceremonies, Ms. Santos proudly posted the flag on the high school stage. For her, things did not work out as she had planned -- they worked out better. Just as she was about to send in her form committing herself to the Air Force, she got word that she had won a scholarship to Norwich University, a military academy in Vermont.
Things did not work out exactly as planned for Mr. Ramos, either. He failed one class, government. His guidance counselor said that was no problem -- he would just take summer school.
But then he failed to show up last week for the two Regents Competency Tests that he still had to pass. Mrs. Scherz wondered whether he was trying to sabotage himself, she said, so that he could stay in school longer and postpone figuring out his future -- a common phenomenon among graduating seniors who have no plans.
Asked whether that was the case, Mr. Ramos said, "In a way, yeah," and conceded that he was scared because he did not know what to do after high school.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Bush Is on Easy Street Early in His Campaign

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 26

 BODY:
Two weeks have now passed since Gov. George W. Bush first hit the campaign trail. And his poll numbers just keep getting better, the crowds keep on coming, and the money keeps on rolling in.
It cannot go on this way forever for the front-runner for the Republican nomination for President in 2000, or so conventional wisdom holds. But for "W," the trail moniker the Governor of Texas has picked up, it has been nothing but smooth sailing so far in these first two weeks of his official candidacy, as he has traveled to nine states, from the Midwest to New England to here in Florida, to pitch his campaign message of "compassionate conservatism." 
 "I'm some kind of fired up!" Mr. Bush blurted on Friday at a fund-raiser here on his first campaign stop in Florida, where his younger brother, Jeb Bush, is the Governor. In most of the polls conducted after his first 10 days on the road, the Texas Governor continues to lead Vice President Al Gore by close to 15 percentage points and has increased his lead over his nearest Republican rival, Elizabeth Dole, to a formidable 50 points.
In New Hampshire, polls indicate he now has more support among Republican voters than all 11 of his primary rivals have, taken together. His opponents have been taking pot shots at him, calling his "compassionate conservatism" a fuzzy, ill-defined notion that tries to be too many things to too many people. But he continues to pitch it, as he did here, telling a crowd of 500 or so supporters in Miami:
"I have a conservative mind and a compassionate heart. It is conservative to cut tax rates and compassionate to help families still left struggling. It is conservative to set high education standards and hold kids to them and it is compassionate to see that not one kid gets left behind. It is conservative to expect people on welfare to find work but compassionate to encourage charity and help those who really can't make it."
To Jeffrey Manchester, a Miami business management consultant who contributed $1,000 to hear the Governor and pick at finger food, that approach bespoke Republican moderation as much as anything and had "just the right balance."
"Everybody says that education is just about the most important issue facing this country today and it pleases me no end that the Governor touched on that at the very start and then kept returning to it," Mr. Manchester said. "I liked what I heard. I have no problem with being conservative and compassionate at the same time."
The Governor had finished speaking and was working the crowd, slapping backs, embracing and being embraced, now winking, now posing for a souvenir picture, now whispering earnestly in an ear. He had been introduced by his brother, Jeb, and the two of them had mugged a bit at the podium about the family thing, the political dynasty thing, as in Kennedys and Roosevelts, to the delight of the upturned faces in the crowd.
Would George W. get Mr. Manchester's vote? "Let's see how he does further down the road," Mr. Manchester said. "Don't they all run into some challenging difficulty sooner or later? I'll be watching."
Celinda Lake, one of the most respected Democratic pollsters, said after running still another Bush survey that she was "startled" at how strongly Mr. Bush was suddenly running among women and Hispanic voters, normally Democratic-leaning constituencies.
Impressive, too, is the number of Republican leaders who have now climbed aboard the Bush bandwagon, many of them over the last two weeks. He now has more than half of the party's Governors, Senators and members of the House of Representatives.
And then there is the money thing.
Mr. Bush is so far ahead in fund-raising -- he expects to top the $20 million mark by the end of this month and double that by primary season next spring -- that he may forgo accepting Federal matching funds and the spending limits that come attached.
In one day, on his sweep through Florida on Friday, in which he touched down at Fort Myers, Tampa, Fort Lauderdale and Miami, he collected $2.5 million, campaign aides said. That is more money than some of his rivals have collected in a full year of fund-raising. In fact, Randy Enwright, a Republican consultant who once was executive director of the Florida Republican Party, predicted that before Election 2000 is over, Mr. Bush will have raised more money in Florida than all his rivals will combined.
"He'll take some of Al Gore's money, too," Mr. Enwright said, suggesting that potential Gore donors might turn instead to Mr. Bush.
The Governor's campaign pitch has now settled into a predictable format and rhythm, as usually happens with candidates. He offers standard hot-button lines, well-tested jokes and themes centered for the most part on tax cuts, better schools, a stronger military, personal responsibility and stronger families and communities.
But the themes are only broadly sketched. He promises details later, once the themes are set, a promise that does not satisfy his critics, who accuse him of on-the-one-hand/on-the-other-hand waffling. What the Bush stump speech does not include are hard-edged, head-on attacks on Mr. Gore, President Clinton and Republican rivals. And sensitive and divisive issues like abortion and affirmative action are relegated to the background, though Mr. Bush says he is opposed to both, generally.
Among his top priorities, Mr. Bush says, are tax cuts and an increase in military spending. The cuts, he argues, would spur the economy to even greater heights. The extra military spending is needed, he says, because of the spread of international terrorism and because more and more countries are developing missile capabilities. He does not touch much on the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal. But when he does, by indirection, saying he would never disgrace the dignity of the Oval Office, he draws his biggest applause. One of his biggest laughs comes when he takes a sideswipe at Mr. Gore for claiming to have helped invent the Internet.
"Al Gore no more invented our current prosperity than I invented the Internet," Mr. Bush says.
As for his own gaffes out on the trail, he has thus far committed only a few of the kind that reporters and opponents pounce on early in a campaign as indications that a candidate has a lot to learn or, worst of all, may not be up to the job.
There was that moment in the first day or so on the road when he committed what is generally classified a political no-no. He declared flatly that he would win the first big contest of Election 2000, the straw poll that Iowa's Republican Party has scheduled for Aug. 14.
Having set the bar, he now must clear it.
Then there was that interview in which he referred to the people of Timor as "Timoreans" -- they are Timorese -- and that remark in Richmond in which he confused Slovakia and Slovenia.
Hardly fatal stuff. Yet it forced him to confess that "this is a big world and I've got a lot to learn."
"But should I be fortunate to be elected," he quickly added, "I'll be ready. I'll be ready to assume the office."

HEADLINE: Bob Grant or Senate? Talk-Show Host Ponders as Whitman Squirms

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
As one of talk radio's original angry white males, Bob Grant of WOR-AM has enjoyed considerable notoriety and won high ratings by making inflammatory comments about the people who upset him. They tend to be poor, politically liberal or black.
In recent months, however, Mr. Grant has been tormenting someone on the other end of the political and economic spectrums: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, a virtual paragon of establishment affluence and Republican moderation. 
 Mr. Grant has feuded with the Governor since 1994, when she chastised him for making racially offensive comments. Now he is flirting with a run as an independent candidate next year for the United States Senate seat that Governor Whitman is seeking.
Many political analysts discount Mr. Grant's very public ruminations as a stunt to boost ratings and make Mrs. Whitman squirm. But because Mrs. Whitman has never won more than 49 percent of the vote in any statewide election, it is widely acknowledged that an independent candidacy by a well-known conservative like Mr. Grant, who lives in Monmouth County, N.J., could hurt the Governor in a close race.
Mrs. Whitman herself conceded that point earlier this month, when she said she feared Mr. Grant would draw crucial conservative votes from her. The tone of the Governor's statement's was generally conciliatory, but she did utter the R-word -- race -- to describe what she said was one of the few issues on which she and Mr. Grant disagreed.
At WOR's studios in Manhattan, the Governor's unexpected comments about race sent a buzz through the halls, and as technicians scurried to edit a tape of them in time for that afternoon's show, Mr. Grant appeared triumphant.
"Get the band ready," Mr. Grant said. "John Philip Sousa."
David Bernstein, the program director, clapped his hands and exclaimed:
"You're gonna get a lot of mileage out of this."
While verbal jousting with Governor Whitman does make good radio drama, Mr. Grant insists that his possible candidacy is actually a matter of patriotic duty. After nearly 30 years as the self-appointed voice of the Little Guy, Mr. Grant, 70, says the Republic desperately needs a populist antidote to what he calls professional office-seekers who he says control American government.
And Mr. Grant, a man who earns a handsome salary but still brings coffee to work each day in a Thermos, says he is just the man to remind Capitol Hill about the concerns of his neighbors and listeners who pay mortgages in Manalapan and get stranded in traffic outside the Holland Tunnel.
If elected, Mr. Grant said, he would try to replace the income tax system with a national sales tax. He would tighten immigration laws, slash welfare and reduce what he describes as the labyrinth of intrusive government regulations.
Mr. Grant also insists he will contribute to the nation's political discourse by talking plainly and honestly about race, an ambitious claim given the furor he has ignited when discussing racial issues and black public figures in the past.
Mr. Grant was fired by WABC in 1996 for making disparaging remarks about Ron Brown, the Commerce Secretary who died in a plane crash. At various points in his career he has called Haitian refugees "unwashed scum" and black South Africans "screaming savages," referred to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with an unprintable slur, and labeled Mayor David N. Dinkins "a men's room attendant."
Mr. Grant now says he regrets his reference to Dr. King, but has no apologies for his other statements. He points to the furor they inspired as evidence of how, he says, the media and left-wing special interest groups have tried to stifle his speech.
His public battle with Governor Whitman began in 1994, when she said she was offended by Mr. Grant's racial comments. The Governor then appeared on his show, chastised Mr. Grant and vowed that she would never return.
Now that race is again New Jersey's most loaded issue, with the Governor having been criticized for failing to respond quickly enough to complaints of racial bias by the state police, Mr. Grant says he is eager to show voters how Mrs. Whitman has repeatedly pandered to minority leaders.
"I was one of her biggest supporters, but she betrayed me back then because she was caving to the black ministers," Mr. Grant said. "She is still caving in to them today, and I think the voters are going to make her pay for that."
For all Mr. Grant's zeal about the issues however, he still seems uncertain about embracing the rigors of a campaign, or stepping away from the microphone after nearly 30 years on the air.
On the day Governor Whitman made her comments about Mr. Grant, for instance, he said surprisingly little to capitalize on a potent political opportunity. The program, broadcast during afternoon drive time, started with a brass band's rendition of "Hail to the Chief" and an emcee introducing "the next Senator from the great state of New Jersey, Bob Grant." Next came sound bites from Governor Whitman.
When the red light flashed and Mr. Grant went on the air, he mused about the Governor's comments briefly. Within five minutes though, he was warning listeners that Democrats in Congress "aren't interested in gun control, they're interested in gun con-FIS-CATION!"
In the WOR control room, the show's producer, Roy Fredriks, was baffled by the abrupt change of topics.
"What's he beating up on Clinton for?" Mr. Fredriks asked the engineer. "We can get a whole show out of Whitman."
Mr. Grant's callers were not as easily distracted from the Senate race.
Cary from the Bronx said he thought it was high time someone like Mr. Grant went to Washington to fight for the common man. Steve in the Car called on his cellular phone to warn Mr. Grant that the Governor would relentlessly try to portray him as a bigot if he continued his campaign.
"I would hope that your people are going to combat that," Cary said, "by showing that you've called so many people savages over the years."
Mr. Grant seemed buoyed by his listeners' loyalty.
"If they do attack me," he said of his potential opponents, "it will insure my victory because people will rally to my side," Mr. Grant said.
Off the air, where Mr. Grant's demeanor is far more genial than his on-air persona, he said he was inspired to run by the unlikely victory of Jesse Ventura, the professional wrestler who last year was elected Governor of Minnesota. Mr. Grant also dismisses suggestions that his candidacy is a publicity stunt designed to reverse a slight drop in his ratings in recent years.
"If you look at what happened in Minnesota, I only need 35 to 37 percent of the vote to win," he said. "That's a real possibility."
Under Federal rules, Mr. Grant would have to either give up his show or provide his opponents equal time on the air if he officially declares his candidacy. Until he does, such bold predictions will do little to sway people who suspect that Mr. Grant is simply enjoying the chance to cause grief for Governor Whitman.
"If I were someone else, I'd probably think that, too," he said. "But this has nothing to do with Christie Whitman. At my age, this is probably my last chance to do something like this. So if I'm ever going to make a difference, now is the time."

HEADLINE: First Lady in a Messy Fight On the Eve of Her Campaign

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Since the collapse of her health care project in 1994, Hillary Rodham Clinton has seemed to retreat from the gladiator pit of high-profile policy issues, devoting herself instead to less visible topics like foster care and adoption.
But for more than a year, Mrs. Clinton has been engaged behind the scenes on a legislative issue -- consumer bankruptcy -- that could prove politically tricky for other Democrats and for her own political ambitions. 
 The high-powered banking and credit card industries, concentrated in New York, are concerned that too many people with money are filing for bankruptcy as a financial planning tool, and the industries are aggressively pushing legislation to make it harder for consumers to use bankruptcy to walk away from their debts.
But Mrs. Clinton has made it clear that she thinks the legislation, which the credit industry essentially wrote, is unfair to women and children, and she has been just as aggressively pushing to amend it. The banking and credit card industries are generous campaign contributors and could favor her competitors in a run for the Senate in New York.
What is more, this is one of the few causes Mrs. Clinton has taken up that her own party is divided over. Democratic support for the legislation is strong enough that the House has already passed it by a veto-proof margin, last month. And the Senate is poised to do the same when the matter comes up later this summer. As one Administration official said, "For many Democrats, this is a free, pro-business vote."
Mrs. Clinton was drawn to the issue through her decades-long interest in matters affecting women and children. Though she supports an overhaul of the bankruptcy system and says that those who can repay their debts should, she says the credit industry should be held equally accountable for making credit too easily available to people who cannot pay their bills.
She also views the legislation as making it harder for women to receive alimony and child support if their former husbands file for bankruptcy, say members of Congress, advisers to Mrs. Clinton and policy experts who have followed the issue. While current law forces debtors to make a priority of claims for alimony and child support, critics of the proposed legislation say it would give equal status to credit card companies and other lenders seeking to recoup money from a limited pool. This could put a single mother in competition with, say, a professional collection agency working for a big bank or credit card company to retrieve money from a bankrupt former husband.
Single women now constitute the largest group of people who file for bankruptcy, making up 39 percent of the nation's annual 1.4 million filings, according to a recent Harvard study. Single men make up 28 percent and married couples 33 percent.
"There is a big stake in this for women and children," said Joan Entmacher, vice president of the National Women's Law Center in Washington. "It was a really critical role that Mrs. Clinton played in having the White House insist that the final bill had to protect those populations."
Some Democrats who support the legislation, however, have played down the effect on women and dismiss it as not significant enough to derail the legislation.
Mrs. Clinton immersed herself in the topic last year, before she considered running for the seat of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, even before Senator Moynihan announced that he was retiring. (She is expected to begin her campaign shortly after July 4 with a 10-day announcement tour across upstate New York.) Her involvement was remarkable for any first lady but particularly for one who had been so seared by the public when she ventured into the policy-making arena on health care.
"She has essentially been functioning as a senior adviser to the President," said Carl Sferrazza Anthony, author of several books on first ladies. He said such a role could be tricky during her Senate campaign because her involvement in various issues will bolster her credibility as someone who cares about public policy and legislation, and yet she needs to steer clear of implications that she has been operating as an unelected co-President.
In the spring of 1998, Mrs. Clinton sought a private tutorial in bankruptcy law from a Harvard law professor, Elizabeth Warren, who has strongly opposed the legislation. Ms. Warren said she met with Mrs. Clinton alone for more than half an hour, with Mrs. Clinton "cross-examining" her about how bankruptcy works and the effects of the bill.
Mrs. Clinton directed her staff to delve into the details and held numerous policy discussions. She devoted two of her weekly newspaper columns to the issue. She wrote dozens of personal notes to lawmakers last year as the bills made their tortuous way through the Congressional process. And she, along with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, played what the bill's opponents say was a decisive role in helping to kill the legislation last year.
Representative Jerrold Nadler, a New York Democrat and strong critic of the legislation, said that he called the White House last October to alert Mrs. Clinton that Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, was trying to slip the bankruptcy legislation into the final omnibus spending bill, a move that would have made it virtually impossible for President Clinton to veto.
"We heard that Lott asked the White House for minimally acceptable language, and we heard that some in the White House were trying to work out such language," Mr. Nadler said. "I called Mrs. Clinton to say, 'Stick to your guns.' That's where she was instrumental. She weighed in, and suddenly we were hearing a changed tune." The bill died.
This year, as the legislation re-emerged, Mrs. Clinton has kept her vigil. She spoke out last month at the White House on what she called abusive and predatory practices by credit card companies, which make four billion unsolicited offers of credit cards every year that critics say are aimed at those least likely to pay their bills on time -- elderly women, unemployed college students, people without health insurance and those already in debt. And she received a briefing on the bankruptcy bill before she left earlier this month with President Clinton for Europe.
"She has been the principal at the White House who cared most about the fate of the details of the bill," said one Administration official.
Mrs. Clinton's involvement in the bankruptcy issue has been unusual in part because her own party is split over what to do about it. The House passed its version with a veto-proof majority even as advisers to the President recommended he veto it.
The Senate version is also expected to win some support from Democrats, who are negotiating with Republicans over aspects such as means testing and requirements for credit card companies to disclose to consumers how much they will owe if they do not pay their bills in full. The White House is waiting to see what the final Senate bill looks like.
Administration officials say that so far the Senate has not adequately addressed the concerns of Mrs. Clinton, who wants both the priority for women and children, and greater accountability by creditors, but they are circumspect about how far the White House will go in pressing for changes, especially if many Democratic senators are satisfied.
"She's very practical," said an official close to Mrs. Clinton. "She wants to improve the bill. She doesn't want to be obstructionist."
Another complicating factor is this: some of the Democrats sympathetic to the Republican proposals that Mrs. Clinton opposes are also major fund-raisers for their party, and the banking and credit interests are prime sources of big campaign contributions.
In the last election cycle, the credit industry, including credit card companies, banks and retailers, gave more than $4.5 million in campaign contributions, according to the Center for Responsive Politics.
"It was a combination of aggressive industry lobbying, by retailers as well as creditors, and they spent a great deal of money," said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America.
He added: "Some Democrats in the House thought this was a free vote because they didn't think the Senate would approve such a draconian piece of legislation or it would be vetoed by the Administration."
William P. Binzel, a spokesman for Mastercard International, said that Mrs. Clinton had worked hard and made her opposition well known but that she had not been able to overcome the industry's basic argument for the legislation.
"It's not a hard sell to say there's a fundamental flaw in the current law when debtors are allowed to walk away from their debts when they have the ability to pay," Mr. Binzel said. "It's fair to say there is strong bipartisan support for bankruptcy reform."

HEADLINE: Beijing Overturns a Hong Kong Court Ruling on the Residency Status of Immigrants

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 26

 BODY:
In a move that has profound implications for Hong Kong's legal system, China today overturned, in effect, a local court ruling that granted residency here to more than a million people.
The decision by China's legislature to reinterpret provisions of the Hong Kong constitution that were the basis of the ruling is tantamount to overruling Hong Kong's highest court. And it marks Beijing's most overt intervention, albeit at the request of Hong Kong's own Beijing-appointed administrator, in the affairs of this former British colony since it reverted to Chinese rule in 1997. 
 While widely expected, the move elicited a torrent of protest from lawyers and pro-democracy politicians here. They said it would jeopardize the rule of law and the high degree of autonomy that Hong Kong was promised in its transition from a Crown Colony to a Chinese metropolis.
In a terse statement issued by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, Beijing declared that Hong Kong's Court of Final Appeal had erred in its landmark ruling, which granted residency to all children born in mainland China who have at least one parent living in Hong Kong.
"The decision of the Court of Final Appeal is not consistent with the Basic Law," said the official New China News Agency, referring to the Beijing-drafted constitution that governs this territory.
Beijing's decree brings to an end a five-month drama that pitted Hong Kong's British-style legal system against China's.
The dispute laid bare the deep ambivalence that Hong Kong people feel toward their mainland brethren. And it forced this independent-minded enclave to face the reality that -- whatever the niceties of the Sino-British agreement known as "one country, two systems" -- Hong Kong is now part of a single country that will not hesitate to assert its suzerainty, in matters legal or political.
"Not only does this set a precedent," said Margaret Ng, a lawyer and member of the legislature here. "It sanctions political intervention in the judicial system in Hong Kong. It ushers in a whole culture of mainland political figures criticizing and putting pressure on Hong Kong courts."
Dozens of protesters crowded around the Government headquarters to protest the action. Several carried a huge banner that said, "Tung Chee-hwa ruins the rule of law, ruins Hong Kong." Mr. Tung, a shipping magnate, is chief executive of the territory.
Critics trained most of their fire on Mr. Tung rather than on Beijing. He asked the Chinese Government to act because of fears that the court decision would have inundated this already teeming city with mainland immigrants.
Beijing's action also provoked concern from the United States, which has kept a low profile on Hong Kong affairs since the handover.
"The issue is whether the common law system in Hong Kong will maintain its integrity," said Richard A. Boucher, the United States Consul General. "Our concern is that reinterpretation could become too easy a precedent. It could undermine future cases and influence future behavior."
Mr. Tung denied that Hong Kong's legal system had been undermined. While he said he had been reluctant to ask Beijing to insert itself in Hong Kong's affairs, he did not rule out doing so again.
"What I want to emphasize is that we have taken this course of action because there were really no other alternatives, and it is not something we would want to do in the future, if we can help it," Mr. Tung said.
Hong Kong's drama began last January when its court extended residency rights to mainland Chinese children regardless of whether their parents were Hong Kong residents before or after their birth. That sweeping language threw open the doors to an estimated 1.6 million mainland Chinese.
The court managed to upset people on both sides of the border. Mainland officials objected because they said the court was trying to usurp the authority of China's legislature. Because the ruling involved the movement of Chinese citizens between the mainland and Hong Kong, Beijing said the court should have referred the case to the National People's Congress.
Hong Kong's government, meanwhile, warned that the newcomers would swamp this city of 6.8 million, swelling unemployment, jamming schools and hospitals, and blighting the environment. Hong Kong estimated the influx would cost $91 billion in additional capital spending.
With anti-immigrant sentiment running high, Hong Kong last month asked Beijing to invoke the rarely used device of reinterpreting the Basic Law. Today, the Chinese legislature responded by limiting the right of residency to mainland children whose parents were residents at the time of their birth.
Officials here estimated today that would reduce the eligible immigrants from 1.6 million to less than 200,000.
While public support has been resolutely behind the Government's efforts to limit immigration, pro-democracy leaders said Hong Kong would pay for its action by opening itself to future meddling by Beijing.
"If you break open a hole in the legal system for one group of people, then nobody is safe," said Martin Lee, the leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party. "Nobody knows how large this hole will be."
Government officials said the critics were simply stubborn in their refusal to adapt to life after the handover. "You must accept that there is a new constitutional order," said Elsie Leung, the Secretary of Justice.

HEADLINE: Colombia Adjusts Economic Figures to Include Its Drug Crops

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
Taking a step that is generating heated criticism in Washington, the Colombian Government has begun to include income earned from growing illegal drugs in the way it calculates the size of the nation's economy.
The move is controversial but necessary, Colombian officials say, to take account of the increasingly uncontrollable reality of the drug trade, which by obviously imprecise assessments could amount to between one-quarter and one-third of Colombia's legal exports, or as much as $4 billion a year. 
 By including revenues from narcotics in gross domestic product, Colombian Government economists say they hope to obtain a more accurate measure of all economic activity in the country. Excluding drug crops, they maintain, leads to distortions that hamper the Government's ability to effectively combat drug production and trafficking.
"This is a purely technical exercise, not a political measure," said Tomas Gonzalez Estrada, the chief economic adviser to President Andres Pastrana, who has stepped up the war against drugs here since taking office last August.
But some in Washington, particularly Congressional Republicans who have criticized other Pastrana policies, have attacked the decision capitulation to drug dealers.
Gen. Barry McCaffrey, President Clinton's antidrug chief, earlier this month called the move "a political error." In a telephone interview from Washington, Robert Weiner, a spokesman for the National Office of Drug Control Policy, said, "They say it in no way means an acceptance of or the legalization of drugs, but they have not fully explained that position or gotten that message out."
Officials here, though, respond that they are merely complying with guidelines set by the International Monetary Fund and World Bank for potential borrowers, and that other countries, like Bolivia, use the same system. Instructions prepared by the I.M.F., World Bank and other international lenders clearly state that "transactions involving the sale or purchase of illegal goods and services must be recorded."
The Colombian economy is suffering its worst recession in decades, and the Government is currently in talks with the I.M.F., without whose bill of good health it would be difficult for Colombia to borrow money from international capital markets.
The official recalculation could add as much as 1 percent to the value of the deteriorating Colombian economy, which has gross national product of nearly $80 billion a year. But Mr. Gonzalez emphasized that "we are not doing this to improve the performance of the Colombian economy," but rather to "have more effective tools" to design strategies like crop substitution.
For the moment, the new accounting system does not include the much larger sums of money earned from the processing or trafficking of cocaine, marijuana and heroin, only the growing of the raw materials. Rene Verswyvel Villamizar, director of the National Statistical Administrative Department, said cultivation "is as far as we can go with certainty."
According to the new statistics, drug crops added about 854 billion pesos to the Colombian economy in 1994, or just over $1 billion, calculated at the average exchange rate for that year. In 1995, the only other year for which figures are available, the estimate slipped because of market conditions in the United States to $762 million at the time.
Recalculated figures for later years, which officials say may be ready by the end of 1999, are likely to be significantly higher. Official United States estimates indicate that the amount of land devoted to cultivation of drug crops rose by more than one-quarter percent last year, despite eradication efforts.
The United Nations estimates that Colombia exports about 772 tons of cocaine a year, growing and processing roughly half the world supply.
"We are realists," Mr. Verswyvel said. "We have to recognize that narcotics and guerrillas exist, because they are a reality that we cannot hide. We have to measure these things as they are, not as we would like them to be."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE SERBS -- BELGRADE MEMO;
Live, in Belgrade, the Milosevic News

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, June 26

 BODY:
Call it the Big Lie show.
This summer season, it's about how Serbs have not lost control of Kosovo, how the once-vilified NATO forces are merely carrying out Slobodan Milosevic's policy of protecting Serbs from Albanian terrorists and how, despite the odd hiccup, things are going pretty darned well in the Yugoslav province that Serbs regard as their holy land. 
 On the state-controlled television that Mr. Milosevic has used so masterfully in the last decade, the evening news this week showed a tranquil Serbian village in Kosovo where contented, secure farm families were surrounded by lush crops, tidy haystacks and trustworthy British soldiers, one of whom sweetly petted a village dog.
That same evening there was horrifying counterprogramming, but only for the affluent sliver of the Serbian population that has access to CNN and BBC on satellite television. Pictures of burning Serbian villages in Kosovo, torched by vengeful Albanians, were broadcast along with accounts of Serbs being shot to death and fleeing by the tens of thousands from Kosovo into what is left of Mr. Milosevic's Yugoslavia.
The production values shaping the show on Belgrade television go back 12 years to the town of Kosovo Polje, where Mr. Milosevic, then an obscure Communist bureaucrat, found his nationalist legs. "Yugoslavia does not exist without Kosovo! Yugoslavia would disintegrate without Kosovo! Yugoslavia and Serbia are not going to give up Kosovo!" Mr. Milosevic declared in a speech that he made sure was broadcast on television. That speech started both his career as a top politician and the cycle of violence that would obliterate multiethnic Yugoslavia.
Since reality, in the form of 21,000 heavily armed, NATO-led troops who have effectively turned Kosovo into a foreign country, has betrayed Mr. Milosevic's best-remembered and most fundamental promise as a Serb leader, it appears to have been decided at the highest levels here in Belgrade that reality is not in the national interest.
Kosovo episodes of this season's Big Lie, like previous "news" programming during the Bosnian war about how mendacious Muslims in Sarajevo were laying siege to themselves to get world sympathy, are part of a pattern of mass deception that has characterized a decade of Mr. Milosevic's nationalist wars.
It is a strategy that sells defeat as victory, ignores the periodic floods of Serbian refugees flowing into Serbia from lost war zones and leaves millions of Serbs in ignorance or confused denial of human rights atrocities committed in their name by Mr. Milosevic's security forces.
Grisly evidence of Serbian atrocities in Kosovo that has been broadcast around the world in the last two weeks has not reached the majority of Serbs whose main source of information is state television. Even for the privileged few who, thanks to satellite dishes, have seen the pictures of rotting bodies being pulled from wells or shallow graves, the images seem to prompt what Westerners regard as counterintuitive reactions, somehow confirming that Serbs are victims.
"We are a little strange and proud people, and my opinion is that nobody likes Serbs," said Angelina Arbutina, 32, a well-traveled Belgrade basketball player who has starred on the Yugoslav national team in the Olympics and European championships. She says she flips back and forth in the evening between local and satellite television, finding the truth somewhere in between.
"This is war, what happened in Kosovo," Ms. Arbutina said. "If we killed Albanians, I'm sure the Albanians killed Serbs."
According to a poll published in Nin, a Belgrade newsmagazine, about two-thirds of Serbs do not believe Western news accounts of Serbian atrocities in Kosovo.
Another poll, by Medium, a private firm, paints a picture of Serbian public opinion that is nationalistic and misinformed. This poll of 800 urban and rural Serbs, conducted in personal interviews to avoid the demographic distortion that comes from telephone polls in this poor country, found that nearly four out of five Serbs support the peace agreement that ended the 10-week war in Kosovo. It also found, though, that only 14 percent support the withdrawal of nearly all Serbian armed forces from Kosovo, and 80 percent said turning the province over to NATO peacekeepers was unacceptable.
"This story is very old in our public opinion polls," said Srbobran Brankovic, polling director for Medium, referring to popular misunderstanding about how lost wars in Croatia and Bosnia were packaged for Serbs on state television. "The pattern in state media is to tell the people just those details that are convenient. Our television says that we managed to keep Kosovo inside Serbia. They never say how many Serb fighters were withdrawn or how many Serbian refugees have fled. They just say that their security is being secured by United Nations and Russian forces."
President Clinton demanded on Friday that Serbs "are going to have to come out of denial" about atrocities in Kosovo. He said that in order to receive aid they would have to "decide whether they think it's O.K. that all those tens of thousands of people were killed, and all those hundreds of thousands of people were run out of their homes, and all those little girls were raped and all those little boys were murdered."
Asked about such Western demands, Mr. Brankovic said that, for Serbs, they always backfire.
"Most people don't know about the atrocities, and those who do know are not feeling guilty," he said. "Everything we get from the West is pressure, pressure, pressure. It makes the people homogenized. We have some growing anti-West feeling in Serbia."
This postwar season, though, as the pace of misleading images on state television accelerates, there are a number of indications that the credibility of Mr. Milosevic's programming is beginning to slide.
Unlike Belgrade television's coverage of the conflicts in Croatia and Bosnia, in which all the violence, destruction and death occurred somewhere else, coverage of Mr. Milosevic's lost war with NATO has to compete with what many Serbs can see and hear for themselves. His euphonious promises about quickly rebuilding war-damaged bridges and factories do not square with the hard-scrabble lives of many people, who are struggling with gasoline shortages, soaring unemployment and collapsing foreign trade.
"Television shows government ministers going throughout Serbia talking about reconstruction, but everyone can see it is a joke and that there is no money," said Ognjen Pribicevic, a senior research fellow at the Institute of Social Sciences in Belgrade and a political adviser to the opposition leader Vuk Draskovic.
Then there is the matter of the 50,000 Serb refugees that Yugoslav aid officials estimate have fled Kosovo and traveled north to Serbia, a number that has never been mentioned on state television. It reports, instead, that conditions are good for Serbs to return to Kosovo.
To prevent refugees from coming to Belgrade and becoming a visible contradiction of state television news, the police stop them on the main highway about 18 miles south of the capital and direct them to towns in central Serbia. A similar diversion occurred when more than 250,000 Serbs fled Croatia in 1995.
The state's lack of money, too, is becoming increasingly hard to hide. In recent days, hundreds of Yugoslav soldiers, some armed and drunk, have blocked roads in central Serbia, demanding unpaid wages and cursing Mr. Milosevic's Government.
No details of those protests, which have reportedly blocked roads near two major towns in central Serbia, have been mentioned on state television. The police confiscated videotape taken at the barricades by local television in the town of Kraljevo.
What television news focused on last week, instead, was how the peace agreement in Kosovo had succeeded in fulfilling Mr. Milosevic's goals. "We put up heroic resistance, and we have risen above the aggressor in every aspect of the struggle," Gorica Gajevic, general secretary of the ruling Socialist People's Party, said in a speech in the Federal Parliament broadcast on the evening news. Similarly, Momir Bulatovic, the Yugoslav Prime Minister, announced on television that "our country's territorial integrity and sovereignty have been defended."
By claiming that Kosovo has not been lost, it appears that state television has ventured beyond mendacious news broadcasting into a realm of bad comedy. More than a dozen Serbs who were asked in Belgrade this week about the claim smiled wanly and shook their heads.
"I heard that on TV," Branislav Nakic, 36, a printer, said, rolling his eyes. "But nobody believes it."

HEADLINE: Longest Shot Is in Just Reaching the First Tee

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., June 26

 BODY:
Almost every Saturday night, Ron Bucci, a chiropractor from Tarrytown, kisses his wife and three children goodbye and drives the family van up to Mohansic Golf Course, where he sleeps in the parking lot with carloads of other men from Westchester County.
Usually, Mr. Bucci arrives around 8 P.M., early enough to tap a few balls around Mohansic's putting green, down a bottle of beer or two at the bar and engage in ritual male banter. Sleep is scarce, and by 4 A.M., the groggy platoon of unshaven fathers, husbands and boyfriends wanders into the cozy clubhouse to collect the holy grail of public-access golf: a Sunday morning tee time. 
 "You got mailmen up there sleeping, construction workers, correction officers, cops, accountants," said Mr. Bucci, 40, a seven-year veteran of the Mohansic sleepovers. "If the manager of the course wants to get an early spot, he's up there sleeping," he said. "I'm lucky. I have a van. Some guys sleep in the front seat of their car."
It is no secret that Westchester County, golf oasis for the wealthy, is a golf desert for everyone else. Though the county is peppered with 50 golf courses, only 5 are open to all free-range duffers, that particular golf subspecies who cannot afford a private club's membership fee and annual dues. A sixth is open only to residents of Rye.
Long Island, by contrast, is home to 64 private and 50 public courses. In southern Connecticut, many towns operate their own public courses.
The problem has become so bad in recent years that Westchester -- one of the most affluent counties in the nation -- is now among the most golf-deprived, experts said.
Consider: The county's five public courses, operating at capacity, were host to 270,000 rounds of golf last year, meeting less than 20 percent of the estimated demand for 1.5 million annual rounds, according to a report by the National Golf Foundation. "If there was anywhere in the country that I would build a golf course, it would be in Westchester County," said Angelo Palermo, the Florida-based golf-course consultant who submitted the report to county officials in 1995.
County officials appear ready to take such advice to heart. By the end of this week, County Executive Andrew J. Spano plans to choose from among five multimillion-dollar bids, including one from his own Parks Department, to build a public course on the grounds of the defunct Hudson Hills Golf Club in New Castle.
"If there was ever a slam-dunk project," Mr. Palermo said, "this is it."
The new course is still at least two years from reality. Though the county bought the 170-acre property from I.B.M. in December 1997 for the bargain price of $3.5 million, officials have done little with the land.
Larry Schwartz, Mr. Spano's deputy, said constructing the course would cost less than $10 million, a relative bargain. Nowadays, with land scarce, and environmental regulations ever more complex, even a starter golf course can cost $20 million.
Even when they manage to get a tee time, Westchester golfers face less-than-ideal conditions.
"Public golf is nuts," said Frank Madalone, 33, a dentist from Yonkers, swinging a three iron just off the first tee on a recent Friday at Sprain Lake Golf Club, where 54,197 rounds were played last year.
"To play on the weekend, it's insanity. The fairways overlap, balls flying everywhere," he said, shaking his head. "It's like a firing range out there.
"Sometimes," he added, taking the measure of the course before him, "even for $12, it's not worth it."
Even on weekdays, Westchester's public courses are crowded, officials said.
"Let's put it this way: If you want a tee time at 3 o'clock in the afternoon on a weekday, on a 95-degree day, you can probably find one," said the county's Parks Commissioner, Salvatore DeSantis.
The dearth of public golf is not, of course, unique to Westchester County.
"There is no place that is undersupplied in golf as much as the New York area," said David Leibowits, a golf course developer at Centennial Golf Club, a 27-hole course in Putnam County that charges $105 for a weekend round. "People drive an hour and a half to two hours for golf," he said. "The demand is unlimited."
Many things have conspired to make that so.
After an ebb in golf's popularity in the 1970's and 1980's, more women and youths are playing than ever, industry analysts said. That is especially true in Westchester, home of some of the most exclusive private clubs in the country and a 32-year-old professional tournament now known as the Buick Classic, at Westchester Country Club in Harrison.
The shift is evident at Ardsley High School, for example.
"The golf club used to be five kids," Henry Tina, the school's golf coach, said at Mohansic's second hole on Saturday. "I got 18 kids now. Where are they going to play?"
Until a few years ago, he said, local private clubs allowed the team to practice on their courses. Now they squeeze onto Sprain Lake's course.
Pro golf's marketing of its young, camera-ready stars like Tiger Woods has also brought legions of young wannabes to public courses.
"You don't have so many guys wearing pink now," said Anthony Federico, of Ardsley, waiting at Mohansic's second hole.
Money is also a factor: The economy's years-long boom has made a decent set of clubs a less intimidating purchase, and a public course's greens fee is often less expensive than a movie, soda and popcorn.
As a consequence of the surge, however, the quality of the public courses has dropped as they absorb more rounds from inexperienced players. Last year, golfers played 30 million rounds on New York State's 857 courses, industry statistics show, an average of about 35,000 per course.
But in Westchester County, Dunwoodie, the least active course, clocked 48,884 rounds, according to the county's Parks Department. Saxon Woods, in Scarsdale, crammed in 61,772 rounds. "That's seven-minute tee-time intervals, "Mr. Palermo said.
As a result, many local golfers simply leave.
Mr. Federico and Dr. Madalone, the dentist, both said they drive up to two hours to play more expensive golf in Dutchess County, Connecticut or Long Island.
"It's crazy," Mr. Federico lamented. "It seems like such a shame that we're in such a wealthy county."
There is another, perhaps more disturbing trend that veteran golfers say is sweeping Westchester County's public-access golf courses.
"There is more anger on the golf course," said John Lewandowski, 52, a sales and marketing executive from South Salem, after whacking a 150-yard drive past Mohansic's first hole one week ago.
"Today, they don't care about anybody else. They don't rake the bunkers. They don't wait for people to leave the green."
What really galls him is the flying balls.
"They'll hit close to you to sort of move you along," Mr. Lewandowski said, leaning on his putter. "That can be dangerous. Golf balls hurt."

HEADLINE: All-Year Benefit Is Seen In New Haven Festival

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 25

 BODY:
Inspired by the success of the Special Olympics World Games here in 1995, Anne Tyler Calabresi had a vision she believed could help start a cultural and economic renaissance in this troubled Ivy League city.
She thought the heart of the downtown, with its 350-year-old green, and the cozy, historic courtyards of Yale University, would be the perfect place for an international festival that could "showcase the city's vast cultural treasures." 
 "There isn't another city this size that can boast having an Ivy League university and internationally renowned art museums and theaters and a world-class symphony orchestra," said Mrs. Calabresi, who in 1992 founded an academic and social enrichment program for inner-city children. "I wanted to create an event to bring people together who know about the depth of the arts in New Haven, and at the same time showcase the city's museums, theaters, restaurants and both visual and performing artists, for people who have no idea what is here."
But Mrs. Calabresi, whose husband, Guido Calabresi, is a Federal judge and former dean of Yale Law School, said she had no idea the International Festival of Arts and Ideas would grow so quickly to become one of the largest in the country. The festival, now in its fourth year, is in the midst of a 16-day run that ends July 3.
With symposiums covering social issues like "Can Our Schools Be Better" and "War and Peace," and performances by internationally renowned entertainers, festival organizers say they are striving to take the event to a level rarely achieved in this country.
Organizers say they want to make the festival -- modeled after European festivals that combine the arts, science and in-depth discussions of ideas -- a tourist attraction that will draw people to New Haven throughout the year.
"The festival provides this extraordinary vehicle that we believe can bring people to New Haven during the event, but also sparks an awareness of the city so they will want to come other times as well," said Paul Collard, the festival's director.
Mr. Collard said more than 150,000 people are expected to spend about $2.5 million in the city during the festival.
"The intangible impact this festival is having on New Haven cannot be overstated," said City Planner Karyn Gilvarg, "both in psychological and real economic terms. We know it is providing a tremendous showcase for our museums, restaurants and other businesses that we could not have dreamed possible a few years ago."
The festival blends mostly free science and art exhibits and musical performances for adults and children, as well as plays performed by the Royal Shakespeare Theater Company.
Mr. Collard, who organized festivals in England, moved from London two years ago with his wife and four children to direct the festival here. He said its growth has been extraordinary.
The festival has a budget of $2.4 million, contributed by sponsors like Fleet Bank, the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, Sikorsky Aircraft, Southern New England Telephone and the Bayer Corporation. This year, advertising supplements were distributed in newspapers throughout Connecticut and in New York and Massachusetts, Mr. Collard said.
"The first year or two, the goal was to reach people in the immediate New Haven area," he said, "but now we want to begin drawing people from around Connecticut and throughout the East Coast."
Judy Phillips, passing through Connecticut on her way home to Baltimore from a Cape Cod vacation, stopped at the festival with her three children. She said it was unlike anything she had ever seen in the United States.
"It's more like a mini World's Fair," Ms. Phillips said. "I've seen festivals like this in Europe, but never before in this country."

HEADLINE: An Open Mind on Interest Rates?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Steven Rattner (Op-Ed, June 23) ends his article by saying "we would all do well to keep an open mind about further interest rate increases." It's a curious bit of advice.
While he is right to point out that unemployment is at its lowest in 29 years, he fails to add that inflation and unemployment have come down together in recent years, in defiance of economic orthodoxy. 
 Second, there is still no real sign of inflation. On the contrary, the latest Consumer Price Index report means that the Federal Reserve will be basing its expected quarter-point rate increase more on intuition than on hard data. Third, global economic competition (based in part on huge differentials in the wage rates that lie at the core of Mr. Rattner's inflation argument) and the Internet-led information revolution will continue to exert downward pressure on prices.
 
WILLIAM D. CORDES
Washington, June 23, 1999

HEADLINE: An Open Mind on Interest Rates?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Steven Rattner ("Interest Rate Roulette?", Op-Ed, June 23) states that "the first tenet of inflation fighting is anticipation." The problem lies in defining who is to do the anticipating.
Since the stock market has been encouraging a general feeling of increasing prosperity, perhaps this is the place to look. 
 However, since the stock market has turned to being more of a casino than an investment market, it has become extremely sensitive to even the slightest winds of change.
Accordingly, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, would be better advised to jaw-bone the public at large rather than play Russian roulette with interest rates. Money is expensive enough for most of the working public, and it is to be hoped that the stock market will sort itself out.
 
PETER HIRSCHMANN
Haifa, Israel, June 25, 1999
